sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
Charizard is a threatening special attacker with great typing and solid bulk. It also outspeeds a majority of the metagame's threats like Rotom-F, Houndoom, and non-Scarf Sawsbuck, which makes it even more difficult to deal with. Fire Blast can be slotted over Flamethrower for a more powerful STAB move, although there are accuracy problems for both of it STAB moves. Focus Blast is great coverage with the ability to OHKO the likes of Lycanroc-N, Alolan Persian, and Vigoroth, whereas its STAB moves do not. Tera Blast Steel can be picked over Focus Blast to target counters that Charizard struggles with like Carbink and Dachsbun. Will-O-Wisp helps cripple opposing physical attackers, which can safely come in on Charizard like Gabite, Vigoroth, and specially defensive Skuntank. However, Air Slash can be chosen over Will-O-Wisp for a more consistent Flying-type STAB alongside the somewhat inaccurate Hurricane. Tera Flying is for greatly boosting Hurricanes power, allowing it to pick up the 2HKO on bulky Gabite sets, Camerupt, and Dachsbun and the OHKO on the threatening Basculin. Defensively, Tera Dragon is the best choice for Charizard. It turns its weaknesses to Electric- and Water-type moves into resistances while still keeping its previous resistances to Grass and Fire and turning Rock-type moves turn into neutral hits. This allows it to take hits from its many threats like Raichu, Golduck, and Lycanroc-N. Tera Fire helps Flamethrower make up for the loss of power when chosen over Fire Blast, especially if it gets into Blaze range. It allows Charizard to 2HKO bulky Pokemon it otherwise wouldn't like Articuno and Tinkatuff. Deciding to Terastallize into either of its offensive types helps relieve its quad weakness to Rock, allowing it to live a hit from Gogoat, Gabite, and Alolan Persian.

Special Charizard works well on balance and offensive teams that are looking for a fast and powerful attacker. Charizard does great when paired with a physical breaker like Perrserker, Basculin, or Lycanroc-N to help with the special walls like Carbink and Dachsbun that it struggles to get through. On the other hand, it does great at breaking through the physically defensive Pokemon that physical attackers like Perrserker, Gogoat, and defensive setup sweeper Carbink have trouble with such as Dartrix, Misdreavus, and Leafeon. Charizard appreciates being paired with the likes of Quaxwell, Mareanie, and Lumineon to take hits for it from Golduck, Basculin, and opposing Lumineon. Although, its most glaring issue is the 4x weakness to Rock, which Lycanroc-N, Dugtrio, and Gabite can take advantage of. There are also other Pokemon like Misdreavus, Gogoat, and Alolan Persian that can slot Rock-type moves to catch Charizard switching in. This is why Charizard appreciates the presence of Whiscash and its own Gabite to handle these issues. Charizard only has one full counter, which is Carbink, barring Tera Blast Steel; however, there are a few other options using Tera such as using Tera Steel Dachsbun, Tera Rock Misdreavus, and Tera Rock Gogoat that can check it in a pinch. Although, the likes of Gabite, Perrserker, and Golduck can help come in and remove them after they Terastallize. Skuntank, Sawsbuck, and Flapple appreciate Charizard for helping them handle Perrserker. It is also worth mentioning that it prefers to be on the same team as a Knock Off absorber like Alolan Persian or Skuntank, because losing Heavy-Duty Boots greatly impacts its longevity.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
With its excellent typing, coverage for nearly everything in PU, and a great Speed tier, Charizard is one of PU's most threatening sweepers. Dragon Dance gives a solid damage boost and also allows Charizard to outspeed common Scarf users after a boost, such as Flapple and Basculin; however, Swords Dance can be used instead, trading away extra Speed for more firepower. While Flare Blitz is the normal STAB move of choice for Charizard, Flame Charge can be used on Swords Dance sets, as it boosts Charizard's Speed and removes the recoil from Flare Blitz, although at the cost of being much weaker. Earthquake is valuable coverage, hitting Pokemon such as Carbink, Skuntank, and Lycanroc-N for super effective damage. Dragon Claw hits opposing Dragon-types such as Gabite and Tera Dragon Articuno for good damage, and Thunder Punch can deal solid damage into Water- and Flying-types such as Lumineon, Golduck, and opposing Charizard. Charizard's Tera Type is very adjustable; Tera Ground is normally preferred to resist Rock-type attacks from Pokemon such as Lycanroc-N, boost the power of Earthquake, and remove Charizard's weakness to the Electric-Type, while Tera Dragon allows for resistances to Water and Electric and should be used with Dragon Claw. Finally, Tera Electric should be used with Thunder Punch.

Charizard's best partners are ones that can beat its offensive and defensive checks to open it up to set up and sweep easier. Wallbreakers such as Choice Band Basculin can help with the Ground-types that Charizard can struggle with. Grass-types such as Gogoat can threaten out Water- and Rock-types that would stop Charizard from setting up such as Basculin and Carbink. Articuno can U-turn to get Charizard in safely and checks the Dragon-types that would otherwise beat Charizard without Dragon Claw such as Gabite. In return, Charizard threatens out Steel-types that check Articuno. On Swords Dance sets, Sticky Web Masquerain can be a good partner, as it allows Charizard to beat the Choice Scarfers that normally outspeed and KO Swords Dance Charizard otherwise, such as Lycanroc-N.

sets.name: Drought Wallbreaker
sets.description: Thanks to its superb coverage and high Special Attack stat, Mega Charizard Y is a terrifying wallbreaker. Drought + Solar Beam allows Mega Charizard Y to subdue Water-types such Rotom-W, Gastrodon, and Tapu Fini, further restricting its defensive counterplay. Fire Blast is preferred to hit as hard as possible, though Flamethrower's perfect accuracy and greater PP make it worth consideration. Weather Ball is an interesting option, as it presents a challenge to rain teams by dealing considerable damage to Pelipper on the switch, but it comes at the cost of Mega Charizard Y losing its primary STAB move outside of sun. Scorching Sands pressures Heatran, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, while Focus Blast threatens Mega Tyranitar. Mega Charizard Y's tremendous wallbreaking prowess allows late-game sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult, Dragonite, and Volcarona to take advantage of Unaware walls that have been compromised, such as Skeledirge and Clodsire. Mega Charizard Y's sun support benefits Protosynthesis users such as Great Tusk. Mega Charizard Y appreciates entry hazard control from teammates such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Kartana, as it is extremely susceptible to Stealth Rock. It also struggles to break bulky Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Mega Latias as well as special walls like Clodsire and Hippowdon. Weavile, Tyranitar, and Kingambit subsequently form strong offensive cores with Mega Charizard Y, as they are able to Pursuit trap its aforementioned checks, with the former being able to deal with Hippowdon as well. Mega Charizard Y's middling Speed tier and unremarkable physical bulk leave it prone to being revenge killed by faster threats such as Dragapult, Mega Lopunny, and Tapu Koko. Therefore, bulky switch-ins such as Assault Vest Tangrowth, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T make for good teammates.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Mega Charizard X is a powerful setup sweeper and wallbreaker thanks to the sheer power of its Tough Claws-boosted Flare Blitz. Earthquake covers a vast majority of Fire-resistant Pokemon, including Heatran, Toxapex, Garganacl, and Skeledirge, as well as Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit without the recoil. Aside from granting Mega Charizard X more setup opportunities, Roost compensates for Flare Blitz recoil and its Stealth Rock weakness, allowing it to take advantage of its typing and natural bulk to soft check common foes like Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Choice Scarf Kartana as well as preventing revenge killing attempts from Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Dragon Claw is an alternative on hyper offense teams where the longevity isn't as necessary, which allows Mega Charizard X to hit Dragonite, Mega Latias, and Garchomp as well as providing neutral coverage against foes like Rotom-W, Tera Water Skeledirge, and Tera Grass Heatran. Offensive partners like Kartana, Weavile, Iron Valiant, and Kingambit can pressure the opposition early-game for Mega Charizard X to sweep more easily, as they can cripple and either pressure or overwhelm shared checks in Toxapex, Slowbro, Skeledirge, and Iron Defense Garganacl; in return, it threatens Tangrowth for Kartana, handles Gholdengo for Iron Valiant, and melts other Steel-types like Mega Scizor and Corviknight for them. Pivots like Dragapult, Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T bring Mega Charizard X in safely via U-turn on Pokemon like Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo, respectively; the latter two in particular can remove entry hazards with Defog so it can enter the field unscathed, especially if it's not running Roost and hasn't Mega Evolved yet. Dual screen setters found on hyper offense teams, such as Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl, give Mega Charizard X an easier time setting up.

sets.name: Dragon Dance (Fire)
sets.description: Mega Charizard X is a ferocious wallbreaker and setup sweeper, aiding Fire teams in matchups like Dragon, Fire, and Electric. Tough Claws-boosted Flare Blitz fires off nuclear-powered attacks, heavily denting walls such as Mandibuzz, Gliscor, and Mega Sableye. Dragon Claw, also powered up by Tough Claws, threatens Garchomp, Rotom-W, and Kommo-o. Earthquake threatens switch-ins like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Heatran, while Roost increases Mega Charizard X's longevity and mitigate recoil damage from Flare Blitz. Alternatively, Thunder Punch may be used to deal more damage to Slowbro, Pelipper, and Tapu Fini while still retaining super effective coverage against Toxapex. Volcarona is an exceptional teammate, as it threatens physical walls such as Slowbro, Toxapex, and Hippowdon after a Quiver Dance. Torkoal supports Mega Charizard X with sun to boost Flare Blitz's power and remove rain, Stealth Rock to wear down switch-ins, and Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards. Rotom-H sets up Reflect and Light Screen to ease Mega Charizard X's setup process and offers pivoting with Volt Switch. Choice Scarf Blacephalon is a great late-game cleaner and is appreciated to wear down troublesome walls like Skeledirge and Slowbro as well as cripple Toxapex and Porygon2 with Trick. Heatran traps and withers down Toxapex with Magma Storm and prevents Stealth Rock from being set up using Taunt. Cinderace provides entry hazard control with Court Change and brings Mega Charizard X in using U-turn.

sets.name: Drought Wallbreaker (Flying)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description: Thanks to Light Ball, Pikachu is a niche Imposter user that can break past less-sturdy Imposter-proofers, although it forgoes defensive utility in exchange. When Pikachu transforms, only the ability, item, and HP EVs listed here matter. The listed moves, non-HP EVs, and nature will very rarely see use: since Pikachu outspeeds all other Imposter users like Chansey, it is extremely rare that Pikachu is not transformed. Nevertheless, Volt Switch provides a reasonably strong pivoting option against opposing transformed Imposter users, which cause Pikachu's Imposter to fail, while Glare can paralyze threats to aid Pikachu later on. Healing Wish and Spikes both provide some utility if Pikachu is no longer needed. Since Pikachu is extremely frail, it can easily fall to any strong move from opposing threats it wants to transform into. Therefore, significant team support is needed to realize its potential. Paralysis spam through Nuzzle and Glare ensures Pikachu always outspeeds opposing threats like Mega Mewtwo X, and it can also generate free turns. Knock Off invalidates Pikachu, so Knock Off absorbers, such as Arceus with a held Plate are recommended. Bulky special walls like Ice Scales Arceus-Ground and Ho-Oh check Mega Diancie and Arceus-Ghost, which Pikachu cannot safely transform into: the former can OHKO with Extreme Speed, and the latter Imposter-proofs itself.

sets.name: Encore Pivot
sets.description:
Raichu's good coverage, blazing Speed tier, and access to Encore make it one of the best offensive pivots available in the tier; it is able to outspeed common Pokemon like Pyroar and Basculin and hit them with powerful super effective moves. Encore can halt setup attempts from the likes of Bulk Up Gogoat, Nasty Plot Misdreavus, and opposing Nasty Plot Raichu while also potentially giving Raichu setup opportunities with Nasty Plot against Pokemon locked into recovery moves, such as Gogoat, Dachsbun, Chansey, and Articuno. Surf threatens Rock- and Ground-types like Carbink, Gabite, and Camerupt. Thunderbolt gives Raichu an Electric-type STAB move that doesn't force it to switch out. Tera Blast with either Tera Ice or Tera Ground gives Raichu crucial coverage against the likes of Gogoat, Flapple, and Dartrix or Electrode and opposing Raichu, respectively. Tera Water boosts Raichu's Surf, letting it 2HKO physically defensive Carbink while also improving Raichu's ability to check the likes of Rotom-F, Basculin, Tera Ice Electrode, and opposing Raichu. Tera Grass gives Raichu resistances to Ground and Grass, greatly improving its matchup against Alolan Dugtrio and Whiscash. Additionally, it boosts the power of Grass Knot, letting it do more chip damage to Whiscash, potentially 2HKOing it. Lightning Rod lets Raichu more easily take advantage of Electric-types such as Rotom-F, Electrode, Rotom-S, and opposing Raichu.

Raichu's Electric immunity means that Water- and Flying-type Pokemon like Basculin, Golduck, Charizard, and Honchkrow make for good partners. The former two can more capably take out Pokemon like Carbink, Dugtrio, and Gabite while the latter two can deal with Grass-types like Gogoat, Flapple, and Dartrix, which Raichu would otherwise be forced to Terastallize against. Other offensive pivots such as Alolan Persian, Perrseker, Squawkabilly, and Drakloak can create powerful VoltTurn cores with Raichu, wearing down foes until they are weakened to the point where Raichu can efficiently clean them up. Additionally, these offensive pivots are able to compensate for Raichu's fragility thanks their ability to pivot it in. Setup Pokemon like Bulk Up Gogoat, Nasty Plot Haunter, Quiver Dance Masquerain, and Swords Dance Sawsbuck appreciate Raichu being able to lock Pokemon like Gogoat, Dachsbun, and Articuno into recovery moves and being able to chip down Pokemon with Volt Switch.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Raichu is a premier special wallbreaker in PU thanks to its excellent Speed and coverage, bolstered further by Nasty Plot and Terastallization. Surf makes for naturally great coverage with Thunderbolt, hitting Ground-types like Camerupt and Alolan Dugtrio and the myriad of Fire-types roaming PU, like Charizard, Houndoom, and Pyroar. Grass Knot can be used instead to hit Whiscash much harder, but Surf makes for generally better coverage outside of this. Tera Blast Flying gives Raichu coverage to hit Grass-types like Gogoat and Flapple, which can otherwise effortlessly take its other attacks. Tera Flying inverts Raichu's Ground weakness while only having two weaknesses thanks to Lightning Rod. Lightning Rod also makes Tera Water a great defensive option that also boosts Surf's power. Tera Blast Ice offers a comfortable midground between both Ground- and Grass-types, although this creates a worse defensive typing than that of Water or Flying, and many Ground-types are neutral to Ice, such as Camerupt and Whiscash. Encore locks Pokemon that can take on Raichu with their natural bulk, such as Carbink, Klawf, and Misdreavus, into setup moves or entry hazards, allowing it to set up more easily.

Raichu appreciates the support of Grass-types like Gogoat, Leafeon, and Quilladin taking on Ground-types like Dugtrio, Gabite, and Whiscash until they're worn into range of Raichu's +2 attacks. In return, Raichu assists its Grass-type teammates by offensively threatening Flying-types like Charizard and Honchkrow. Although Raichu's Speed tier is quite excellent, its poor bulk leaves it vulnerable to the few faster Pokemon faster than it, like Dugtrio, Alolan Persian, and Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N, so defensive pivots like Lumineon and Perrserker work in tandem to help Raichu safely come in and out of battle. Indeedee's Psychic Surge assists Raichu by shielding it from priority attacks that expose its poor bulk, such as Sucker Punch from Alolan Dugtrio, Honchkrow, and Houndoom, as well as Aqua Jet from Basculin and Quick Attack from Zangoose.

sets.name: Surge Surfer (Electric)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Clefable's great movepool, passable bulk, and Magic Guard + Soft-Boiled give it a unique niche as a defensive Fairy-type. It's able to fulfill many roles such as a Stealth Rock setter, a support Pokemon thanks to Thunder Wave and Knock Off crippling its checks like Heatran and Mega Scizor, and a potent sweeper with Calm Mind. Magic Guard lets Clefable absorb status moves like Toxic and Will-O-Wisp for teammates like Ting-Lu, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon. It also allows it to ignore entry hazards, helping it check Pokemon like Mega Lopunny and Dragapult. Rocky Helmet punishes U-turn from Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T. The given EV spread allows it to survive two Returns from Mega Lopunny with Leftovers recovery while also checking special attackers like Choice Specs Dragapult. If Rocky Helmet is used, an alternative spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with a Bold nature is recommended. Tera Water allows Clefable to have a better matchup into rain teams while resisting Steel-type attacks from Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Kingambit, allowing Clefable to catch them off-guard and cripple them. Tera Steel, on the other hand, allows Clefable to catch Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant with a Thunder Wave. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn appreciate Clefable's ability to incapacitate common Defog users such as Tornadus-T and Rotom-W thanks to Knock Off. They also appreciate having one moveslot being freed if Clefable carries Stealth Rock. Similarly, Clefable can cripple common entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Heatran, helping Defog users like the aforementioned Tornadus-T and Rotom-W perform their role. Toxapex works well with Clefable, as it checks Poison- and Steel-types like Iron Moth and Mega Scizor, helping Clefable spread Thunder Wave or set up with Calm Mind. They can also both overwhelm Ferrothorn, as the former can burn it and the latter nullifies Leech Seed's recovery. If Thunder Wave is used, Hex users like Gholdengo and Dragapult can be used to break Pokemon like Toxapex and Heatran that would otherwise stop Clefable from sweeping with Calm Mind.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Clefable’s excellent utility, movepool, and defensive typing allow it to function as a powerful defensive piece. Its excellent pure Fairy typing creates favorable matchups versus Pokemon such as Latios, Meowscarada, Buzzwole, and Iron Hands. Clefable acts as a Toxic immunity thanks to Magic Guard and also possesses a permanent immunity to Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Sandstorm. On offensive teams, Clefable usually fills the role of hazard setter through Stealth Rock. It can use Knock Off to limit the longevity of potential switch-ins such as Aegislash, Celesteela, Galarian Slowking, Iron Treads, and Leftovers variants of Excadrill. Thunder Wave is another useful option, adding the potential to cripple offensive threats such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, Enamorus, and Z-Celebrate Victini. Defensive teams may choose to employ a more passive variant of Clefable using Wish and Protect to provide longevity to Pokemon without access to reliable recovery such as Mega Tyranitar, Excadrill, Celesteela, and Aegislash. Aromatherapy is similarly useful to allow teammates to outlast the opposing team. Additionally, it allows for more aggressive play against Pokemon reliant on status such as Skeledirge and Galarian Slowking, allowing for them to be safely Pursuit trapped by Mega Tyranitar. Clefable’s ability to spread chip damage through utility moves such as Stealth Rock and Knock Off lends it to supporting wallbreakers like Latios, Meowscarada, Galarian Zapdos, and Excadrill. Clefable also pairs well with entry hazard users such as Mega Tyranitar, Hippowdon, Skarmory, Meowscarada, and Sandy Shocks to wear down the opposition, as it can get rid of items from entry hazard removers such as Excadrill, Tapu Fini, Cinderace, and Iron Treads. Clefable struggles with heavy hitters able to trade powerful attacks for the chip damage inflicted by Clefable, such as Iron Moth, Excadrill, and Enamorus. This weakness is mitigated by teammates able to act as revenge killers like Meowscarada, Choice Scarf Tapu Fini, and Mega Aerodactyl. Defensive partners such as Slowbro, Celesteela, Galarian Slowking, Mega Tyranitar, and Blissey can beat Steel, Poison, and Fire-types which often beat Clefable. In return, Clefable can beat Dark- and Fighting-types such as Buzzwole, Iron Hands, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada. Clefable is also a good switch-in to many Knock Off users that might cripple many of its partners, most notably Assault Vest Tangrowth and Chansey.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: Calm Mind Clefable is a strong wincon, becoming extremely difficult to threaten once boosted. Magic Guard allows it to set up in the face of defensive Pokemon that would otherwise rely on status moves to threaten it, such as specially oriented Aegislash, Buzzwole, Gastrodon, and Hippowdon. Leftovers is the preferred item to decrease the likelihood of running out of Soft-Boiled PP, but Life Orb can also be used in combination with Magic Guard for a significant increase in damage, helping defeat Pokemon such as specially defensive Celesteela, Taunt Tapu Fini, and Excadrill. Flamethrower is preferred to hit Steel-types such as Aegislash, Excadrill, Iron Treads, Celesteela, and Scizor. Thunder can also be used for passable neutral coverage in addition to the chance to paralyze foes such as Iron Moth, Galarian Slowking, Hisuian Arcanine, and Mega Venusaur. Knock Off offers more permanent damage on Steel-types, removing their items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots at the cost of being unable to directly break through them. Aromatherapy is often seen on stall teams in addition to Unaware, allowing Clefable to function as both the team’s cleric and wincon. Clefable naturally checking Fighting-types makes it a good teammate for Pokemon such as Excadrill and Meowscarada. Mega Tyranitar appreciates this while providing Clefable with crucial Pursuit support, trapping Galarian Slowking and Skeledirge. Offensive pivots such as Cinderace, Meowscarada, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon appreciate Clefable taking advantage of the defensive walls they might be unable to break through. Calm Mind Clefable is vulnerable to foes able to immediately threaten it such as Excadrill, Celesteela, Galarian Slowking, and Iron Moth. Steel- and Poison-resistant teammates such as Celesteela, Slowbro, and Mega Aerodactyl can cover for Clefable, giving it more opportunities to set up. Unaware Clefable being pressured by entry hazards means it necessitates strong hazard control options, such as Defog Skarmory, Mega Sableye, and Salamence. A relative lack of bulk and initial power means friendly entry hazards are appreciated from teammates including Skarmory, Chansey, Hippowdon, and Jirachi that can help wear down incoming defensive Pokemon more quickly.

sets.name: Aurora Veil (Ice)
sets.description: With access to Snow Warning and Aurora Veil, a great typing, and a key Speed tier that lets it deal with the likes of Keldeo and Urshifu-R, Alolan Ninetales proves to be extremely useful for Ice teams. Freeze-Dry makes it a menace in the Water matchup, dealing heavy damage to Swampert, Gastrodon, and Pelipper. Encore enables Alolan Ninetales to disrupt walls and slower setup sweepers like Ting-Lu and Tapu Fini. Alolan Ninetales's teammates appreciate its supportive capabilities; setup sweepers like Swords Dance Weavile and Dragon Dance Baxcalibur have a lot more setup opportunities, and offensive Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan have an easier time switching in. Cloyster is a stellar partner; its defensive set removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin and sets Spikes to wear down Keldeo and Toxapex for Alolan Ninetales, while Shell Smash variants can more easily set up with its assistance. SubRoost Kyurem helps Alolan Ninetales pressure Water teams with its own Freeze-Dry and checks Fighting-types like Galarian Zapdos with a Chople Berry. Piloswine lays down Stealth Rock and switches into and checks a variety of Fire-types that Alolan Ninetales hates, such as Volcarona and Iron Moth.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Dugtrio is a consistent trapper that distinguishes itself from Gothitelle by being able to revenge kill some premier threats like Koraidon, Miraidon, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle. Stone Edge hits Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle for maximum damage. Tera Fairy + Tera Blast allows it to trap and OHKO unboosted Koraidon, Choice Band Chien-Pao that isn't locked into Ice Shard, and weakened offensive Great Tusk and Walking Wake. Additionally, it can dispatch Choice item Koraidon, Walking Wake, and Miraidon locked into Outrage or Draco Meteor. Memento gives setup opportunities to teammates on a trapped Pokemon Dugtrio can't do much against, such as Great Tusk, while Final Gambit trades it for more damage on Iron Bundle, Koraidon, and unboosted Tera Fairy Miraidon. Choice Scarf Dugtrio is used on balance teams but has no defensive utility and fails to beat Double Dance Miraidon, Iron Bundle in Electric Terrain, Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao. Thus, it is crucial to pair it with checks to these threats such as Iron Treads, Clodsire, Toxapex, Alomomola, and Dondozo. Pelipper and Corviknight are solid walls that can also pivot Dugtrio in, establishing opportunities for it to trap Pokemon. Miraidon, Walking Wake, Iron Bundle, Chien Pao, and offensive Great Tusk appreciate Dugtrio getting rid of the Pokemon that check or revenge kill them. Dugtrio can also fit on stall teams since it traps strong threats and prevents them from getting multiple KOs, including Gothitelle, which is a major hindrance to bulkier structures.

sets.name: Teach Me How to Duggy (Trapper)
sets.description:
• Dugtrio functions as a valuable revenge killer and trapper for Miraidon, being able to OHKO it with a bit of chip damage or Tera Ground.
  • Dugtrio can trap other threats, most notably Chi-Yu but also Iron Bundle without Electric Terrain, Choice Band Chien-Pao not using Ice Shard, Iron Treads, Toxapex, Clodsire, and Blissey.
  • Stealth Rock can be used to quickly set up entry hazards should Dugtrio's trapping abilities no longer be required.
  • Memento will greatly weaken the offensive abilities of whatever is on the field, allowing Dugtrio's teammates to set up. It can also be used in cases where Dugtrio cannot KO a boosting threat.
  • As Dugtrio often forces a reactionary Terastallization from the opponent, Tera Ground is chosen for the extra power in general, and for taking out non-Terastallized Miraidon from full health.
  • Tera Fairy is an alternative option, as Fairy Tera Blast can take out Koraidon and weakened Great Tusk. Fairy's resistances can be useful against Sucker Punch Kingambit as well as Miraidon and Koraidon Choice-locked into a Dragon-type move.
  • Sucker Punch can be helpful damage in a pinch against weakened faster threats like Life Orb Flutter Mane in sun.
  • The given EVs allow Dugtrio to always survive a -2 Draco Meteor from Miraidon and outspeed +1 base 100 Speed Pokemon such as Chi-Yu.
  • Take care when trapping Miraidon, as Terastallizing to a type other than Electric allows it to take an Earthquake it would otherwise faint to.
  • Dugtrio should only be used on team archetypes that are designed to excel once Miraidon and Chi-Yu are eliminated, particularly bulkier teams that appreciate the aforementioned wallbreakers being gone.
  • Miraidon itself works as a fantastic teammate, as it doesn't have to worry about opposing Miraidon revenge killing it, and Dugtrio trapping Iron Treads, Clodsire, and Blissey makes sweeping much easier.
  • Corviknight is a fantastic partner for taking on Chien-Pao and letting Dugtrio come in on Miraidon with U-turn.
  • RestTalk Dondozo is another great teammate, as Curse makes it extremely hard to stop once Miraidon is eliminated, and it checks a myriad of offensive threats that Dugtrio struggles against like Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Palafin.
  • Dugtrio cannot always check Miraidon by itself, so Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire are highly recommended. These Pokemon can also set entry hazards, which makes Dugtrio's job significantly easier.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
While slower than its Kantonian cousin, Alolan Dugtrio still serves as one of the PU metagame's strongest wallbreakers thanks to its uncommon Steel typing, high power, and great coverage. This access to a rare STAB typing, as well as a still excellent Speed tier, cement its niche alongside other powerful Ground-types such as Dugtrio and Gabite. Earthquake and Iron Head allow Alolan Dugtrio to threaten commonplace Pokemon such as Carbink, Pyroar, Dachsbun, and Lycanroc-N. Stone Edge allows Alolan Dugtrio to hit Charizard for meaningful damage while also providing extra power against targets such as Masquerain and Vespiquen. Substitute, on the other hand, allows Alolan Dugtrio to take advantage of slower, more passive Pokemon, such as Vespiquen, Tinkatuff, and Carbink, in order to buffer a hit, gain momentum from a forced switch, or safely set up with Swords Dance. Sucker Punch provides insurance against Choice Scarf users and Pokemon that are naturally faster than Alolan Dugtrio, such as Basculin and Dugtrio, respectively. Swords Dance allows Alolan Dugtrio to take advantage of passive opponents and forced switches as well as break through naturally bulky Pokemon it may not have coverage for, such as Whiscash. Heavy-Duty Boots helps to provide more opportunities for Alolan Dugtrio to come in by negating entry hazards, while Life Orb provides a damage boost, which can be especially helpful if Alolan Dugtrio chooses not to run Swords Dance. Air Balloon is also a choice, making Alolan Dugtrio immune to Ground-type moves, like Dugtrio or Gabite's Earthquake, as well as providing a temporary immunity to Sticky Web and Spikes. Tera Ground allows for Alolan Dugtrio's Earthquake to deal even more damage, which is especially helpful against neutral targets like Gabite. Tera Steel is also an option, as it provides key resistances against moves such as Gogoat's Horn Leech and Choice Scarf Rotom-F's Blizzard while also boosting the power of Iron Head.

Alolan Dugtrio serves as an excellent wallbreaker for fast-paced offensive teams that need a combination of speed and power to deal with threats such as Carbink, Pyroar, and Dachsbun. Due to being one of the few Steel-types available in the tier, Alolan Dugtrio's access to a strong, fast Iron Head is a quality greatly appreciated by common Fire-type wallbreakers such as Charizard, Pyroar, and Houndoom, which struggle against common Rock-types such as Carbink and Lycanroc-N. In return, Alolan Dugtrio greatly appreciates the Fire-types' ability to deal with Grass-types such as Gogoat and Thwackey, as these Grass-types resist Earthquake and also often have good matchups against the entry hazard setters it is paired with. This especially applies to Thwackey, which further reduces the damage of Alolan Dugtrio's Earthquake by setting Grassy Terrain. A teammate that can deal with Misdreavus, such as Haunter or Houndoom, is also imperative, as Misdreavus can easily cripple Alolan Dugtrio with Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
Alongside Alolan Dugtrio's amazing typing, great Speed, and decent Attack, Choice items make it a more immediate offensive threat compared to support items such as Heavy-Duty Boots. Stone Edge is Alolan Dugtrio's best coverage option, hitting the few Pokemon that resist its STAB combination like Rotom-S and Charizard. Sucker Punch can also situationally be used alongside Choice Scarf to move before foes like Aqua Jet Basculin. Memento is good late-game, allowing Alolan Dugtrio to provide momentum and offer potential setup opportunities for teammates. Stealth Rock is a niche option on Choice Scarf sets if a team has no space for it otherwise, and, although it is a bad move to be locked into, it can also be used to fake being non-Choice Scarf. Jolly is by far the preferred nature to outspeed threats such as Basculin and Pyroar, but Adamant can be used with Choice Band to further Alolan Dugtrio's wallbreaking capabilities. Tangling Hair is situational but can punish moves such as Skuntank's Sucker Punch and Choice Scarf Sawsbuck's Horn Leech. Tera Ground and Steel power up Alolan Dugtrio's STAB moves to harder hit select targets, such as Earthquake against Whiscash and Lumineon and Iron Head against Gogoat and Misdreavus. They also offer defensive perks, such as Tera Ground making Alolan Dugtrio lose the weakness to Gabite's Earthquake and Tera Steel the weakness to Basculin's Aqua Jet. Choice Band makes Alolan Dugtrio a threatening wallbreaker, and Choice Scarf provides speed control for fast threats such as Alolan Persian, Dugtrio, and +1 Quiver Dance Masquerain. Alolan Dugtrio is notably one of the fastest Choice Scarf users, outspeeding not only other Choice Scarf users such as Rotom-F and Haunter but also Speed-boosting setup move users such as Dragon Dance Charizard and Agility Wyrdeer. This also means that even without the extra Speed, Choice Band Dugtrio still makes for solid Speed control, especially alongside Sucker Punch.

Alolan Dugtrio makes for great glue on balance and offensive teams, being flexibly able to swap Choice items based on the team's need of either a wallbreaker or speed control while also being a last resort option for roles such as Stealth Rock setter and Volt Switch immunity if need be. Due to being Choice-locked, Alolan Dugtrio is very prediction reliant, which means an incorrect prediction could allow common threats such as Dragon Dance Charizard and Bulk Up Gogoat to use it as setup fodder. Bulky teammates with utility moves can stop this from getting out of hand, such as Haze Mareanie, Thunder Wave or Will-O-Wisp Misdreavus, and Roar Dachsbun. Being Choice-locked will inevitably also lead to a lot of switches, and while Alolan Dugtrio's typing allows it to switch into a handful of moves such as Lycanroc's Stone Edge and Rotom-F's Volt Switch or Discharge, its common weaknesses and frailty leave it at risk of being OHKOed by attacks such as Close Combat and Blizzard. Pivots such as Alolan Persian, Raichu, and Lumineon can help take away this risk and increase Alolan Dugtrio's overall longevity. Alolan Persian and Raichu can also run Nasty Plot sets, which benefit from Alolan Dugtrio's Memento making setting up easier. Alolan Dugtrio can be paired with other Choice item users like Haunter and Basculin to create mind games as to which the wallbreaker and Choice Scarf user are while also helping one another weaken foes and clean up the match, respectively. An alternative option to Alolan Dugtrio is its Kantonian form, Dugtrio. Dugtrio's higher Speed allows it to naturally outspeed Alolan Persian and Raichu, although lack of secondary STAB makes it worse with Choice items and is overall better used as a setup sweeper or wallbreaker. Alolan Dugtrio should be used if seeking immediate power as a wallbreaker with Choice Band or reliable speed control with Choice Scarf.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Alolan Persian's useful utility options along with its incredible Speed tier and Fur Coat allow it to function as one of PU's best pivots. Foul Play threatens physical attackers such as Alolan Dugtrio and Basculin with good damage. Parting Shot allows Alolan Persian to weaken the foe by lowering its offensive stats, allowing teammates an easier time coming in safely, but U-turn can be used to deal slight chip damage and notably also allows Alolan Persian to pivot out from Carbink. Thunder Wave can cripple foes such as Quiver Dance Masquerain, Dragon Dance Charizard, and opposing Alolan Persian. Taunt can prevent Pokemon such as Tinkatuff and Misdreavus from attempting to set entry hazards or spread status and can also prevent setup sweepers from setting up safely. Tera Ghost allows Alolan Persian to deal with Fighting-types such as Crabominable and Falinks as well as block Carbink's Body Press. Alolan Persian opts to run Defense EVs over HP EVs due to Fur Coat making Alolan Persian bulkier on the defensive side.

Wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Crabominable, Choice Specs Indeedee, and Swords Dance Alolan Dugtrio appreciate Alolan Persian being able to get them safe entry onto the battlefield. In return, these wallbreakers can muscle through threats Alolan Persian struggles with such as Skuntank and Tinkatuff. U-turn and Volt Switch users such as Perrserker, Flapple, and Raichu can form a VoltTurn combination with Alolan Persian. Chansey makes an excellent partner, as Chansey covers the special attackers such as Houndoom that Alolan Persian struggles with while Alolan Persian deals with the physical threats such as Honchkrow that can cause Chansey problems. Revenge killers and late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Basculin and Pyroar appreciate Alolan Persian helping them come in safely, spreading paralysis for them, and being a fallback against threats such as Alolan Dugtrio. Pokemon such as Alolan Dugtrio, Whiscash, and Gogoat are useful partners, as they pressure Carbink, allowing Alolan Persian to be able to use Parting Shot more safely.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Despite a middling Special Attack stat, Alolan Persian makes for a solid Nasty Plot user thanks to a great Speed tier and unresisted coverage, making it dangerous late-game where its checks have been weakened or removed. Thunderbolt provides solid coverage alongside Dark Pulse, hitting checks to Dark-types like Dachsbun and Houndoom for decent damage, as well as forcing out wallbreakers such as Basculin and Charizard. Taunt stops switch-ins like Dachsbun, Hisuian Sliggoo, and Gogoat from using recovery moves while also stopping status attempts from foes like Skuntank and Misdreavus. Parting Shot keeps up momentum on offensive teams, letting Alolan Persian pivot mid-game against Pokemon it struggles to deal with, like Tinkatuff and Whiscash. Tera Electric makes Alolan Persian harder to cripple by Thunder Wave users like Chansey and Wyrdeer, allows Thunderbolt to heavily dent foes like Dunsparce and Tera Fairy Misdreavus at +2, and makes revenge killing it with Electrode and Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N&emdash;two solid speed control options&emdash;much more difficult. However, Tera Steel with Tera Blast can be used to immediately remove Carbink, one of Alolan Persian's most annoying switch-ins, as well as allow it to more easily setup on Pokemon like Skuntank, Gogoat, and Rotom-F Choice locked into Blizzard, at the cost of being much more reliant on Terastallizing for coverage and lacking the defensive utility Tera Electric provides versus paralysis and Electrode.

As stated before, Alolan Persian is at its best late-game when its checks have been sufficiently weakened; as such, it appreciates strong mid-game wallbreakers such as Basculin, Charizard, and Pyroar, which can force damage on shared checks like Gogoat, Carbink, and Gabite, respectively, clearing the way for an Alolan Persian cleanup. Fellow Nasty Plot users such as Misdreavus and Rotom-F are equally adept at wearing down shared switch-ins like Chansey and Whiscash. Rotom-F can also form a strong pivoting core with Parting Shot variants of Alolan Persian. Alolan Persian isn't forced out by much, but before Terastallizing, it can be exploited by foes like Electrode and Choice Scarf Indeedee-F, so switch-ins to them, like Whiscash and Perrserker, are recommended. Both of the latter two Pokemon can also set entry hazards to wear down Alolan Persian's switch-ins like Tinkatuff and Dunsparce while Perrserker can bring Alolan Persian in with a slow U-turn.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Mankey is one of the most powerful Choice Scarf users in Little Cup thanks to its high Speed, which allows it to outpace or tie with the entire unboosted metagame. This allows Mankey to beat other common Choice Scarf users such as Magnemite, Mudbray, and Gothita. U-turn allows it to greatly capitalize on the switches it forces. Earthquake is a powerful coverage move that hits Mareanie, Glimmet, and Voltorb. Assurance is used to deal as much damage as possible to Ghost-types, OHKOing Eviolite variants on the switch if Stealth Rock is up, while Ice Punch OHKOes Toedscool and threatens Flying-types like Wattrel. Stone Edge is an uncommon option to hit Larvesta and Flying-types. Vital Spirit can be helpful on teams lacking a Grass-type, as it provides a switch-in to Toedscool's Spore, while Defiant is very useful in matchups against Pokemon such as Sticky Web Surskit and Parting Shot Shroodle, as the Attack boosts make Mankey nigh unwallable. Tera Fighting allows Mankey to hit as hard as possible with Close Combat in situations where an unboosted hit is insufficient. Some of Mankey's best teammates include Toedscool to switch in on Ghost-types and remove entry hazards, which can hamper Mankey's pivoting abilities, and either Gothita or Diglett, which can remove the bulky Poison-types like Mareanie and Foongus that give Mankey trouble. Mankey also performs well as part of a VoltTurn core with Pokemon like Volt Switch Voltorb and U-turn Zorua.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Bulky Bulk Up
sets.description: 16 Speed EVs with a Jolly nature is to outspeed Frosmoth and Modest Toxtricity.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description:
• A unique combination of Intimidate, Extreme Speed and multiple support tools make Arcanine a versatile and unpredictable defensive option.

  • Extreme Speed: Even on a defensive set, Extreme Speed's strong base power and priority combined with Arcanine's naturally high Attack make it a potent cleaning tool.

  • Roar: Roar lets Arcanine phaze out troublesome set-up foes that are hard for teammates to switch into, such as Wo-Chien and Garganacl.

  • Bulldoze: Bulldoze's speed control can be used to set up your own offense for a countersweep.

  • EV Spread: After Intimidate, the given EV spread lets Arcanine avoid a 2HKO from Choice Band Chien-Pao's Crunch and Baxcalibur's Earthquake. The HP investment minimizes Stealth Rock damage when not running Heavy-Duty Boots, and the Speed investment outspeeds Adamant Breloom.

Other Options

  • Snarl: This move lets Arcanine pester special attackers that switch into it, potentially letting it stay in longer or ease a switch to a teammate.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: As a defensive switch-in with a Stealth Rock weakness, Arcanine heavily favors Heavy-Duty Boots to remove said weakness.

  • Rocky Helmet: Against targets like Chien-Pao, Arcanine can rack up passive chip damage.

  • Leftovers: Passive recovery is a valuable asset to have on a defensive Pokemon, but since Arcanine is an Intimidate user that switches a lot, Leftovers doesn't always have enough turns to produce good value.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Terastallization can do a lot to further improve Arcanine's unique set of attributes, but it's not necessarily something that Arcanine needs to function.

  • Normal: Tera Normal gives Arcanine even more cleaning power by boosting Extreme Speed. It's also a nice pinch option for blocking Ghost-type moves, as Flutter Mane and Mimikyu are often forced to use them due to Arcanine's Fairy resistance.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy provides defensive insurance against some of the hardest hitting Choice Band users, such as Tera Dark Chien-Pao and Outrage Dragonite.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• The given EV spread minimizes Stealth Rock damage, and the Speed investment lets Arcanine outspeed Adamant Tyranitar by 2 points.

  • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band (Rock)
sets.description:
Hisuian Arcanine is a terrifying wallbreaker capable of threatening Steel- and Grass-types due to its strong STAB moves and supporting ability, great coverage, and Fire typing, helping Rock teams combat the aforementioned type matchups. Notably, it lives all of Meowscarada's attacks and +2 Scizor's Bullet Punch. Rock Head allows Hisuian Arcanine to freely use Head Smash and Flare Blitz without their recoil damage. Head Smash is an immensely powerful move, enabling Hisuian Arcanine to 2HKO Toxapex and defensive Landorus-T after Intimidate. Flare Blitz threatens Amoonguss, Corviknight, and Toedscruel, while breaking through Steel teams in general with ease in conjunction with Close Combat. Close Combat provides coverage for Hisuian Goodra, Ursaluna, and Heatran, while also fighting off Dark-types such as Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and non-Choice Scarf Hisuian Samurott. Extreme Speed allows Hisuian Arcanine to revenge kill faster opponents like weakened Greninja, Azumarill, and Breloom.

Lycanroc-D appreciates Hisuian Arcanine threatening walls like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Amoonguss; in return, Lycanroc-D deals with Chien-Pao, Hydreigon, and Greninja under sand. Garganacl is one of Hisuian Arcanine's best teammates due to its ability to force progress against Water and Steel, notably wearing down Quagsire, Gastrodon, and Quaquaval with Salt Cure. Glimmora forms a potent wallbreaking core with Hisuian Arcanine, taking on Grass and Fairy teams effectively. Furthermore, Glimmora provides entry hazard control with Mortal Spin and sets its own array of hazards to wear down Hisuian Arcanine's switch-ins. In return, Glimmora appreciates Hisuian Arcanine removing Steel-types for it so it can freely use Mortal Spin. Tyranitar provides sandstorm to help chip down opponents and improve Hisuian Arcanine's special bulk, making it trickier to shut down, as well as sets Stealth Rock and spreads paralysis with Thunder Wave to help Hisuian Arcanine outpace and OHKO faster offensive Pokemon. Kleavor provides Stealth Rock with Stone Axe and pivots into Hisuian Arcanine with U-turn, as well as provides additional support in the Steel matchup by hitting Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Heatran with either Night Slash or Close Combat. Shell Smash Drednaw is a great asset in the Water and Ground matchups due to Swift Swim and Air Balloon, heavily weakening those types for Hisuian Arcanine. In return, Drednaw appreciates Amoonguss and Toxapex being removed by Hisuian Arcanine.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Rock)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Hisuian Arcanine is a strong wallbreaker, capable of denting many physically defensive Pokemon such as Scream Tail while taking advantage of Magic Guard by using Head Smash and Flare Blitz in combination with Life Orb without any drawbacks. Close Combat allows Hisuian Arcanine to hit Ting-Lu and Well-Baked Body Iron Treads, while Will-O-Wisp threatens burns on checks like physically defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Extreme Speed is useful priority that picks off weakened targets, Stealth Rock allows Hisuian Arcanine to act as an offensive entry hazard setter that pressures Corviknight and Iron Treads, and Flame Charge boosts its Speed to thwart potential revenge killers. As Hisuian Arcanine places a lot of pressure on physical walls, other physical cleaners like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao can be partnered with Hisuian Arcanine to clean up after it has broken those walls while providing speed control. Since Hisuian Arcanine is checked by Garchomp and bulky Water-types like Quaquaval, Refrigerate Regieleki makes a good partner for it by forcing these Pokemon out, pivoting Hisuian Arcanine in, and helping to deal with faster threats through its raw Speed. Hisuian Arcanine's middling Speed makes slow pivots like Corviknight good partners due to their ability to bring it in safely; alternatively, Corviknight's dual screens set allows Arcanine to take a hit and strike back.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Slowbro's valuable defensive typing, solid physical bulk, and remarkable longevity between Slack Off + Regenerator make it a very reliable defensive pivot, capable of consistently checking dangerous physical attackers like Urshifu-R, Mega Medicham, Mega Lopunny, and Mega Swampert. The combination of Teleport + Future Sight lets Slowbro support its offensive teammates by providing them free entry while forcing immense pressure on a prospective switch-in. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Slowbro to switch freely in spite of any entry hazards. Tera Steel can be used in a pinch to check foes like Kingambit, Mega Tyranitar, and Tapu Lele, letting it either cripple them with a Scald burn or use Teleport into a revenge killer. Wallbreakers such as Kingambit, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta appreciate Slowbro's FuturePort to bring them in safely on foes like Ferrothorn and Garganacl and subsequently pressure their switch-ins like Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Toxapex with the impending Future Sight. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Heatran help cover threats like Tapu Koko, Volcarona, and Gholdengo, respectively; in return, Slowbro deals with Ground- and Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Urshifu-R. Corviknight, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole cover other physical attackers such as Kartana, Kingambit, and Weavile that Slowbro struggles with; the former two remove entry hazards with Defog in case Slowbro is forced to take a Knock Off, while the latter can make use of Future Sight to wallbreak easier.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Psychic)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Slowbro's high physical bulk combined with Regenerator makes it a fantastic defensive pivot, able to check numerous physical attackers such as Cinderace, Excadrill, and Galarian Zapdos. As they're forced out, Slowbro can use Teleport to maintain momentum and stay healthy. Scald serves as a spammable STAB attack that can cripple targets with burns, dissuading otherwise decent checks like Mega Tyranitar and physically-centric Aegislash sets from setting up. Even foes that don't rely on physical attacks, like Serperior and Latios, tend to dislike the chip from burn. Future Sight supports wallbreakers like Choice Band Tyranitar, Buzzwole, and Enamorus in breaking through their checks such as Tangrowth and Skarmory for the former two and Galarian Slowking for the latter. It also synergizes excellently with Teleport. Slack Off serves as reliable recovery that doesn't require Slowbro to switch out. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Slowbro to avoid taking damage from entry hazards, maximizing HP regained from Regenerator, though Rocky Helmet can be held instead to punish contact move users, notably foes that run U-turn like Cinderace. A Relaxed nature and 0 Speed IVs are used to make Slowbro as slow as possible, maximizing its odds of moving slower than opposing Teleport users. Slowbro best fits on bulky offense and balance teams looking for a reliable defensive pivot that can also generate momentum for wallbreakers. Hazard-stacking teammates like Skarmory, defensive Clefable, and Hippowdon pair up nicely with Future Sight, further putting pressure on opposing defensive cores. Many hazard-stacking teammates can also double as checks to Pokemon Slowbro struggles against, such as Clefable checking Dark-types like Hydreigon, Skarmory handling Bug- and Grass-types like Buzzwole and Meowscarada, and Hippowdon checking Electric-types like Iron Hands as well as Galarian Slowking. Similarly, pivots like Scizor and Iron Treads also check threats like Galarian Slowking while pairing nicely with Slowbro's own pivoting potential to maintain offensive momentum. If it isn't running Heavy-Duty Boots, hazard control from teammates like Hydreigon, Choice Scarf Serperior, and Iron Treads is necessary.

sets.name: Defensive (Psychic)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Magneton distinguishes itself as a good offensive pivot through its Steel typing, which lets it check Pokemon such as Bruxish, Jolteon, and Scyther, and the fact that it is difficult to switch into due to the combination of its high Special Attack stat and Analytic. Volt Switch allows Magneton to bring in frail teammates such as Zoroark, Medicham, and Bruxish safely. Flash Cannon is able to threaten Sandaconda, which blocks Magneton's Volt Switch, and Tera Fairy Drifblim, Umbreon, and Vaporeon. Magnet Rise is notable to wall Sandaconda, preventing it from forcing Magneton out. Tera Blast lets Tera Fairy Magneton threaten Dark- and Dragon-types that check it such as Umbreon and Appletun, or it hits Ground-types that cause Magneton trouble like Whiscash and Sandaconda if it is Tera Grass. Tera Fairy flips the script on Fighting-types, like Passimian and Paldean Tauros, while Tera Grass comes with the added benefit of giving Magneton resistances to Ground- and Water-type moves, which can be useful against Sandaconda and Bruxish.

Magneton fits well in VoltTurn cores with Pokemon such as Passimian, Scyther, and Bombirdier. Magneton can struggle against special walls such as Eelektross, Chansey, and Appletun, so Magneton appreciates teammates that can break these Pokemon, such as Passimian, Bruxish, and Mabosstiff. Magneton is liable to be chipped down over time by entry hazards due to its lack of recovery, so it appreciates Defoggers such as Drifblim, Lurantis, and Scyther. Additionally, Magneton does not like its Eviolite being removed by Knock Off, which makes Pokemon such as Umbreon and Qwilfish that can absorb Knock Off great partners. Magneton can also struggle versus Ground-types not threatened by Flash Cannon, like Camerupt and Whiscash, so Water- and Grass-types such as Vaporeon and Appletun make for helpful teammates.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Thanks to a solid typing with one weakness and good defensive stats, Alolan Grimer is able to use Knock Offs consistently throughout a game, weakening the opposing team for its teammates to take advantage of. Gunk Shot is used to hit Pokemon that have already been hit by Knock Off, while Drain Punch OHKOs Pawniard and provides some recovery to increase Grimer's longevity. Drain Punch also allows it to damage other Alolan Grimer neutrally, making it valuable in matchups against opposing Alolan Grimer. Sleep Talk can be used to make Alolan Grimer a great Foongus check and sleep absorber for the team, while Memento gives sweeper teammates a chance to set up. Imprison, together with a bit of Speed investment, lets Alolan Grimer completely shut down opposing Alolan Grimer. Tera Grass eliminates Grimer's only weakness to Ground and lets it take on opposing Hisuian Voltorb more easily.

Alolan Grimer is forced out by Ground-types like Mudbray, Numel, and opposing Toedscool, so checks to those Pokemon like Drifloon, Toedscool, and Shellos are essential. Alolan Grimer pairs well with offensive sweepers like Unburden Shroodle, Shellder, and Numel, which can sweep more easily due to Alolan Grimer weakening the enemy team with Knock Off. Grookey is a good partner as well, since Grassy Terrain gives Alolan Grimer much appreciated passive recovery and cuts damage from Earthquake in half, while Alolan Grimer's Knock Off makes switching into Grookey's Wood Hammer much harder. Volt Switch users like Hisuian Voltorb and Wattrel can help get Alolan Grimer in safely, and they can help pressure and overwhelm Ground-types for each other.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Muk serves as a great tank and Haze user in SV NU, checking various special attackers such as Vivillon and Zoroark and threatening them with Poison Jab and Drain Punch respectively. Poison Touch and Poison Jab let Muk effortlessly spread poison, even on Pokemon immune to Toxic Spikes such as Drifblim and Eelektross. Drain Punch hits Steel-types such as Copperajah and Terastallized Appletun that would otherwise wall Muk. Haze stops setup sweepers such as Vivillon and Calm Mind Vaporeon from setting up. Toxic Spikes lets Muk take advantage of free turns and cripple the opposing team with poison. Tera Dark allows Muk to beat threats like Bruxish and Zoroark after baiting them into their powerful Dark- and Psychic-type attacks and retaliate back while also being able to use Haze against boosted Stored Power users like Veluza and Farigiraf. Alternatively, Tera Water provides an overall better defensive typing, more specifically easing the matchup against offensive Water-types like Calm Mind Vaporeon and Choice Specs Clawitzer. Muk struggles with Pokemon such as Sandaconda, which does not fear its poison due to Shed Skin and can threaten it back with Earthquake. As a result, Muk appreciates teammates such as Rotom, Eelektross, and Cacturne, which can switch into Sandaconda and force it out. Muk is physically frail, making physical walls such as Sandaconda and Drifblim great partners, with the latter also getting rid of entry hazards, which chip Muk down throughout a game.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: Curse Muk checks specially offensive threats while having the additional benefit of acting as a wincon. Curse boosts Muk's above-average Attack and below-average Defense, complementing its good Special Defense. Drain Punch not only hits special attackers like Zoroark, Rotom-F, and Dudunsparce but also gives Muk longevity, solidifiying its sweeping potential. Shadow Sneak provides Muk with a form of priority, allowing it to revenge kill Ghost-types like Haunter and Rotom or faster threats like Bruxish and Veluza. Poison Touch in combination with Poison Jab gives Muk a 51% chance to poison foes, wearing them down in the process. Sticky Hold prevents Muk from being crippled by Trick from Rotom or Knock Off from Passimian. Tera Water serves as a strong defensive typing, while Tera Dark can be used to help Muk combat Pokemon like Bruxish and Farigiraf. Lurantis pairs well with this particular Muk set, removing Pokemon like Sandaconda, Haze Vaporeon, and Taunt Qwilfish. Zoroark and Passimian can scare away Psychic-types like Bruxish, Indeedee-F, and Medicham that hinder Muk's ability to set up and sweep.

sets.name: Special Sludge (Poison)
sets.description:
Alolan Muk finds serves critical role on Poison teams thanks to its immense special bulk and Dark typing allowing it to come in and threaten out several Psychic- and Ghost-types like Flutter Mane, Basculegion-F, Espathra, and Galarian Slowking with ease. STAB Knock Off allows Poison teams to much more reliably outlast common foes such as Clodsire and Garganacl. Drain Punch provides Alolan Muk with a solid recovery tool and gives it coverage for common Dark and Steel threats such as Hydreigon, Chien-Pao, and Hisuian Goodra. Protect allows Alolan Muk to scout for coverage move and gain additional Black Sludge recovery. For its final slot, it has two major options that stand out; Poison Jab is a strong second STAB option with a 51% chance to Poison thanks to Poison Touch, allowing Alolan Muk to spread Poison more effectively, while Rest can remove status and allows it to deal with threats like Spectrier one-on-one. Ice Punch can also be useful in easing matchups like Flying and Electric by defeating threats such Iron Jugulis and Thundurus-T.

Physically defensive Amoonguss is an incredible partner for Alolan Muk thanks to its Ground neutrality, Water resistance, and STAB Grass moves, as it can handle the Ground and Water threats that would normally feast on Alolan Muk like Great Tusk, Garchomp, Quagsire, and Urshifu-R without much worry. Physically defensive Toxapex can handle threats such as Kleavor and Mimikyu thanks to Haze and Toxic. Both Galarian Slowking and Clodsire compliment Alolan Muk as fellow special walls, as Assault Vest Galarian Slowking handles Enamorus, Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Landorus-I while creating pressure with Future Sight while Alolan Muk helps deals with the Ghost- and Dark-types that would normally threaten it. Meanwhile, Unaware Clodsire deals with setup threats like Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Sneasler while creating pressure by providing hazards which Alolan Muk helps take advantage of by removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Glimmora also appreciates Alolan Muk removing Heavy-Duty Boots, which makes its hazards much more threatening towards threats such as Amoonguss and Articuno, while Alolan Muk appreciates the hazard removal Glimmora brings thanks to Mortal Spin allowing it to come in safely over the course of a game and by putting Corrosion Toxic onto bulky threats such as Corviknight and Toxapex which will just absorb Alolan Muk's attacks otherwise. Corrosion Salazzle can also threaten Toxic onto the previously mentioned Alolan Muk checks along with being able to handle Steel-types like Kingambit and Heatran thanks to Substitute and Protect. Sneasler also breaks the aforementioned Steel-types using Close Combat and can bring in Alolan Muk against threats that eradicate Sneasler like Gholdengo thanks to U-turn.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: With a great defensive typing, solid special bulk, and Knock Off, Alolan Muk is a great RegenVest user, repeatedly entering the battle and disrupting fierce special attackers like Iron Moth and Zapdos. Knock Off provides critical utility and disruption, deters potential answers from switching into it, and provides decent uninvested damage output against neutral targets. Poison Fang semi-reliably spreads Toxic poison onto opposing walls, while Poison Jab can 2HKO Enamorus-T and Meowscarada. Rock Slide hits Zapdos, Volcanion, Talonflame, and Volcarona hard, punishing them for switching in. Ice Punch nails common switch-ins like Landorus-T and Garchomp, while Thunderbolt snipes Corviknight. Physical walls like Corviknight, Unaware Scream Tail, and Quaquaval are a natural pairing, as they can better deal with the physical attackers that threaten Alolan Muk like Garchomp, Chien-Pao, and Galarian Zapdos. Mixed attackers like Magic Guard Volcanion and Heatran threaten Alolan Muk out, so offensive answers to these like Sword of Ruin Garchomp, Chien-Pao, and Galarian Zapdos are recommended. Entry hazards wear down Alolan Muk over the course of the game and prevent it from properly dealing with repeated attacks from threats like Iron Moth and Iron Jugulis, so hazard removers like Iron Treads, Quaquaval, and Corviknight are all recommended teammates.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: 84 Attack EVs let Muk OHKO a Mega Charizard Y at full with Rock Slide.

sets.name: Assault Vest (Poison)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physical Shell Smash
sets.description:
Shellder is a powerful sweeper with access to Shell Smash, especially when supported by its ability Skill Link. Shellder’s base 100 Defense gives it plenty of opportunities to set up versus the tier's physical attackers such as Pawniard, Mudbray, and Alolan Grimer. Rock Blast is a fantastic compliment to Liquidation, allowing Shellder to break through Water resistances such as Foongus, and Hisuian Voltorb.Protect is useful for scouting foes' Tera types while blocking priority moves such as Sucker Punch and First Impression. Tera Water boosts its STAB damage even further, demolishing neutral targets that would otherwise take a hit such as Crabrawler and Pawniard. Tera Rock guarantees KOs on Water resistances such as Foongus and Hisuian Voltorb. Tera Dark doesn’t have the benefits of added power but instead blocks Prankster Encore from Shroodle and improves Shellder’s defensive profile by resisting Sucker Punch.

Glimmet can greatly facilitate a sweep with its ability to set entry hazards. Alolan Grimer helps deal with Grass-types that deter Shellder's sweep and weakens the opposing team by using Knock Off. Grookey's Grassy Terrain provides Shellder with some passive recovery, and Grookey can pivot in Shellder via U-turn in addition to also having access to Knock Off. Choice Scarf Gothita can trap Pokemon via Shadow Tag to help facilitate a sweep, removing key pieces of the opposing team or using Trick to trap them using a non-helpful move. Memento support works wonderfully from teammates such as Drifloon, which can also use Will-O-Wisp to provide more Shell Smash opportunities, or Alolan Diglett, which can also set up Stealth Rock.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Cloyster acts as an entry hazard lead on hyper offense teams that can also threaten a sweep thanks to Shell Smash. Shell Smash gives Cloyster the ability to outspeed and threaten out Great Tusk and non-Choice Scarf variants of Koraidon and Miraidon, as well as break through Corviknight. Rock Blast gives Cloyster a way to OHKO Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao. Tera Ghost prevents opposing spinners from removing the hazards Cloyster sets and provides an immunity to Fighting-type attacks, such as Koraidon's Close Combat and Breloom's Mach Punch. Cloyster fits on hyper offense teams where its Spikes weaken foes for setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Koraidon, Double Dance Miraidon, Iron Moth, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao. Cloyster has no way to remove opposing hazards, so partners such as Hatterene and Great Tusk can act as a form of hazard control, letting Cloyster and its teammates, such as Chien-Pao and Breloom, maintain their Focus Sashes. Cloyster also struggles to make progress against Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Kingambit, so partners that can threaten them such as Great Tusk, Kingambit, Chien-Pao, Hatterene, and Taunt Koraidon are appreciated. Grimmsnarl also pairs well with Cloyster by providing dual screens support, which lets Cloyster and its teammates set up much more easily. Gholdengo can also keep Cloyster's Spikes on the field, and in return, Cloyster takes on Ting-Lu for it. Chien-Pao and Koraidon are especially noteworthy partners, since they appreciate its Spikes and can overwhelm Toxapex for Cloyster.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper (Ice)
sets.description:
Cloyster is one of Ice's best setup sweepers thanks to its access to Shell Smash in addition to its high Defense stat, which gives it opportunity to set up on the tier's physical attackers like Garchomp, Iron Treads, and Ceruledge. Icicle Spear targets opposing Flying-, Ground- and Dragon-type Pokemon such as Kilowattrel, Clodsire, and Walking Wake while breaking Focus Sash on Pokemon such as Breloom. Rock Blast benefits from Skill Link and threatens Fire-types like Ceruledge after a boost and other Ice-type Pokemon like Chien-Pao. Ice Shard is useful for revenge killing faster Choice Scarf Pokemon that are weakened like Flutter Mane, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon. Hydro Pump is the alternative in order to not be walled by opposing Steel-types like Kingambit and Forretress. It is also beneficial for threatening Paldean Tauros-F, which is a significant issue to Ice teams, as well as Skeledirge and Torkoal, easing the Fire matchup. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature allows +2 Cloyster to outspeed Choice Scarf users such as Walking Wake, Hydreigon and Indeedee; a Naive nature with the remaining 4 EVs going into Special Attack should be used if opting for Hydro Pump to not reduce its damage. Skill Link is the best ability to run on Cloyster since it guarantees Icicle Spear and Rock Blast hit 5 times. White Herb is Cloyster's preferred item, as it is able to offset the Defense drops of Shell Smash, which makes Cloyster harder to revenge kill. Focus Sash is the alternative to always guarantee one turn of setup from full health, but it is less preferred since Cloyster is harder to OHKO under snow or Aurora Veil.

Cloyster's best partner on Ice is Abomasnow. Abomasnow allows Cloyster to have an easier time to set up thanks to it setting snow, which, combined with Aurora Veil, allows it to set up on Pokemon that can usually threaten it out like offensive Great Tusk and Cinderace. Abomasnow also has Leech Seed support to improve Cloyster's longevity and handles Unaware Pokemon Quagsire and Dondozo with its STAB Giga Drain. Cloyster is able to threaten Fire's weather setter Torkoal after a boost, which benefits Abomasnow, as it can come back in to reset the weather for its teammates. Cloyster also appreciates Chien-Pao as an offensive partner, as Swords Dance sets are able to weaken its defensive checks like Toxapex, Kingambit and Rotom-W. Choice Scarf sets are also able to clean up late-game more easily thanks to Cloyster's sweeping. Baxcalibur is also one more offensive partner for Cloyster, as its ability to switch into Will-o-Wisp from Pokemon like Sableye and Rotom-W supports Cloyster's sweeping capabilities, while Cloyster offers additional support against the Dragon-types that threaten Baxcalibur like Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon. Choice Band Baxcalibur can also wear down defensive walls like Corviknight and Skeledirge, which gives Cloyster an easier sweep. Glaceon also pairs well with Cloyster, as it can threaten defensive Water-type Pokemon like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Dondozo with Freeze-Dry. Avalugg can support Cloyster with its Rapid Spin to remove hazards, so Cloyster can come in easier and set up. Avalugg is also able to handle Cloyster's offensive checks like Great Tusk under snow. Froslass is Ice's only viable option for Spikes, which Cloyster appreciates, as defensive Pokemon like Hatterene and Iron Hands aren't able to check it properly after a boost.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
• Shell Smash and Skill Link more than make up for Cloyster's weak Attack stat, making it a formidable sweeper that Focus Sash and Mimikyu can't easily stop.

  • Ice Shard: Priority may seem like overkill, but it helps pick off weakened threats without setup. It also gets around priority attacks from Breloom, Dragapult, and Meowscarada after a Shell Smash.

  • Rock Blast: This is Closyer's best shot at dealing with the many Tera Fires that resist Icicle Spear, as well as OHKOing Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle, and Iron Moth.

  • Drill Run: This hits Gholdengo and other Steel-types hard without needing to Terastallize.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: Adamant is the preferred nature to maximize offensive power, as a single Shell Smash lets you outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. However, Cloyster is in the same speed tier as Breloom, so Jolly is a consideration if you want to minimize Speed tie scenarios in that matchup.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: As a Focus Sash user, Cloyster wants to avoid using Tera when possible, but opposing priority attacks and defensive typings can sometimes make it a necessity.

  • Ghost: Since Cloyster will often be at extremely low health after Shell Smash, Tera Ghost helps it avoid getting revenge killed by Breloom's Mach Punch and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed. It also provides coverage against Gholdengo with Tera Blast.

  • Ice: The increased damage from Tera Ice makes it very difficult for Pokemon to wall Cloyster without resisting it, with even Corviknight getting OHKOed by +2 Adamant Icicle Spear after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Ground: Volt Switch users like Rotom-W love to take Cloyster down to its Sash and pivot to a priority attacker; Tera Ground both immunes the damage and prevents the switch, giving Cloyster significant momentum with a free turn to Shell Smash. It also lets Cloyster challenge defensive Gholdengo, blocking Thunder Wave and giving +2 Adamant Drill Run a strong chance to OHKO.

  • Fire: While Tera Fire Tera Blast actually does less damage to Corviknight than Tera Ice Icicle Spear, Tera Fire otherwise helps Cloyster muscle past Steel-types it traditionally struggles to beat, such as Scizor.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is a niche option that offers no offensive benefits to Cloyster, but it does prevent Mimikyu and Gallade from revenge killing it with Shadow Sneak.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Considering Cloyster's paper thin Special Defense, Focus Sash gives Cloyster by far the most set up opportunities.

  • King's Rock: King's Rock is a risky option that doesn’t help Cloyster set up, but it does give Icicle Spear and Rock Blast a 41% chance of flinching.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ice)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper (Ice)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Choice Specs Haunter is a powerful wallbreaker in a tier with few Ghost-type checks, spamming strong Shadow Balls supplemented by its great coverage moves. Focus Blast is useful for hitting Dark- and Normal-types such as Alolan Persian, Pyroar, and Komala that would switch into a Shadow Ball. Trick cripples checks it cannot immediately break through such as Chansey and Skuntank, while Energy Ball is specifically used for Whiscash, an otherwise solid midground option to scout whatever Haunter uses. Tera Ghost is the preferred option in order to boost Shadow Ball's power, lessening the need to predict against Pokemon like Assault Vest Crabominable; however, Tera Blast Ground can remove Skuntank, one of Haunter's most efficient checks.

Despite its strong power, Haunter is slower than common wallbreakers such as Basculin, Charizard, and Alolan Dugtrio as well as being extremely fragile to anything it isn't immune to, so pivot support is necessary in order to bring it in safely. Alolan Persian is a top tier pivot that can easily bring Haunter in with Parting Shot and can switch into physical wallbreakers that threaten Haunter out like Dugtrio and Basculin. Rotom-F is also a strong pivot that synergizes well with Haunter, pivoting it in on Pokemon like Misdreavus while wearing down shared checks like Chansey and Whiscash. Ground-types like Camerupt and Whiscash can switch into the fast Electric-types that threaten Haunter out like Electrode and Raichu and set entry hazards that wear down Haunter's checks that do not run Heavy-Duty Boots like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Haunter is a great Choice Scarf user and late-game cleaner in NU because it outspeeds other notable Choice Scarf users such as Rotom, Passimian, and Bruxish and has perfect coverage for the tier. Shadow Ball threatens Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Drifblim, Rotom, and Medicham, while Focus Blast threatens Normal- and Dark-types such as Dudunsparce, Ursaring, and Umbreon that can comfortably switch into Shadow Ball. Trick lets Haunter punish walls such as Chansey, Poison Touch Muk, and Umbreon by crippling them with a Choice Scarf. Sludge Bomb threatens Pokemon such as Appletun and Cacturne and can inflict poison on special walls like Eelektross, which pressures them throughout the match. It can also threaten various Pokemon such as Tera Fairy Umbreon and Drifblim. Nasty Plot can be run instead to give Haunter a boosting option after it has gotten rid of its Choice Scarf via Trick, threatening Pokemon such as Umbreon much more effectively. Destiny Bond can be used as a last resort to neutralize dangerous setup sweepers such as Coil Eelektross, Coil Sandaconda, and Bulk Up Ursaring as well as punish offensive threats such as Passimian, Zoroark, and Scyther that may attempt to revenge kill Haunter after it has lost its Choice Scarf. Tera Ghost is able to increase Haunter's cleaning potential by powering up Shadow Ball. Tera Fighting can be used to assist Haunter versus Pokemon such as Cacturne and Lycanroc by granting resistances to Sucker Punch and Accelerock, and it also powers up Focus Blast. Haunter has horrible bulk and cannot take even resisted hits well, so it is advised that you pair it with pivots such as Eelektross, Passimian, and Scyther. Furthermore, Haunter struggles with special walls such as Chansey, Umbreon, and Muk, so powerful physical attackers such as Passimian and Medicham can assist in solving this issue.

sets.name: Hex
sets.description:
Gengar's strong utility movepool allows it to potentially take on a longer term approach, spreading a variety of status options to wear down checks such as Gastrodon and Tyranitar and using Hex for strong damage without item-based downsides. Gengar's movepool when running Hex sets is fairly flexible based on its team. It can spread status very well with Will-O-Wisp + Sludge Bomb, but Toxic Spikes can also let it help wear down its own future switch-ins, like Gastrodon, or Pokemon such as Scream Tail and Wo-Chien as they switch into its teammates.
