Focus Blast can be a good option to avoid letting Tyranitar switch in freely, while Substitute lets Gengar punish switches it forces against Pokemon like Wo-Chien to provide free turns and protect itself from revenge killers. Will-O-Wisp should preferably not be dropped to run a combination of these other moves, as it is fantastic for crippling Tinkaton and Tyranitar and can ensure an immediate status against Heavy-Duty Boots Gastrodon too. Tera Ghost lets Gengar significantly power up its Hex to pressure Pokemon like Gastrodon even more while removing its Ground weakness, but Gengar is often not a priority Terastallization user.

This set fits best on bulkier teams that like to take their time wearing down the opposing team. Quagsire is an excellent teammate for this set, as it can threaten Tyranitar and Grafaiai while also spreading Toxic and entry hazards in order to wear down other Pokemon, such as Gastrodon and TInkaton. Teammates such as Wo-Chien and Cyclizar that can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes like Gastrodon, Wo-Chien, and Sandy Shocks are highly appreciated if Gengar is running Toxic Spikes. Wo-Chien can also help check Pokemon such as Greninja and Sandy Shocks for Gengar, while Cyclizar can help keep entry hazards off Gengar's side without removing its Toxic Spikes and give it switch-in opportunities against Decideueye and Slither Wing with U-turn. Gengar also appreciates defensive support against Pokemon such as Noivern, Scizor, and Talonflame, so teammates like Gastrodon and Talonflame are valuable. Offensive teammates, such as Pawmot and Tyranitar, appreciate Gengar's Toxic Spikes support to pressure checks like Hippowdon. Espeon can help check Gastrodon and deny it from setting Spikes against Gengar; it can also wear down Tinkaton, and it appreciates Toxic Spikes to prevent Pokemon like Scream Tail from checking it. Tinkaton can check Noivern, provide Stealth Rock, and use Knock Off to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from Gastrodon and Slowbro. Sandy Shocks can provide Spikes to help pressure switch-ins like Tinkaton, and it can offer entry points against Decideueye and Wo-Chien with Volt Switch. In return, it appreciates Gengar pressuring Gastrodon.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Gengar is an adept revenge killer and late-game cleaner thanks to its blazing Speed tier alongside solid offensive presence between its remarkable Special Attack and offensive movepool. It can outspeed boosted threats like Polteageist, Toxtricity, Salamence, and opposing Choice Scarf users like Sandy Shocks, Pawmot, and Staraptor. Energy Ball blows away Gastrodon and Sandy Shocks while doing servicable damage to Tyranitar and Hippowdon. On the other hand, Focus Blast hits Grafaiai and Dark-types like Tyranitar and Bisharp, and it lets Gengar revenge kill foes like Tera Normal Lucario and Lycanroc-D, although Gengar likes the ability to immediately KO Gastrodon. Thunderbolt allows Gengar to nail Dragon Dance Gyarados and Booster Energy Iron Jugulis super effectively. Trick improves its matchup against defensive teams by crippling switch-ins like Tinkaton, Hippowdon, and Tera Poison Wo-Chien, as well as shutting down bulky setup sweepers like Oricorio-E. Tera Ghost amplifies Shadow Ball damage, notably 2HKOing Quagsire and OHKOing Gallade, Gardevoir, and Slowbro, while still maintaining Gengar's immunity to Lucario's Extreme Speed.

Gengar finds a place on bulky offense and offense teams. Early-game wallbreakers like Scizor, Slither Wing, Tyranitar, and Bisharp can severely weaken or overwhelm Tinkaton, Hippowdon, and Dark-types for Gengar to clean up late-game. Tyranitar and Bisharp also provide a solid defensive backbone against opposing Choice Scarf Gengar to avoid risking Speed ties, with the latter switching into Lokix and opposing Bisharp's Sucker Punch as well. In return, Gengar matches up well against offensive threats like Pawmot, Lucario, and Choice Scarf Gallade that would pose a threat to them. Offensive pivots like Sandy Shocks, Tsareena, and the aforementioned Scizor and Slither Wing can bring Gengar in safely on foes such as opposing Tsareena, Talonflame, Paldean Tauros-W, and Scream Tail, respectively. Moreover, Sandy Shocks provides entry hazards to chip down Gengar's checks, while Tsareena threatens bulky Ground-types like Hippowdon and Gastrodon, the latter of which is especially problematic since its Sticky Hold prevents Gengar's Trick.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Disruptor
sets.description:
• Gengar's useful immunities and great support movepool give it a niche as an incredibly disruptive Pokemon, especially if taking the correct predictive risks.

  • Destiny Bond: Destiny Bond is excellent at making foes second guess attacking Gengar. When slower foes don't take the bait and use a setup move, Gengar can punish them with Encore.

  • Encore: Gengar's excellent speed makes it an especially disruptive user of Encore, being able to disrupt key threats such as Garchomp and Dragonite.

  • Icy Wind: Icy Wind's Speed control can give Gengar the upper hand against fast Focus Sash leads such as Flutter Mane, and lets Gengar outspeed faster threats that it may want to Destiny Bond, such as Meowscarada.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave is great at crippling faster sweepers if Gengar's Focus Sash is intact, and punishing fast, common switch-ins such as Roaring Moon.

  • Sludge Bomb: This covers Meowscarada and Fairy-types, in addition to being Gengar's most powerful attack.

  • Dazzling Gleam In addition to OHKOing Hydreigon after Stealth Rock damage, Dazzling Gleam is an appealing secondary STAB move when using Tera Fairy.

  • Focus Blast: Focus Blast is Gengar's best shot at beating Kingambit outside of Destiny Bond.

Other Options

  • Will-O-Wisp Gengar does a great job of burning bulky sweepers that Gengar can be forced to Destiny Bond against, such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Tera Annihilape.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal Gengar can turn slower Ghost-types such as Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Annihilape into easy Encore targets.

  • Fairy: A Dragon-type immunity gives Gengar new Encore targets and better threatens Dragon-types.

  • Flying: Earthquake is a common attack against Gengar, so Tera Flying can turn the tables effectively. It also takes advantage of common Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type lets Gengar surprise Espathra, letting it Encore Stored Power and potentially ruin its sweep.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker (Ghost)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Tera Pivot
sets.description: Voltorb's elite Speed tier and STAB Volt Switch make it one of Little Cup's premier pivots, as well as an excellent offensive check to fast threats like Wingull and Crabrawler. Volt Switch lets Voltorb deal solid damage while preserving itself and capitalizing on the switches it forces with its Speed. Thunderbolt deals a stronger blow, invaluable against bulky Water-types like Mareanie, Quaxly, and Shellos, and is valuable for cleaning up weakened fast threats. Tera Blast, once Voltorb has Terastallized, gives it the heralded BoltBeam coverage and turns the tables on would-be checks like Toedscool, Mudbray, Diglett, and Wattrel. Because of Voltorb's limited coverage and the prominence of Ground-types, Voltorb often depends on Terastallization (or the threat of it) to function well in a match. Voltorb leans on a few utility options for its fourth move due to its limited movepool; Protect stops Nymble's First Impression from revenge killing it and can scout defensive Terastallizations, especially Tera Water on Toedscool. Taunt prevents setup and entry hazards from the likes of Pawniard, Surskit, and Glimmet, and Thunder Wave neutralizes setup sweepers and faster threats that Voltorb cannot OHKO. Voltorb pairs well with teammates that can switch into its Ground-type checks when it has not Terastallized. Toedscool is a natural partner thanks to its bulk, Ground resistance, and ability to remove entry hazards for Terastallized Voltorb, given its new Stealth Rock weakness. Drifloon's Ground immunity also supports Voltorb well. As a pivot, Voltorb appreciates the support of other pivots to continually put your opponent on the back foot. Nymble has a powerful STAB U-turn and often invites in Mareanie, which Voltorb can pressure. Wingull not only checks Ground-types with its dual STAB types and Ground immunity, but also appreciates Voltorb handling the bulky Water-types that check it.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Electrode's blazing Speed tier and ability to take advantage of Terastallization cement it a niche as an effective pivot and late-game cleaner. Taunt shuts down recovery attempts from checks like Gogoat, setup attempts from Pokemon like Rotom-F, and entry hazards from foes like Carbink and Tinkatuff. The move pairs well with Electrode's nature as a pivot, giving partners an easier time setting up without dealing with annoying status. Due to Electrode's relative fragility and the prevalence of entry hazards, Aftermath is more effective at punishing priority users like Alolan Dugtrio and Basculin, as they are much more afraid of the guaranteed chip damage when revenge killing Electrode than the potential paralysis that Static provides. Tera Blast Fighting is an solid option that lets Electrode revenge kill Alolan Dugtrio, Houndoom, and Rotom-F as well as dent walls like Hisuian Sliggoo and Dunsparce. Tera Blast Ice is very useful for hitting Ground- and Grass-types like Gabite and Gogoat, although its inability to OHKO Whiscash does hinder its viability. Tera Water increases Electrode's revenge killing capability against Fire-types like Charizard and Pyroar, as well as Alolan Dugtrio; however, it also leaves it susceptible to Electric-types like Raichu and opposing Electrode in the one-on-one matchup. Lastly, Tera Grass is useful for hitting Whiscash, Carbink, and Klawf all in the same slot, something no other Tera type allows Electrode to do, while Tera Ground is also an option to specifically hit Raichu.

Electrode fits best with strong mid-game wallbreakers that struggle to get in, such as Zangoose and Basculin. Not only do they enjoy the free turn on Pokemon such as Gogoat and Carbink, they can also break down shared checks such as Gabite, making it easier for Electrode to win late-game. Whiscash is a major annoyance for Electrode, as it is immune to Taunt and is the only viable Ground-type to not take super effective damage from either of Electrode's common Tera types; thus, a strong Grass-type like Gogoat or Sawsbuck is recommended as a partner. They can also potentially force Whiscash to Terastallize, removing its Electric immunity for Electrode. Other fast Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Rotom-F can form a VoltTurn core with Electrode, utilizing entry hazards and a good Speed tier to pivot into each other's checks, such as Flapple, Skuntank, and Misdreavus, racking up chip damage. Entry hazards from Pokemon like Whiscash and Tinkatuff also benefit Electrode, as it can constantly force in Pokemon like Gabite and Dunsparce, which do not use Heavy-Duty Boots, and wear them down faster.

sets.name: Rain Dance
sets.description:
Electrode's phenomenal Speed, which allows it to outrun the entire unboosted metagame, good utility options, and ability to quickly pivot out after setting up Rain Dance allows it to be PU's best lead for rain teams. Taunt can prevent opposing leads such as Sticky Web Masquerain, and Stealth Rock Alolan Dugtrio from setting up entry hazards and block Gogoat from attempting to set up to break the team in the early game. Thunder is gives Electrode a powerful, accurate STAB move in rain. Explosion is normally used in the last slot, as it gives Electrode a nuclear option and gives a guaranteed free switch to a partner, but Volt Switch allows Electrode to pivot into a teammate after setting up Rain Dance to set up Rain Dance again.

Swift Swim sweepers like Golduck and Beartic are necessary teammates to exploit Rain Dance. Other Water-types such as Basculin and Wugtrio enjoy having their Water-moves boosted as well. Masquerain is a particularly notable partner, as it has its Hurricane made 100% accurate, it can set up on foes it could normally not set up on outside of rain, such as Pyroar and Camerupt and has its Water-type coverage boosted as well, letting it chip foes like Carbink harder. Electric-types such as Raichu and Rotom-F enjoy being able to use a 100% accurate Thunder and can offensively check the opposing Water-types that would want to take advantage of rain, such as Basculin. Other Rain Dance setters such as Murkrow and Golduck are helpful for Electrode to not have to exclusively set Rain Dance for its team.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Hisuian Electrode's excellent Speed tier, powerful Volt Switch, and ability to nail Ground-types like Garchomp and Iron Treads make it an outstanding offensive pivot. Leech Seed lets Hisuian Electrode chip down targets it can't meaningfully damage like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey, while Worry Seed directly forces out these Pokemon and can generate momentum for Hisuian Electrode by denying its checks of their Regenerator, wearing them down. Hisuian Electrode works best with strong physically offensive pivots like Cinderace and Galarian Zapdos that can wear down shared checks like Garchomp; in return, Hisuian Electrode can force in Pokemon they take advantage of like Meloetta, Hisuian Goodra, and Blissey. Entry hazards setters like Landorus-T and Garchomp make solid partners, as the residual damage they provide greatly helps to wear down Hisuian Electrode's switch-ins, such as Hisuain Goodra. In return, Landorus-T can use its slow U-Turn to pivot Hisuian Electrode in, while Garchomp can come in on Pokemon like Heatran for Hisuian Electrode.

sets.name: Utility Wall
sets.description:
While Chansey is bulkier than Blissey thanks to Eviolite, this is rendered moot due to it being affected by hazards and Blissey’s ability to use Heavy-Duty Boots. However, this set has a niche on stall teams, as it takes over as the utility wall, freeing up Blissey to run Calm Mind to better beat special setup sweepers like Oricorio-P, Vivillon, and Mesprit. Thunder Wave allows Chansey to cripple Fighting-types that love to switch in on it and threaten it out while also slowing down Quiver Dance users. Heal Bell allows Chansey to clear status conditions for its teammates, which helps it against more defensive teams that may carry Toxic. Tera Ghost allows it to soft check a multitude of common physical attackers like Toxicroak and Tauros, while Tera Fairy grants it a great defensive typing against most of the metagame as well as a resistance to Fighting-type attacks.

Thanks to Chansey taking care of Blissey’s utility and ability to run Stealth Rock, Blissey and Sandaconda can now use Calm Mind and Coil for added insurance against special and physical boosters, respectively. Chansey quickly falls against physical attackers, so physical walls like Avalugg, Sableye, and Sandaconda make for great teammates. Because Chansey is forced to run Eviolite, it requires hazard control from the likes of Avalugg and Braviary. Common switch-ins to Trick and Knock Off like Sandaconda and Sticky Hold Muk are also greatly appreciated against Pokemon like Sableye, Mesprit, and Bombirdier, as Chansey requires its Eviolite. Setup sweepers like Mesprit and Hisuian Sneasel tend to overwhelm Chansey, so Pokemon like Sableye and Choice Scarf Ditto make for amazing partners. Against Rotom, Chansey is completely useless and is especially taken advantage of by Nasty Plot sets or crippled by Choice Scarf sets with Trick, so Pokemon like Umbreon, Crocalor, and Sticky Hold Muk check it.

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: With Eviolite and Ice Scales, Chansey becomes the bulkiest specially defensive wall in the tier, capable of walling virtually every special attacker. Ruination bypasses Chansey's meager offenses to deal damage. Toxic cripples bulky Pokemon like Arceus formes and setup sweepers like Palkia-O. Parting Shot allows Chansey to safely pivot teammates in thanks to its low Speed. Chansey’s low Attack limits Strength Sap healing from common special attackers, making it effective at wearing them down in the long run. Chansey's poor Defense means that it enjoys Fur Coat teammates like Groudon, Eternatus, and Arceus formes to check powerful physical attackers like Koraidon and Groudon. Chansey is also hindered by poison from Mortal Spin and Toxic, so having Hell Bell somewhere on the team is useful. Tera Ghost protects Chansey from being trapped, whereas Tera Poison makes it immune to poison and grants a resistance to Pixilate Extreme Speed from Arceus-Fairy.

sets.name: Pink Blob (Defensive)
sets.description: Thanks to its gargantuan Eviolite-boosted special bulk alongside a lack of relevant weaknesses, Chansey stands firmly as a formidable wall that blanket checks the metagame's special attackers, including Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona. Toxic lets Chansey whittle them down, especially in conjunction with repeated Seismic Tosses, while Thunder Wave punishes poison-immune foes like Heatran and Toxapex and cripples switch-ins such as Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Chansey can provide cleric support with Aromatherapy, especially since it can switch into status users like Clodsire and Rotom-W thanks to Natural Cure. However, Stealth Rock can be used if the team lacks another user, and Chansey can do it sufficiently by outlasting common entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T. Tera Steel allows it to reliably check Tapu Lele, Hatterene, and Tornadus-T, and it prevents Chansey from being poisoned. Chansey is generally reserved for bulkier builds that appreciate its defensive profile and can tolerate its overall passivity. Sturdy walls like Skeledirge, Buzzwole, Skarmory, and Corviknight can cover physical attackers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Kartana for Chansey. Skeledirge's Unaware helps against setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Mega Charizard X that attempt to use Chansey as setup fodder, while Corviknight's Defog alleviates Chansey from entry hazard pressure that would overwhelm it easily. Knock Off and Trick absorbers like Clefable, Toxapex, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo make sure that Chansey can keep its valuable Eviolite; Additionally, Mega Scizor helps deal with Psyshock Tapu Lele, Gholdengo threatens Calm Mind Hatterene, and Calm Mind Clefable overwhelms Heatran—especially if it's paralyzed—all of which are special attackers that can beat Chansey one-on-one.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Armed with excellent Speed and STAB U-turn, Scyther is an elite pivot in NU. Aerial Ace targets opposing Scyther and the plethora of Grass- and Fighting-types found in the tier, such as Appletun, Lurantis, Toxicroak, and Paldean Tauros. Thief targets Rotom and Drifblim and can steal items should Scyther lose its Heavy-Duty Boots. Close Combat strikes Steel-types like Magneton and Perrserker as well as Normal-types like Blissey and Ursaring. While both Tera types turn Scyther’s double weakness to Stealth Rock into resistances and remove its weaknesses to Electric and Fire, Tera Ground prevents Volt Switch users like Rotom and Magneton from pivoting on it, while Tera Fighting boosts Close Combat’s power. Tera Dark boosts Thief's power and gives it an immunity to Sableye's Prankster moves.

Scyther is an excellent facilitator for VoltTurn teams, pairing well with specially offensive pivots like Eelektross, Articuno, and Magneton. These pivots can threaten physical walls like Sandaconda, Qwilfish formes, and Drifblim; Scyther can pressure special walls like Appletun, Blissey, and Muk. Clerics like Umbreon and Blissey can provide Scyther with extra longevity with Wish and cure it of status with Heal Bell, respectively. Entry hazard setters like Sandaconda, Cacturne, and Froslass can rack up residual damage against the aforementioned physical walls, making them easier to wear down over the course of a game.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Scyther is a terrific Swords Dance sweeper, courtesy to its fantastic Speed, good power, and variety of Technician-boosted moves. Aerial Ace scares off slower Grass- and Fighting-types, like Cacturne, Abomasnow, Toxicroak, and non-Choice Scarf Medicham. U-turn can allow it to pivot against physical walls like Sandaconda and Drifblim, as well as Pokemon that resist Aerial Ace like Rotom and Eelektross. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Magneton and Tera Steel Appletun for super effective damage while hitting Blissey harder than any of its other moves. Trailblaze allows Scyther to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame while also hitting Sandaconda harder. Tera Grass removes Scyther’s 4x weakness to Stealth Rock and allows Scyther to 2HKO Sandaconda at +2, while Tera Fighting strengthens its Close Combat to frightening levels and turns its Rock weakness into a resistance.

Swords Dance Scyther is best used mid- to late-game, where it has a better chance of picking off sufficiently weakened physical walls like Drifblim and Sandaconda. Scyther must be wary of the adverse contact effects like Aftermath and Rocky Helmet, respectively, from these two. If U-turn is selected, VoltTurn pivots like Rotom, Eelektross, and Mesprit once again make for excellent teammates, threatening out walls like Sandaconda and Blissey while providing additional utility or coverage. Revenge killers like Tauros and Choice Scarf Rotom can preemptively cause Scyther to Terastalize or stop its sweep altogether, so specific checks to them like Sandaconda and Camerupt respectively, can help preserve Scyther's longevity. Special wallbreakers like Clawitzer, Cacturne, and Pyroar can soften up physical walls like Sandaconda and Sableye so Scyther can find better chances to sweep late-game. Due to its 4x weakness to Stealth Rock, switch-ins to Knock Off like Sticky Hold Muk and Sandaconda can greatly help it.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Tauros is a great wallbreaker and late-game sweeper thanks to its combination of Sheer Force + Life Orb attacks, good coverage, and solid Speed tier. Rock Slide hits Flying-types like Oricorio-F, Articuno, and Scyther. While both Earthquake and Close Combat hit Steel-types that otherwise come in safely, the former gives Tauros an advantageous matchup against Poison-types such as Qwilfish and Muk, whereas the latter hits Steel-types harder while also nuking Ice-types like Abomasnow and Glaceon. Tera Ghost makes Tauros immune to Fighting-type attacks from Medicham and Hisuian Sneasel, and Tera Blast lets it hit Psychic- and Ghost-types in Hattrem and Rotom for greater damage than its other attacks. Tera Fairy is another option that helps against Fighting-types, and Tera Blast Fairy lets it beat Sableye and Spiritomb, which can otherwise wall it. Assurance can be used instead in combination with Stealth Rock from a teammate to OHKO Rotom on the switch. Tera Normal with Body Slam can also be used to take care of checks like Sandaconda, which gets 2HKOed after Stealth Rock.

Qwilfish and Froslass are good partners for Tauros, as it usually can’t KO its checks off the bat, so Spikes support is greatly appreciated—along with having a switch-in to Fighting-type attacks. Jolteon and Rotom are also amazing partners, as they can, together with Tauros, overwhelm Sandaconda with their Tera Blast Ice or Trick, respectively. A pivot such as Mesprit or Assault Vest Eelektross can use U-turn to draw in switch-ins like Appletun, Blissey, and Bombirdier, which Tauros can take advantage of.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Paldean Tauros is a terrific Bulk Up sweeper with its great Speed and wide offensive movepool. After using Trailblaze, Paldean Tauros outspeeds Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Rotom. Stone Edge is great coverage for common Fighting-resistant foes like Haunter, Scyther, and Drifblim, while Tera Electric lets Paldean Tauros hit the aforementioned Flying-types and Vaporeon with Tera Blast and offers an immunity to paralysis. Tera Rock Stone Edge and Tera Electric Tera Blast both allow Paldean Tauros to OHKO Drifblim. Leftovers aids its general longevity, while Lum Berry allows it to set up safely once against status users like Rotom and Drifblim. Offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Rotom and Zoroark appreciate Paldean Tauros forcing out foes like Umbreon and Chansey; in return, they can check Ghost-types like opposing Rotom and Drifblim. Defensive teammates like Vaporeon and Chansey can sponge special attacks and either help its longevity with Wish or its offensive capabilities with Thunder Wave.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Paldean Tauros-F’s unique defensive typing with Intimidate allows it to act as a capable defensive pivot against prominent physical attackers like Kingambit and Meowscarada. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Roaring Moon on the switch-in to prevent an otherwise losing matchup. Body Press is a powerful attack on Paldean Tauros-F, as it has the power to OHKO Greninja, Kingambit and Meowscarada. It also has a chance to OHKO Roaring Moon while dealing notable damage to Garganacl and Ting-Lu. Raging Bull hits foes like Breloom and Gholdengo while removing Light Screen and Reflect against offensive teams. Protect lets Paldean Tauros-F stall for Will-O-Wisp damage and grants it Leftovers recovery while scouting moves from Choice-locked foes like Dragapult and Walking Wake. Leftovers is its only source of recovery, helping it more consistently switch into resisted attacks. Heavy-Duty Boots helps Paldean Tauros-F more easily switch into U-turn from pivots like Meowscarada and Roaring Moon while synergizing well with Tera Flying to remove the Stealth Rock weakness. Heavy-Duty Boots can be more easily opted out of for Leftovers on teams with sufficient entry hazard control. Intimidate allows it to more easily take neutral hits from its checks, such as Roaring Moon’s Dragon Claw and Meowscarada’s Play Rough. Tera Flying is the preferred Tera type for granting Paldean Tauros-F resistance to Fighting and an immunity to Ground while keeping its resistances to Bug and Grass intact, allowing it to check foes like Garchomp and Great Tusk. If opting to run Leftovers, Tera Flying also grants the benefit of an immunity to all entry hazards, apart from Stealth Rock, which becomes a more inconvenient weakness.

Paldean-F works well on many balance and bulky offense teams because of its solid defenses and lack of passivity. Due to its ability to check Dark-types like Roaring Moon and Kingambit, Paldean Tauros-F makes a great partner to Ghost-types like Dragapult and Gholdengo. In return, Dragapult can put pressure on Paldean Tauros-F’s checks, such as Dondozo and Garchomp, and Gholdengo checks status-spreading foes like Rotom-W and Toxapex. Water-types like Slowking and Greninja also appreciate Paldean Tauros-F checking Meowscarada and Breloom while countering offensive Water types like Quaquaval that can threaten Paldean Tauros-F. They can also help check Cinderace and Baxcalibur more reliably. If running Leftovers, hazard removal from allies like Corviknight and Great Tusk is appreciated. Corviknight is an especially good partner for its ability to hard counter offensive Ground-types like Great Tusk. Additionally, Great Tusk can pressure foes like Toxapex and Clodsire. Hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk can aid the offensive pressure Paldean Tauros-F can exert by making it more difficult to switch into a typical check like Toxapex or Dragapult. Great Tusk does this job well by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from foes like Slowking, while Ting-Lu can check foes like Dragapult, Iron Moth, and bulky Volcarona.

sets.name: Bulk Up (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: FIREFIGHTER (Defensive)
sets.description:
• Will-O-Wisp and Intimidate make Paldean Tauros-F a potent check to physical attackers, notably enabling it reliably check Chien-Pao and Kingambit.

  • Raging Bull: This provides a powerful STAB attack that can also break screens, allowing Paldean Tauros-F’s teammates to clean up more easily.

  • Body Press Body Press is valuable because unlike Close Combat, it doesn’t cause defense drops.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb allows Paldean Tauros-F to check Volcarona despite its meager Special Defense.

  • Bulk Up: While this set is unlikely to sweep, Bulk Up does give Paldean Tauros-F a good way to punish foes that attempt to sacrifice their Pokemon to it.

  • Tera Dependency - Very Situational: Paldean Tauros-F should generally avoid Terastallizing, as its typing is a big part of what lets it act as such a sturdy check to Kingambit and other massive threats, such as Baxcalibur.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry / Figy Berry: A quick burst of recovery from a berry fits playing this set a bit more recklessly.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This allows Paldean Tauros-F to switch around more freely in after entry hazards are set.

  • Rocky Helmet: Paldean Tauros-F tends to force a lot of switches, so Rocky Helmet lets it get some useful chip damage when switching into moves like Chien-Pao's Crunch.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a high value item that other Pokemon want, but the gradual recovery is useful.

sets.name: Offensive Screen Smasher
sets.description:
• Paldean Tauros-F is fast enough to outspeed key threats such as Mimikyu and Modest Chi-Yu, making an offensive set viable.

  • Raging Bull versus Flare Blitz: Raging Bull might not be as powerful as Flare Blitz, but its ability to break Reflect and Light Screen give Paldean Tauros-F a unique niche.

  • Flame Charge versus Trailblaze: Flame Charge gives Paldean Tauros-F an unexpected late-game win condition, letting it outspeed threats such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle. Trailblaze is often weaker, but the greater chip dagainst against Water-types such as Azumarill can be beneficial.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb's speed control is useful when sacrificing Paldean Tauros-F against a threat and prevents Dragonite from getting easy Speed boosts.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Despite this set's offensive nature, Will-O-Wisp is good for punishing Dragonite, Dragapult, and slower foes that may Terrastallize, such as Ting-Lu and Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Paldean Tauros-F makes major use of its unique typing defensively, so it only needs to Terastallize for situational win conditions.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type makes Paldean Tauros-F far less vulnerable to Rotom-W and Rotom-W, in addition to dealing with Focus Sash Breloom.

  • Fairy: When paired with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type means Dragonite will no longer wall Paldean Tauros-F without Teratsallizing itself.

Items

  • Eject Pack: With Close Combat, this will give Paldean Tauros-F a powerful, one-time use pivot option.

  • Life Orb: This high value item can be tough to slot in, but the increased power makes sweeping with a Speed boost much easier.

  • Mirror Herb: Mirror Herb punishes setup sweepers even more effectively and pairs especially well with Intimidate.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• With an Assault Vest, Paldean Tauros-F finds itself a niche checking Choice Band Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Iron Moth.

  • Raging Bull Despite Flare Blitz having more power, Raging Bull is Paldean Tauros-F's preferred STAB move as a result of its ability to break Aurora Veil, Reflect, and Light Screen, as well as the lack of recoil associated with the move.

  • Iron Head vs Stone Edge Iron Head is used because of its ability to hit foes that can Terastallize into Fairy-types, such as Dondozo and some Dragonite; it also provides a midground against Rock-types such as Garganacl and Tyranittar. It also is Paldean Tauros-F's best shot at OHKOing Flutter Mane without Terastallizing. However, Stone Edge can be used in lieu of it, as it is Tauros-F's best chance of defeating Iron Moth.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type allows Paldean Tauros-F to be immune to Acid Spray attempts from Iron Moth, as well as boosting the power of Iron Head. It also allows Paldean Tauros-B to defeat Flutter Mane more easily, as Flutter Mane would otherwise need lots of defensive investment to survive it.

  • Grass: Tera Grass prevents Azumarill's Liquidation from OHKOing Paldean Tauros-F, as well as providing a boost to Trailblaze.

  • Fire: Like Tera Steel, Tera Fire provides useful resistance to Fairy, notably Flutter Mane. It also allows Paldean Tauros-B to OHKO Flutter Mane that don't invest in bulk with Raging Bull.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 12 Atk / 76 Def / 36 SpD / 140 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread allows Paldean Tauros-B to defeat Flutter Mane with Trailblaze into Raging Bull. The Defense EVs allow it to beat Choice Band Chien-Pao after Intimidate one-on-one. The Speed investment allows Paldean Tauros-B to outpace Flutter Mane after Trailblaze.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Paldean Tauros-F secures a niche in AAA thanks to Desolate Land, which allows it to take advantage of its powerful STAB moves, decent Speed tier, and great Attack. Raging Bull is a consistent STAB option with no drawbacks, whereas Flare Blitz provides the power necessary to 2HKO particularly sturdy foes like Ting-Lu. Earthquake lets Paldean Tauros-F hit Skeledirge, which otherwise blanks it. Paldean Tauros-F is limited by its good but not great Speed tier and bulky Fire-resistant foes like Dondozo and Gyarados, so ways to deal with its offensive and defensive counterplay are important. Fast Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Iron Moth can force out foes like Kilowattrel and Sandy Shocks. Speed control via Thunder Wave from allies like Blissey and Scream Tail is useful in deterring faster foes like Greninja. Electric-types like Rotom-W and Kilowattrel can consistently force out the sturdy Water-types that threaten Paldean Tauros-F while bringing it in on their switch-ins like Roaring Moon and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This set is currently in copyediting. It can be found here.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Mega Gyarados is a powerful sweeper on hyper offense teams thanks to Dragon Dance, Mold Breaker, and its high Attack stat. Mega Gyarados also possesses a valuable defensive typing that helps against foes such as Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Kingambit. Mold Breaker lets Mega Gyarados break through foes such as Tera Fairy Gastrodon and Skeledirge, the latter being a troublesome foe for teammates such as Dragonite and Dragapult. Substitute allows Mega Gyarados to avoid status from foes such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W while also avoiding revenge killers such as Tapu Lele and Kartana. Alternatively, Earthquake lets Mega Gyarados break through Toxapex and Rotom-W. Taunt can also be used to deny recovery, Haze, and Iron Defense from Toxapex and Skarmory, though it is generally not preferred since it leaves Mega Gyarados vulnerable to Scald burns and revenge killers such as Tapu Lele. Mega Gyarados appreciates dual screen support from Tapu Koko, which allows it to set up more easily. In return, Mega Gyarados can pivot into Ground-type attacks from foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Mega Gyarados struggles against physical walls such as Skarmory, Ferrothorn, and Buzzwole, so it appreciates teammates such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant handling them. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Landorus-T and Glimmora helps weaken defensive foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Water Landorus-T for Mega Gyarados. Teammates such as Dragonite also appreciate Mega Gyarados weakening defensive foes such as Skeledirge and Ferrothorn so it can clean late-game.

sets.name: Defensive Dragon Dance (Flying)
sets.description:
Outspeeds Great Tusk at +1, OHKO'es Flutter Mane with Waterfall at +1, 3HKO'ed by Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Rocky Helmet
sets.description:
• Gyarados utilizes its unique typing alongside Rocky Helmet to cushion physical sweepers such as Scizor, Great Tusk and Palafin.

  • Taunt: Taunt forces foes such as Corviknight and Dondozo to attack Gyarados, constraining them to take Rocky Helmet chip while often dealing minimal damage themselves.

  • Waterfall versus Iron Head: Waterfall provides Gyarados with a reliable STAB move, but Iron Head works better with Thunder Wave thanks to its higher flinch chance. They can be run together, though usually at the cost of overall coverage.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake checks several common Gyarados switch-ins, such as Iron Hands and Magnezone.

  • Ice Fang: Ice Fang hits bulky Dragon-types such as Dragonite that otherwise can withstand attacks from Gyarados.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave combined with flinch moves like Waterfall and Iron Head can shut down foes for several turns at a time. It can also catch foes switching into Gyarados, though keep in mind that many prominent Gyarados checks are naturally immune.

  • EV Spread: This spread allows Gyarados to survive two unboosted Moonblasts from Flutter Mane and minimizes Stealth Rock chip. The Speed investment outspeeds 4 Speed Rotom formes and, when using Thunder Wave, outspeeds paralyzed Speed-boosting nature Dragapult.

Other Options

  • Dragon Dance: Rocky Helmet sets can still opt to utilize Dragon Dance for more offensive presence, but this usually involves cutting bulk to invest in Attack and Speed.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Gyarados has uses for Terastallization, losing its unique defensive typing jeopardizes its Rocky Helmet niche and makes it much harder to check its key targets. Terastallization must be timed properly if Gyarados is to get proper value out of it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel powers up Iron Head to more serviceable levels and makes it easier to OHKO bulky Flutter Mane.

  • Ground: Tera Ground prevents Gyarados from getting dismantled by its 4x Electric-type weakness and provides a sizable power boost to Earthquake.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Gyarados's high Attack and good coverage make it a dangerous sweeper with Dragon Dance and Moxie. Bounce must be used alongside Flyinium Z to cleave through would-be counters in Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth as well as Buzzwole. Even checks that aren't weak to Flying, like Latios, Latias, and Tapu Fini, are often taken out after one to two boosts. Ice Fang is an alternative if Gyarados isn't running Flyinium Z, providing it with the means to threaten Grass- and Dragon-types. Life Orb should be held if Gyarados isn't using Bounce, helping Gyarados OHKO foes such as Serperior with +1 Ice Fang and Tapu Fini with +1 Power Whip. Substitute can be used to take advantage of Pokemon that struggle to threaten Gyarados outside of status, like Mega Sableye. Power Whip is an alternative to threaten Water-types like Slowbro, Quagsire, and Tapu Fini, which it otherwise struggles to break through if it doesn't have access to Supersonic Skystrike. Gyarados best fits on offense teams, enjoying being paired with other sweepers like Iron Hands and Swords Dance Scizor. It supports these physical attackers by luring in and KOing common physical walls such as Buzzwole and Tangrowth with Supersonic Skystrike. Gyarados lacks the means to break through certain physical walls like Skarmory, and based on its choice of coverage it will lack the means to break through certain foes like Tangrowth and Iron Hands, making special attackers like Latios and Galarian Moltres important partners. In return, it can take advantage of some of Steel-types they tend to get picked off by like Celesteela and Scizor. Hazard support, notably from dedicated leads such as Mew and Excadrill, is very useful for chipping Gyarados's checks like Iron Hands and Choice Scarf Latias into KO range of its attacks. Conversely, Gyarados's Stealth Rock weakness means it greatly appreciates partners that can remove them or stop them from being set up, like Iron Treads and the aforementioned Mew and Excadrill. Grimmsnarl is another notable partner, as its dual screens support gives Gyarados a much easier time setting up.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Ditto is a niche revenge killer in Anything Goes that can handle some strong setup sweepers like Swords Dance Koraidon, non-Double Dance Miraidon, Iron Moth, Gholdengo, and others like Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Iron Bundle once they are weakened. From there, it can attempt a reverse sweep. Ditto's EVs and IVs minimize Speed and maximize bulk: this helps against opposing Ditto by triggering its own Imposter latest to make the foe run out of PP first, as well as minimizing Struggle damage. Tera Fairy elevates Ditto against a Choice Scarf Miraidon or Koraidon that will likely attack Ditto with a Dragon-type move. Ditto eases the pressure on the defensive backbone of a team by revenge killing some common threats, so it is advised to fit more offensive wallbreakers on the team like Chien-Pao, Miraidon, Koraidon, and Iron Bundle. However, Ditto still fails to revenge kill bulkier sweepers like Double Dance Miraidon, Bulk Up Koraidon and Great Tusk, and Quark Drive and Protosynthesis users like Iron Valiant, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane. Additionally, most sweepers can take advantage of Ditto with a surprise Terastallization, such as Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Fairy Miraidon, and Tera Water Gholdengo. Thus, backup checks to them like defensive Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, Clodsire, Alomomola, and Toxapex are appreciated. These teammates additionally check wallbreakers like Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Ditto is a niche revenge killer that can also be used to attempt a reverse sweep, but it must be wary of threats that may counter it with a surprise Terastallization, such as Tera Fairy Miraidon, Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Ice Iron Bundle, and Tera Water Gholdengo.
  • Ditto doesn't add much value to teams on its own outside of helping overwhelm opposing checks. It is also strongly prediction reliant.
  • Maximum bulk and minimum Speed allow Ditto to force opposing Ditto to trigger Imposter first and run out of PP quicker.
  • Tera Fairy defeats Choice Scarf Miraidon, Koraidon, and Walking Wake that may try to attack it with a Dragon-type move.
  • Ditto is rarely a reliable check for reasons explained earlier, so it appreciates support from backup checks, especially for potent threats that it fails to revenge kill such as Swords Dance Chien-Pao, Double Dance Miraidon, and Bulk Up Great Tusk. Thus, teammates like Toxapex, Skeledirge, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads are good picks.
  • Ditto's ability to revenge kill many strong threats makes teambuilding flexible, allowing offensive Pokemon like Miraidon, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Koraidon to fit more easily.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description: Tera Steel makes Ditto immune to Toxic Spikes and take less from Stealth Rock. It also lets Ditto revenge kill Belly Drum Hariyama. A Quiet nature and the Special Attack investment is in case Ditto transforms into a Future Sight user like Slowbro.

sets.name: Choice Scarf Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Thanks to Ditto's signature ability Imposter, which also copies enemy stat changes, Ditto is one of the best revenge killers in the tier. Ditto's presence alone scares off sweepers like Baxcalibur and Azumarill from setting up. Ditto does not copy the enemy HP stat, so 248 HP EVs are used to minimize damage taken from entry hazards before transforming while maximizing Ditto's HP stat, as well as allowing Ditto to use Struggle 4 times before it faints. 252 Defense EVs minimize the damage Ditto takes from opposing Ditto in the extremely rare mirror matchup. Finally, a Relaxed nature coupled with 0 Speed IVs guarantees that Imposter will never activate first, which ensures that Ditto will have more Transform PP in the aforementioned mirror match.

Ursaluna is a great teammate for Ditto, as it can switch into walls and begin applying immediate pressure. Ditto also appreciates Ursaluna's unrivaled ability to punch holes in the opposing team, making a late-game Ditto sweep much easier. If Ditto copies certain targets like Chien-Pao and a majority of the opposing team is weakened, Ditto can win the game. Indeedee is a good teammate for Ditto, as its Psychic Surge ability prevents Ditto from being picked off by priority moves. Blissey is a nice partner for Ditto, as it can absorb status moves that would otherwise cripple Ditto and then shrug them off via Natural Cure. Blissey can also use Thunder Wave to slow down opposing Choice Scarf users that would otherwise Speed tie with Ditto such as Meowscarada and Enamorus Choice Specs Hisuian Zoroark is a powerful teammate that pairs well with Ditto, as Ditto can copy the stat boosts from setup sweepers that aim to take advantage of a Choice-locked Hisuian Zoroark. Cyclizar can be used to remove entry hazards so that Ditto can switch in frequently without getting chipped. Additionally, it is able to keep hazards away and use Shed Tail to bring Ditto in behind a Substitute and make it even more threatening. Maushold can use its high speed tier to lock Bulk Up users like Landorus-Therian that would otherwise be able to stall out Ditto. Additionally, Maushold is able to break down walls due to the sheer power of Population Bomb. Pivots are great teammates for Ditto because they can lure in targets for Ditto to copy. Choice Scarf Staraptor and Defensive Braviary are solid picks, as they can use U-turn to go right into Ditto. Braviary is also capable of using Defog to keep Ditto alive for longer.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
• Ditto is widely hailed as the best revenge killer and finds a small niche with a Choice Scarf.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Ditto rarely needs to Terastallize unless it is being threatened by Dragon Dance Dragonite's Extreme Speed at +3.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Ditto immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed, preventing it from defeating Ditto after three Dragon Dances.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: The safest option, Choice Scarf guarantees that Ditto will always outspeed the foe unless said foe is holding a Choice Scarf.
  • Focus Sash: A high-risk yet high-reward option, Focus Sash allows Ditto to switch moves at the cost of being nullified by entry hazards. However, it should be noted that Imposter doesn't copy Protosynthesis or Quark Drive boosts, making Focus Sash a lot less niche, as it allows Ditto to beat foes such as Flutter Mane more consistently assuming the field is clear of hazards.

EV Spreads

  • Effort Values: The given EVs maximize Ditto's bulk in the rare case of a mirror matchup.
  • Individual Values: 0 Speed IVs and a minus Speed nature is key to beating opposing Ditto, as the Ditto that moves last on the fourth turn will win the mirror.

sets.name: Scarf Imposter
sets.description: Ditto solidifies itself to once again be the goo that holds balanced and offensive Normal teams together thanks to its incredibly strong ability in Imposter. Reversing the momentum of fast offensive threats such as Iron Valiant, Mega Charizard X, and Excadrill allows Ditto to force counterplay against offensive teams. Ditto can also take advantage of entry hazard setters and removers, such as Ferrothorn, Kleavor, and Zapdos, using their own longevity or utility against them. In order to take advantage of Pokémon that use either Return or Frustration, such as Mega Altaria or Mega Pinsir, Ditto likes to run 128 Happiness instead of 252 or 0. Walls like Blissey and Porygon2 appreciate Ditto being able to prevent threats such as Baxcalibur and Spectrier from using them as setup fodder, while Ditto appreciates both defensive switch-ins and slow pivots via their use of Teleport. Mega Lopunny is a staple on Normal teams that accents Ditto's role expertly; many of the offensive threats and setup sweepers that revenge kill Mega Lopunny, such as Mega Charizard X, Kommo-o, and Galarian Moltres, are usually very weak to their own sets or coverage. Mega Lopunny can lure a threat in and pivot with U-turn, allowing Ditto to come in safely and transform. Ditto appreciates Mega Lopunny's Speed tier and fast pivot with U-turn, as well as potentially setting up Ditto with Encore Sets to stop foes from using Substitute or setting up completely. Hisuian Zoroark makes for another stellar teammate for Ditto, as Hisuian Zoroark disguised as a passive Pokemon, such as Blissey, or another offensive threat, such as Diggersby or Mega Lopunny, can lead to Hisuian Zoroark wallbreaking and netting KOs on vital foes, making it easier for Ditto to sweep once it has transformed. While Ditto is immune to Sticky Web, it is susceptible to other hazards such as Stealth Rock and Toxic Spikes, so forms of hazard control such as Staraptor or Cyclizar are appreciated. Staraptor is another defensive option, while Cyclizar can enable Ditto to utilize Transform with a Substitute from Shed Tail. Smeargle on more offense-oriented teams' pairs well with Ditto, as Smeargle can set hazards with Stone Axe or Ceaseless Edge and spread status with Nuzzle, Mortal Spin, or Spore, allowing Ditto to exploit the opposing team easier. Smeargle will usually give up Sticky Web when paired with Ditto so as to not hinder Ditto's revenge killing prowess.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
248 HP EVs ensure that Ditto will be able to use Struggle four times before fainting, and 252 Defense EVs minimize Struggle damage from an opposing Ditto. The minimum possible Speed allows Imposter to not activate first and therefore allow Ditto to have more Transform PP.

This is a sample set, stay tuned for future updates!

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Articuno solidifies itself as a top tier special wall in NU, thanks to its ability to take on scary wallbreakers such as Abomasnow, Clawitzer, and Appletun that can tear through slower teams. Haze helps stop setup sweepers like Farigiraf, Mesprit, and Lilligant, but Hurricane can be used to hit Pokemon like Appletun, Abomasnow, and Cryogonal harder while also helping against Fighting-types such as Hiusian Sneasel and Toxicroak in a pinch. U-turn lets Articuno pivot on incoming Ice-resistant foes like Magneton and Cryogonal while also generating momentum for offensive teammates on the switches Articuno can force against the bevy of Grass-, Water-, and Fighting-types in the tier. The given EV spread allows Articuno to outspeed maximum Speed Cacturne and Ursaring while maintaining as much special bulk as possible. Tera Ground gifts an Electric-type immunity, letting Articuno easily handle Rotom and Eelektross, and it gets a Stealth Rock resistance, which helps Articuno if it gets hit by a Knock Off; Tera Steel helps against setup sweepers such as Mesprit, Lilligant, and Farigiraf so that Articuno can use Haze without fear of being OHKOed; and Tera Fairy can be used to take care of Fighting-types which overwhelm it otherwise with their powerful STAB moves.

Articuno easily falters in the face of physical wallbreakers like Mabosstiff, Medicham, and Tauros, so Pokemon like Sandaconda, Sableye, and Mesprit to check them pair well with Articuno as they love a partner to tank special attacks. Electric-types like Magneton, Eelektross, and Rotom tend to overpower Articuno; therefore, partners like Appletun, Lurantis, and Eelektross pair well alongside it. Item displacement from Knock Off or Trick is very detrimental for Articuno’s longevity. To combat this, Knock Off absorbers like Sandaconda and Sticky Hold Muk work well to help it. Entry hazard support from Hattrem, Drifblim, and Lurantis also helps Articuno if it happens to lose its item. Wallbreakers such as Samurott, Bruxish, and Pyroar work well alongside Articuno, as it can take care of their checks like Cacturne, Appletun, and Qwilfish. Because Articuno beats Ground- and Grass-types, Electric-types pair well as partners, as they can create a VoltTurn core and whittle down each other’s checks.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Flying)
sets.description:
Outspeeds uninvested Landorus-T. An alternative spread of 240 HP / 84 SpD / 184 Spe lets Articuno never 2HKO'ed by Greninja and lets it outspeed Pelipper.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Zapdos's excellent typing and gargantuan stats make it one of the most consistent offensive Pokemon in the metagame. Its typing is amazing offensively, making it an Electric-type that can threaten Great Tusk and Landorus-T. Its great defensive stats let it take hits from the likes of Zamazenta and Gholdengo in a pinch. Roost further boosts this defensive capability, giving Zapdos longevity. Volt Switch is essential for maintaining offensive momentum against Pokemon that Zapdos otherwise struggles with such as Galarian Slowking. Heat Wave heavily pressures Steel-types such as Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Iron Treads. Tera Electric further boosts Zapdos's Thunderbolt's power, notably giving it odds to 2HKO pivot Galarian Slowking and Zamazenta. Alternatively, Tera Steel gives Zapdos extra defensive utility, letting it take Fairy-type attacks and more easily fish for paralysis from Static, while the Poison immunity lets Zapdos more easily switch into Pokemon like Toxapex.

Offensive Zapdos fits best on offense and bulky offense teams looking for a consistent, strong special attacker. Entry hazards from the likes of Great Tusk, Heatran, and Garganacl are heavily appreciated by Zapdos, as the chip damage is essential in helping Zapdos overwhelm common checks to it such as Landorus-T, Galarian Slowking, and Iron Treads. Garganacl also appreciates Zapdos being able to switch in on Ground- and Fighting-type moves from Pokemon like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Landorus-T. Thanks to STAB Thunder and Hurricane, Zapdos is a natural fit on rain teams to threaten out bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo that rain otherwise struggles with. Pelipper also doubles as a slow pivot, letting Zapdos come in without taking any damage. Other offensive Pokemon like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Kingambit heavily appreciate Zapdos's pivoting and ability to threaten common bulky Pokemon like Great Tusk and Toxapex. Dragapult, in particular, can form a potent VoltTurn core with Zapdos, hitting specially defensive Pokemon like Galarian Slowking and Clodsire for solid damage while appreciating Zapdos forcing out Pokemon like Toxapex and Corviknight. Gholdengo is another excellent offensive teammate, being able to deal with Pokemon like Galarian Slowking and Clodsire that Zapdos otherwise struggles with.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Zapdos is one of the best defensive pivots in the metagame due to its bulk and typing, which allow it to check and force out threats such as Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Hisuian Samurott. Additionally, its excellent offensive presence lets it generate momentum for its team with Volt Switch, which is quite difficult to block due to Zapdos's ability to nail Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Landorus-T with a powerful Hurricane. Heat Wave 2HKOes Iron Treads, which otherwise blocks Volt Swich with impunity, and it pressures other Steel-types such as Kingambit and Gholdengo. Discharge is an option over Volt Switch or Heat Wave as an Electric-type attack that doesn't force Zapdos out, allowing it to fish for paralysis against Pokemon such as Heatran and Dragonite. Zapdos can also opt to use U-turn alongside Discharge for unblockable pivoting, which is particularly useful against Ground-types that don't fear Hurricane such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire, but it usually prefers the power and role compression of Volt Switch. Thunder Wave is another option that reliably paralyzes opposing Pokemon but makes Zapdos significantly more passive. The given EV spread allows Zapdos to outspeed Great Tusk. A more defensive spread of 248 HP / 240 Def / 20 Spe with a Bold nature sacrifices Zapdos's ability to outspeed key threats, such as Great Tusk and Gholdengo, but makes it a much more formidable wall; for example, this spread avoids the 2HKO from Great Tusk's Ice Spinner and is likely to avoid the OHKO from +2 Sneasler's Gunk Shot. Static is the preferred ability to punish physical attackers such as Great Tusk and Sneasler; however, Pressure can be used to allow Zapdos stall out low-PP moves such as Great Tusk's Close Combat, Dragapult's Draco Meteor, and Heatran's Magma Storm. Tera Steel helps Zapdos check many common sweepers in a pinch, most notably letting it take Fairy-, Ice-, and Poison-type attacks from Iron Valiant, Enamorus, Alolan Ninetales, and Sneasler. Tera Fairy is another strong option that improves Zapdos's matchup against dangerous Dark- and Dragon-types, such as Kingambit, Hisuian Samurott, Dragapult, and Walking Wake, while maintaining its Fighting-type resistance.

Zapdos is an excellent fit on bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to keep dangerous sweepers in check and pivot powerful offensive threats into play. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Hisuian Samurott can make it much harder for Pokemon such as Heatran and Ting-Lu to continuously check Zapdos. Great Tusk is a particularly good partner that can also threaten Zapdos's switch-ins, such as Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Galarian Slowking, and remove Stealth Rock if Zapdos loses its Heavy-Duty Boots. Gholdengo handles offensive threats that may overwhelm Zapdos, such as Sneasler and Iron Valiant, while Zapdos covers it against Great Tusk and Hisuian Samurott. Setup sweepers such as Kingambit and Iron Valiant can make great use of Zapdos's ability to generate free turns by pivoting them into play and spreading paralysis; Kingambit especially has brilliant synergy with Zapdos, taking on Galarian Slowking, Garganacl, and Clodsire, while Zapdos handles Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Dondozo. Similarly, Zapdos can provide free entry for powerful wallbreakers such as Volcanion, Hoopa-U, Dragapult, and Heatran.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Electric)
sets.description:
Choice Specs Zapdos is a potent wallbreaker for Electric teams, being able to threaten Pokemon that give its teammates a hard time such as Great Tusk, Gastrodon, specially defensive Iron Treads, and Landorus-T. Aside from that, its Flying typing provides Electric teams an immunity to Ground and a resistance to Fighting. Hurricane is Zapdos's strongest STAB move, being able to OHKO Sableye, Amoonguss, and possibly Quagsire, and also being able to 2HKO physically defensive Skeledirge and Ursaluna. Zapdos can also take advantage of matchups against rain teams by being able to spam Hurricane without fear of missing. Volt Switch allows Zapdos to bring in teammates safely against special walls like Assault Vest Iron Hands, Assault Vest Galarian Slowking, and Heatran. Heat Wave provides Zapdos great coverage, allowing it to 2HKO Magnezone, as well as Klefki under Light Screen and Iron Treads. Static has a chance to paralyze Pokemon that make contact with Zapdos such as Dragonite and Mimikyu.

Sandy Shocks makes for a great partner, being able to provide entry hazard support with both Stealth Rock and Spikes, as well as being able to threaten Heatran with Earth Power. Regieleki is another great partner, as it is able to remove hazards with Rapid Spin so that Zapdos can switch in more often without losing a good amount of its health to Stealth Rock. It is also able to outspeed Pokemon that outspeed Zapdos such as Flutter Mane and non-Choice Scarf Greninja. Pokemon with great special bulk such as Assault Vest Galarian Slowking and Tyranitar can be tough for Zapdos, with the latter being able to threaten it with Stone Edge. Hence, Iron Hands pairs well with Zapdos, as it is able to threaten Galarian Slowking with Earthquake and Tyranitar with Drain Punch. In return, Zapdos can switch into anticipated Ground-type attacks from the likes of Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Magnezone is another great partner, being able to threaten Hatterene and Flutter Mane, as well as potentially winning the Chien-Pao matchup. Lastly, Zapdos's wallbreaking opens up sweeping opportunities for fast sweepers such as Nasty Plot Rotom-W and Choice Scarf Pawmot. Both of them can beat Landorus-T with Hydro Pump and Ice Punch, respectively, and Pawmot has the added merit of potentially reviving Zapdos with Revival Blessing.

sets.name: SubRoost (Electric)
sets.description:
Substitute isnt broken by Toxapex's moves. 100 SpA EVs may be considered to increase bulk and always OHKO Urshifu-R.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Zapdos, with its solid defensive typing and strong Special Attack, is a potent pivot that is able to check Corviknight, Galarian Zapdos, and Talonflame, as well as potent offensive Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge thanks to Primordial Sea. Primordial Sea also enables Zapdos to spam its strong STAB moves in Hurricane and Thunder, which allow it to OHKO offensive threats such as Meowscarada, Quaquaval, and Talonflame; Zapdos also pressures common RegenVest users like Meloetta with U-turn. Zapdos can opt to go for a more bulky spread of 252 HP / 4 SpA / 252 Spe to better check strong Fighting-types like Slither Wing and Galarian Zapdos. Zapdos is a good partner for offensive Pokemon like Slither Wing, Meowscarada, and Zamazenta-C, as it can bait in targets like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta that they can take advantage of. Zapdos also pairs well with Corviknight, as Primordial Sea's Fire immunity allows Corviknight to run more physically defensive abilities such as Fluffy and Intimidate. Zapdos can struggle against bulky Ground-types like Regenerator Garchomp and Landorus-T, so pairing it with an attacker like Chien-Pao is recommended.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Thanks to Zapdos’s great typing and strong offensive presence, few Pokemon aside from specially defensive walls such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire would want to switch into it. Volt Switch wears down common switch-ins such as Blissey, Heatran, Rotom-W, and Mega Tyranitar, bringing in teammates that punish them like Zamazenta and Kartana. Alternatively, Defog can clear away entry hazards set by Landorus-T and Great Tusk, though Zapdos sets lacking Heavy-Duty Boots struggle to reliably remove hazards. It also misses out on pivoting provided by Volt Switch. Static punishes contact attackers and pivots like Zamazenta, Tornadus-T, Mega Scizor, and Mega Lopunny. If not running Flyinium Z, Tera Flying lets Zapdos break past Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon with relative ease, all while still threatening Pokemon like Annihilape. Flyinium Z allows Zapdos to muscle through the likes of Annihilape and Gastrodon. The given EV spread allows Zapdos to OHKO Annihilape with Supersonic Skystrike. Teammates like Kingambit, Heatran, and Mega Lopunny appreciate Zapdos putting pressure on their checks, as it threatens Pokemon like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Toxapex. Without Heavy-Duty Boots, Zapdos is very susceptible to Stealth Rock. As such, entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Rotom-W are much appreciated. Wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Garchomp help deal with Zapdos checks such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. Mega Scizor is a notable partner for Zapdos, as it checks strong, offensive threats such as Mega Diancie and Mega Lopunny, absorbs poison for Zapdos, and forms a good pivoting core with it.

sets.name: Rain
sets.description: Zapdos in rain is a dangerous attacker due to it boosting Hurricane and Thunder’s accuracy, as well as destroying common rain checks like Rotom-W, Ferrothorn, and Tangrowth. Weather Ball under rain allows Zapdos to hit Landorus-T, Clodsire, and Heatran super effectively. Roost allows it to stay healthy throughout the game and consistently be able to check Grass-types like Kartana. Tera Flying allows Zapdos to break through Ferrothorn and Gastrodon after slight chip damage. The given EVs allow Zapdos to outspeed Great Tusk while also maximizing its offensive power to break foes such as Rotom-W, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon. Pelipper is a mandatory partner for Zapdos, as it sets up rain and can safely pivot out to it. Ferrothorn checks foes such as Weavile and Mega Tyranitar while also setting entry hazards to weaken foes such as Heatran and opposing Ferrothorn. Additionally, Swift Swim Pokemon like Mega Swampert, Floatzel, and Barraskewda can help with Clodsire and Mega Tyranitar, which Zapdos struggles to break through. In return, Zapdos wears down Pokemon that the aforementioned rain wallbreakers would struggle with, such as Ferrothorn, Rotom-W, and Gastrodon, clearing the path for them to clean up after their checks are weakened.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Leveraging an incredible ability in Static accompanied by a powerful Volt Switch and Hurricane, Zapdos serves as a stellar defensive pivot. Zapdos effectively switches into physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, Kartana, and Great Tusk, discouraging them from attacking by threatening a chance of paralysis. Zapdos can Volt Switch out as it pleases because of common Ground-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and the aforementioned Great Tusk fearing its powerful Hurricane. Hidden Power Ice can be used to threaten Ground-types like the aforementioned Landorus-T and Garchomp while additionally hitting Gliscor harder and much more reliably than Hurricane. Carrying Heat Wave is recommended with Hidden Power Ice to maintain the ability to OHKO Kartana. These positive matchups into many Ground-types allow Zapdos to serve as a solid Defog user, but it struggles to beat bulkier Stealth Rock users such as Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, and Clodsire. Alternatively, Zapdos can forgo Defog for Heat Wave, allowing it to threaten Pokemon such as Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo. Tera Steel is utilized by Zapdos to flip its Rock- and Ice-type weaknesses versus Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar, Weavile, and Mega Diancie as well as check Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele in a pinch. However, it becomes weak to common Ground- and Fighting-type moves from Pokemon it wants to check. Teammates that appreciate the spread of paralysis, such as Mega Medicham, Urshifu-R, and Weavile, naturally pair well with Zapdos. Mega Medicham particularly pairs nicely with it, as Mega Medicham threatens Clodsire while enjoying Zapdos pivoting it into favorable matchups such as Heatran, with Zapdos punishing Tornadus-T and Mega Lopunny looking to revenge kill Mega Medicham in return. Pursuit users like Kingambit and the aforementioned Weavile are useful teammates to assist in chipping down Clodsire as well as punishing Dragapult. Rock-types like Mega Diancie and Mega Tyranitar threaten Zapdos, so teammates that mitigate these weaknesses, like Hippowdon and Gastrodon, are appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Electric)
sets.description: With Choice Specs equipped, Zapdos's already amazing Special Attack is boosted to even greater heights, turning it into an incredible wallbreaker. Its Flying typing also grants an invaluable Ground immunity for Electric teams. Hurricane is Zapdos's most powerful move, threatening a variety of Pokemon that resist or are immune to Electric such as Mega Venusaur and Gastrodon. Heat Wave beats Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Iron Treads, and Ferrothorn, thus making it an incredible asset in the Steel and Grass matchups. Hidden Power Ice cleanly OHKOes Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp; alternatively, Hidden Power Grass can be used if reliably eliminating Gastrodon and Swampert is more important. Volt Switch lets Zapdos switch out of its checks like Tyranitar and Blissey, keeping momentum in favor of Zapdos's team. As dangerous as Zapdos is, it is highly susceptible to Stealth Rock; hence, Rotom-W is a great partner that can use Defog while also helping Zapdos beat Ground-types thanks to Hydro Pump. Iron Hands and Zeraora help Zapdos wallbreak by wearing down special walls like Heatran, Blissey, and Clodsire. Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can take advantage of Zapdos weakening teams and removing Ground-types so that they can clean up with their deadly Rising Voltage later in the game.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Galarian Zapdos is a fearsome wallbreaker that can overwhelm common defensive cores. Close Combat and Brave Bird have fantastic neutral coverage and power, OHKOing virtually everything short of a physical wall and 2HKOing those, further amplified by Choice Band. Thunderous Kick overpowers some of its few checks like Fluffy Corviknight, which could otherwise stall it out. Adamant is the preferred nature to have a high chance to 2HKO Intimidate Corviknight after Leftovers recovery, but Jolly is an option to Speed tie Zapdos and outspeed Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Galarian Zapdos pairs exceptionally well with special pivots like Hisuian Electrode and Kilowattrel, as they can draw in special walls like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta for it. Fast physical cleaners like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada appreciate Galarian Zapdos blowing through physical walls for them. Since Galarian Zapdos is prone to Stealth Rock, opposing Rocky Helmet, and Brave Bird recoil wearing it down, it appreciates pivots like Iron Treads and Corviknight that can also clear Stealth Rock and Wish passers like Scream Tail. Galarian Zapdos is relatively slow and easily revenge killed, so it relies on a sturdy defensive core like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra to switch out to.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Galarian Zapdos serves as a potent physical threat that can either wear down and outlast its checks with U-turn or set up and serve as an excellent wincon with Bulk Up or Agility. U-turn allows Galarian Zapdos to maintain momentum in face of switch-ins like Fluffy Corviknight, while Taunt allows Galarian Zapdos to deny defensive walls recovery and outlast them. Bulk Up provides immediate wallbreaking power, while Agility allows Galarian Zapdos to outpace would-be revenge killers; Adamant is the preferred nature on Agility sets. Offensive special threats like Refridgerate Regieleki and Primordial Sea Inteleon serve well as teammates, appreciating Galarian Zapdos's ability to threaten special walls like Hisuian Goodra while also threatening Galarian Zapdos's own checks like Fluffy Corviknight and Zapdos, both able to pivot on their respective walls to create opportunities to wallbreak or accumulate entry hazard chip. Fast physical threats like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada also serve well as teammates to pressure and overload physical walls as well as handle faster offensive threats that Galarian Zapdos cannot. Galarian Zapdos also partners well with defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest Meloetta which can safely pivot Galarian Zapdos in. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp that help wear down its help wear down Galarian Zapdos's checks and can take hits from faster offensive Pokemon; alternatively, Galarian Zapdos can partner well with dual screens support from the likes of Prankster Mew and Corviknight to help facilitate setup sets.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Thanks to its natural bulk, typing, and Flame Body, physically defensive Moltres can threaten crippling burns to most physical attackers in the tier and force out threats such as Kingambit, Zamazenta, Swords Dance Iron Valiant, Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and Sneasler. Moltres gets many free turns over the course of a game thanks to the many Pokemon it forces out, which makes U-turn a fantastic tool for pivoting and gaining momentum while also ensuring that Moltres is not passive against Pokemon such as Heatran and Ting-Lu. Hurricane is an alternative that can OHKO Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Sneasler and 2HKO Zamazenta. 12 Speed EVs allows Moltres to outspeed Jolly Kingambit. Tera Fairy removes all of Moltres' previous weaknesses and strengthen its matchup against Kingambit and Roaring Moon. Alternatively, Tera Water is a solid defensive type that also improves Moltres's rain matchup allowing it to live rain-boosted Tera Water Wave Crash from Floatzel and Basculegion and be able to threaten them back with Will-O-Wisp. 248 Special Defense EVs with a Calm nature can be used instead of the Defense investment and Bold nature to more comfortably take on Enamorus and most special Iron Valiant sets. Great Tusk can form a good core with Moltres thanks to Great Tusk's ability to threaten Moltres's switch-ins, such as Garganacl, Ting-Lu, Galarian Slowking, and Heatran, and remove Stealth Rock if Moltres loses its Heavy-Duty Boots. Ting-Lu can take advantage of Moltres's switch-ins such as Zapdos, Dragapult, and Iron Moth to lay entry hazards while Moltres covers it against Fighting- and Fairy-types such as Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Sneasler. Similarly, Gholdengo handles offensive threats that may overwhelm Moltres, such as pivot Sneasler and Iron Valiant, while Moltres covers it against Cinderace and Kingambit. Setup sweepers such as Kingambit and Iron Valiant can make great use of Moltres's ability to generate free turns by pivoting them into play and spreading burn for easier setup.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Flying)
sets.description:
Brave Bird with a specially defensive spread may be considered if Spectrier is an issue to the team, but a physically defensive spread lets it be a check to Chien-Pao.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Moltres’s main niche comes from its variety of useful qualities making it a prominent defensive Pokemon. It is a defogger that can threaten Gholdengo; a check to common Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk, Heatran, and Garchomp; and a deterrent to contact attackers like U-turn users, Kartana, and Mega Lopunny. However, its main weakness lies in its overreliance on its Heavy-Duty Boots—although Tera could let it drop its weakness to Rock, Tera is usually better spent on other Pokemon, so Moltres still fears Knock Off from opponents it would otherwise check, like Iron Valiant, Landorus-T, Kartana, and Mega Scizor. Tera Water is used to ease the matchup against rain, becoming a check to common rain abusers like Basculegion-M, Mega Swampert and Barraskewda and threatening to burn them with Flame Body. Tera Ground instead grants a resistance to Stealth Rock and Stone Edge from Choice Scarf Landorus-T and an immunity to Volt Switch from Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Rotom-W and Thunderbolt from Iron Valiant. Mystical Fire is chosen over Flamethrower, as its Special Attack drop is useful to more easily check Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Charizard Y, and Gholdengo. Scorching Sands is used to beat Heatran and also deter physical attackers looking to set up due to its high burn chance. Hurricane allows Moltres to OHKO Great Tusk and Mega Lopunny while heavily denting Volcarona and is useful in general as a powerful STAB option, U-turn allows Moltres to function as a pivot, pivoting out on foes like Heatran and Garganacl, and Toxic allows Moltres to punish Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp looking to soak up its STAB options. The given EVs allow Moltres to survive two Frustration from Mega Lopunny without Stealth Rock damage. However, there are still many opponents that can pressure Moltres, like Garganacl, Toxapex, and Tapu Koko. Moltres thus pairs well with wallbreakers that can take advantage of such switch-ins to come in, like Tapu Lele or Iron Valiant. Moltres also dislikes having its Heavy-Duty Boots removed, so teammates that can absorb Knock Off are appreciated, including Mega Scizor and Gliscor.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description: Galarian Moltres is a terrifying sweeper due to its access to both Nasty Plot and Agility as well as a near-unresisted STAB combination. After one Nasty Plot boost, it can 2HKO the likes of Assault Vest Galarian Slowking and Curse Garganacl, and after one Agility boost, it can outspeed would-be faster Pokemon such as +1 Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and +1 Walking Wake. Tera Blast Fairy lets it OHKO the likes of Baxcalibur and Hoopa-U while also being able to net 2HKOs on Kingambit, Assault Vest Hoopa-U, and Dragonite, all after one Nasty Plot boost. Tera Fairy also maintains its Dark resistance while letting it potentially set up in the face of Dragon-type attacks from foes like Dragapult and Baxcalibur. Alternatively, Hurricane is a strong neutral STAB move that prevents Galarian Moltres form relying too much on Terastallization to function. Tera Dark boosts Fiery Wrath's power, being able to OHKO Assault Vest Galarian Slowking after a Nasty Plot boost and Stealth Rock damage, as well as being able to 2HKO specially defensive Moltres and Assault Vest Toxapex after a Nasty Plot boost. It also removes Galarian Moltres's Ice weakness, allowing it to avoid the OHKO from Baxcalibur’s +1 Icicle Crash and the 2HKO from its +1 Ice Shard. Tera Flying is only to be used if running Hurricane, which can OHKO Zamazenta without a Nasty Plot boost, as well as non-Assault Vest Azumarill and Enamorus after a Nasty Plot boost. Sitrus Berry lets it set up much more easily, and can potentially let it trigger Berserk twice. Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to ignore Stealth Rock. Finally, Weakness Policy is a viable alternative if running dual screens support to take on super effective hits more comfortably. Because of its reliance on setup, Galarian Moltres is best utilized on hyper offense teams. Hence, it appreciates entry hazard support from suicide leads such as Glimmora, Hisuian Samurott, and Meowscarada so that incoming foes can be worn down for Galarian Moltres to clean.
