• With Poison Heal, Breloom can act as a pivot versus defensive Pokemon such as Dondozo and Umbreon as it is unaffected by Yawn.

  • This set can catch opponents expecting the more popular Focus Sash set off guard. However, do note that this set is very susceptible to Taunt and Encore, which can make it difficult to even select Breloom in the team preview phase.

  • Protect: Protect gives Breloom an opportunity to scout out its opponents and further stall them out once Leech Seed has been set up.

  • Timer Stalling: If you obtain a numerical advantage early in the match, you can utilize Breloom to win on timer. This is particularly effective since the Leech Seed damage happens after recovery from Leftovers and Poison Heal.

  • Bulldoze: Bulldoze allows Breloom to further support its teammates and threaten Gholdengo, which likes to absorb status moves. Do be wary that many Gholdengo are Tera Flying, which can render Breloom ineffective versus it.

Other Options

  • Toxic: Toxic can be difficult to fit into the set, but it allows Breloom to punish Tera Grass foes that attempt to circumvent Breloom's Spore and Leech Seed.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: While Breloom's typing does have some useful resistances, its low bulk means more favorable resistances granted by Terastallization can be key to setting up.

  • Water: This defensive Tera type allows Breloom to resist Baxcalibur's Icicle Spear and Skeledirge's Torch Song, both of which are threats to Substitute. It also helps against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, though note that Choice Specs Chi-Yu can still OHKO with Tera Fire Overheat.

  • Fire: This Tera type allows Breloom to resist Ice- and Fire-type attacks while also providing Breloom with a Fairy-type resistance. With Toxic, Breloom is able to fight back against common Grass-type switch-ins. However, this type has more weaknesses when compared to Water.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: This spread allows for maximum physical bulk.

  • 156 HP / 100 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread allows for maximum Speed and can survive a Choice Band Extreme Speed from Tera Normal Dragonite after Stealth Rock.

  • 204 HP / 164 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread hits a Speed stat of 108 which ties 4 Spe Adamant Baxcalibur. Furthermore, the defensive investment means that after Terastallization, Breloom's Substitute has a high chance of surviving three hits from Baxcalibur's Icicle Spear.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• With threats such as Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Chien-Pao around, Hariyama carves a niche for itself as an Assault Vest user capable of taking them on. Along with its decent bulk, Thick Fat gives it key resistances to Fire- and Ice-type attacks.

  • Bullet Punch: Bullet Punch provides Hariyama with a non-situational priority move that can grab KOs on weakened targets, and, when boosted by Tera Steel, turn the tides against Fairy-type opponents such as Flutter Mane and Mimikyu.

  • Fake Out versus Knock Off: Fake Out gives Hariyama another source of priority, and it can even be used to scout for Covert Cloak users if the opponent doesn't get flinched by it. Knock Off cripples switch-ins by removing their items; however, it can't remove a Booster Energy from an opponent with the Protosynthesis or Quark Drive in Sun or Electric Terrain, respectively, as it's consumed before Hariyama gets to move.

  • Close Combat versus Drain Punch: Close Combat is the stronger move but at the cost of cutting into Hariyama's bulk with each use. Drain Punch can fail to get a 2HKO on specially defensive Ting-Lu more than 90% of the time, but it provides Hariyama with some recovery, bolstering its bulk.

  • Headlong Rush: Headlong Rush drops Hariyama's defenses with each use, but it 2HKOes defensive Toxapex and Gholdengo.

Other Options

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Hariyama a strong option to hit Dragonite with and can catch it by surprise, considering it isn't pressured to Terastallize against Hariyama's other moves.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam, coupled with Tera Steel, provides Hariyama with a strong move against lightweight foes such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, Mimikyu, and Terastallized Iron Moth and Volcarona that doesn't drop its defenses.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Hariyama can work without Terastallization, it can provide an extra kick to its coverage or improve its defensive presence against certain threats.

  • Steel: Steel Tera gives Hariyama STAB on Bullet Punch, a resistance to Fairy, Psychic, and Steel, and an immunity to Poison, greatly improving its matchup against Flutter Mane, Mimikyu, Psychic Chi-Yu, Gholdengo, and Tera Fairy Iron Moth and Volcarona. Thanks to Thick Fat, it can take on non-Choice Specs variants of Chi-Yu even after Terastallizing if it's kept healthy.

  • Fire: Besides the burn immunity, Tera Fire capitalizes on Hariyama's Thick Fat, discouraging threats like Tera Fire Chi-Yu and Choice Band Chien-Pao from using their most powerful moves.

  • Fighting: While Tera Fighting doesn't provide anything defensively for Hariyama, it makes Close Combat a force to be reckoned with.

sets.name: Guts Attacker
sets.description:
• Thanks to Guts, Hariyama can work as a status absorber and boost its high Attack at the same time, making it a threat to Toxic Spikes-stacking teams.

  • Bullet Punch: Bullet Punch gives Hariyama a consistent priority move and an option to hit Fairy-type foes.

  • Fake Out versus Knock Off: Fake Out is an option to safely activate Flame Orb and Guts, while Knock Off provides utility in removing items from the opponent.

  • Close Combat versus Drain Punch: Guts-boosted Close Combat is a force to be reckoned with, being one of the few moves capable of OHKOing physically defensive Wo-Chien. Drain Punch is weaker, but the recovery can help offset the burn damage.

  • Earthquake versus Headlong Rush: Earthquake complements Hariyama's coverage nicely, hitting Poison-types that resist Close Combat. Headlong Rush is stronger, but comes with the drawbacks of lowering defenses and being a contact move, triggering Rocky Helmet.

Other Options

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch is Hariyama's best hope of hitting Dragonite, as it doesn't fear much from Hariyama's other moves.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Terastallization gives a much appreciated boost to Bullet Punch, but it isn't necessary on every match.

  • Steel: Terastallizing into the Steel-type turns Hariyama's Fairy and Psychic weaknesses into resistances along with giving STAB to Bullet Punch.

sets.name: Defensive Magic Bounce
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Prankster Wall
sets.description:
Sableye stands out as a good physical wall in the tier thanks to its amazing ability in Prankster and defensive typing, giving it great matchups into the tier's Fighting-, Normal-, and Psychic-type attackers like Hisuian Sneasel, Medicham, Tauros, Paldean Tauros, and Bruxish, immediately threatening them with a burn from Will-O-Wisp. Sableye also blanket checks many setup sweepers in the tier as well, such as Dudunsparce, Ursaring, Coil Sandaconda, and Coil Eelektross, with Encore. Knock Off allows Sableye to punish Pokemon that may rely on their items for their bulk or longevity on a switch such as Hisuian Qwilfish, Eelektross, Ursaring, and Bombirdier. Foul Play is a reliable source of damage against physical setup sweepers, such as Scyther and Bruxish, over options such as Knock Off or Will-O-Wisp. Tera Poison gives Sableye an immunity to Toxic and a resistance to Fairy while retaining its positive matchup into Fighting-types. Tera Steel has a similar function but instead retains Sableye's favorable matchup into Psychic-types while giving it some additional resistances to common attacking types such as Ice from Pokemon like Abomasnow. Tera Dark is notable for letting Sableye OHKO Pokemon such as Rotom and Bruxish with Knock Off while providing Sableye with a Ghost resistance.

Sableye struggles with the tier's myriad of Dark-types such as Cacturne and Bombirdier, which all ignore Prankster, while Tera Dark users such as Toxicroak, Hisuian Sneasel, and Bruxish can also Terastallize to completely ignore Sableye and use it as setup fodder. To help alleviate this issue, Pokemon like Hisuian Qwilfish, Carbink, Articuno, and Appletun can all help answer these threats. In addition, Sableye is fairly passive in nature with horrible special bulk, which means it can invite special wallbreakers such as Clawitzer and Glaceon. Pairing Sableye with special walls such as Blissey, Eelektross, and Muk can help make up for these faults.

sets.name: Stallbreaker (Dark)
sets.description:
Sableye is a good choice for Dark teams due to its Fighting immunity, great array of utility moves such as Will-O-Wisp and Taunt, and reliable recovery, letting it disrupt opposing teams and assist its teammates in either breaking through opposing teams or staving off attacks. Prankster Will-O-Wisp lets Sableye neutralize threats to Dark-type teams such as Great Tusk and Dragonite by burning them before they can make a move. Taunt lets it shut down set up attempts from Pokemon such as Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Bulk Up Corviknight or hinder opposing defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Taunt also blocks entry hazards from going up, which is huge for Dark due to its lack of entry hazard control. Alternatively, Encore lets Sableye halt the aforementioned setup attempts and gain more momentum from them. Knock Off capitalizes on the switches that Sableye forces by knocking off crucial items from Pokemon such as Toxapex or Dondozo. Alternatively, Night Shade deals steady damage throughout the game. Finally, Recover gives Sableye longevity to continually check the aforementioned threats. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Sableye come in and out without worrying about residual damage from entry hazards.

Some great teammates for Sableye include Skuntank and Kingambit, as both of them boast a critical neutrality to Fairy that lets them take hits such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant's and Flutter Mane's Moonblasts and force both out. In return, Sableye can complement Skuntank's chip damage from Toxic Spikes through its utility moves and ease Kingambit's setup through item removal and spreading burns. Ting-Lu is another good teammate, as it can set entry hazards to further wear away at the opposing team while also acting as an emergency soft check to Fairy-types if it is running Heavy Slam. Reciprocally, Sableye can accentuate the effect of Ting-Lu's entry hazards by removing Heavy-Duty Boots and taking Fighting-type moves such as Slither Wing's and Great Tusk's Close Combats. Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Greninja all greatly appreciate Sableye's ability to grind down the opposing team with Knock Off and Will-O-Wisp, while also liking Sableye's ability to hinder walls such as Toxapex and Dondozo and keep entry hazards off the field with Taunt. Lokix is a decent teammate, as it greatly assists in the Dark-type mirror matchup, where Sableye can do nothing due to Prankster being nullified by Dark-types.

sets.name: Rocky Helmet
sets.description:
• Protect scouts Choice item users like Dragapult and Choice Specs Iron Bundle, leaving them open to Disable.

  • Encore handles setup Pokemon like Curse Dondozo as well as stall sets like Azumarill's.

  • Recover is especially useful against recoil move users like Talonflame and Arcanine.

  • Minimum Speed is run for opposing Sableye to guaranteed a slower Struggle.

  • Sableye should always use Protect turn one and then Encore against status moves or Disable against attacks. If Encore is used, the correct sequence is Encore > Protect > Disable > Encore and heal with Recover as necessary. Encore can also be used against weak attacks that have no chance of KOing Sableye. Sableye should also use Disable while the foe is using Struggle in order to conserve Recover's few PP against foes with Leftovers or other forms of recovery.

  • If Disable is used first, use Encore and Recover while the foe is stuck with Struggle. Since Recover has low PP, it should only be used when Sableye could faint to a critical hit.

sets.name: Trick + Disable
sets.description:
• Trick gives the foe Sableye's Choice Scarf, allowing Sableye to use Disable and force it into using Struggle. This allows Sableye to beat threats like Dondozo, Iron Hands, and Donphan.

  • Fling gets rid of any unwanted items, such as a given Assault Vest and Sableye's Choice Scarf.

  • Recover allows Sableye to heal off damage dealt while stalling its foe.

  • 252 HP and Defense EVs with an Impish nature maximize Sableye's physical bulk.

  • Sableye should almost always use Trick turn 1 and Disable turn 2, then repeatedly use Recover until the foe faints from Struggle recoil.

  • An exception to this is with Choice item Pokemon like Choice Band Dondozo and Donphan, where Sableye should use Fling turn 1 and Disable turn 2, then spam Recover.

  • Sableye struggles to beat Encore and Taunt users, like Annihilape and Skeledirge, and Pokemon that OHKO it, like Iron Valiant and Sylveon. Additionally, Sableye can not defeat Dark-types such as Meowscarada and Ting-Lu, due to its status moves not affecting them.

sets.name: Mixed Wall (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Mixed Wall (Ghost)
sets.description: Mega Sableye is a staple on bulkier Ghost teams due to its Dark typing, great abilities before and after Mega Evolution, and great defensive stats. Knock Off hinders Chansey and Porygon2 for Mega Sableye's wallbreaking teammates and eases the matchup against Landorus and Nidoking. Due to Sableye's meager HP and need for longevity, Recover's a must-have utility option, further enabling Metal Burst. Protect allows Sableye to Mega Evolve safely, ensuring it can utilize Magic Bounce later into the game. Metal Burst retaliates against Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie, while Dazzling Gleam eliminates Mega Sableye's passivity in front of Hydreigon and Roaring Moon. Will-O-Wisp in conjunction with Prankster renders physical attackers like Mega Gallade, Dragonite, and Mamoswine less threatening. The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Nidoking's Earth Power, assuming Mega Sableye uses Knock Off after the first Earth Power. Mimikyu threatens Dark-types such as Mandibuzz, Galarian Moltres, and opposing Mega Sableye. Gholdengo checks Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant as well as preventing foes from removing entry hazards set by Froslass and Galarian Corsola. Blacephalon handles opposing Gholdengo and utilizes Choice Scarf to clean through Steel, Ghost, and Psychic teams once Heatran, Mega Sableye, and Galarian Slowking, respectively, are removed. Skeledirge has great synergy with Mega Sableye, appreciating the prevention of opposing Stealth Rock and in return walling Volcarona, Mega Lopunny, and Alolan Ninetales.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Mega Medicham is a tremendously strong wallbreaker due to Pure Power, strong STAB moves, and coverage. Fake Out lets Mega Medicham chip down and revenge kill Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. It also can let Mega Medicham stall out rain, Toxic, and Terrain on foes, all while putting opponents into range for one of its stronger attacks safely. Ice Punch lets Mega Medicham get rid of Landorus-T and Dragonite, which can enable it to freely use its STAB moves. Bullet Punch can be used to snipe Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Weavile, and it also removes revenge killers like Tapu Koko and Mega Lopunny after chip damage. Thunder Punch can be used to hit Slowbro, and in tandem with Electric Terrain, it can 2HKO Pokemon like Gholdengo and Victini. Alternatively, Thief can be used to immediately damage the aforementioned Pokemon, so it can use its STAB moves more. Due to Mega Medicham’s frailty and mediocre Speed tier, it is easily revenge killed. Defensive partners like Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn help check threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult. Knock Off and Pursuit users like Kingambit and Weavile also support Mega Medicham, as they break through Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon Mega Medicham struggle with, such as Slowbro, Victini, Gholdengo and Skeledirge, allowing it to consistently use its STAB attacks. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn benefit Mega Medicham, as it forces a lot of switches and entry hazards wear down checks quickly. Tapu Koko is a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it handles Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Slowbro reliably and powers up Mega Medicham's Thunder Punch. Tapu Lele can also be a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it powers up Zen Headbutt to insane levels, but blocking Fake Out and Bullet Punch from being used can be problematic. Pokemon like Volcarona and Kartana appreciate Torandus-T, Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Gholdengo being pressured constantly by Mega Medicham, enabling them to wreak havoc once the checks are removed or chipped.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Medicham is a solid revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Pure Power gives Medicham an edge over Passimian, one of its main sources of competition, by allowing its Close Combat to 2HKO bulky foes like Vaporeon before Terastallization. Zen Headbutt's Base Power is good against foes like Tera Fairy Chansey, but Psycho Cut is an alternative that doesn't make contact, which helps against Rocky Helmet users, Drifblim, and Poison Point Qwilfish. Thunder Punch and Ice Punch hit Bruxish and Sandaconda respectively, and Flying-types like Drifblim and Oricorio-F. Trick punishes defensive switch-ins like Sandaconda and is especially beneficial to use against bulky teams, since they are generally slower than Medicham anyway. Tera Fighting enhances Medicham's wallbreaking and cleaning potential by powering up Close Combat, and it lets Medicham resist Toxicroak and Bombirdier's Sucker Punch. Partners that commonly run Choice Scarf, such as Zoroark and Rotom, can revenge kill foes instead of Medicham early-on, keeping its set a mystery. Zoroark can also use Illusion to lure in and eliminate Ghost-types, which reduces how many predictions Medicham needs to make, while Rotom checks Flying-types and blanks Sandaconda and Choice Scarf Toxicroak.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Medicham's damage output is unrivaled thanks to Pure Power in tandem with Life Orb or a Choice Band. Zen Headbutt is a powerful STAB option that hits Poison-types like Qwilfish and Muk, as they can easily take a Close Combat. Psycho Cut is a weaker alternative that avoids contact effects like Poison Point and Rocky Helmet from the likes of Qwilfish and Sandaconda. Trailblaze allows Medicham to pull off sweeps and patch up its offensive shortcoming in its middling Speed. Trick is used with Choice Band to cripple walls such as Drifblim and Tera Fairy users like Chansey and Umbreon. Ice Punch is great neutral coverage for walls like Drifblim and Sandaconda. Tera Fighting gives Choice Band sets a favorable roll to KO Sandaconda after minimal chip or a single layer of Spikes. Tera Steel allows Medicham to defensively check fast revenge killers like Scyther and Zangoose on top of boosting Bullet Punch's damage output. Medicham struggles against bulky Ghost-types like Drifblim and Rotom, which makes Zoroark, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Haunter great offensive partners. Special sweepers like Dudunsparce, Oricorio, and Jolteon appreciate Medicham's ability to break past Chansey, Umbreon, and Vaporeon. Medicham also enjoys pivots like Scyther, Rotom, and Eelektross; it especially likes the latter two, which threaten out Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Drifblim.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description: Fire Spin and Grass Tera Blast can effectively lure otherwise undesirable matchups like Sandaconda and Vaporeon. 88 Speed allows Camerupt to outspeed the likes of Muk, Crocalor, and Perrserker

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
Torkoal is best known for setting up sun and facilitating strong sun teams, carrying them on its shell. Torkoal uses Lava Plume for its good Base Power and burn chance, but Flamethrower can be used for more power, notably guaranteeing in breaking Dragapult's Substitute, which would otherwise use Torkoal as setup fodder. Stealth Rock is used, as Torkoal is usually leading and can get entry hazards up early-game. Rapid Spin keeps entry hazards off the field, which allows it and its teammates, particularly the Fire-types, to stay healthy throughout the game. Yawn provides opportunities for its strong teammates, whether through a sleeping foe or a forced switch. However, Will-O-Wisp can be used to more consistently cripple physical attackers, while Body Press can be used to take advantage of its great Defense against Kingambit, Baxcalibur, and Roaring Moon. Tera Water gives Torkoal a great defensive typing, flipping matchups against Pokemon like Great Tusk and Azumarill and removing its weakness to Stealth Rock, letting it stay in the game longer and cripple the aforementioned wallbreakers with a burn. A Calm nature alongside maximum Special Defense investment can also be considered, as it can avoid the 2HKO from attacks like Iron Moth's Sludge Wave, Galarian Slowking's Future Sight and Gholdengo's unboosted Shadow Ball

Pokemon that take advantage of Torkoal's sun are great partners. Some of these Pokemon include Walking Wake, which greatly appreciates the immense power boost to both its Special Attack or Speed alongside Hydro Steam, and it is also great at threatening weather setters like Tyranitar and Pelipper. Other strong Protosynthesis Pokemon can use the power or Speed boosts the sun provides. Great Tusk can use an Attack or Defense boost to wallbreak or check physical attackers such as Kingambit and Dragonite, respectively. Similarly, Roaring Moon uses the Speed or Attack boost to become a powerful wallbreaker with Choice Band. Brute Bonnet is a particularly excellent sun abuser; its Spore can effectively shut down a target, and with an Attack boost from Protosynthesis its Bullet Seed easily breaks past Dondozo while its Sucker Punch is devastating against faster threats like Dragapult or opposing Walking Wake. Hisuian Lilligant is another solid teammate and a decent alternative to Brute Bonnet; its powerful Solar Blade can muscle past Dondozo, its STAB Close Combat can deal with Heatran, and it can become an incredibly dangerous sweeper even against offensive teams thanks to Chlorophyll's Speed boost. Fire-types like Cinderace, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth enjoy having their STAB moves boosted even further. Moreover, the aforementioned Cinderace and Great Tusk also provide additional entry hazard control with Court Change and Rapid Spin, alleviating Torkoal from entry hazard pressure and having to remove them itself. Hatterene is a great teammate on fast-paced sun teams, as it deflects Stealth Rock with Magic Bounce and prevents Torkoal and their teammates from taking as much chip damage as well as potentially heal Torkoal up with Healing Wish. Lastly, Kingambit offers sun teams a solid answer to Galarian Slowking and a powerful late game wincon, as it can clean up once Torkoal and the teammates it enables have worn the opposing team down sufficiently. It especially appreciates Torkoal's ability to give it openings to set up a Swords Dance thanks to Torkoal's Yawn or Will-O-Wisp support.

sets.name: Offensive Sun Setter
sets.description: Max Attack alongside a Brave nature allows Torkoal to 2HKO Galarian Slowking, preventing it from resetting Torkoal's sun with Chilly Reception. 40 Special Attack EVs allow Torkoal to always OHKO Iron Valiant from full HP with Overheat.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
Torkoal is an essential member of Fire teams, providing valuable role compression by setting up sun and Stealth Rock, removing entry hazards, and tanking physical attacks. STAB Lava Plume provides decent damage and a high chance to burn, which proves particularly useful against physical attackers like Mimikyu and Iron Hands. Body Press allows Torkoal uses Torkoal's high Defense to heavily damage the likes of Kingambit, Blissey, and Tyranitar, as well as preventing Roaring Moon and Hydreigon from setting up freely. Alternatively, Yawn can be used to force a switch, allowing Torkoal to freely bring a teammate that can benefit from the sun. Heat Rock provides more turns of sun for allies to benefit from, but Heavy-Duty Boots greatly increases Torkoal's longevity. If using the latter, getting fewer turns of sun also allows Fire teams to better manage opposing Protosynthesis sweepers, such as Flutter Mane or Sandy Shocks.

Thanks to Chlorophyll and its unique typing, Scovillain pairs well with Torkoal, as the sun allows it to outspeed and KO foes such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Quaquaval. Choice Specs Scovillian can significantly damage to Toxapex with Solar Beam and even 2HKO Clodsire in the sun with Flamethrower. Cinderace is another wallbreaker that thrives under the sun and appreciates Stealth Rock chipping at the opposing team. It can run Court Change, allowing for more entry hazard control if you're running Heat Rock Torkoal, or use a Choice Scarf to defeat foes like Flutter Mane and Choice Specs Greninja. Iron Moth can use sun and Fire Blast to OHKO foes such as Iron Jugulis and Sableye. Ceruledge scares out Flutter Mane, which can otherwise become problematic due to Power Gem and Protosynthesis boosting its Speed in sun. Thanks to its great defensive stats and Unaware, Skeledirge is an amazing partner for Torkoal, handling setup sweepers such as Curse Dondozo and Belly Drum Azumarill for it. Also, sun weakens Water-type moves for Skeledirge and boosts its Torch Song. Rotom-H can tank special hits Torkoal can't withstand from the likes of Iron Valiant, as well as providing a valuable Ground immunity, which allows it to come in on foes such as Clodsire, Sandy Shocks, and Ting-Lu. Volcarona can dismantle Dark-type teams and occasionally weaken physical attackers thanks to Flame Body.

sets.name: Sun Support
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Grumpig is not viable in PU, but this is considered its best set.

136 Speed EVs let Grumpig outspeed Modest Glaceon. 44 SpA EVs allow unboosted Tera Ground Grumpig to KO offensive Skuntank with Earth Power after Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Offensive Spikes
sets.description: Cacturne is an amazing offensive Spiker in NU. Due to its strength and typing, it finds many opportunities to switch in on and threaten tier staples like Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Drifblim. Cacturne is also good at taking advantage of Water-types like Bruxish and Floatzel thanks to Water Absorb, giving it more chances to set up Spikes and dish out heavy damage. Dark Pulse reliably pressures Defoggers like Drifblim and Lurantis as well as Magic Bounce Hattrem. A Naive nature lets Cacturne outspeed Modest Clawitzer without sacrificing any power. Braviary is an excellent teammate for Cacturne, since it dissuades Defog attempts with Defiant and reliably pressures special walls. In return, Cacturne offers Braviary safety from Bruxish, offensively checks Ghost-types, and can facilitate late-game cleaning with Spikes. Setup sweepers like Hisuian Sneasel and Vivillon become much harder to stop when backed by Spikes and also match up well against Defoggers like Braviary and Lurantis.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: The EV spread is to outrun Adamant Brute Bonnet. Fire Spin should be run alongside Perish Song.

sets.name: Offensive Dragon Dance (Dragon)
sets.description: Mega Altaria's unique typing and offensive potential allow it to serve as a valuable setup sweeper that checks threats like Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Iron Hands, and Keldeo. Pixilate-boosted Return checks the aforementioned Dragon-types as well as Fighting- and Dark-types such as Terrakion, Mega Sableye, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is essential coverage, as it hits Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Magnezone and—in conjunction with Return—eases the Dark and Electric matchups. Roost increases Mega Altaria's longevity so it can continuously Dragon Dance throughout the match or use its bulk to switch into threats. The given EV spread allows Mega Altaria to survive Mega Lopunny's Triple Axel. Choice Specs Kyurem is a great teammate, as it breaks past the likes of Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo for Mega Altaria. Garchomp sets up Stealth Rock and Spikes, wearing down Mega Altaria's switch-ins. Kommo-o breaks past Steel-types like Skarmory, Aegislash, and defensive Celesteela as well as other troublesome walls like Toxapex and Hippowdon for Mega Altaria. Roaring Moon threatens obstacles such as Mega Diancie, Choice Specs Greninja, and Skeledirge.

sets.name: Toxic Boost
sets.description:
Zangoose is a high risk, high reward physical breaker capable of tearing through walls if it predicts correctly, but is punished severely by Toxic damage and entry hazards if it doesn't. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Perserrker and Tinkatuff that could come in on Facade, as well as being its best tool against Carbink. Night Slash catches Ghost-types like Misdreavus and Banette that would otherwise switch into Zangoose safely and punishes Tera Ghost from Pokemon like Gabite and Whiscash. Quick Attack lets Zangoose kill fast Pokemon like Charizard, Raichu, and Choice Scarf Rotom-F. Swords Dance turns Zangoose into an even more powerful breaker, OHKOing foes like Tinkatuff and Dachsbun at +2, at the cost of being unable to deal with faster Pokemon, making it a good choice against bulkier teams that lack faster Pokemon. Protect lets Zangoose scout Choice Scarf users like Lycanroc-N and Rotom-F as well as consistently activate Toxic Orb, but it is much less consistent overall than the other two options. Toxic Orb is the only item that can activate Toxic Boost on Zangoose, which pairs wonderfully with Facade. Tera Normal gives Zangoose a solid boost of power on Facade and Quick Attack, which is especially useful on sets lacking Swords Dance. It also gives Zangoose an easier time KOing frail, faster Pokemon like Pyroar and Houndoom.

Zangoose suffers heavily from the chip damage it accrues, so ways to mitigate this are helpful. Dachsbun is useful for its ability to pass Wish to Zangoose, helping it stay alive and break for a longer time; it is also useful for coming in on Pokemon that force Zangoose out like Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N. Fast Taunt users like Electrode and Pyroar can prevent entry hazards from foes like Perserrker and Tinkatuff, limiting the amount of chip damage that Zangoose takes. Electrode can also bring Zangoose in on its checks, like Gogoat and Dunsparce, to help it break. Offensive partners like Sawsbuck and Indeedee-F can help Zangoose overwhelm shared checks like Misdreavus and Tinkatuff, and Indeedee-F's Healing Wish is useful for giving Zangoose more chances to break, although Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F pairs poorly with Zangoose's Quick Attack. Zangoose also benefits heavily from Sticky Web from Pokemon like Spidops and Masquerain, as being able to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Golduck and other fast Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio is a massive boon for it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Whiscash is a defensive entry hazard setter with great typing and solid bulk. Stealth Rock can help chip common foes such as Misdreavus, Choice Scarf Rotom-F, and Haunter. However, even though Spikes don't affect the aforementioned Pokemon, it does better at hitting Rock-resistant threats such as Tinkatuff, Gabite, and Alolan Dugtrio. Earthquake can be used over Earth Power for the slightly higher damage, especially against special setup sweepers like Calm Mind Spiritomb and Wyrdeer, but Earth Power is generally preferred for inflicting better damage on physical walls like Klawf, Perrserker, and Alolan Persian and being unaffected by Grassy Terrain set by Thwackey, a common switch-in to Whiscash. Ice Beam is great for doing a chunk of damage on Grass-types like Gogoat, Flapple, and Dartrix. Surf is an option over Ice Beam, landing better damage on neutral targets instead of the previously mentioned foes. Stone Edge is great in the last slot to cover the likes of Charizard, as well as preventing setup sweepers like Rotom-F and Masquerain from taking advantage of Whiscash's relative passivity. Stealth Rock can be opted for instead to compress both forms of entry hazards into one Pokemon, possibly freeing up another team slot. Protect is used for scouting and gaining a bit more Leftovers recovery, but it is not very useful when running the more popular Heavy-Duty Boots. Oblivious allows Whiscash to set up hazards even against Taunt users like Alolan Persian and Misdreavus. Tera Poison is great for removing Whiscash's 4x weakness to Grass, with the added benefit letting it absorb Toxic Spikes. Tera Ghost turns it into a spinblocker in a pinch. The EV spread focuses on Special Defense over Defense because it makes for a better matchup against Volt Switch users like Rotom-F, as well as other special attackers like Alolan Persian and Fire-types like Charizard.

Whiscash appreciates spinblockers like Misdreavus and Spiritomb to keep its entry hazards up against Rapid Spin users like Quaxwell. Whiscash appreciates Charizard and Honchkrow's ability to deal with Grass-types; in return, it can take on the Rock- and Electric-types like Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N and Electrode. Grass-types like Gogoat and Dartrix also make for great teammates, as Whiscash can take on Fire- and Poison-types like Charizard, Houndoom, and Skuntank that threaten them. Its presence as an Electric-immune to help the likes of Masquerain and Honchkrow is superb, as it has the typing and bulk to take hits from the coverage moves that Pokemon like Raichu, Rotom-F, and Electrode carry. Dachsbun, Crabominable, and Carbink all benefit from Whiscash, as it can take Steel-type hits from Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio for them. With a lot of the tier being weak or neutral to Rock, Whiscash finds itself having the typing to help the likes of Charizard, Masquerain, and Rabsca avoid dealing with Lycanroc-N, Dugtrio, and Gabite. It does find a lot of trouble handling Misdreavus, as it lacks the super effective coverage to get past its bulk. This is why pairing it with a Dark-type like Skuntank or Alolan Persian can be beneficial. Since Whiscash doesn't have recovery, it really doesnt like taking Will-O-Wisp from said Misdreavus, and Charizard or Toxic from Skuntank. As a result, status absorbers like Chansey, Dragonair, and Tinkatuff make for great teammates.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Special Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Salamence stands out as one of the premier Pokemon in the tier thanks to its defensive and offensive presence. Its typing, bulk, and ability in Intimidate make it one of the best responses to physical threats like Slither Wing, Lucario, and Scizor. Hydro Pump blows away foes like Hippowdon, Tyranitar, and Sandy Shocks while providing a strong neutral hit on Tinkaton and Scizor. Flamethrower hits the aforementioned Steel-types, alongside others like Bisharp and Tinkaton. Flamethrower also hits Brambleghast without reaping the downsides of using Draco Meteor. Heavy-Duty Boots removes Salamence's Stealth Rock weakness, which allows it to switch in more freely against threats it needs to check. Terastallizing is primarily used defensively to improve its matchups against common offensive Pokemon. Tera Water allows Salamence to resist Bullet Punch from Scizor and still retain a Water-type resistance against Floatzel. Tera Steel improves the matchup against Tinkaton, turns Salamence into a decent Staraptor and Maushold check, and provides a resist to many forms of priority in the tier such as Accelerock from Lycanroc-D and Bullet Punch from Scizor. Tera Dragon should be used to help break through sturdier Pokemon like Gastrodon and Slowking more easily.

Pawmot and Scizor can help remove Gastrodon, Tyranitar, and Scream Tail— all of which Salamence struggles to break past—while also serving as more reliable checks to Bisharp. Faster Pokemon such as Pawmot, Sandy Shocks, and Lycanroc-D can revenge kill or force Salamence out, so partners like Hippowdon and Quagsire are appreciated, both also acting as decent Knock Off absorbers against Grafaiai and Tinkaton. Quagsire can also provide Spikes support to help wear down some of the aforementioned special walls as well as put them on a timer with Toxic, as well as reliably check most Swords Dance Scizor and Lucario if Salamence isn't Tera Steel.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance makes Salamence one of the scariest sweepers in the tier thanks to its great offensive typing. Outrage is a powerful STAB move that helps muscle through sturdier walls like Gastrodon and Hippowdon after a boost; however, Dragon Claw is a weaker alternative that doesn't have the downside of being locked in. Earthquake provides perfect coverage to deal with Tyranitar, Tinkaton, and Bisharp. Dual Wingbeat helps break through Scream Tail better and can pick off weakened Flying-types like Noivern and Iron Jugulis without locking into Outrage. Roost is an alternative that provides longevity against Pokemon like Slither Wing and Lokix. It is best used alongside Intimidate on bulkier teams that need the defensive utility of Salamence's typing. Otherwise, Moxie is preferred, as it can easily let Salamence snowball through a team. Tera Steel lets Salamence set up on Tinkaton—though it must be wary of Encore—and provides needed resists to many priority moves like Accelerock, Bullet Punch, Ice Shard, and Extreme Speed from Lycanroc-D, Scizor, Weavile, and Lucario.

Quagsire is very problematic due to Unaware ignoring any Dragon Dance and Moxie boosts. Pawmot can remove Quagsire with Seed Bomb, Scizor can lure it in and remove it with Trailblaze, and Sandy Shocks can threaten to OHKO with Tera Blast after Terastallizing into a Grass-type. Sandy Shocks can also help remove physically defensive Hippowdon, which is especially helpful if it's running Roar. Sandy Shocks and other entry hazard setters such as Tyranitar can wear down Pokemon like opposing Tyranitar and Scream Tail into range of its attacks. Gengar is a fantastic wallbreaker to pair with Salamence, as it can forcefully remove Grafaiai, which can be a massive hindrance due to Prankster Encore limiting setup opportunities. Gengar also spinblocks alongside the aforementioned entry hazard setters and weakens Tyranitar and Tinkaton into Earthquake range.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Flying)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Specsmence Returns
sets.description:
• Salamence finds a niche for itself among other special attacking Dragon-types due to an incredible ability in Intimidate and a useful typing that provides a handy Fissure immunity.

  • Hurricane versus Air Slash: Hurricane's accuracy may not be very reliable, but the sheer damage output makes it worth it. Air Slash is much weaker than Hurricane, but the more reliable accuracy and flinch chance make it a reasonable alternative. It becomes especially attractive if using Tera Flying.

  • Hydro Pump: If not using Tera Fairy, Hydro Pump is a reasonable choice that deals massive damage to Hippowdon and Fire-types without risking Draco Meteor.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Not only does Tera Fairy give Salamence an edge against many Dragon-types, but it also pairs extremely well with Intimidate, transforming Salamence into an effective hit-and-run threat.

  • Steel: Tera Steel comes in handy against Dragon- and Fairy-types alike, though the added weaknesses to Ground and Fighting make it less effective at taking physical hits with Intimidate.

  • Flying: Air Slash becomes much easier to justify with Tera Flying, and if you're willing to risk it, Hurricane can be used to become almost impossible to wall with Choice Specs.

  • Fire: Tera Fire doesn't offer as much defensive utility, but the powerful STAB attacks come in handy against Steel-types like Corviknight.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon trades defensive advantages for an extremely powerful Draco Meteor that catches defensive foes like Dondozo by surprise.

Items

  • Choice Specs: With Salamence already standing at a decent Speed tier, it can get away with Choice Specs, making it extremely difficult to wall outside of using Blissey.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf trades wallbreaking power for the ability to get the jump on major offensive threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Garchomp.

sets.name: Physically Offensive
sets.description:
• Salamence is somewhat overshadowed by other physical Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragapult, but it has a trick up its claws: Dual Wingbeat, which OHKOes Breloom and Meowscarada through their Focus Sash.

  • Earthquake versus Fire Blast: Earthquake is the best option for hitting Steel-types such as Gholdengo hard, but Fire Blast is Salamence's best shot at 2HKOing Corviknight.

  • Dragon Dance: After a boost, Dual Wingbeat's Focus Sash slaying powers go into overdrive, being able to bust through Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, a boosted Dual Wingbeat has a 75% chance to OHKO offensive Mimikyu through its disguise! It also means Salamence no longer needs a boost to OHKO Great Tusk and Flutter Mane.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Tera Blast Salamence OHKO Azumarill and Iron Bundle, and potentially 2HKO Dondozo after Stealth Rock damage.

Abilities

  • Intimidate: While Salamence isn't particularly bulky, Intimidate makes setting up far easier when paired with a Flying Tera type that removes Salamence's common weaknesses.

  • Moxie: With Moxie, Salamence has the potential to seriously punish Breloom leads or snowball through teams even without Dragon Dance.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
• Salamence's great mixed offenses, Intimidate, and decent Speed give it a niche as a powerful wall breaker.

  • Dual Wingbeat: Dual Wingbeat lets Salamence OHKO Breloom regardless of its Focus Sash, something very few Pokemon can do.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor deals massive damage to Dondozo, usually doing more than 50% to physically defensive ones.

  • Substitute: Substitute makes the Dondozo match-up even better, making Yawn a non-issue. It's also a good way to scout Terastallization against slower threats.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type covers a lot of Salamence's weaknesses and makes dealing with Mimikyu, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane much easier.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Salamence a great match-up against most Dragon-types, and pairs especially well with Intimidate to turn Salamence into a good hit-and-run attacker.

  • Fire: With a Fire Tera type, Salamence gains a resistance to Fairy-type attacks and deals massive damage to Assault Vest Magnezone.

  • Electric: Tera Electric gives Salamence a great tool against Dondozo with Tera Blast.

  • Dragon: While this Tera type fails to help Salamence much defensively, it makes Draco Meteor 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf Kyogre is a solid form of speed control found on bulky offense teams. Its ability to outspeed Zacian-C and pressure common Pokemon found on bulky archetypes, like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Groudon, gives it a decent offensive presence. Choice Scarf Kyogre can also pressure hyper offense teams because those teams don't run Pokemon naturally faster than it. However, Choice Scarf Kyogre is prediction reliant, as there are a lot of Pokemon that resist Water-type attacks in Ubers, mainly metagame staples like Koraidon, Miraidon, and other defensive Pokemon like Water Absorb Clodsire and Eternatus. Choice Scarf Kyogre is also relatively weak, which means that it'll often be forced to use Tera to power up its attacks; even then, Pokemon like Eternatus and Clodsire will still wall Kyogre.
  • Koraidon is the biggest threat to Kyogre, as it commonly switches into it, takes little damage from its Water-type attacks, and sets sun. Catching Koraidon with Ice Beam is extremely important, as it can make the difference between Kyogre sweeping in the late game or not. This makes Choice Scarf Kyogre extremely prediction reliant, as one single bad move can mean the entire momentum of the battle is lost.
  • Tera Water boosts Kyogre's Water-type moves to insane levels. For instance, Water Spout now OHKOes max HP Arceus formes that are neutral to Water and 2HKOes Arceus formes that resist Water. It also has a good chance to OHKO Groudon even if sun is active.
  • Kyogre should be brought onto the field via pivoting moves like U-turn from the likes of Koraidon, Miraidon, and Landorus-T. Unless there are Water Absorb Pokemon on the enemy team, Water Spout is a relatively free move to spam; however, hitting Koraidon on the switch with a well-timed Ice Beam can be game-changing.
  • Choice Scarf Kyogre appreciates Pokemon that can wallbreak by themselves. A good teammate for this reason is Miraidon, which shares a common check in Clodsire. Taunt Miraidon in particular can shut down Clodsire completely, as Clodsire will be at half HP after switching into Draco Meteor. Miraidon can also bring Kyogre onto the field via U-turn. Arceus-Ground is another great teammate for Kyogre, as it can keep Pokemon like Eternatus, Clodsire, and Miraidon in check.
  • Pokemon that can check Koraidon, like Arceus-Fairy, Groudon, and Skeledirge, are a must, as Koraidon is one of the most annoying Pokemon in Ubers for Kyogre to deal with: it replaces rain with sun, weakening Kyogre's main attacking moves. They can also set entry hazards and, in Landorus-T's case, bring Kyogre onto the field with U-turn.
  • Entry hazard removers like Giratina-O and Corviknight are appreciated, as Kyogre loses a lot of power when its HP is lowered. Both Pokemon also check threats like Extreme Killer Arceus, which can revenge kill Kyogre with Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Kyogre is a devastating wallbreaker that can OHKO or 2HKO the entire metagame. However, the ever-present sun set by Koraidon and its relatively low Speed make it harder to use than it may appear, even with its incredible power.
  • Water Spout gives Kyogre the power to OHKO even resistant Pokemon such as Miraidon and Eternatus when paired with Tera Water, and it lets Kyogre claim KOs with ease early on. Ice Beam lets Kyogre hit Koraidon and Clodsire super effectively, cleanly OHKOing the former lacking bulk EVs and 2HKOing the latter. Thunder is Kyogre's strongest option for breaking through bulky Water-types such as Toxapex, Arceus-Water, and opposing Kyogre.
  • Tera Water lets Kyogre perform feats such as OHKOing Miraidon, Toxapex, Arceus-Water, and Eternatus with Water Spout or Origin Pulse with a layer of Spikes up.
  • An alternate EV spread of 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 Def can be used to take on Arceus formes and switch into defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Landorus-T better.
  • Kyogre fits well on bulky offense. It has trouble getting onto the field and loses a significant part of its power if it takes a hit, so it should be paired with pivots such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Landorus-T. They can bring Kyogre in on their incoming checks such as Arceus-Fairy and Skeledirge, Arceus-Ground, and Ting-Lu, respectively.
  • Kyogre also greatly appreciates entry hazard removal, such as Defog support from Giratina-O and Corviknight, which keeps Water Spout at full power. Speed control options help Kyogre to wallbreak to its fullest, as it tends to have to take a hit before attacking thanks to its lower Speed, such as Thunder Wave from Arceus, Miraidon, Giratina-O, and Groudon, and Sticky Web from Masquerain.
  • Entry hazards support from Ting-Lu and Clodsire is also appreciated to make sure Kyogre's attacks can cleanly OHKO most of their switch-ins. The aforementioned two Pokemon are also able to check Miraidon and Eternatus, both of which can come in on Kyogre and revenge-kill it. Koraidon can force Kyogre out and can switch into its Water-type attacks, so checks to Koraidon such as Skeledirge, Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Arceus-Fairy are also appreciated. That said, Kyogre can also predict Koraidon coming in and catch it with an Ice Beam, which is a clean OHKO on all Koraidon without bulk EVs.
  • Kyogre can also be used as a solid offensive check to Arceus formes, as it can pivot into a Taunt or a Calm Mind and force them out with a strong Origin Pulse or Water Spout. Kyogre can also pivot into opposing Calm Mind Kyogre, forcing it out with Thunder.

sets.name: Bulky Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Thanks to Kyogre's naturally high bulk, it can use Calm Mind to set up on defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, as well as Pokemon it forces out through its typing, such as Zacian-C and Koraidon.
  • Surf is the move of choice thanks to its higher PP as well as accuracy over Origin Pulse. Ice Beam lets Kyogre hit Miraidon, Koraidon, Eternatus, and Clodsire super effectively, which would otherwise freely switch into Kyogre. Tera Blast can be used if paired with Tera Ground to break through Clodsire, regardless of whether it has used Tera.
  • Substitute can be used to set up on Clodsire, which cannot break it with Earthquake, and avoid status in general. Rest lets Kyogre repeatedly come in and absorb status, though it must be wary of Miraidon's Hadron Engine setting Electric Terrain.
  • Tera Fairy flips Kyogre's matchup against Eternatus and Koraidon, letting Kyogre freely come in on Dragon-type moves and resist Koraidon's STAB attacks. Tera Ground lets Kyogre set up on Miraidon's Electro Drift, although it cannot take Draco Meteor well without previously having set up. Tera Poison is another option for becoming immune to Toxic from Clodsire, Toxapex, and Eternatus while also resisting Koraidon's Fighting-type attacks.
  • Leftovers provides Kyogre with a form of recovery and gives it more chances to enter the field.
  • The given EV spread lets Kyogre take on physical attackers like Groudon and Koraidon better while outspeeding some paralyzed +1 Arceus formes and paralyzed Zacian-C.
  • Kyogre fits best on balance and bulky offense teams thanks to the defensive utility it provides as well as being a solid late-game wincon.
  • Miraidon is a great partner for non-Rest variants of Kyogre, as it can break through Taunt and Calm Mind Arceus formes and pressure bulky Water-types such as Toxapex and Arceus-Water. Miraidon can also use U-turn to bring Kyogre in on Ground-types that it can set up on, such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Ting-Lu and Groudon are solid partners for Kyogre, since they can set up Spikes to weaken Kyogre's checks, while also being able to switch into Electric-type attacks that threaten Kyogre. Physical attackers such as Groudon, Arceus-Ground, Chien-Pao, and Koraidon pair well with Kyogre, as they can use Kyogre's checks as an entry for them to start breaking, and Kyogre pressures all of their checks apart from Arceus-Water.
  • Kyogre needs Koraidon eliminated before it can start setting up, as Kyogre is generally forced out by it and its STAB moves are weakened. As such, defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Great Tusk, and Arceus-Fairy are solid partners that check Koraidon effectively. Finally, Kyogre has trouble coming in against faster offense teams, so partners that can pressure these teams such as Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon, Extreme Killer Arceus, and Zacian-C are preferred.

sets.name: Offensive Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Offensive Calm Mind Kyogre is a decent setup sweeper on offensive and balance teams for its ability to punch big holes in defensive cores for its team to exploit.
  • Ice Beam allows Kyogre to threaten Dragon-types like Koraidon, Miraidon, and Eternatus, which can withstand Kyogre's STAB attacks. Koraidon is a noteworthy target, because it can otherwise easily oppose Kyogre’s rain with its sun. Ice Beam also hits Clodsire, which otherwise completely walls this Kyogre set without Tera Ground Tera Blast.
  • Kyogre can easily spread paralysis with Thunder Wave thanks to it naturally forcing out Ground-types, which is appreciated by slower teams.
  • Thunder lets Kyogre smack defensive Water-types that resist Surf and Ice Beam, like Toxapex and Dondozo, as well as lays waste to opposing Kyogre. It also hits Pokemon that may Terastallize into a Water-type, like Eternatus and Zacian-C.
  • With Tera Ground, Tera Blast can 2HKO Clodsire without setting up, even if it is Terastallized into a Steel-type, while also hitting Toxapex. However, it has very little practical use outside of this.
  • Kyogre has no reliable recovery, so Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item so it doesn’t get worn down by entry hazards. Leftovers can be used on teams that have reliably hazard control like Giratina-O.
  • Tera Fairy gives Kyogre a Fighting resistance and Dragon immunity, making it impossible for Koraidon to threaten Kyogre in rain.
  • Tera Poison gives Kyogre a Fighting resistance and immunity to Toxic, and also allows it to absorb Toxic Spikes from Eternatus, Toxapex, and Clodsire.
  • Tera Ground gives Kyogre an Electric immunity, letting it avoid Electro Drift from Miraidon and Thunder from opposing Kyogre.
  • Tera Grass, on the other hand, gives Kyogre Ground and Electric resistances, letting it set up on Pokemon it otherwise cannot, like Groudon, Arceus-Ground, and Miraidon.
  • This Kyogre set is a good fit on balance teams that struggle against defensive teams, as it is a bulky setup sweeper that can take advantage of common defensive Pokemon like Skeledirge and Ting-Lu to spread paralysis with Thunder Wave.
  • Zacian-C is a fantastic partner, able to threaten many Pokemon commonly used to threaten Kyogre without a Substitute, like Koraidon and Miraidon. Zacian-C also loves Kyogre’s rain neutering its Fire weakness.
  • Koraidon can pivot into Kyogre with U-turn while taking attacks used against Kyogre, like opposing Koraidon’s Flare Blitz when Kyogre is Terastallized and Miraidon’s Electro Drift. Koraidon also loves Kyogre threatening physical checks like Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Groudon.
  • Clodsire lures like Choice Specs Miraidon are great for Kyogre, as Kyogre is completely walled by Clodsire that has Terastallized into a Steel-type if it doesn't have Tera Ground Tera Blast.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Primal Kyogre is an effective specially defensive pivot that is able to blanket check special attackers such as Mega Diancie, Eternatus, and Palkia-O. U-turn is not boosted by STAB but cannot be blocked by Desolate Land. Coming from Primal Kyogre's high Special Attack, Scald does respectable damage against neutral targets and greatly threatens Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Mega Steelix; the threat of burn also deters physical wallbreakers like Mega Mewtwo X from switching in. If Scald burns are undesirable because they conflict with other status conditions, Origin Pulse is a strong alternative. Knock Off removes key items like Covert Cloak, Assault Vest, and Imposter Chansey's Eviolite, allowing Primal Kyogre to status foes and assisting offensive teammates like Lumina Crash users. Mortal Spin is useful to force chip damage on Imposter users and threats like Palkia-O, and it also benefits from most Steel-types fearing Scald, preventing them from spinblocking. Nuzzle is an alternative that is more effective into offensive threats like Magic Guard Mega Mewtwo X and Ho-Oh but is noticeably worse into defensive Pokemon. Stone Axe doesn't conflict with Scald and is easier to Imposter-proof, but it makes Primal Kyogre almost helpless against threats like Palkia-O and Arceus-Fire, meaning reliable checks to these like Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy and Fur Coat Miraidon are needed. Primal Kyogre is threatened by powerful physical wallbreakers like Mewtwo Mega X; thus, physical walls such as Fur Coat Miraidon, Yveltal, and Arceus-Poison are good teammates. Special attackers like Mega Diancie, Mega Gardevoir, and Mega Alakazam appreciate Primal Kyogre removing key items like Assault Vest and Covert Cloak from special walls like Arceus-Fairy and opposing Primal Kyogre, and they can also be Imposter-proofed by Primal Kyogre. Primal Kyogre can be tricky to Imposter-proof; depending on the moveset, some decent options are Ice Scales Dialga-O and Jungle Healing users. Teammates such as Kartana also can offensively Imposter-proof Primal Kyogre by threatening an OHKO on Imposter users.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Thanks to Groudon's excellent physical bulk, it soft checks numerous physical threats in the tier such as Arceus, physical variants of Arceus-Ground, Koraidon, and Zacian-C.
  • 16 EVs in Speed allow Groudon to outspeed uninvested Kyogre, Giratina-O, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, a spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD can be used to maximize Groudon's bulk.
  • Precipice Blades is a powerful STAB option that OHKOes Zacian-C and Miraidon and has a chance to OHKO Eternatus, whereas Earthquake is a weaker STAB option that offers greater accuracy.
  • Will-O-Wisp cripples physical threats Groudon switches into such as Arceus, Koraidon, and physical variants of Arceus-Ground.
  • Spikes helps chip down switch-ins for the rest of the game due to the limited distribution of hazard removal in the tier. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used for the same purpose but Spikes is recommended as it hits all targets neutrally.
  • Groudon tends to struggle against special wallbreakers such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane, so Protect is a great option to scout for a potential Choice item and increase its Leftovers recovery. Alternatively, Bulk Up can be used to beat physical setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Arceus formes and Koraidon.
  • Leftovers is mandatory on Groudon, since it does not have any reliable recovery.
  • Tera Fairy gives Groudon an immunity to Dragon-type attacks from the likes of Miraidon, Eternatus, and Koraidon.
  • Tera Water lets Groudon resist Zacian-C's STAB Behemoth Blade, Calyrex-I's STAB Glacial Lance, and Koraidon's sun-boosted Fire-type attacks.
  • Due to Groudon being unable to reliably check physical threats long-term, it’s best to have some form of speed control such as Choice Scarf Koraidon or a reliable wall such as Skeledirge alongside it.
  • Breakers such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane really appreciate Groudon's ability to reliably set both sun, which boosts their Fire-type attacks, and Spikes, which allows them to wallbreak more effectively. Koraidon also has great synergy with Groudon as they both set sun. It also appreciates Spikes support from Groudon.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance Groudon is a threatening wallbreaker that is able to pressure defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu.
  • Crunch is chosen as the primary coverage move to hit Giratina-O super effectively and also hit Corviknight neutrally. Spikes and Stealth Rock make progress against the switches Groudon forces, but Fire Punch is another option that breaks through Corviknight while also synergizing with Drought and Tera Fire.
  • The given EV spread outspeeds uninvested Giratina-O, Kyogre, and Landorus-T while maximizing bulk and damage output. An alternate spread with 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe and a Jolly nature can be used on Sticky Web teams as a sweeper.
  • Lum Berry can be used to get past Will-O-Wisp users like Arceus and Giratina-O, though this cuts into Groudon's longevity.
  • Tera Ground boosts Groudon's Precipice Blades to absurd levels, letting it OHKO even bulkier variants of Arceus at +2. Tera Fire lets Groudon avoid Will-O-Wisp entirely and powers up Fire Punch but makes it susceptible to being revenge killed by Arceus-Ground and opposing Groudon. Tera Fairy is an option to become immune to Miraidon's and Giratina's Draco Meteor, but the other Tera types are generally preferred thanks to their offensive power.
  • Groudon is best used on bulky offense as an offensive entry hazard setter that can come in on slower Pokemon such as Clodsire, Skeledirge, and Ting-Lu and use them as setup fodder. Groudon forces switches thanks to its power, so use these chances to aggressively set hazards or use Swords Dance.
  • Miraidon is a great partner for being able to pivot Groudon into Clodsire and Ting-Lu while also being able to pressure Groudon's checks like Giratina-O and Corviknight. The two Pokemon also share a check in Arceus-Ground, which they can overwhelm. Koraidon is a similarly good partner for sharing a check in defensive Arceus-Fairy, which they can overwhelm together. Koraidon also can U-turn into Groudon on incoming Skeledirge, which Groudon can use as an opportunity to set hazards or force a defensive Terastallization. Utility Arceus-Fairy can form a hazard stacking core with Groudon while also helping check Giratina-O, Koraidon, and Miraidon. Finally, Arceus-Water, Clodsire, and Eternatus are solid partners, as they all check Kyogre, which cannot switch into Groudon repeatedly but can threaten it out.

sets.name: Setup Attacker
sets.description: Groudon's base stats and STAB on Precipice Blades make it a premier choice for a bulky attacker. Fur Coat allows Groudon to wall many common threats, such as Koraidon and opposing Groudon, while Mold Breaker ignores Fur Coat and Levitate on walls like Eternatus, Arceus-Ghost, and Zamazenta-C. Victory Dance lets it reliably set up on opposing physical attackers like Groudon and Koraidon, whereas Tidy Up removes entry hazards and makes it harder for Imposter users to safely switch in thanks to the lack of a Defense boost. Toxic heavily cripples Precipice Blades switch-ins like Arceus formes and Dondozo, and it works especially well with Mold Breaker, which lets Groudon bait and punish Prankster users. Alternatively, Knock Off removes Heavy-Duty Boots, Leftovers, and Ability Shield from bulkier targets like Dondozo, Eternatus, and opposing Groudon. Earth Plate boosts Precipice Blades's damage, whereas Heavy-Duty Boots leaves Groudon less susceptible to chip damage from Spikes, and Rocky Helmet provides extra security against Population Bomb users like Ursaluna. Groudon's best fit is on balance and offense teams that want to compress a bulky attacker, non-passive wall, and possibly an entry hazard remover into a single teamslot. Teammates like Dondozo and Eternatus are recommended to shore up Groudon's weakness to Palafin-H, with the latter also helping out against Solar Beam Arceus-Fire. Use Corviknight to Imposter-proof Toxic and Mold Breaker Groudon variants, and a Fur Coat user that doesn't mind Knock Off for other variants.

sets.name: Aerilate
sets.description: Rayquaza is a dangerous mixed attacker with very few consistent long-term answers. Tera Flying Boomburst deals absurd damage, OHKOing everything that isn't a special wall or Flying-resistant target and 2HKOing many resistant foes like Corviknight and Dialga-O, provided the latter's Assault Vest has been removed. Extreme Speed helps chase out opposing offensive threats like Flutter Mane and Koraidon; Tera Flying Extreme Speed also 2HKOes Arceus and Zacian. Both coverage moves nuke Steel-types; Collision Course beats Chansey and is easier to Imposter-proof, while Headlong Rush beats Arceus-Electric and Zacian-C and makes offensive Imposter-proofing easier thanks to lowered defenses. Strength Sap helps offset Life Orb recoil and takes advantage of the switches Rayquaza forces, while Jungle Healing allows it to completely nullify Toxic Groudon at the cost of lower healing per use. Rash is used to maximize damage output, while Naive allows Rayquaza to outrun Jolly Groudon and most opposing Rayquaza. Rayquaza offers basically no defensive utility and hates taking status or Knock Off, meaning slow pivoting support from Dondozo and RegenVest users like Dialga-O is mandatory. Entry hazard setters like Zacian and RegenVest users are recommended, as hazards help remove Rayquaza's need to predict and allow it to safely spam Boomburst. Imposter-proof Rayquaza with Ice Scales Arceus formes, Soundproof users, or Zacian-C.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Psychic)
sets.description:
20 Spe EVs lets it outspeed Breloom and Pokemon around that speed tier

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Z-Happy Hour (Psychic)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Psychic)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Kamikaze (Normal)
sets.description:
A great addition to Normal-type teams, Staraptor checks threats such as Choice Band Breloom, Great Tusk, Quaquaval, and non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and provides muscle power against Steel- and Dragon-type teams. Brave Bird makes short work of the aforementioned Fighting-types, as well as bulky Grass-types like Wo-Chien and Amoonguss, and threatens specially defensive Toxapex and Skeledirge with a 2HKO if they switch into it. Close Combat is what gives Staraptor its amazing wallbreaking potential, OHKOing Kingambit, Chien-Pao, Greninja, and Cyclizar while KOing Baxcalibur after Stealth Rock damage and threatening Iron Treads with a 2HKO. Final Gambit, boosted by 28 HP EVs, OHKOes targets Staraptor wouldn't otherwise beat, such as Rotom-W, physically defensive Toxapex, Hatterene, Klefki, and Forretress after Stealth Rock damage—denying dual screens and/or entry hazards from the last two. Alternatively, Double-Edge threatens checks like Rotom-W and Kilowattrel. Finally, U-turn allows this reckless bird to pivot into a teammate, if there really is nothing else it can do, such as against Gholdengo or Corviknight. Equipping a Choice Scarf will let it outspeed Greninja, Flutter Mane, and Walking Wake, which otherwise force it out, and threaten them instead.

A great partner for Staraptor is Hisuian Zoroark. When it uses Illusion to disguise as Staraptor, pairing its Fighting immunity with Staraptor's Ground immunity, an apparent "Staraptor" could be immune to either type. This uncertainty completely dismantles Great Tusk. Furthermore, disguised as Staraptor, it can bait in an unsuspecting Corviknight, Gholdengo, or Dondozo to cripple or OHKO it. Maushold is another great partner thanks to Tidy Up, which keeps both Stealth Rock and Reflect off the field for Staraptor to not worry about. Also, its Population Bomb can break through Ting-Lu and non-Rocky Helmet Toxapex for Staraptor. A less prominent partner that also provides hazard removal, as well as Knock Off support, is Cyclizar. With Stealth Rock breaking Sturdy and further advancing Staraptor's wallbreaking, Blissey is another highly appreciated teammate to set it up, provide Healing Wish and Heal Bell support, and check both Sandy Shocks and Choice Scarf Greninja for Staraptor. Indeedee, likewise, offers Healing Wish support, as well as checking Poison-types like Toxapex and Glimmora that Staraptor struggles with. Lastly, making good use of Staraptor's U-turn, Ditto is a teammate that can turn a bleak situation into a winning one, copying setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Chien-Pao to reverse sweep opponents.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Normal)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Floatzel leverages the nuclear power of its Choice Band Tera Water Wave Crash under rain to be one of the archetype's most potent wallbreakers, capable of 2HKOing even problematic bulky Water-resistant Pokemon like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Amoonguss. Moreover, its naturally high Speed tier alongside Swift Swim lets Floatzel outspeed the whole unboosted metagame under rain, giving it an edge against offensive teams by outpacing and threatening boosted frail threats like Dragapult, Volcarona, and every Speed-boosting Booster Energy Pokemon, such as Iron Valiant, Iron Moth, and Walking Wake. Liquidation is a safer attack to keep Floatzel healthy when Wave Crash's power isn't necessary, such as against weak and neutral targets like Great Tusk, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge, and is the preferred attack to clean up late-game once the opposition is weakened enough. Aqua Jet picks off faster and boosted foes especially if rain isn't active, such as Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Tera Flying Roaring Moon, and outprioritizes Kingambit's Sucker Punch and Ceruledge's Shadow Sneak. Ice Spinner complements Floatzel's STAB moves to reliably hit the likes of Dragonite, Dragapult, Amoonguss, and Water Absorb Clodsire.

Floatzel is exclusively found on offensive rain teams. Pelipper is a mandatory teammate to reliably set rain with Drizzle and compensate for Floatzel's frailty by bringing it in safely via U-turn. Choice Specs variants of Pelipper and other offensive rain partners like Azumarill, Walking Wake, and Greninja can keep up the pressure against the opposition, overwhelming shared checks like Dondozo, Toxapex, and Tera Water Garganacl. Ground-types like Iron Treads, Great Tusk, and Clodsire provide a necessary Electric immunity while setting entry hazards, making Dondozo and Toxapex easier to break through; Iron Treads and Great Tusk also provide Knock Off to cripple the bulky Water-types, including Alomomola and Tera Water Skeledirge, by making them susceptible to Stealth Rock as well, while Water Absorb Clodsire is a rigid defensive backbone against the likes of Azumarill, Walking Wake, and Tera Grass Volcarona, all of which can force Floatzel out. Eject Button Amoonguss can bring Floatzel in safely on Pokemon like Great Tusk, Gholdengo, Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Ting-Lu, incapacitate foes with Spore to give it more wallbreaking opportunities, and switch into and threaten Dondozo and Tera Water Garganacl for Floatzel. Pawmot's Revival Blessing compensates for Floatzel's tendency to faint early-game from Wave Crash recoil—especially against common Rocky Helmet users like Corviknight and Amoonguss—and lets it wallbreak or even clean up in the late-game afterwards and enjoys Floatzel pressuring Great Tusk in return. Kingambit is a stellar late-game cleaner that enjoys Floatzel pressuring its checks in Great Tusk and Volcarona and overwhelming a common answer in Dondozo, as well as takes advantage of Floatzel fainting early-game from Wave Crash recoil to accumulate Supreme Overlord boosts.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Swift Weasel
sets.description:
• Wave Crash: This is your main offensive option. When further boosted by rain, Tera Water, and Choice Band, it becomes one of the most powerful physical moves in the game, 2HKOing the likes of Bold Amoonguss and OHKOing maximum Defense Corviknight. Mystic Water is an option for flexibility but sacrifices the listed KOs.

  • Liquidation versus Waterfall: Liquidation is a secondary option, and it's preferred when facing frailer offensive teams due to the significant recoil drawback of Wave Crash. However, Waterfall is worth considering for its possible flinch chance.

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet allows Floatzel to maintain offensive presence outside of rain, as well as being a great response to opposing priority moves, such as Kingambit's Sucker Punch.

  • Rain Setter: Pelipper's rain is mandatory for both Swift Swim and maximum damage output.

Tera Types

  • Water: Tera Water massively bolters Floatzel's damage output, and the weasel simply doesn't have the bulk needed for more defensive options.

EV Spreads

  • 60 HP / 252 Atk / 196 Spe:196 Speed EVs are used to outspeed the entire tier in rain, including Choice Scarf Dragpault.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: Maximum Speed investment outspeeds Hydreigon and Mimikyu outside of rain, in addition to tying with Salamence, at the cost of having less buffer HP for Wave Crash recoil.

sets.name: Rain Wallbreaker
sets.description: Floatzel is an incredible wallbreaker on rain teams, making use of its decent Attack stat powered by its Choice Band. Low Kick hits Ferrothorn and Ice Spinner hits Dragapult and Dragonite more reliably. However, because of Tera Water, its Water-type moves are all boosted considerably, so coverage is often unnecessary. Aqua Jet gives Floatzel priority outside of rain against weakened targets such as Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny, and it bypasses Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Tornadus-T and Zapdos all appreciate Floatzel's offensive capabilities, as it deals with wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Mega Diancie, Gholdengo, Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Valiant. Zapdos can reliably check Water-types that counter Floatzel like Slowbro and Dondozo. Tornadus-T can weaken and cripple Floatzel checks in Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Ferrothorn, as Knock Off removes Leftovers from them, making it easier for Floatzel to wallbreak. Offensive partners like Manaphy and Mega Swampert can overwhelm those same Water-resistant Pokemon as well as Dragonite. Ferrothorn can check priority users such as the aforementioned Dragonite and Kingambit, alleviating Floatzel's weakness to them.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Gastrodon's solid bulk and incredible defensive typing make it one of the better specially defensive walls and hazard setters in the tier. It's able to check Pokemon like Gengar, Iron Jugulis, Salamence, and Kilowattrel and set up hazards against other hazard setters like Hippowdon and Sandy Shocks to help wear down Pokemon like Wo-Chien and Tinkaton. Stealth Rock should only be used as Gastrodon's hazard of choice if it cannot be fit onto another team member. Sludge Bomb and Ice Beam both help to take care of Grass-types like Wo-Chien and Tsareena. Sludge Bomb poisons hinders Alomomola and Slowbro, while Ice Beam also serves as an effective way of hitting Dragon-types like Salamence, Noivern, and Haxorus. Surf can be used as an alternative to hit Hippowdon harder and force Talonflame out more reliably. Storm Drain allows Gastrodon to counter rain by absorbing on Water-type attacks from Floatzel and Barraskewda as well as from other threats like Paldean Tauros-W and Tatsugiri while giving a boost to Gastrodon's attacks, though Gastrodon must Terastallize in order to handle the Paldean Tauros-W's Close Combat. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Gastrodon from getting worn down by hazards. Covert Cloak makes Gastrodon a hard counter to Grafaiai, and makes it able to answer Pokemon like Gengar and Iron Jugulis more reliably by ignoring secondary effects from their moves. Tera Ghost lets Gastrodon spinblock Quaquaval and Tsareena while letting it wall Fighting-types like Slither Wing, Lucario, and the aforementioned Quaquaval, though it does become weaker to Gengar. Tera Poison removes Gastrodon's Grass weakness, gives it a valuable immunity to Toxic that lets it switch in on Quagsire's Toxic and Toxic Spikes, and powers up its Sludge Bomb, allowing it to 3HKO Brambleghast and 2HKO Tsareena. Tera Electric allows Gastrodon to completely blank Kilowattrel and resist Hurricane from Salamence.

Gastrodon works best on hazard stack, balance, and bulky offense teams that appreciate its defensive utility. Stealth Rock setters like Tyranitar and Tinkaton allow Gastrodon to free up a moveslot to run Spikes. Gastrodon struggles greatly against Grass-types without Terastallizing, so Pokemon that can deal with them, such as Talonflame, Slither Wing, and Salamence make good teammates. Gastrodon struggles to handle strong wallbreakers like Lucario, Dragon Dance Salamence, and Pawmot, so it pairs well with Pokemon like Wo-Chien, Scream Tail, and Hippowdon that can check these breakers more reliably, though the former must Terastallize to do so. Wallbreakers like Pawmot, Iron Jugulis, and Choice Specs Gengar greatly appreciate the hazards that Gastrodon sets up, as it makes it easier for them to break through bulkier foes like Hippowdon and opposing Gastrodon.

sets.name: The Slug (Ground)
sets.description:
Gastrodon's great bulk, typing, and ability allow it to function as a sturdy mixed wall and check to Water-types for Ground teams, letting Clodsire use Unaware. Earth Power targets Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Skeledirge, while Earthquake deals more damage to Clodsire and Flutter Mane. Ice Beam hits Dragonite, Garchomp, and Kilowattrel. Alternatively, Clear Smog may be used to prevent Espathra and Dondozo from setting up, while Chilling Water eases matchups against physical attackers such as Quaquaval, Scizor, and Iron Treads. Stealth Rock and Spikes are interchangeable depending on what its teammate Ting-Lu is using. Gastrodon prefers maximum Defense investment to check Pokemon like Barraskewda and Quaquaval; however, an EV spread of 252 HP / 68 Def / 188 SpD with a Bold nature can be used to prevent a 2HKO from Choice Specs Greninja's Ice Beam.

Gastrodon's immunity to Water-type attacks and ability to set entry hazards is heavily appreciated by Clodsire, Great Tusk, and Garchomp. Clodsire completes the hazard stack core with Toxic Spikes and answers threats such as Meowscarada and Flutter Mane as well as setup sweepers like Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Gholdengo due to Unaware.
