In return, Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks deals with fast threats such as Choice Specs Greninja, Flutter Mane, and Scovillain, while Iron Hands pressures matchups such as Dark and Dragon due to its sheer bulk and coverage in Ice Punch. Pawmot can revive Rotom-W with Revival Blessing, which allows it to take more risks. Additionally, Pawmot has good coverage moves in Seed Bomb and Ice Punch, which lets it break down types such as Water, Flying, and Ground alongside Rotom-W. Choice Specs Kilowattrel deals with fast threats such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant, Choice Specs Greninja, and Volcarona, removes Grass-types like Amoonguss and Breloom, and pivots Rotom-W in with Volt Switch or U-turn. Assault Vest users such as Magnezone and Eelektross deal with special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Hatterene, and Greninja for Rotom-W they also tend to invite in passive Pokemon, which provide it more setup opportunities.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Electric)
sets.description:
48 Speed EVs outspeeds Azumarill.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Water)
sets.description:
Outspeeds Adamant Scizor, 144 HP alongside 112 Def lets its Substitute not be broken by Clodsire's Poison Jab.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Rotom-W's Speed access to Volt Switch and great typing make it an excellent pivot and revenge killer.

  • Trick and Neutral Natures: If using a Choice Item, Trick is seriously worth considering for its ability to cripple defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Dondozo. Make sure Rotom-W is a neutral nature that has had a Timid Mint used on it. This way, Rotom-W can eat any Berry without getting confused.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Rotom-W's excellent typing means its fully functional without Terastallizing, but thanks to Levitate, it's still a powerful user of it.

  • Fairy: When combined with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type lets Rotom-W take on Chien-Pao Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon far more effectively.

  • Electric: Not only does the damage boost from Tera Electric come in handy, but it also removes any weaknesses Rotom-W has.

  • Ghost: Terastallizing back to its Ghost-type roots gives Rotom-W a vast array of immunities, helping against Dragonite and Great Tusk in particular. It also makes Shadow Ball viable for picking off Ghost-types with Choice Scarf.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs tends to be safer to Trick than Choice Scarf, and it gives a big power boost.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-W outspeed major threats such as Iron Bundle, Chi-Yu, and Chien-Pao.

  • Assault Vest: Increasing Rotom-W's special bulk gives it a far better matchup against foes like Flutter Mane, Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Gholdengo.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: This spread sacrifices Rotom-W's revenge killing potential, but, in exchange, it makes it a better pivot, and the better bulk makes Rotom-W more suited to finding the right time to cripple a wall with Trick.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Rotom-W's Special Attack is part of what makes it an effective revenge killer if using a Choice Scarf.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 108 SpA / 140 SpD / 4 Spe with Calm: This spread is meant for Assault Vest, letting Rotom-W avoid a 3HKO from Modest Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
• Levitate and excellent status moves make Rotom-W a clean choice for a bulky pivot!

  • Foul Play: Foul Play is essential for hitting Baxcalibur hard, since it's immunity to burns would otherwise let it set up on Rotom-W.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Thunder Wave: Will-O-Wisp's ability to cripple top-tier physically offensive threats such as Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Scizor as well as punish the otherwise problematic Iron Hands makes it the best support option. However, Thunder Wave does provide additional insurance against Baxcalibur and punishes special attackers such as Flutter Mane.

  • Hydro Pump: Hydro Pump gives Rotom-W offensive presence against foes that don't care about the rest of the moveset, like Garganacl, Chi-Yu, Volcarona, and Skeledirge.

Other Options

  • Discharge: Giving Rotom-W an Electric STAB attack to better deal with Flying-types like Corviknight and Tera Flying Roaring Moon is useful, but it can be tricky to fit into the set.

  • Hex: If using Tera Ghost, Hex gives Rotom-W a much fiercer offensive kick than usual after inflicting status.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Defensive Rotom-W works fine without Terastallizing, but some Tera types do make it harder to break through.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Rotom-W an incredible defensive typing, vastly improving its matchups against Pokemon that rely on Ground-type coverage such as Dragonite, Baxcalibur, and Garchomp. It also provides a useful Freeze-Dry resistance against Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy guards against fearsome powerful Dark, Dragon, and Fighting attacks that Rotom-W can have trouble handling and lets it use Tera Blast to hit Dragonite and Chien-Pao hard.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost offers Rotom-W a vast array of immunities with Levitate, enabling it to defeat certain Dragonite sets and do much better against Iron Hands and Iron Valiant when Rotom-W lacks Will-O-Wisp. Being a Ghost-type also prevents Rotom-W from getting trapped, letting it escape faster trappers without Volt Switch.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry will turn many powerful, unboosted attacks such as Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao's Crunch, Dragonite's Outrage and Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush into 3HKOs. Just make sure to run an even HP stat so that Sitrus Berry activates with one use of Ruination.

  • Leftovers: If Sitrus Berry is already in use, Leftovers is a reasonable alternative.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet's extra chip damage can make Rotom-W a less passive pivot.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• With a great typing, ability, and good bulk, Rotom-W makes for an effective user of Nasty Plot.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: This move is essential for getting past Dragon-types like Dragapult and Roaring Moon. Even when not Terastallized, it's a decent coverage move.

  • Hydro Pump versus Substitute: Hydro Pump is by far Rotom-W's strongest STAB, but it can be worth sacrificing for Substitute, which lets Rotom-W effectively defeat most Garganacl and defensive Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While this Rotom-W can sweep on its own, Terastallization can prevent revenge kills from the likes of Iron Bundle.
  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Rotom-W can turn the tables on its Dragon-type adversaries, as well as catch Crunch Chien-Pao off guard.

Items

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Rotom-W easily set up on Hippowdon, and avoid getting put to sleep by Dondozo.

  • Sitrus Berry: If Sleep isn't a big issue, Rotom-W appreciates the burst recovery Sitrus Berry provides. Make sure to run an even HP stat so it activates after Rotom-W gets hit by Ruination once.

  • Covert Cloak: If using Hydro Pump, this is Rotom-W's best way around Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: Maximizing Speed with a Timid nature gives Rotom-W the jump on Gholdengo. If Gholdengo isn't an issue, a Modest nature will still outspeed Jolly Breloom.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: Rotom-W's good bulk can be maximized instead of outspeeding Breloom; this spread avoids the 2HKO from Timid Gholdengo's Shadow Ball.

  • 244 HP / 180 Def / 84 SpA with Bold: This Sitrus Berry optimized spread avoids a 2HKO from Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao and Timid Flutter Mane.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Rotom-W can either serve as a strong offensive pivot, revenge killer, and potential late-game cleaner with Choice Scarf or as an immediately powerful wallbreaker with Choice Specs. With its dangerous type combination, it dissuades Pokemon that are immune to Water-type attacks such as Desolate Land Iron Moth from switching in through its powerful Electric-type moves while Hydro Pump scares off Ground-types like Ting-Lu. Hadron Engine affords a powerful boost to all its attacks, while Primordial Sea boosts its Water-type attacks even further and grants it an immunity to Fire. Trick and Will-O-Wisp allow Rotom-W to cripple and irritate defensive switch-ins such as Blissey and RegenVest Roaring Moon, while Will-O-Wisp can also provide utility against offensive threats such as Meowscarada. Volt Switch allows Rotom-W to pivot on and maintain momentum against common defensive answers like Regenerator Roaring Moon and pairs well with offensive threats like Choice Band Slither Wing and Chien-Pao. Rotom-W also can partner well with other powerful special threats like Hydreigon and Hadron Engine Iron Moth, which can combine with it to overload common special walls. Being mainly an offensive pivot, Rotom-W also appreciates entry hazard removal from the likes of Iron Treads and Corviknight, which both double as pivots that allow Rotom-W to safely get in.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Rotom-W is an excellent defensive pivot that can take on dangerous attackers such as Palafin, Scizor, and Iron Treads and generate momentum with Volt Switch. While Scald offers more PP and reliability, Steam Eruption OHKOes Great Tusk after Stealth Rock and improves Rotom-W's overall offensive presence. Will-O-Wisp hinders physical attackers more reliably than Scald. Alternatively, Apple Acid breaks down defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl, while Haze neutralizes slow setup sweepers such as Scizor and Freeze-Dry hits Dragon-types like Dragonite and Garchomp super effectively. Roost provides consistent recovery, while Strength Sap makes Rotom-W more effective against physical attackers such as Great Tusk and Chien-Pao, but leaves it unable to recover against Gholdengo. The given Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed Jolly Azumarill and uninvested Great Tusk, but more Speed can be run to handle certain threats; 224 Speed outspeeds Palafin, while 240 Speed with a Timid nature outpaces Gholdengo. Tera Steel allows Rotom-W to more easily pivot into Toxapex and take on Dragon-types such as Garchomp. Alternatively, Tera Electric strengthens Volt Switch and makes Rotom-W less vulnerable to Salt Cure. Rotom-W appreciates partners that can pivot such as Ting-Lu, Slither Wing, and Corviknight. Physical walls like Garganacl and Skeledirge after Terastallizing can take on many of the physical attackers that Rotom-W cannot handle, such as Roaring Moon. Powerful offensive Pokemon such as Roaring Moon, Iron Valiant, and Iron Treads appreciate Rotom-W's ability to pivot them into battle.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Rotom-W is a stupendously effective pivot on teams because its great defensive profile allows it to check a laundry list of threats like Mega Swampert, Tornadus-T, and Mega Scizor. Volt Switch lets Rotom-W start the spin cycle, pivoting out on opposing threats that it lures in like Ferrothorn and Dragapult, helping to position teammates favorably. Hydro Pump is a fantastic complement to Volt Switch, leaving Ground-types like Great Tusk and Landorus-T out to dry. Will-O-Wisp neutralizes physical sweepers like Mega Scizor, Kingambit, and Dragonite, hampering their hopes to use Rotom-W as setup fodder. Pain Split provides Rotom-W longevity in conjunction with Leftovers, but Defog can be used for entry hazard control, as Rotom-W easily folds common Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Despite this, Rotom-W struggles to remove entry hazards against offensive setters like Garchomp and often misses the recovery that Pain Split offers. Tera Ghost improves Rotom-W’s matchup against the likes of Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Mega Medicham while letting it spinblock against Great Tusk. Tera Steel gives Rotom-W a Toxic immunity and valuable resistances, improving its prospects against the likes of Kartana, Clodsire, and Toxapex. Strong wallberakers like Dragapult, Heatran, and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T all appreciate Rotom-W positioning them against walls like Ferrothorn, Gholdengo, and Dragonite. Iron Valiant likes Rotom-W luring out Dragon-types like Dragapult and Dragonite. Teammates such as Volcarona, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor can check Grass-types for Rotom-W as well. Notably, Mega Scizor forms a great VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, as Mega Scizor irons out threats that Rotom-W has trouble with like Kartana, Weavile, and Tapu Lele, while Rotom-W can deal with common Mega Scizor checks such as Zapdos and Skeledirge.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Rotom-W functions as a shockingly potent pivot, as a lightning-quick Volt Switch allows it to reliably create big surges of momentum for teammates. Will-O-Wisp reliably chips down bulkier threats like Mega Scizor and Garchomp while also surprising faster physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny. Thunder Wave is an option that can pour a cold water onto a sea of speedy sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Kartana, slowing them down. Trick stifles walls like Ferrothorn and Gastrodon who could otherwise stem the tide of Rotom-W’s momentum. Choice Scarf Rotom-W should not be Terastalizing in most cases, but a Steel or Ghost typing can be situationally useful against prominent metagame forces such as Great Tusk and Tapu Lele. Other pivots such as Mega Scizor, Tornadus-T, and Victini can create formidable VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W. Victini in particular deals with Grass-types like Ferrothorn and Kartana, while Rotom-W can threaten physically defensive walls such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Strong wallbreakers like Heatran, Iron Valiant, and Mega Medicham pair swimmingly with Rotom-W, as they plow through common defensive staples such as Gastrodon and Ferrothorn and benefit from Rotom-W pivoting them into advantageous positions.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot (Electric)
sets.description: With its access to Levitate, Rotom-W is nearly mandatory on all Electric teams. Its Ground immunity and Water-type resistance make Pokemon like Mega Swampert unable to bother it; it also has access to Hydro Pump to hit annoying Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Hippowdon. Rotom-W is also a really good blanket check to Ice- and Fire-types like Mamoswine, Victini, and Galarian Darmanitan. Volt Switch provides great momentum, which is needed in hyper offense teams. In addition to providing momentum, Rotom-W has access to Will-O-Wisp and Toxic, crippling foes such as Mega Garchomp and Mimikyu with Will-O-Wisp, while Toxic punishes switch-ins such as Gastrodon and Kyurem. Defog lets Rotom-W compress roles, freeing up Zapdos to run Choice Specs, while Rotom-W prevents hazards from hurting teammates. Pain Split is another option, as it massively improves Rotom-W's longevity; however, this requires Zapdos to run Defog. The 44 invested Speed EVs ensure Rotom-W outspeeds Jolly Azumarill so that it can punish Azumarill for setting up Belly Drum with Will-O-Wisp or Volt Switch. Zapdos covers Rotom-W's weakness to Grass-types with access to Hurricane and Heat Wave, being able to OHKO the likes of Mega Venusaur and Ferrothorn, respectively, while also being immune to Mold Breaker Excadrill's Earthquake. Regieleki can be used as a Rapid Spinner, removing pressure from Rotom-W to function as the only hazard removal while also luring in Ground-types that Rotom-W can punish such as Iron Treads or Great Tusk. With access to Taunt and having an amazing Speed tier, Zeraora can prevent hazards from coming up and allow Rotom-W to switch in freely and get off a strong Hydro Pump or gain a lot of momentum and Volt Switch into one of its offensive teammates. Zeraora also pressures Hydreigon and Gholdengo, which can use Rotom-W as setup fodder. Iron Hands provides the coverage and bulk against Pokemon like Dragon Dance Dragonite, Volcarona, and SubRoost Kyurem that Rotom-W can't deal with while also putting a lot of pressure on Normal teams, as Rotom-W can Volt Switch against Blissey into Iron Hands and force Blissey to tank a hit or switch out. Alolan Raichu gives Rotom-W's slow Volt Switch a lot of value as it is strong but frail, being able to deal with Ice-types like Baxcalibut with Focus Blast and Poison-types like Mega Venusaur and Clodsire with Psyshock. Magnezone provides a valuable Poison immunity while also checking other threats like Tapu Lele, Meowscarada, and Alolan Ninetales.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Rotom-F is a premier wallbreaker in the PU tier thanks to its decent Speed and great offensive and utility options, allowing it to become a great nuisance for most teams. Its unresisted STAB combination hits the entire tier for at least neutral damage, and its typing in conjunction with Levitate allows it to come in on weaker Pokemon such as defensive Misdreavus, Whiscash, and Gogoat. Will-O-Wisp cripples defensive Pokemon such as Tinkatuff and Perrserker, though Discharge is another option that trades Thunderbolt's damage output for a 30% paralysis chance, which can support a late-game cleaner such as Alolan Persian. Lastly, Volt Switch grants Rotom-F the ability to pivot out of unfavorable matchups such as against Carbink and Crabominable. Substitute can be utilized instead since Rotom-Frost is normally able to force out switch-ins rather efficiently due to its great offensive typing, becoming a terrifying sweeper with the addition of Terastallization. Tera Electric grants Rotom-F an even higher damage output on its main STAB move. Tera Ghost and Tera Water remove its weaknesses to Fighting and Fire-types such as Crabominable and Charizard, respectively.

Thanks to its multitude of options and offensive potential, Rotom-F functions best on offensive and balance teams that appreciate a wallbreaker that’s able to cripple special walls for a late-game cleaner. Alolan Persian and Haunter appreciate Rotom-F’s ability to break through, weaken, or cripple walls such as Gogoat and Carbink. Whiscash is a great defensive teammate for Rotom-F, able to switch in on threats such as Pyroar, Charizard, and Alolan Dugtrio. In return, Rotom-F threatens Grass-types such as Gogoat and Leafeon. Frail wallbreakers such as Basculin and Dugtrio appreciate being brought in safely through Rotom-F's Volt Switch. VoltTurn cores with Perrserker and Honchkrow should also be considered due to the great offensive synergy these Pokemon provide against common defensive cores.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Rotom-F's good Speed stat allows it to outspeed common threats and Choice Scarf users such as +1 Masquerain and Lycanroc-N. Its coveted BoltBeam STAB combination, fast Volt Switch, and Spikes immunity make it one of the most potent revenge killers in the tier. Trick allows Rotom-F to cripple specially defensive walls that would otherwise check it such as Tinkatuff, as well as Pokemon that rely on Heavy-Duty Boots to be effective, such as Masquerain. Rotom-F has many options for its third moveslot. Discharge can be used as an Electric-type STAB without needing to switch out while also being able to fish for paralysis, Will-O-Wisp can spread burn to physical attackers such as Gogoat and Skuntank, and Nasty Plot can allow Rotom-F to become a terrifying setup sweeper after using Trick. Rotom-F also has many viable Tera type options, with Electric being the most common, to boost its power while shedding Ice-type's annoying weaknesses to common Rock, Fire, and Fighting moves. However, Tera Ghost can be used to be immune to common Fighting-type attacks such as Carbink's Body Press and Crabominable's Close Combat, while Tera Water gives a valuable resistance to Fire-type attacks while generally being a good defensive typing.

Rotom-F's weakness to Stealth Rock can be an issue, so entry hazard control from Pokemon such as Dartrix and Quaxwell can be useful. Water- and Ground-types such as Whiscash, Gabite, and Camerupt can switch into the Fire- and Rock-types such as Charizard and Carbink that can otherwise threaten out Rotom-F. Pokemon such as Carbink and Tinkatuff can switch into foes that Rotom-F would otherwise have a hard time breaking through on its own, such as Tera Steel Dachsbun, opposing Tinkatuff, and Ampharos. Wish users such as Leafeon and Dachsbun can use Wish before switcihing to Rotom-F, allowing it to alleviate Stealth Rock damage. Dachsbun can also dissuade Fire-types from clicking Fire-type moves thanks to Well-Baked Body and can check Carbink depending on Carbink's moveset. Gogoat can check Whiscash and Raichu, allowing Rotom-F to use Volt Switch more easily while Rotom-F can pressure or cripple Gogoat's checks, such as Misdreavus. U-turn users such as Alolan Persian, Perrserker, and Flapple can form a VoltTurn combination with Rotom-F. Perrserker can also provide entry hazards with Stealth Rock, making it harder for Rotom-F's checks to switch in safely, and can threaten out Pokemon such as Carbink and Tinkatuff that would otherwise annoy Rotom-F.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Offensive Setup
sets.description:
Mesprit is an amazing setup sweeper because it has great coverage and Substitute to shield it from crippling utility moves like Toxic, Thunder Wave, and Trick. Nasty Plot allows Mesprit to be more immediately threatening, while Calm Mind lets it tank more special attacks and take advantage of Substitute and Stored Power more. Even though Dazzling Gleam is stronger than Draining Kiss, the latter is preferred for longevity, but Dazzling Gleam 2HKOes Appletun, Umbreon, and, with Tera Fairy, Hisuian Qwilfish at +2 after Stealth Rock. Stored Power lets Mesprit be even more threatening over time as you amass more boosts, but Mystical Power gives it a decent attacking move right off the bat that can help you steamroll teams by just attacking. Psyshock helps beat special walls like Articuno, Blissey, and Muk more easily as well as setup sweepers like Vivillon and Lilligant that can boost Special Defense. Tera Fairy lets Mesprit turn would-be checks in Dark-types such as Umbreon and Bombirdier into setup fodder, even letting it use Substitute on their attacks.

Mesprit is checked by special walls and Dark-types alike, so checks such as Bombirdier, Toxicroak, and Scyther pair greatly alongside it. Because faster physical attackers like Bruxish and Scyther easily threaten Mesprit out, physical walls like Lurantis, Avalugg, and Sandaconda work as amazing partners. Encore from Sableye, Cacturne, or Alolan Raichu can be quite annoying for Mesprit to deal with, as these Pokemon can lock Mesprit into a non-damaging move and then whittle it down. To combat this, Dark-types to beat them like Bombirdier and Hisuian Qwilfish are good teammates that can also cripple the opposing team with Knock Off, entry hazards, and status conditions.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
After donning a Choice Scarf, Mesprit becomes an excellent revenge killer that beats common threats like Samurott, Toxicroak, and Hisuian Sneasel. Psyshock 2HKOes Cryogonal while also letting Mesprit beat down special walls that love to come in on it, while Psychic can be used instead to let you take care of Pokemon like Sandaconda and Avalugg. Mystical Power with Choice Scarf is a powerful combination on Mesprit, letting it become a revenge killer that can easily spiral out of control and beat weakened teams. Trick helps with crippling walls like Blissey and Articuno that Mesprit draws in and helps it check bulky setup sweepers like Ursaring and Eelektross. Healing Wish can be used instead to help bring a teammate that has longevity issues back to full or give a setup sweeper another chance like Assault Vest Eelektross, Tauros, or Bruxish. Tera Fairy helps Mesprit revenge kill Toxicroak and Cacturne more safely, as it then resists Sucker Punch. Also, STAB Dazzling Gleam lets Mesprit muscle past Dark-types far more consistently.

Hisuian Qwilfish is the best Mesprit answer in the tier, so Pokemon like Bruxish, Froslass, and Appletun that can draw it in and force meaningful damage onto it are important teammates to have. Choice Scarf Mesprit pairs nicely with Choice Band wallbreakers like Hisuian Sneasel and Medicham because, with U-turn, Mesprit can pivot them in versus special walls and Dark-types. All of Mesprit's checks heavily rely on their items, like Blissey, Hisuian Qwilfish, and Eelektross, so Knock Off from teammates such as Samurott, Bombirdier, and Sableye especially helps it to clean late-game. Healing Wish pairs well with Life Orb Samurott, Tauros, and Choice Band Bruxish, as they tend to have poor longevity—a second chance for a setup sweepers like Eelektross and Swords Dance Hisuian Sneasel is also highly appreciated.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Lead
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Dialga-O is a reliable specially defensive pivot. Revelation Dance lets it reliably threaten Arceus-Fairy and invalidates Normalize Flutter Mane, whereas Draco Meteor can OHKO Palkia-O. Nuzzle spreads paralysis and discourages faster threats like Zamazenta-C from switching in. U-turn allows Dialga-O to safely bring in teammates thanks to its low Speed. Stone Axe's Stealth Rock help make offensive threats more dangerous; alternatively, Knock Off removes items like Heavy-Duty Boots, Covert Cloak, and Imposter Chansey's Eviolite. Dialga-O's best fit is on balance teams that appreciate a non-passive slow pivot and a reliable source of paralysis. Offensive threats like Groudon, Flutter Mane, and Palkia-O are recommended to take maximum advantage of Dialga-O's slow U-turn; Dialga-O can also Imposter-proof the latter two. Imposter-proofing Dialga-O is normally done with a bulky Covert Cloak user like Arceus-Water or Groudon. Tera Fairy grants a Dragon immunity and makes Revelation Dance Fairy-type, improving Dialga-O's matchup against Koraidon and Palkia-O.

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: Ice Scales Dialga-O is a robust special wall that can tank hits from most of the special attackers in the tier. Draco Meteor OHKOes the two most common special attackers in Palkia-O and Eternatus, and it also prevents specially-frail targets like Dondozo and Groudon from switching in safely. Toxic annoys bulky defensive Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Arceus formes, notably invalidating most setup variants of the latter, and it also prevents Fairy-types like Zacian from switching in freely. Parting Shot lets Dialga-O safely pivot in offensive teammates and can be cycled alongside a Prankster user to safely rack up Toxic damage; alternatively, Teleport allows Dialga-O to use 252 Speed EVs and moves after Ting-Lu's U-turn, which helps get dangerous wallbreakers like Koraidon and Enamorus in safe from utility moves like Knock Off and Nuzzle. Moonlight and Recover are largely the same, though Moonlight benefits from sun, whereas Recover is more consistent. Ice Scales Dialga-O's best fit is on balance teams that want a reliable, non-passive special wall and a slow pivot. Fairy-types like Zacian are recommended as backup checks for Tera Dragon + Dragon Energy attackers like Palkia-O, which can break past Dialga-O after Nasty Plot. Teammates like Primordial Sea Corviknight and Fur Coat Arceus-Fire are recommended to shore up Dialga-O's weakness to Pixilate Enamorus, which can threaten to 2HKO it with V-create or Headlong Rush. Tera Fairy grants a Dragon immunity and drops the Ground weakness, allowing Dialga-O to check Arceus-Ground, Palkia-O, and Enamorus in a pinch, even though it must watch out for the former's Toxic. Dialga-O Imposter-proofs itself thanks to its Toxic immunity, but it can be hard to prevent the foe from healing; pivoting to an offensive teammate like Choice Band Groudon or Koraidon is recommended to take advantage of this.

sets.name: Nasty Plot Sweeper
sets.description: Nasty Plot Palkia-O is a terrifying sweeper thanks to its brutally powerful STAB combination and good Speed. A Timid nature guarantees that Palkia-O outspeeds and threatens to OHKO almost all Arceus. Steam Eruption provides more consistent damage output and a potential burn, while Water Spout has potentially higher damage, won't miss, and can OHKO Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy after Nasty Plot and Spikes. Strength Sap is necessary to keep Dragon Energy and Water Spout's damage high as well as to allow Palkia-O greater freedom to switch in. Tera Dragon allows Dragon Energy to OHKO Dondozo and +4 Dragon Energy to OHKO Ice Scales Dialga-O, while Tera Water lets Palkia-O withstand Fairy-type attacks from users like Arceus-Fairy and Zacian. Palkia-O's best fit is on offense teams that can maximize the opportunities it gets and can easily pressure faster threats like Koraidon. Prankster and Ice Scales Chansey are complete counters for Palkia-O, as they are never threatened by its attacks and make Strength Sap worthless; as such, mixed attacking teammates like Enamorus and Triple Arrows Arceus-Ghost are highly recommended. Imposter-proof Palkia-O with a Desolate Land Arceus-Fairy or Ice Scales Chansey.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
With its unique typing and high stats all around the board, Heatran makes for a bulky attacker able to threaten all kinds of Pokemon in the tier. Magma Storm allows Heatran to trap and potentially remove opposing Pokemon, as well as chipping them down with its passive damage. Earth Power hits Toxapex and Fire-types such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, Volcanion, and opposing Heatran for super effective damage. Taunt can be used to stop Toxapex's Recover and Galarian Slowking's Chilly Reception and Slack Off, thus allowing Heatran to trap them. Heatran is an effective Stealth Rock user thanks to its good matchup against common entry hazard removal options in Defog Corviknight and bulky Court Change Cinderace. Tera Blast Grass gives Heatran a way to hit Water-types such as Rotom-W, Hisuian Samurott, and Azumarill, as well as threatening a OHKO against Great Tusk. Furthermore, Tera Grass works well with Flash Fire and turns Heatran's Ground and Water weaknesses into resistances, improving its matchup against the aforementioned Pokemon as well as Volcanion and letting it potentially trap the likes of Dondozo and Clodsire. Leftovers lets Heatran heal throughout the game and makes it easier for it to trap its targets. Air Balloon is another option that allows Heatran to take a hit from Pokemon that would usually target it with Earthquake or Earth Power such as Enamorus, Ursaluna, and opposing Heatran and heavily damage them. The matchup against opposing Heatran also makes a Timid nature desirable to outspeed the other and hit it with Earth Power; it also lets Heatran outspeed the likes of Modest Gholdengo and Volcanion. Alternatively, Heatran can opt to run a Modest nature to further boost its power.

Heatran usually finds itself on bulky offense teams due to its ability to threaten defensive Pokemon and common forms of entry hazard control. Kingambit appreciates Heatran's support against Will-O-Wisp users in Cinderace, Dragapult, and Moltres and its ability to take on walls such as Corviknight as well as Dondozo and Great Tusk if Terastallized. Heatran's ability to force heavy damage against Amoonguss, Hatterene, and defensive Zapdos makes it a good Great Tusk partner. Great Tusk, in turn, provides Rapid Spin support to keep the field clear from entry hazards, which Heatran tends to get worn down by. Zapdos can defensively check Fighting-types that outspeed Heatran, such as Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, Sneasler, and offensive Great Tusk, as well as Hisuian Samurott, which tends to use Heatran as an opportunity to fire off Ceaseless Edge. Enamorus is also able to check Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Hisuian Samurott, though it struggles to safely switch into them consistently due to its lesser bulk. Dragapult can threaten the Dragon-types that don't take much damage from Heatran's attacks, such as Dragonite, Walking Wake, and Garchomp. Furthermore, its Water resistance and Fighting immunity let it answer Volcanion and Zamazenta aiming to KO Heatran. Lastly, Rillaboom's ability to summon Grassy Terrain via Grassy Surge provides Heatran with extra passive recovery, boosts the power of its Tera Blast Grass, and weakens the damage it takes from Earthquake, letting Heatran survive physically defensive Great Tusk's Earthquake from full health.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Heatran's natural high bulk and decent typing make it a solid wall able to shrug off resisted and weaker neutral hits and, in conjunction with Flash Fire, take on the likes of Iron Moth and bulky Cinderace. Magma Storm is a strong STAB move that lets it potentially trap the likes of Toxapex and Galarian Slowking, and which even Fire-resistant foes such as Garchomp and Rotom-W can struggle against due to its passive damage. Taunt allows Heatran to block status moves such as Toxapex's Recover and Galarian Slowking's Chilly Reception. Alternatively, Protect can be used to gain extra Leftovers recovery, deal further damage with Magma Storm, and scout Choice item users such as Dragapult, Enamorus, and Zamazenta. Earth Power provides a way for Heatran to dent Fire-types such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, and opposing Heatran, and it lets Heatran continuously chip Toxapex and Galarian Slowking to more easily remove them after having trapped them. Stealth Rock is used to take advantage of its good matchup against hazard control options such as Hatterene, Corviknight, and bulky Cinderace. Tera Blast Grass is an alternative that lets Heatran threaten the likes of Rotom-W and Hisuian Samurott. Lastly, Will-O-Wisp is another option that allows Heatran to punish Dragonite, Garchomp, and Roaring Moon trying to switch in, as well as Kingambit aiming to revenge kill Heatran with Sucker Punch. The set opts for near maximum Special Defense investment with enough Speed EVs to outspeed Adamant Kingambit and Azumarill. The 4 Defense EVs in conjunction with maximum HP allows Heatran to always survive an Earthquake from Clodsire from full health. Tera Grass's benefits go beyond the Tera Blast coverage, as it also gives Heatran a resistance to Water- and Ground-type attacks, which expands its range of Pokemon it can trap to include Dondozo, Clodsire, and Garganacl. Tera Grass also synergizes beautifully with Flash Fire, as it removes the potential weakness to Fire-type attacks. Tera Flying is another option that gets rid of Heatran's weakness to Fighting- and Ground-type attacks, notably improving its matchup against Great Tusk and Landorus-T. Dragapult appreciates Heatran's ability to switch into Choice Scarf Gholdengo's Shadow Ball, Choice Scarf Enamorus's Moonblast, and opposing Dragapult's STAB moves. Great Tusk is another Pokemon that appreciates Heatran's support against said special attackers, as well as against Zapdos, Amoonguss, and Hatterene, and in turn it is able to keep Heatran healthy by removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Heatran and Toxapex make for a solid defensive core thanks to the former's ability to take on Hatterene, Zapdos, and Gholdengo that annoy Toxapex, and the latter's resistance to Fighting- and Water-type moves that aim to target Heatran such as Close Combat from Iron Valiant, Sneasler, and Zamazenta, Walking Wake's Hydro Steam, and Greninja's Hydro Pump.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Steel)
sets.description:
Specially defensive Heatran is an invaluable part of any Steel team. It is a fantastic check to many metagame staples that Steel would greatly struggle to otherwise deal with, such as Volcarona, Corviknight, Skeledirge, Zapdos, and Iron Moth. It serves Steel teams consistently well even outside of these problem matchups due to its great natural bulk, plethora of useful resistances including a crucial immunity to Fire via Flash Fire, and utility for its team through its access to Stealth Rock and capacity to spread burns.

Lava Plume is Heatran’s primary attacking move, which not only hits neutral targets hard due to Heatran’s naturally good Special Attack but also has a 30% chance to burn foes. Fire’s nature as an attacking type that has no natural immunities means Heatran can use Lava Plume many times throughout the course of a game to generate progress with minimal risk. The burn chance of Lava Plume makes Heatran incredibly risky for foes to switch into, as physical attackers such as Great Tusk that could threaten a KO on Heatran do not want to risk the possibility of being burned and having their offensive power crippled. Furthermore, walls such as Toxapex also fear being burned, as the passive damage will affect their longevity over the course of a game. Earth Power is the only coverage necessary for Heatran, giving it the capability to easily break through foes such as Skeledirge and Iron Moth. It is notable that an EV spread including 56 Special Attack EVs will allow Heatran to OHKO offensive opposing Heatran with Earth Power. Heatran serves as an excellent setter of Stealth Rock due to its propensity to easily force switches against Pokemon such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Amoonguss. Protect rounds out Heatran’s moveset, not only giving it the chance to extend its longevity via Leftovers and accumulate burn damage on foes but also the capability to scout foes’ movesets, which can be especially useful when facing off against foes using Choice items. One should be careful when using Protect not to fall into predictable patterns and give foes the chance to set up on Heatran, however. Magma Storm can be used instead of Lava Plume to trap and eliminate foes such as Toxapex and force damage against bulky threats such as Iron Hands; the passive damage synergizes well with Protect, but Magma Storm's low PP and accuracy makes it less consistent throughout longer games. Taunt is an option that can be used place of Stealth Rock that synergizes particularly well with Magma Storm, preventing foes from using recovery moves, getting entry hazards up, or setting up on Heatran. However, a lack of Speed investment means it will have somewhat limited utility. As another option to Stealth Rock, Power Gem easily OHKOes Moltres, which walls Heatran otherwise, and prevents bulky Volcarona sets from outlasting Heatran. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp can be used over Stealth Rock in conjunction with an investment of 40 Speed EVs to allow Heatran to outspeed and burn maximum Speed Adamant Kingambit. If desired, it is also possible to run one of the aforementioned alternative options of Taunt, Power Gem, or Will-O-Wisp instead of Protect, but this comes at the cost of significantly impacting Heatran's longevity and foregoing Protect's scouting utility.

Heatran serves as one of the three pillars of Steel’s “immunity trinity” along with Corviknight and Gholdengo; combined, these three offer immunities to Steel’s core weaknesses of Fire, Ground, and Fighting, forming an excellent defensive backbone for any Steel team. Corviknight is Heatran’s most important partner, being able to nullify Ground moves targeted at Heatran while Heatran in turn blocks Fire moves aimed at Corviknight. Furthermore, Corviknight can also threaten prominent Fighting-types in the metagame such as Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Sneasler with its STAB Brave Bird. With a physically defensive pivot set, Corviknight further synergizes with specially defensive Heatran by being able to soak up physical hits while Heatran takes special ones, having the ability to remove opposing Stealth Rock and Spikes to prevent Heatran from being worn down by entry hazards over the course of a game and providing Heatran with opportunities to switch in safely via U-turn. Bulk Up Corviknight appreciates Heatran too, as Stealth Rock and burn support can increase its sweeping potential. Gholdengo completes the immunity trinity by voiding Fighting moves aimed at Heatran. Gholdengo can further support Heatran by blocking Corrosion Toxic from Glimmora thanks to Good as Gold; this ability combined with Gholdengo's Ghost typing also lets it completely prevent the removal of Heatran's Stealth Rock, as Gholdengo blocks both Rapid Spin and Defog. With an Air Balloon, Gholdengo can block Ground-type moves and use Nasty Plot to break through walls, both of which Heatran appreciates. Alternatively, using a Choice Scarf, Gholdengo can switch into Enamorus and outspeed and OHKO it in return, and it can use Trick to cripple opposing special walls such as Toxapex and Blissey or lock sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite into setup moves to prevent them from exploiting Heatran. Outside of the immunity trinity, Hisuian Goodra also makes a good pairing with Heatran due to its unique Water resistance on Steel and capacity to threaten opposing Water-types such as Basculegion-F and Greninja with Thunderbolt. Hisuian Goodra can also check Hydreigon and Walking Wake, which both wall and exploit Heatran. Moreover, Hisuian Goodra can act as a switch-in to opposing Heatran and threaten it with Earthquake, and it is able to survive an Earth Power from Landorus and OHKO it in return with Ice Beam if necessary. Iron Treads can spin away hazards for Heatran without removing Heatran’s Stealth Rock, set Stealth Rock itself to free Heatran to use other moves if desired, and serve as an offensive check to Sandy Shocks with its STAB Earthquake as well as Landorus with Ice Spinner, which Heatran’s other teammates can struggle to handle. Physical sweepers such as Kingambit and Scizor are grateful for Heatran’s ability to absorb Will-O-Wisp for them, and they can clean up teams Heatran has worn down with Stealth Rock and chip damage. Klefki can complement Heatran's Stealth Rock with its own Spikes while taking advantage of Heatran's Fire immunity, which can help break down opposing teams faster as they switch around to deal with the immunity trinity. It should be noted that this is by no means an exhaustive list of potential teammates for Heatran; all Steel-type Pokemon in the metagame appreciate Heatran’s Fire immunity, and no Pokemon currently competes with Heatran in this regard.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Steel)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Stallbreaker (Fire)
sets.description:
Heavy Slam OHKOs Flutter Mane.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Assault Vest Heatran uses its unique typing and defensive stats to match up well against common special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Gholdengo and threaten them back with its great offensive stats and wide coverage. While Heatran boasts an innately good defensive typing, Tera Grass allows it to turn its common weaknesses to Ground and Water into resistances, letting it match up better against the likes of Landorus-T and Palafin-H. Heat Wave is a spread STAB attack that chips away at foes, notably 2HKOing Amoonguss. Flash Cannon is Heatran's best way of hitting Fairy-types, as it OHKOes Diancie and 2HKOes Flutter Mane. Heavy Slam OHKOes Flutter Mane but is generally less reliable because it can be weakened by Intimidate and does less damage to Diancie and opposing Tera Grass Heatran mirror. Tera Blast hits Water- and Ground-types super effectively once Heatran has Terastallized, notably OHKOing Great Tusk and 2HKOing Bulk Up Palafin-H. Earth Power hits the Fire-types such as Volcanion, Chi-Yu, and opposing Heatran that otherwise resists all of Heatran's attacks. Heatran's base resistances let it take common Fairy-, Ice-, and Steel-type attacks such as Flutter Mane's Moonblast, Chien-Pao's Ice Spinner, and Gholdengo's Make It Rain much better. After Terastallization, Heatran matches up better against Palafin-H, Volcanion, and Iron Hands at the cost of receiving more damage from the aforementioned attacks. Heatran has a lot of defensive responsibilities on most teams, so Terastallization should not be used too frivolously. Heatran commonly finds itself in Fire / Water / Grass cores with Rillaboom and Palafin, as they complement each other offensively and defensively, with Rillaboom eradicating Water-types and Palafin punching through Fire-types. Iron Hands is a common Heatran partner that can pressure Palafin and Volcanion with Wild Charge and Chi-Yu and Tera Dark Kingambit with Drain Punch. Heatran has no form of recovery, so it appreciates teammates that can extend its longevity, such as Cresselia with Lunar Blessing and Amoonguss with Pollen Puff.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Heatran is a strong mixed attacker that threatens massive damage to the format's defensive pivots with its powerful Steel- and Fire-type attacks. Steel Beam is Heatran's best offensive option, as Magic Guard negates its massive recoil, while Flare Blitz acts as a strong secondary STAB attack that breaks down Steel-types and special walls like Hisuian Goodra. Power Gem acts as a strong coverage option, targeting common Fire- and Steel-type switch-ins like Skeledirge and Primordial Sea Zapdos. A Hasty nature is chosen to maximize both Heatran's physical and special power, and 96 Attack EVs let it 2HKO common RegenVest users like Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra after Stealth Rock damage. 200 Speed EVs let Heatran outspeed Slither Wing, Volcanion, and defensive Garchomp; the rest of the available EVs are put into Special Attack to maximize Steel Beam's power. Heatran relies on being able to consistently force foes out to make progress, so bulky entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu can help set up Spikes alongside Heatran's Stealth Rock to consistently chip and punish the opponent's switches. Additionally, to help seal the deal against bulky pivots like Garchomp and fast revenge killers like Chien-Pao, Heatran appreciates teammates like Scream Tail to absorb their hits and have a chance to make progress against them. Finally, offensive teammates like Chien-Pao can take advantage of Heatran's ability to chip switch-ins early-game, as well as defeating Goodra, leading to a more threatening end-game presence.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description: IronPress Heatran trades immediate damage for more defensive utility and sweeping potential, being able to handle common Ground-types like Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Ting-Lu. Lava Plume is preferred over Flamethrower to spread burns against switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra, Magic Guard Quaquaval, and Ting-Lu. IronPress allows Heatran to better take on RegenVest users such as Alolan Muk and Meloetta, Garchomp, and Well-Baked Body Steel-types, most notably Kingambit. Substitute blocks Dragon Tail from Garchomp and Knock Off from Iron Treads, takes advantage of the switches Heatran forces versus foes like Blissey, and also benefits from Iron Defense boosts. 200 Speed EVs and a Timid nature make Heatran outrun Timid Volcanion and Adamant Slither Wing. This Heatran variant is very vulnerable to common Primordial Sea users in Zapdos, Kilowattrel, and Inteleon, so partners that can take them on like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta are mandatory. Primordial Sea Zapdos can switch in against Fire-types such as Iron Moth, Skeledirge, and Ceruledge that threaten Heatran. In return, Heatran takes on RegenVest users that Zapdos struggles to break through. Another Fire-type teammate with Desolate Land like Cinderace, Iron Moth, or Ceruledge appreciates Heatran taking on Ground-types for it, while they can punish Water-types and the aforementioned Primordial Sea users.

sets.name: Desolate Land
sets.description: A set with maximum Special Attack investment and a Modest nature can be used instead for more offensive pressure.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Heatran serves as an effective defensive pivot into Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Tornadus-T, Victini, Mega Scizor lacking Close Combat, Volcarona, and Gholdengo. Magma Storm allows Heatran to trap and remove defensive Pokemon, such as Zapdos, Toxapex, and Skeledirge. Taunt allows Heatran to deny recovery from Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Clodsire, and Zapdos, making trapping them much more efficient, though it has to Terastallize for the former two. Earth Power provides consistent damage versus Pokemon such as Clodsire, Toxapex, and Gastrodon while also allowing Heatran to deal damage without running the risk of missing Magma Storm, particularly on its trapped opponents. Tera Grass allows Heatran to invalidate typical counterplay such as Gastrodon and Clodsire while also avoiding being revenge killed by Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Taunt further bolsters Heatran's effective use of Tera, as it can avoid one of its only potential flaws in becoming vulnerable to Toxic. Heatran can also use Toxic itself to threaten Pokemon using it to set up, such as Garchomp and Dragonite while reducing longevity of Pokemon such as Pelipper, Mega Swampert, and opposing Terastallized Heatran. Tera Grass in conjunction with Flash Fire gives Heatran a unique defensive profile that lets it wall Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y and opposing Heatran. Heatran must be careful with Tera usage, as Tera Grass can leave it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Volcarona and Tornadus-T. The given EV spread allows Heatran to outspeed uninvested Gholdengo while maximizing special bulk. Electric-types such as Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Rotom-W appreciate Heatran’s ability to bait and remove popular Ground-types once Terastallized, such as Landorus-T, Clodsire, and Gastrodon, as well as heavily chippping Garchomp. Teammates such as Urshifu-R, Dragapult, and Mega Lopunny appreciate Heatran's ability to check Tapu Lele, taking its often choice locked STAB attacks and setting Stealth Rock or firing off a Magma Storm to force progress, benefitting its teammates. Pokemon such as Dragonite and Garchomp can benefit Heatran defensively with both punishing physical attackers such as Mega-Lopunny while also capitalizing on its wallbreaking potential. Heatran is also able to bait and eliminate Tera Fairy Skeledirge for these aforementioned teammates. Rotom-W defensively supports Heatran by preventing it from immediately Terastallizing to beat Clodsire, opposing Rotom-W, and Landorus-T if not desired, providing a safe switch. Heatran struggles to stay healthy in certain matchups versus offensive entry hazard-stacking teams that deny it from coming in freely without seriously chipping itself, so Defoggers like Tornadus-T benefit Heatran while also providing a Ground immunity. Heatran can take advantage of Choice-locked Grass types such as Rillaboom and Kartana when they are trying to hit Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T particularly likes Heatran's ability to check Zapdos and Tapu Koko. Heatran appreciates Pokemon who can soak up Fighting-type moves such as Great Tusk and Tangrowth as Heatran tends to invite in particularly strong revenge killers like Mega-Lopunny and opposing Great Tusk.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Thanks to its unique typing and the combination of Magma Storm, Taunt, and Toxic, Heatran acts as an offensive wallbreaker capable of trapping and remove Pokemon like Clodsire and Toxapex for its teammates. Heatran's fantastic typing also allows it to check Pokemon like Tornadus-T, non-Close Combat or Sand Tomb Mega Scizor, and Tapu Lele. Leftovers gives Heatran longevity and consistency in its role, while Air Balloon lets it check itself and avoid Earthquake from common switch-ins like Garchomp, Gastrodon, and Gliscor. Firium Z allows Heatran to nuke the aforementioned Gliscor and Clodsire. While it doesn't help Heatran offensively, Tera Grass is its best Tera type; it gives it a resistance to Earthquake and takes advantage of the aforementioned Ground-types while also allowing it to be a nightmare for rain teams, as it can now spread Toxic and chip foes on rain very easily. Pivots like Tornadus-T, Tapu Koko, and Rotom-W makes great partners, as they lure Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor, letting Heatran threaten them with a KO. It also appreciates Pokemon that share checks with it, such as Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo, as Heatran can cripple these common checks, namely Toxapex, Mega Tyranitar, and Gastrodon. Knock Off users like Toxapex and Tornadus-T remove Clodsire's and Toxapex's items, making them less consistent at checking Heatran in the long run.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Steel)
sets.description: Heatran is a mainstay on Steel teams due to its ability, Flash Fire, letting it switch into threats like Blacephalon, Victini, and Iron Moth. Lava Plume makes Heatran annoying to switch into thanks to its burn chance, while Magma Storm softens walls like Toxapex and Rotom-W by trapping them. Earth Power threatens Poison- and Fire-types and makes Heatran an important asset against opposing Steel teams by hitting opposing Heatran. Roar lets Heatran phaze the likes of Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Z-Celebrate Victini and synergizes well with Stealth Rock to deal extra damage. Alternatively, Toxic cripples walls like Mantine and Rotom-W, as well as Pokemon that fancy switching into Heatran such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Substitute pairs well with Toxic and allows Heatran to be massively annoying against types like Steel, Electric, and Psychic by capitalizing on the many switches it forces in these matchups. Thanks to their typing and bulk, Corviknight and Celesteela are excellent teammates to check Ground- and Fighting-types like Mamoswine and Great Tusk for Heatran. Setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Z-Happy Hour Jirachi appreciate Heatran wearing down teams with burn and Toxic. Iron Treads removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin and deals with Mega Charizard Y, Zeraora, and Cinderace with its Choice Scarf set. Ferrothorn checks Water-types like Mega Swampert and Urshifu-R and aids Heatran with Spikes and Leech Seed.

sets.name: Offensive Utility (Fire)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Prankster
sets.description: Prankster + Haze Giratina's huge bulk and recovery and disruption options allow it to function as a reliable answer to setup users. Giratina has a wide array of options it can use to disrupt foes attempting to set up: Glare paralyzes fast attackers such as Palkia-O, Encore keeps them locked into moves such as Nasty Plot, Parting Shot lets Giratina pivot and Destiny Bond trades a KO, and Entrainment helps force out ability-dependent attackers. Heavy-Duty Boots helps Giratina switch in more easily without fear of entry hazard chip, while Covert Cloak helps prevent status from moves like Mortal Spin and Nuzzle. Tera Fairy improves Giratina's matchup into opposing Dragon-types such as Koraidon while maintaining a Fighting-type resistance, whereas Tera Dark grants immunity to status moves from opposing Prankster users and a Ghost- and Dark-type resistance for Flutter Mane and Arceus-Dark. Great partners for Prankster Giratina include RegenVest Ting-Lu, Fur Coat Dondozo, and Imposter users thanks to their strong defensive synergy, which allows Giratina to get in more comfortably against Arceus-Ghost and Koraidon.

sets.name: Magic Bounce
sets.description: Giratina is a great defensive Pokemon that provides utility and disruption with its immunity to Fighting and resistance to powerful attacks like V-create and Rising Voltage. Court Change makes Giratina effective at removing entry hazards against Mold Breaker entry hazard setters and Stone Axe Pokemon. Strength Sap helps with keeping strong physical attackers such as Groudon in check. Whirlwind bypasses Substitute to force out foes, whereas Encore can be used as another form of disruption. Scald is useful for spreading burns, especially against physical attackers such as Groudon and Zamazenta-C. Tera Fairy is great for the immunity to Dragon-type attacks from Koraidon, Eternatus, and Palkia-O, while Tera Dark is great for being resistant to Ghost- and Dark-type attacks from Arceus-Ghost and Hoopa-Unbound. Covert Cloak helps Giratina beat Imposter users and blocks troublesome status from Scald and Mortal Spin. Dondozo and RegenVest Ting-Lu are great partners for Giratina thanks to their physical bulk and complementary typings, which help Giratina against threats such as Eternatus and Arceus-Ghost.

sets.name: Physical Utility
sets.description:
• Giratina-O is not only one of the few viable Defoggers in the tier but also a great check to several dangerous attackers, most notably Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground and E-Killer Arceus.
  • Will-O-Wisp can be used on teams weak to physical threats like Zacian-C and Koraidon.
  • On the other hand, Giratina-O naturally forces out Ground-types, making it good at spreading Thunder Wave.
  • The given EV spread with an Adamant nature allows Giratina-O to survive +1 Zacian-C’s Play Rough from full HP, avoid the 2HKO from Choice Scarf Kyogre’s Ice Beam, and 2HKO Zacian-C with Earthquake.
  • Tera Steel grants Giratina-O a resistance to otherwise super effective attacks like Arceus-Fairy's Judgment, Zacian-C's Play Rough, and Miraidon's Draco Meteor while giving it an immunity to Toxic from Clodsire and Toxapex.
  • Tera Poison keeps the resistance to Fairy-type attacks that Tera Steel grants, but it also maintains a positive matchup against Fighting-type attacks, most notably Koraidon's Low Kick.
  • Giratina-O is best used on balance teams to ease up an otherwise bad matchup into Ground-types like Groudon and Arceus-Ground. Its Fire resistance and access to Will-O-Wisp and Dragon Tail means it isn't too threatened by Groudon carrying a Fire-type move and Taunt Arceus-Ground like Corviknight is, while its access to Defog means it can act as hazard-clearing support, unlike Landorus-T.
  • Giratina-O makes for an excellent defensive pairing with either Clodsire or Ting-Lu with Skeledirge, as they can defensively check threats Giratina-O cannot reliably handle like Zacian-C, Koraidon, and Miraidon. They also love Giratina-O easing up their matchup against Ground-types like Groudon and Arceus-Ground.
  • Pokemon that dislike entry hazards and love Giratina-O removing them with Defog, like Koraidon, offensive Arceus forms, Chien-Pao, and Rayquaza, are good partners.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind Cresselia is a potent late-game wincon thanks to its gargantuan bulk, reliable recovery, and access to Calm Mind + Stored Power as well as solid coverage to deal with the Dark-types. After several Calm Mind boosts, Stored Power allows Cresselia to muscle past both Unaware walls like Skeledirge and Dondozo and bulky Psychic-resistant foes like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Heatran while making it nigh impossible to KO with special attackers. Moonblast rounds out Cresselia's coverage, allowing it to hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu, Hisuian Samurott, and Greninja super effectively while being able to at least damage Kingambit; Tera Blast Fighting greatly improves Cresselia's matchup against Kingambit and hits these Dark-types harder than Moonblast, but makes Cresselia more reliant on Terastallization. Leftovers grants Cresselia crucial passive healing, allowing it to conserve its limited Moonlight PP long-term; Covert Cloak, on the other hand, blocks secondary effects from an array of moves, including Heatran's Magma Storm, Garganacl's Salt Cure, Zapdos's Discharge, and Sneasler's Dire Claw, allowing Cresselia to set up against these threats more safely. Grassy Seed is an option if Cresselia is used on Grassy Terrain hyper offense teams, which gives it more opprotunities to set up in the face of physical attackers while also boosting its Stored Power. Tera Poison has wonderful synergy with Levitate, giving Cresselia a single weakness to Psychic-type attacks, granting it resistances to Poison- and Fairy-type attacks, and an immunity to Toxapex's Toxic while still maintaining its Fighting resistance. Defensively, Tera Fighting lets Cresselia flip its Dark weakness against prominent Pokemon like Meowscarada, Greninja, Hisuian Samurott, and the aforementioned Kingambit as well. 52 Speed EVs allow Cresselia to outspeed Kingambit.

Cresselia fits well on an array of hyper offense, offense, and balance teams capable of supporting such a potent wincon. Heatran, Hisuian Samurott, and Landorus-T can provide entry hazard support to wear down foes over time. Heatran can also use Will-O-Wisp to cripple Kingambit or trap and wear down threats like Haze Toxapex and Chilly Reception Galarian Slowking with Magma Storm and Taunt; in return, Cresselia can handle threats like Great Tusk and Zamazenta that Heatran struggles against. Kingambit is ubiquitous and is a major thorn in Cresselia's side; as such, Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Low Kick Kingambit are crucial partners that can help stop opposing Kingambit's attempt to countersweep. Assault Vest Toxapex is a great teammate for Cresselia; it can take on Encore Iron Valiant, which is a frustrating matchup for Cresselia, and it can trap and deal with opposing defensive Toxapex, which can shut down Cresselia's boosts with Haze and force Cresselia to Tera Poison in order to avoid being crippled by Toxic. Thanks to Grassy Surge, Rillaboom is a necessary partner for Grassy Seed variants; it can support Cresselia with utility options like Knock Off and U-turn too.

sets.name: Trick Room
sets.description: This EV spread survives a Dark Pulse from Timid Choice Specs Chi-Yu.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Serene Queen (Calm Mind)
sets.description:
• With its great bulk and the advent of Terastallization, Cresselia is a formidable defensive presence with the ability to take over late in the game.

  • Calm Mind: Calm Mind allows Cresselia to bolster its defensive profile while also increasing its damage output.

  • Moonblast: While lacking STAB, Moonblast has no immunities, which makes it Cresselia’s most reliable offensive move.

  • Stored Power: While blanked by Dark-types, Stored Power allows Cresselia to threaten walls like Unaware Dondozo and more reliably win Calm Mind wars against foes like Flutter Mane. It also allows Cresselia to potentially beat Heatran with sheer power should it accrue enough boosts.

  • Thunderbolt - Thunderbolt allows Cresselia to immediately threaten Urshifu-R and is a great general attacking move if used with an Electric Tera.

  • Ice Beam: Ice Beam allows Cresselia to immediately threaten the many Ice weak Pokémon in the metagame, such as Dragonite, Landorus-T, and Ting-Lu

Other Options

  • Substitute: While difficult to fit, Substitute can protect Cresselia from debilitating status from the likes of Dondozo and Clodsire, giving it a wider reach against slower paced teams without relying on Covert Cloak as much.

  • Lunar Dance: While seemingly odd on a defensive set, Lunar Dance allows Cresselia to bring back a battered teammate in the event it itself cannot finish the game, giving formidable partners such as Chien-Pao and Ursaluna a second chance to break down the opponent.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak guards Cresselia from adverse effects such as flinches and Defense drops that would otherwise impede its ability to take over the endgame. It also negates the passive damage from Garganacl’s Salt Cure, allowing Cresselia to heavily punish it.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers’s passive recovery allows Cresselia to better conserve its limited Moonlight PP, more safely set up against powerful attackers like Flutter Mane, and be a more active presence on the field by not mandating it use a turn to heal off every hit it takes manually.

Tera Types

  • Electric-type: Thanks to Levitate, Tera Electric grants Cresselia a complete lack of weaknesses, giving it an extremely diverse defensive profile courtesy of its immense bulk. It also guards against paralysis, minimizing the chance of an ill-timed lost turn ruining a sweep.

  • Poison-type: Tera Poison protects Cresselia against Toxic, allowing it to more safely set up against Pokémon like Clodsire. It also grants security against even Tera Fairy Choice Specs Flutter Mane by allowing Cresselia to resist Fairy.

  • Fairy-type: Tera Fairy grants Cresselia a crucial resistance to Dark, allowing it to better take on foes like Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu.

sets.name: Unaware
sets.description: Unaware Cresselia is an effective mixed wall and unorthodox setup sweeper with the ability to surprise opponents with its combination of Calm Mind and Stored Power. Cresselia is a reliable stop to powerful setup sweepers like Zamazenta-C and Garchomp, which can even be setup fodder for Cresselia. Once set up, Stored Power is Cresselia's main offensive option, dealing ridiculous damage against any non-Psychic-immune foes after two or three Calm Mind boosts. Additionally, Moonblast lets Cresselia threaten Dark- and Dragon-types like Chien-Pao and Garchomp. Because of Cresselia's passive stature and inability to make progress early-game, it shouldn't attempt to set up Calm Mind and sweep until physical attackers with super effective moves like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Slither Wing have been removed from play. Additionally, Cresselia fails to effectively defeat some special walls like Unaware Scream Tail and RegenVest Meloetta and Alolan Muk, making offensive teammates that threaten a 2HKO on either of these foes like Kingambit necessary to create openings for Cresselia to sweep. In addition to offensive pairings, this Pokemon appreciates defensive teammates like Intimidate Corviknight that can prevent it from being overwhelmed by Choice item users. Finally, Cresselia appreciates entry hazard removal from teammates like Corviknight, letting it preserve Moonlight's PP for the late-game.

sets.name: Stored Power
sets.description: Cresselia serves as a potentially terrifying setup sweeper, using its naturally titanic mixed bulk alongside Terastallization to accumulate multiple Calm Mind boosts, bolstering its Stored Power to incredibly dangerous levels to easily snowball if given the opportunity. Even without Terastallization, it can use its natural typing to withstand attacks from dangerous Pokemon such as Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Mega Medicham. Hidden Power Fighting is the preferred coverage move to hit Mega Tyranitar and Heatran much harder, while Moonblast provides a stronger hit against the likes of Dragapult and Urshifu-R if Cresselia cannot afford to accumulate multiple Calm Mind boosts. Tera Poison is essential for removing Cresselia's weaknesses to Dark- and Ghost-type attacks from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Hisuian Samurott while providing less exploitable weaknesses compared to Tera Steel, which makes Cresselia prone to being revenge killed by Fighting- and Fire-types such as Mega Lopunny, Sneasler, Heatran, and Mega Charizard Y. Covert Cloak allows Cresselia to negate secondary effects from Garganacl's Salt Cure and status from the likes of Toxapex, Sneasler, and Zapdos, while Leftovers provides passive recovery that makes Cresselia less exploitable and forced to heal. Maximum Speed EVs allow Cresselia to consistently outspeed Heatran and Gholdengo, which could otherwise irritate it, although more Defense investment could be used instead to better withstand attacks from the likes of Urshifu-R and Zamazenta. Cresselia fits best on either bulky balance or hyper offense teams, both able to provide support in different ways; the former give Cresselia a defensive core to fall back on should its sweep fail, while the latter pressure opposing defensive teams and can provide dual screens support via Tapu Koko and Dragapult to bolster its bulk even further. Both playstyles can reliably keep up Spikes using Skarmory, Clodsire, Mega Diancie, or Garchomp, which Cresselia mandates in order to wear down its checks such as Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Heatran. Similarly, Knock Off support from the likes of Toxapex and Iron Valiant helps Cresselia pressure the aforementioned checks more effectively. Cresselia has difficulty withstanding rain teams due to them cutting Moonlight's healing, so defensive partners that match up positively against them such as Toxapex and Tera Water or Dragon Garganacl are appreciated. Cresselia struggles with bulkier playstyles that can neutralize it with the likes of Haze Toxapex and Unaware Tera Dark Clodsire, so Pokemon that can break defensive teams such as Swords Dance Gliscor and Gholdengo make for good partners.

sets.name: Rain Wallbreaker
sets.description: Manaphy carves a small niche as an adequate wallbreaker on rain teams. Its Tail Glow-boosted Hydro Vortex possesses nuclear power, capable of feats like OHKOing Chansey after Stealth Rock and significantly denting Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Tera Grass Heatran that give rain wallbreakers a hard time. Longevity from Rest + Hydration lets it sponge status moves in rain against defensive teams, which gives it plenty of opportunities to wallbreak by shrugging off their chip damage, such as against Toxapex and Clodsire's Toxic and Garganacl's Salt Cure. Energy Ball covers Gastrodon as well as Water-resistant foes like Rotom-W, Tera Water Ting-Lu, and Tera Water Garganacl without expending its Z-Move. Alternatively, Psychic hits Water Absorb Clodsire and Toxapex much stronger. Pelipper is a mandatory teammate due to providing the highly important rain with Drizzle. Swift Swim users like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda can keep the offensive pressure up against the opposition; their high Speed allows them to beat offensive teams by outpacing fast Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko that can overwhelm Manaphy, and they enjoy it dealing with bulky teams in return, impairing the likes of Tangrowth, Slowbro, and Rotom-W for them. Utility options from Tornadus-T and Ferrothorn are also appreciated; the former checks Kartana and Serperior that would otherwise revenge kill Manaphy, while the latter covers Tapu Koko and provides entry hazards. Kingambit and Weavile can Pursuit trap Dragapult and Mega Latias, both of which are problematic for Manaphy to face.

sets.name: Tail Glow
sets.description: Manaphy has a niche as a powerful wallbreaker outside of rain thanks to Tail Glow and its solid coverage, breaking through defensive foes such as Hippowdon, Heatran, and Garganacl. Energy Ball hits foes such as Gastrodon, Rotom-W, and Tapu Fini while Psychic hits foes such as Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire. Rindo Berry can be used so Manaphy can avoid revenge killers such as Kartana while improving its matchup against foes such as Tangrowth. Alternatively, Wacan Berry helps prevent Manaphy from being revenge killed by Tapu Koko and Iron Valiant. Ice Beam can be used over Psychic or Energy Ball to dent Dragonite, Ferrothorn, and Hydreigon, but Manaphy can no longer hit foes such as Toxapex and Gastrodon. Salac Berry with Substitute with either Tera Steel or Grass can be used to exploit the Pokemon that Manaphy threatens such as Hippowdon and Garganacl, outspeeding would-be revenge killers such as Tapu Koko and Kartana. Tera Water is used to boost the power of Surf, allowing Manaphy to 2HKO foes such as Ferrothorn and Unaware Clodsire. Manaphy fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its wallbreaking capabilities. Dual screens support from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl improves Manaphy's longevity, allowing it to set up easier. Teammates such as Dragapult and Volcarona appreciate Manaphy removing troublesome foes such as Mega Tyranitar, Kingambit, and Heatran for them to sweep. Manaphy also appreciates entry hazard support from teammates such as Glimmora and Landorus-T weakening foes such as Ferrothorn so Manaphy can break through them easier.

sets.name: Extreme Killer (Swords Dance)
sets.description:
• The combination of Swords Dance and STAB Extreme Speed turns Arceus into a deadly setup sweeper.
  • Shadow Claw hits Giratina-O and Skeledirge hard, especially if Arceus has Terastallized into the Ghost-type.
  • Taunt denies opposing recovery and blocks status moves such as Will-O-Wisp from Giratina-O and Skeledirge, but Recover can let Arceus acquire multiple boosts, making it nigh unstoppable.
  • Earthquake hits Toxapex and Zacian-C hard while doing respectable damage to Skeledirge.
  • A Silk Scarf lets Arceus secure important benchmarks such as OHKOing offensive Kyogre at +2 with Extreme Speed. Alternatively, Leftovers offers more longevity, while Lum Berry offers extra insurance against status effects.
  • The given EV spread and nature maximize Arceus's damage output and let it outspeed Adamant Rayquaza, with the rest of the EVs going into HP to facilitate setup.
  • Tera Normal boosts Extreme Speed to absurd levels, letting Arceus OHKO offensive Koraidon at +2 if holding a Silk Scarf.
  • Alternatively, Tera Ghost is useful for preventing Koraidon and Zacian-C from revenge killing it. It also boosts Shadow Claw against targets such as Giratina-O and Skeledirge.
  • Tera Fire makes Arceus immune to burn, which is helpful against Skeledirge and Giratina-O.
  • Swords Dance Arceus is a good fit on hyper offense and bulky offense, working best as a late-game sweeper when checks such as Corviknight, Zacian-C, and Skeledirge are weakened or removed. With Extreme Speed, Arceus also serves as an emergency check to opposing sweepers.
  • Good teammates for Arceus include Zacian-C, Groudon, and Koraidon, which share similar checks such as Corviknight and Skeledirge and can wear them down for Arceus to sweep.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• Dragon Dance allows Arceus to outspeed opposing Arceus formes as well as turn the tables on faster Normal-resistant or immune Pokemon such as Zacian-C, Flutter Mane, Arceus-Ghost, and Tera Ghost Pokemon.
  • Extreme Speed is a powerful priority move that lets Arceus revenge kill opposing sweepers as well as clean weakened teams late-game.
  • Shadow Claw OHKOes Flutter Mane and hits Giratina-O, Skeledirge, and foes that have Terrastalized into the Ghost-type hard, especially if Arceus has Terastallized into the Ghost-type itself.
  • Flare Blitz is a powerful coverage move that OHKOes Zacian-C at +1 and deals heavy damage to Corviknight and Tera Steel Giratina-O. Earthquake has no recoil and also has a good chance to OHKO Zacian-C at +1 after Stealth Rock, but it cannot hit Corviknight. Recover keeps Arceus healthy throughout a match and potentially lets it set up more than once.
  • Silk Scarf is recommended to boost the power of Extreme Speed to secure benchmarks such as OHKOing offensive Kyogre at +1 with Tera Normal. Leftovers is another good option, especially alongside Recover, to let Arceus accrue multiple boosts. Lum Berry is useful for giving Arceus additional insurance against status moves such as Will-O-Wisp from Giratina-O or Skeledirge.
  • The given EV spread maximizes Arceus's damage output while giving it enough Speed to outrun max Speed base 90 Pokemon, as well as uninvested Koraidon and Miraidon.
  • Tera Normal with a Silk Scarf gives Extreme Speed the extra power needed to OHKO Miraidon and offensive Kyogre at +1 after Stealth Rock. However, Tera Ghost is also an option to boost the power of Shadow Claw and avoid being revenge killed by Koraidon and Zacian-C. Finally, Tera Fire makes Arceus immune to Will-O-Wisp.
  • Arceus fits best on hyper offense and bulky offense, where it keeps opposing sweepers in check with its powerful priority while threatening to sweep itself.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Thanks to the combination of Fairy- and Ground-type attacks, which has excellent neutral coverage, Arceus-Fairy is a very strong Calm Mind user.
  • Arceus-Fairy's powerful Fairy-type Judgment discourages Ting-Lu from coming in, giving it a niche compared to other Calm Mind Arceus formes.
  • With Earth Power and the given Special Attack investment, Arceus-Fairy can 2HKO Leftovers Clodsire at +2 and 2HKO Skeledirge outright.
  • The Speed investment is used to outspeed base 90 Speed Pokemon, while the rest is dumped into HP and Defense. This allows Arceus-Fairy to be a utility switch-in to Dragon-types and physical attackers in general, and it works well with Calm Mind's Special Defense boost.
  • An alternative EV spread of 108 HP / 148 SpA / 252 Spe with a Timid nature still lets Arceus-Fairy 2HKO Clodsire at +2 whilst having maximum Speed to have a better matchup against opposing Arceus with Taunt. Do note that the loss of physical bulk makes taking on Clodsire, Koraidon, and Zacian-C much more difficult.
  • Either Tera Poison or Tera Steel is critical to prevent Clodsire and Eternatus from landing a Toxic on Arceus-Fairy. Tera Poison has the additional benefit of absorbing Toxic Spikes and gives Arceus-Fairy fewer weaknesses than Tera Steel, so it is generally preferred. Tera Steel can be useful against Zacian-C, and it also can be used as a backup option against Cresselia thanks to the Stored Power resistance it provides.
  • Arceus-Fairy works fantastically on a countless number of balance teams, as not only does it provide a strong wincon, but it is one of the few Pokemon to have a Dragon-type resistance in the tier, making it a good backup check to Koraidon and Miraidon. Its general physical bulk and good Special Attack also allows it to be a good burn absorber against Groudon and Giratina-O.
  • While Arceus-Fairy can damage Zacian-C on the switch with Earth Power, Zacian-C's strong Behemoth Blade is the greatest obstacle for Arceus-Fairy to overcome. As a result, solid Zacian-C checks like Skeledirge, Groudon, Toxapex, and Corviknight are recommended partners.
  • Giratina-O can provide Defog and status support, and in return, Arceus-Fairy can provide a Dragon-type resistance and take on Dark-types such as Ting-Lu, Urshifu-S, and Arceus-Dark.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• Arceus-Fairy is one of the best Stealth Rock users in the metagame thanks to its good matchup against common entry hazard removers in Ubers like Giratina-O, Corviknight, and Great Tusk. Arceus-Fairy also has a positive matchup against opposing entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Groudon, as it can comfortably deny entry hazards thanks to Taunt. Taunt also allows Arceus-Fairy to deny entry hazards from Pokemon like Clodsire that, by virtue of their typing and bulk, would have no problems setting them up against it.
  • Arceus-Fairy can also run options like Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave over Stealth Rock, giving it a way to punish Pokemon like Zacian-C and Clodsire even harder as they switch into it.
  • The given spread allows Arceus-Fairy to outspeed threatening Pokemon like Arceus and Palkia-O without a Speed-boosting nature.
