The remaining EVs are used to maximize physical bulk, which can let Arceus-Fairy better switch into attackers like Choice Scarf Koraidon and Chien-Pao. Another option is to run max Speed, which gives Arceus-Fairy a better matchup against opposing Calm Mind Arceus formes. However, the loss of bulk is very noticeable.
  • Tera Water allows Arceus-Fairy to have a better matchup against not only Fire-type moves like Flare Blitz from Tera Fire Koraidon, but also Ice-type Pokemon like Calyrex-Ice and Chien-Pao. It also turns Arceus-Fairy's Steel-type weakness into a resistance, which can come in handy against Zacian-C, especially if Arceus-Fairy is running a status move.
  • Arceus-Fairy will be regularly switching in, as thanks to its good typing and stats it can, at the very minimum, soft check Pokemon like Koraidon. Koraidon needs to use Tera Fire in order to beat Arceus-Fairy one-on-one, which in general is a positive trade for Arceus-Fairy's team.
  • That being said, Arceus-Fairy appreciates teammates like Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex, as they also check Koraidon and can help Arceus-Fairy against other threats like Zacian-C. Groudon in particular is a good teammate, as it forms an hazard-stacking combination with Arceus-Fairy.
  • Pokemon with access to Taunt like Miraidon and Koraidon are also good teammates for Arceus-Fairy, as they can, combine with it to shut down walls like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Toxapex and win the entry hazard game.
  • Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Clodsire can also provide entry hazard support for Arceus-Fairy while checking Pokemon that can overwhelm it like Miraidon, and, in Clodsire's case, Flutter Mane and Eternatus.

sets.name: Bulky Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Arceus-Fairy is one of the best setup sweepers in the tier thanks to its very good bulk, typing, access to utility moves like Will-O-Wisp that discourage common Arceus-Fairy checks like Zacian-C from switching into it, and STAB move that nothing is immune to. What differentiates Arceus-Fairy from other Calm Mind Arceus formes is its Dragon immunity, which grants it an invaluable defensive niche against some of the metagame's top threats, like Koraidon, and its Judgment being at least a neutral hit on the vast majority of the metagame, as Pokemon that resist Fairy are scarce.
  • The given EV spread allows Arceus-Fairy to outspeed Adamant Rayquaza while maximizing bulk. This allows Arceus-Fairy to avoid the 2HKO from Pokemon like Choice Scarf Koraidon and Jolly Life Orb Rayquaza.
  • Tera Poison is essential to prevent Clodsire and Eternatus from poisoning Arceus-Fairy with Toxic; it also allows Arceus-Fairy to absorb Toxic Spikes. It also retains Arceus-Fairy's ability to check Fighting-type attacks from the likes of Koraidon in a pinch, which can be useful for pivoting. In conjunction with Will-O-Wisp, Tera Poison Arceus-Fairy can potentially take on Zacian-C one-on-one if it has enough Calm Mind boosts.
  • Arceus-Fairy should be spreading Will-O-Wisp before attempting to sweep, as Pokemon like Clodsire and Zacian-C can stop Arceus-Fairy on its tracks before it accomplishes anything. Arceus-Fairy can be overwhelmed fairly easily by strong powerhouses like Tera Fire Koraidon and Choice Specs Miraidon, so taking care of them first before attempting to sweep is advised.
  • Skeledirge is the best counter to Arceus-Fairy, as it ignores Calm Mind boosts with Unaware, can break through it with Torch Song, and is naturally immune to Will-O-Wisp. Because of this, Pokemon like Eternatus, Kyogre, Miraidon, and Clodsire are good teammates, as they can comfortably sit on Skeledirge and force it out.
  • Pokemon like Skeledirge can check Zacian-C and Koraidon for Arceus-Fairy and spread burns with Will-O-Wisp; the combination of Skeledirge + Arceus-Fairy checks Koraidon pretty well. Similarly, Landorus-T can act as a soft check to Koraidon and Zacian-C that can also provide both entry hazard and Taunt support. Pokemon that can check special attackers for Arceus-Fairy, like Ting-Lu and Clodsire, are recommended, as they also can set up entry hazards on the field for Arceus-Fairy to have an easier time sweeping late-game.

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Arceus-Fairy is a solid wallbreaker that also reliably removes entry hazards with Boomburst and unblockable Rapid Spin, respectively. Extreme Speed provides a strong priority option against opposing attackers like Koraidon and Palkia-O; alternatively, Nuzzle lets Arceus-Fairy cripple Palkia-O, Imposter users, and defensive checks, and a pivoting move like Volt Switch or Flip Turn is also an option to retain momentum. Heavy-Duty Boots increases Arceus-Fairy's longevity and further improves its entry hazard removal potential, while Covert Cloak protects Arceus-Fairy from common moves with secondary effects, such as Nuzzle and Mortal Spin. Pixie Plate is another alternative to provide more immediate power, notably allowing Tera Fairy Arceus-Fairy to potentially OHKO Palkia-O, and also is immune to Knock Off. Wallbreakers such as Enamorus and Koraidon appreciate Arceus-Fairy removing entry hazards, threatening opposing sweepers, and pressuring common walls like Dondozo and Ting-Lu. Tera Fairy further boosts Arceus-Fairy's damage output, whereas Tera Steel provides a wide array of useful resistances, allowing Arceus-Fairy to pick off threats like Dialga-O.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Arceus-Fire's great defensive typing and base stats make it a solid Fur Coat wall. Lava Plume's burn heavily cripples common physical attackers like Koraidon and Groudon and forces chip damage on opponents. Heal Bell allows Arceus-Fire to support its teammates by removing status conditions like paralysis, burn, and poison. U-turn allows Arceus-Fire to safely bring in offensive teammates to exploit passive Lava Plume switch-ins, such as Dondozo and Giratina; alternatively, Knock Off allows Arceus-Fire to remove items like Covert Cloak and Heavy-Duty Boots, as well as an Imposter user's Eviolite. Arceus-Fire best fits on balance teams that appreciate a reliable check to V-create users and a bulky pivot. Teammates like Palkia-O and Koraidon appreciate Arceus-Fire's pivoting and ability to bring in and force damage on passive walls. Imposter-proofing can be done with any Pokemon immune to burn, such as a Covert Cloak user. Tera Flying gives Arceus-Fire an immunity to Ground-type attacks from Groudon and Ursaluna, on top of gaining a Spikes immunity.

sets.name: Desolate Land
sets.description: Arceus-Fire's Desolate Land-boosted V-create is a brutally strong attack, letting it force out most Pokemon by threatening an OHKO. Arceus-Fire's niche over other V-create users is its powerful Solar Beam, which removes common physical walls such as Dondozo and Groudon. Growth enables Arceus-Fire to set up on passive walls, whereas Glacial Lance targets Dragon-types such as Eternatus and Giratina. Life Orb increases Arceus-Fire's power to absurd levels, OHKOing Arceus formes that don't resist its moves and 2HKOing most resistant targets with V-create. Heavy-Duty Boots, on the other hand, allows Arceus-Fire to take better advantage of its resistance to common Fairy- and Fire-type attacks. Arceus-Fire has difficulty breaking past Fire-immune foes, most commonly Well-Baked Body Steel-types, so it pairs well with teammates that can handle these targets like Groudon and Headlong Rush Enamorus. Imposter-proofing is done with Well-Baked Body Steel-types or Primordial Sea users. Tera Fire boosts the power of V-create even further, while Tera Grass grants a Ground resistance and a much stronger Solar Beam.

sets.name: No Retreat
sets.description: Simple + No Retreat turns Arceus-Ghost into a threatening setup sweeper that is hard to revenge kill. Spooky Plate + Judgment allows Arceus-Ghost to Imposter-proof itself and block Knock Off's item removal. Triple Arrows provides perfect neutral coverage with Spooky Plate Judgment and keeps Arceus-Ghost Imposter-proof. The secondary effects also allow Arceus-Ghost to break past walls like Yveltal and Ice Scales Pokemon. Low Kick has more PP and consistently does more damage than Triple Arrows, but it can't be used to luck past non-Covert Cloak foes, and Mega Audino walls Low Kick variants. Jungle Healing removes crippling status conditions while also acting as a form of recovery to mitigate chip damage. Its lower healing compared to alternatives like Strength Sap is valuable for breaking through Imposter users, although, in a pinch, these can use No Retreat and attempt to stall Judgment. Arceus-Ghost highly appreciates Knock Off users like RegenVest Pokemon to help remove Imposter Chansey's Eviolite, weaken opposing RegenVest Pokemon, and remove Covert Cloaks for Triple Arrows; in return, Arceus-Ghost acts as a decent Knock Off and status absorber. Arceus-Ghost can struggle against Pokemon like Fur Coat Yveltal and Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy, so offensive teammates like Mega Diancie and Teravolt Kartana pair well with it.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• Shadow Claw or Dragon Claw is used to hit Giratina-O while also giving you coverage for other Ground-immune foes and Air Balloon users. On the other hand, Gravity bypasses the need for super effective coverage to hit Ground-immune Pokemon such as Corviknight and is commonly paired with Tera Ground. Flare Blitz paired with Tera Fire can be used to hit Tera Steel Giratina-O and Flying-types such as Corviknight and Tera Steel Giratina-O. Lastly, Extreme Speed can be used to revenge kill potentially faster threats such as Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon while also giving you fast priority attack against threats like Chien-Pao and Arceus-Normal.
  • Taunt works better on offensive teams to block Will-O-Wisp or recovery attempts from Pokemon like Skeledirge, while Recover usually benefits from being on a more balanced build, allowing Arceus to have more defensive utility and check threats such as Miraidon and Zacian-C.
  • While using Recover on your moveset you should consider using bulkier spreads that benefit from the longevity for more defensive utility or easier setup opportunities; for example, a spread of 248 HP / 144 Atk / 48 SpD / 68 Spe can work for this purpose.
  • Tera Fire is mainly used to absorb Will-O-Wisp without relying on Taunt, freeing up a moveslot; it also helps against Koraidon's Flare Blitz and Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade and Play Rough.
  • Tera Ground gives Arceus-Ground an immense power boost to Earthquake, which allows it to OHKO Koraidon, Palkia-O, and Mewtwo, 2HKO defensive Groudon with a boost, and threaten to OHKO bulky Kyogre variants and Calm Mind Arceus after a boost and entry hazard damage.
  • Tera Fairy aids in the Miraidon matchup by making it immune to Draco Meteor while also giving a solid defensive typing that benefits from specially bulkier spreads.
  • Ground-immune Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Giratina-O, and Corviknight and bulky walls like Giratina and Dondozo are its best answers, so Arceus-Ground appreciates teammates that can threaten them like Miraidon, Kyogre, and Eternatus.
  • Other physical attackers like Zacian-C, Rayquaza, Koraidon, Chien-Pao and Calyrex-I help Arceus-Ground by threatening damage on their checks and allowing a later sweep by Arceus-Ground on a weakened foe.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
• Calm Mind enables Arceus-Ground to set up and become a strong cleaner that sweeps through most teams with a largely unresisted Ground-type STAB Judgment while being able to better take hits from Miraidon.
  • Ice Beam allows Arceus-Ground to hit Giratina-O, Arceus-Grass, and Corviknight, which can otherwise force it out.
  • Arceus-Ground's Special Attack investment allows it to OHKO Skeledirge, as well as OHKOing Zacian-C after a Spike. The bulk allows for it to take two Flare Blitzes from Jolly Koraidon, while the Speed investment outruns neutral-natured base 90 Speed Pokemon such as Kyogre and Groudon.
  • Tera Fairy allows Arceus-Ground to be immune to Koraidon and Miraidon's Dragon-type moves and prevents Giratina-O from phazing it with Dragon Tail but comes at the expense of now being OHKOed by Zacian-C.
  • Tera Water allows Arceus-Ground to set up in front of Kyogre and comfortably survive a Flare Blitz from Koraidon, but this does come at the expense of becoming weak to Miraidon's Electro Drift.
  • Arceus-Ground is best used alongside Pokemon that reliably weaken Ting-Lu and Kyogre, such as Choice Specs Miraidon and Mewtwo. It also appreciates partners that can weaken Kyogre, such as Koraidon, Kyogre, and Zacian-C.
  • Defensive teammates such as Skeledirge, Toxapex, Corviknight, Kyogre, and Eternatus can help check Koraidon, Kyogre, and Zacian-C, which Arceus-Ground can struggle with prior to getting a Calm Mind up.
  • Arceus-Ground is best saved for the end game, ideally once the opponent's Tera has been revealed or their Koraidon has been removed, as it is the most reliable revenge killer to Arceus-Ground after a Calm Mind. It can get setup opportunities against most Arceus formes that are not carrying Taunt; defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Corviknight; and Miraidon.
  • While this set can be overwhelmed by fast offensive threats such as Koraidon and Zacian-C, it is still one of the premier threats in the tier and can quickly snowball out of control if its handful of checks such as Ting-Lu and Kyogre get chipped throughout the course of the game.
  • Arceus-Ground can afford to drop its Defense or Special Attack investment and run more Speed if it wishes to try to outrun opposing Arceus formes that are running Taunt.

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: Ice Scales Arceus-Ground is a good special wall that can reliably tank hits from most special attackers in the tier. Strength Sap can slow down most physical Pokemon. Tidy Up provides unblockable entry hazard removal and boosts Arceus-Ground's offensive capabilities, allowing it to clean late-game provided roadblocks like Ho-Oh and Celesteela have been removed. Toxic bypasses Covert Cloak, extering pressure on defensive Pokemon like opposing Arceus formes. Mega Mewtwo X pairs excellently with Arceus-Ground, as Arceus-Ground can deal with Mega Diancie, while, in return, Mega Mewtwo X can help Arceus-Ground deal with Water-types such as Mega Swampert and Mega Slowbro by using Chloroblast. Arceus-Ground pairs well with RegenVest Yveltal and Ice Scales Dialga-O, as these provide a good option against Chloroblast users and Palkia-O, respectively. Arceus-Ground can struggle against the likes of Kyurem-B because of the latter's Glacial lance, so it pairs well with bulky Water-types like Fur Coat Dondozo and Mega Slowbro which, can help manage the aforementioned Pokemon and bring Arceus-Ground in on their checks with Flip Turn, forcing them out. Arceus-Ground can be Imposter-proofed by the likes of Celesteela and Magic Guard Ho-Oh.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Arceus-Poison's great bulk and typing make it an effective check to Koraidon and Enamorus. Its natural immunity to poison notably inflicted by Mortal Spin and Toxic, which are common countermeasures to setup Arceus formes, also makes it a dangerous Calm Mind sweeper. Icicle Plate Judgment hits numerous threats super effectively, including Koraidon, Groudon, Eternatus, Rayquaza, and Ting-Lu while also hitting both Dialga-O and Corviknight neutrally, preventing them from comfortably blocking Mortal Spin and Toxic. Mortal Spin removes entry hazards and bypasses Magic Bounce, while Toxic bypasses Covert Cloak and exerts more pressure on defensive checks like Ice Scales Arceus formes. Tera Steel retains Arceus-Poison's poison immunity while granting a resistance to Flying-type attacks from Rayquaza. Arceus-Poison is susceptible to Imposter users, as Imposter copies Arceus-Poison's immunity to poison, so a threatening Imposter-proof like Flare Boost Flutter Mane is recommended. Groudon is a physical attacker that Arceus-Poison cannot handle, so it appreciates a teammate like Corviknight or a Jungle Healing Pokemon such as Dondozo. Offensive wallbreakers like Koraidon and Enamorus can be Imposter-proofed by Arceus-Poison and offer high immediate power to compensate for Arceus-Poison's low initial power.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Arceus-Water is a strong defensive wall thanks to its great typing and bulk. Scald reliably spreads burns, helping spread chip damage and neutralize physical attackers. Knock Off removes items like Covert Cloak and Leftovers, making its burns easier to spread and more damaging, and also boosts Arceus-Water's own survivability by removing Choice Band; alternatively, Spikes can force passive damage on foes, which offensive teammates can exploit. Flip Turn allows Arceus-Water to bring in dangerous offensive teammates against Scald switch-ins like Dondozo and Giratina. Covert Cloak allows Arceus-Water to stop status from moves like Magical Torque, Nuzzle, and Scald, while Leftovers boosts its longevity. Arceus-Water's best fit is on balance teams, which appreciate a reliable physcial wall and a pivot. Offensive teammates, like Koraidon and Flutter Mane, are recommended as they enjoy the safe pivoting Arceus-Water provides and the chip damage it inflicts. Arceus-Water is best Improofed by itself, as Knock Off sets can threaten Imposter users with item removal and Scald burns.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Courtesy of its Spikes-setting signature move, Ceaseless Edge, Hisuian Samurott is a good lead for hyper offense teams. With Sharpness, Razor Shell is Hisuian Samurott's strongest move, dealing high damage to many opposing leads such as Great Tusk and Glimmora. Surf is an alternative over Razor Shell that trades overall power for the ability to hit Great Tusk's lower Special Defense and avoid activating Glimmora's Toxic Debris. Knock Off allows Hisuian Samurott to make progress against the enemy team by removing items, especially Heavy-Duty Boots, but Taunt is another option that denies opposing entry hazards and prevents Defog. For the last slot, Aqua Jet is useful for finishing off faster leads such as Great Tusk, while Sucker Punch is a stronger but less reliable Aqua Jet alternative that hits Pokemon like Dragapult and Walking Wake. Finally, Encore is useful for locking opposing Pokemon into undesirable moves such as forcing an opposing lead to use Stealth Rock repeatedly, allowing Hisuian Samurott to stack more Spikes with Ceaseless Edge. Taunt and Encore also prevent Hisuian Samurott from becoming setup fodder from Pokemon like Iron Defense Zamazenta and Tera Water Garganacl that attempt to exploit Hisuian Samurott's relative passivity. Focus Sash ensures Hisuian Samurott can take any one hit and set up at least one layer of Spikes. Tera Ghost is the preferred option to block Rapid Spin. However, Tera Water can also be considered to power up Hisuian Samurott's Water-type STAB moves, especially if running Aqua Jet. Sharpness is generally the preferred ability to boost the power of both Ceaseless Edge and Razor Shell. However, if Hisuian Samurott is using Surf instead, Torrent can also be considered for greater power against bulky variants of Great Tusk when at low health, which works extremely well with Focus Sash.

Hisuian Samurott fits best on hyper offense teams looking for a suicide lead to start the game off with entry hazards. This set is useful, as it virtually guarantees that a layer of Spikes will go up, since Ceaseless Edge is not affected by Taunt and Hatterene's Magic Bounce. Gholdengo is highly recommended to deny opposing Rapid Spin and Defog. A Stealth Rock setter such as Great Tusk or Sandy Shocks can further supplement the team's hazard pressure. In particular, Sandy Shocks has a strong matchup against Zapdos and Glimmora, while Hisuian Samurott can cover Ting-Lu for Sandy Shocks. A Knock Off user such as Meowscarada, Great Tusk, or Iron Valiant can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from enemy Pokemon to make them vulnerable to Spikes. Powerful sweepers that can take advantage of the hazard pressure Hisuian Samurott creates are good teammates. Such Pokemon include Kingambit, Dragonite, Sneasler, Roaring Moon, and Iron Valiant. These Pokemon all appreciate Spikes support to wear down bulky targets such as Dondozo, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu. Strong wallbreakers such as Ursaluna also enjoy Hisuian Samurott's Spikes to make them even harder to wall.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance allows Hisuian Samurott to go far beyond its presumed role of just an entry hazard setter, boosting its attack to obscene levels and letting it pose a wallbreaking threat as well. Aside from its reliability and higher critical hit ratio, Aqua Cutter's main benefit is to avoid Static from Zapdos and Rocky Helmet from the likes of Great Tusk and Landorus-T; on the other hand, Razor Shell can be used for its Defense drop alongside slightly higher Base Power. Aqua Jet rounds off Hisuian Samurott's moveset by providing ever-so-useful priority to clean up weakened teams with faster threats and either revenge kill or discourage Pokémon like Iron Valiant, Enamorus, and offensive Great Tusk from coming in. Sucker Punch is a much stronger alternative and hits Water-resistant foes like Walking Wake and Dragapult, but it's less reliable due to poor interaction with status moves like Will-O-Wisp, Thunder Wave, and Substitute. Mystic Water can be used boost Hisuian Samurott's damage output on its Water-type moves without the cost of its HP like Life Orb would; Heavy-Duty Boots, on the other hand, helps give Hisuian Samurott more longevity so that it gets more chances to spread hazards via Ceaseless Edge and wallbreak early-game. Tera Water serves a similar purpose to Mystic Water, being potentially useful to sweep a team or generally increase the damage of Aqua Jet and Aqua Cutter; on the other hand, Tera Dark significantly boosts Ceaseless Edge and Sucker Punch. Both Tera types can also have defensive impacts, like Tera Water allowing Hisuian Samurott to stomach a hit from Zamazenta or Iron Valiant and Tera Dark doing the same for Zapdos.

Hisuian Samurott is a great fit on bulky offenses and balances that appreciate its entry hazard stacking ability and wallbreaking prowess all condensed in one slot; more well-rounded team styles can afford giving Hisuian Samurott more turns to click Ceaseless Edge or apply raw offensive pressure between Swords Dance and Aqua Cutter. To aid in that, teammates that can help provide momentum are very welcome, such as U-turn users like Cinderace, Dragapult; Volt Switch users like Zapdos; and even Eject Pack users like Close Combat Great Tusk. Pokemon that appreciate their checks getting worn down by Spikes are also fantastic teammates; Dragapult and Gholdengo deserve a mention, as their most common check in Kingambit especially dislikes coming into Spikes if it's not holding an Air Balloon, but almost any wallbreaker strongly appreciates Hisuian Samurott's Spikes and offensive pressure, with examples including Kingambit, offensive Zapdos, and Walking Wake. Hisuian Samurott may have trouble with its work being undone by hazard removers like Great Tusk, Defog Corviknight, and Court Change Cinderace. Gholdengo is a good help with the first two, whereas for the latter, having a team with strong momentum options like the aforementioned U-turn, Volt Switch, and Eject Pack users as well as Pokemon that take advantage of pivot Cinderace like Heatran or Volcanion are welcome.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Equipped with Choice Scarf and excellent Sharpness-boosted STAB moves in Ceaseless Edge and Razor Shell, Hisuian Samurott is able to serve as both a fast entry hazard setter and a great offensive threat against slower Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Dragapult, Cinderace, and Ting-Lu. Knock Off removes valuable items from Pokemon that rely on them, such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Dragonite as well as Leftovers from Corviknight and Toxapex. Sacred Sword is a great coverage move for Hisuian Samurott, allowing it to OHKO Pokemon such as Kingambit and opposing Hisuian Samurott. Tera Water boosts the power of Razor Shell, allowing it to OHKO Pokemon like Ursaluna and Great Tusk. On the other hand, Tera Dark boosts Ceaseless Edge and Knock Off, allowing Hisuian Samurott to OHKO Skeledirge.

Hisuian Samurott shines on various balance and offense teams, as it serves a unique role of being able to deal damage while also reliably setting Spikes. This allows said teams to punish switches and more easily wear down bulky archetypes. Gholdengo is a great partner for Hisuian Samurott due to pressuring faster offensive threats such as Sneasler and Iron Valiant, and thanks to its ability, it can block Defog attempts from Corviknight. Hisuian Samurott also has great type synergy with Gholdengo, with it being able to pressure Dark-types Gholdengo tends to struggle with like Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and opposing Hisuian Samurott. Heatran and Ting-Lu both make for good partners, since they can stack hazards alongside Hisuian Samurott while also checking Zapdos, which otherwise forces it out. In return, Hisuian Samurott can pressure Ground-types that Heatran and Ting-Lu both tend to struggle with, like Great Tusk and Ursaluna. Walls such as Amoonguss, Toxapex, Dondozo, and Corviknight can force Hisuian Samurott out, so it pairs well with offensive teammates that can beat them, like the aforementioned Gholdengo as well as Choice Specs Hoopa-U and Zapdos. Lastly, sweepers such as Iron Valiant, Dragonite, and Sneasler appreciate Hisuian Samurott laying down hazards and beating Pokemon they can struggle with, like Air Balloon Gholdengo.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
The name of the game with Hisuian Samurott is finding as many opportunities as possible to use Ceaseless Edge in order to repeatedly set up Spikes. This set aims to leverage Hisuian Samurott's natural resistances by equipping an Assault Vest, allowing it to come in on Gholdengo, Heatran, and Kingambit lacking Low Kick and Tera Blast Fairy. Knock Off makes progress against teams otherwise unphased by Hisuian Samurott's offensive profile, removing valuable items from the likes of Zapdos, Dondozo, and Toxapex. Sacred Sword is an alternative that better rounds out Hisuian Samurott's neutral coverage while hitting Kingambit and opposing Hisuian Samurott. Hisuian Samurott is a great utilizer of priority moves due to its proficiency at weakening teams with entry hazards damage, and it has two options in Aqua Jet and Sucker Punch. Aqua Jet has better coverage against Fighting-types like Iron Valiant and Sneasler, while Sucker Punch trades in reliability for power and is a better option for revenge killing the likes of Choice-locked Dragapult. If electing to run Aqua Jet, Tera Water is ideal to boost its power as well as Razor Shell's. If running Sucker Punch, Tera Dark is the better choice, especially if Knock Off is also being used. On the flipside, Tera Steel is useful as a defensive Tera type for reversing the matchup against Moonblast from Enamorus and Iron Valiant and resisting Dragon-type moves from Dragapult. Tera Ghost is another option, stifling foes attempts at removing hazards via Rapid Spin, though this does make Hisuian Samurott vulnerable to Shadow Ball from Dragapult and Gholdengo, which it was previously able to come in on. 20 Special Defense EVs in combination with an Assault Vest ensures Hisuian Samurott takes a Moonblast from non-Choice Specs Iron Valiant or a Draco Meteor from Modest Choice Specs Dragapult from full HP.

Hisuian Samurott fits very well on balanced and bulky offensive teams that appreciate entry hazard stacking as well as role compression from it being able to take a few special hits thanks to its Assault Vest. Other Pokemon that fit on these sorts of offensive teams that also appreciate the opposing team being weakened by Spikes, such as Kingambit, Dragonite, and Sneasler are beneficial allies. Gholdengo specifically is a very good teammate, as it blocks both Rapid Spin and Defog and can take advantage of some of Hisuian Samurott's switch-ins like Amoonguss and Toxapex. Dragapult is also an option for spinblocking. It additionally is great at forcing switches, racking up hazard damage. VoltTurn support from Zapdos, Landorus-T, and Corviknight is a worthwhile consideration to give Hisuian Samurott more opportunities to throw off attacks. While Hisuian Samurott can come in once or twice on attacks from Pokemon like Gholdengo and Heatran, it's by no means a reliable answer. Ting-Lu and Tera Water Garganacl work well as primary answers to these threat while also forming a hazard stacking core alongside Hisuian Samurott. They can set up Stealth Rock while also greatly benefiting from its ability to remove Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Water)
sets.description:
Hisuian Samurott is one of Water’s best options for a Choice Scarf user. This is owed to its great STAB combination, of which both types are resisted by only a scant few Pokemon in the metagame, higher power than what is initially apparent due to Sharpness bolstering its slicing moves, a good Speed tier that allows it to outspeed and revenge kill key threats such as Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and unique progress-making utility for Water in the form of Ceaseless Edge and Knock Off.

Ceaseless Edge is Hisuian Samurott’s most important move, allowing it not only to threaten and KO foes with the raw power of a Sharpness-boosted Dark-type STAB move but also set up a layer of Spikes with each use, putting pressure on opposing teams and potentially opening up holes in defensive cores for its teammates to exploit. It is important to note that Spikes laid by Ceaseless Edge cannot be reflected by Magic Bounce, meaning Hisuian Samurott can safely click Ceaseless Edge against Hatterene and still get Spikes up. Hisuian Samurott’s secondary STAB move is a choice between Aqua Cutter and Razor Shell. Aqua Cutter is generally preferred for its consistency due it not making contact with the opponent and its perfect accuracy, allowing Hisuian Samurott to safely deal with Volcarona and Moltres. However, Razor Shell is guaranteed to OHKO Flutter Mane and provides Hisuian Samurott with more wallbreaking capability due to its 50% chance to reduce Defense if the user is willing to tolerate the risk of missing. Sacred Sword serves as an excellent coverage option, allowing Hisuian Samurott to eliminate foes such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Hisuian Samurott. Finally, Knock Off provides Hisuian Samurott with a secondary utility in the form of item removal, which can cripple Leftovers users such as Rotom-W, Corviknight, and Toxapex and open up Heavy-Duty Boots users such as Amoonguss to being chipped down by entry hazards, making Hisuian Samurott even riskier for foes to switch into.

In terms of teammates, physically defensive Rotom-W is an excellent partner for Choice Scarf Hisuian Samurott, checking several of Hisuian Samurott’s bad matchups such as Azumarill, Garchomp, and Scarf Great Tusk and providing Hisuian Samurott with safe opportunities to come in via Volt Switch. Toxapex is another great teammate for Hisuian Samurott, being able to switch into and take hits repeatedly from faster Choice Scarf users such as Sneasler, Enamorus, and Iron Valiant thanks to its defensive typing coupled with Regenerator and Recover. Moreover, Toxapex can serve as an answer to Urshifu-R and can compound on the pressure of Hisuian Samurott’s Spikes with its own Toxic Spikes, while benefitting itself from Hisuian Samurott’s Spikes punishing foes switching around. Gastrodon or Quagsire can absorb Electric-type moves for Hisuian Samurott and set up Stealth Rock to compliment Hisuian Samurott’s Spikes. Wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Greninja, Basculegion-M, and Walking Wake as well as sweepers such as Basculegion-F also synergize well with Hisuian Samurott, with Spikes support allowing them to more easily break through enemy teams and the speed control from Choice Scarf meaning potential revenge killers can be removed ahead of time. The speed control from Choice Scarf is still useful even on rain teams even when accompanied by Swift Swim Pokemon such as Basculegion-F, as rain will not always be present on the battlefield. Furthermore, either forme of Basculegion can serve as a spinblocker to prevent the removal of Hisuian Samurott’s Spikes.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Hisuian Samurott is a decent wallbreaker due to Adaptability, Choice Band, and a great STAB combination that also pressures the ever-present Corviknight to choose between recovery and Defogging. Ceaseless Edge is a versatile move that deals good damage to foes while also setting up Spikes, helping Hisuian Samurott's teammates or even itself to pick off chipped foes later in the game. Knock Off provides utility by removing items from switch-ins such as Corviknight and Quaquaval. Sucker Punch is a good priority move that lets Hisuian Samurott deal heavy damage to faster foes such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Zapdos. Brick Break can be used instead to deal with dual screens leads such as Corviknight and Mew. Hisuian Samurott's ability to set up Spikes and pester defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Scream Tail by removing their items is appreciated by various offensive teammates such as Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos that can take advantage of chipped foes. Fluffy and Intimidate Quaquaval wall Hisuian Samurott very easily, so spinblockers such as Desolate Land Skeledirge and Ceruledge are good partners as they can pressure Quaquaval and block it from removing Spikes set by Hisuian Samurott. Hisuian Samurott is susceptible to getting revenge killed due to low Speed and bulk, so robust walls such as Corviknight and Meloetta that can pivot and provide safe switch in opportunities to it are appreciated.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: After a Swords Dance boost, Hisuian Samurott becomes a terrifying wallbreaker that can dent physically defensive walls like Corviknight. Sucker Punch acts as speed control against Pokemon like Zapdos and Iron Moth. Ceaseless Edge forces defensive Pokemon, such as Corviknight, to switch in and choose between entry hazard removal or healing. Black Glasses is the item of choice, boosting its Dark-type moves without the recoil of Life Orb. Pokemon like Thundurus and Iron Moth are very useful teammates, as they compensate for Hisuian Samurott's average Speed tier and can heavily damage physical walls that counter Hisuian Samurott like Quaquaval and Zamazenta-C. In return, Hisuian Samurott wears down special walls with its ability to set up a layer of Spikes. Additionally, due to its unimpressive bulk, Hisuian Samurott relies on walls such as Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra to compensate for the lack of defensive utility it brings.

sets.name: Quiver Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Lilligant is a fearsome setup sweeper in NU thanks to the infamously potent combination of Quiver Dance + Terastallization. Tera patches up two of Lilligant's main weaknesses, being poor coverage and a poor defensive typing. Pollen Puff allows Lilligant to hit Grass-types like Appletun and Lurantis without having to rely on Tera Blast. It also doubles as nice coverage for Pokemon such as Umbreon and Mesprit, which pack the bulk and utility options to hinder a Lilligant sweep. Because Lilligant has Pollen Puff for Grass-types, it uses a Tera Blast type capable of threatening Flying-types, commonly Rock or Electric. Tera Rock has the added benefit of resisting Poison, letting Lilligant more easily deal with Muk or take a Poison-type attack from Hisuian Sneasel or Toxicroak in a pinch. Lilligant can opt to run Encore last in tandem with Tera Electric to take advantage of careless Thunder Wave users like Blissey and Umbreon, locking them into the move and granting Lilligant free setup opportunities. Sleep Powder can be used to grant even more setup opportunities, but without the added coverage, these setup opportunities are often moot. Life Orb is great for Lilligant, as Giga Drain can offset the recoil, and the added damage to special walls like Appletun and Bombirdier is greatly beneficial.

Lilligant is often found on more offensive teams, both creating and using openings and momentum for and by its teammates. Dedicated leads like Bombirdier and Froslass are the forefront of generating early momentum for offensive Pokemon; the entry hazards and utility options like a respective Memento or Destiny Bond create ample opportunities for Lilligant and other offensive teammates like Hisuian Sneasel, Veluza, and Vivillon. Choice Scarf Mesprit and Rotom can invite in special walls like Blissey, Cryogonal, and Umbreon and Trick them, completely impairing their ability to check Lilligant effectively.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description: Hisuian Lilligant is a dangerous sweeper due to its high Attack, Chlorophyll-boosted Speed in sun, and access to Victory Dance, which allows it to set up on physical attackers like Great Tusk, Hisuian Samurott, and Kingambit. In sun, Hisuian Lilligant can use its Grass-type STAB move Solar Blade without the drawbacks of the normal two-turn charge. Ice Spinner allows it to hit common checks that resist both of its STAB types such as Zapdos, Amoonguss, Dragapult, and Dragonite for super effective damage. Leftovers in particular works well with Victory Dance, as Hisuian Lilligant is able to heal from some of the damage it takes while it sets up on physical attackers. Life Orb is an option that helps Hisuian Lilligant overwhelm some targets with extra power like Walking Wake, OHKOing it with Close Combat after a Victory Dance. A Jolly nature allows it to Speed tie Unburden Adamant Sneasler in sun, while an Adamant nature provides extra power that may be necessary to overwhelm targets like Zapdos, Amoonguss, and Zamazenta. Tera Ghost allows Hisuian Lilligant to spinblock and threaten some of its best checks in Galarian Slowking, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge with Tera Blast. Tera Ghost also allows Hisuian Lilligant to block Extreme Speed from Dragonite, preventing revenge kills. Tera Fire with Tera Blast is also an option, giving Hisuian Lilligant a strong sun-boosted Fire-type STAB move for coverage to hit bulky targets like Amoonguss and Gholdengo hard. Another benefit of Tera Fire is an immunity to burn from Pokemon like Moltres and Cinderace. Hisuian Lilligant requires Torkoal as a partner, as Hisuian Lilligant requires sun support, which Torkoal is able to set up automatically with Drought. Hisuian Lilligant’s ability to weaken Water-types and opposing team structures makes Iron Moth a dangerous late-game sweeper in sun. Hisuian Lilligant is only able to afford to run one coverage move, which can leave it vulnerable to checks it cannot afford to run coverage for, such as Galarian Slowking, Gholdengo, Amoonguss, and Moltres. Great Tusk, Sandy Shocks, and Walking Wake are all great teammates capable of handling some of the aforementioned checks. Great Tusk and Sandy Shocks threaten Galarian Slowking, Gholdengo, and Moltres. Walking Wake is able to break Amoonguss with Draco Meteor, as well as blow past Moltres, which is usually able to wall Hisuian Lilligant.

sets.name: Victory Dance (Fighting)
sets.description:
Hisuian Lilligant is a strong choice on Fighting teams because of its ability to clean up games thanks to its signature move, Victory Dance, and being a great asset in the Ground, Water, and Flying matchups, which Fighting teams can struggle against. Leaf Blade 2HKOes Toxapex at +1 and threatens Water's two Unaware Pokemon, Dondozo and Quagsire. Close Combat hits Ice- and Steel-types trying to switch into Hisuian Lilligant's Grass STAB move, as well as having a favorable roll to OHKO both Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra at +1. Finally, Ice Spinner hits Dragon- and Flying-types such as Dragonite and Thundurus-T, as well as Unaware Clodsire on Ground. Wide Lens is used to reduce the accuracy drop from Hustle. Sleep Powder can be run to give Hisuian Lilligant more setup opportunities, but the loss of coverage in Ice Spinner or STAB in Close Combat is notable.

Great Tusk is a great teammate for Hisuian Lilligant, as it threatens out Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and the Poison-types that can stop a Hisuian Lilligant sweep. Great Tusk can soften up Hisuian Lilligant's checks by setting Stealth Rock. In return, Hisuian Lilligant uses Water-types such as Hisuian Samurott and Quagsire, which threaten Great Tusk, as setup opportunities. Iron Valiant can break through common checks to Hisuian Lilligant such as the aforementioned Skeledirge and Gholdengo thanks to either Shadow Ball on special sets or Knock Off on mixed ones. Sneasler is a secondary sweeper that can also threaten Fairy-types such as Enamorus-T. Its Choice Scarf set can also beat Volcarona, which can use Hisuian Lilligant as setup fodder, with Rock Slide and use Switcheroo to hinder defensive walls trying to switch in. Iron Hands uses its insane bulk, bolstered by Assault Vest, to sponge special attacks very easily from Pokemon such as Zapdos and Hatterene. It also hits Flying-types hard with its Electric STAB moves, and can pivot Hisuian Lilligant in with Volt Switch. In return, Hisuian Lilligant breaks the Ground-types that threaten both Iron Hands and Sneasler. Finally, Zamazenta takes physical attacks well with Dauntless Shield and can threaten Ghost-types that Hisuian Lilligant struggles to break with Crunch. Its Iron Defense sets also do well against Steel, where Hisuian Lilligant is less effective.

sets.name: Victory Dance Sweeper (Grass)
sets.description:
Hisuian Lilligant is a solid late-game sweeper for Grass teams thanks to Victory Dance in conjunction with Hustle. It can deal out considerable damage to some of the meta's bulkiest Pokemon such as Corviknight and Iron Hands and is the best wincon on Grass in order to beat Flying. Ice Spinner allows Hisuian Lilligant to threaten opposing Dragon- and Flying-types like Enamorus, Galarian Zapdos, and Dragapult, as well as opposing Ground-types like Clodsire and Great Tusk if it does not run Leaf Blade. Sleep Powder is often preferred over Leaf Blade to give Hisuian Lilligant an easier chance to set up, and the combination of Ice Spinner and Close Combat still targets a good portion of the metagame. However, Leaf Blade can be used to target Pokemon that resist Ice Spinner and Close Combat such as Toxapex and Azumarill. Wide Lens allows Hisuian Lilligant to offset the accuracy drop of its attacks due to Hustle and it also boosts the accuracy of Sleep Powder, making it a more consistent option to use in order to set up safely.

Choice Scarf Meowscarada is a great teammate that threatens faster Dragon-types like Dragapult and Walking Wake, while Hisuian Lilligant is able to beat bulky Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra and Corviknight that Meowscarada often lures in. Amoonguss is Hisuian Lilligant's best defensive partner, as its Poison typing helps it deal with opposing Fairy-types like Azumarill, Enamorus, and Iron Valiant and also removes Toxic Spikes. Amoonguss appreciates Hisuian Lilligant's ability to dispatch opposing Flying-types like Corviknight, which can render it setup fodder, and can also assist Hisuian Lilligant's setup using Spore. Iron Leaves is another offensive partner for Hisuian Lilligant that can threaten opposing Poison-types which Lilligant cannot break through like Toxapex. Iron Leaves appreciates Hisuian Lilligant being able to threaten opposing Dark-type Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Kingambit. Brambleghast offers hazard support with Spikes, allowing Hisuian Lilligant to have secure KOs on Pokemon like Alolan Muk. Furthermore, Brambleghast offers hazard removal with Rapid Spin, which improves Hisuian Lilligant's longevity by giving it more opportunities to switch in. Zarude is also an offensive partner that is able to threaten Gholdengo and also Skeledirge, which gives Grass teams a tough time in the Ghost matchup. Furthermore, its ability to threaten Poison's defensive staples like Clodsire, Toxapex, and Alolan Muk after a boost is appreciated. Rotom-C helps Hisuian Lilligant threaten key members Water teams if it opts not to use Leaf Blade, like Pelipper and Basculegion, while Hisuian Lilligant can threaten Thundurus-T so Rotom can threaten Flying teams easier.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description: With Chlorophyll, powerful STAB options in Solar Blade and Close Combat, along with a respectable base 105 Attack stat, Hisuian Lilligant can function as a powerful sun sweeper. It pairs well with the main sun setter, Mega Charizard Y, as it can switch into and threaten Mega Charizard Y’s checks such as Hippowdon, Heatran, and Clodsire; in return, Mega Charizard Y beats its checks like Gholdengo and Mega Scizor, if Hisuian Lilligant lacks Tera Blast. Solar Blade is used for raw power, although Leaf Blade is still an option for consistency outside sun. Tera Blast Fire, especially in sun, gives Lilligant a powerful third STAB option to punish foes that can tank its original STAB combination like Gholdengo, Mega Scizor, and Tera Poison Cresselia. Sleep Powder is an option to shut down checks such as Dragapult or scout for Tera types from Pokemon like Kingambit and Dondozo, which can be used as setup fodders or opportunities to give a free switch to an ally; this also allows Hisuian Lilligant to use Tera Fighting over Tera Fire for more power. Ice Spinner is another option, granting an OHKO on Flying-types that can absorb Hisuian Lilligant's STAB options such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and most Zapdos sets. Hazard support is invaluable in allowing boosted Solar Blade to OHKO Toxapex lacking Heavy-Duty Boots and Mega Scizor, making Great Tusk and Heatran good partners that also passively benefit from the sun. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster threats once the sun ends, so it appreciates a sturdy defensive core to back it up; Toxapex, Heatran, and Great Tusk can tank hits from and reliably check threats such as Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny once the sun goes down, while Landorus-T and Rotom-W are examples of pivots that can help bring Hisuian Lilligant in more easily.

sets.name: Hustle Breaker
sets.description: Hustle coupled with Victory Dance can be used to break common defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Great Tusk, Landorus, Kingambit, and Heatran; Hisuian Lilligant also outspeeds a good portion of the metagame after a Victory Dance boost, allowing it to threaten even common Choice Scarf users such as Urshifu-R, Tapu Lele, and Gholdengo. Its main drawback lies in the decrease in accuracy, which makes it inconsistent and potentially easy to KO. Wide Lens can be used to circumvent this, as the accuracy boost will minimize the chances of a miss. Grassium Z can allow Hisuian Lilligant to dismantle defensive cores, letting it OHKO the likes of Toxapex , Landorus-T, and defensive Tornadus-T and heavily damage Zapdos after a Victory Dance and Stealth Rock damage to potentially open up a hole for another ally like Kartana or Volcarona to clean up. Victory Dance allows it to outpace most of the metagame and fire off powerful attacks. Tera Blast Ground allows Hisuian Lilligant to snipe Gholdengo and Skeledirge for super effective damage whilst also notably beating common Poison-types like Toxapex and Sneasler. Sleep Powder can be considered to shut down foes and set up more easily. Ice Spinner is also an option to beat common Flying-types like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Icium Z is an option when running this, as it allows Hisuian Lilligant to score an OHKO on Gliscor, defensive Landorus-T, and defensive Garchomp whilst avoiding Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin chip from the latter two. Hisuian Lilligant has trouble setting up, as it is frail enough to be susceptible to the multitude of offensive Pokemon in the tier. Its inconsistent accuracy may also sometimes leave it open to attacks. Thus, dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko is beneficial, although it should be noted that the latter summons Electric Terrain, which nullifies Sleep Powder. Entry hazard support is important to score OHKOs on certain Pokemon; for example, Bloom Doom OHKOes Toxapex and Tornadus lacking Heavy-Duty Boots after Stealth Rock damage. As such, Garchomp and Ferrothorn are examples of good entry hazard setters. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant can still be defensively checked by Pokemon like Zapdos, if lacking Ice Spinner, Volcarona, and defensive Gholdengo; allies that can beat these checks include Volcarona and Mega Diancie.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: EV spread avoids an OHKO from Cobalion’s Close Combat while still outpacing Jolly Lucario.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Hisuian Zorua provides excellent utility to a team with its combination of a high Special Attack stat, unique defensive typing, and its ability to spread burns and Knock Off. Thanks to its Normal typing, Hisuian Zorua can use Tera Blast as a STAB move even before Terastallizing to hit threats like Alolan Grimer and Shroodle. Tera Fight let it hit Pawniard and provides defensive value by flipping its Dark-type weakness, while Tera Ground additionally allows it to hit Alolan Grimer, Glimmet, and Tinkatink. Hex in combination with Will-O-Wisp's burns does massive damage to even bulkier foes like Mudbray and Toedscool while cleanly OHKOing Drifloon. Will-O-Wisp helps neutralize physical attackers like Pawniard and Crabrawler and can turn them into setup fodders for other sweepers. Knock Off lets Hisuian Zorua soften up opposing teams and is also its best option for hitting opposing Hisuian Zorua. U-turn is an alternative that lets Hisuian Zorua capitalize on the switches it forces from foes like Drifloon. Nasty Plot is an option on dual screens teams where Hisuian Zorua can become a threatening sweeper.

Illusion is a highly unique ability that lets Hisuian Zorua create uncomfortable turns for your opponent by disguising as Pokemon whose checks it might beat, and Glimmet and Mudbray appreciate its ability to chip or beat opposing Mudbray and Drifloon, respectively. Pawniard enjoys Hisuian Zorua checking Crabrawler. Hisuian Zorua is often competing with Drifloon for the team's Ghost-type, so it appreciates teammates like Wattrel and Toedscool that can cover for its lack of Ground-type immunity. Crabrawler and Mudbray check opposing Pawniard for Hisuian Zorua when Tera Fight is not an option, and Alolan Grimer, Mudbray, and Croagunk switch into opposing Alolan Grimer.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Choice Specs Hisuian Zoroark is a fast and strong wallbreaker with good coverage. Not only are its coverage moves good, but it has STAB on a very spammable type with fantastic neutral coverage in OU, Ghost. An incredible ability in Illusion greatly improves its wallbreaking: it can disguise itself as another teammate to create mind games, scoring great damage if opponents guess wrong. Its unique typing blocks some revenge killing moves such as Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Ceruledge's Shadow Sneak, and Breloom's Mach Punch. Grass Knot is a great coverage option to OHKO Great Tusk and physically defensive Dondozo, potentially OHKO Garganacl, and 2HKO specially defensive Dondozo. Alternatively, Hyper Voice is a good STAB option, getting neutral coverage on most Pokemon that Shadow Ball cannot, and it ignores Hydreigon and Terastallized Skeledirge's Substitute. Flamethrower allows Hisuian Zoroark to 2HKO Corviknight and Amoonguss, as well as OHKOing Scizor. Alternatively, Focus Blast gives Hisuian Zoroark a way to catch incoming Kingambit off guard, and it hits Garganacl and Ting-Lu super effectively, which is very helpful if forgoing Grass Knot. With Trick, Hisuian Zoroark can cripple walls like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Garganacl, as well as bulky setup sweepers it cannot threaten immediately, like Tera Fairy Garganacl and Tera Fire or Tera Water Hatterene. However, giving away Choice Specs sacrifices some of the OHKOs and 2HKOs mentioned above. U-turn is a great alternative to bring teammates in safely on Assault Vest Azumarill and Ting-Lu. Tera Normal and Tera Ghost boost Hisuian Zoroark's already powerful STAB moves, with boosted Hyper Voice always OHKOing Great Tusk, while boosted Shadow Ball 2HKOes Assault Vest Azumarill. Tera Fighting is another good option, as it not only boosts Focus Blast, but it also turns Hisuian Zoroark's Dark weakness into a resistance, meaning it no longer fears Sucker Punch revenge killers.

Hisuian Zoroark fits best on offensive teams. Great Tusk can set Stealth Rock, helping Hisuian Zoroark KO foes more easily, and check the Dark-types it struggles with such as Kingambit and specially defensive Ting-Lu. Pivots such as Rotom-W and Meowscarada can bring Hisuian Zoroark safely into Amoonguss and Corviknight, respectively. Rotom-W in particular is a great teammate, since it can also spread paralysis, crippling boosted sweepers and naturally fast Pokemon such as Dragonite, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult for Hisuian Zoroark to outspeed and KO. Hisuian Zoroark dislikes opposing hazards: not only does it get worn down easily, but opponents may see through its disguise based on the damage it takes from Stealth Rock. Hence, it appreciates hazard removal and prevention from the aforementioned Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Hatterene. Great Tusk and Corviknight can also come in and take a hit from Kingambit and Meowscarada, respectively, which can revenge kill Hisuian Zoroark. Corviknight in particular really appreciates Hisuian Zoroark threatening Gholdengo, which blocks its Defog. Specially defensive Pokemon like Assault Vest Azumarill and Clodsire can take a hit from Hisuian Zoroark, thus forcing it out, given its frailty. To threaten both of these checks, Choice Band Breloom is a great partner. In return, U-turn Hisuian Zoroark can bring Breloom in on these Pokemon. Lastly, setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Volcarona, and Iron Moth appreciate Hisuian Zoroark's ability to threaten their checks such as Garganacl, Dondozo, and Skeledirge, letting them clean up afterwards. Hisuian Zoroark can also disguise as them to lure in their checks and either KO them or cripple them with Trick. Hisuian Zoroark can disguise as Dragonite, Kingambit, Baxcalibur, and Roaring Moon to lure in physical walls such as Great Tusk and Dondozo, only for them to be OHKOed by Grass Knot. Similarly, Hisuian Zoroark can also disguise as Volcarona and Iron Moth to lure in Clodsire and Toxapex, using Trick to cripple them and open up a potential sweep.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot Hisuian Zoroark is a devastating special wallbreaker thanks to its combination of unique typing, coverage, fantastic Speed, and a high Special Attack stat, and it can almost always threaten a KO after a boost. Its ability, Illusion, provides good utility by letting it draw out an unsuspecting teammate's check and blasting them with powerful special attacks. Shadow Ball hits nearly everything in the tier for solid damage with very few drawbacks, and it has the lovely side effect of potentially dropping a foe's Special Defense. Grass Knot can be utilized to sink many heavy defensive threats, such as Garganacl, Great Tusk, and Dondozo. This also comes with the advantage of being a reliable move against heavy foes like Ting-Lu without burning up valuable PP on Focus Blast or dealing with its less-than-stellar accuracy. Flamethrower hammers would-be switch-ins like Kingambit and Scizor. Alternatively, Focus Blast can be used to hit Ting-Lu, Hydreigon, Kingambit, and Garganacl with the same move. Tera Ghost allows Shadow Ball to more reliably OHKO Gholdengo on Focus Sash sets, and it also allows +2 Shadow Ball to OHKO Baxcalibur, Volcarona, Walking Wake, Iron Moth, and Slowking. Alternatively, Tera Fighting turns its Dark-type weakness into a resistance, leaving it less susceptible to Kingambit's Sucker Punch, Meowscarada's Knock Off, and Greninja's Dark Pulse, and it powers up Focus Blast to staggering heights. Tera Fighting Focus Blast OHKOes Baxcalibur and Garganacl and even has a good chance to OHKO Ting-Lu at +2 after Stealth Rock. Alternatively, Tera Fairy allows Hisuian Zoroark to hold off Dark-types as well as become immune to Dragapult's Dragon-type attacks. Focus Sash guarantees that Hisuian Zoroark has a chance to set up or attack. On the other hand, Life Orb can be used to add further power to Hisuian Zoroark's already formidable prowess. Life Orb allows Focus Blast to OHKO Baxcalibur, and it also ensures that +2 Shadow Ball OHKOes Volcarona, physically defensive Rotom-W, and Corviknight after Stealth Rock.

Hisuian Zoroark functions best as a setup sweeper on hyper and bulky offense teams. Great Tusk is a top-class partner, providing Hisuian Zoroark invaluable utility with its excellent defenses and Rapid Spin, which keeps entry hazards off Hisuian Zoroark's side of the field and leaves its Focus Sash intact. It also provides Hisuian Zoroark more opportunities to come in and set up by threatening Pokemon that hold it down indefinitely, such as Clodsire. Dragapult and Meowscarada are faster than Hisuian Zoroark, so Pokemon that can come in and revenge kill them, such as Kingambit and Choice Band Baxcalibur, are also appreciated. In return, Hisuian Zoroark can use Illusion to mask itself as Kingambit, Baxcalibur, and Roaring Moon and lure in physical walls like defensive Great Tusk and Dondozo to weaken or KO them. Entry hazard setters like Glimmora, Meowscarada, and Garchomp set up hazards to chip down foes into Hisuan Zoroark's KO range, and it can stop an incoming Rapid Spin from Great Tusk in return. Hisuian Zoroark can force damage on special walls like Ting-Lu, which is highly appreciated by other special attackers like Iron Moth and Hydreigon, and vice versa. In particular, Hydreigon and Hisuian Zoroark can play Illusion mind games with Fighting-type moves, and Hydreigon can topple Clodsire with Earth Power and Substitute or Tera Steel.

sets.name: Utility (Ghost)
sets.description:
Hisuian Zoroark is essential on Ghost teams due to its immunity to opposing Ghost-type moves, favorable Speed, and unique ability. It is an incredible asset in the Ghost matchup, as it allows you to play mind games against an opponent using Flutter Mane and Dragapult by disguising itself as Gholdengo and takes advantage of Substitute by forcing a lot of switches. Hex in conjunction with Will-O-Wisp deals superb damage against threats like Flutter Mane, Amoonguss, and Quagsire and negates passive recovery on walls such as Corviknight, Toxapex, and Ting-Lu. Furthermore, Will-O-Wisp lets you play around Sucker Punch users like Kingambit and burns other physical attackers such as Scizor that pose a threat to teammates like Flutter Mane and Mimikyu. Knock Off further cripples the aforementioned walls and removes Heavy-Duty Boots from foes, enhancing Brambleghast's Spikes, while Nasty Plot allows Hisuian Zoroark to capitalize on Substitute and use passive walls such as Toxapex, Brambleghast, and Dragalge as setup fodder. Leftovers and 252 HP EVs let Hisuian Zoroark take full advantage of Substitute and potentially sustain a few neutral attacks.

Flutter Mane appreciates Hisuian Zoroark luring in walls like Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Amoonguss and wearing them down with Hex and Will-O-Wisp. In return, it removes threatening Dark-types like Chien-Pao, Greninja, and Iron Jugulis. Dragapult checks Hydreigon, Baxcalibur, and Gholdengo and pivots into Hisuian Zoroark with U-turn. Gholdengo threatens Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant, Hatterene, and Flutter Mane and supports Hisuian Zoroark's Hex with Thunder Wave. Hisuian Zoroark also likes to disguise itself as the previously mentioned Dragapult and Gholdengo due to them also using Substitute and Hex, potentially tricking opponents and forming a very formidable Hex spam core. Mimikyu aids against Dark-types like Kingambit and Roaring Moon and provides useful priority in Shadow Sneak. Additionally, Mimikyu appreciates Hisuian Zoroark withering down and burning the majority of opposing teams, letting Mimikyu clean up late-game without any complications. Brambleghast helps Hisuian Zoroark chip down opposing teams with Spikes, removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin, and checks Water-types such as Rotom-W, Slowking, and Barraskewda. Skeledirge walls setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Mimikyu as well as general threats like Iron Valiant, Scizor, and Magnezone.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Normal)
sets.description:
Hisuian Zoroark is a crucial member of any good Normal team, offering good power along with an invaluable immunity to Fighting, letting it take attacks such as Choice Band Breloom's Mach Punch and Choice Scarf Iron Valiant's Close Combat that would otherwise threaten the type. Additionally, it can win the Ghost matchup with good prediction, which is a type that Normal teams usually struggle against. Trick lets Hisuian Zoroark ruin defensive answers, such as Toxapex and Ting-Lu, that would otherwise take its attacks with ease. Flamethrower allows Hisuian Zoroark to hit Steel-types like Corviknight and Iron Treads more reliably than Focus Blast, while Grass Knot hits Dondozo, which would otherwise take Hisuian Zoroark's attacks. Focus Blast lets Hisuian Zoroark eliminate troublesome Dark-types such as Hydreigon and Ting-Lu. Illusion lets Hisuian Zoroark bait in defensive answers to other threats, such as Corviknight and Toxapex switching into Maushold, and hinder them with Trick while also giving it a safe opportunity to switch into Fighting-type attacks.

Maushold greatly appreciates Hisuian Zoroark's ability to remove Ghost- and Steel-types, alongside its ability to hinder and remove Rocky Helmet from Pokemon such as Toxapex and Corviknight, to enable it to clean up with Population Bomb. In return, Maushold can remove entry hazards with Tidy Up and break through answers to Hisuian Zoroark such as the aforementioned Toxapex and Ting-Lu. Choice Scarf Staraptor is another great partner, as it provides a safe switch-in to Choice Scarf Great Tusk, which tends to lock into Headlong Rush, while dealing high amounts of damage itself to enable Hisuian Zoroark to clean up the rest of an opponent's team. It also provides a form of speed control against faster threats such as Dragapult. Cyclizar also provides a safe switch-in with Shed Tail while keeping hazards off the field with Rapid Spin. In return, Hisuian Zoroark can use these switch-in opportunities to hit the aforementioned Steel-types hard. Ditto can turn setup attempts on a Choice-locked Hisuian Zoroark on their heads, while Blissey can take strong special hits such as Sandy Shocks's STAB moves. Indeedee provides Psychic Terrain support to improve Hisuian Zoroark's matchup against Kingambit, and it can also use a Choice Scarf to deal with fast threats such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Flamigo and provide Healing Wish support.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Hisuian Zoroark plays as a terrifying setup sweeper with its Nasty Plot set, as it has an amazing STAB combination and can bait Pokemon with Illusion. It can break through Heatran, Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit with Focus Blast, which in tandem with Tera Fighting allows Hisuian Zoroark to strengthen its Focus Blast to break the aforementioned threats more easily while also baiting Sucker Punch from Kingambit. Setup sweepers and wallbreakers like Mega Scizor and Iron Valiant appreciate Hisuian Zoroark baiting Skeledirge and Gholdengo. In return, Mega Scizor deals with Weavile and Kartana while Iron Valiant threatens Ting-Lu and Kingambit. Great Tusk is also a valuable teammate, as it deals with threats like Kingambit and Mega Lopunny while also providing general utility. While Hisuian Zoroark is powerful, it is vulernable to revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, and Tapu Koko. As such, Pokemon like Zapdos, Slowbro, Ferrothorn, Kingambit and Great Tusk are good partners. Checks to revenge killers like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult are recommended; these include Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Heatran.

sets.name: Happy Hour
sets.description: With Happy Hour + Normalium Z, Hisuian Zoroark becomes a decent wincon, being given setup opportunities by baiting Pokemon with Illusion. +1 Focus Blast OHKOes Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn and Dark-types like Weavile and Mega Gyarados. Happy Hour Hisuian Zoroark is best suited on hyper offense teams because it can take advantage of dual screens to set up more easily. Hisuian Zoroark can disguise as Defiant Kingambit and bait Kingambit checks like Great Tusk and Skarmory. Tapu Koko can provide dual screens and pivot into Hisuian Zoroark against Pokemon like Gholdengo and Tornadus-T; this is best when Hisuian Zoroark is disguised as Kingambit or Mega Gyarados. Grimmsnarl is also an excellent teammate because it provides dual screens and lures and KOs Kingambit with Superpower. Tapu Lele appreciates Hisuian Zoroark beating Steel-types like Gholdengo and Heatran; Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain also blocks Kingambit's Sucker Punch, letting Hisuian Zoroark KO it. Similarly, Mega Gyarados offensively checks Kingambit and wallbreaks early-game, letting Hisuian Zoroark sweep late-game. Dragapult can form an offensive Ghost-spam core with Hisuian Zoroark and appreciates it KOing Dark-types with Focus Blast. Entry hazard support from setters like Landorus-T and Glimmora allows Hisuian Zoroark to sweep more easily, since it struggles to OHKO most Pokemon even at +1.

sets.name: Utility (Ghost)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Z-Happy Hour (Normal)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Gothitelle is a wallbreaker that enables its teammates by trapping and removing various walls. Thunderbolt targets Corviknight, Alomomola, Toxapex, and Pelipper, while Grass Knot OHKOes Dondozo, Hippowdon, and defensive Great Tusk, 2HKOes Garganacl, and 2HKOes Ting-Lu and Iron Treads with Tera Grass. Psyshock is chosen over Psychic to more effectively remove Blissey and Clodsire. Trick is a decent midground option that cripples Pokemon Gothitelle might not otherwise beat, like Tera Steel Ting-Lu and Corviknight, but it comes at the cost of greatly reducing Gothitelle's wallbreaking potential, so it should generally be used sparingly. Tera Fairy is used to trap Miraidon, Walking Wake, and Koraidon locked into their Dragon-type STAB moves, and it lets Gothitelle revenge kill weakened Chi-Yu and Chien-Pao locked into a Dark-type STAB move. Alternatively, Tera Grass allows it to 2HKO Ting-Lu and Iron Treads while weakening strong attacks from Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads. Gothitelle fits best on balance teams, where it can make powerful teammates like Miraidon, Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao into wincons, since it removes many of their common checks. Gothitelle is frail and dislikes hard switching into the walls it seeks to remove, so it greatly appreciates pivots such as Flip Turn Iron Bundle and U-turn users such as Miraidon, Koraidon, and Corviknight. After Gothitelle has picked up a KO, many offensive Pokemon force it out, so standard defensive backbones consisting of Pokemon like Toxapex, Iron Treads, Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Skeledirge are vital.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Shadow Tag Gothitelle can trap most defensive Pokemon, paving the way for its teammates to sweep.
  • Trick facilitates trapping defensive walls like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk by locking them into an unfavorable move. Psychic targets Great Tusk and Toxapex, while Psyshock helps Gothitelle trap Clodsire better. Thunderbolt allows Gothitelle to trap Corviknight if it's not running U-turn or has a Choice item. Grass Knot KOes Great Tusk, Dondozo and hits Ting-Lu hard. Taunt is used to limit phazing attempts and Choice locked status moves, forcing the trapped Pokemon to use Struggle.
  • Rest allows Gothitelle to more effectively PP stall foes and remain healthy.
  • Choice Specs Gothitelle plays a more offensive role, aiming to rack up KOs. On the other hand, Choice Scarf variants are more likely to use Trick to beat opposing walls.
  • 32 HP and 4 Defense EVs allow Gothitelle to avoid being 2HKOed and 3HKOed from Ting-Lu's and Clodsire's Earthquake, respectively. 220 Speed EVs allow Choice Specs variants to outspeed defensive Great Tusk and Annihilape and Choice Scarf variants to outspeed offensive Great Tusk.
  • Gothitelle usually uses its Tera type to trap and beat Choice locked foes it otherwise would not trap; Tera Fairy beats Miraidon and Koraidon Choice locked into Dragon moves, Tera Water tanks Koraidon's Flare Blitz and Iron Bundle's Ice Beam, and Tera Flying avoids Earthquake from Ting-Lu and Great Tusk.
  • Gothitelle's favorite partners are powerful sweepers and cleaners such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Kingambit, and Chien-Pao, all of which appreciate Gothitelle removing one or more of their checks.

sets.name: Delay Goth (Trapper)
sets.description:
• This Gothitelle set aims to trap and PP stall weak walls so that its offensive teammates can take over mid- to late-game. This Gothitelle set can come in on weak walls like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Alomomola, and defensive Great Tusk and beat them by PP stalling them.
  • Charm and Calm Mind are use to boost Gothitelle's survivability while PP stalling its foe.
  • Taunt is used to stop phazing attempts and make the trapped Pokemon use their attacking PP, thus depleting their PP faster. Stored Power is an alternative for teams that benefit from having more wallbreaking potential or that have a good matchup against the Dark-types of the tier like Chien-Pao and Kingambit.
  • The 24 Speed EVs allow Gothitelle to be faster than uninvested Corviknight, trapping it if it's not running U-turn. The Defense investment is used to tank hits well for PP stalling purposes, with attacks such as Ting-Lu's Earthquake being only a 4HKO.
  • Tera Fairy is used for its solid defensive typing and ability to trap Choice-locked Dragon-types like Miraidon and Koraidon, Tera Water is an option for its overall great defensive typing, granting resistances to Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash, Koraidon's Flare Blitz, and Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump or Ice Beam. Lastly, Tera Ground is used to allow Gothitelle to trap Miraidon locked into an Electric move or defeat Double Dance sets one-on-one.
  • Gothitelle's favorite partners are powerful sweepers and cleaners, especially setup sweepers that take advantage of defensive Pokemon having their PP drained to set up easily and without risk. Common examples include Swords Dance Koraidon, Swords Dance Chien-Pao, Double Dance Miraidon, and Calm Mind Flutter Mane.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
With Sawsbuck's niche combination of Headbutt and Serene Grace, it can utilize Choice Scarf to outspeed and attempt to shut down the entire unboosted metagame through flinches and potentially turn the tides on a match. Sawsbuck's great Speed also makes for decent speed control, getting the jump on many other Choice Scarf users such as Rotom-F and Indeedee-F and setup sweepers such as Quiver Dance Masquerain. However, Sawsbuck can also be unreliable at times, only Speed tying with threats like Choice Scarf Haunter and Trailblaze Houndoom and being outsped by Choice Scarf Alolan Dugtrio and Dragon Dance Charizard. When not wanting to rely on Headbutt flinches, Double-Edge gives Sawsbuck a much stronger Normal STAB move that also helps make up for its average Attack and makes it a more reliable revenge killer. Tera Normal further strengthens Double-Edge, helps make up for Headbutt's low power, and allows Sawsbuck to better take attacks such as Haunter's Sludge Bomb and Pyroar's Fire Blast. Horn Leech gives Sawsbuck a secondary STAB move, hitting threats like Klawf, Whiscash, and Misdreavus harder while providing some longevity. Zen Headbutt OHKOes Haunter while also benefiting from Serene Grace and Stomping Tantrum is Sawsbuck's best coverage move for Steel-types such as Tinkatuff and Perrserker. However the last slot is somewhat flexible, with other options including Megahorn for Gogoat, Play Rough for Spiritomb, and Thunder Wave to benefit Headbutt later on.

Alolan Persian and Tinkatuff both help to facilitate Sawsbuck as a late-game cleaner; the two of them can reliably spread paralysis with Thunder Wave, while the former can use Parting Shot to grant Sawsbuck safer field entry, and the latter can remove items with Knock Off to hinder the longevity of walls that rely on Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers as well as slow down faster Choice Scarf users like Basculin and Alolan Dugtrio. Dark-types like Skuntank and the previously mentioned Alolan Persian help with Ghost-types, making Sawsbuck's Headbutt much easier to spam. Skuntank's Toxic and Toxic Spikes also pair well with Sawsbuck's Headbutt flinches to wear down foes, with Skuntank also offering extra speed control in Sucker Punch and helping against Grass-types like Gogoat while Sawsbuck helps against Ground-types like Whiscash and Dugtrio. Normal-type teammates like Indeedee-F and Pyroar can also help against Ghost-types and other Normal checks, being able to overwhelm them and make them easier for Sawsbuck to pick off. Furthermore, special wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Basculin and Flapple can help break through defensive threats such as Hisuian Avalugg and Spiritomb. Finally, when deciding on coverage moves, teammates that can pick up sacrificed coverage are greatly appreciated, such as Alolan Dugtrio and Whiscash to check Steel-types and Charizard and Rotom-F to check Grass-types.

sets.name: Spore
sets.description:
Amoonguss is the tier's sole defensive user of Spore, as it can stick around and put foes to sleep throughout a match. Giga Drain affords Amoonguss extra longevity, which is particularly helpful because Regenerator often cannot keep up with the damage that Amoonguss takes. However, Grass Knot hits foes like Dondozo, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu harder. Clear Smog removes the boosts of setup sweepers like Dragonite, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and Bulk Up Great Tusk. Foul Play, on the other hand, gives Amoonguss a way to pressure Dragapult immediately while still punishing physical setup sweepers. Red Card phazes setup sweepers like Iron Valiant and Walking Wake. Alternatively, Rocky Helmet lets Amoonguss punish U-turn users like Meowscarada and Scizor, while Covert Cloak is a valid option to check Garganacl more easily. Tera Water Amoonguss checks Cinderace, while Tera Fire Amoonguss can use Clear Smog safely on Tera Fire Breloom at the cost of becoming weak to Ground-types like Great Tusk. Maximum HP investment with 84 Special Defense EVs prevents a 2HKO from Choice Specs Dragapult's Shadow Ball; the rest of the investment is poured in Defense to better check Great Tusk.

Amoonguss is best utilized on balance teams that appreciate it taking a foe out of commission with Spore. Gholdengo and Dragapult greatly appreciate this as well as Amoonguss's ability to check Ting-Lu. Cinderace and Kingambit are other good offensive teammates that appreciate Amoonguss threatening Dondozo. Because Amoonguss relies mostly on Regenerator for its recovery, entry hazard removal in the form of Great Tusk or Iron Treads is key; Great Tusk also checks Cinderace, while Iron Treads can help deal with Gholdengo. Even though Amoonguss has the ability to check some setup sweepers with Clear Smog, it is best to pair it with an Unaware teammate like Skeledirge or Dondozo, which can handle Pokemon like Tera Flying Roaring Moon much more effectively. Pokemon like Dragonite and Choice Band Roaring Moon also make for good partners, as Amoonguss is one of the best Iron Valiant checks.

sets.name: Mixed Wall (Grass)
sets.description:
Survives Choice Specs Greninja's Ice Beam.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Poison)
sets.description:
Amoonguss provides Poison teams with breathing room against Ground-type attacks from behemoths like Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks due to its status as the only viable Poison team option with a Ground neutrality, which helps it form a defensive core alongside Toxapex and Skuntank. Growth lets Amoonguss threaten Ground teams by breaking through Water Absorb Clodsire after enough boosts. Alternatively, Toxic or Spore may be used to double Stomping Tantrum's power against Steel- and Poison-types like Gholdengo and Gengar that can pivot into Amoonguss and use it as setup fodder. Giga Drain and Synthesis provide Amoonguss with ample recovery to sustain itself in the Water and Ground matchups. A Relaxed nature is used to not dampen the power of Amoonguss's Stomping Tantrum, while Defense EVs are prioritized to help against physical Ground-types like Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

Toxapex forms an effective physically defensive Regenerator core alongside Amoonguss, as it deals with Fire- and Ice-types such as Paldean Tauros-F and Chien-Pao that give Amoonguss trouble while wearing down the opposing team with a combination of Toxic Spikes and Rocky Helmet. Skuntank deals with Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Espathra and Flutter Mane and uses Sucker Punch to pick off threats such as Dragapult late-game. It can also run Fire Spin to trap and forcibly remove Hatterene—a Pokemon that greatly threatens Amoonguss and prevents Skuntank from setting Toxic Spikes against Fairy and Psychic teams with ease. Unaware Clodsire is a specially defensive wall that deals with nearly all special attackers including Volcarona, Hydreigon, and non-Psyshock Flutter Mane. It also sets Spikes, which Amoonguss benefits from due to its ability to force switches, and is able to heavily damage Kingambit in a pinch. Glimmora provides entry hazard support by setting Stealth Rock and can use Toxic in combination with Corrosion to debilitate Steel- and Poison-types that Amoonguss hates such as Corviknight and Toxapex. It can remove entry hazards with Mortal Spin, which helps with Amoonguss's longevity in case its Heavy-Duty Boots have been removed, and is also the primary way of dealing with Skeledirge. Iron Moth can don a Choice Scarf to deal with boosted threats such as Swords Dance Chien-Pao and Dragon Dance Baxcalibur, which shatter Poison teams, or run a Substitute set to better deal with Kingambit. Both Glimmora and Iron Moth can also run Air Balloon, which is greatly appreciated when up against Choice Specs Sandy Shocks or Choice Band Great Tusk, as these two have a good chance to overwhelm Amoonguss in the long run.

sets.name: Redirection Support
sets.description:
• Amoonguss is the tier’s premier redirector, neutralizing foes with Spore and sustaining its teammates with Pollen Puff. Its defensive prowess, coupled with Regenerator, provides the sustainability to soak up hits while supporting its team.
