Amoonguss pairs incredibly well with setup attackers such as Bulk Up Palafin-H and Swords Dance Iron Hands, which appreciate its redirection and healing capabilities and make up for its near-nonexistent offensive pressure. While Amoonguss is a great support Pokemon, it struggles against Fire-types like Heatran and Volcanion, and its utility is diminished by Cresselia's Lunar Blessing and Safety Goggles users.

  • As the most consistent sleep user in the tier, Amoonguss's Spore forces switches to powder-immune foes. This is especially powerful in Trick Room, as Amoonguss can utilize its low Speed to render foes immobile before they can act.

  • Rage Powder makes it easier for teammates to use setup moves like Swords Dance and Bulk Up or set field conditions such as Trick Room or Tailwind safely. In addition, it can draw attacks away from frail attackers like Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane, generating space for them.

  • Pollen Puff heals teammates and damages foes in a pinch, allowing Amoonguss to provide value even during the effects of Taunt.

  • Clear Smog enables Amoonguss to check setup threats like Bulk Up Palafin-H and Belly Drum Iron Hands. Protect is helpful in scouting foes’ moves, blocking Fake Out, and improving overall survivability.

  • 244 HP and 136 Special Defense EVs ensure that Amoonguss can take two Shadow Balls from Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Sitrus Berry recovery. The remaining EVs are dumped into Defense.

  • 28 Speed IVs let Amoonguss underspeed Iron Hands and Kingambit under Trick Room.

  • Sitrus Berry improves Amoonguss's survivability when redirecting multiple attacks. Rocky Helmet can be used to rack up damage upon redirecting contact attacks such as Palafin-H's Jet Punch and punish U-turn from Rillaboom and Landorus-T.

  • Tera Water turns Amoonguss's weaknesses to Fire- and Ice-type moves from foes such as Volcanion and Chien-Pao into resistances. Tera Dark can be used to improve its matchup against Indeedee-F and Armarouge teams and gain immunity to Prankster Taunt from Tornadus and Grimmsnarl.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Amoonguss has a great defensive profile compared to most other Toxic Spikes absorbers, and this set can help it even further with a slow switch to another teammate once per game.

  • Pivoting with Leaf Storm: After using Leaf Storm, Eject Pack activates and Amoonguss is switched out; however, it can also be activated by other stat drops, such as Intimidate and Special Defense drops from Shadow Ball.

  • Sludge Bomb versus Clear Smog: Sludge Bomb is preferred for breaking Tera Fairy Wo-Chien's Substitutes and dealing good chip damage against Chi-Yu, but Clear Smog does a great job of clearing boosts from bulky sweepers such as Palafin-H.

  • Bold versus Relaxed: Using Relaxed with a Speed IV of 0 gives Amoonguss the slowest possible pivoting, mostly against mirror matches. However, if both are Terastallized, this means the slower Amoonguss could get hit by Spore, and Amoonguss is already slower than the vast majority of the metagame with Bold.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Amoonguss has a good defensive typing, it'll need Terastallization to deal with some top tier threats like Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Amoonguss a key resistance to Ice- and Fire-type attacks, making the matchup against Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Chi-Yu much more reasonable.

  • Steel: Tera Steel makes the Iron Bundle match up tilt in Amoonguss's favor, with even Focus Sash Iron Bundle being unable to catch Amoonguss if Eject Pack is intact.

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type grants a Psychic-type immunity, along with a STAB Foul Play.

  • Poison: A Poison Tera type removes Amoonguss's Ice-, Fire-, and Flying-type weaknesses; and makes Clear Smog stronger due to its Base Power being increased to 60 along with the bonus STAB; however this increases its vulnerability to Ground-type attacks. Tera Poison also still retains Amoonguss's Toxic Spikes absorbing utility.

  • Fire: Fire isn't the best defensive typing, but it's a way to retain a Fairy resistance if dealing with Ice- and Fire-type attacks is needed.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• With good bulk, a solid defensive typing, the ability to absorb Toxic Spikes, and access to Spore and Regenerator, Amoonguss is a fantastic support and disruptor option.

  • Sludge Bomb versus Clear Smog: Sludge Bomb gives Amoonguss a decent STAB to use against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, and breaks Wo-Chien's Substitute when its weak to it. On the other hand, Clear Smog prevents Amoonguss from getting set up on unless the opponent is Steel-type or has a Substitute up.

  • Giga Drain: Unlike Sludge Bomb, Giga Drain OHKOs Iron Bundle after Stealth Rock damage, and doesn't have to worry about Tera Water.

Other Options

  • Toxic: Toxic's conflicts with Spore make it a lesser option, but it's a devastating option against some bulky Spore absorbers such as Wo-Chien and Annihilape.

  • Hex: Hex both punishes foes put to sleep by Spore and hits Air Balloon Gholdengo and Flutter Mane.

  • Stomping Tantrum: Stomping Tantrum deals decent damage to Gholdengo and Magnezone.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite Amoonguss's solid defensive typing, several major threats such as Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur will require Terastallization to deal with.

  • Water: Tera Water is Amoonguss's ticket for dealing with Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur.

  • Dark: Tera Dark removes its weakness to Psychic-type attacks and makes Foul Play stronger.

  • Poison: Tera Poison retains Amoonguss's ability to use Black Sludge and absorb Toxic Spikes, at the cost of being weak to the common Earthquake.

  • Steel: While it makes Amoonguss weak to Ground- and Fighting-type attacks, it also grants Amoonguss a better matchup against Iron Bundle, especially if using Giga Drain.

Items

  • Leftovers: The extra recovery from Leftovers pairs well with the free turns Spore often grants Amoonguss.

  • Black Sludge: Black Sludge is a great way to get around Item Clause if Leftovers is already in use. Note, if Amoonguss Terastallizes into a type that isn't Poison, it will take damage instead.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet punishes contact moves with residual damage, potentially breaking Focus Sash from foes like Breloom and Great Tusk in the process.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Amoonguss is a decent wall that serves as a stopgap against rain wallbreakers like Barraskewda and Floatzel while also checking other offensive threats like Kartana, Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, and Urshifu-R. Regenerator allows Amoonguss to check those same threats long-term; it also prevents it from being worn down by pivots like Rotom-W and Tapu Koko as well as entry hazards if its Heavy-Duty Boots is removed via Knock Off. Spore incapacitates switch-ins such as Heatran, Volcarona, and Dragapult; the latter two would otherwise use it as setup fodder, while the former completely walls Amoonguss by being immune to Sludge Bomb. Sludge Bomb spreads status against the aforementioned Volcarona and Dragapult as well as bulkier switch-ins like Skeledirge and Tornadus-T and threatens Iron Valiant. Hidden Power Fire lets Amoonguss chip Poison-immune foes like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor as well as OHKO Kartana, preventing them from safely switching in. Heavy-Duty Boots lets it switch in as much as needed without fear of entry hazard damage; it also prevents Regenerator recovery from being stifled in longer games. Rocky Helmet is an alternative that wears down contact attackers like Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T as well as the aforementioned rain wallbreakers in Barraskewda and Floatzel. It should only be used if entry hazard control is decent enough, however, with support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Rotom-W. Tera Water provides invaluable resistances against Fire and Ice, letting Amoonguss potentially get an emergency Sludge Bomb or Spore in against foes like Weavile and Heatran. Tera Steel is an alternative that lets Amoonguss emergency check offensive foes like Tapu Lele while also giving it a better matchup against non-Heat Wave Tornadus-T; it also retains the Ice resistance given by Tera Water. Rotom-W is an excellent partner, as it stifles offensive and defensive Pokemon alike that Amoonguss struggles with, such as Heatran, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. In return, Amoonguss takes pressure off Rotom-W as a check to rain wallbreakers and can deal with Rotom-W switch-ins like Ferrothorn and Tangrowth. Gholdengo completely counters Amoonguss by virtue of its immunity to Spore and it taking negligible damage from Hidden Power Fire; as such, checks to it such as Kingambit and Poison Jab Clodsire are recommended, with the latter forcing Gholdengo to Terastallize so it can freely fish for poison.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: 252 HP EVs and 80 Special Defense EVs allow Amoonguss to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Primarina's Hydro Pump after Stealth Rock and guarantee that it survives Mega Manectric's Overheat after Stealth Rock. Seed Bomb lets it handle Calm Mind Primarina

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Alomomola is a solid defensive pivot that sets itself apart from Toxapex as a result of its lack of Ground-type weakness and access to Wish, with the former quality letting it check Great Tusk in addition to Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Palafin-H. However, Alomomola is quite passive, succumbs to Koraidon and Chien-Pao after they have boosted their Attack or Terastallized, and is easily trapped by Gothitelle. Whirlpool's passive damage makes up for Alomomola's poor offenses and prevents double switches from the opponent. Play Rough hits Koraidon and Chien-Pao decently hard, and it prevents Miraidon from switching into Alomomola relatively freely. Minimum Speed investment ensures that Corviknight cannot exploit Alomomola to get off a slower U-turn to gain momentum. Tera Fairy resists Koraidon's Fighting-type STAB moves as well as Chien-Pao's Crunch, and it is immune to Dragon-type attacks such as Koraidon's Outrage and Choice-locked Miraidon and Walking Wake's Draco Meteor. Rocky Helmet prevents passivity by punishing Pokemon like Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao. Alomomola appreciates being paired with special walls that can check Pokemon like Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane for it, such as Clodsire, Blissey, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu. The latter two also especially benefit from Alomomola's Wish due to their lack of reliable recovery. Skeledirge and Gholdengo are also effective partners since they check Breloom for Alomomola. Alomomola requires an entry hazard remover in Great Tusk, Corviknight, or Iron Treads, as it is likely 2HKOed by Choice Scarf Koraidon's Close Combat or Choice Band Chien-Pao's Crunch after Stealth Rock. Alomomola should also be used in tandem with secondary defensive Koraidon checks such as defensive Great Tusk or Skeledirge—which also checks Breloom for it—or speed control in the form of Iron Bundle, Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Choice Scarf Koraidon, or Choice Scarf Miraidon to revenge kill Koraidon and Chien-Pao at +2.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
• Alomomola is a bulky pivot against physical attackers such as Koraidon and Chien-Pao on balance or defensive teams.
  • The decision between Play Rough and Chilling Water depends on your preference. Play Rough is important since it provides actual damage against Chien-Pao and Koraidon; on the other side, Chilling Water is an effective stop to Bulk Up Great Tusk and bulky Palafin, which otherwise are annoying Pokemon to deal with for defensive teams.
  • Whirlpool is a better support option than Light Screen on more defensive teams, since its continuous damage and trapping allow Alomomola to break past some Pokemon, such as Ting-Lu. On the other hand, Light Screen is better for offensive teams, since it helps them switch against powerful special attackers such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane without sacrificing a Pokemon.
  • Besides healing Alomomola with Protect, Wish helps its teammates not get worn down, especially walls without reliable recovery like Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk.
  • The item choice depends on your team structure. If you have good entry hazard removal and need more damage against threats, then Rocky Helmet is the best choice. Leftovers is useful when you have good hazard removal but can also inflict good damage with your teammates; it also prevents some 2HKOs, for example from Choice Band Chien-Pao's Crunch. Without good hazard removal, Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred choice.
  • Run a Relaxed nature with Play Rough, or if you have Chilling Water + Whirlpool and wish to sacrifice some Speed for full Whirlpool damage. Otherwise, run Bold.
  • Tera Fairy provides Alomomola with Fighting and Dark resistances, letting it switch in more comfortably and stop setup from Koraidon and Chien-Pao. Additionally, the Dragon immunity lets it sponge hits such as Koraidon's Dragon Claw and Outrage, or Draco Meteor from Miraidon.
  • Special walls work well alongside Alomomola's physical defense, such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Blissey, and Corviknight.
  • Other great partners are Toxapex and Dondozo, as Alomomola relieves pressure on them to check threats such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk. Dondozo is especially helpful here due to its Unaware ability. Unfortunately, you also stack weaknesses against common special attackers such as Miraidon and Iron Bundle; this should be considered while teambuilding.

sets.name: Wish Fish (Defensive)
sets.description:
Alomomola is a defining aspect of stall teams, as its huge HP stat and unique combination of Wish and Regenerator let it keep itself healthy while repeatedly pivoting out to and healing teammates such as Dondozo, reducing their reliance on low-PP recovery moves and compensating for their lack of reliable recovery. Furthermore, its excellent typing and great physical bulk allow it to check threats like Cinderace and Dragonite and absorb Knock Off from common Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, preserving its teammate's Heavy-Duty Boots. Whirlpool further enhances Alomomola's pivoting abilities, letting it trap switch-ins and pivot out to the appropriate answer while preventing their double switch. In conjunction with Protect, Whirlpool also racks up passive damage on offensive Pokemon and walls such as Rotom-W and Ting-Lu that lack reliable recovery. Protect also allows Alomomola to heal itself with Wish, scout the moves of powerful wallbreakers, and prevent them from forcing progress when paired with Future Sight. Chilling Water makes Alomomola a more self-sufficient physical wall, reducing its passivity against sweepers such as Roaring Moon, Ceruledge, and Bulk Up Great Tusk. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Alomomola to avoid entry hazard damage before getting struck by Knock Off, which is especially important against Toxic Spikes. Minimizing Alomomola's Speed allows it to underspeed Corviknight to hit the incoming switch-in from U-turn instead and thus, avoid wasting PP due to Pressure. Tera Flying improves Alomomola's matchup against Great Tusk and Meowscarada, turning it into an even better Knock Off absorber, and lets it wall Breloom. It also makes Alomomola immune to Spikes and allows it to take less passive damage from Salt Cure.

Alomomola's Wish and ability to blanket check various threats benefit all of its teammates on stall teams. Toxapex is an exceptional partner that forms a strong Regenerator core with Alomomola. Together, they can stall Garganacl out of Salt Cure PP and pivot around strong physical attackers such as Breloom, Choice Band Dragapult, and Roaring Moon. Dondozo handles physical sweepers too powerful for Alomomola to deal with, such as Kingambit and Azumarill, and greatly appreciates Wish due to its lack of reliable recovery. Alomomola's low special bulk mandates sturdy specially defensive partners; Clodsire can take on special sweepers such as Gholdengo and Hydreigon that attempt to use Alomomola as setup fodder, while Blissey switches into the tier's most powerful special wallbreakers, such as Choice Specs Dragapult, Walking Wake, and Hisuian Zoroark. Ting-Lu checks special attackers like Dragapult and Iron Moth and, alongside Clodsire and Toxapex, sets entry hazards that can quickly wear down offensive teams to let Alomomola apply more pressure with Whirlpool. Like Dondozo, it also greatly appreciates Wish to reduce its reliance on Rest. Talonflame carries Defog to account for Alomomola's vulnerability to entry hazards after taking Knock Off. Corviknight can do the same as well as absorb Knock Off for Alomomola. In addition, Talonflame checks Breloom, while Corviknight checks Meowscarada, which lets Alomomola preserve its Terastallization. Lastly, Gholdengo checks Breloom and Iron Valiant, appreciates Alomomola dealing with Cinderace and Great Tusk, and provides stall with a setup sweeper to break down balance teams with Nasty Plot.

sets.name: Coil
sets.description: Eelektross makes for one of the most potent bulky setup sweepers in the tier due to its lack of weaknesses and access to the highly coveted Coil. Eelektross' defensive profile, notably boasting a paralysis and Ground immunity, grants it safe entry against tier staples like Sandaconda, Chansey, and Jolteon, and it can even set up Coil in front of them. Drain Punch allows Eelektross to maintain its health while boosting. Dragon Tail lets Eelektross beat opposing setup sweepers like Coil Sandaconda, Bulk Up Ursaring, and Curse Muk. Instead of Dragon Tail, Eelektross can use a move like Substitute or Rest to greatly help against status inducers such as Rotom, Drifblim, and Qwilfish. The former two can otherwise easily outspeed and burn Eelektross and eventually beat it down with boosted Hex. Tera Steel prevents Toxic from Muk, Qwilfish, and Vespiquen and retains an amazing defensive profile thanks to Levitate. Entry hazards set by the likes of Qwilfish and Sandaconda allow Eelektross to rack up damage against incoming checks like Rotom and Lurantis with Dragon Tail. Drifblim and the aforementioned Qwilfish also appreciate Eelektross's Electric resistance.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Assault Vest Eelektross is a premier defensive pivot. Its lack of weaknesses, immunity to Spikes and Toxic Spikes, and excellent Assault Vest-boosted special bulk allow it to check common special attackers like Jolteon, Zoroark, and Oricorio. Its low Speed tier paired with 0 Speed IVs allows it to take hits and then safely bring in frailer teammates like Haunter, Zoroark, and Bruxish with U-turn. As such, it fits well on VoltTurn cores with the likes of Bombirdier, Passimian, and Scyther, wearing down the opposing team with pivot moves. Discharge is prefered over Thunderbolt due to the increased paralysis chance. Giga Drain threatens Sandaconda while providing some recovery. Dragon Tail phazes foes, pairing well with Spikes support from the likes of Qwilfish and Cacturne, and keeps Tera Ground Quiver Dance users such as Oricorio and Vivillon in check despite their Discharge immunity. Drain Punch is an alternative that still allows Eelektross to defeat Tera Ground Quiver Dance users while hitting common special attackers like Zoroark and Pyroar super effectively. Acid Spray is a viable alternative that lets Eelektross defeat setup sweepers even when they are the only remaining opposing Pokemon. Tera Steel is preferred, as it improves Eelektross's matchup against common special attackers like Indeedee-F and non-Tera Fire Vivillon while gaining an immunity to Qwilfish's Toxic.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Mold Breaker Funny Moments Compilation
sets.description:
• With its workable Speed, sky-high Attack stat, and the ever-valuable Mold Breaker, Haxorus is notable as one of the few setup sweepers not bothered by Mimikyu or Unaware.

  • With one Dragon Dance, it can outspeed most unboosted foes, but Choice Scarf users still cause issues, notably Hydreigon and Play Rough Meowscarada.

  • Dragon Claw may be worth using in place of Outrage to avoid locking Haxorus in.

  • Earthquake is extremely valuable on Haxorus due to Mold Breaker nullifying Levitate and Earth Eater, allowing Haxorus to hit foes like Rotom-W and Hydreigon hard without the need to lock into Outrage, and giving it a way to hit Orthworm hard at all

Items

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets Haxorus deal damage much more effectively at the cost of recoil

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Haxorus safely set up against a foe that may use crippling status moves such as Will-O-Wisp and Spore.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Steel grants good security against opposing Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-types.

  • Fairy: Fairy maximizes Haxorus's security against opposing Dragon-types, specifically.

  • Electric: Electric provides a surefire way of dealing with Dondozo thanks to Tera Blast.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: 244 Atk / 12 SpD / 252 Spe is an alternate EV spread takes on +1 Nihilego after Stealth Rock when holding Assault Vest.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Braviary stands out as a good setup sweeper thanks to its fantastic Fighting-type coverage to threaten Flying-type answers and physical walls such as Magneton, Avalugg, and various other Tera Steel users such as Appletun, as well as recovery alongside great bulk that is boosted even further with Bulk Up. Roost gives Braviary reliable recovery and helps it heal off recoil it takes from using Brave Bird as well as giving it more opportunities to use Substitute. Substitute can take advantage of Pokemon such as Appletun and Lurantis while also allowing Braviary to avoid status from Pokemon such as Qwilfish, Sandaconda, and Umbreon. Tera Dark allows Braviary to stop Prankster from Sableye, allowing it to take advantage of it via a Substitute or Bulk Up. Alternatively, Tera Ground gives Braviary a more favorable matchup versus Electric-type Pokemon like Rotom and Eelektross as well as a Rock resistance; (SC) however, the resulting Grass weakness means it can no longer switch in on Lurantis and Appletun as freely. Tera Fighting can be used with Close Combat over Substitute for more overall power and the ability to take down Flying-type answers like Magneton while also gaining a resistance to Rock-type moves, but doing so makes Braviary vulnerable to status moves.

Braviary struggles with faster threats with super effective coverage, often forcing it to Terastalize. As a result, specially defensive walls such as Blissey, Eelektross, and Umbreon pair well with it, with the former being notable for supporting Braviary with Wish, as Braviary will not be able to Roost easily due to its average Speed and large number of checks. Physically defensive walls such as Sandaconda and Sableye can also be useful to check Pokemon such as Tauros, Paldean Tauros, and Bombirdier. Pokemon with access to status moves such as Sableye if you are not running Tera Dark and Qwilfish if you are not running Substitute can also be troublesome for Braviary, so status absorbers such as Blissey and Hisuian Qwilfish can help with this problem. Braviary also dislikes Rocky Helmet users such as Sandaconda and Qwilfish, as the recoil can add up with Brave Bird over time. To deal with this, item disruption from Trick and Knock Off on Pokemon like Rotom, Sableye, and Samurott is ideal.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
The spread allows Mandibuzz to take two Draco Meteors from Choice Specs Dragapult from full, and outspeed defensive Rotom-W.

The set(s) displayed are used as a plalceholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Speed investment outspeeds Specs Primarina and Modest Magnezone. 252 HP / 160 SpD / 96 Spe is an alternative specially defensive spread.

This is a sample set, stay tuned for future updates!

sets.name: Substitute + Nasty Plot
sets.description:
With Nasty Plot, well-rounded stats, great coverage, and rather decent Speed, Hydreigon makes for a great wallbreaker. Substitute allows it to set up Nasty Plot safely, avoid would-be detrimental threats such as Garganacl's Salt Cure and status from Toxapex, Clodsire, and Rotom-W, and take advantage of the switches it forces. For its fourth move, Hydreigon can utilize Earth Power to dent Pokemon that can comfortably take a Dark Pulse such as Kingambit, Toxapex, and Garganacl. Alternatively, Flash Cannon provides coverage against Fairy-types, being able to OHKO Iron Valiant and Hatterene after a Nasty Plot, as well as having good chance to 2HKO Tera Fairy Garganacl and Skeledirge unboosted if running Life Orb. Draco Meteor can also be used as a strong neutral coverage option to straight up OHKO Great Tusk and dent Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Amoonguss. With Tera Steel, Hydreigon acquires a better defensive typing, turning its weaknesses into resistances, improving its matchups against would-be threats like Dragonite, Dragapult, Walking Wake, Roaring Moon, and Baxcalibur. Tera Steel also boosts its Flash Cannon, able to OHKO Hatterene unboosted with Life Orb. Tera Poison can also be used to grant Hydreigon a Fighting resistance and more importantly, resisting both of Iron Valiant's STAB moves. Both Tera types also give Hydreigon the ability to switch into Toxapex and Clodsire safely due to their immunity to poison, and they both work well with Levitate, which provides an immunity against an otherwise super effective attack.

Hydreigon best fits on various offense and balance teams. Rotom-W is a good teammate since it can spread paralysis against faster Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Dragapult and bring Hydreigon in safely on walls like Amoonguss and Toxapex via Volt Switch. Other defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Skeledirge make for good teammates since they can switch into Iron Valiant, Breloom, and Volcarona. Faster offensive Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and Choice Specs Dragapult match up well against offensive teams that can overwhelm Hydreigon easily by KOing Pokemon like opposing Dragapult and Hisuian Zoroark, respectively. In return, Hydreigon can overwhelm Pokemon that they typically struggle with such as Skeledirge and Kingambit. Entry hazards from the likes of Garganacl, Clodsire, and Glimmora are appreciated to wear down foes into Hydreigon's KO range; the former two Pokemon can also check Volcarona and Choice Specs Dragapult defensively, which would otherwise revenge kill Hydreigon easily—even if it's behind a Substitute—thanks to Bug Buzz and Infiltrator. If Hydreigon isn't running Earth Power, teammates that can deal with Kingambit such as Breloom and Great Tusk are appreciated; Great Tusk can also remove Stealth Rock so Hydreigon isn't worn down easily, especially if it's running Life Orb. The two of them can also handle Ting-Lu, which can otherwise wall Hydreigon and phaze it with Whirlwind. Setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Iron Valiant, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite appreciate Hydreigon threatening Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Dondozo for them to sweep more easily.

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Dragon)
sets.description:
Hydreigon's great stats, unresisted coverage, and useful ability let it serve as an excellent wallbreaker on Dragon teams, checking threats like Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Toxapex. Dark Pulse targets Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Gholdengo, Gengar, and Armarouge. Flamethrower threatens Steel-types like Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Kingambit, while Earth Power aids in the Poison matchup, hitting Clodsire, Skuntank, and Toxapex. Alternatively, Flash Cannon may be used to threaten Fairy-types like Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Gardevoir behind Substitute. Substitute alongside Leftovers makes Hydreigon difficult to revenge kill and offers more setup opportunities against passive Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Klefki, and Forretress. Alternatively, Taunt prevents Ting-Lu from phazing Hydreigon with Whirlwind as well as obstructing Clodsire, Dondozo, and Gastrodon's recovery attempts. Draco Meteor is a niche option to OHKO opposing Dragon-types like Baxcalibur and Dragalge; however, Draco Meteor negates Nasty Plot boosts and requires Hydreigon to give up useful utility.

Hydreigon's ability to break past physical walls such as Quagsire, Skeledirge, and Dondozo is heavily appreciated by Baxcalibur and Dragonite. In return, Baxcalibur checks Clodsire, Dragonite, and opposing Hydreigon, while Dragonite threatens Quaquaval and Cinderace. Cyclizar sets up Shed Tail for non-Substitute Hydreigon, allowing for more setup opportunities and freeing up a moveslot for Hydreigon. Furthermore, Cyclizar removes Stealth Rock off the field with Rapid Spin, preserving Hydreigon's ability to set up. Dragapult combats Flutter Mane, Gallade, and opposing Dragon-types, while Hydreigon forces Kingambit off the field and switches into Shadow Sneak from Brambleghast and Ceruledge. Garchomp sets up entry hazards to enhance Hydreigon's wallbreaking capabilities and helps to take care of Clodsire and Volcarona. Dragalge is valued as a check to Fairy-types like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant as well as an entry hazard setter, aiding in the Dark and Fairy matchups with Toxic Spikes.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dragon)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Dark)
sets.description:
Due to Hydreigon's wonderful movepool, terrifying Special Attack stat, and useful ability, it's an easy-to-fit wallbreaker on Dark teams that is a huge asset in the Steel, Poison, Ground, and Water matchups. Draco Meteor provides nuclear power after a Nasty Plot, removing threats like Urshifu-R, Baxcalibur, and Great Tusk, while Dark Pulse is a great alternative due to its accuracy, good Base Power, and synergy with Flamethrower or Earth Power. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Corviknight, Kingambit, and Iron Treads; however, Earth Power hits Hisuian Goodra, Toxapex, and Alolan Muk. Stealth Rock is appreciated to allow Ting-Lu to use Spikes while also capitalizing on the many switches Hydreigon forces. Alternatively, Substitute raises Hydreigon's potency as a wallbreaker, providing safety in front of passive Pokemon like Amoonguss, defensive Rotom-W, and Gastrodon as well as putting lots of pressure on more offensive types like Ground and opposing Dark teams.

Chien-Pao and Hydreigon form a formidable wallbreaking core due to Chien-Pao's ability to threaten Unaware Clodsire, Enamorus, and Roaring Moon. In return, Hydreigon uses Toxapex and Quagsire as setup fodder. Sableye provides a Fighting-type immunity and Will-O-Wisp support, discouraging Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Sneasler, and Quaquaval from using their STAB moves. Meowscarada and Greninja are great in the Grass and Water matchups, eliminating Quaquaval, Ice Beam Gastrodon, and Azumarill. Additionally, Meowscarada threatens Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, while Greninja breaks (remove double space) past Unaware Clodsire. Kingambit checks Fairy-types like Hatterene and Flutter Mane while also picking off faster threats like Dragapult, Spectrier, and Barraskewda after a few Supreme Overlord boosts. In return, Kingambit values Hydreigon's ability to remove roadblocks like Great Tusk and Urshifu-R. Ting-Lu provides entry hazards and phazing with Whirlwind to wear down defensive checks, while Alolan Muk is an additional asset in the Fairy and Dragon matchup, taking on Enamorus, Iron Valiant, and Walking Wake. Choice Scarf Hoopa-U threatens Chien-Pao, Clodsire, and hinders Hydreigon's checks with Trick while appreciating Alolan Muk's removal in return.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: HARBINGER (Choice Item)
sets.description:
• With access to the incredible Levitate, Hydreigon sets itself apart from Roaring Moon as a dangerous offensive force that effectively utilizes Terastallization.

  • Flash Cannon: This is Hydreigon's best option to hit Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Flutter Mane.

  • Flamethrower versus Fire Blast: Flamethrower is usually good enough for hitting Steel-types such as Scizor and otherwise decent Dark Pulse switch-ins like Meowscarada. On the other hand, Choice Specs Fire Blast is capable of OHKOing bulky Gholdengo and Corviknight.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs Hydreigon is a nuclear wallbreaker that can pummel unsuspecting teams.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf patches up Hydreigon's somewhat lackluster Speed, allowing it to threaten a wider portion of the metagame with its high-powered attacks.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Hydreigon has a lot of competition from other Dragon-types, as well as having to face down strong Dark-resists like Chien-Pao. Terastallization is it's best way to flip these matchups when absolutely necessary.

  • Steel: Tera Steel can be used to get around the many Dragon and Fairy-types that try to revenge kill Hydreigon, though it is still vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

  • Poison: Tera Poison has great synergy with Hydreigon's former typing, making it do especially well against Great Tusk.

  • Fire: Tera Fire will grant Hydreigon a resistance to Fairy-types while removing its weakness to Fighting-types and powering up Flamethrower or Fire Blast. However, unlike Tera Steel it does not grant a resistance to Dragon, and it also gives Hydreigon a few new weaknesses.

  • Dark: Tera Dark boosts Dark Pulse into an absurdly powerful weapon, and when coupled with its flinch rate, Tera Dark Hydreigon can potentially muscle its way out of otherwise hopeless situations.

sets.name: Versatile Attacker
sets.description:
• Hydreigon's useful support movepool can add quite a bit of unpredictability to its offensive potential.

  • Note that this Hydreigon is fully capable of running three attacking moves with one support move.

  • Nasty Plot: Nasty Plot makes Hydreigon a surprisingly dangerous sweeper against slower teams and pairs particularly well with Substitute.

  • Substitute: Substitute is excellent for scouting Terastallization and punishes common status users such as Yawn Dondozo as well as Leech Seed Wo-Chien.

  • Taunt: Taunt can stop setup from defensive foes such as Hippowdon, Wo-Chien and Clodsire, and is especially dangerous if they lack coverage to hit back effectively.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Hydreigon sets of this kind normally prey on bulkier targets, using its support tools to overwhelm them. However, Hydreigon will likely still have to deal with its Dragon-type brethren, so Terastallization is sometimes necessary.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has fantastic synergy with Levitate, helping Hydreigon against Dragon- and Fairy-types without the dreaded Ground weakness.

  • Poison: With a Poison Tera type, Hydreigon can do well against Fairy-types without fear of powerful Fighting-type attacks. Thanks to Levitate, it also matches up well into Great Tusk.

  • Fire: When using Flamethrower, a Fire Tera type is handy for both the Fairy resistance and a better matchup against Kingambit.

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers's extra bit of recovery helps reduce its risk.

  • Life Orb: A simple power boost still comes in handy, even if only using two attacks.

  • Black Glasses: If a teammate is already using Life Orb, Black Glasses is a good compromise.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Hydreigon's new access to Stealth Rock makes it a surprisingly effective offensive support Pokemon.

  • Taunt: Taunt effectively shuts down common support leads like Ting-Lu, Hippowdon, and Clodsire.

  • Thunder Wave: This is a powerful deterrent against offensive foes and can even stop sweepers in emergency situations when used with Focus Sash.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low / Medium: If running Focus Sash, Terastallization is generally not needed. For other items, Terastallization is sometimes more necessary.

  • Steel: Thanks to Levitate, a Steel Tera type is an incredible defensive typing for Hydreigon, giving it an advantage over Fairy- and Dragon-types.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a good alternative to Steel, with fewer resistances but an important Fighting-type resistance for targets like Great Tusk and Iron Hands.

  • Fire: Fire-type Hydreigon is better against Kingambit and Fairy-types.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash makes setting up Stealth Rock a much easier task against offensive teams. Be warned that it doesn't stop Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

  • Leftovers: If using Taunt, Leftovers is the best choice for giving Hydreigon longevity against defensive foes such as Corviknight.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets Hydreigon be played more offensively if setting Stealth Rock isn't needed.

  • Dark Glasses: Dark Glasses work if a teammate is using Life Orb.

vgc2023.overview:
• Hydreigon is a strong contender for the title of best Pokemon in the Series 1 metagame thanks to its diverse movepool and high damage output.

  • Terastallization proves to be a boon for Hydreigon, as it can get rid of its ever-burdening Fairy-type weakness by changing to much more beneficial types such as Steel.

  • Hydreigon has a good offensive typing, leaving few Pokemon able to switch in safely. It is one of the best checks to Gholdengo and also pairs well with it, forming a fundamentally powerful core when used with Tailwind support from Murkrow. Armarouge and Garchomp also synergize well with Hydreigon, covering for Steel-types, which it may not be able to damage effectively depending on its Tera type. Hydreigon can, however, struggle against damage reduction such as Snarl and Light Screen, with the latter coming especially from Grimmsnarl, which can easily take its STAB moves and OHKO it back with Spirit Break if Hydreigon is not Terastallized. Repeated usage of Draco Meteor can also make Hydreigon deal unimpressive amounts of damage, but this can be counteracted with Haze from Murkrow, allowing it to continue dealing devastating damage.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
• Tailwind allows Hydreigon to support allies such as Armarouge and Sylveon, forming strong offensive combinations. The third moveslot depends on Hydreigon's Tera Type and can be changed accordingly. Protect is utilized on teams with a different primary Tailwind setter such as Murkrow, but Hydreigon can still be kept as a secondary setter.

  • Life Orb lets Hydreigon dish out consistent damage without the need to set up.

  • The Steel Tera type synergizes wonderfully with Hydreigon's original typing and Levitate, allowing it to resist a plethora of common types such as Fairy, Ground, and, Dragon. This makes Hydreigon one of the best checks to Tera Ground Garchomp, which cannot hit Hydreigon with Earthquake and deals minimal damage to it with Dragon Claw and Rock Slide. A Fire Tera type allows Hydreigon to beat opposing Tera Steel Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Salamence. The Poison Tera type lets Hydreigon maintain the resistance to Fairy that Steel and Fire possess while also gaining an additional resistance to Fighting, crucial against the likes of Annihilape, Hariyama, and Close Combat Lycanroc. It is only left with Psychic as a relevant weakness, synergizing well with its original Dark typing. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon for coverage against Fairy-types on sets that use Tera Poison.

sets.name: Scope Lens
sets.description:
• Heat Wave is a great coverage move to deal with Steel-types that can withstand Draco Meteor such as Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Scope Lens takes advantage of the +2 critical hit rate from Focus Energy, allowing Hydreigon to always critical hit, especially through Draco Meteor Special Attack drops and other means of damage reduction such as Light Screen.

  • A Timid nature lets Hydreigon speed tie other Hydreigon as the raw power it gains from having the ability to always critical hit is enough. A Modest nature can, however, be utilized on teams with good methods of speed control such as Tailwind from Murkrow.

  • The Fire Tera type powers up Hydreigon's Heat Wave, letting it OHKO Kingambit on a critical hit and nearly OHKO Amoonguss, and gives Hydreigon a Fairy resistance.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Snarl is an immensely useful tool for reducing the damage dealt by strong special attackers such as Gholdengo, Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Force Armarouge, and opposing Hydreigon.

  • Flash Cannon in combination with the Steel Tera type is used as a way to keep Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Sylveon in check. Heat Wave is used as coverage to hit opposing Steel-types, but Dark Pulse is usually preferred over it for its ability to deal consistent damage to most other types overall.

  • Assault Vest makes Hydreigon a very potent sponge against special moves when combined with its ability to use Snarl for further reduction, especially for its teammates. Its high Special Attack lets it deal respectable damage despite running a more support-oriented set.

  • The Speed EVs allow Hydreigon to outrun maximum Speed Timid Gholdengo, and as a result, Armarouge of all Speed investments, allowing it to immediately use Snarl and lower their damage output. The Special Attack EVs let it always 2HKO maximum HP and 4 Special Defense Armarouge and uninvested Gholdengo with Dark Pulse. The Special Defense EVs make -1 Modest maximum Special Attack Choice Specs Gholdengo's Shadow Ball only a possible 5HKO on Tera Steel Hydreigon, while Make It Rain rocks a petty chance to even 7HKO. -1 Armarouge Aura Sphere also only has about a 50% chance to 4HKO Hydreigon. Note that Hydreigon should not be Terastallized against Armarouge to maintain the Fire resistance and Psychic immunity, as it is still weak to Aura Sphere when Terastallized. Opposing Tera Fire Hydreigon never OHKOes Tera Steel Hydreigon with Life Orb Heat Wave when spread damage is accounted for, allowing Hydreigon to retaliate with Snarl. The physical bulk allows Hydreigon to never be 2HKOed by maximum Attack Adamant Annihilape Drain Punch and Jolly maximum Attack Garchomp Brick Break.

  • Steel Tera type is the best defensive type for Hydreigon, allowing it to hard check most special attackers such as Gholdengo and Sylveon while holding its own against Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl. Poison Tera type, on the other hand, lets Hydreigon maintain the Fairy resistance that Steel gives it while also awarding it an additional resistance to Fighting in the face of Pokemon such as Annihilape and Hariyama. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon to hit Fairy-types on Tera Poison sets.

sets.name: The Clicker (Choice Specs)
sets.description: Utilizing its high Special Attack, Beads of Ruin, powerful STAB attacks, and solid coverage options, Hydreigon is a formidable wallbreaker that can tear down the tier’s most robust special walls like Hisuian Goodra, Meloetta, and Blissey over the course of a game. Focus Blast is a powerful option to muscle past Hisuian Goodra, Blissey and Zamazenta-C. U-turn allows Hydreigon to provide additional utility as a pivot, ease prediction, and maintain momentum against switch-ins like Blissey and Diancie, while Flash Cannon serves as an option to handle the Fairy-type switch-ins like Enamorus-T and Diancie that Hydreigon would otherwise struggle to beat. Hydreigon has unimpressive Speed and can be revenge killed quite easily by threats such as Slither Wing, Chien-Pao, and Pixilate Scream Tail, so walls that can handle these like RegenVest users, Corviknight, and Quaquaval are appreciated, with the latter two being able to pivot Hydreigon in. Powerful physical wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing are appreciated, forming a potent VoltTurn core with Hydreigon if it opts for U-turn, handling the special walls that Hydreigon can struggle against, and pivoting in Hydreigon to break the physical walls they may struggle with.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Hydreigon carves a niche in National Dex courtesy of its powerful Choice Specs-boosted attacks and nearly unresisted STAB combo. Additionally, its useful typing allows it to pivot into common defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Gholdengo, giving it opportunities of entry. Fire Blast complements Dark Pulse and Draco Meteor very well, hitting Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Kingambit. Flash Cannon allows Hydreigon to hit Fairy-types that would otherwise pivot into it, such as Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant, as well as hitting Mega Tyranitar moderately hard. U-turn is an alternative over the latter two moves that provides a more risk-free option to exploit Hydreigon's checks, giving Pokemon like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny free entry. Tera Dark further boosts Hydreigon’s power, allowing its Dark Pulse to reliably 2HKO the likes of Toxapex and Heatran. Hydreigon fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that have reliable options to switch it in safely. Hydreigon pairs very well with pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T, as they can switch it in against opposing defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Rotom-W. Assault Vest Tornadus-T pairs particularly well with Hydreigon, as it notably checks Dragapult, as well as providing insurance against foes such as Iron Valiant. Pokemon that can exploit common switch-ins to Hydreigon such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit pair well with Hydreigon, meaning the likes of Great Tusk and Zamazenta are good partners. Similarly, Pokemon that can lure or weaken the aforementioned switchins, such as Gholdengo and Dragapult, pair well with Hydreigon.

sets.name: Fire Spin
sets.description: With its solid natural bulk and good defensive typing in conjunction with Levitate, Hydreigon serves as a trapper that checks and eliminates Pokemon like Skeledirge and Mega Charizard Y lacking Focus Blast. Fire Spin traps and accumulates chip on a myriad of defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex, Ting-Lu, Gastrodon, and Clodsire. Earth Power, in combination with Fire Spin, increases the damage that the aforementioned Pokemon take while also threatening Heatran. Alternatively, Dark Pulse can be used as a solid STAB move to hit airborne Pokemon such as Gliscor. Taunt prevents passive walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon from healing while also preventing Hydreigon from being crippled by status from the aforementioned Pokemon as well. Tera Poison gives Hydreigon a Toxic immunity and a favorable defensive typing, allowing it to safely trap Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Valiant. Offensive teammates like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, and Dragapult appreciate Hydreigon trapping and removing walls like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Gastrodon support Hydreigon, as they heavily chip and pressure switch-ins like Kingambit in combination with Hydreigon's Fire Spin. Hydreigon is easily forced out by Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant. As such, Pokemon that can handle the aforementioned threats such as Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Toxapex make great teammates for it.

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: The Original Moth (Bug)
sets.description:
Volcarona performs as a solid late-game setup sweeper for Bug teams, threatening to sweep any unprepared team thanks to Quiver Dance. Flamethrower is the go-to STAB move for Volcarona, as it hits Steel- and Ice-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Chien-Pao. Optionally, Fiery Dance can be used over Flamethrower, which has an additional effect of boosting Special Attack, but Flamethrower is preferred due to a higher Base Power. Psychic primarily covers Poison-types like Toxapex, Glimmora, and Iron Moth, but it also hits Fighting-types such as Quaquaval and Great Tusk. Morning Sun provides reliable recovery, which allows Volcarona to further set up and threaten to sweep. Alternatively, Giga Drain targets Water- and Ground-type Pokemon such as Quagsire, Greninja, and Gastrodon. Bug Buzz can be used over Psychic to hit Dark- and Psychic-types such as Hydreigon, Ting-Lu, and Espathra. Heavy-Duty Boots keeps Volcarona safe from entry hazards, while Flame Body debilitates physical attackers. A Timid nature allows Volcarona to outspeed Choice Scarf Flamigo after a single Quiver Dance boost.

Volcarona and Scizor make a great pair, as Scizor—thanks to its Steel-typing—helps Volcarona by switching into Toxic from Clodsire, and it deals with Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc thanks to Bullet Punch. Volcarona appreciates entry hazard support from Forretress, which pressures and wears down the opposing team. Choice Scarf Heracross helps against Steel- and Dark-types—such as Iron Treads and Kingambit—and Flying-types—like Kilowattrel—with Close Combat and Stone Edge, respectively; in return, Volcarona helps deal with Corviknight, which Heracross struggles to break. Slither Wing threatens Flying- and Water-types such as Iron Jugulis, Pelipper, and Greninja with Wild Charge, and threatens Corviknight with Flare Blitz. It can safely pivot in Volcarona, enabling its sweep. Both Slither Wing and Heracross pressure specially defensive walls such as Clodsire and Blissey, which Volcarona struggles to break. Lokix helps against Ghost-, Psychic- and Dark-types like Skeledirge, Espathra, Armarouge, Meowscarada, and Greninja thanks to First Impression, Throat Chop, and Sucker Punch. Volcarona appreciates Sticky Web support from Masquerain or Spidops to deal with Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Iron Moth.

sets.name: Bulky Quiver Dance (Bug)
sets.description: These are the sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Quiver Dance (Fire)
sets.description:
A potent offensive presence, Volcarona's access to Quiver Dance provides the backbone to its sweeping capabilities. Bug Buzz is Volcarona's main attacking option and can be combined with Swarm to increase damage as Volcarona loses HP while setting up, allowing Volcarona to OHKO checks like offensive Garchomp after one Quiver Dance. Psychic is essential, as it allows Volcarona to hit one of Fire's strongest checks, Toxapex, but also super effectively damages Poison-types and Fighting-types such as Glimmora and Quaquaval. The last slot is interchangeable, though generally Flamethrower is preferred as a STAB move that can also take advantage of sun support on Fire teams and is essential to for the Flying matchup, allowing it to hit Corviknight and Kilowattrel. Giga Drain can be used to give Volcarona a better chance of breaking through Water and Ground teams and give it a recovery option. Similarly, Morning Sun gives Volcarona more setup opportunities. Flame Body can also be used to threaten burns on Pokemon such as Kingambit and Dragonite, which oftentimes revenge kill Volcarona. Given its all-around solid defensive stats, Volcarona finds a myriad of opportunities to set up and takes advantage of the maximum Speed spread given to capitalize on the boosts as much as possible, outspeeding Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Great Tusk or Choice Scarf Dragapult after one or two Quiver Dance boosts, respectively.

Generally, Volcarona is best saved for mid- to late-game, when the opposing team has been chipped down and Volcarona has an opportunity to sweep after setting up. Utilizing its offensive teammates such as Scovillain, Ceruledge, Cinderace, and Paldean Tauros-F to slowly chip down defensive walls such as Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Blissey provides better opportunity for Volcarona to sweep later in the game. Paldean Tauros-F is specifically useful with its ability to remove dual screens, preventing Volcarona's setup from being hindered. Rotom-H also provides excellent support, aiding in the Water matchup if Giga Drain is not used and providing pivot support to switch Volcarona in. Skeledirge and Talonflame provide defensive support to wear down offensive threats such as Dragonite. Torkoal providing sun support on Fire aids Volcarona, not only increasing Flamethrower's damage output, but giving Volcarona the opportunity to survive attacks like Choice Specs Greninja's Surf, giving it an opportunity to set up.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Bulkarona
sets.description:
• With recovery and massive investments in bulk, Volcarona is capable of setting up multiple Quiver Dances, making it a potent sweeper.

  • Tera Blast: Even before Terastallization, Tera Blast can come in handy for hitting Chi-Yu and Roaring Moon

  • Giga Drain: Giga Drain is Volcarona's best shot at beating Water-types such as Rotom-W and Palafin; note that Dondozo is not 2HKOed.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Burning foes is great for letting Volcarona set up against powerful foes like Chien-Pao and Great Tusk.

  • Substitute: Though it can be difficult to fit-in, Substitute allows Volcarona to punish users of status moves, such as sleep moves from Breloom and Gholdengo's Thunder Wave.

Other Options

  • Bug Buzz: This is Volcarona's best tool against foes behind a Substitute like Wo-Chien, and it hits physically defensive Ting-Lu hard.

  • Psychic: Psychic 2HKOs Toxapex, who can otherwise be problematic with Haze, and it hits Iron Moth hard.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While the massive Rock-type weakness often pressures Volcarona to Terastallize, Volcarona's useful resistances to Fighting and Fairy mean this isn't always the right play.

  • Grass: With a Grass Tera type, Volcarona can now 2HKO most Dondozo with Giga Drain and is better insulated against revenge kills from Water-types like Azumarill and Palafin-H.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Volcarona take on powerful Dark and Dragon attacks from the likes of Chien-Pao and Choice Band Dragonite, and gives it powerful coverage against them with Tera Blast.

  • Water: Besides removing all of Volcarona's old weaknesses, a Water Tera type also massively improves the match up against Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and Skeledirge with Tera Blast.

  • Flying: While a Flying Tera Type isn't a huge help defensively, the immunity to Fissure makes Volcarona better equipped to handle Dondozo.

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type simply gives Fiery Dance more power, and makes sense if not using Tera Blast.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Stealth Rock is common enough that this is the safest item for Volcarona to hold.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry gives Volcarona more durability against teams that lack hazards, and with an even HP stat, it'll eat Sitrus Berry right away after switching into Sealth Rock.

  • Lum Berry: This allows Volcarona to recover from status once against threats like Spore Breloom, Yawn Dondozo, and Thunder Wave Dragonite.

  • Covert Cloak: If Terastallized against Garganacl, Covert Cloak stops it from beating Volcarona with Salt Cure.

  • Safety Goggles: This allows Volcarona to handle Spore from Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Amoonguss without Terastallizing.

EV Spreads

  • All of the given EV spreads except for the last one will outspeed offensive Iron Bundle and OHKO it with Fiery Dance after one Quiver Dance. If using Giga Drain, feel free to redistribute the SpA EV's.

  • Odd HP versus Even HP: Volcarona will usually prefer an odd HP stat to take less residual damage, with Stealth Rock no longer 2HKOing being the most important. However, if using Sitrus Berry, move 8 Defense EV's to HP so that one hit from Ruination or Stealth Rock activates it.

  • 244 HP / 204 Def / 12 SpA / 4 SpD / 44 Spe with Timid: This EV spread is the standard for outspeeding Iron Bundle after Quiver Dance, while simultaneously maximizing Volcarona's bulk.

  • 244 HP / 188 Def / 76 Spe with Timid: This EV spread sacrifices some physical bulk for being able to outspeed Dragapult after one Quiver Dance. If 8 Def EV's are moved to HP for the Sitrus Berry variant, this EV spread guarantees that Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Crunch triggers Sitrus Berry, always avoiding a 2HKO.

  • 244 HP / 236 Def / 28 Spe with Bold: This EV spread outspeeds Iron Valiant after Quiver Dance, and gives Volcarona a very strong chance of avoiding a 2HKO from Jolly Focus Sash Chien-Pao even without Sitrus Berry.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance
sets.description:
• This far speedier approach to sweeping with Volcarona is more risky, but can catch more passive teams by surprise with its greater coverage.

  • Giga Drain: Giga Drain is the best coverage option for Volcarona, as it helps it deal with Water-type Pokémon, as well as recover a good amount of HP.

  • Bug Buzz versus Psychic: Bug Buzz's ability to ignore Substitute and hit Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon hard make it a reasonable consideration. Psychic's coverage isn't amazing, but it does help Volcarona deal with Iron Moth and Toxapex.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: This Volcarona is heavily pressured to start sweeping after it sets up, so Terastallization can widen the opportunities to do so.

  • Water: Terastallizing into the Water typing nullifies Volcarona's most common weakness in Rock-type, and Water-type Tera Blast is also the best option Volcarona has to hit Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, Skeledirge.

  • Grass: The Grass typing strengthens Giga Drain and nullifies Volcarona's weakness to Water-types, most notably helping against Dondozo, Azumarill, and Palafin-H.

  • Rock: Tera Rock is Volcarona's at covering Chi-Yu, Dragonite, Iron Moth, and Skeledirge with one move, especially with the useful Extreme Speed resistance. When used with Hippowdon's Sand Stream, it also makes Volcarona quite specially bulky.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is a big help against powerful Dragon-type attacks such as Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage, and it gives Volcarona good coverage against it too.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: It is the best option on Volcarona, as it circumvents its crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Lum Berry: This Volcarona's more offensive nature makes it especially vulnerable to status moves from the likes of Dragonite and Focus Sash Breloom, so Lum Berry is a reasonable way around this.

  • Sitrus Berry: If used with an even HP stat, Sitrus Berry will restore Volcarona's health the moment it switches into either Stealth Rock or gets hit by Ruination.

teams.name: Choice set from previous regulations written by

sets.name: Fast Support
sets.description: Volcarona serves as a solid support pokemon with valuable defensive utility to check the likes of Hariyama and Glaceon. Fiery Dance lets Volcarona increase its Special Attack without having to setup, while Flamethrower has more PP and immediate power. U-turn allows Volcarona to maintain momentum, while Quiver Dance serves as an option to go for a potential late-game sweep. Will-O-Wisp cripples switch-ins like Garganacl and is generally great for weakening physical attackers like Quaquaval. Teammates such as Meowscarada and Roaring Moon appreciate Volcarona's ability to sponge priority moves from Slither Wing and Hatterene. Bulky Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Donphan also benefit from Volcarona ability to somewhat safely switch into offensive Water-types such as Inteleon and non-Brave Bird Quaquaval. Volcarona is walled by common Well-Baked Body users like Kingambit and Corviknight, so attackers like Quaquaval and Sandy Shocks are helpful for breaking through them. Volcarona can also have trouble getting past Fire-resistant specially defensive walls that resist fire like Roaring Moon and Garganacl, so a physical wallbreaker such as Slither Wing is recommended.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Volcarona serves as a passable late-game sweeper after checks such as Well-Baked Body Corviknight and special walls such as Garganacl, Blissey, and Clodsire have been eliminated from the game. Volcarona wants to quickly rack up stat boosts with Quiver Dance and Fiery Dance to sweep the enemy team while also providing a Water immunity in the form of Desolate Land. Alternatively, Volcarona can opt for Storm Drain to turn fast Primordial Sea users such as Greninja and Barraskewda into setup fodder. Will-O-Wisp is preferred on the last slot to cripple physical attackers such as Garchomp and Quaquaval, which seek to exploit Volcarona's low Defense, but Volcarona can run Bug Buzz to threaten bulky phazers such as Ting-Lu and RegenVest Roaring Moon or Psychic to chunk Haze users such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Volcarona is completely walled by Well-Baked Body Steel-types such as Corviknight and Kingambit; thus, partners such as Sandy Shocks help to eliminate them in the early-game. While Giga Drain can hurt Garganacl, Volcarona's massive weakness to Rock means it doesn't want to stay into Garganacl at all; thus, teammates such as Magic Guard Quaquaval are particularly helpful. Lastly, Volcarona appreciates entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Clodsire, as the chip damage allows Volcarona to sweep more effectively.

sets.name: Chilan Berry
sets.description:
• Chilan Berry helps Volcarona defeat Chien-Pao, non-Power Gem Meowscarada, and Slaking.
  • Will-O-Wisp helps Volcarona defeat Avalugg and non-Stone Edge Ting-Lu.
  • Substitute prevents Soak and Fake Tears from Bellibolt and Sylveon, respectively, as well as beating Choice Band Donphan if it uses Head Smash.
  • Morning Sun allows Volcarona to defeat specially defensive Sylveon.
  • Overheat allows Volcarona to defeat Sylveon as well as Steel-types like Corviknight, Magnezone, and Kingambit.
  • The HP and Defense EVs let Volcarona survive Throat Chop from Choice Band Chien-Pao, while the Speed EVs let it outspeed Adamant Annihilape.
  • Will-O-Wisp + Morning Sun lets Volcarona defeat Iron Hands, while Will-O-Wisp + Overheat lets it beat Avalugg.
  • Against Sylveon, Volcarona should use Quiver Dance once, then use Overheat twice.
  • Against Slaking, Volcarona should Quiver Dance twice, then use Bug Buzz.

sets.name: Passho Berry
sets.description:
• Passho Berry helps Volcarona defeat Iron Bundle.
  • Will-O-Wisp allows Volcarona to defeat Avalugg, non-Stone Edge Ting-Lu, and non-Head Smash Donphan.
  • Substitute prevents Soak and Fake Tears from Bellibolt and Sylveon, respectively, as well as beating Choice Band Donphan if it uses Head Smash.
  • Morning Sun allows Volcarona to defeat specially defensive Sylveon and Iron Hands in combination with Will-O-Wisp.
  • Overheat OHKOes Iron Bundle. It also defeats Steel-types like Corviknight, Magnezone, and Kingambit, as well as Sylveon and Avalugg in combination with Will-O-Wisp.
  • The EVs allow Volcarona to survive Hydro Pump from Modest Choice Specs Iron Bundle and Psyshock from Choice Specs Sylveon twice. The Speed EVs outspeed maximum Speed Corviknight, and the remaining EVs are put in Special Attack.
  • Against Espathra, Volcarona should use Bug Buzz turn 1, then Quiver Dance, then Bug Buzz again to secure the win.
  • Against Choice Specs Sylveon, Volcarona should use Quiver Dance once, then Overheat twice.
  • Against Kingambit and Magnezone, Volcarona should use Bug Buzz and then Overheat to avoid losing to Metal Burst and Mirror Coat.
  • Be aware of Choice Specs Meowscarada, as Power Gem can OHKO Volcarona.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance
sets.description: Volcarona makes for a threatening late-game sweeper thanks to Quiver Dance, strong coverage moves, and a decent defensive profile. Fire Blast can be slotted over Flamethrower to hit much harder, notably OHKOing most variants of Gholdengo, but Flamethrower is usually better because of its consistency. Volcarona can utilize Giga Drain with Tera Grass to hit a plethora of Water-type Pokemon like Gastrodon, Rotom-W, and Urshifu-R hard, in addition to Ground- and Rock-types such as Great Tusk and Garganacl. Hidden Power Ground and Tera Ground help Volcarona bypass checks like Toxapex and Heatran after slight chip damage while also removing Volcarona’s glaring Rock weakness. Psychic with Tera Psychic allows Volcarona to break through Clodsire and Toxapex more reliably, but it is inferior to either of the previously mentioned Tera types due to its greater vulnerability to being revenge killed, and it leaves Volcarona completely stonewalled by Heatran. Flame Body can threaten to burn physical attackers like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta, crippling them. Maximum Speed investment and a Timid Nature lets Volcarona outrun Choice Scarf users such as Tapu Lele and Urshifu-R after a boost. Modest can be run to hit walls like Clodsire and Toxapex harder, but it leaves Volcarona much more vulnerable to the aforementioned Choice Scarf users. Volcarona’s defensive utility is appreciated by allies such as Urshifu-R and Kingambit, as it can check dangerous Fighting-types like Iron Valiant and Zamazenta in a pinch. Bulky Dragon-types like Dragonite and Garchomp can use it as setup fodder—with the latter additionally threatening Volcarona’s longevity with Toxic—so allies that can handle them such as Ferrothorn and Rotom-W are great partners to support Volcarona in its sweep. Heatran and Toxapex wall Volcarona if it doesn’t have Hidden Power Ground, so teammates like that can check them such as Garchomp and the aforementioned Rotom-W are much appreciated. Heatran also makes for a great ally, as it can eliminate or cripple Toxapex, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, which clears the way for Volcarona to clean up late-game.

sets.name: Bulky Quiver Dance
sets.description: Volcarona distinguishes itself as a bulky setup sweeper by boasting reliable recovery, Quiver Dance, and being able to check Zamazenta and Iron Valiant with its unique typing. Bug Buzz can hit Mega Gyarados, Garchomp, and Mega Latias harder, but Giga Drain can be run to hit Water-types such as Urshifu-R, Gastrodon, and Rotom-W. Psychic can also be ran to threaten Clodsire and Toxapex. Will-O-Wisp makes Volcarona more utility-oriented, threatening physical attackers like Zamazenta and Dragonite with a burn more reliably, crippling them. However, the lack of coverage leaves Volcarona walled easily by most Fire-resistant Pokemon. The given Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outspeed Dragapult after a Quiver Dance, with the rest invested in HP and Defense so that it will always be 3HKOed by Zamazenta and defensive Great Tusk’s Earthquake. Volcarona struggles with status conditions, as they can hinder its ability to check threats like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant in the long term, thus status absorbers like Gliscor and Toxapex make good partners; the former provides Defog support, a Knock Off absorber, and a Heatran check, and the latter helps prepare Volcarona’s sweep with Knock Off and status inducement. Volcarona can be easily exploited by setup sweepers like Garchomp, Dragapult, Mega Tyranitar, and Dragonite, and so checks like Rotom-W, Kingambit, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Lele can help to alleviate these matchups.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance (Bug)
sets.description: Volcarona is one of Bug's strongest setup sweepers, with a respectable Speed stat, high Special Attack, and great coverage. In addition to being one of very few special attacking options on Bug, Volcarona helps apply pressure in a variety of matchups thanks to its strong STAB moves and coverage. Fire Blast can be used over Fiery Dance for more immediate damage output. Giga Drain deals with Water- and Ground-types, most notably Swampert, Gastrodon, and Rotom-Wash. Bug Buzz can be used instead for Volcarona to overwhelm types like Dragon, Dark, and Psychic with Quiver Dance-boosted STAB attacks. Hidden Power Ground hits Heatran, allowing Volcarona to break Steel's immunity-based defensive core that can otherwise give Bug teams problems. Alternatively, Psychic can be used to damage bulky Poison-types, like Toxapex and Mega Venusaur, that can wall physical attackers like Heracross and Buzzwole. These physical attackers, in addition to Lokix and Scizor, are able to break through specially defensive walls, like Chansey and Mantine, that Volcarona struggles against. Araquanid and Armaldo provide helpful entry hazards in Sticky Web and Stealth Rock, respectively, to make sweeping mid- or late-game much easier.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance (Fire)
sets.description: Volcarona is one of the top setup sweepers that Fire has access to, with Quiver Dance allowing it to become a dangerous threat to teams unequipped to deal with it defensively. Psychic allows Volcarona to pressure Fighting and Poison teams, especially after one Quiver Dance, which lets Volcarona outspeed and beat Keldeo, Glimmora, and Crobat. Similarly, Giga Drain does the same to Water and Ground teams after one Quiver Dance, threatening Tapu Fini, Gastrodon, and Hippowdon. Bug Buzz covers the Psychic and Dark matchups very well and allows it to hit Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, and Latias, which would otherwise be a challenge to deal with. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Volcarona from being worn down by entry hazards, most notably Stealth Rock, which would otherwise stop Volcarona from being able to set up safely. Psychium Z lets Volcarona OHKO Toxapex with a +1 Shattered Psyche and beat otherwise troublesome threats like +1 Kommo-o, Iron Hands, and Clodsire. Cinderace and Mega Charizard X are especially good partners due to their ability to break through special walls such as Blissey, Clodsire, and Galarian Slowking with relative ease. Entry hazard removers such as Torkoal, Rotom-H, and Court Change Cinderace are near necessities if Volcarona is running Psychium Z. Torkoal and Rotom-H can also provide excellent utility in the form of Stealth Rock and dual screens, respectively, to help Volcarona sweep more easily. Volcanion is also an excellent partner for Volcarona that, thanks to its Water immunity, can act as a strong pivot into Pokemon like Azumarill and Mantine, which could revenge kill it or clear Quiver Dance boosts with Haze.

sets.name: Tailwind Setter
sets.description:
• Tornadus is an incredibly effective Tailwind user in DOU thanks to Prankster and its high Speed stat, ensuring that it can give its team a speed boost on demand. It pairs best with mid-speed attackers, such as Gholdengo and Landorus, which appreciate the immediate speed boost to knock out fast threats before they can respond with their own attacks.
  • Bleakwind Storm is Tornadus's best attack, dealing relatively consistent damage to both opponents. While it won't win any awards for damage output, it allows Tornadus to stay on the field without losing too much momentum after using Tailwind.
  • Taunt is used primarily to stop Pokemon like Cresselia and Diancie from setting up Trick Room. It can also prevent Protect, most entry hazards, setup moves, and redirection from the likes of Amoonguss, allowing you to make the most of Tailwind's limited duration.
  • Protect lets Tornadus avoid powerful attacks that might KO it or faster moves like Fake Out or an opposing Taunt that would stop it from using Tailwind. Protect can also be used to stall out field effects like weather and Trick Room.
  • Focus Sash is Tornadus's go-to item and lets it survive any one hit in spite of its mediocre bulk. Covert Cloak can be used instead to set Tailwind against Fake Out users.
  • Tera Ghost grants Tornadus an immunity to both Fake Out and Dragonite's Extreme Speed, which both have higher priority than Tornadus's Prankster-boosted moves and can prevent Tailwind from going up. However, Tornadus should usually not Terastallize, as it is unlikely to represent a game-ending threat. Tornadus should only Terastallize when it will directly lead to winning a game.
  • Tornadus has several other options over Taunt in the third moveslot. Rain Dance and Sunny Day can help support Pokemon like Palafin and Flutter Mane, respectively. Icy Wind, meanwhile, can double down on speed control while dealing some chip damage and is very helpful against opposing Tailwind teams.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: The given EV spread allows Tornadus-Therian to outspeed Maushold as well as survive a Draco Meteor from Modest Choice Specs Hydreigon after Stealth Rock.
