sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Landorus-T is a specially defensive pivot with respectable offensive power to boot. Earthquake is its main STAB move, threatening offensive Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Iron Moth that fail to OHKO Landorus-T. U-turn allows Landorus-T to gain momentum and switch out, giving powerful-but-frail attackers like Chien-Pao and Iron Moth the ability to switch in for free. Rock Tomb and Sludge Bomb are used to whittle down Earth Eater Fire-types like Skeledirge and defensive Fairy-types like Scream Tail, respectively, with Rock Tomb being able to heavily damage Zapdos. Alternatively, Smack Down can be used to threaten switch-ins like Corviknight, (add comma) while Sandsear Storm can burn pivots like Garchomp. A Sassy nature with 0 Speed IVs lets Landorus-T underspeed defensive pivots like Garchomp, Scream Tail, and non-minimum Speed Corviknight with U-turn. RegenVest Landorus-T can form a powerful defensive VoltTurn core with physically defensive pivots like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Additionally, fast revenge killers and late-game sweepers like Chien-Pao and Hisuian Electrode benefit from slow pivots that can get them on the field without having to absorb an attack themselves. Due to its typing, Landorus-T does not act as an adequate switch-in to Water-type attackers like Volcanion; Water-resistant teammates like Dondozo and Water Absorb Iron Treads help mitigate this weakness.

sets.name: Fluffy
sets.description: Fluffy makes Landorus-T a decent defensive pivot that can take hits from physical attackers such as Slither Wing, Kingambit, and Ursaluna. Stealth Rock + Smack Down makes Landorus-T a decent entry hazard setter against Corviknight, the most common hazard removal option; Smack Down also ensures that Talonflame can't use Landorus-T as setup fodder. Taunt can also be used to deny recovery to Corviknight and Scream Tail and setup opportunities to foes, such as Talonflame and Roaring Moon. Landorus-T best fits on balance and bulky offense teams, where it can provide defensive support against the aforementioned physical attackers. Common defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, and Scream Tail are good teammates that can switch into Pokemon that threaten Landorus-T, such as Chien-Pao, Zapdos, and Quaquaval; Scream Tail can also provide Wish support. Landorus-T struggles to beat offensive Pokemon one-on-one, but its ability to safely pivot into teammates benefits fast offensive Pokemon such as Iron Moth, Greninja, and Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Well-Baked Body
sets.description: With an added immunity to Fire, Landorus-T becomes a fantastic check to many of the Fire-types in the tier such as Cinderace, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth that also doubles as an entry hazards setter and a pivot. It differentiates itself from Garchomp as a Fire-type answer with its immunity to Will-O-Wisp as well as access to U-turn and Smack Down, allowing it to generate momentum and pressure Corviknight and other Flying-types. It can further capitalize on this added offensive presence with Swords Dance, especially if it has activated Well-Baked Body beforehand. Alternatively, running Hammer Arm over Smack Down allows it to still beat Earth Eater Heatran by itself and potentially hit Earth Eater Iron Treads hard on the switch. As a Fire-type answer, it makes a fantastic partner for Corviknight, which also appreciates its Fighting resistance to help against Pokemon like Slither Wing and in turn can handle many strong wallbreakers such as Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao that Landorus-T lacks the bulk and recovery to answer. Landorus-T also benefits RegenVest Pokemon such as Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta by preventing them from getting overwhelmed by strong Fire-type attacks and, in the case of Hisuian Goodra, helping against Ground-types such as Sandy Shocks and Landorus, while in return they handle the many special attackers in the tier. Water-immune partners, such as Desolate Land Heatran and Ceruledge, make good teammates for Landorus-T as well. Frail wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao and Cinderace also benefit from its pivoting ability to enter the battlefield safely as well as the hazards its sets to wear down their checks.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Landorus-T is an amazing defensive measure against revenge killers such as Zamazenta, Mega Scizor, and offensive Garchomp; it can also provide utility with entry hazards and status. U-turn allows Landorus-T to safely pivot into wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Tapu Lele, and Dragapult, as well as other defensive pivots like Tornadus-T and Rotom-W. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Rotom-W. Alternatively, Hidden Power Fire can be used over Toxic to critically hit Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Ferrothorn, which can exploit Landorus-T with a free turn to set up hazards or set up with Swords Dance. Landorus-T can also forgo setting entry hazards and instead clear them with Defog. Rocky Helmet is the preferred item for Landorus-T to punish physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny and Kartana; however, if it decides to opt for Defog, then Leftovers is preferred for reliable passive recovery. Tera Water turns Landorus-T's most common weaknesses into resistances, which helps against moves such as Weavile's Triple Axel and Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes. It is most efficient to Tera when Landorus-T's counters use a move against it rather than on a switch. Defensive Landorus-T fits extremely well on balance and bulky offense teams. Wallbreakers such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Volcarona all appreciate the utility and pivot support that Landorus-T provides with U-turn. Being heavily threatened by Pokemon like Weavile, Mega Medicham, and Dragapult makes partners like Heatran, Gholdengo, and Ferrothorn solid to use alongside it.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Flying)
sets.description: Choice Scarf Landorus-T is one of the best revenge killers Flying teams have access to, outrunning threats like Tapu Koko, Mega Diancie, and Terrakion while boasting great firepower. It's also very desirable thanks to its defensive traits, which include an immunity to Electric-type attacks and Intimidate. U-turn takes advantage of the switches Landorus-T forces, allowing it to pivot out of walls that come in on it such as Corviknight and Mega Venusaur. Similarly, Knock Off cripples some of the bulky Pokemon it invites in, like Porygon2 and Ferrothorn, by removing their items. Stone Edge notably hits Kyurem the hardest and is Landorus-T's best move versus Flying-types like Zapdos and Pelipper. Alternatively, Explosion lets Landorus-T score a surprise KO against an offensive threat it normally cannot OHKO, such as Keldeo or Mega Lopunny. Special wallbreakers like Galarian Moltres, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y are great partners to deal with the aforementioned physical walls Landorus-T draws in. Thundurus-T relieves pressure from Landorus-T by acting as a secondary Electric immunity and is a great asset against the Water and Flying teams Landorus-T can't do much to. Mega Aerodactyl is able to form a powerful revenge killing core alongside Landorus-T while providing Stealth Rock support for it to clean teams more easily. Corviknight switches into most Ice-type attacks aimed at Landorus-T, removes Stealth Rock with Defog, and is able to bring Landorus-T safely onto the field via its slow U-turn.

sets.name: Bulk Up (Ground)
sets.description:
Ferrothorn's Power Whip does not break Substitute at +1 Def or -1 Atk from Intimidate.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs (Normal)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: With a good typing, solid special bulk, and access to a slow U-turn, Meloetta is a solid RegenVest user for more offensively-oriented teams that want to keep up momentum while also being able to check prominent special attacking threats like Thundurus, Skeledirge, and Choice Specs Volcanion. Low Kick is used to chip Hisuian Goodra as well as severely dent Iron Treads and Heatran that may be looking to switch in on it. Frail wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos appreciate Meloetta's ability to slow pivot, ensuring they get in safely. Physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Quaquaval pair well with Meloetta, as they can shore up its Knock Off weakness and vulnerability to strong physical attackers like Slither Wing. Meloetta is prone to entry hazards that impede its ability to take repeated attacks from Zapdos, Thundurus, and Inteleon, so hazard removers like Corviknight and Iron Treads make for good teammates. Meloetta can also struggle with mixed attackers like Magic Guard Volcanion and Heatran, so paring it with offensive pokemon like Regieleki and Galarian Zapdos that can threaten them out is advised. Meloetta also appreciates hazard support from setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu so that attackers like Inteleon, Greninja, and Rotom-W cannot pivot for free.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
When equipped with Choice Specs, Greninja becomes a potent wallbreaker thanks to its great coverage and Protean. Since Choice Specs ensures it only uses one attack per switch-in, even though Protean only activates once per switch-in, Greninja will have STAB every time it attacks. Hydro Pump is Greninja's most powerful move, pummeling both offensive and defensive Water-weak Pokemon like Cinderace, Skeledirge, and Great Tusk. Dark Pulse hits the likes of Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Hisuian Zoroark super effectively while also dealing the most damage to Toxapex and Rotom-W. Dark Pulse's flinch chance can also come in clutch against the aforementioned walls. Ice Beam eviscerates Amoonguss, Water Absorb Clodsire, and Dragon-types like Dragonite and Roaring Moon. Grass Knot can OHKO Dondozo, Garganacl, and Walking Wake after minor chip damage, and it deals good damage to lighter Water-types like Quaquaval and Azumarill. Alternatively, Spikes lets Greninja wear down checks like Toxapex while taking advantage of the switches it often forces. In addition, Greninja also beats common entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight, making Spikes easy to maintain. Tera Water further enhances Greninja's already powerful Hydro Pump to extreme levels, letting it OHKO Pokemon like Corviknight, Hatterene, and Unaware Clodsire. Meanwhile, Tera Dark lets Greninja 2HKO Toxapex and Rotom-W with Dark Pulse.

Choice Specs Greninja fits best on hyper offense and bulky offense teams as a menacing wallbreaker. Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Glimmora are amazing for Spikes Greninja, as it can create a hazard-stacking core with them. Alternatively, these Pokemon can also let Greninja drop Spikes for Grass Knot, as they can set up hazards and Grass Knot overwhelming Dondozo and Walking Wake. Strong offensive Pokemon like Kingambit and mixed Iron Valiant make for excellent partners, as Greninja threatens their checks like Great Tusk, Dondozo, and Garchomp for the former, and Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Clodsire for the latter. They can also threaten Pokemon that would otherwise revenge kill Greninja, such as Dragapult and Meowscarada, granting Greninja more consistency against teams with these Pokemon.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Greninja is an excellent dedicated lead due to its high Speed tier alongside Spikes, Toxic Spikes, and valuable utility options. It differentiates itself from Meowscarada due to its better matchup against other leads as well as entry hazard setters and removers such as Glimmora, Iron Treads, Garchomp, Toxic Spikes Iron Moth, and Court Change Cinderace. Taunt has various applications; it blocks Amoonguss's Spore, prevents entry hazards from the likes of Ting-Lu and leads like Glimmora and Iron Treads, stops Defog from Corviknight, and prevents setup from Pokemon Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Tera Water Garganacl that attempt to exploit Greninja's relative passivity. Greninja can choose to run Toxic Spikes to punish offensive teams filled with setup sweepers like Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant better, but Ice Beam OHKOes Garchomp and dents Water-resistant Pokemon like Dragonite, Meowscarada, Dragapult, Tera Grass Glimmora, and Water Absorb Clodsire, especially if its Focus Sash is still intact for the former three. Focus Sash guarantees that Greninja can set at least one layer of entry hazards and works extremely well to safely put it into Torrent range, which allows Surf to OHKO Hisuian Zoroark and provides significant odds to OHKO Iron Valiant, one of the biggest threats to offense teams. Alternatively, Protean improves Ice Beam's damage and allows Greninja to block Volt Switch from Rotom-W, Iron Treads, and Sandy Shocks when using Spikes, maintaining offensive momentum. Tera Water boosts Greninja's Surf, notably netting the OHKO on specially defensive Garganacl and 2HKO on Tera Fairy Skeledirge with Torrent, as well as the 2HKO on Gholdengo and Corviknight after Stealth Rock.

Greninja is perfectly suited for hyper offense teams. Offensive teammates like Iron Valiant and Roaring Moon put further pressure on entry hazard removers such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk to maintain Greninja's Spikes throughout the game and enjoy Spikes chipping down their checks like Garganacl, Clodsire, Amoonguss, and Dondozo. They also appreciate Spikes invalidating Focus Sash from Pokemon like Hisuian Zoroark, Ceruledge, and Meowscarada. Aside from possessing insane late-game potential themselves, Kingambit and Iron Moth particularly help against Meowscarada—one of the few leads that can easily beat Greninja—and Hatterene, which can freely switch into Greninja and reflect its Taunt and entry hazards with Magic Bounce, with Calm Mind variants using it as setup fodder as well. Kingambit in particular appreciates Greninja's tendency to faint early-game to accumulate Supreme Overlord boosts. Knock Off from Bulk Up Great Tusk and Swords Dance Iron Valiant can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from walls like Dondozo, Slowking, and Tera Fairy Skeledirge, making them susceptible to Greninja's Spikes. Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Dragon Dance Dragapult can spinblock the likes of Great Tusk and Iron Treads in a pinch to keep Greninja's Spikes up; Gholdengo in particular does it exceptionally well by blocking Defog and Glimmora's Mortal Spin as well, and it has the added benefit of threatening Hatterene and crippling walls like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu with Choice item + Trick, making them more vulnerable to Greninja's entry hazards.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Dark)
sets.description:
Greninja is a staple for Dark teams thanks to its blitzing Speed tier that outpaces Cinderace and Iron Valiant. Protean + Choice Specs allows it to take full advantage of its coverage moves to OHKO and 2HKO common threats. Hydro Pump 2HKOes specially defensive Corviknight after Stealth Rock; however, Surf is a safer option while still OHKOing Iron Valiant after Stealth Rock. Ice Beam targets threats such as Dragonite and Clodsire. Grass Knot can 2HKO Ting Lu and Gastrodon while OHKOing Dondozo after Stealth Rock. Extrasensory targets Poison- and Fighting-types such as Toxapex and Quaquaval.

Meowscarada forms a dual Protean core with Greninja to break each other's checks; Greninja can break Toxapex for Meowscarada, while Meowscarada can break Iron Hands for Greninja. Chien-Pao and Greninja form a dangerous core that shatters teams without a proper Ice-resistant Pokemon. Chien-Pao is also capable of breaking Steel-types such as Kingambit with Sacred Sword. Kingambit can take on Fairy-type Pokemon for Greninja, such as Flutter Mane and Hatterene, while it can break past physical walls such as Quagsire in return. Ting-Lu can stack Stealth Rock and Spikes allowing Greninja to more easily score OHKOs such as against Corviknight and Dondozo and take care of Hatterene and Flutter Mane with Heavy Slam for Greninja. Sableye switches into Fighting-type attacks such as Great Tusk's Close Combat; additionally, it can block Rapid Spin, keeping entry hazards up for Greninja. Skuntank is amazing in the Fairy matchup, as it can check threats such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and trap Klefki with Fire Spin. Skuntank also absorbs and sets Toxic Spikes for Greninja.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Water)
sets.description:
Thanks to a wide array of coverage options alongside Protean, Choice Specs Greninja is a devastating special wallbreaker that can dismantle several types, including Grass, Ground, Water, and Poison. Its naturally high Speed tier is invaluable to outpace and threaten fast foes such as Iron Valiant and Sandy Shocks. Aside from hitting Psychic- and Ghost-types like Bronzong and Gholdengo, Dark Pulse's lack of immunities makes it a spammable attack that can be used to muscle past neutral Pokemon such as Corviknight with flinches. Ice Beam covers a large portion of the metagame, including Dragon, Ground, Grass, and Flying teams, decimating prominent foes like Hydreigon, Clodsire, Amoonguss, and Iron Jugulis. It's also Greninja's hardest hitting attack against Skuntank, which is important in the Poison matchup. Extrasensory pressures Poison- and Fighting-types like Toxapex and Assault Vest Iron Hands and prevents Greninja from being picked off by Breloom's Mach Punch. Grass Knot rounds out its coverage, significantly damaging Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Water-types such as Gastrodon and Dondozo.

Choice Specs Greninja appreciates being paired with other wallbreakers like Barraskewda and Quaquaval that can handle Normal and Steel teams. They break through bulky Pokemon like Blissey and Kingambit that Greninja struggles with; they are also potent late-game cleaners that enjoy Greninja's ability to threaten Storm Drain Gastrodon and their physically defensive checks like Amoonguss, Toxapex, Slowbro, and Dondozo. Moreover, Barraskewda under rain excels at tearing down fast offensive teams that Greninja can struggle with, as it can threaten out Meowscarada, boosted Volcarona, and Choice Scarf Iron Moth. Quaquaval can also run Rapid Spin to let Greninja enter the field multiple times to wallbreak without worry, preventing it from being chipped down into KO range of priority attacks like Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Baxcalibur's Ice Shard. Pivot support from Slowking is helpful to bring Greninja in safely on foes like Dragalge and Gastrodon, letting it fire off attacks freely. Defensive teammates such as Toxapex, Dondozo, Gastrodon, and Quagsire can switch into potential revenge killers like Meowscarada, Chien-Pao, Dragapult, and Slither Wing, respectively; notably, Gastrodon and Quagsire also provide entry hazards to take advantage of the countless switches that Greninja forces, putting the likes of Ting-Lu, Toxapex, and Assault Vest Iron Hands into Greninja's KO range, as well as switch into and check Electric-types such as Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Assault Vest Iron Hands.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description: Primordial Sea Greninja can use its rain-boosted attacks to wallbreak with Choice Specs or serve as a valuable revenge killer and late-game cleaner with Choice Scarf, outspeeding boosted threats such as Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Sandy Shocks, and +1 Volcarona. Choice Specs-boosted Hydro Pump's higher power 2HKOes even Water-resistant foes such as Dondozo, and Quaquaval. U-turn lets it act as a solid offensive pivot, pairing extremely well with other offensive teammates like Hatterene and Armarouge that threaten its switch-in such as Toxapex, Desolate Land Iron Moth, and Roaring Moon. Greninja can run an entry hazard of choice since it forces multiple switches and threatens common hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight, whittling down its checks in the long run. Switcheroo immediately cripples its defensive checks as well as bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Scream Tail and Florges, especially for Choice Scarf variants that can't immediately harm them. Water Shuriken is a fringe option that can pick off weakened foes like Sandy Shocks and Chien-Pao. VoltTurn support from Pokemon such as Cinderace and Iron Moth is appreciated to bring Greninja in safely on foes like Garganacl.

sets.name: Magic Guard + Life Orb
sets.description: With high Speed that allows it to outspeed most of the unboosted metagame and Life Orb-boosted Special Attack, Greninja is a powerful special threat that uses its fantastic STAB combination to threaten common metagame threats like Ceruledge and Garganacl. Water Shuriken allows Greninja to reliably revenge kill weakened opponents and break through Substitute, while Ice Beam gives coverage against Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Garchomp. Greninja struggles against special walls like Florges and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, so physically offensive Pokemon like Well Baked Body Kingambit and Ceruledge that can threaten them are good teammates. Due to its defensive frailty, Greninja also appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Cinderace that can safely pivot it in. Thanks to its immunity to entry hazards, Greninja fits well on offensive entry hazard stacking teams with little or no entry hazard removers.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Greninja is the fastest Choice Scarf user in the metagame, taking advantage of its blistering Speed tier and colorful Protean-boosted coverage to be a strong revenge killer and offensive pivot. Gunk Shot decimates Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. Ice Beam covers a plethora of Pokemon, including Tornadus-T, Dragapult, Kartana, and Landorus-T. Rock Slide deals with Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Aside from enabling Greninja to pivot, U-turn also provides coverage against Mega Tyranitar, Mega Gyarados, and opposing Greninja. The Special Attack EVs guarantee the OHKO against Kartana with Ice Beam. Terastallizing is mainly used to improve its offensive capabilities; for instance, Tera Poison gives Gunk Shot significant odds to OHKO specially defensive Tera Grass Heatran, Clefable, and Tera Fairy Garganacl after Stealth Rock, while Tera Ice boosts Ice Beam to OHKO Dragapult and physically defensive Tangrowth and Great Tusk. Wallbreakers like Garchomp, Zamazenta, Tapu Lele, and Mega Charizard Y appreciate Greninja's U-turn bringing them in safely on foes like Heatran, Garganacl, Toxapex, and Gholdengo, respectively. Garchomp also provides entry hazards to punish Greninja's forced switches, chipping down the likes of Garganacl and Heatran. In return, Greninja outpaces faster threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult that would otherwise overwhelm them. Greninja can form a VoltTurn core with Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Mega Scizor; the former two also provide Defog so Greninja can pivot more freely, especially if running Tera Ice.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Taunt
sets.description:
Talonflame acts as a fantastic fast revenge killer to threats like Gengar and switch-in to Pokemon like Slither Wing that it can further punish with Flame Body. Taunt lets Talonflame break through Pokemon it would otherwise struggle with such as Quagsire, Gastrodon, Scream Tail, and Roar Hippowdon, while preventing them and Tinkaton from using their entry hazard or utility moves like Roar and Encore. Talonflame can also use Taunt more aggressively to deny setup or recovery from Pokemon such as Salamence and opposing Talonflame and match up well into hyper offense teams. Brave Bird is the required STAB move to ensure Talonflame can pressure Noivern and Water-types like Gastrodon and Slowking. Will-O-Wisp synergizes with Taunt to add chip damage to its checks and spread burns to cripple would be answers like Tyranitar. Flame Body allows Talonflame to potentially punish Pokemon like Slither Wing and Tsareena with burns when switching into them. Tera Ghost gives Talonflame the ability to spinblock and remove its Stealth Rock weakness after potentially having its Heavy-Duty Boots removed by Tinkaton or Wo-Chien. It also lets Talonflame pressure Pokemon like Slowking and Stone Edge Hippowdon, switch into Slither Wing more safely without fear of Wild Charge, beat Extreme Speed Lucario, and makes it harder for Life Orb Pawmot to force it to switch unless Pawmot Terastallizes. However, Talonflame must be careful of being burned by opposing Talonflame if it does this and should consider if its typing is still needed for Scizor and Bisharp.

Taunt Talonflame fits on a wide variety of teams from bulky offense to stall that appreciate its revenge killing capabilities, and defensive applications against wallbreakers like Slither Wing, and its ability to put pressure on various physical and mixed walls. Taunt Talonflame greatly appreciates being paired with entry hazard setters that can help it spread chip damage even more. Gastrodon and Brambleghast can help check Sandy Shocks for Talonflame. Gastrodon covers Pokemon like Salamence, Iron Jugulis, and Grafaiai, while Brambleghast provides a Pawmot answer and Rapid Spin support in case Talonflame gets hit by Knock Off as well as a primary spinblocker if Talonflame does not want to Terastallize. Other hazard setters like Tinkaton can help remove Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Gastrodon and Slowking while providing a Gengar answer, while Quagsire can check Tyranitar and help Talonflame spread chip damage with Toxic. Hazard removers such as Tsareena and Tatsugiri can also help Talonflame be more aggressive into Tinkaton and Wo-Chien. Tsareena can also pressure Slowking, while Tatsugiri appreciates Talonflame wearing down checks like Scream Tail and Tinkaton. Wallbreakers such as Sandy Shocks, Salamence, and Pawmot appreciate Talonflame wearing down their checks like Gastrodon and Hippowdon. Other Knock Off users such as Grafaiai and Wo-Chien can also help Talonflame make more progress alongside entry hazards. Grafaiai can also check Gengar and spread further chip damage with Poison Touch sets or help cover against setup threats that Talonflame struggles with such as Oricorio-E with Prankster Encore, while Wo-Chien can further pressure Pokemon like Slowking and Gastrodon and help check Tyranitar and Sandy Shocks.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Utility Talonflame serves as a premier Slither Wing switch-in, especially with Flame Body punishing U-turn, while still providing solid revenge killing capabilities against weakened foes like Gengar and Noivern, spreading even more burns with Will-O-Wisp, and potentially serving as a Defogger. Flare Blitz is the primary STAB option to pressure Tinkaton and Scizor, but Brave Bird provides better coverage against bulky Water-types like Slowking and Gastrodon. Will-O-Wisp punishes physical attackers—especially Mimikyu and Tyranitar—and opposing walls alike, while U-turn can get frail teammates like Gengar and Gallade in safely; Defog is another utility option if the team needs it, as it can semi-reliably Defog against Tinkaton and non-Stone Edge Hippowdon. Tera Ghost allows Talonflame to safely dispatch Extreme Speed Lucario, while Tera Steel allows for an emergency Will-O-Wisp against foes like Tyranitar; both also shed Talonflame's debilitating Stealth Rock weakness, letting it still check Tinkaton after Knock Off.

Utility Talonflame fits on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate it spreading burns and punishing opposing pivots, namely Slither Wing and Scizor. It can form a potent pivot core with teammates like Sandy Shocks and Slither Wing to pressure opposing teams. Talonflame cannot safely switch into several dangerous physical attackers like Tyranitar and Gyarados, making bulky teammates like Hippowdon and Wo-Chien desirable. Talonflame struggles against powerful Electric-types like Sandy Shocks and Kilowattrel, making Gastrodon and Hippowdon good teammates. Tsareena is a valuable teammate that provides entry hazard removal, letting Talonflame drop Defog for other utility moves, and checks the bulky Water-types that Talonflame hates.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Talonflame utilizes its great Speed tier, good power, and bevy of utility moves to function as one of the best late-game sweepers in the tier. Brave Bird's excellent power and neutral coverage allow Talonflame to effectively run mono-attacking sets while still forcing out most offensive Pokemon, like Meowscarada and Galarian Zapdos. Bulk Up provides insurance against revenge killers like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf users, while Swords Dance offers faster setup. Taunt is the preferred last move to take advantage of passive foes like Unaware Scream Tail and Well-Baked Body Corviknight, turning them into setup fodder; Will-O-Wisp provides team support by crippling bulky foes like Garganacl and Garchomp. Flare Blitz is a final option to provide coverage for Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. Talonflame struggles with special Choice Scarf users like Sandy Shocks and Greninja, as they can force it out no matter how much it has set up, so teammates like Hisuian Goodra are excellent partners. Bulky Flying-resistant foes like Glimmora and Zapdos frustrate Talonflame, making teammates like Greninja and Garchomp that threaten them valuable. Talonflame truly shines in long games, as it can outlast its checks, so bulkier teammates like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Unaware Scream Tail that can help it get in multiple times are recommended.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description:
Vivillon is a good choice for hyper offense teams, as the combination of Sleep Powder and Quiver Dance can easily wrest momentum from the opponent and potentially sweep outright, giving Vivillon a niche in NU as a dangerous setup sweeper. Sleep Powder enables Vivillon to cripple opposing Pokemon that may otherwise check it, such as Eelektross and Drifblim, and give it the free turn needed to set up a Quiver Dance. Substitute is an option to ease setup by helping Vivillon play around the uncertainty of sleep turns and dodge status. Bug Buzz targets Pokemon such as Umbreon and Hattrem, which can otherwise cut Vivillon's sweep short with Thunder Wave or Nuzzle. Finally, Tera Blast with Tera Ground does heavy damage to Muk and outright OHKOes Magneton. Vivillon's very poor overall bulk makes Focus Sash a good option, as it guarantees a Quiver Dance boost or the ability to put a foe to sleep. However, if your team lacks multiple forms of entry hazard removal, Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred. Compound Eyes boosts the otherwise shaky accuracy of Sleep Powder and Hurricane, making them far more reliable. A Timid nature is preferred over a Modest nature to outspeed Choice Scarf users such as Indeedee-F, Passimian, and Medicham after a Quiver Dance and outspeed and threaten an OHKO on offensive threats like Toxicroak and Mabosstiff unboosted. Tera Ground allows Vivillon to turn the tables on Volt Switch users such as Jolteon and Rotom and also helps it survive Accelerock from Lycanroc. Alternatively, Tera Ghost along with Substitute allows Vivillon to set up against Chansey, which would normally wall it, and Tera Flying can be used to power up Vivillon's Hurricane.

If Vivillon is running Focus Sash over Heavy-Duty Boots, strong hazard control is key, so Hattrem, which prevents opposing hazards through Magic Bounce, and other hazard removal options such as Drifblim and Lurantis are mandatory. Special walls such as Chansey and Eelektross are a serious obstacle for Vivillon to overcome, with the former's Natural Cure negating the effect of Sleep Powder, so physical wallbreakers that can take advantage of them like Toxicroak, Paldean Tauros, and Ursaring make for great partners. Trick users, such as Rotom and Zoroark, can also bait in these foes and cripple them by giving them a Choice item, with Rotom deserving special mention for inviting in Lurantis and Appletun, which gives a Vivillon relatively free setup opportunity. Spikes support from the likes of Qwilfish and Cacturne is also appreciated to help wear down answers to Vivillon over time. Strong setup sweepers like Veluza, Dudunsparce, and Lycanroc, which all appreciate foes being put to sleep, also make for powerful partners in conjunction with Vivillon.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
Pyroar is a strong special attacker with a solid STAB combination that can also act as speed control against slower breakers like Charizard, Rotom-F, and Sawsbuck. Fire Blast is the preferred STAB attack for its greater power, allowing Pyroar to always 2HKO foes like Tinkatuff and Gogoat, though Flamethrower is much more consistent for revenge killing purposes, dealing with faster but frailer Pokemon like Haunter and Rotom-F. Tera Blast is Pyroar's Normal STAB option due to its flexibility, functioning either a Normal STAB attack or a Tera type STAB attack. Will-O-Wisp cripples and chips down switch-ins like Klawf and Lumineon. Hyper Voice can also be used over either of these moves as a slightly more powerful and consistent Normal STAB attack. Taunt shuts down status attempts from foes like Skuntank and Misdreavus as well as recovery attempts from Pokemon like Quaxwell and Dunsparce while also denying entry hazards from Pokemon like Masquerain and greedy Carbink. Tera Ground allows Pyroar to threaten out the Rock- and Fire-types that resist its STAB attacks like Carbink, Klawf, and Houndoom while also allowing it to check Electric-types like Ampharos and Electrode. Tera Normal boosts Pyroar's damage output, allowing to do more damage to Water- and Fire-types like Golduck and Camerupt while removing its Water and Ground weaknesses. Lastly, Tera Grass functions similarly to Tera Ground, trading the latter's ability to hit Fire-types super effectively for better matchups against Raichu, Whiscash, Basculin, and Alolan Dugtrio.

Pyroar is heavily effective on offensive builds that focus on wearing down shared checks. Despite it seeming like bad synergy, Fire-types like Charizard and Houndoom are recommended, as they can help force in and wear down shared checks that lack reliable recovery, like Carbink and Whiscash. Pyroar can also form a powerful offensive core with Water- and Ground-types like Golduck and Alolan Dugtrio, since they threaten the Rock- and Fire-types that Pyroar does not like. In return, Pyroar can threaten out their switch-ins, like Gogoat and Dartrix, while helping wear down a shared check in Misdreavus. Foes like Dugtrio and Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N can consistently force out a Pyroar that has not Terastallized, so switch-ins to them, such as Dachsbun and Gabite, are appreciated. Dachsbun can heal chip damage Pyroar has sustained with Wish, while Gabite provides entry hazards to wear down switch-ins that do not run Heavy-Duty Boots, like Quaxwell and Ampharos.

sets.name: Taunt Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Pyroar's excellent Speed and solid movepool make it a great wallbreaker that checks setup sweepers. Taunt allows Pyroar to prevent bulky Pokemon like Blissey, Muk, and Ursaring from getting free switch-in to use their utility moves while also stopping setup sweepers such as Bulk Up Braviary, Coil Eelektross, and Nasty Plot Mesprit. Will-O-Wisp threatens Pyroar switch-ins like Samurott, Muk, and Assault Vest Eelektross. Tera Blast is most commonly run with Tera Grass, allowing Pyroar to destroy threats like Floatzel, Sandaconda, and Veluza. Endeavor can be used over Will-O-Wisp to severely weaken special walls like Blissey, Appletun, and Ursaring if they attempt to trade damage after Pyroar uses Taunt versus them. Tera Ghost allows Pyroar to turn the tables against common Fighting-types such as Toxicroak, Medicham, and Hisuian Sneasel that would usually destroy it. Alternatively, Tera Grass allows Pyroar to tank powerful Water- and Ground-type attacks from Bruxish, Floatzel, and Sandaconda.

Pyroar can't reliably defeat walls such as Blissey, Umbreon, and Appletun; it best pairs with physical wallbreakers like Toxicroak, Scyther, and Samurott that can deal with these threats. If Pyroar loses its Heavy-Duty Boots, it becomes susceptible to entry hazards, so hazard removers such as Avalugg, Drifblim, and Lurantis or a hazard deterrent like Hattrem are great partners. Grass-types like Cacturne, Appletun, and Lurantis appreciate Pyroar for checking threats such as Scyther, Avalugg, and Vivillon; in return, they check Water-types like Bruxish, Clawitzer, and Samurott. Fighting-types like Hisuian Sneasel and Choice Scarf Medicham can threaten out Pyroar, so it pairs best with Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Mesprit, Bruxish, and Drifblim.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Florges's extremely high Special Defense stat makes it an effective wall that also provides utility in the form of Wishpassing. With Unaware, Florges is able to comfortably set up on and check Pokemon such as Quiver Dance Volcarona, Fiery Dance Iron Moth, and Hatterene. Tablets of Ruin is also a viable option that allows Florges to easily switch into and threaten Pokemon such as Chien-Pao. Calm Mind + Wish and Synthesis give Florges the longevity necessary to serve a bulky sweeper. Wish + Protect provides guaranteed healing and can be used to scout options from foes; it also synergizes well with chip damage from other sources, like Garganacl's Salt Cure and poison damage from Toxic Spikes. Despite its naturally high Special Defense, Florges is threatened by special attackers that can muscle through it, such as Shell Smash Polteageist. Florges thus appreciates teammates that can handle these threats such as RegenVest Roaring Moon and Blissey. To compensate for its relatively low physical bulk, Florges can be paired with teammates who are more physically defensive, such as Dondozo and Corviknight.

sets.name: Stall
sets.description: Defense gives the best odds against opposing Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Gogoat is an amazing defensive wincon, able to boost past special threats like Indeedee-F and Charizard late-game thanks to its great special bulk, usage of Terastallization, and recovery in Horn Leech and Milk Drink. It is also a solid switch-in to Water-types like Whiscash and Basculin, comfortably taking their STAB moves and threatening to OHKO them or set up. Bulk Up is what lets Gogoat become so threatening late-game, letting it take on physical attackers like Perserrker and Sawsbuck after a Bulk Up or two. Rock Slide is optimal coverage alongside Horn Leech, hitting Grass-type checks like Charizard, Honchkrow, and Articuno. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Gogoat ignore entry hazards, namely the otherwise debilitating Toxic Spikes. Water is the premier Tera type due to its overall defensive utility, reversing Gogoat's Fire weakness and making it take Flying- and Bug-type attacks more easily, which lets it set up on various foes it could not before such as Charizard, Rabsca, and Camerupt. However, Tera Rock gives Gogoat STAB on Rock Slide while still having it resist Fire and Flying, but it becomes vulnerable to Ground- and Steel-types like Gabite and Perrserker. Both Tera types keep Gogoat's usefulness as a Grass-type check due to Sap Sipper.

Before Terastallizing or setting up, Gogoat is threatened by common offensive Pokemon like Charizard, Pyroar, and Rotom-F, so additional special walls like Carbink and Ampharos are recommended as partners. Carbink can also set entry hazards to wear down Gogoat's checks like Gabite and Tinkatuff, while Ampharos can bring Gogoat in with Volt Switch. Pokemon like Basculin and Alolan Dugtrio appreciate having a Pokemon that can come in on Electric- and Grass-types like Raichu and Leafeon. Misdreavus is particularly annoying for Gogoat, able to cripple it with Will-O-Wisp + Hex and use it at setup bait, so ways to dispose of or significantly weaken Misdreavus are appreciated. Wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Skuntank, special Honchkrow, and Indeedee-F can threaten Misdreavus while not caring about Will-O-Wisp, while paralysis from Tinkatuff and Alolan Persian can help Gogoat brute force its way past Misdreavus.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: 132 Speed EVs are to outrun uninvested Sylveon.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: 172 Speed EVs are to outrun uninvested Alomomola, Umbreon, and Vaporeon.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: With Choice Specs and the unique Mega Launcher ability, Clawitzer uses its exceptional coverage to be one of the most devastating wallbreakers in NU. Tera Dragon not only maintains Clawitzer's Water and Fire resistances, but it also turns Clawitzer's Grass and Electric weaknesses into resistances. Further, it gives Clawitzer a more powerful STAB move in Dragon Pulse, which guarantees a 2HKO on common special walls like Umbreon and Assault Vest Eelektross after Stealth Rock. Aura Sphere hits Chansey and Steel-types like Perrserker and Tera Steel Eelektross. U-turn can be used in the fourth moveslot to bring in teammates like Passimian and Toxicroak, which better deal with healthy special walls like Chansey and Umbreon or Tera Fairy threats, allowing Clawitzer to use Dragon Pulse more freely. Flash Cannon can also be used to hit Tera Fairy Pokemon like Chansey, Umbreon, and Vaporeon, which are immune to Dragon Pulse and Water Pulse, in Vaporeon's case. Without Terastallizing, Electric-types like Rotom, Jolteon, and Magneton pose a threat to Clawitzer. Appletun and Electric immunities like Sandaconda and Jolteon work as partners to eat up their moves and restore any HP they lose.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Calm Mind + Wish
sets.description: 48 SpD EVs allows Sylveon to avoid the 2HKO from Tera Flying Booster Energy Iron Jugulis Hurricane.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With its good natural bulk, Sylveon can serve as a potent special attacker and decent revenge killer.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Blast serves as a good alternate STAB attack once Sylveon has Terastallized, providing highly valuable coverage against the Steel-types that could otherwise exploit it, like Scizor. It also gets around potential users of Throat Chop before Terastallization, such as Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon.

  • Psyshock: This is Sylveon's best shot of dealing with Iron Moth.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball hits foes such as Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo super effectively, and it means Sylveon does not have to Terastallize to hit Gholdengo for good damage.

  • Quick Attack: Though it is weak, Quick Attack gives valuable priority for picking off weakened threats, and thanks to Pixilate, surprise users of Tera Ghost aren't able to absorb it. A Quiet nature can be used to increase its power, though this risks Sylveon getting outsped by Kingambit.

Other Options

  • Psychic: Psychic deals more damage to physically defensive Toxapex and Amoonguss, but its lower damage output against Iron Moth makes it disappointing if not using Tera Ground.

  • Hyper Beam: Despite the serious risks from the recharge turn, Hyper Beam's extreme power makes it a good filler move.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest lets even offensive Sylveon be specially resilient.

  • Choice Specs: With the boost from Choice Specs, Sylveon is a surprisingly potent wallbreaker, making the most out of its many opportunities to switch in.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA: This spread capitalizes on Sylveon's good natural bulk while maximizing its power.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: While no bulk investment makes Sylveon more difficult to safely get in, Speed investment allows it to outrun and threaten a wider range of foes, such as Scizor and Corviknight.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Sylveon suffers coverage issues on its own, so its heavily reliant on either Tera Blast or the sheer power of Tera Fairy Hyper Voice to break past them.

  • Fire: Tera Fire allows Sylveon to break past troublesome Steel-types, like Gholdengo and Kingambit, and gives it a key resistance to Ice and Fire attacks from Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu respectively.

  • Water: Tera Water gives good coverage against Fire-types like Iron Moth and Skeledirge, in addition to surprising Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu by resisting their strongest STAB attacks.

  • Ground: Tera Ground doesn't match up quite as well against Steel-types as Tera Fire, but it lets Sylveon turn the tables on Iron Moth, and deal massive damage to Toxapex and Skeledirge.

  • Fairy: Getting an extra boost on Hyper Voice and Hyper Beam makes Choice Specs Sylveon far more difficult to wall, with even resists such as Gholdengo and physically defensive Skeledirge getting 2HKOed by Hyper Voice!

Items

  • Assault Vest: Giving Sylveon extra special bulk lets it take on powerful threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle more reliably.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs turns Sylveon into a surprising wallbreaker, especially if using Tera Fairy.

  • Throat Spray: With Hyper Voice activating Throat Spray, Sylveon could potentially break apart slower foes in the late game, though it only gets one shot at this Special Attack boost. This is best used with Tera Blast to give Sylveon an alternative STAB attack that doesn't activate Throat Spray.

sets.name: CUTESY CRUSADER (Defensive)
sets.description:
• With its good bulk and Special Attack and a reasonable healing move in Wish, Sylveon is a good choice for a bulky Fairy-type.

  • Hyper Voice: Hyper Voice gives Sylveon a reliable STAB even when Terastallized, and hits through common Substitute users like Iron Bundle and Wo-Chien. While It's possible to drop this attack for Tera Blast in an attempt to run more coverage, this seriously worsens Sylveon's matchup against Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu.

  • Tera Blast: Beyond just Terastallization, Tera Blast is still impacted by Pixilate, making it a good move to use against foes that sometimes carry Throat Chop, like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon.

  • Protect: Protect pairs excellently with Leftovers, and makes Wish a more reliable recovery move.

  • Yawn: Sylveon's good bulk makes it a great choice for phazing with Yawn.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock is Sylveon's best hope for Iron Moth switch-ins.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball offers important coverage on Gholdengo without demanding that Sylveon Terastallize.

  • Leftovers versus Sitrus Berry: Leftovers is the preferred recovery item for its synergy with Protect and Wish, but Sitrus Berry is a reasonable alternative if Protect isn't wanted, or if another teammate needs Leftovers more.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Sylveon's coverage issues are much easier to deal with when using Terastallization, but this set can still be used well defensively without it.

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type grants Sylveon resistances to Steel and Fairy, allowing it to take on foes it would otherwise have to run from, such as Gholdengo, and a good STAB to hit Chien-Pao hard with if not using Hyper Voice. It also works against Scizor, but note that Tera Water is common on that foe. Tera Fire also makes Sylveon far more vulnerable to Ting-Lu.

  • Water: Tera Water is a great mono-attacking option, making it ideal if only running Tera Blast to do decently well against Steel-types. It also gives Sylveon a better matchup against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, and is a safer option against Ting-Lu and Tera Water Scizor.

  • Fairy: If not using Tera Blast, Fairy becomes a reasonable option for boosting Hyper Voice's damage output. Note that Tera Blast is not needed to justify a different Tera Type.

  • Ground: Tera Ground worsens Sylveon's matchup with Chien-Pao, but it does let it deal big damage to Iron Moth, Gholdengo, and Toxapex.

sets.name: Babiri Berry
sets.description:
• Babiri Berry lets Sylveon survive Heavy Slam from Choice Band Great Tusk, Choice Band Iron Hands, and Choice Band Dondozo.
  • Hyper Voice allows Sylveon to bypass Substitute from Leech Seed Meowscarada, Dragapult, and Booster Energy Roaring Moon, and it's a spammable STAB option to beat Encore + Disable Iron Valiant.
  • Fake Tears is for non-Clear Amulet Bellibolt, maximizing Sylveon’s damage against it, and it synergizes with Calm Mind against non-Clear Amulet Espathra, non-Clear Amulet Dondozo, and Unaware Skeledirge.
  • The HP EVs let Sylveon survive two Hydro Pumps from Booster Energy Walking Wake by using Calm Mind. The Defense EVs let Sylveon survive Headlong Rush from Choice Band Great Tusk.

sets.name: Weakness Policy
sets.description:
• Charm helps Sylveon beat slower physical attackers like offensive Azumarill and Choice Band Ting-Lu.
  • Draining Kiss provides Sylveon enough recovery to beat Choice Band Donphan.
  • Fake Tears can be used to beat stall Azumarill, while Hyper Voice can be used to have a better matchup against Leech Seed Meowscarada.
  • The EVs allow Sylveon to outspeed Choice Band Donphan and survive its Gunk Shot twice by using Charm on turn 1, then using Draining Kiss twice to secure the win.
  • An alternate EV spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA with a Bold nature can be used to have the best possible odds against Choice Band Meowscarada. This set should also use Hyper Voice to reliably win against Leech Seed sets. However, this set loses against Donphan, and Choice Band Meowscarada's Giga Impact still has a slight chance to OHKO Sylveon. It's also unreliable against Ting-Lu, as Choice Band Ting-Lu can outspeed and beat it with Heavy Slam.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Hyper Beam OHKOes Ting-Lu, Dondozo, non-Assault Vest Azumarill, and non-specially defensive Bellibolt.
  • Hyper Voice allows Sylveon to bypass Substitute from Leech Seed Meowscarada, Dragapult, and Petaya Berry Espathra. Hyper Voice also has perfect Accuracy and lets Sylveon beat slower Sylveon variants.
  • Psyshock allows Sylveon to beat Clodsire and occasionally Life Orb Salazzle.
  • Shadow Ball 2HKOes Skeledirge.
  • The Speed EVs are for Sylveon to outspeed Pokemon with 50 base Speed unless if they use a Speed boosting nature.
  • Against Espathra, Sylveon should always use Hyper Voice for the best chance to win against most Espathra. Unlike other Sylveon sets, Choice Specs loses to Encore + Disable Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Unburden Sweeper
sets.description:
• Hawlucha is a niche pick as a potentially threatening Unburden sweeper that only fits on hyper offense teams and is reliant on Miraidon's Electric Terrain to function.
  • Taunt can be used to shut down phazing attempts from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, status moves like Toxic from Clodsire, setup attempts from opposing sweepers like Bulk Up Palafin and Espathra, and recovery attempts from Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Toxapex.
  • Substitute lets Hawlucha take any one hit, despite its frailty, giving it an opportunity to set up with Swords Dance. Substitute also blocks status moves like Toxic from Clodsire and Toxapex and Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge.
  • Protect lets Hawlucha scout for potential Terastallizations like Tera Fairy Miraidon or Tera Ghost Ting-Lu.
  • Roost allows Hawlucha to stay healthy over the course of its sweep, keeping it out of range of priority like Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch.
  • 140 EVs in Speed allow Hawlucha to outrun +1 Iron Bundle and +2 Miraidon when Unburden is active.
  • Tera Fighting removes Hawlucha’s Flying type and powers up Close Combat, letting it OHKO Miraidon and removing its weakness to Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard.
  • Hawlucha is an all-or-nothing late-game sweeper that, has to fully commit to a sweep once it activates Unburden's speed boost. For this reason, it's only a decent pick on hyper offensive teams.
  • Miraidon is a necessary partner, activating Hawlucha’s Electric Seed with the Electric Terrain it sets via Hadron Engine. It also threatens Dondozo, a physical wall and Unaware Pokemon that can halt Hawlucha’s sweep. Hawlucha also threatens Clodsire, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu, all of which check or counter setup variants of Miraidon, allowing Miraidon to clean up should Hawlucha’s sweep fail.
  • Iron Bundle threatens all three common Unaware Pokemon in Dondozo, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, as well as Toxapex, paving the way for Hawlucha to sweep.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Unburden Sweeper
sets.description: Hawlucha is a terrifying setup sweeper with a stellar Speed tier alongside Unburden to instantly outspeed the entire metagame, including boosted foes like Iron Valiant, +2 Mega Gyarados, and weather sweepers such as Mega Swampert and—with the given Speed EVs—Excadrill. Its high-powered STAB moves—which can be boosted further by Swords Dance—hit almost the entire metagame neutrally; Acrobatics grants Hawlucha strong neutral coverage against the likes of Tornadus-T, Dragapult, and Tapu Lele, which is backed up by Close Combat to decimate Flying-resistant Pokemon like Kingambit, Garganacl, and Mega Tyranitar. Its item instantly activates Unburden under the corresponding Terrain and grants it setup opportunities from the Defense boost, especially in conjunction with Roost. Electric Seed helps against Kingambit, Zamazenta, and Great Tusk and prevents revenge killing attempts from Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Weavile's Ice Shard, while Psychic Seed helps against Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Choice-locked Dragapult. Taunt or Substitute deals with problematic walls, ignoring status like Toxapex's Toxic and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp; Taunt also prevents their recovery and phazing as well as Defense-boosting attempts such as from Skarmory or Tera Water Buzzwole, while Substitute blocks Landorus-T's Intimidate and punishes the use of weak attacks like its U-turn, Garganacl's Salt Cure, and Alomomola's Scald. The bulk investment allows Hawlucha to survive Clefable's Moonblast, which is unnecessary if running Psychic Seed. 176 Speed EVs can be used instead to revenge kill +1 Dragon Dance Dragapult. Tera Flying boosts Hawlucha's Acrobatics, potentially OHKOing Clefable at +2 and letting it set up against defensive Tornadus-T if necessary. The corresponding Alolan Guardian is a mandatory teammate to reliably activate Hawlucha's Unburden; Tapu Koko provides dual screens and brings Hawlucha in safely on Tangrowth and Ferrothorn with U-turn, while Tapu Lele pressures Toxapex and overwhelms Gholdengo. Offensive Pokemon on hyper offense teams such as Iron Valiant, Volcarona, Dragonite, and Mega Gyarados help maintain offensive pressure against the opposition; notably, they can force damage onto shared checks like Gholdengo, Skeledirge, Zapdos, and Toxapex, respectively, for Hawlucha to sweep more easily.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Carving out a niche for itself as an entry hazard setter with good matchups against common threats such as Charizard and Articuno, Carbink is easily able to exploit the fact that many common offensive Pokemon will struggle to OHKO it, making entry hazards on the opponent's side of the field nearly guaranteed. Body Press further takes advantage of Carbink's naturally high Defense by allowing it to deal modest damage, especially to frail attackers such as Pyroar or Steel-types that may try to switch in, such as Perrserker or Alolan Dugtrio, although its reliance on Body Press to not be immensely passive can invite in opposing Misdreavus or other Pokemon that may choose to utilize Tera Ghost. Power Gem allows for Carbink to target common Pokemon in the tier that have a large Rock weakness, such as Charizard, Articuno, Masquerain, and Vespiquen, while also insuring that it is not entirely helpless against the aforementioned Misdreavus. Spikes allows Carbink to be of greater assistance to more fast-paced offensive teams, further exploiting its natural bulk to apply even more pressure to the opponent in the form of entry hazards. Rest allows for Carbink to somewhat make up for its lack of recovery, which helps it to still be a threat later in the game and to set hazards back up if they are removed. Lastly, Iron Defense allows Carbink to become a threatening sweeper by making it even more difficult to break through while also greatly increasing the damage done by Body Press. Heavy-Duty Boots helps Carbink by making it immune to opposing hazards, greatly increasing its longevity, while Leftovers allows for a small amount of passive recovery. Tera Fighting increases the damage of Body Press even further, while Tera Ghost allows for Carbink to block attempts at using Rapid Spin to clear away hazards. A more physically defensive spread of 248 HP / 252 Def / 8 SpD with a Bold nature is also viable to improve Carbink's matchup against threats such as Gogoat and Dugtrio.

Carbink's high success rate when it comes to setting up entry hazards is greatly appreciated by almost all teams, especially those that make use of setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Charizard or powerful breakers like Zangoose, which greatly benefit from the extra chip damage that Carbink provides. In addition, Grass-types such as Gogoat and Thwackey appreciate Carbink's ability to take hits from the multitude of powerful Fire-types in the tier. Thwackey is also one of the few Pokemon in PU with access to Knock Off, which is valuable for removing Heavy-Duty Boots from opponents and making Carbink's hazards much more difficult to manage. Furthermore, Grassy Terrain lessens the damage dealt by Earthquake and provides Carbink with passive recovery, which is especially beneficial should it choose to run Heavy-Duty Boots. In return, these Pokemon are strong answers to Water-types such as Whiscash and Golduck that can solidly threaten Carbink with super effective attacks. Carbink also appreciates strong Ground- and Fire-types, such as Dugtrio, Charizard, and Pyroar, that can handle threatening Steel-types such as Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio for it. Due to Carbink being extremely slow and vulnerable to moves such as Taunt and Encore, fast teammates such as the aforementioned Dugtrio, as well as Alolan Persian and Raichu, are also appreciated to handle attempts to stifle Carbink alongside providing much-needed speed control.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
Iron Defense Carbink is an incredibly terrifying defensive setup sweeper with incredible stats, making really hard to stop even for some of the most threatening physical attackers like Crabominable, and Lycanroc-N, especially after it starts boosting with Iron Defense. Body Press hits most of the tier for neutral or super effective damage, making its switch-ins very limited after a boost. Most of these switch-ins like Charizard and Masquerain also have to be wary of Power Gem. Carbink could choose to run Moonblast instead, hitting the likes of Drakloak and Spiritomb. Rock Polish is an option in the last slot to boost past Pokemon that could normally pick it off at low health like offensive Perrserker, Klawf, and Gabite. Carbink can also opt to run RestTalk alongside Iron Defense and Body Press to function better as a late-game sweeper once opposing Ghost-types and bulky Pokemon that resist its attacks are removed. Clear Body helps with many aspects, like avoiding defensive drops from moves like Misdreavus's Shadow Ball or Quaxwell's Liquidation, blocking Alolan Persian's Parting Shot, and ignoring Sticky Web's Speed drop. Tera Fighting is used to boost Body Press's power, helping Carbink pick up the 2HKO on Gogoat, Skuntank, and Whiscash. A defensive Tera like Ghost or Water also work well with helping Carbink get by various foes. Ghost drops all of its weaknesses, allowing it to tank hits with greater ease, but it makes enemies like Misdreavus, Banette, and Haunter more problematic. Water is a great option for stuffing the likes of Golduck, Basculin, and Lumineon, though Carbink then has to be wary of Rotom-F and Raichu in addition to being a generally good defensive typing that also allows it to shrug off hits from Steel-type moves that would usually obliterate it. Carbink can opt to run a more specially defensive spread of 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD with a Calm nature to better take hits from Whiscash, Lumineon, and Raichu for an easier time setting up on them. However, you do miss out on initial Body Press power.

Carbink works great on balance or bulky offensive teams looking for an endgame sweeper. It does great at supporting the likes of Misdreavus, Haunter, and Indeedee-F since it can wall Dark-types like Honchkrow, Alolan Persian, and Spiritomb. Carbink also isn't bothered by the likes of Houndoom, Pyroar, and Charizard which teammates like Gogoat, Rotom-F, and Rabsca really appreciate. It also fits the role of a Knock Off absorber, being able to take the hit when switching in and either immediately deal damage back or start setting up on Banette, Tinkatuff, and Klawf. While Carbink's defensive capabilities make it a great teammate, it also can break through bulky teams that rely on the likes of Hisuian Sliggoo and Chansey, which special attackers such as Haunter, Persian and Rotom-F enjoy having removed. Grass-types such as Gogoat, Dartrix, and Flapple really help Carbink find multiple opportunities to come back in to set up since they can help take hits from the likes of Whiscash, Basculin, and Sawsbuck. Carbink also really appreciates having a partner that can help with its 4x weakness to Steel, specifically against Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio, like defensive Misdreavus, Lumineon, and RestTalk Gabite.

sets.name: Special Tank
sets.description:
Acid Spray can be used instead of Dragon Pulse to help Hisuian Sliggoo take on specially bulky foes like Chansey, Gogoat, and Calm Mind Misdreavus. Thunderbolt and Ice Beam are other options that offer Hisuian Sliggoo great coverage and deal more damage to Pokemon like Charizard and Gogoat, respectively.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

sets.name: RestoChesto (Dragon)
sets.description:
Due to its exceptional bulk and Steel typing, Hisuian Goodra is a staple on Dragon teams, being able to take on Fairy-, Dragon-, and Ice-type threats. Heavy Slam checks Fairy-types like Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Hatterene while also hitting Dragapult and other Dragon-types neutrally. Body Press, further enhanced by Acid Armor, threatens Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Hydreigon, as well as deals considerable damage to opposing Hisuian Goodra and Walking Wake after Defense boosts. Rest, in conjunction with Chesto Berry, provides instant recovery, comma allowing Hisuian Goodra to preserve Acid Armor boosts while remaining healthy, severely threatening Dragon and hyper offensive Dark teams. The given EV spread provides enough Defense to OHKO Chien-Pao with an unboosted Body Press while retaining as much Special Defense as possible to improve the Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Walking Wake matchups. Shell Armor prevents foes from breaking through Acid Armor boosts with a critical hit.

Baxcalibur is a great teammate in the Ground and Flying matchups, threatening Landorus, Sandy Shocks, and Corviknight. Garchomp provides entry hazards to wear down wallbreakers like Sneasler, Sandy Shocks, and Urshifu-R, as well as deals with walls such as Clodsire, Skeledirge, and Iron Hands. Dragapult offers a Fighting-type immunity to combat Sneasler, Zamazenta, and Urshifu-R. Dragonite and Hydreigon switch into Ground-type attacks from Iron Treads, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu and also aid in the Steel and Poison matchups. Walking Wake is a huge asset in the Ground matchup and threatens Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Cyclizar removes entry hazards for Hisuian Goodra to improve its longevity and provides it a safe switch in against threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant with Shed Tail.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, vist the format page!

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Hisuian Goodra's incredible special bulk, typing, and useful immunity to Spore via Sap Sipper make it one of the prime choices for Assault Vest!

  • Flash Cannon versus Heavy Slam: Flash Cannon has great synergy with Acid Spray and is a reliable STAB move in general. While Heavy Slam isn't very useful against heavy targets, it's worth using for OHKOing offensive Flutter Mane, one of the biggest threats in the metagame.

  • Draco Meteor versus Ice Beam: Draco Meteor's power makes switching offensive threats like Urshifu-R into Hisuian Goodra tricky, and it is notable for 2HKOing Dondozo. Ice Beam lets Hisuian Goodra punish important Ground-types.

  • Acid Spray: Acid Spray is a useful wallbreaking tool, capable of making even specially bulky foes like Clodsire risk taking massive damage after the Special Defense drop.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is another way to 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo and OHKO offensive Urshifu-R and pairs very well with Ice Beam in terms of coverage.

  • Earthquake: While not particularly strong, Earthquake is highly recommended for 2HKOing Heatran and 3HKOing opposing Assault Vest Hisuian Goodra, as both of these will wall this set otherwise.

  • Flamethrower: For other Steel-types like Gholdengo and Scizor, Flamethrower will deal much more damage than Earthquake.

  • Modest versus Quiet: The importance of mirror matches makes Modest an appealing option for Hisuian Goodra, but Quiet will ensure that all but the bulkiest Flutter Mane will need to Terastallize to avoid a OHKO from Heavy Slam.

Other Options

  • Surf: Surf is a decent option to hit Ground-types and Heatran with one attack, but Surf will, at best, usually only 3HKO Heatran.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite Hisuian Goodra's superb typing, its common weaknesses to Ground and Fighting make Terastallization a valuable route for it.

  • Flying: Tera Flying covers Hisuian Goodra's former weaknesses fantastically, even giving it an out against Fissure Dondozo. This comes at the cost of doing much worse against Iron Bundle, Thundurus-T, Zapdos, and Rotom-W though.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy still gives Hisuian Goodra a vital Fighting resistance, as well as being a good defensive typing in general.

  • Water: Tera Water has good synergy with Sap Sipper, giving Hisuian Goodra a sole weakness to Electric, in addition to gaining a useful Ice resistance against Chien-Pao, at the cost of doing worse against Iron Bundle.

Minor Optimizations

  • Female Gender: If using Heavy Slam, there is a a chance that Hisuian Goodra can become infatuated by the very rare Cute Charm Enamorus, making a female gender very slightly superior.

sets.name: Armor Press
sets.description:
• Hisuian Goodra's bulk lends itself naturally to boosting its Defense for Body Press, especially with a useful immunity to critical hits that gives it a great matchup against Urshifu formes after Terastallization.

  • Heavy Slam: As Flutter Mane is the most dangerous Special Attacker in the format, Heavy Slam is the best Steel-type STAB move, OHKOing all but the most defensive Flutter Mane if they don't Terastallize.

  • Protect: Protect has good synergy with Leftovers for extra healing, though Urshifu formes can ignore it.

  • Draco Meteor versus Ice Beam: If using a Sassy or Relaxed nature, Draco Meteor can threaten to 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo. Ice Beam, on the other hand, is a safer and stronger option against Landorus-T and Garchomp.

Other Options

  • Rest and Chesto Berry: Rest and Chesto Berry combine to give Hisuian Goodra a great way to restore health, though the combination is only reliable once.

  • Life Dew: Life Dew doesn't restore much health even with Leftovers, but it can help Hisuian Goodra last longer against some physical threats after setting up.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Hisuian Goodra's fantastic typing doesn't make Terastallization a requirement, but it does make setting up against major physical threats like Urshifu-R and Landorus-T much more feasible.

  • Flying: Tera Flying not only covers all of Hisuian Goodra's former weaknesses, but it also means Fissure is no longer an option to break through its boosts from the likes of Dondozo or Ting-Lu. The new weaknesses to Electric and Ice can harm it though, since Electric- and Ice-type coverage moves are commonly special.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Hisuian Goodra shielding from both Urshifu formes without giving it the harmful Electric and Ice weaknesses that Flying does, though it can harm mirror matches against Assault Vest Hisuian Goodra.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful or Sassy: This specially defensive spread is Hisuian Goodra's best shot at avoiding a 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Tera Fairy Moonblast, assuming extra Leftovers recovery from Protect.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish or Relaxed: Maximum physical bulk means Hisuian Goodra won't check Flutter Mane nearly as well, but it let will let Body Press become a better sweeping tool.

Minor Optimizations

  • Acid Armor: Acid Armor is the best option for boosting Defense due to its higher PP, but it requires Hisuian Sligoo to evolve while knowing the move in either Scarlet or Violet, as it's not able to be relearned by Hisuian Goodra. Shelter is still a viable, albeit strictly inferior, option.

  • Female Gender: While very rare, Heavy Slam being a contact move means Hisuian Goodra does risk of activating Enamorus's Cute Charm, making a female gender a marginally better choice.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Hisuian Goodra, with its excellent defensive typing and enormous special bulk, is a premier RegenVest user that is able to check common special attackers such as Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Greninja while also being able to phase setup sweepers like Volcarona and Polteageist with Dragon Tail. Earthquake hits opposing Hisuian Goodra and can also OHKO Fire-types like Iron Moth, while Flamethrower can threaten Steel-types like Corviknight. Thunderbolt provides coverage for offensive Water-types like Greninja, Volcanion, and Inteleon while denying minimum Speed Corviknight an opportunity to use Roost; Draco Meteor is a strong STAB move for threats like Garchomp, and Ice Beam provides coverage against prominent special attackers like Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Kilowattrel. Hisuian Goodra is a great teammate for frail offensive Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Talonflame, as it can soak up hits from Choice Scarf revenge killers like Greninja and Azelf; in return, Zapdos and Talonflame can revenge kill strong special wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T and Hoopa, which could otherwise threaten Goodra. Goodra is vulnerable to strong physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Landorus-T, so pairing it with a physical wall such as Corviknight is recommended. Goodra can also be chipped down by entry hazards, which limit its walling prowess, so spinners like Quaquaval and Iron Treads make for good teammates to provide Goodra with more longevity.

sets.name: Dual Screens (Fairy)
sets.description:
Klefki is a popular choice for Fairy-type teams due to Prankster, dual screens, and Spikes. This set excels at enabling setup sweepers such as Mimikyu and Azumarill providing them with boosted bulk and chipping the opposing team thanks to Spikes. With maximum HP and Defense EVs and Foul Play, Klefki efficiently counters opposing Swords Dance and Dragon Dance sweepers such as Scizor and Dragonite. Alternatively, it can use Thunder Wave to cripple fast threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant. Klefki’s Steel typing also provides a useful immunity against Poison-type teams and blocks Glimmora's Mortal Spin, ensuring that entry hazards remain on the opposing field.

Belly Drum Azumarill is an excellent partner for Klefki, as the dual screens greatly facilitate setting up with Belly Drum and sweeping opposing teams. Additionally, Spikes provide some chip damage to ensure OHKOs on foes like Meowscarada. Choice Specs Flutter Mane can also take advantage of the chip damage from Klefki's Spikes to power through teams and more easily defeat walls such as Toxapex, Quagsire, and Amoonguss. Calm Mind Flutter Mane benefits both dual screens to set up and sweep and from Thunder Wave slowing down threats like Barraskewda. Iron Valiant appreciates Klefki slowing down faster foes like Flutter Mane, Cinderace, and Dragapult with Thunder Wave, allowing it to defeat them. Iron Valiant also provides a much-needed offensive pressure against Steel-types like Kingambit and works as a devastating offensive core when paired with Flutter Mane. Hatterene and Klefki form a strong defensive core, with the former’s Magic Bounce punishing any attempt from Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Forretress to set entry hazards, while the latter can come in on Poison-type moves, potentially forcing a switch on a Choice locked Pokemon like Greninja in the process. The additional bulk that Hatterene receives from the dual screens even allows it to take a stand against foes such as Glimmora, Clodsire, and Toxapex, preventing them from setting their hazards while countering them.

sets.name: Dual Screens (Steel)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Screen Setter (Fairy)
sets.description: Klefki is the ideal dual screens setter on Fairy due to its Steel typing, which negates Poison-type attacks from Nihilego and Alolan Muk and ability to fend off threats like Mega Scizor with Foul Play. Klefki is a better option than Grimmsnarl due to its typing and ability to set up Spikes, which, like its screens, go up quickly with Prankster. This support allows for Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Azumarill from setting up and sweeping, teams. Foul Play prevents Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Mimikyu to set up and sweep while Thunder Wave cripples foes and allows Mega Diancie to outspeed threats such as +1 Mega Charizard X and Nihilego, which will normally beat Klefki one on one. Setting up Spikes creates solid chip damage on Alolan Muk and Gholdengo, allowing for late-game sweeping from its teammates Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Mega Diancie punishes opponents trying to set up entry hazards against Klefki and beats Fire-types such as Heatran and Mega Charizard Y. Tapu Bulu helps Klefki with Grassy Terrain, which halves the damage it takes from Earthquake, making Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Mamoswine not hit as hard.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Sturdy Support
sets.description:
• With incredible Defense and the ability Sturdy, Avalugg finds a niche on stall-based teams as a physical wall that prevents fishing for OHKOs.

  • Icicle Crash versus Avalanche: While Avalanche has bigger damage potential when Avalugg is attacked head on, its defensive profile normally forces switches. This makes Icicle Crash the more consistent option for overall damage.

  • Toxic Support Partners: Even though Avalugg stops foes such as Dondozo from using Fissure, it lacks the power to cleanly beat these targets on its own. Common stall teammates such as Toxapex and Clodsire can bring Toxic or Toxic Spikes to spread status, allowing Avalugg to simply stall while poison wears down the opposition.

  • EV Spread: Full investment into HP and Defense give Avalugg insane physical bulk. Even Choice Band Chien-Pao’s Sacred Sword isn’t a reliable 2HKO!

Other Options

  • Mirror Coat: Combined with Sturdy, Mirror Coat is a tempting last resort against the special attackers that Avalugg can’t wall. However, this almost assuredly destroys Avalugg’s survivability afterwards, which can compromise the defensive cycle of its team.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Situational: Most commonly a member of stall-based teams, Avalugg’s bad matchups are supposed to be covered by the team’s defensive cycle. Tera is normally only used if it is necessary to prevent the collapse of said defensive cycle.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting balances offense and defense, making dealing with physical Fighting- and Rock-type attacks much more manageable and giving a sizable boost to Avalugg’s best attack in Body Press.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost lets Avalugg escape from precarious situations against trapping moves and Gothitelle. It also outright walls Close Combat from the likes of Iron Hands and Iron Valiant, although the new Dark-type weakness significantly worsens its matchup with Chien-Pao.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is another option for weakening Fighting-type moves directed at Avalugg while also blocking Toxic and allowing for Toxic Spikes absorption later in the match.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Since Avalugg can expect to do a lot of switching, removing its vulnerability to Stealth Rock damage is extremely important for its longevity and preservation of Sturdy.

  • Rocky Helmet: Avalugg can punish many physical attackers it switches into with Rocky Helmet chip, slowly wearing them down without having to be offensively involved.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Tera Fairy lets Noivern check opposing Dragon-types while retaining its important resistances to Fighting and Bug. Tera Dragon boosts the power of Draco Meteor significantly. Tera Steel lets Noivern better handle Pokemon like Scizor, Grafaiai, and Lucario.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Investment in defense helps it stomach a hit from Choice Scarf Zarude. Can go max max offensive too.

sets.name: Mixed Wallbreaker
sets.description: Mega Diancie cements itself as an excellent mixed attacker, capable of punching through defensive cores with its superb STAB moves and coverage. Mystical Fire punishes Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor for attempting to switch into and take advantage of it. Alternatively, Earth Power significantly dents or OHKOes Heatran and hits Gholdengo and Clodsire harder.
