Mega Diancie acts as an excellent entry hazard stacker, as it takes advantage of the switches it forces and threatens out common entry hazard removers such as Tornadus-T and Great Tusk. Mega Diancie can use Spikes or Stealth Rock to weaken checks such as Mega Scizor and Heatran, depending on its coverage move, while punishing them for attempting to pivot into it. A Naive nature is preferred, as it allows Mega Diancie to take less damage from common priority moves in Kingambit's Sucker Punch and Mega Lopunny's Fake Out. However, Mega Diancie can also use Hasty in order to sponge Hurricane from Tornadus-T. Mega Diancie fits best on bulky offense and offense teams, which appreciate its early- to mid-game wallbreaking and ability to set entry hazards. Pokemon that appreciate Mega Diancie weakening common Steel-types such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult pair well with it, using their higher Speed tiers to clean late-game. Additionally, Mega Diancie pairs well with Knock Off users like Tornadus-T and Kingambit, as they make Mega Diancie's entry hazards more effective and force checks such as Toxapex and Clodsire to succumb to them. Mega Diancie can struggle with entering the field given its relative frailty and poor defensive typing, which also gives it a tendency to be revenge killed by Pokemon like Mega Swampert and Zamazenta. As such, pivots that can bring it in safely such as Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T make for good partners.

sets.name: Trick Room Sweeper
sets.description: • Diancie is an effective offensive Trick Room setter due to its low Speed and high Attack, allowing it to punch holes in the opposing team. Its high defensive stats make it very difficult to take out in a single attack and demands whittling it down with multiple neutral attacks instead of super effective attacks, out of fear of activating Weakness Policy. • Diamond Storm hits a lot of top threats, notably 2HKOing Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Volcanion. Gaining Defense boosts from it also helps Diancie against physical attackers such as Rillaboom and Palafin. • Body Press synergizes very well with Defense boosts from Diamond Storm, giving Diancie useful coverage to hit foes it would normally have a tough matchup against such as Kingambit and Hisuian Goodra. • Trick Room allows Diancie to support itself and its teammates such as Iron Hands and Torkoal by turning their low Speed into an advantage. Diancie is an effective Trick Room setter as it is hard to remove and, unlike other Trick Room setters such as Cresselia, has the offensive capabilities to make the most of it. • Foes must always be wary of Weakness Policy, as activating it turns Diancie into a fearsome sweeper. As such, Diancie forces opponents to either OHKO it or whittle it down with multiple neutral attacks, as a weak super effective attack into the bulky Diancie will put it in a commanding position. This is especially effective once Diancie has accrued enough Defense boosts, as even Rillaboom's Wood Hammer and Palafin's Wave Crash may not OHKO it anymore. Diancie can also use Mental Herb to guarantee it sets up Trick Room once against Taunt users such as Tornadus and Landorus-T. • Tera Grass allows Diancie to resist the Grass-, Water-, and Ground-type attacks that would otherwise OHKO it before a before a Defense boost such as Rillaboom's Wood Hammer, Palafin's Wave Crash, and Landorus's Earth Power. It also removes Diancie's 4x Steel-type weakness, which helps it matchup better against Steel-type foes like Heatran and Gholdengo and Pokemon with Steel-type coverage such as Iron Hands. Tera Grass also grants Diancie an immunity to powder moves, preventing Amoonguss's Spore from affecting it and circumventing Rage Powder. • Clear Body notably makes Diancie immune to Landorus-T's Intimidate and Grimmsnarl's Parting Shot, allowing Diancie to maintain a constant offensive presence on the field during its valuable Trick Room turns. • A Sassy Nature and maximum HP investment allow Diancie to survive a Steam Eruption from Volcanion. • Diancie enables Trick Room attackers like Kingambit, Torkoal, and Glastrier to sweep alongside it. Diancie wants Fake Out support to help set up Trick Room more easily. Rillaboom is a Fake Out user that can eliminate Palafin and provide Grassy Terrain recovery , while Iron Hands functions better under Trick Room specifically and deals with Volcanion and Kingambit better. Amoonguss also acts as a great partner for Diancie, with its Rage Powder and Spore protecting it from the Ground, Water, and Steel attacks that would threaten it. Pollen Puff also helps to increase its longevity.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description: Mixed Mega Diancie is a powerful wallbreaker that also provides utility with its strong priority. Life Orb-boosted Pixilate Extreme Speed OHKOes fast threats like Pheromosa, Palkia-O, and Mega Mewtwo X, with only the latter requiring slight chip damage to do so. V-create is the strongest coverage option against Steel-types, OHKOing Solgaleo, Ferrothorn, and Mega Scizor, as well as KOing Mega Steelix that has switched into Boomburst. Precipice Blades is a weaker alternative that misses KOs on the aforementioned but instead hits Fire-types like Arceus-Fire and Victini. Rapid Spin can provide entry hazard removal in a pinch. Pain Split is an effective recovery move due to Mega Diancie's low HP to offset Life Orb recoil, and it's also ineffective for Imposter users. Strength Sap is an alternative that is more reliable, but it can be more annoying to Imposter-proof. Mega Diancie has difficulties bypassing certain walls like Ho-Oh and Fur Coat Arceus-Poison, so offensive partners like mixed Mega Mewtwo X and Mega Garchomp synergize well. Knock Off support also is helpful for removing Assault Vest from Pokemon like Primal Kyogre and Mega Steelix to make Boomburst more spammable, and it's also useful against Heavy-Duty Boots Ho-Oh. Mega Diancie can be Imposter-proofed by Ho-Oh, Ice Scales Arceus formes, and, depending on the coverage option, Steel-types not weak to Ground or Fire.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Mega Diancie is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to a strong and fast Pixilate-boosted Boomburst, which can rip through anything that doesn't resist it or have Ice Scales or Assault Vest. Revelation Dance chunks Fire-types like Ho-Oh and Arceus-Fire for heavy damage, invalidating both as checks. Volt Switch helps keep momentum against bulky checks like Primal Kyogre and Arceus-Fairy, giving opportunities to teammates to help whittle them down. The last move is fairly customizable; Extreme Speed picks off faster threats like Pheromosa and weakened Mega Mewtwo X and Palkia-O, while the other moves target Poison- and Steel-types like Arceus-Poison and Mega Steelix. Mega Diancie's main drawback is that it often lacks the raw power to beat special walls like Ice Scales Arceus formes, so supporting allies like Eternatus help wear them down over time. Mega Steelix is a severe thorn in Mega Diancie's side, as it can reliably scout the move it locks into, denies Volt Switch, and can pivot in an offensive teammate; as such, Knock Off support is recommended, as Mega Steelix is 2HKOed by Boomburst without its Assault Vest. Imposter-proof Mega Diancie with Mega Steelix, Chansey, or Fur Coat Arceus-Poison, depending on its last move.

sets.name: Mixed Wallbreaker (Rock)
sets.description: Mega Diancie is the ideal Mega Evolution for Rock teams due to its ability to check Dragon-types like Kommo-o, punish passive Pokemon and entry hazard setters such as Toxapex and Klefki with Magic Bounce, and be a mixed wallbreaker that threatens Great Tusk and Galarian Slowking. Diamond Storm does considerable damage to special walls like Blissey and Alolan Muk and can also provide a Defense boost. Psychic heavily damages Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Nidoking, which eases the matchup against Poison teams. Earth Power deals heavy damage to Steel-type Pokemon like Heatran and Iron Treads and is paired nicely with Mystical Fire to damage Skarmory and Corviknight. On a hyper offensive team, Mega Diancie runs four attacks for coverage. With Shuckle's Sticky Web up, its good Speed tier becomes more devastating and outspeeds Pokemon like Mega Gallade and Zeraora. Mega Diancie also pairs well with Omastar and Terrakion, as Omastar takes care of the Ground matchup with a well-timed Shell Smash, while Terrakion's access to Earthquake and Close Combat takes care of most Steel-types. On bulky offense, Mega Diancie prefers to run Spikes, as the chip damage sets up a potential late-game cleanup from more offensive Pokemon on the team like Terrakion and Nihilego. Garganacl pairs well with Spikes, as Salt Cure forces a lot of Pokemon to switch out and take additional chip damage.

sets.name: Mixed Wallbreaker (Fairy)
sets.description: Mega Diancie is a valuable asset to Fairy teams, featuring Magic Bounce to deflect entry hazards and status, wide coverage, and strong offensive capabilities with its high Speed. Diamond Storm often increases Mega Diancie's bulk and threatens foes like Enamorus and Mega Charizard Y. Moonblast handles threats like Mega Sableye and Latias. Earth Power can be used to counter Steel teams, OHKOing Heatran, Excadrill, and Magnezone, while dealing heavy damage to the likes of Skeledirge and Garganacl. Mystical Fire targets Steel-types that don't mind Earth Power, such as Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Scizor under Psychic Terrain. Alternatively, Mega Diancie can run Nature Power and use the various terrains set by its teammates to expand its wallbreaking abilities. Stealth Rock can be used to allow Mega Diancie to set its own hazard, but four attacks are recommended given Mega Diancie's wide coverage. Klefki provides Spikes and dual screens support which allows Mega Diancie to OHKO threats like Gholdengo, and it can also carry Thunder Wave to let Mega Diancie outspeed and take out threats like Mega Gallade and Mega Aerodactyl. Tapu Koko takes on Water-types and aids in the Steel matchup by forcing out Corviknight and Celesteela. Tapu Bulu counters Ground- and Water-types like Great Tusk and Urshifu-R, while Tapu Lele takes on Poison-types and prevents priority moves from Azumarill and Mega Scizor. Iron Valiant is a great partner for the Steel matchup, but it also benefits from Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain to outspeed and take out faster threats such as Zeraora and Greninja. All of these teammates appreciate Mega Diancie's ability to bounce hazards back to the opponent, as Fairy teams do not possess entry hazard removal.

sets.name: Special Wallbreaker
sets.description: Hoopa is a passable wallbreaker that fits on offensive teams, particularly when paired with Sticky Web support from Masquerain and Spidops and teammates that can pivot it in safely. Psyshock allows Hoopa to hit special walls like Blissey on their weaker physical bulk, while Knock Off cripples RegenVest users like Alolan Muk and Meloetta that can otherwise take a hit and threaten a KO or pivot out to a faster offensive threat like Chien-Pao. Focus Blast 2HKOes Hisuian Goodra and KOes Kingambit that would attempt to switch in. Defensive pivots that can take a hit and pivot out like Corviknight and Meloetta can get Hoopa in safely. Dual screens setters like Prankster Corviknight and Mew also make for a good partner, as they allow Hoopa to have an easier time setting up with Nasty Plot or tank a hit in a pinch and retaliate. Offensive pivots like Slither Wing and Galarian Zapdos pair well with Hoopa with their ability to bait in and pivot out on checks like Corviknight and defensive Zapdos, allowing Hoopa to set up and threaten a KO; faster offensive threats like Chien-Pao and Barraskewda also pair well with it by making up for its lackluster Speed while Hoopa threatens out their checks like defensive Quaquaval.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Hoopa-U is an extremely strong physical wallbreaker that can be very threatening to more balanced and defensive teams due to its massive Attack stat and reliable STAB move in Hyperspace Fury, which is capable of impressive feats such as 2HKOing physically defensive Corviknight and Toxapex the majority of the time and always 2HKOing physically defensive Rotom-W. Zen Headbutt is a nice complementary STAB move, allowing Hoopa-U to smack prominent Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant that may try to switch in on a predicted Hyperspace Fury. Drain Punch hits Dark-types like Kingambit and Ting-Lu, while Gunk Shot offers coverage against Fairy-types like Enamorus and Azumarill, as well as Tera Fairy Moltres, Garganacl, Kingambit, and Baxcalibur. A Jolly nature allows Hoopa-U to outspeed Pokemon like Timid Heatran, Modest Gholdengo, and Timid Volcanion, while an Adamant nature allows Hoopa-U to hit even harder, 2HKOing Garganacl the majority of the time. Tera Dark boosts the power of Hyperspace Fury even further, 2HKOing physically defensive Dondozo; Tera Dark also offers the additional benefit of making Hoopa-U resist other Dark-type attacks, which can be crucial against Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Hoopa-U fits well on bulky offense teams that are in need of a physical wallbreaker. Physical setup sweepers like Kingambit, Baxcalibur, and Dragonite appreciate Hoopa-U's presence on a team, as Hoopa-U is able to break through or dent physically defensive Pokemon that could stand in their way, like Dondozo, Great Tusk, and Rotom-W. One of Hoopa-U's biggest challenges is safely getting on the field due to its frail physical defense and quadruple weakness to U-turn, so it pairs well with pivots such as Chilly Reception Galarian Slowking, U-turn Dragapult, and Volt Switch Zapdos. Hoopa-U is also held back by its middling Speed, which tends to exacerbate Hoopa-U's physical frailty, so it appreciates paralysis support from partners like Rotom-W and Substitute Dragapult. Static Zapdos is a particularly notable partner for Hoopa-U, because it is able to switch in and potentially paralyze faster Pokemon like Cinderace and Dragapult, rendering those Pokemon no longer threatening to Hoopa-U. Pokemon that can set entry hazards like Ting-Lu, Heatran, and Landorus-T help facilitate with Hoopa-U breaking through its switch-ins. Opposing physical Dark-types, such as Kingambit, Hisuian Samurott, and Roaring Moon, typically force Hoopa-U out, especially after a Defense drop. For this reason, sturdy Dark-resistant teammates like Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Low Kick Kingambit synergize well with Hoopa-U, while those Pokemon also appreciate Hoopa-U punching holes in the opposing team's defensive backbone.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Hoopa-U is an incredibly threatening special wallbreaker, especially to slower and more defensive teams, that is able to OHKO the majority of the tier and 2HKO essentially every other relevant Pokemon. This is thanks to Hoopa-U's astronomically high Special Attack stat and potent dual STAB combination. Focus Blast rounds out its coverage, allowing Hoopa-U to hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Hisuian Samurott; Focus Blast also OHKOes specially defensive Heatran after entry hazard chip. Trick can be run in the fourth slot to cripple the few special walls that Hoopa-U is unable to reliably blast through, like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Alolan Muk, while also affording Hoopa-U the ability to switch moves, alleviating the need for prediction in exchange for less immediate power. Alternatively, Thunderbolt can be used instead as Hoopa-U's best option to hit Corviknight and Galarian Moltres while also providing a more reliable option than Focus Blast to OHKO Hisuian Samurott and Greninja. A Timid nature makes Hoopa-U faster than Pokemon like Timid Heatran, Modest Gholdengo, and Timid Volcanion, while a Modest nature gives Hoopa-U even more breaking power so that it is able to potentially 2HKO Blissey and Alolan Muk with Focus Blast after entry hazard damage. Tera Dark increases the power of Dark Pulse, giving it an opportunity to 2HKO Scream Tail and specially defensive Heatran while also threatening to OHKO Baxcalibur, bulky Cinderace, and defensive Landorus-T. Tera Dark also makes Hoopa-U resist Dark-type attacks, which can prevent Kingambit from answering it with Sucker Punch. Quick special attackers like Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Enamorus make good teammates, as they appreciate Hoopa-U's ability to break through even the bulkiest of specially defensive walls. One of Hoopa-U's biggest flaws is that its physical frailty and crippling 4x weakness to U-turn can make it difficult for it to safely be brought onto the field. As a result, Hoopa-U greatly benefits from being paired alongside pivots that can facilitate its entry, like Galarian Slowking with Chilly Reception; Landorus-T, Dragapult, and Sneasler with U-turn; and Rotom-W and Zapdos with Volt Switch. Paralysis support from Thunder Wave users like Rotom-W, Substitute Dragapult, and defensive Gholdengo can help alleviate Hoopa-U's lackluster Speed and make previously faster threats easy targets. Static Zapdos synergizes particularly well with Hoopa-U in this regard, since Zapdos can punish U-turns directed at Hoopa-U from faster Pokemon like Cinderace, Sneasler, and Meowscarada to potentially paralyze them. Hoopa-U also appreciates the inclusion of hazard setters like Hisuian Samurott, Ting-Lu, Landorus-T, and Heatran, allowing it to punch holes in defensive backbones more easily and damage the opposing team thanks to the switches it forces. Some of the most difficult Pokemon for Hoopa-U to handle are opposing Dark-types like Kingambit, Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, and Hisuian Samurott because they can force Hoopa-U to rely on Focus Blast and good prediction to break through. To help mitigate this issue, Pokemon that can reliably switch into Dark-types like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Azumarill also make good partners for Hoopa-U, and in return they appreciate Choice Specs Hoopa-U's ability to threaten physical walls as well. Bulk Up Great Tusk and Belly Drum Azumarill can also clean up late-game after Hoopa-U wears down the opposing team.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Equipping Hoopa-U with an Assault Vest makes the most of its excellent coverage and surprisingly high special bulk, letting it trade with various special attackers like Dragapult and Walking Wake. Strong Knock Off is a large reason to use this set, as it is an excellent progress maker, particularly against bulkier teams. Psychic is run over Zen Headbutt for its higher accuracy and better damage against physically defensive Pokemon like Zapdos and Great Tusk. Drain Punch provides Hoopa-U with adequate recovery and logevity, and it is largely used to hit Kingambit and other Dark-types, which otherwise walls this set. Gunk Shot provides important coverage for Fairy-types like Enamorus and Tera Fairy foes like Garganacl while potentially poisoning checks like Ting Lu. Tera Poison not only empowers its Gunk Shot but also gives it a crucial Fairy and U-turn resistance. 248 HP and 40 Defense investment with a Lonely Nature allows Hoopa-U to survive one Sucker Punch from Adamant Kingambit with a maximum Supreme Overlord boost and gives it an easier time against weaker physical attacks from Pokemon like Garganacl and Clodsire. Meanwhile, 84 SpA EVs give Hoopa-U a guaranteed OHKO on Iron Moth with Psychic and 92 Speed EVs allow it to outspeed Jolly Kingambit. Hoopa-U is best utilized on bulky offense teams that can support a slow, powerful wallbreaker like it while still appreciating its ability to trade hits with common special attackers. It is incredibly physically frail, so pairing it with physically bulky Pokemon like Garganacl and Great Tusk is a good idea, as it will often be forced out by physical attackers. Additionally, pivot support from Cinderace and Zapdos can put Hoopa-U in favorable positions to dish out damage with its strong attacks, something that is necessary given its aforementioned physical frailty. Because Hoopa-U often makes great progress with Knock Off, entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Landorus-T are great teammate options. Hoopa-U excels at punching holes in the opposition, so faster offensive teammates like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Enamorus are good ideas to take advantage of the resultant weakened foes. Teammates like Amoonguss and Galarian Slowking also deserve consideration for checking Iron Valiant and Enamorus without having to expend Terastallization.

sets.name: Choice Band (Psychic)
sets.description:
Hoopa-U is one of Psychic's best physical wallbreakers. Its strong offensive STAB combination coupled with great coverage allows it to muscle through bulky Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Toxapex, Iron Hands, and Amoonguss, and with its great special bulk, it can prove useful against Ghost teams. Drain Punch grants Hoopa-U super effective coverage against Dark- and Steel-types such as Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. Brick Break can also be run as Hoopa-U's Fighting-type move, as this allows it to remove dual screens set by Fairy- and Dark-type teams. Trick is a great option for Hoopa-U to hinder Pokemon that can take a hit like Sableye and Klefki, as well as potentially disrupt Pokemon reliant on their items such as Moltres. Gunk Shot is another great option, as it allows Hoopa-U to threaten Fairy-types like Azumarill and to OHKO Hatterene. By investing 8 EVs in Special Defense, Hoopa-U can live a Moonblast from Choice Scarf Flutter Mane.

Azelf and Scream Tail make for great partners, as they can set up entry hazards for Hoopa-U to be able to wallbreak more easily. Azelf can also run Taunt to prevent Defog users like Corviknight removing its hazards, while Scream Tail can also set up dual screens for both Hoopa-U and its teammates and provide Wish support. Because of Hoopa-U's lack of longevity outside of Wish, it can get easily worn down by hazards. Hence, Hatterene is a great partner, as it is able to provide great hazard control for Psychic teams through Magic Bounce. Galarian Slowking is another great partner for Hoopa-U, as it provides Hoopa-U a switch-in to Fairy-types and aids Hoopa-U's wallbreaking through Future Sight. Galarian Slowking can also set up Toxic Spikes to annoy Hoopa-U's switch-ins such as Azumarill, and its Poison typing allows it to remove Toxic Spikes to prevent Hoopa-U from getting worn down by poison. Indeedee is another great addition to Psychic teams, as its Normal typing grants it an immunity to Ghost. Aside from this, Indeedee can set up Psychic Terrain to allow Hoopa-U to threaten Kingambit with Drain Punch without fearing Sucker Punch. Lastly, late-game sweepers such as Gallade and Armarouge appreciate Hoopa-U beating their checks such as Azumarill for the former and Galarian Slowking for the latter. Lastly, Espathra appreciates Hoopa-U breaking through its checks such as Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Sableye so it can set up and sweep late-game.

sets.name: Choice Band (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Psychic)
sets.description:
Ice Punch OHKOes Landorus while Drain Punch OHKOes Chien-Pao.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Substitute (Psychic)
sets.description:
Outspeeds Kingambit.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Hoopa-U is a strong physical wallbreaker that threatens slower teams thanks to its massive Attack stat and spammable STAB move in Hyperspace Fury. That said, Hoopa-U competes with Kingambit, which has significantly higher bulk and a way to bypass its Speed tier issue in Sucker Punch. Hoopa-U has a 4x weakness to U-turn and neutrality to Pursuit, meaning it cannot enter or leave the field easily. Nonetheless, Hoopa-U does not require setup, and it therefore has a niche into bulkier teams thanks to its immediate power. Drain Punch lets Hoopa-U take on Dark-types that would otherwise wall it, such as Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, and Zen Headbutt hammers Zamazenta, Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Toxapex while also hitting Clefable and Tera Fairy Garganacl neutrally. Gunk Shot provides Hoopa-U with another way to break through Fairy-types such as Tera Fairy Garganacl and Clefable. Tera Dark powers up Hoopa-U's Hyperspace Fury while giving it a resistance to Pursuit. Hoopa-U fits well on bulky offense teams, which appreciate its power allowing teammates to clean. As such, partners such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele pair well with Hoopa-U. The former three also check Kingambit, making Hoopa-U less prediction reliant with its attacks, while the latter appreciates Hoopa-U being able to wear down Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Kingambit. Hoopa-U also has trouble getting into the field due to its low Speed and frail physical bulk, so pivots such as Mega Scizor and Rotom-W are appreciated to bring it in Hoopa-U more consistently. Rotom-W also pivots into Toxapex and Heatran to bring in Hoopa-U, while Mega Scizor pivots into Tapu Lele and Kingambit and brings in Heatran and Skeledirge for Hoopa-U to break through. Entry hazard setters are also appreciated, as Hoopa-U can more easily break through defensive teams with Spikes or Stealth Rock on the field. Thus, partners such as Ferrothorn and Garchomp are appreciated.

sets.name: Utility Wallbreaker
sets.description: Volcanion's high Special Attack and great offensive typing make it an excellent wallbreaker with solid defensive utility thanks to Water Absorb. Good coverage options as well as a powerful STAB move that can burn its foes make it very difficult to switch into. Earth Power is crucial for hitting Toxapex, which easily switches into both of Volcanion's STAB moves; it also hits Galarian Slowking harder, notably guaranteeing a 2HKO on physically defensive variants. Taunt is useful against bulkier Pokemon, preventing Dondozo or Toxapex from using healing moves and Galarian Slowking from using Thunder Wave. Substitute eases prediction, as Volcanion can force switches, and it takes advantage of certain Pokemon that fail to break the Substitute such as bulky Cinderace and non-Assault Vest Toxapex while still avoiding status attempts from the aforementioned walls. It also allows Volcanion to avoid Sucker Punch from Kingambit. Tera Blast alongside Tera Fairy can be used to hit Pokemon such as Dragapult, Walking Wake, and Hisuian Samurott. Becoming a Fairy-type offers useful defensive utility, giving it an immunity to both of Walking Wake's STAB moves and a resistance to Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Alternatively, Tera Ground can be used to grant Volcanion an Electric immunity, improving its matching against Zapdows and Rotom-W, while also boosting Earth Power's damage. Both Tera types also neutralize its weakness to Earthquake from Pokemon like Landorus-T and Great Tusk. 140 Speed EVs are used to outspeed uninvested Great Tusk. Volcanion fits on bulky offense teams that appreciate a strong wallbreaker. Entry hazards, especially Spikes, make Volcanion much harder to deal with. Therefore, hazard setters including Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, Hisuian Samurott, and Landorus-T make good partners. Ting-Lu can also switch into special attackers like Dragapult and Zapdos for Volcanion. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Galarian Slowking cause problems for Volcanion, so teammates that can help overwhelm them such as Nasty Plot Gholdengo and Utility Dragapult are also useful. Finally, Swords Dance Iron Valiant and Kingambit can clean late-game once Volcanion has worn down the opposing team, and they also pressure the aforementioned specially defensive Pokemon. Kingambit in particular appreciates Volcanion's ability to deal with Fire-types like Cinderace and Moltres, and especially its immunity to Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Volcanion is a wallbreaker with absurd strength thanks to its sky high Special Attack and amazing high-Base Power moves, allowing it to make progress every time it is in. Steam Eruption is Volcanion's most spammable move and has very limited switch-ins, as many Pokemon that resist both of Volcanion's STAB moves like Dragapult, Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and Hisuian Samurott end up getting 2HKOed or burned. Fire Blast is Volcanion's best move for Grass-types such as Meowscarada, Amoonguss, and Tera Grass Galarian Slowking. Earth Power helps immensely with Toxapex, Water Absorb Clodsire, and Assault Vest Galarian Slowking. Sludge Bomb hits Azumarill and Tera Grass Heatran while crippling foes like Rotom-W more than burn, while Tera Blast Fairy can hit many Dragon types such as Dragapult, Walking Wake, Dragonite, and Roaring Moon as well as Pokemon like Assault Vest Hisuian Samurott. Tera Fairy also makes Volcanion immune to Dragon-type moves, negating both of Walking Wake's STAB types, and removes all of Volcanion's weaknesses, particularly to Ground-type attacks such as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu and Landorus-T's Earthquake. Tera Fairy also allows Volcanion to resist Kingambit's Sucker Punch, making it a great revenge killing option. Tera Water and Tera Fire make Steam Eruption and Fire Blast even stronger, allowing Volcanion to muscle through Assault Vest Galarian Slowking and even 2HKO physically defensive Toxapex. Its main counters are Tera Water Galarian Slowking and Water Absorb or Tera Water Clodsire, alongside Blissey. Volcanion appreciates support from wallbreakers that can deal with these threats or wear them down, such as Black Glasses Kingambit and mixed Iron Valiant. Kingambit in particular loves Choice Specs Volcanion's matchup against Fire-types like Cinderace, Moltres, and Heatran. In turn, Kingambit has a good matchup versus the aforementioned counters and can help pressure other checks such as Toxapex. Dragapult can also be a great partner, as it provides pivoting and speed control along with adding pressure on said counters and checks and has the option to provide great support with Thunder Wave. Great Tusk is another great option, as it can provide hazard removal, which is crucial for Volcanion. It is also a great blanket check for physical attackers that threaten Volcanion, and it provides Knock Off support, making it one of the best defensive partners for Volcanion. Volcanion also fits great on VoltTurn teams, as it loves being brought in as many times as possible by Pokemon such as Cinderace, Dragapult, and Rotom-W.

sets.name: Water Absorb (Fire)
sets.description:
Volcanion is a useful Pokemon on Fire teams mainly thanks to its ability, Water Absorb, offering the type an immunity to one of its most common weaknesses. Steam Eruption is Volcanion's preferred Water-type move, with it being able to burn its switch-ins like Alolan Muk, Hisuian Goodra, and Iron Hands, reducing their overall longevity. Earth Power allows Volcanion to threaten opposing Volcanion, Toxapex, and Heatran. Sludge Bomb allows Volcanion to revenge kill Azumarill after a Belly Drum and threaten other Fairy-type Pokemon like Hatterene and Enamorus. It is also able to target Walking Wake and Rotom-W, which resist Volcanion's STAB attacks, potentially crippling them thanks to the 30% poison chance. Flamethrower is preferred over Fire Blast since it doesn't miss, and the reduced damage is not too significant if Volcanion is under sun, but Fire Blast can be used in order to 2HKO Hisuian Goodra under sun. 96 Speed EVs let Volcanion outspeed Adamant Azumarill in order to revenge kill it with Sludge Bomb, and the rest of the EVs are put in HP to improve Volcanion's overall bulk.

Torkoal is a solid partner for Volcanion that assists it with Stealth Rock support, chipping down its switch-ins like Rotom-W and Alolan Muk and working well in conjunction with Steam Eruption's burn chance. Torkoal can also use Rapid Spin to clear away entry hazards for Volcanion if its Heavy-Duty Boots get removed by Alolan Muk or Meowscarada. Furthermore, Torkoal provides Volcanion with sun thanks to Drought, which boosts Volcanion's Fire-type attacks. In return, Volcanion can switch into Water attacks from Barraskewda and Pelipper, which threaten Torkoal. Scovillain helps out Volcanion by threatening Water-immune Pokemon like Clodsire and Gastrodon, and its damage onto the former allows Volcanion to revenge kill it and proceed to threaten slower Ground-types like Quagsire and Ting-Lu. Cinderace is able to threaten Hisuian Goodra with Libero High Jump Kick, whose Assault Vest set easily shrugs off Earth Power from Volcanion and chips it down with Draco Meteor. Cinderace can also steal dual screens from Klefki with Court Change in the Fairy matchup, which supplement Volcanion's naturally good bulk, letting it take hits better. In return, Volcanion offers an answer to Belly Drum Azumarill and threatens Cinderace's defensive answers like Toxapex and Skeledirge. Choice Scarf Hisuian Arcanine offers a solution to handle opposing Dragon-types like Baxcalibur, which can use Volcanion as setup fodder, and also threatens Dragapult and non-Choice Scarf Hydreigon. Rotom-Heat provides an invaluable Ground immunity for Volcanion to avoid Earthquake from Pokemon like Iron Hands, Iron Treads, and Landorus-T and threatens all 3 of them with a burn from Will-O-Wisp. Rotom-H is also able to threaten defensive Water-types like Toxapex and offensive Water-types like Hisuian Samurott and Quaquaval if it opts for a Choice Scarf. Heatran can help Volcanion deal with Poison teams with its stallbreaker set, which allows it to trap and beat Pokemon like Toxapex one-on-one. Choice Scarf Iron Moth can revenge kill weakened Dragon-types like Walking Wake and Baxcalibur.

sets.name: Wallbreaker (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: A Quiet Nature instead of a Modest Nature allows Volcanion to OHKO Flutter Mane without bulk investment with Heavy Slam.

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Primordial Sea Volcanion excels as a fantastic wallbreaker with its great Special Attack and offensive typing. Rain-boosted Steam Eruption combined with Choice Specs allows Volcanion to 2HKO most Pokemon in tier, including most specially defensive walls such as RegenVest Garchomp, Meloetta, and Alolan Muk. Weather Ball dissuades promient Desolate Land users that might want to switch in to Volcanion such as Cinderace and Iron Moth. Earth Power is a more reliable way to deal with Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Heatran, and it's a reliable way to hit Hisuian Goodra without missing. Focus Blast 2HKOes a would-be check in RegenVest Roaring Moon, as well as Hisuian Goodra after Spikes chip. Volcanion pairs well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Garchomp, which help wear down common RegenVest Pokemon like Goodra and Hisuian Goodra, and hazards also guarantee a 2HKO on Meloetta. Due to Volcanion's Stealth Rock weakness it pairs well with hazard removers like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also help pivot it in safely. Volcanion also pairs well with offensive pivots like Zapdos and Roaring Moon, which can help bring it in on targets like Corviknight.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Volcanion serves as a great mixed wallbreaker with a typing that also offers defensive utility. Flare Blitz is notably able to 2HKO RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, and Steam Eruption's burn chance deters would-be switch-ins like defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Earth Power reliably threatens Toxapex and Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Skeledirge, and Cinderace. Taunt can be used to hinder defensive walls with recovery such as Scream Tail and Quaquaval, while Will-O-Wisp is able to reliably burn switch-ins like defensive Quaquaval and Garchomp. Flame Charge is also a niche option to outspeed common revenge killers to Volcanion like Zapdos, Hisuian Arcanine, and Choice Band Galarian Zapdos. Magic Guard helps Volcanion with its weakness to entry hazards while also negating recoil from Flare Blitz and Life Orb. Offensive pivots such as Slither Wing and Iron Moth can bring Volcanion in against defensive cores featuring staples like Intimidate Corviknight and RegenVest users. Fast late-game cleaners like Chien-Pao and Regieleki also appreciate Volcanion's ability to weaken defensive checks like Quaquaval and common RegenVest users, which can allow them to take over games, while also providing speed control against faster threats to Volcanion like Zapdos, Hisuian Electrode, and Roaring Moon. Volcanion's susceptibility to being revenge killed by aformetioned threats makes defensive partners such as Corviknight and Meloetta essential, as they can tank hits and also help pivot to bring in Volcanion safely. Despite being immune to hazards, Volcanion still lacks recovery, so a teammate that can grant it longevity like Wish Scream Tail is also appreciated.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Crabrawler is a fantastic bulky attacker that checks dangerous threats such as Hisuian Growlithe and Toedscool, and can sweep teams with Bulk Up. Coverage moves such as Ice Punch, Thunder Punch, and Earthquake offer Crabrawler extreme flexibility in the threats it needs to cover. Ice Punch hits Foongus, Wattrel, and Toedscool, while Thunder Punch hits Mareanie, Wingull, and Quaxly; both options also hit Drifloon super effectively. Earthquake allows Crabrawler to hit Mareanie and Fuecoco and is its strongest neutral option against Hisuian Zorua. Tera Fire makes Crabrawler immune to burns, while Tera Electric makes Thunder Punch stronger against Water-types and gives it defensive utility against threats like Hisuian Voltorb and Wingull. Crabrawler hates dealing with opposing Ghost-types such as Hisuian Zorua, Greavard, and Drifloon, as well as Gothita. Hisuian Growlithe checks these threats and makes an excellent teammate for Crabrawler, as do Ghost-types such as Hisuian Zorua and Drifloon that benefit from the removal of opposing Pawniard.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
With Assault Vest bolstering its naturally good bulk, Crabominable becomes a solid tank that forces advantageous trades against several Pokemon, including Rotom-F, Alolan Persian, and even Charizard if need be. Thanks to Iron Fist and its strong STAB moves, Crabominable excels at pressuring walls like Misdreavus on the switch, Gogoat, and Whiscash, which can make it awkward for balance teams to play around. Earthquake hits Skuntank without triggering Aftermath and, after some chip damage, 2HKOes specially defensive Carbink, physically defensive Tinkatuff, and Mareanie. Close Combat is a secondary Fighting STAB option that's stronger than Drain Punch, but Thunder Punch is more reliable against Flying-types than Ice Hammer due to its higher accuracy. 60 Speed EVs allow Crabominable to outrun uninvested base 50s like Perrserker, Chansey, and Carbink. Tera Water helps against Fire-, Water-, and Steel-types like Pyroar, Basculin, and Alolan Dugtrio, all of which can otherwise overwhelm Crabominable. Tera Electric lets Crabominable take Electric-, Flying-, and Steel-type attacks from Pokemon like Rotom-F, Honchkrow, and Tera Steel Alolan Persian and is best used with Thunder Punch. Tera Ground gives Crabominable an Electric immunity, notably letting it block Volt Switch, and secures the OHKO on Skuntank with Earthquake. On teams with entry hazard control, Tera Fire can be considered to let Crabominable absorb Will-O-Wisp and thus more easily handle Misdreavus as well as Fire-types like Pyroar.

Crabominable's main flaw is that its poor longevity can limit its ability to repeatedly handle special attackers; this is made worse with Crabominable being vulnerable to all hazards and tending to attack last. Entry hazard removers like Dartrix and Komala can give Crabominable an easier time switching in, with the latter not removing any hazards set by Crabominable's team. Wish support from the likes of Dachsbun and Leafeon is another way to keep Crabominable healthy, with the former also absorbing Fire-type moves from Pokemon like Misdreavus and Charizard. In return, Crabominable pressures Ice- and Steel-types like Rotom-F and Perrserker. Healing Wish Indeedee-F can similarly give Crabominable another chance to sponge hits or break if it gets worn down too quickly. Physical walls like Alolan Persian and Misdreavus can form a good defensive core with Crabominable and facilitate wallbreaking through moves like Parting Shot, Thunder Wave, and Will-O-Wisp. Fast Pokemon like Electrode, Dugtrio, and Choice Scarf Indeedee-F are good at compensating for Crabominable's bad matchup against offense and benefit from its ability to both tear through balance cores and trade with revenge killers like Choice Scarf Rotom-F. Fire- and Dark-types like Charizard and Skuntank can more reliably pressure Misdreavus for Crabominable and appreciate it wearing down bulky foes like Whiscash, Carbink, and Hisuian Sliggoo.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Lycanroc-N makes for a fantastic cleaner and wallbreaker with No Guard + STAB Stone Edge and great coverage. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio and Normal-types like Zangoose and Sawsbuck. Rock Blast is a great way of getting around Substitute from the likes of Articuno and Rotom-F while preventing Focus Sash Masquerain from setting up Sticky Web. Play Rough hits Gabite, which makes for an otherwise great Lycanroc-N check, while Iron Head nails Carbink. With a Choice Scarf, Lycanroc-N outspeeds threats like Alolan Persian and Pyroar. Tera Rock and Tera Fighting both boost Lycanroc-N's most spammable moves. Tera Fighting also allows Lycanroc-N to resist Sucker Punch from the likes of Honchkrow and Skuntank.

Lycanroc-N is checked by Pokemon that resist Rock like Gabite, Tinkatuff, and Whiscash, so Pokemon that can weaken these checks like Zangoose and Basculin make for great offensive partners. As a Choice Scarf cleaner, Lycanroc-N appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Whiscash and Carbink to more easily put foes in range of its moves. When locked into an undesirable move, Lycanroc-N appreciates defensive teammates to fall back on like Articuno and Perrserker, which can also provide momentum with U-turn for Lycanroc-N to safely hit the field.

sets.name: Choice Band (Rock)
sets.description:
Lycanroc-D is a great choice for Rock teams thanks to its offensive presence and good Speed tier, which allows it to outspeed and get rid of threats like Urshifu-R, Walking Wake, and Iron Treads. An excellent ability combined with a STAB priority move in Accelerock allows Lycanroc-D to revenge kill foes that greatly threaten Rock teams like Chien-Pao, Belly Drum Azumarill, and Shell Smash Cloyster. With Choice Band, Stone Edge 2HKOes Corviknight. Close Combat deals with Normal-, Rock-, Dark- and Steel-types like Ursaluna, Tyranitar, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Hisuian Goodra. Psychic Fangs not only breaks screens in the Fairy matchup, but it also deals with Fighting- and Poison-types like Urshifu-R, Great Tusk, Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Clodsire. Play Rough is another option to deal with Dragon- and Dark- types like Walking Wake, Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Sableye.

Garganacl pairs well with Lycanroc-D, as Salt Cure wears down defensive Pokemon Lycanroc-D struggles with such as Quagsire and Corviknight. In return, Garganacl benefits from Lycanroc-D's ability to remove wallbreakers such as Walking Wake and Urshifu-R which threaten Garganacl's Iron Defense + Body Press set. Tyranitar is an essential teammate as it sets up sand to further chip down walls and checks threats like Flutter Mane, Espathra, and Kingambit due to its sheer bulk and great coverage in Heavy Slam, Crunch, and Low Kick. Hisuian Arcanine's wallbreaking power covers walls that are harder for Lycanroc-D to take down, dealing with Toxapex and Corviknight with Head Smash and Flare Blitz, respectively. Kleavor is a great lead, as Stone Axe sets up Stealth Rock to break through any opposing Focus Sash, allowing Lycanroc-D and Hisuian Arcanine to clean teams more easily. It can also pivot into Lycanroc-D with U-turn, luring in foes like Toxapex, Iron Treads, and Heatran in the process. Choice item Glimmora's colorful moveset helps against walls like Quagsire and Toxapex through the use of Energy Ball and Earth Power, with Choice Scarf allowing Glimmora to outspeed and take down fast offensive threats such as Iron Valiant and Greninja if they aren't running Choice Scarf. Coalossal removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin, checks Scizor, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit with Flamethrower and Body Press, and can burn threats with Flame Body. Iron Defense + Calm Mind Diancie can check Garchomp with Moonblast. Shell Smash Air Balloon Drednaw provides a temporary Ground-type immunity and appreciates defensive walls being worn down by Lycanroc-D. In return, it readily cleans weakened Flying and Ground teams, eliminating threats like Landorus-T and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Mareanie is one of the top walls in Little Cup, capable of checking threats such as Hisuian Growlithe, Crabrawler, and Shellder. Haze shuts down dangerous set-up sweepers like Crabrawler and Swords Dance Pawniard, while Ice Beam hits Toedscool and Foongus. Mareanie has some other viable options for its fourth moveslot; Toxic Spikes wears down foes like Toedscool and synergizes with partners like Hex Hisuian Zorua, and Iron Defense turns Mareanie into a defensive wincon. Tera Ghost lets Mareanie excape Gothita's Shadow Tag while letting it take neutral damage from Crabrawler's coverage. Grass-types like Toedscool and Foongus are great partners that can switch into foes like Hisuian Voltorb and Mudbray; Foongus forms a potent Regenerator core with Mareanie as well.

sets.name: The Pex
sets.description:
With a valuable defensive profile and remarkable longevity, Toxapex cements itself as a very sturdy mixed wall and defensive pivot. It can switch into and counter Pokemon like Cinderace and Greninja, scout for Choice item users like Dragapult, Breloom, and Iron Valiant, and absorb Toxic Spikes from Glimmora and opposing Toxapex. Surf forces damage onto Toxic-immune foes such as Gholdengo, Garganacl, Iron Moth, and Kingambit. Toxic shuts down Pokemon such as Dragonite, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W, and if Toxapex should run Toxic Spikes, it matches up well against offensive teams that contain setup sweepers such as Roaring Moon, Iron Valiant, and Great Tusk. Any attempts of boosting past Toxapex gets shut down easily by Haze, which combined with poison damage prevents Toxapex from being used as setup fodder by Pokemon such as Calm Mind Hatterene. Covert Cloak is an option to ignore Garganacl's Salt Cure, Dragapult and Gholdengo's Shadow Ball drops, and Greninja's Dark Pulse flinches, but Leftovers's longevity reduces Toxapex's reliance on Recover, and it is used over Black Sludge in case Toxapex decides to Terastallize. Tera Steel improves Toxapex's matchup against non-Earthquake Roaring Moon and Meowscarada while still maintaining an immunity to poison. Alternatively, Tera Fairy fares better against Dragapult, Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Choice Band Roaring Moon. The given EVs allow Toxapex to survive two Choice Band Meowscarada's Flower Trick from full health.

Toxapex fits nicely on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate a sturdy defensive backbone. Teammates like Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl are terrific defensive partners that covers Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Tera Electric Iron Valiant, respectively. Corviknight and Great Tusk in particular provide a backup check to multiple combinations of physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Kingambit that attempt to overwhelm Toxapex. They also remove entry hazards, which would mitigate Toxapex's Regenerator and force it to use Recover more often; in return, Toxapex covers Pokemon such as Cinderace for the former and Greninja for the latter. Bulky setup sweepers like Garganacl, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo can take advantage of Toxic Spikes slowly chipping down checks such as Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk. Particularly, Skeledirge and Gholdengo can make use of Hex easily to take advantage of Toxapex spreading poison, as well as threaten Hatterene, which can block Toxapex's Toxic Spikes and use non-Haze variants as setup fodder. Offensive partners like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Kingambit compensate for Toxapex's overall passivity; in return, they appreciate Toxapex switching into their revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo, Scizor, and Iron Valiant, respectively.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Assault Vest allows Toxapex to maximize its Special Attack EVs, letting it turn the tables on offensive Pokemon looking to exploit its passivity with Taunt or Substitute, while retaining excellent special bulk to check threats such as Choice Specs Dragapult, Walking Wake, Iron Moth, and Iron Valiant. Surf does a solid chunk of damage to common Toxapex switch-ins like Kingambit, physically defensive Corviknight, and Gholdengo and often 2HKOes Garganacl after Stealth Rock. Sludge Bomb has good coverage alongside it, dealing heavy damage to Fairy-types like Iron Valiant, Hatterene, and Azumarill while breaking Hydreigon's Substitute. Sludge Bomb's high chance to poison can be critical for crippling Rotom-W and Slowking in the long term. Infestation provides a nice source of chip damage while letting Toxapex trap and beat defensive threats, such as Amoonguss, Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Clodsire, in conjunction with Acid Spray. Furthermore, Infestation prevents the opponent from double switching on Toxapex, enabling much safer plays. Instead of Acid Spray, Ice Beam works to offer more immediate damage against Clodsire, Dragonite, Dragapult, and Amoonguss. Tera Blast, with Tera Fighting, is also viable to nab surprise KOs on Kingambit and Roaring Moon, which might otherwise set up on it. However, Fairy is the most standard Tera type for Toxapex, allowing it to block Dragon-type attacks from Dragapult and Walking Wake.

Toxapex fits best on balance and bulky teams that appreciate its unique combination of bulk and power. Assault Vest Toxapex likes to pivot around aggressively and spread chip damage, thanks in part to Regenerator: entry hazard setters like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu can help it pressure opposing teams more, punishing opponents for switching out against it. Without either Haze or Toxic, Toxapex is vulnerable to setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Roaring Moon, so Unaware Pokemon such as Dondozo and Skeledirge are excellent teammates. Since Assault Vest Toxapex's physical bulk is rather lacking, physically defensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Dondozo, and Corviknight can offer much-needed switch-ins to the likes of Kingambit and Choice Band Roaring Moon. Toxapex can often struggle to make progress against bulkier teams due to its middling power and lack of Toxic, so it appreciates strong balance wallbreakers like Iron Valiant. Hydreigon deserves special mention as an excellent teammate, sharing near-perfect type synergy with Toxapex. Hydreigon checks key threats to Toxapex such as Armarouge, Kingambit, and Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and it can set up on bulkier Pokemon like defensive Great Tusk and Clodsire. In return, Toxapex can check Iron Valiant, Dragapult, and Greninja, which can threaten Hydreigon. Finally, Scream Tail is also a great partner, using Wish to extend Toxapex's longevity and having solid defensive synergy with it.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Toxapex is a potent physical wall that is capable of taking on offensive threats such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and rain staples including Palafin and Floatzel. Haze shuts down attempts of boosting past Toxapex from the likes of Swords Dance Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit. Toxic punishes strong attackers that can threaten Toxapex such as Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk, and it can hinder walls for Toxapex's teammates. Toxic Spikes can instead be used in conjunction with Pokemon that prevent hazard removal, such as Gholdengo and Annihilape, to pester the opposing team long-term. Infestation can trap and deal chip damage, notably to Pokemon like Corviknight, Iron Treads, and opposing Toxapex, which are immune to Toxic. Alternatively, Baneful Bunker lets Toxapex scout foes like Miraidon, Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Choice Specs Iron Bundle while possibly poisoning them, at the risk of letting them set up on it. Rocky Helmet somewhat offsets Toxapex's passive nature by dealing chip damage and wearing down Pokemon like Koraidon and Chien-Pao, potentially putting them into KO range from a partner and dissuading them from freely using U-turn and Crunch, respectively. Tera Fairy makes Toxapex immune or resistant to attacks like Choice Band Koraidon's Outrage and Choice Band Chien-Pao's Crunch while also making Toxapex neutral to super effective hits from Iron Bundle, Great Tusk, Dugtrio, and Gothitelle. Toxapex is useful on many team styles thanks to its great bulk and Regenerator. Pokemon that are susceptible to being revenge killed by Choice Scarf Koraidon and Ice Shard Chien-Pao, like Miraidon, opposing Koraidon, and Iron Bundle, appreciate Toxapex facing these threats for them. Another notable mention is Gothitelle, which benefits from Infestation's trapping ability, allowing it to switch in and trap defensive Pokemon without fear of them switching out the same turn. Toxapex benefits from being paired with Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Iron Treads, and Corviknight, which are able to check Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk for it.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
• Toxic prevents strong attackers like Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk and walls like Ting-Lu from switching into Toxapex for free and threatening it. Baneful Bunker is useful to scout attacks from Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane and to get a surprise poison on Koraidon and Chien-Pao, especially if they are locked into an attack.
  • Chilling Water allows Toxapex to beat Taunt + Bulk Up Palafin and Quaquaval and helps it be less passive against Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Alternatively, Surf deals more damage to Chien-Pao, Annihilape, Chi-Yu, and Gholdengo.
  • Rocky Helmet secures decent chip damage on Pokemon that try to exploit Toxapex's passive nature, such as Choice Scarf Koraidon using U-turn to pivot to another teammate or Chien-Pao using Crunch. However, Eject Button is an option to absorb a hit and get immediate momentum in the game.
  • Tera Ground Toxapex can comfortably survive otherwise super effective attacks from Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Dugtrio, while Tera Fairy is helpful to weaken attacks such as Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle, Crunch from Chien-Pao, and Outrage from Koraidon.
  • Toxapex cannot reliably beat Swords Dance and Choice Band variants of Chien-Pao and Koraidon on its own, so it must be paired with backup checks such as Skeledirge, Alomomola, Great Tusk, and Corviknight. Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire are good special walls that check strong special attackers and set entry hazards so they can't switch into Toxapex for free.
  • Toxapex creates many opportunities for wallbreakers and sweepers like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, Annihilape, Iron Bundle, Miraidon, and Koraidon to flourish while functioning as a solid check to the Pokemon that revenge kill them.
  • Toxapex acts as a pivot that can scout for attacks, especially from passive Pokemon, as it absorbs their hits and weakens them with Rocky Helmet damage or Toxic to bring them in range of attacks from its teammates.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Water)
sets.description:
Thanks to its typing and its incredible bulk, Toxapex is able to check many physical attackers in Monotype such as Meowscarada and Quaquaval. Safety Goggles allows it to avoid Spore and check Breloom, which otherwise would overwhelm Water-type teams. Its Poison-type STAB moves hit Grass- and Fairy-types such as Breloom and Iron Valiant for super effective damage while also spreading poison to chip down switch-ins such as Great Tusk and Garchomp. Poison Jab can hit Hatterene and Flutter Mane harder than Sludge Bomb. Recover allows Toxapex to remain healthy, while Haze prevents foes such as Volcarona and Quaquaval from setting up. Toxic can be used to stall out foes such as the aforementioned Volcarona and Quaquaval, and it can punish switch-ins that can try to use Toxapex as setup fodder such as Dragapult. Toxic Spikes can punish teams without entry hazard removal such as Dark and Fairy. Black Sludge can be used for passive recovery, and Rocky Helmet can be used to wear down physical attackers such as Chien-Pao. Eject Button can be an option on rain teams to get free pivoting to wallbreakers such as Floatzel and Barraskewda.

Quaquaval is a great teammate that can remove hazards to keep Toxapex healthy. Dondozo and Quagsire can help Toxapex deal with setup sweepers such as Chien-Pao and Dragapult. Quagsire and Gastrodon provide a useful Electric immunity and can stack entry hazards up along with Toxapex. Rotom-W can check Ground-types for Toxapex. In exchange, Toxapex can switch on Grass-type Pokemon such as Breloom and Meowscarada. Slowking can fulfil a pivoting core on Water teams and check Psychic-types such as Indeedee and Armarouge. Toxapex's inability to hit Steel-types such as Kingambit and Iron Treads can be very huge, so teammates that do well against them such as Quaquaval and Greninja are great partners.

sets.name: Mixed Wall (Water)
sets.description:
Is not 2HKO'ed by Thunder Punch from non-Choice Band Meowscarada or Thunderbolt from Choice Scarf Flutter Mane.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Poison)
sets.description:
Toxapex, thanks to its solid type combination and high defensive stats, is a pivotal wall on Poison teams, being able to take hits from many physical threats, such as Barraskewda, and deter them with Chilling Water. Surf is an alternative to Chilling Water thanks to its higher damage output, which lets Toxapex threaten to OHKO threats like Hisuian Arcanine after minimal chip damage and is better off against threats that don't care for their attack being lowered, such as Moltres. Haze removes the buffs from sweepers, including Ceruledge, Mimikyu, and Kingambit. Toxapex has three notable options for its second support move: Toxic Spikes to complete Poison's entry hazard stacking core and puts teams on a timer; Baneful Bunker to allow Toxapex to scout opponents, poison contact attackers such as Chien-Pao, and heal with Black Sludge; and Infestation to trap opponents that don't threaten Toxapex such as Alolan Muk and Klefki. Infestation can also be ran as instead of a Water STAB move with Baneful Bunker or Toxic to trap and waste away the plentiful contact attackers.

Alolan Muk serves as a great teammate for Toxapex, being a special tank able to take on many of the special Psychic- and Ghost-types that threaten Toxapex, like Espathra, Galarian Slowking, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo. Overqwil, while not as specially bulky as Alolan Muk, can also deter Psychic- and Ghost-types, soft check physical Iron Valiant and check physical Dragapult thanks to Intimidate, and benefit much more from Toxic Spikes with Barb Barrage. Amoonguss is a second Regenerator physical wall with a neutrality to Ground and resistance to Electric able to combat many Pokemon that threaten Toxapex such as Great Tusk, Quagsire, Rotom-W and Regieleki. Clodsire is an Unaware special wall immune to Electric that checks attack threats like Regieleki and Magnezone along with special setup Pokemon like Volcarona and Hydreigon. Air Balloon Glimmora can support Toxapex by removing entry hazards from the field for non-Heavy-Duty Boots sets, being temporarily immune to Ground with Air Balloon, and using Corrosion Toxic to put threats Toxapex majorly dislikes such as opposing Toxapex, Hisuian Goodra and Heatran on timers. Corrosion Salazzle can also provide Corrosion Toxic support along with using Encore to mess up Pokemon that view Toxapex as a setup opportunity like Kingambit. Sneasler can also be used to punch holes through teams thanks to its powerful STAB Close Combat, which can KO threats like Iron Treads and Baxcalibur, while Toxapex can come in and absorb damage for Sneasler and wear foes down with Infestation and Toxic Spikes.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Return Of The Pex
sets.description:
• With the rise of powerful defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Dragonite, Toxapex stands out as a masterful spreader of poison to support its teammates!

  • Toxic: Toxic is the most reliable way to spread the deadliest version of poison and is especially effective against Taunt users like Annihilape if using Mental Herb.

  • Toxic Spikes: Toxic Spikes makes the team less reliant on Toxapex to spread status directly, and acts as excellent support for stalling teammates like Ting-Lu, Dragonite and Gholdengo.

  • Haze: Even with Toxapex's great bulk, powerful setup sweepers like Chien-Pao and Dragonite quickly get out of control for it, so Haze is the best solution to prevent Toxapex from being setup bait.

  • Liquidation versus Chilling Water: Liqudation isn't particularly strong but it allows Toxapex to 2HKO Chi-Yu and is the best option for breaking Substitute against targets like Flutter Mane. Chilling Water with a Bold or Impish nature gives Toxapex another tool against physical sweepers, but makes it much more vulnerable to Substitute in general.

  • Baneful Bunker: If using Black Sludge or Leftovers, Baneful Bunker is a fantastic way to spread poison against physical attackers and get some extra recovery with one moveslot, but keep in mind that this won't work against Urshifu-R. It's also key for scouting dangerous uses of Trick from the likes of Gholdengo and Rotom-W.

  • Physically Defensive versus Specially Defensive: Physically defensive Toxapex does well against some hard-to-check threats, such as Urshifu-R and Chien-Pao. Specially defensive Toxapex, on the other hand, has a better shot of beating Heatran and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu.

Other Options

  • Infestation: Infestation is Toxapex's best chance of doing chip damage to Toxic-immune threats, such as Corviknignt and Gholdengo, and the trapping works fairly well against foes that do have problems with Toxic. It also prevents double switching from being an issue for Toxapex.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Terastallization can help Toxapex beat a new set of threats, its bulk and good defensive typing usually makes it a rare occurrence compared to its teammates.

  • Poison: Besides making Toxapex far less vulnerable to Electric, which some foes like Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur may Terastallize into, Tera Poison retains the ability to restore health with Black Sludge.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy removes all of Toxapex's weaknesses and can save it from taking massive damage from Chi-Yu's Dark Pulse. It also does well against powerful Dragon-type attacks such as Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage and Choice Specs Dragapult's Draco Meteor.

  • Grass: Tera Grass can prevent Breloom and Amoonguss from being disastrous with Spore, in addition to doing well against Rotom-W. It also gives an important Ground-type resistance against targets such as Ting-Lu and Dragonite.

  • Normal: While Normal isn't an impressive defensive type, Tera Normal can punish Choice locked Ghost-types, such as Flutter Mane and Gholdengo.

  • Bug: While the Stealth Rock weakness can be an issue, Tera Bug is a niche way to resist Ground-type attacks while being neutral to both Ice- and Electric-type moves, unlike other methods.

  • Flying: Tera Flying not only protects Toxapex from its irritating Ground-type weakness but also means bulky users of Fissure, such as Dondozo and Ting-Lu, will no longer pressure Toxapex. However, this typing makes Toxapex much worse into general offense.

Items

  • Black Sludge versus Leftovers: Having passive healing is wonderful, especially with Baneful Bunker. Black Sludge is a clever way to get around Item Clause, but Leftovers gives Toxapex more freedom in choosing its Tera type.

  • Rocky Helmet: While Urshifu-R often has contact protection, other physical attackers such as Chien-Pao can be gradually worn down through Rocky Helmet chip.

  • Mental Herb: With Mental Herb providing one-time protection from Taunt, Toxapex can surprise foes like Annihilape and Ting-Lu with Toxic, which is especially helpful if not running an attack.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Toxapex is a stout physically defensive wall that deters common physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge. Toxic targets foes that commonly run Heavy-Duty Boots or are Ground immune like Cinderace and Galarian Zapdos, while Toxic Spikes provides excellent team support; Corrosion variants should always run Toxic to punish common switch-ins like Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra that otherwise might use Toxapex as free recovery. Prankster + Haze, on the other hand, is an excellent tool to frustrate hyper offense teams and stop dangerous setup sweepers like Chien-Pao, Polteageist, and Chesnaught. While the consistent recovery of Black Sludge is generally preferred, Rocky Helmet allows Toxapex to annoy non-Magic Guard Galarian Zapdos and Chien-Pao even when it is forced to use Recover. Toxapex is utterly unable to threaten most Magic Guard users, like Galarian Zapdos and especially Water-resistant ones like Hisuian Electrode and Quaquaval, so reliable checks to them like Hisuian Goodra and Fluffy Corviknight are recommended. Toxic Spikes variants appreciate spinners like Iron Treads, as they can provide entry hazard removal without removing Toxic Spikes as well. Toxapex can easily be overwhelmed by multiple attackers, so it should always have a secondary physically defensive teammate, especially one that handles Ground-types, like Intimidate Corviknight; this also relieves some of the pressure off of Toxapex of checking pivots without Regenerator.

sets.name: The Pex
sets.description: Toxapex acts as a fantastic defensive pivot on bulkier playstyles courtesy of its excellent bulk and Regenerator. This allows it to scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Dragapult and Zamazenta and pivot around powerful attackers such as Iron Valiant. Scald and Knock Off allow Toxapex to meaningfully threaten foes and make progress by either causing crippling status or removing the foe's item respectively, while Toxic takes advantage of Toxapex's excellent bulk and Regenerator, putting foes on a timer for its teammates. Haze removes boosts from the likes of Dragon Dance Dragapult and Espathra. Other options such as Toxic Spikes and Baneful Bunker can be explored over either Toxic or Haze, with the intent to cripple offensive teams or maximize Toxapex's ability to scout and pivot, respectively. However, removing Toxic leaves Toxapex worse off against common Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Rotom-W, while removing Haze makes it harder to handle setup sweepers. Although Toxapex rarely Terastallizes, Tera Dragon ensures Rotom-W's Volt Switch never outdamages Regenerator while also removing its Ground and Electric weaknesses against the likes of Great Tusk and Tapu Koko. The EV spread maximizes Toxapex's physical Bulk while allowing it to survive two Scorching Sands from Mega Charizard Y. Toxapex fits best on defensively oriented teams, which don't mind its passivity and can make up for any of its defensive shortcomings. Toxapex pairs well with Unaware Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Clodsire, which can handle setup sweepers that Toxapex falters to such as Kingambit and Gholdengo. In return, Toxapex sponges various weaker attacks using Regenerator from the likes of Gastrodon and Rotom-W. Toxapex dislikes losing its item, as it can easily be pushed into KO range against wallbreakers such as Zamazenta and Dragapult alongside entry hazards. As such, Pokemon that can generally withstand Knock Off well, such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor, pair excellently with it. Tornadus-T in particular makes for a great partner, as it can use Regenerator alongside Toxapex, pivoting between each other to handle Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Garganacl. Toxapex appreciates extra insurance against strong special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. As such, Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Heatran pair well, especially since Toxapex can switch into the Shadow Balls and Focus Blasts aimed that them respectively.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Water)
sets.description: Toxapex is an incredible asset to Water teams due to its great defensive profile and wide range of utility options. Scald burns physical attackers such as Dragonite and Mega Lopunny, as well as Garchomp and Mega Gallade attempting to switch in. Poison Jab threatens Fairy- and Grass-types like Tapu Bulu, Iron Valiant, and Rillaboom. Toxic Spikes enhances offensive teammates such as Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Greninja, while Toxic lessens Toxapex's passivity, putting Gastrodon, Tornadus-T, and Mega Altaria on a timer. Haze allows Toxapex to shut down setup sweepers like Mega Scizor, Mimikyu, and Mega Altaria. Knock Off bothers item-reliant walls such as Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Celesteela. Black Sludge allows Toxapex to outlast tankier foes with the help of chip damage from Toxic Spikes and Toxic, while Heavy-Duty Boots enables it as a pivot, letting it sponge attacks without worrying about entry hazards. Teammates appreciate Toxapex absorbing Toxic Spikes and fighting off Grass-types like Meowscarada and Breloom. Toxapex appreciates Slowking and Rotom-W taking Psychic- and Ground-type moves, respectively. Mega Swampert switches into Electric-types like Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Magnezone and threatens Poison-types like opposing Toxapex, Clodsire, and Nidoking. Gastrodon forms a great defensive core with Toxapex, taking on the aforementioned Electric-types and providing entry hazards to further chip down pivots such as Meowscarada, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Moth. Greninja checks Ground-types like Clodsire, Garchomp, and Landorus and aids in the Flying matchup. Urshifu-R checks Pokemon like Kyurem and Hydreigon, which take advantage of Toxapex. Pelipper provides a Ground immunity against Landorus-T, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk and synergizes well with Toxapex against Grass teams.

sets.name: Z-Haze (Poison)
sets.description: Toxapex is a main-stay on Poison teams due to its defensive typing, impeccable ability, ridiculous bulk, and utility moves like Toxic, Knock Off, and Haze. Scald allows Toxapex to spread burns on physical attackers such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Mega Scizor. Toxic puts threats like Rotom-W, Baxcalibur, and Urshifu-R on a timer and spreads chip damage on offensive teams like Dragon, Psychic, and Fire. Knock Off is another great option to bother Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Celesteela. Haze, paired with Icium Z, shuts down setup sweepers like Z-Happy Hour Jirachi and Clangorous Soulblaze Kommo-o, immediately regaining its health to continue walling them. Toxic Spikes are an option instead of Toxic or Knock Off; however, Toxapex has other teammates capable of setting them up and it increases Toxapex's passivity. The given EV spread avoids an OHKO from +1 SpA Jirachi's Psychic, allowing Toxapex to activate its Z-Crystal. Mega Venusaur and Crobat are excellent teammates due to their Ground-type neutrality and immunity, respectively, checking Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Mamoswine, while the former also threatens Ferrothorn with Hidden Power Fire. Due to Toxapex's Psychic-type weakness, Alolan Muk and Galarian Slowking are notable teammates, checking Tapu Lele, Deoxys-S, and Latias; Galarian Slowking, in particular, forms a very strong Regenerator core with Toxapex. Clodsire and Nidoking patch up Toxapex's Electric-type weakness, and Nidoking specifically threatens Steel teams with its wide array of coverage. Galarian Weezing provides another Ground-type immunity and removes entry hazards with Defog as well as serving as a concrete answer to Baxcalibur. Sneasler appreciates Toxapex's ability to chip down foes, offering more opportunities for setup. Iron Moth threatens Steel-types like Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo, which are otherwise difficult to break for Poison teams.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: Not only is Lurantis one of the few Pokemon with access to Defog, but it also has solid bulk, reliable recovery, and a typing that fares well into many top threats like Bruxish, Eelektross, and Sandaconda. Contrary + Leaf Storm lets Lurantis accrue boosts very quickly, and Tera Blast can patch up any holes in its coverage; Tera Electric hits Flying-types like Drifblim and Oricorio-F, and Tera Fire hits Steel-types like Perrserker and Tera Steel Eelektross. Pollen Puff is an option to hit Grass-types like Appletun and Lurantis without relying on Terastallization. Lurantis is hampered by its weaknesses to U-turn and Poison-types like Muk and Toxicroak, making physical walls like Sandaconda and Drifblim great teammates. Lurantis also works excellently with entry hazard setters, as Contrary can punish Defog. Special walls like Chansey, Bombirdier, and Muk can take consecutive boosted Leaf Storms, so powerful physical attackers like Passimian and Bruxish pair well with Lurantis. 48 Speed EVs let it outspeed Chansey and Muk, giving Lurantis an edge against them should they be weakened.

sets.name: Corrosion (Poison)
sets.description:
Encore makes dealing with Swords Dance Kingambit more manageable.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Tsareena to outspeed Iron Bundle under Tailwind, retain enough Attack to OHKO 252 HP Palafin-Hero with Power Whip, then invests the remaining EVs in HP.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Tera Fire allows Mimikyu to avoid Flame Body and Will-O-Wisp from Talonflame and Coalossal. Tera Ghost powers up Shadow Claw and lets it OHKO Tinkaton after a boost.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fairy)
sets.description:
Mimikyu is one of Fairy's premier setup sweepers thanks to Disguise near guaranteeing one free turn to set up Swords Dance to boost its Attack. Play Rough is Mimikyu's strongest STAB move and allows Mimikyu to secure a OHKO on Iron Hands after a Swords Dance and also deals with bulky Great Tusk. Shadow Sneak lets Mimikyu revenge kill weakened offensive threats like Iron Moth and faster Ghost-type Pokemon such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult. Shadow Claw lets Mimikyu break past bulkier Ghost-type Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Skeledirge more readily compared to Shadow Sneak, while Drain Punch is an alternative that threatens opposing Steel-types such as Magnezone and Kingambit. Mimikyu's preferred item is Life Orb to boost its damage output as much as possible.

One of Mimikyu's best partners on Fairy teams is Klefki. Mimikyu appreciates Spikes from Klefki, which allows Mimikyu to take down Pokemon easier after a Swords Dance boost. In return, Mimikyu can block Rapid Spin, allowing Klefki's hazards to stay up during the course of the game. Flutter Mane is often paired with Mimikyu since it can threaten physically defensive pokemon that give Mimikyu a hard time like Amoonguss, Quagsire, and Forretress and also faster offensive threats like Iron Moth and Kilowattrel. Mimikyu is able to break through specially defensive Pokemon like Dragalge which gives Flutter Mane an easier time. Hatterene is also a good partner for Mimikyu, as it can bounce back debilitating status conditions like Will-O-Wisp from Sableye and Thunder Wave from Klefki and also bounces back hazards, which helps with Mimikyu's longevity since it runs Life Orb. Furthermore, Mimikyu with its Disguise up can check opposing Ghost-type Pokemon like Flutter Mane and Gholdengo for Hatterene. Iron Valiant is also one of Mimikyu's best offensive teammates, as special sets are able to threaten other physically defensive Pokemon like Dondozo. Additionally, Iron Valiant is useful for Mimikyu in the Ground matchup, where a Choice Specs set can check answers to Mimikyu, such as Quagsire and Clodsire, using Psyshock. Azumarill can use Belly Drum against Steel teams and weaken foes like Orthworm and revenge kill Iron Treads with Aqua Jet.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ghost)
sets.description:
Mimikyu is a staple on Ghost-type teams, as Disguise allows it to deal with Dark-types and faster threats such as Barraskewda. Swords Dance can further take advantage of Disguise. Play Rough threatens Dark- and Fighting-types such as Meowscarada, Krookodile, and Quaquaval. Shadow Sneak picks off faster threats that could otherwise revenge kill Mimikyu, such as Dragapult and Flutter Mane. Drain Punch helps against Steel-types like Kingambit and offers some recovery—Disguise's recoil, entry hazards, and Life Orb damage can wear Mimikyu down pretty easily. Wood Hammer can potentially be used over Drain Punch to hit Pokemon such as Quagsire better, but the recoil damage isn't appreciated. Mimikyu's mediocre Attack forces it to use Life Orb to significantly damage neutral targets.

All of Mimikyu's teammates appreciate its ability to take on Dark-type teams. Froslass and Brambleghast can place Spikes to help Mimikyu clean up and use Taunt or Rapid Spin, respectively, so opposing entry hazards don't wear it down. Choice Scarf Flutter Mane helps Mimikyu against both Dark- and Dragon-type teams by taking down faster threats that could KO it after Disguise has been removed, such as Meowscarada and Chien-Pao, which resist Shadow Sneak. Nasty Plot Gholdengo deals with bulkier teams like Ground and Poison teams, as well as absorbing Toxic from bulky walls such as Toxapex. Furthermore, Gholdengo can also run Trick with a Choice item, which can cripple annoying walls such as Quagsire and Dondozo to help Mimikyu deal with them. Polteageist can clean up Poison teams after Skuntank is KOed, as well as Ground, Water, and Fighting teams.
