Spiritomb can tank some Dark-type attacks so that Mimikyu needn't waste Disguise's protection. Skeledirge can take some hits from foes like Iron Valiant and Dragalge for the same benefit. Dragapult can use a Dragon Dance set to boost against faster Pokemon that threaten Mimikyu, such as Iron Moth.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Thanks to Disguise, Mimikyu is a premier revenge killer and sweeper in Battle Stadium Singles, being particularly apt at revenge killing Flutter Mane with Shadow Sneak.

  • Shadow Claw: While not a particularly powerful STAB, Shadow Claw is Mimikyu's most reliable attack against Poison-types such as Iron Moth and Toxapex.

  • Drain Punch: If using Tera Fighting, Drain Punch is a good coverage move against Steel-types such as Kingambit and Magnezone.

  • Fire Tera Blast: Tera Blast is a risky option due to making your team commit to Terastallizing Mimikyu, but it can be worth it for muscling through Mimikyu's usual checks, such as Corviknight and Tera Steel Pokemon.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Terastallization can clinch in some key win conditions in certain situations, but Mimikyu functions perfectly fine without it.

  • Ghost: The extra damage on Shadow Sneak gives Mimikyu an easier time sweeping late-game, particularly helpful once sturdy physical walls like Corviknight and Toxapex are worn down.

  • Fighting: The boosted power of Drain Punch gives Mimikyu a far better matchup against certain targets weak to it, such as Iron Bundle, Kingambit, and bulky Chi-Yu.

  • Fairy: A boosted Play Rough lets Mimikyu clean through weakened bulky Pokemon like Dondozo more easily.

  • Fire: With Tera Blast, Jolly Mimikyu has a 75% chance to OHKO Corviknight after Swords Dance, which means most other Steel-types will have a far more difficult time dealing with Mimikyu.

  • Normal: Tera Normal doesn't help Mimikyu offensively and makes Mimikyu vulnerable to Mach Punch and Dragon Darts, but the Ghost-type immunity could give it a surprise set-up or revenge kill opportunity against other Ghost-types.

  • Electric: While not as effective against Steel-types as Tera Fire, it still deals massive damage to Corviknight, and gives Mimikyu better chip damage to Dondozo.

sets.name: Curse Stall
sets.description:
• The combination of Curse, Substitute, and Pain Split is devastating against key defensive Pokemon such as Dondozo and Wo-Chien.

  • Play Rough versus Shadow Claw: Play Rough is the most consistent option due to having no immunities, and doing well against the large amount of Dark and Fighting Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu. Shadow Claw is Mimikyu's best shot at dealing damage to Gholdengo, at the cost of doing poorly against Normal-types.

Other Options

  • Taunt: Taunt does an even better job of shutting down defensive foes, but makes Mimikyu totally useless against Gholdengo and vulnerable to faster uses of Taunt itself.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: This Mimikyu rarely Terastallizes, but it can be useful in a few situations.

  • Fairy / Ghost: Terastallizing this Mimikyu for extra damage output is fairly situational, but getting a bit of extra power can help late game.

  • Steel: Besides being a good defensive typing, Tera Steel means Mimikyu can get around Toxic Spikes later in the match.

  • Flying: Against common users of Fissure such as Dondozo, this gives Mimikyu a situational way to stall them out more easily while healthy.

  • Poison: Tera Poison lets Mimikyu absorb Toxic Spikes, which seriously threaten this strategy otherwise.

Items

  • Life Orb: Despite this set's focus on stalling, Life Orb's offensive boost is worth considering to give Mimikyu the potential to clean up weakened teams, as well as OHKO frail foes such as Chien-Pao with Play Rough.

  • Salac Berry: Salac Berry gives Mimikyu a new option for cleaning up teams late-game. Note that unlike almost any other user of Salac Berry, this Mimikyu will prefer to use Substitute as much as possible to fully take advantage of Curse, so using an HP stat divisible by 4 is not recommended.

  • Figy Berry: Figy Berry and it's other counterparts give Mimikyu another method of healing after using Substitute enough times.

  • Bright Powder: While not particularly reliable, even one miss against Mimikyu can be devastating!

EV Spreads

  • 20 HP / 220 Atk / 12 Def / 4 SpD / 252 Spe This EV spread lets Mimikyu maintain its Substitute against 4 Attack EV Garganacl's Salt Cure, The odd HP number is relevant if Mimikyu uses Curse without its Disguise being broken, keeping Mimikyu's HP stat odd so that it can use Substitute twice after using Curse, or use Curse twice in a row without KOing itself.

  • 244 HP / 12 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: This bulkier EV spread gives Mimikyu an odd HP number that it can take advantage of if it uses Curse without its Disguise being broken, letting it use Curse again without KOing itself the next turn or using Substitute twice after using Curse. The rest is place in Defense to take priority attacks better.

sets.name: Trick Scarf
sets.description:
• Mimikyu might seem like an odd user of Choice Scarf with its low offenses, but with Trick and Disguise, it becomes a very disruptive Pokemon against defensive foes like Ting-Lu, Wo-Chien, Dondozo, and Corviknight.

  • Shadow Sneak: Shadow Sneak is a reasonable option to give Mimikyu priority after using Trick, which is especially helpful against Flutter Mane.

  • Wood Hammer hits Water-types such as Rotom-W and Iron Bundle very hard.

  • Thunder Wave, Will-O-Wisp, and Curse: Thunder Wave, Will-O-Wisp, or Curse let Mimikyu further disrupt Pokemon after using Trick, or can be used as an emergency way to stop a sweeper while still holding Choice Scarf.

  • Using a neutral Nature with a mint: Mimikyu should have a neutral nature with a Jolly Mint used on it. This way, Mimikyu can't be confused by eating any Berry after using Trick.

Other Options

  • Destiny Bond: Mimikyu's good Speed makes it a good option for making trades with Destiny Bond.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: This Mimikyu's supportive nature means it'll only Terastallize under specific conditions.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives enough of a boost to Play Rough to OHKO Chien-Pao and deal over 50% to Ting-Lu that don't invest in Defense.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Mimikyu a good chance to OHKO Dragapult with Shadow Claw, and a boosted Shadow Sneak has situational value in the late-game.

  • Grass: With Wood Hammer being boosted, Mimikyu OHKOes offensive Rotom-W.

  • Normal: While this makes Mimikyu far more vulnerable to Breloom, it is useful for catching other Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane off guard.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ghost)
sets.description: Mimikyu is an outstanding asset to Ghost teams, boasting both a valuable part-Fairy typing and a unique ability that complements revenge killing and late-game cleaning. Play Rough hits threatening Dark- and Dragon-types like Galarian Moltres, Mandibuzz, and Kommo-o. Shadow Claw notably allows Mimikyu to threaten Psychic teams even under Psychic Terrain, while Drain Punch deals more damage to Steel-types such as Iron Treads, Magnezone, and Excadrill and can mitigate Life Orb recoil. Shadow Sneak enables Mimikyu to revenge kill weakened foes and pick off faster threats like Blacephalon, Gengar, and Victini. Disguise almost always allows Mimikyu to set up a Swords Dance or revenge kill faster foes that Shadow Sneak cannot deal enough damage to. Mega Sableye is heavily appreciated due to its ability Magic Bounce, which adds to Mimikyu's longevity by bouncing back entry hazards and status moves aimed at it. Wallbreakers like Gholdengo wear down bulkier teams by checking walls such as Corviknight, Mega Venusaur, and Toxapex, which lets Mimikyu have an easier time cleaning up late-game. Blacephalon and Skeledirge threaten the Steel-types Mimikyu struggles against, like Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor. They can also cripple troublesome walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon with Trick and Will-O-Wisp, respectively. Hisuian Zoroark is deeply valued for its Ghost-type immunity, as it can catch Gholdengo and Gengar off guard.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Bruxish's Speed tier coupled with Strong Jaw-boosted Psychic Fangs lends it great wallbreaking capability. Its high Base Power STAB moves are nearly unresisted, and it has enough coverage moves to get around potential checks like Cacturne and Vaporeon. Poison Fang hits Grass-types like Cacturne and Appletun while also badly poisoning common walls like Vaporeon and Umbreon. Crunch targets Psychic-types like Hattrem and Oricorio-P while also securing the OHKO on Farigiraf. Tera Dark further boosts Strong Jaw-boosted Crunch and helps Bruxish get past the aforementioned Cacturne and Vaporeon. Tera Fairy coupled with Tera Blast helps its matchup versus Cacturne while also resisting Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Toxicroak and Honckrow. Teammates should be pivots that bring Bruxish safely on the field like Eelektross, Passimian, and Rotom. Pokemon like Oricorio and Clawitzer appreciate Bruxish targeting their checks like Chansey and Eelektross.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Strong Jaw-boosted Psychic Fangs and Crunch turn Bruxish into a dominant offensive force in NU. It also has Aqua Jet, which lets it revenge kill weakened faster threats like Zoroark and Choice Scarf Passimian and sweep after boosting with Swords Dance. Bruxish's Speed tier is also great, allowing it to outspeed Rotom, Mabosstiff, and Bombirdier. Tera Blast can be used in the fourth moveslot in conjunction with Tera Fairy to give Bruxish a better defensive typing while also being able to beat common walls to it like Cacturne and Tera Dark Toxicroak and Vaporeon. Tera Dark combined with Strong Jaw, however, gives Crunch a deadly bite with it becoming a third STAB move to nail opposing Bruxish and Veluza. Alternatively, Tera Water makes Aqua Jet even more dangerous for the aforementioned faster threats. If Bruxish is not running Tera Fairy + Tera Blast, having a partner like Toxicroak or Rotom to deal with Tera Dark Toxicroak and Vaporeon is appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Bruxish outspeeds other common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Rotom, making it a very effective late-game cleaner. While it forgoes boosting elements like Choice Band and Swords Dance, Bruxish still boasts a good offensive presence with its powerful STAB moves. Tera Dark further boosts its Strong Jaw-boosted Crunch, and prevents Bruxish from being revenge killed by Sucker Punch users like Toxicroak and Zoroark. Choice Scarf Bruxish can surprise and OHKO common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Rotom that expect to be faster, so teammates that appreciate their removal like Pyroar, Lycanroc, and Vivillon make good partners.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Clangorous Booster
sets.description: Kommo-o is a fearsome wallbreaker with its capability to omniboost as soon as it gets an opportunity with Clangorous Soul. Its ability to set up on common Pokemon like Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Volcarona and to potentially use Tera Steel to ignore Toxic from defensive Pokemon like Heatran and Toxapex allows it to start wallbreaking very early with its powerful coverage. Throat Spray grants an extra Special Attack boost when using Clangorous Soul, whereas Kommonium Z gives it Clangorous Soulblaze, which allows it to deal heavy damage while boosting its stats. Boomburst lets Kommo-o neutrally hit much of the metagame for large damage, which, when coupled with STAB Clanging Scales and Flamethrower as coverage for Steel-types, can easily break cores featuring the likes of Great Tusk, Skarmory, Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Gliscor, Landorus-T, and more. Bulletproof along with Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to wall Choice Scarf Tapu Lele looking to revenge kill it as well as set up in front of Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Tera Normal gives Kommo-o a stronger Boomburst, while Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and useful resistances to all of its weaknesses, allowing Kommo-o to take would-be checks, such as Dragapult, Tapu Lele, Baxcalibur, and Iron Valiant, by surprise and set up in front of them. However, Kommo-o likes to use its Tera and thus denies its teammates this option, and it can be checked by a well-timed Tera from Pokemon such as Tera Steel Garchomp and subsequently be revenge killed. It is also walled by the likes of Heatran, Garganacl, and Clodsire, which can tank its coverage options even without Terastallizing and cripple it with Toxic or Salt Cure or simply force it out and deny future setup opportunities. Finally, due to the nature of Kommo-o’s setup, it can only reasonably do so once per game, making Kommo-o more suited for offensive teams. Thus, having allies that can take care of Kommo-o’s defensive checks before it sets up can allow it to do its job much more effectively; physical attackers like Iron Valiant, offensive Landorus-T, and Samurott-H can pressure and remove checks for Kommo-o to break and potentially sweep. Hazard support is also valuable in preventing opponents from switching back and forth between Pokemon in a Regenerator core; in particular, Assault Vest Tornadus + Toxapex; Pokemon like Great Tusk and Garchomp can set up Stealth Rock to pressure switches.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description: With Belly Drum, Kommo-o becomes a fearsome sweeper capable of wiping unprepared teams with relative ease. The HP cuts from Substitute and Belly Drum will immediately activate Salac Berry, giving Kommo-o maximum Attack along with increased Speed to sweep offensive and defensive teams alike. Substitute also allows Kommo-o to dodge status moves like Ferrothorn’s Leech Seed, Garganacl's Salt Cure, Landorus-T's Toxic, and Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp that could potentially ruin Kommo-o’s sweep, instead giving it a free set up opportunity. Drain Punch is chosen over heavier hitting moves like Close Combat, as the extra damage is not needed, and Drain Punch can heal off the HP lost through Belly Drum and Substitute, making Kommo-o harder to revenge kill. Thunder Punch is used to dent and possibly KO common defensive tanks that can survive Drain Punch, like Skarmory, Toxapex, Tera Water Garganacl, Gholdengo, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Bulletproof stacked on top of Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to surprise opponents like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Dragapult looking to revenge kill it. Although Soundproof blocks moves such as Roar from defensive Garchomp and Bug Buzz from Volcarona, it is generally not preferred due to the lack of relevant sound-based moves in comparison to the bevy of aforementioned qualities gained from Bulletproof. Tera Electric can power up Thunder Punch with STAB to score KOs on the likes of Gholdengo, Tapu Lele, and Tera Fairy Kingambit, while Tera Steel gives it useful resistances that may allow it to reach Salac Berry range without Substitute by tanking a resisted hit from the likes of Tapu Lele or Mega Diancie. Belly Drum Kommo-o fits on hyper offensive teams that appreciate its ability to sweep or clean up teams once its checks are removed. Therefore, it appreciates partners that can lure and remove Pokemon like Clodsire, Tera Grass Heatran, Gliscor, and Landorus-T that check it; Tapu Koko in particular is good, as it can run Hidden Power Ice to bait and KO the latter two and badly chip the former two potentially into Kommo-o’s range while also boosting the power of its Thunder Punch by setting Electric Terrain. Belly Drum Kommo-o also has trouble setting up, as it mainly uses the element of surprise to get up a Substitute —namely, it exploits the opponent's fear of Clangorous Soulblaze and thus forces them to switch. Thus, it appreciates dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl in order to more consistently set up Belly Drum.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper (Fighting)
sets.description: An incredible asset for Fighting teams, Kommo-o is often the best wincon on the type thanks to Clangorous Soulblaze, which helps it overcome otherwise difficult matchups such as Dragon, Flying, and Water. Flamethrower takes care of Steel-type Pokemon neutral to Drain Punch like Mega Scizor and Corviknight. Taunt allows Kommo-o to block status moves from defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Swampert, and Gliscor, preventing them from resetting its boosts with Haze or statusing it with Toxic. Alternatively, Clangorous Soul powers up Kommo-o without using its Z-Move, letting its Clangorous Soulblaze outright OHKO Toxapex and Hippowdon, at the cost of longevity. Bulletproof is Kommo-o's preferred ability to better handle Gholdengo or Aegislash in the Steel matchup. Unboosted Kommo-o's average Speed tier leaves it outsped by threats to Fighting teams like Tornadus-T and Tapu Lele, so Choice Scarf users like Galarian Zapdos and Terrakion are great partners to assist it against them. Iron Valiant's Fairy typing and wide coverage movepool lets it deal with opposing Dragon-types, and it forms a wallbreaking core with Kommo-o by pressuring the likes of Mega Sableye and Ting-Lu. Cobalion and Great Tusk provide Stealth Rock, which maximizes Kommo-o's opportunities to wallbreak after using Clangorous Soulblaze. Great Tusk can also remove entry hazards for Kommo-o with Rapid Spin, and Cobalion has the added bonus of checking Fairy-types like Mega Diancie. Mega Gallade can pressure Poison-, Ground-, and Flying-types like Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T for Kommo-o. It can also outspeed and revenge kill offensive threats to it like Kyurem and Garchomp.

sets.name: Mixed Omni-Boost Sweeper (Dragon)
sets.description: Kommo-o is an exceptional setup sweeper due to its great mixed offensive stats, respectable defenses, and exclusive access to Clangorous Soulblaze; this makes it an amazing tool to clean up Steel, Dark, and Dragon teams late-game. Drain Punch threatens Steel- and Normal-types like Heatran, Blissey, and Porygon-2 as well as increasing Kommo-o's longevity, making it harder for revenge killers to shut it down after using its Z-Move. Additionally, Drain Punch is Kommo-o's best move to hit Ditto, as it copies its ability Soundproof. Flamethrower targets Fighting-resistant or -immune Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Celesteela, and Aegislash. Taunt is preferred to shut down phazers like Haze Toxapex and Hippowdon and bulky walls like Porygon2 and Clodsire, which can inconvenience Kommo-o with Toxic. Meanwhile, Clangorous Soul allows for more boosts and breaking power, notably enabling Clangorous Soulblaze to OHKO the aforementioned Hippowdon and Toxapex. Furthermore, Clangorous Soulblaze allows Kommo-o to set up on Fairy-types and Soundproof Pokemon like Alolan Ninetales, Trace Porygon2, and opposing Kommo-o. Soundproof prevents revenge killing attempts from Ditto or opposing Kommo-o, and a Naive nature permits Kommo-o to outpace Mega Aerodactyl, Mega Lopunny, and Zeraora after obtaining the omni-boost. Mega Altaria is a wonderful teammate, as it helps weaken and clean up opposing Dragon teams; In return, it appreciates Kommo-o dealing with the aforementioned Steel-types. Kyurem aids in matchups against Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Mantine, and Dragonite, as well as Fairy-types such as Azumarill, Tapu Fini, and Mega Altaria. Choice Scarf Latias and Roaring Moon provide speed control; the former offers healing and setup opportunities with Healing Wish, while the latter checks Psychic-types like Deoxys-S, Victini, and Latias. Garchomp offers entry hazards support to pressure and chip down Kommo-o's switch-ins and aids in the Steel matchup with Earthquake. Hisuian Goodra is a huge help in the Fairy matchup, taking on Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Mega Diancie. Mega Latios threatens Flying-type threats with its BoltBeam coverage; in addition, when paired with Garchomp, it puts a lot of pressure on Poison teams, which Kommo-o tends to struggle against. Cyclizar provides entry hazard control with Rapid Spin and extra protection for Kommo-o with Shed Tail, encouraging the use of Clangorous Soul over Taunt. Baxcalibur is excellent in the Dark and Flying matchups, dispatching threats like Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Enamorus with its Swords Dance or Dragon Dance set, and it also ravages Poison teams with Galarian Slowking, which Kommo-o might not be able to handle. In return, Kommo-o removes the aforementioned Steel- and Normal-types that can easily wall Baxcalibur or use it to reverse sweep, specifically Ditto.

sets.name: Utility Terrain Setter
sets.description: Thanks to Grassy Surge, Rillaboom is used as a Grassy Terrain setter to support its teammates. Access to moves like U-turn, Knock Off, and Taunt further allows it to enable the setup sweepers on its team. Knock Off removes Leftovers from Pokemon like Heatran and Corviknight, as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from Zapdos, Galarian Slowking, and Moltres, making them easier to beat with entry hazards up. It also prevents Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Dragapult from coming in for free. U-turn allows Rillaboom to pivot out after setting up Grassy Terrain into a teammate who benefits from it. Drain Punch can be used alongside the passive healing of Grassy Terrain to keep Rillaboom healthy throughout the game. It's also crucial for hitting Kingambit while ensuring Heatran and Baxcalibur can't easily take advantage of Rillaboom. Taunt prevents defensive Pokemon such as Galarian Slowking and Corviknight from using healing moves, and it also stops the former from using Chilly Reception and the latter from using Defog, and prevents Pokemon like Ting-Lu and defensive Landorus-T from setting hazards. Wood Hammer is an alternative STAB move that can be used to hit harder at the cost of longevity; for instance, it nets the OHKO against offensive Great Tusk, specially defensive Garganacl, and physically defensive Rotom-W. Terrain Extender is used to allow Rillaboom and its teammates to benefit from Grassy Terrain for longer, but Eject Button is another option that allows Rillaboom to immediately switch into a teammate after getting hit without wasting a turn of Grassy Terrain. Rillaboom will almost never Terastallize, as a teammate will almost always benefit more from it. In rare cases, Tera Fairy or Steel can provide key resistances, allowing Rillaboom to act as an emergency check to Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Enamorus, and Baxcalibur, especially with Grassy Terrain to weaken the latter's Earthquake. 52 Speed EVs are used to outspeed Kingambit and uninvested Landorus-T, allowing Rillaboom to hit the former with Drain Punch, as long as it's out of Sucker Punch KO range, and get a hit off or use Taunt on the latter to prevent Stealth Rock from going up. Rillaboom fits on hyper offense teams that benefit from Grassy Terrain, especially with teammates holding a Grassy Seed. Sneasler and Hawlucha are powerful setup sweepers that benefit from the Defense and Speed boost they get from Grassy Seed and Unburden. Sneasler in particular benefits from Earthquake damage being decreased in Grassy Terrain, giving it better odds against Pokemon like Landorus-T and Great Tusk without Headlong Rush. Bulky Calm Mind sweepers such as Hatterene and Enamorus-T can use the Defense boost from Grassy Seed to become even more difficult to KO as they start setting up, with the former also appreciating the passive recovery from Grassy Terrain to somewhat make up for the lack of Leftovers. Hazard setters such as Hisuian Samurott and Great Tusk benefit from Rillaboom's ability to remove Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off and assist the aforementioned sweepers. Kingambit is another great Pokemon that fits on hyper offense and benefits from Rillaboom and its teammates wearing down the opposition. It also greatly benefits from Grassy Terrain providing extra longevity and weakening Earthquake.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Rillaboom's combination of Grassy Glide and Grassy Surge makes it a reliable revenge killer, pressuring faster threats like Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, Garchomp, Barraskewda, and Iron Valiant. It also possesses great utility thanks to U-turn and Knock Off. Wood Hammer is Rillaboom's strongest STAB move, dealing massive damage to all non-resistant foes. Knock Off catches would-be checks like Tornadus-T and Zapdos on the switch, getting rid of their item at the same time. Superpower hits Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Ferrothorn. Tera Grass makes Rillaboom even more threatening; with Terrain-boosted Grassy Glide, it becomes near unstoppable, 2HKOing Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock. Rillaboom fits best on bulky offense teams, which appreciate speed control in Grassy Glide. Grassy Terrain sweepers like Hawlucha and Choice Scarf Kartana appreciate Rillaboom weakening their common checks—namely Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Corviknight—so they can clean late-game. Magnezone is a standout partner for Rillaboom, as it can trap and remove Steel-types like Corviknight, Skarmory, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn, letting Rillaboom clean more easily. Heatran appreciates Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain giving it passive recovery and weakening Earthquake from the likes of Galarian Slowking. In return, Heatran pressures Rillaboom's checks, such as Buzzwole, Corviknight, Volcarona, Skarmory, and Skeledirge, while also providing Stealth Rock and checking Tornadus-T.

sets.name: Bulky Swords Dance
sets.description: Thanks to Grassy Glide and Grassy Surge, Rillaboom forces many switches against Pokemon like Rotom-W and Urshifu-R, meaning it can safely set up with Swords Dance to threaten the opposing team. Knock Off punishes its checks, like Zapdos and Tornadus-T. Superpower allows Rillaboom to threaten Steel-types like Heatran, Kingambit, and Ferrothorn, while Wood Hammer does massive damage to all neutral threats, even without a boost. The given EV spread allows Rillaboom to outspeed Mega Tyranitar while maximizing its bulk. The added bulk maximizes Rillaboom’s longevity, helping it perform long-term and deal with other terrain setters, like Tapu Lele. Life Orb gives Rillaboom a chance to OHKO offensive Tornadus-T with Tera Grass-boosted Grassy Glide, with its recoil being negated by the Grassy Terrain. On the other hand, Leftovers provides increased longevity for Rillaboom, allowing it to setup multiple times throughout a game. Tera Grass gives Rillaboom an even stronger Grassy Glide, allowing it to storm through most offensive teams that have limited resistances to it. Some Flying-resistant Tera types such as Steel and Electric can punish Zapdos and Tornadus-T, but they are usually suboptimal and don't benefit Rillaboom's offensive power. Magnezone works well with this set, as it can trap and remove Steel-types like Corviknight, Skarmory, and Mega Scizor. Hawlucha is a good partner as well, as Grassy Seed will activate Hawlucha's Unburden thanks to Grassy Terrain and Rillaboom can weaken their shared check in Zapdos so it can clean late-game. Since Superpower weakens Steel-types, Pokemon like Weavile and Mega Mawile pair well with Rillaboom. The latter also appreciates Grassy Terrain, as it softens Earthquake from the likes of Gliscor and Landorus-T.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Rillaboom is an excellent glue Pokemon in the tier, with Fake Out pressure, pivoting capabilities, and passive healing from Grassy Terrain making it a excellent partner for setup sweepers and offense teams alike. Rillaboom can also provide offensive pressure with its powerful Wood Hammer in Grassy Terrain and decent coverage.
  • Fake Out generates free turns for setup sweepers like Palafin and Kingambit while also helping allies that can assist with speed control like Tornadus and Cresselia to set up Tailwind and Trick Room, respectively. Rillaboom is the fastest Fake Out user, letting it use Fake Out before a prominent Fake Out user like Iron Hands.
  • Wood Hammer is Rillaboom's main way of exerting offensive pressure, OHKOing Palafin, Diancie, and Flutter Mane after minimal chip, while also doing good damage to most of the unresisted metagame, picking up 2HKOs on the likes of Iron Hands and Volcanion.
  • U-turn allows Rillaboom to bring in teammates like Palafin safely without them taking damage while additionally doing good damage to opposing Rillaboom.
  • Brick Break hits Steel-type Pokemon such as Kingambit and Heatran, while also OHKOing Chien-Pao. Removing dual screens enables the likes of Kingambit and Palafin to continue their own sweeps. On non-Assault Vest sets, Taunt stops Trick Room setters like Diancie and Cresselia, setup Pokemon like Kingambit, entry hazard setters, and other general utility Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Grimmsnarl. Stomping Tantrum 2HKOes common Grass resistances such as Heatran, Armarouge, and Gholdengo.
  • Assault Vest helps Rillaboom match up better against special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Gholdengo, while Sitrus Berry grants a one-time burst recovery and the freedom to use Taunt.
  • This EV spread lets Rillaboom survive an Ice Spinner from Jolly Chien-Pao and, with Assault Vest, two Choice Specs Moonblasts from Flutter Mane after Grassy Terrain recovery.
  • Tera Fire helps Rillaboom match up better against Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Armarouge by inverting its weaknesses, allowing it to trade positively with its coverage options against these Pokemon.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Cinderace is a good offensive pivot thanks to its high Speed, decent Attack, and wide coverage that gains a STAB boost thanks to Libero each time it enters the field. Pyro Ball is its most reliable move, as it can hit hard while preserving Libero. Sucker Punch gives Cinderace a means to hit faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Dragapult super effectively. Alternatively, Gunk Shot can be run to OHKO Iron Valiant and Hatterene while preserving the team's ability to Terastallize. Court Change is an extremely useful move, as it can provide hazard control that is unaffected by Gholdengo's Good as Gold while also stealing Light Screen and Reflect from hyper offensive teams; however, Cinderace can choose to run High Jump Kick instead to hit Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Ting-Lu harder as well as inflicting more damage against Pokemon that resist Pyro Ball like Garchomp and Garganacl. Tera Fire is the Tera type that Cinderace wants to utilize in order to maximize Pyro Ball's damage, giving it the ability to, with an Adamant nature, OHKO Corviknight after Stealth Rock. It also helps Cinderace hit bulkier targets like Hatterene and offensive Great Tusk, especially if it isn't running Gunk Shot or High Jump Kick. A Jolly nature is preferred to augment Cinderace's role as a fast pivot, allowing it to outspeed Iron Valiant, Iron Moth, and Iron Treads. However, an Adamant nature can be run instead to increase its damage output.

Cinderace works best on balance and bulky offense teams, providing utility and entry hazard control while simultaneously exerting offensive pressure. Defensive Water-type Pokemon like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Dondozo can all sponge Water-type attacks while taking neutral damage from Rock- and Ground-type moves, with the exception of Toxapex. In turn, Cinderace can match up well against wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant and Meowscarada, which can all cause difficulties for the aforementioned Water-types. Ground-types that provide entry hazard support such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu make it easier for Cinderace to check threats with Stealth Rock and Spikes, especially if it is running an Adamant nature. Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Iron Valiant pair well with Cinderace, as they can eradicate foes that wall it such as Great Tusk, Dondozo, and Rotom-W. Similarly, Dragonite and Kingambit can check Pokemon such as Hatterene and Skeledirge, which can both cause issues for Cinderace. In return, Cinderace can provide hazard control for all of these partners and help them come in the field more safely without having to worry about chip damage from entry hazards.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description:
Cinderace functions as an excellent bulky pivot thanks to its great Speed tier, serviceable bulk, and access to support moves such as Court Change and Will-O-Wisp. Cinderace can force out important offensive threats like Gholdengo and Iron Valiant with the threat of STAB Pyro Ball while keeping up momentum against defensive switch-ins with U-turn. Will-O-Wisp allows Cinderace to cripple physical attackers such as Kingambit, Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Great Tusk, and it can also negate Leftovers for defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Toxapex, and Ting-Lu. Specifically, Will-O-Wisp offers a safe way for Cinderace to check Kingambit, since it avoids Sucker Punch mindgames. Finally, Court Change offers unmatched utility in providing entry hazard control that cannot be blocked by Gholdengo and is also able to steal opposing dual screens. The 32 Attack EVs guarantee a KO on Gholdengo sets lacking defensive investment and 2HKO on physically defensive Corviknight after Leftovers. Although this set rarely wants to Terastallize, Tera Fire can potentially come in handy for securing KOs with Pyro Ball, especially with a Blaze boost. Alternatively, Tera Flying grants Cinderace an immunity to Ground-type attacks, such as Great Tusk's Earthquake, which can grant it extra opportunities to KO foes or cripple them with Will-O-Wisp. Tera Flying also matches up well against common Ground-type hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk, letting Cinderace safely Court Change against them.

Cinderace works best on bulkier teams where its ability to guarantee hazard removal shines. Defensive Pokemon such as Dondozo, Slowking, Toxapex, and Amoonguss are great teammates, as they appreciate Cinderace's ability to ensure hazard removal, freeing them up to run items other than Heavy-Duty Boots. Water-types such as Dondozo and Toxapex have notably strong synergy with Cinderace; Dondozo checks Great Tusk and Tera Fire Kingambit, while Toxapex can check Water-types, such as Walking Wake and Greninja. Hazard-weak breakers such as Iron Moth and Choice Band Dragonite also fit well with Cinderace, as it's able to bring them in with U-turn. These breakers also enjoy bulky Water-types like Toxapex or Dondozo being burnt, making it easier to overwhelm them long-term. Cinderace usually requires the presence of another hazard control Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Hatterene, or Corviknight so it doesn't get overwhelmed. Corviknight synergizes especially well with Cinderace thanks to its Ground immunity and ability to absorb Knock Off from Meowscarada, which outspeeds Cinderace. Skeledirge and Dragapult can take advantage of bulky Cinderace, since both completely wall it and can potentially set up a Substitute. Kingambit is a great partner, as it can offensively check both Skeledirge and Dragapult. In return, it appreciates Cinderace burning Great Tusk and Ting-Lu, opening up the way for it to sweep.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Cinderace serves as a dangerous wallbreaker, as it easily exploits would-be checks thanks to its ability, Libero. Double-Edge becomes a STAB move after using Swords Dance, allowing Cinderace to not only wound Pokemon like Toxapex and Slowbro but also OHKO them with Normalium Z. High Jump Kick KOes Heatran and Mega Tyranitar, while Sucker Punch threatens faster Pokemon like Dragapult and Tornadus-T. Pokemon that can set entry hazards such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, Ferrothorn, and Ting-Lu help Cinderace break through its checks like Great Tusk and Tera Dragon Skarmory. Cinderace is vulnerable to faster Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Tapu Koko, so Pokemon like Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Landorus-T are good teammates. Cinderace also benefits from dual screens from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl, allowing it to safely set up and start wreaking havoc on the opponent. Pokemon that can wear down Great Tusk, Skeledirge, and Tera Dragon Skarmory such as Iron Valiant, Mega Gyarados, and Dragapult form great offensive cores with Cinderace, which, in return, threatens Pokemon like Toxapex, Kingambit, and Mega Scizor. Entry hazard removers such as Tornadus-T and Great Tusk support Cinderace's Stealth Rock weakness.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Cinderace utilizes its solid coverage alongside Libero and its high Attack and Speed to serve as a strong offensive pivot. High Jump Kick OHKOes foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Heatran while hitting others like Garganacl and Ting-Lu, though Cinderace must be mindful of Protect from the former and Tera Ghost from the latter causing it to take heavy recoil. U-turn lets Cinderace generate momentum, pivoting on switch-ins such as Toxapex and Slowbro to bring in teammates like Tapu Koko and Gholdengo that can handle them. Sucker Punch lets Cinderace threaten Dragapult, which would otherwise revenge kill it. Tera Fire boosts Pyro Ball's power, allowing Cinderace to 2HKO foes such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Tera Fairy Garganacl after Stealth Rock. Cinderace must careful when using Tera, however, as Libero will no longer activate, leaving it more vulnerable to foes such as Rotom-W. Cinderace fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its pivoting ability. Tapu Koko forms a potent pivoting core with Cinderace, taking advantage of foes such as Toxapex and Rotom-W while granting Cinderace free entry against foes such as Ferrothorn and Tangrowth. They also overwhelm foes such as Ladorus-T, Gastrodon, and Great Tusk together. Cinderace also appreciates teammates such as Ferrothorn and Gastrodon providing entry hazard support to weaken foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk while also checking foes such as Rotom-W and Urshifu-R. Dragapult appreciates Cinderace handling foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit; in return, it threatens foes such as Skeledirge, which Cinderace struggles against. Future Sight support from teammates such as Slowbro and Tapu Lele helps pressure foes such as Toxapex for Cinderace; in return, Cinderace handles foes that threaten them such as Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
Cinderace is a valuable asset to Fire teams due to its mix of offensive presence and utility. Pyro Ball lets Cinderace threaten out Sableye trying to take High Jump Kick on Dark-type teams while also dealing high amounts of general damage under sun. Libero-boosted High Jump Kick provides valuable coverage, notably hitting Ting-Lu trying to set entry hazards while dealing large amounts of damage to Pokemon with a Fire resistance trying to switch in on its Pyro Ball, such as Hydreigon and Garganacl. Low Kick is an alternative, letting Cinderace deal decent damage to most heavy foes such as Ting-Lu and Iron Hands without the large risk of High Jump Kick's crash damage. Court Change lets Cinderace force the opposing team to deal with their own hazards while making it unlikely that hazards go up again. U-turn lets Cinderace keep momentum against foes it cannot threaten out like defensive Great Tusk and Garchomp. Alternatively, Sucker Punch lets Cinderace pick off weakened threats such as Flutter Mane and Baxcalibur. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Cinderace come in repeatedly to remove hazards without worrying about residual damage from them.

Rotom-H is a great teammate for Cinderace, as its Ground immunity lets it come in on Great Tusk while threatening Water-types such as Toxapex and Dondozo—that Cinderace can't do much against—with its Electric-type STAB moves. Additionally, Rotom-H can beat Poison teams with its Substitute + Nasty Plot set, which Cinderace greatly appreciates. In return, Cinderace can pivot Rotom-H in with U-turn and keep Stealth Rock off its side of the field. Torkoal is another good teammate for Cinderace, as it provides sun to boost Cinderace's Pyro Ball damage to astronomical levels, provides entry hazard support to chip switch-ins, threatens Chien-Pao and physical Dragapult with a burn, and supplies a secondary source of hazard removal. In return, Cinderace can threaten out Ting-Lu, which might try to switch into Torkoal, while also keeping hazards off against Ghost teams. Scovillain deals with the aforementioned Water-types as well as Gastrodon while appreciating Cinderace removing the hazards that hurt Scovillain's longevity. Volcarona appreciates Cinderace chipping away at the opposing team, facilitating an endgame sweep. In return, Volcarona can hit Dark-types such as Ting-Lu and Hydreigon hard with Bug Buzz, ruin Gastrodon through Giga Drain, and damage Poison-types such as Iron Moth, Toxapex, and Glimmora with Psychic. Skeledirge is able to come in on physical hits like Iron Hands's Earthquake and force it out with the threat of a burn. Finally, Ceruledge can remove Ghost-types such as Dragapult that Cinderace can't do much against. In return, Cinderace can eliminate Dark-types and keep hazards off the field for both.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Cinderace is a potent wallbreaker that can OHKO or 2HKO common defensive Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Kingambit. While Mold Breaker beats Well-Baked Body users like Corviknight, Desolate Land allows Cinderace to 2HKO even Fire-resistant Pokemon like Roaring Moon with Pyro Ball. Gunk Shot is a good option to hit Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Florges, while Sucker Punch allows Cinderace to revenge kill weakened opponents that outspeed it, such as Kilowattrel. Cinderace struggles against Primordial Sea users like Barraskewda and certain physical walls like Dondozo, so it appreciates teammates like Rotom-W that can threaten these Pokemon. Due to its low defensive stats and weakness to entry hazards, Cinderace appreciates pivoting and entry hazard removal from teammates like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Cinderace also pairs well with offensive pivots like Greninja, as they can easily maneuver around and threaten each other's checks.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: With its high Attack and Speed stats, good coverage moves, and inability to be worn down by entry hazards thanks to Heavy-Duty Boots, Cinderace is a versatile pivot that is able to outspeed and offensively respond to various threats such as Latios and Clefable. Pyro Ball is Cinderace's main STAB move, allowing it to hit Steel-types such as Celesteela and Excadrill while also dealing significant damage to other defensive Pokemon such as Buzzwole and Amoonguss; it notably preserves Libero's type-changing ability in the process. U-turn, besides allowing Cinderace to maintain momentum by bringing in a teammate like Hydreigon, can also wear down defensive Pokemon such as Slowbro. Gunk Shot gives Cinderace useful coverage for Pokemon such as Tapu Fini and Mega Altaria, and it also lets Cinderace force out Calm Mind Clefable more reliably. Alternatively, High Jump Kick is an option to OHKO Mega Tyranitar and Hydreigon, as well as 2HKO physically defensive Ting-Lu, which U-turn cannot do. Sucker Punch lets Cinderace revenge kill chipped sweepers such as Agility Iron Moth and Z-Celebrate variants of Victini after their respective boosts while also threatening Choice Scarf users such as Blacephalon. Cinderace fits best on offensive teams that can supply it with the tools needed to break through defensive Pokemon; entry hazard setters such as Mega Tyranitar, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads can support Cinderace in this manner, with Mega Tyranitar also being able to trap Slowbro and Skeledirge with Pursuit after Cinderace pivots against them. Similarly, defensive Pokemon such as Celesteela, Slowbro, and Tapu Fini appreciate Cinderace's ability to threaten out the likes of Aegislash, Meowscarada, and Scizor; in return, they can help sponge the Water- and Ground-type moves aimed at Cinderace or provide Future Sight or Taunt support in the case of the latter two. Powerful wallbreakers such as Latios and Gengar also appreciate the safe entry Cinderace can facilitate against most physically defensive Pokemon it commonly invites in on top of Cinderace being able to force out the Steel-types that would otherwise threaten them, like Aegislash and Scizor.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance turns Cinderace into a threatening wallbreaker, using its immense power to break through most defensive Pokemon that would otherwise switch into it comfortably. At +2, Breakneck Blitz manages to OHKO the likes of Slowbro after Libero. High Jump Kick is a necessary coverage option to let Cinderace reliably KO Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu. Cinderace fits best on hyper offense teams that benefit from its ability to break open defensive cores; as Cinderace is often revenge killed by faster Pokemon such as Sand Rush Excadrill and Choice Scarf Latias, other Pokemon that can take advantage of these revenge killers like Galarian Moltres, Swords Dance Scizor, and Bulk Up Galarian Zapdos become valuable teammates, as they also appreciate Cinderace's innate ability to threaten common walls such as Buzzwole and Skarmory. Cinderace also appreciates having dual screens support from Grimmsnarl to improve its setup opportunities, while anti-entry hazard options such as Excadrill and Iron Treads can help alleviate Cinderace's crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fire)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Inteleon is a strong wallbreaker that fits well on balance and bulky offense teams. U-turn allows it to pivot out on switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey while also forming strong VoltTurn cores with other pivots like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing that can wear down each other's checks with entry hazards up. Mud Shot allows it to threaten Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Cinderace that would otherwise switch into Inteleon freely. Ice Beam allows it to chip specially bulky Dragon-types like RegenVest Roaring Moon and Goodra, while Surf acts as a more reliable option late-game when the opposing team has been heavily chipped or to snipe frailer or slower targets like Azelf and both Zapdos formes. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon appreciate Inteleon pivoting into them on its switch-ins like the aforementioned Hisuian Goodra and Blissey as well as Inteleon's ability to threaten physical walls like Corviknight and defensive Quaquaval. Inteleon brings close to no defensive utility bar a Fire-type move immunity, which means that walls like Corviknight and Goodra are a must-have to make up for the lack of defensive utility; these Pokemon also switch into revenge killing attempts from Slither Wing and Regieleki. Inteleon appreciates Spikes support from Pokemon like Garchomp and Ting-Lu that helps it to wear down RegenVest Pokemon like Meloetta and Alolan Muk.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Physically defensive Corviknight is a fantastic check to dangerous attackers like Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite, an effective slow pivot, and one of the few viable entry hazard removers. Brave Bird nails the likes of Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, Meowscarada, Breloom, and Amoonguss, chips at neutral targets such as Azumarill, Hatterene, Dragapult, and Hisuian Zoroark. Body Press is Corviknight's best option against Kingambit and Roaring Moon. Leftovers is the preferred item to provide extra longevity, but Rocky Helmet can further punish physical attackers, especially on weak hits like Scizor's and Meowscarada's U-turn. Tera Water serves as an emergency check to dangerous Fire- and Water-types such as Cinderace and Floatzel. Alternatively, Tera Fighting grants it a resistance to Dark-type attacks and powers up its Body Press, letting it check Kingambit more easily.

Corviknight is a fantastic slow pivot, making it a great partner for frail-but-powerful teammates like Greninja and Iron Valiant. It is also one of the few viable Defoggers, allowing it to partner up with teammates like Dragonite that loathe Stealth Rock. Be warned, Corviknight is utterly unable to Defog against Gholdengo, so secondary entry hazard removal like Great Tusk and a reliable switch-in like Ting-Lu are recommended. Corviknight is unable to handle powerful physical Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge and Electric-types like Iron Hands. Teammates that can cover these weaknesses like Dondozo and Great Tusk are wonderful partners. Its middling special bulk makes teammates like Slowking and Ting-Lu valuable. Slowking has the added benefit of being another slow pivot as well, while Ting-Lu forms a strong entry hazard core with Corviknight and threatens Gholdengo.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Corviknight is a poor Defogger in the metagame, but its defensive profile still allows it to check Mega Lopunny, Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Kartana. It also individually beats hazard setters like Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Clodsire. Brave Bird is the preferred option that pressures Dragapult, Zamazenta, Urshifu-R, and Iron Valiant, while Body Press pressures Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Weavile. Iron Defense or Bulk Up can be used over Defog to turn Corviknight into a bulky win condition and to improve its ability to check threats like Kingambit, Urshifu-R, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Body Press should be used with Iron Defense, while Brave Bird can instead be used with Bulk Up. U-turn allows Corviknight to maintain momentum against the threats that it checks while also bringing in frailer teammates. The given HP and Defense EVs allow Corviknight to live a +2 Continental Crush from Landorus-T, while the rest of the EVs being in Special Defense helps out against Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Rocky Helmet allows Corviknight to chip threats like Mega Lopunny and Weavile. Tera Dragon removes Corviknight's Electric and Fire weaknesses and potentially allows it to turn the tables on Heatran and Rotom-W. Tera Ground can instead be used to halt Volt Switch attempts and surprise Tapu Koko, but the resistances it grants are not as consistently valuable as Dragon. Corviknight's biggest problem by far is Gholdengo, which blocks Corviknight's Defog attempts and sets up on it. Options that deal with it, such as Kingambit, Weavile, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire are therefore mandatory partners. U-turn can bring in the former two to Pursuit trap Gholdengo, while the latter two can stave it off defensively. Kingambit is especially potent with Corviknight, as it appreciates Corviknight's Rocky Helmet applying chip damage onto its checks like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta. U-turn can also bring in other threats safely, such as Dragapult, Walking Wake, and Heatran. Corviknight's defensive profile gets taken advantage of by threats like Heatran, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona, so options such as your own Heatran, Garchomp, and Toxapex can help out in this regard.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Corviknight is a formidable wincon that takes advantage of its typing and impressive bulk to garner boosts. It also provides a sturdy defensive backbone, consistently checking threats such as Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Dragonite. However, as Corviknight lacks immediate offensive presence and coverage, it suffers from being forced out by the likes of Zapdos and Heatran and being setup fodder from the likes of Kingambit and Gholdengo. Pressure, in conjunction with Substitute, allows Corviknight to PP stall checks like Heatran and Skarmory safely while bypassing status moves like Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp and Clefable's Thunder Wave. Tera Water improves the matchup against Heatran, Weavile, and Urshifu-R, giving crucial resistances to safely let Corviknight boost up. Alternatively, Tera Dragon lets it take on Electric-types like Zapdos and Rotom-W while also helping against Heatran and Urshifu-R. However, Pokemon like Mega Diancie, Weavile, and Dragapult can now almost always force it out, though they do have to watch out for repeated Brave Bird hits. The given EV spread maximizes special bulk while still being able to survive a +2 Continental Crush from Garchomp followed by Stone Edge after Roost; it also lets Corviknight outspeed Skarmory and become only 3HKOed by Great Tusk's Close Combat. However, note that Corviknight will be taking a super effective Body Press from Skarmory after using Roost. Corviknight fits best on bulkier teams, which appreciate its ability to PP stall threats like Heatran and Toxapex while being a solid wincon. Pokemon like Toxapex and Clefable thus work well with it. Toxapex appreciates Corviknight reliably checking Tapu Lele and Landorus-T for it. In return, Toxapex helps check Weavile, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny, which Corviknight struggles to do. Calm Mind Clefable loves Corviknight draining PP from opposing Toxapex’s Haze; in return, it softens up Heatran. Ground-types like Gliscor and Great Tusk make excellent partners, as they absorb Electric attacks from the likes of Tapu Koko and remove entry hazards from the field. In exchange, Corviknight helps take Kyurem and Iron Valiant’s attacks. Due to Corviknight being walled by Electric- and Steel-types, such as Zapdos and Gholdengo, partners that can threaten them such as Mega Tyranitar and Heatran work well with it.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Corviknight is one of the most versatile defensive pivots in AG, checking a myriad offensive threats such as Iron Bundle, Great Tusk, Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane while providing its team with invaluable entry hazard control. Iron Head OHKOes Flutter Mane and hits Chien-Pao hard. Alternatively, Body Press 2HKOes Iron Bundle and OHKOes Chien-Pao, but Brave Bird is also an option to hit Great Tusk and Annihilape harder and chip potential switch-ins more. The given EVs maximize Corviknight's physical bulk while ensuring that it always avoids a 2HKO from unboosted Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump. If Iron Head is used, Corviknight should instead run a spread of 252 HP / 4 Atk / 156 Def / 96 SpD to guarantee an OHKO on Flutter Mane. Tera Steel allows Corviknight to resist Ice moves, making it a better check to Chien-Pao, while also allowing it to take a hit from Double Dance Miraidon and avoid being 2HKOed by Gothitelle. Alternatively, Tera Water provides decent overall defensive utility while also letting Corviknight pivot into Flare Blitz from Koraidon in a pinch. A Relaxed nature and minimum Speed IVs ensure that Corviknight will U-turn after most defensive Pokemon, allowing it to generate safer switches for its teammates. Corviknight fits well on all manner of balance teams as a member of the defensive core, so teammates like Toxapex, Skeledirge, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire fit well alongside it thanks to their ability to handle Koraidon and Miraidon. Additionally, Corviknight works as a great enabler to common offensive Pokemon like Miraidon, Koraidon, and Chien-Pao, bringing them in freely with U-turn, and benefits greatly from their ability to pressure its biggest threat in Gholdengo.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
• Corviknight's high physical bulk gives it a strong defensive presence in the tier. It is one of the few consistent counters to strong Ground-types like Great Tusk, physical attackers like Chien-Pao, and some special attackers like non-Choice Specs Iron Bundle. Furthermore, its access to Defog also makes it a solid entry hazard remover, though it struggles against Gholdengo.
  • Body Press provides Corviknight with a way to leverage its high Defense stat, doing significant damage to Fighting-weak Pokemon.
  • Brave Bird allows Corviknight to threaten Flutter Mane and Great Tusk. Alternatively, Iron Head can be used to threaten the former while avoiding recoil damage.
  • Maximum HP investment and enough Defense to check Chien-Pao is combined with Leftovers and 96 Special Defense EVs, which allows Corviknight to take two Mystical Fires from most Flutter Mane, as well as giving it the ability to take on non-Choice Specs Iron Bundle and weaker attacks like Freeze-Dry from Choice Specs Iron Bundle.
  • Tera Steel or Flying can be used to shed the weaknesses of Corviknight's dual typing: Tera Steel allows Corviknight to resist Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao, while Tera Flying allows Corviknight to resist Great Tusk's Fighting-type attacks. Depending on your choice, Terastallization also amplifies the power of either Iron Head or Brave Bird.
  • Corviknight works well as a part of a defensive core with Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Blissey, which can handle threats like Miraidon that obliterate Corviknight. Additionally, Corviknight makes a great partner for offensive threats like Chi-Yu, which appreciate a teammate that easily switches into Ting-Lu, or Great Tusk, which appreciates opposing Great Tusk being worn down.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• Specially defensive Corviknight can switch into foes like Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Gholdengo, and Glimmora.
  • U-turn is used to make Corviknight an effective defensive pivot that can maintain momentum against foes that force it out such as Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Mirror Armor allows Corviknight to check Mystical Fire Flutter Mane, which would otherwise beat it. Alternatively, when paired with Pressure, Protect enables Corviknight to avoid being 2HKOed by Hydro Pump from Choice Specs Iron Bundle, as well as allowing Corviknight to deplete PP with Pressure more effectively.
  • Corviknight can use Tera Steel to get rid of its weakness to Electric and better take on Ice-type moves from Iron Bundle. Alternatively, it can opt to use Tera Ground to become immune to Miraidon's powerful Electro Drift.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight needs help dealing with strong physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao from teammates like Dondozo and Scream Tail. Furthermore, Pokemon that are especially threatened by Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, such as Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge, are able to rely on specially defensive Corviknight as a consistent switch-in.

sets.name: Defog (Flying)
sets.description:
Corviknight has easily cemented itself as a staple on Flying teams, acting as an extremely versatile defensive wall that can also remove entry hazards for its teammates. Iron Head allows Corviknight to handle Flutter Mane and other Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Hatterene. Body Press hits Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and other Dark- and Steel-types hard. On the other hand, U-turn safely brings in stronger attackers like Dragonite, Iron Jugulis, and Kilowattrel, providing extra counterplay against Pokemon such as Volcarona and Gholdengo, which commonly switch into Corviknight. Pressure is the preferred ability for PP stalling Stealth Rock, while Mirror Armor counters Flutter Mane and Hatterene, which would otherwise overwhelm Corviknight with Mystical Fire. With the listed EV spread and a Careful nature, Corviknight avoids a 2HKO from Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball while guaranteeing Iron Head OHKOes Flutter Mane in return. The remaining EVs are put into Defense to ease its matchup against physical threats such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Baxcalibur.

Corviknight's capability to take on many offensive threats combined with its Steel typing makes it a stellar asset that almost any offensive Pokemon benefits from. For instance, Iron Jugulis appreciates Corviknight removing Flutter Mane, and Flamigo struggles with Ice Shard variants of Chien-Pao, which Corviknight can safely switch into. Dragonite greatly benefits from Corviknight's ability to soak up Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type attacks while also covering Corviknight's weaknesses to Fire- and Electric-types such as Cinderace, Magnezone, and Volcarona. Gyarados can also act as a reliable wincon against types like Fire and Ground while also making Chien-Pao significantly more managable with Intimidate. Additionally, Kilowattrel is a great offensive pivot to pair with Corviknight, as it removes threats that could harm Corviknight like Greninja, Volcarona, and Azumarill while also absorbing Electric-type attacks. In return, Corviknight counters Iron Treads and Ting-Lu, which threaten Kilowattrel. Pelipper can be paired with Kilowattrel and Corviknight to form a potent rain core that softens the impact of Fire moves and gives Kilowattrel a Water-type Weather Ball, OHKOing many Fire-types that annoy Corviknight including Skeledirge and Rotom-H. Corviknight appreciates having Talonflame as an alternative option against physical attackers, as Talonflame is able to hold off Chien-Pao and burn Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Dragonite, tremendously easing Corviknight's role.

sets.name: Bulk Up (Steel)
sets.description:
Corviknight is an exceptional wincon for Steel teams due to its unmatched bulk and great dual typing, capable of easily snowballing Ground and Fighting teams. Body Press targets Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon that resist Brave Bird or could take advantage of its recoil like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Iron Treads, as well as capitalizes off of the Defense boost given by Bulk Up. Alternatively, Taunt prevents Ting-Lu from phazing Corviknight out with Whirlwind and breaks passive teams like Poison due to the prominence of Haze and recovery moves, while Substitute makes it harder to shut down once setup and stalls out Landorus-T's Smack Down. Leftovers provides much-needed recovery and is almost always the preferred item; however, Occa Berry + Body Press can surprise Heatran and Flamethrower Hydreigon. An alternative EV spread of 248 HP / 80 Def / 180 SpD with an Impish nature allows Corviknight to survive Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R after a Swords Dance, as well as prevents Zamazenta from breaking Substitute with Body Press.

Heatran is a great teammate, as it switches into Fire-type moves from Iron Moth, Scovillain, and Moltres and traps and removes Toxapex so Corviknight doesn't need to use Taunt. In return, Corviknight provides an immunity to Ground-type attacks directed at Heatran as well as a Fighting-type neutrality. Gholdengo threatens out Skeledirge and Iron Valiant and takes advantage of walls like Toxapex, opposing Corviknight, and Klefki by setting up Nasty Plot freely. Kingambit checks Ghost-type threats such as Dragapult, Spectrier, and Flutter Mane, as well as heavily wears down teams so Corviknight can setup relatively easily and clean up late-game. Hisuian Goodra is a great specially defenisve tank, taking on Greninja, Basculegion-F, and Volcanion as well as opposing Heatran. Iron Treads offers an Electric-type immunity, handling threats such as Zapdos, Regieleki, and Sandy Shocks, as well as luring Landorus in for a potential KO with Ice Spinner.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Pivot Knight
sets.description:
• Corviknight's fantastic typing makes it one of the best pivots in the metagame; it easily gets dangerous teammates such as Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult in.

  • Body Press versus Iron Head: Body Press has decent damage output and helps massively against common Dark-types like Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Meanwhile, Iron Head ensures that Corviknight will not be walled by Flutter Mane, Mimikyu, and Dragapult.

  • Taunt: Corviknight might not be fast, but it's fast enough to shut down most other defensive Pokemon with Taunt, such as Dondozo and Toxapex.

  • Brave Bird: Brave Bird can be difficult to fit in, but it's a fantastic response against Breloom, and means Corviknight doesn't have to be passive against Amoonguss and Brute Bonnet.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Corviknight's defensive typing is fantastic, so don't Terastallize too hastily, or else it'll lose to threats it normally checks.

  • Dragon: Dragon and Fairy weaknesses are devastating, but in the late-game, resisting Electric and Fire can give Corviknight new win conditions against old foes such as Rotom-W, and a shot to seriously damage Chi-Yu with Body Press. Just note that Modest Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu can still OHKO with Overheat.

  • Fighting: Getting STAB on Body Press can give Corviknight a surprisingly decent chance at cleaning weakened teams, with being able to 3HKO specially defensive Ting-Lu being a highlight.

  • Water: With Tera Water, Corviknight consistently survives all but Modest Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu's Overheat, letting it deal serious damage with Body Press. It also gains a key resistance to Ice for Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur.

  • Flying: While this set doesn't always use Brave Bird, Tera Flying lets Corviknight keep its typing while using Roost, meaning Earthquake and Fissure can no longer hit Corviknight while its restoring health.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: This lets Corviknight wear down physical threats more quickly while pivoting.

  • Safety Goggles: Safety Goggles ensures Corviknight won't be impacted by Spore from Breloom, Amoonguss, or Brute Bonnet, regardless of having Taunt.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers's consistent recovery can be quite helpful for taking repeated hits from Ruination when attempting to stall it out with Pressure.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: Mirror Armor's ability to punish Flutter Mane for using Mystical Fire makes it the best ability choice on Corviknight.

  • Pressure: Corviknight's excellent bulk makes Pressure a good alternative for stalling out foes such as Dondozo, and is particularly good at stalling out Ruination from Ting-Lu and Wo-Chien.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Corviknight stands out as one of the best choices around for sweeping with Iron Defense and Body Press, thanks to its excellent typing and Roost.

  • Taunt: This lets Corviknight effectively shut down slower defensive Pokemon, such as Dondozo and Clodsire.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head helps Corviknight check Mimikyu more easily, especially if not running Rocky Helmet. It also prevents Corviknight from being walled by Flutter Mane and Dragapult.

  • U-turn: While U-turn with this set may seem strange, Corviknight is still a decent pivot even if it must give up Taunt.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Corviknight has a fantastic defensive typing, so only Terastallize if you need to win certain matchups, especially since it becomes vulnerable to Toxic.

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Body Press is easier to sweep with, with many Ting-Lu variants now being 2HKOed by boosted Body Press.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Corviknight a way to resist both Chien-Pao's and Chi-Yu's most powerful STAB attacks, though Modest Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu can still OHKO with Overheat.

  • Dragon: A Dragon Tera type lets Corviknight resist common attacks aimed at it, such as Electric- and Fire-type attacks. However, the new weaknesses to Fairy and Dragon make this an especially reactive Terastallization.

  • Flying: A Flying Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing even when using Roost, making it a more reliable check to Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: The passive damage from Rocky Helmet against Mimikyu gives Corviknight a much easier time using Taunt over Iron Head.

  • Covert Cloak: When paired with Taunt, Covert Cloak makes Corviknight an effective Garganacl check, though note Corviknight will no longer drop Flutter Mane's Special Attack with Mirror Armor.

  • Safety Goggles: With Safety Goggles blocking Spore, this Corviknight is now an excellent check against most offensive Breloom, just watch out for the occasional Tera Fire Breloom.

  • Sitrus Berry versus Leftovers: Since this Corviknight attempts to sweep, Sitrus Berry's burst of quick recovery can make it less pressured to spend a turn using Roost. Leftovers on the other hand, will still keep healing Corviknight even after being hit by Ruination, so it can make sense with Pressure.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: Mirror Armor means Flutter Mane can't use Mystical Fire without getting its Special Attack dropped, unless Corviknight is holding Covert Cloak.

  • Pressure: Corviknight's ability to take powerful, low PP moves such as Close Combat after Iron Defense makes Pressure a viable alternative, in addition to giving Corviknight a better chance of dealing with Ruination from Ting-Lu and Wo-Chien effectively.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• With Bulk Up giving an Attack boost, Corviknight is free from having to use Body Press for good damage output, making it easier to run Taunt against defensive foes without fear of being walled by Ghost-types.

  • Iron Head versus Brave Bird: Iron Head reliably 2HKOs Chien-Pao without a boost, while Brave Bird is the only hope of 2HKOing Chi-Yu.

Other Options

  • Power Trip: Power Trip takes several boosts to get powerful, but it's Corviknight's best shot at dealing decent damage to Gholdengo. It's also an important aspect of Espathra Baton Pass teams, but Ting-Lu has made this team archetype much more difficult to use compared to past regulations.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Remember that most of Corviknight's good Tera types leave it vulnerable to Toxic, so Terastallize carefully and only win a win condition is clear.

  • Flying: This Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing while using Roost, meaning Fissure users such as Dondozo are much easier to handle.

  • Water: Tera Water is an effective tool against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, though note that Choice Specs Chi-Yu can OHKO with Tera Fire boosted Overheat.

  • Dragon: Once Fairy-, Ice-, and Dragon-types are out of the way, the Dragon Tera type allows Corviknight to get around Electric- and Fire-type attacks.

  • Dark: If using Power Trip, Tera Dark is highly recommended to boost its damage output.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: In addition to punishing Flutter Mane for using Mystical Fire when not using Covert Cloak, Mirror Armor also protects Corviknight from Charm, Chilling Water, and Intimidate.

  • Pressure: Pressure is a reasonable alternative for whittling down PP, which can be especially helpful against Ting-Lu's troublesome Ruination.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: When paired with Taunt, Corviknight can effectively take down Garganacl.

  • Safety Goggles: While Substitute and Taunt are effective against slower users of Spore like Amoonguss, Breloom's Speed means Safety Goggles are required to truly check it.

  • Sitrus Berry versus Leftovers: Sitrus Berry is preferred due to the quicker burst of recovery better fitting a sweeper, but Leftovers can work very well with Pressure in an attempt to out-stall Ruination.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Corviknight is simultaneously the best physical wall and Defogger in AAA, making it a staple on most teams. Intimidate is the preferred ability to better check Chien-Pao and potentially pass off a weakened attacker to a teammate, while Fluffy offers more overall walling potential against Galarian Zapdos and Kingambit; more rarely, immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Volt Absorb can be used, but they lack walling capabilities against neutral attackers. Brave Bird is its strongest available attack and threatens Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Quaquaval, while Body Press beats Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Corviknight is exceedingly passive on its own, but minimum Speed investment + U-turn allows it to bring in powerful offensive teammates like Slither Wing, Iron Moth, and Cinderace easily. RegenVest teammates like Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra cover the special attackers that like to come in on Corviknight, and they appreciate U-turn's extra chances to cycle in safely and gain additional Regenerator recovery. Corviknight is powerless to check dangerous physical Fire-types like Talonflame, Cinderace, and Ceruledge, making a secondary physical check like Garchomp or Well-Baked Body Iron Treads a good pairing. Corviknight needs to be at nearly 100% health to check foes like Galarian Zapdos and Chien-Pao, making secondary hazard removal options like Iron Treads and Quaquaval useful.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description: Prankster Corviknight’s excellent typing, solid bulk, and tailor-made movepool make it a premier dual screens lead for hyper offense teams. Taunt blocks entry hazards and denies setup attempts from opposing leads looking to capitalize on Corviknight’s passivity, while U-turn lets Corviknight, with its relatively low Speed, usually bring in a teammate safely. 64 Speed EVs outpace Prankster Spidops, allowing Corviknight to deny Sticky Web. Prankster Corviknight should be found exclusively on hyper offense teams with teammates like Volcarona, Zamazenta-C, and Chien-Pao that can take advantage of dual screens support to set up safely. Corviknight is unable to prevent Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Chien-Pao from setting hazards or setting up, so strong Fighting-type anti-leads like Slither Wing make excellent teammates.

sets.name: Shell Smash (Rock)
sets.description:
Drednaw is a fierce setup sweeper, capable of turning the tide against unfavorable matchups like Ground, Steel, and Water. Stone Edge is Drednaw's hardest hitting move, dealing with Chien-Pao, Pelipper, and Dragonite. Liquidation hits troublesome Ground-types like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu. Earthquake threatens Water Absorb Clodsire, Toxapex, and Kingambit, while Strong Jaw-boosted Crunch nails switch-ins such as Slowbro, Brambleghast, and Bronzong. Swift Swim is preferred to aid Rock in the matchup against Water rain teams; however, Strong Jaw allows Drednaw to muscle through the aforementioned roadblocks when using Crunch. Air Balloon improves Drednaw's performance in the Ground matchup, allowing for more setup opportunities, while White Herb retains Drednaw's defensive stats to have an improved chance against priority move users like Azumarill, Mimikyu, and Kingambit.

Garganacl's ability to pressure Gastrodon, Quagsire, and Corviknight with Salt Cure is heavily appreciated, easing Drednaw's time sweeping. Glimmora's colorful movepool allows it to check a myriad of threats like Breloom, Meowscarada, and Iron Valiant with Sludge Wave, Great Tusk, Quagsire, and Quaquaval using Energy Ball, Gholdengo, Toxapex, and Toxicroak with Earth Power, and finally Hydreigon, Chien-Pao, and Gallade using Dazzling Gleam. Choice Band Tyranitar heavily dents walls such as Corviknight, Slowbro, and Toxapex and sets up sand to increase Drednaw's bulk. Lycanroc aids in the Dark matchup due to its useful coverage in Close Combat and Play Rough and takes out faster foes like Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane with Accelerock. Coalossal provides entry hazards in Spikes and Stealth Rock, removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin, and helps against Gholdengo and Meowscarada due to its Fire typing.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Rock)
sets.description:
Coalossal is a decent defensive wall that fits well on Rock teams due to it being able to tank physical hits from Scizor, non-Choice Band Chien-Pao, and Meowscarada, which greatly threaten Rock teams. Coalossal does well in the Steel matchup, as it threatens Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Kingambit. Flame Body allows it to fish for burns to weaken physical threats like Kleavor, Scizor, Kingambit, Mimikyu, and Meowscarada. Body Press is a great move thanks to Coalossal's high Defense stat that allows it to deal incredible damage to Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Rapid Spin combined with Heavy-Duty Boots allows Coalossal to come in and remove hazards without taking any chip damage, so its teammates won't get worn down. Will-O-Wisp allows Coalossal to burn physical threats such as Kleavor, Hoopa-U, and Iron Hands. An alternative EV spread of 252 HP / 92 Def / 164 Spe allows Coalossal to outspeed and burn uninvested Kingambit with Will-O-Wisp. Spikes is another option to run on Coalossal over Will-O-Wisp to help Rock teams stack hazards and wear down foes.

Garganacl helps Coalossal by dealing with defensive Pokemon like Quagsire, Gastrodon, and Heatran with Salt Cure. In return Garganacl appreciates Coalossal checking Meowscarada. Air Balloon Shell Smash Drednaw is another good teammate for Coalossal, providing a soft Ground-type immunity and dealing with Ground- and Steel- types like Landorus-T, Sandy Shocks, Iron Treads, Heatran, and Hisuian-Goodra. Choice Scarf Glimmora with its diverse moveset is another option to pair with Coalossal, as it can outspeed and threaten to OHKO non-Choice Scarf users like Iron Valiant and Greninja. Glimmora can also deal with Water-, Fighting-, Dark-, and Dragon- Types like Quagsire, Hisuian Liligant, Hisuian Samurott, and Hydreigon with its various coverage moves. Furthermore, Glimmora run Air Balloon to act as an alternative Ground-type immunity that can deal with threats like Quagsire and Great Tusk. Tyranitar sets sand for Coalossal to boosts its Special Defense, which can allow Coalossal to tank special attacks from Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Choice Specs Magnezone and threaten them in return. Choice Band Lycanroc-D is a good revenge killer that can help out Coalossal by taking out threats such as Enamorus and Cloyster with Accelerock and Urshifu-R and Clodsire with Psychic Fangs. Hisuian Arcanine is another good revenge killer with Extreme Speed and can act as a wallbreaker, taking out foes such as Toxapex and Clodsire with Head Smash and Flare Blitz, respectively. Kleavor is a good lead for Rock teams, as it can deal damage while setting up Stealth Rock with Stone Axe, which helps with hazard stacking. In return, Coalossal complements Kleavor by dealing with Scizor. Diancie can ease the Fighting match by dealing decent damage to Gallade and Iron Valiant with Moonblast and by being able to take Fighting-type moves due to its Fairy-typing. In return, Coalossal helps Diancie by dealing with Scizor, Kingambit and Meowscarada.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Flapple's unique offensive typing, naturally high Attack stat, decent Speed stat, and acess to an amazing boosting move in Dragon Dance allow it to become one of PU's most devastating wallbreakers. Dragon Dance means Flapple is able to boost its damage output while also being able to outspeed common threats such as Charizard, Dachsbun, and Rotom-F. Sucker Punch can gives Flapple priority to finish off weakened foes. Tera Blast can be used with Tera Ground to threaten Steel-types such as Perrserker and Tinkatuff, which would otherwise counter Flapple. On Ripen sets, Flapple can opt for Arcobatics, giving it strong coverage into foes such as Gogoat, Crabominable, and Rabsca.
