  • Hex becomes stronger than Shadow Ball when boosted by status; it should only be used with Will-O-Wisp or with Toxic Spikes support from Pokemon like Toxapex and Clodsire.
  • Will-O-Wisp cripples common Dragapult switch-ins such as Ting-Lu, Toxapex, and Clodsire.
  • Tera Ghost lets Dragapult 2HKO Toxapex with Shadow Ball and Clodsire with a boosted Hex; it also retains Dragapult's useful Fighting immunity while giving it a neutrality to Dragon- and Fairy-type attacks, letting it survive a Dragon Claw from Choice Scarf Koraidon in a pinch.
  • Dragapult is a revenge killer best suited for bulky offense teams that can't afford to run frail Speed-boosting Pokemon.
  • Strong wallbreakers like Choice Band Koraidon and Chien-Pao are recommended as teammates, as Dragapult lacks immediate breaking power. Defensive Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Toxapex, and Clodsire are also helpful, as they can setup Spikes or spread status to help Dragapult break more easily.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Dragapult is a good pivot in Ubers thanks to its high Speed stat and support moves like Will-O-Wisp and U-turn; its decent bulk also lets it switch into walls like Toxapex and Corviknight without fearing much, making it a surprisingly decent annoyance against bulkier teams.
  • The given EVs allow for Dragon Darts to 2HKO Clodsire after Spikes damage.
  • U-turn lets Dragapult pivot out of checks like Ting-Lu. Substitute can be used instead, easing prediction and allowing Dragapult to click Will-O-Wisp more freely.
  • A boosted Hex will chip down every Dragapult check bar Blissey, making it potentially dangerous if entry hazards are up.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots allows Dragapult to switch in without fear of entry hazards such as Spikes and Toxic Spikes. Leftovers is Dragapult's only form of recovery.
  • Tera Ghost lets Dragapult 2HKO Corviknight with a boosted Hex after Stealth Rock damage while retaining its useful immunity to Fighting. Tera Dragon can be used instead, as it allows Dragapult to 2HKO Blissey, but it doesn't offer much outside of that; Dragon is also a bad defensive typing in Ubers.
  • Pivot Dragapult is best suited for entry hazard-stacking teams, as these teams greatly appreciate Dragapult's ability to outspeed and keep in check various threats to them, such as Iron Bundle. Dragapult appreciates entry hazards weakening its checks in return.
  • Pokemon that can spread status for Dragapult, such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, also make good partners.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Dragon)
sets.description:
As the fastest unboosted Pokemon in the Monotype metagame, Choice Specs Dragapult is an excellent offensive threat that deals with Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Greninja for Dragon teams. Draco Meteor and Shadow Ball are helpful against a variety of types lacking the necessary immunities and can be used to decimate types such as Dark, Flying, Fairy, and Ghost. Flamethrower roasts Steel-types such as Corviknight and Scizor without the risk of getting stalled by Pressure, and Thunderbolt nails Toxapex and Dondozo and cleans Water teams late-game. Alternatively, U-turn brings in team mates like Baxcalibur, Garchomp, and Hydreigon, which take advantage of common switch-ins such as Ting Lu, Clodsire, and Kingambit. Infiltrator lets Dragapult bypass dual screens, which is sorely needed to properly deal with Flutter Mane.

Since Dragapult excels at cleaning teams with its natural speed, wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Hydreigon, Baxcalibur, and Choice Band Haxorus, as well as entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Dragalge are excellent teammates. Dragonite loves Dragapult's ability to wear down or outright remove Steel-, Water-, and Ghost-types such as Klefki, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, allowing it to clean up types such as Fairy, Water, and Fire with a Dragon Dance or Choice Band set. Choice Scarf users like Baxcalibur, Hydreigon, and Roaring Moon are appreciated, as these deal with opposing Choice Scarf users such as Gallade and Gholdengo, which revenge kill Dragapult with ease. Cyclizar provides entry hazard removal and can pass a Shed Tail to Dragapult, allowing it to get in the field safely.

sets.name: Dragon Dance (Ghost)
sets.description:
Dragon Dance gives Dragapult the ability to not just boost its fantastic Speed to new heights, allowing it to outspeed fast Choice Scarf users such as Meowscarada and Roaring Moon, but also beef up its decent Attack stat. Dragon Darts is a reliable, hard-hitting Dragon-type STAB move that allows Dragapult to break Breloom's Focus Sash and Dragonite's Multiscale. Phantom Force is Dragapult's best choice for Ghost-tpye STAB move, as otherwise it is walled by any Fairy- or Steel-type, while Disable can disrupt Choice-locked Pokemon from potentially breaking its Substitute or attacking Dragapult in general. Substitute allows Dragapult to ease prediction and also adds a layer of protection against status moves, allowing it to set up on more passive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss. It also synergizes well with Disable, allowing Dragapult to set up with ease. Will-O-Wisp is another option over Disable to allow Clodsire and Quagsire to become setup bait, while also crippling Kingambit and Ting-Lu; however, Disable is more consistent. Leftovers allows Dragapult to use Substitute multiple times throughout a game and be more annoying overall with Disable, while Dragon Fang is a good choice to boost Dragon Darts.

Skeledirge is a fantastic partner, as it can wall Fairy-types such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and Hatterene while also threatening foes like Kingambit that can easily take out Dragapult with their STAB priority moves. Gholdengo is another fantastic partner that can threaten Fairy-types like Klefki and Flutter Mane, if Gholdengo uses a Choice Scarf, and take care of physical walls such as opposing Skeledirge. Brambleghast is another good partner, as it can keep entry hazards off of the field, allowing Dragapult to come in multiple times, as well as providing Spikes support to soften up Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Iron Treads. Hisuian Zoroark provides the team with not just a Ghost immunity, but also can easily use Illusion to disguise itself as Dragapult and lure in foes that would normally threaten it, such as Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and opposing Dragapult, to open up for a potential Dragapult sweep. Flutter Mane is another great partner thanks to its ability to handle opposing Dragon-types such as Baxcalibur, Roaring Moon, and Walking Wake. It can also provide immediate speed control if need be to take care of other Choice Scarf users that could revenge kill Dragapult before it gets a Dragon Dance up. Mimikyu is an amazing wallbreaker that can either help wear down physical walls for Dragapult to clean up or can take advantage of Dragapult punching holes in the opponent's team to clean up itself. Mimikyu can also heavily threaten opposing Ghost-types for Dragapult like Choice Scarf Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo thanks to its STAB priority in Shadow Sneak. It also provides a one-time check to setup sweepers such as Chien-Pao and Kingambit thanks to its ability Disguise.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Dragapult's blistering Speed makes it a very effective hit-and-run attacker.

  • Phantom Force: This is risky due to the two turns making Dragapult vulnerable to Normal-types and surprise Terastallization, but it still makes an effective late-game cleaning move.

  • Sucker Punch: Despite Dragapult's dynamite Speed stat, Sucker Punch still makes sense to pick off common Choice Scarf holders like Gholdengo, and play around priority from other foes.

  • Shadow Ball: With a Naive nature, Shadow Ball is an easy way to 2HKO Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, and incoming Skeledirge.

Other Options

  • Dragon Dance: Dragon Dance is fairly difficult to set up without Focus Sash, and it can lead to coverage issues. That being said, outspeeding Pokemon that commonly have their Speed boosted via an item, such as Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and Iron Bundle, can lead to surprising win conditions.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Dragapult's cleaning capabilities are improved quite a bit by Terastallization, though it doesn't need to rely on it to be functional.

  • Dragon: Boosting the power of Dragon Darts makes Dragapult very effective at shredding through Focus Sash Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, in addition to removing the annoying Sucker Punch weakness.

  • Steel: Steel has a fantastic synergy with Dragapult's former typing, giving it a far better match-up against foes such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Mimikyu.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost is notable for letting Dragapult use a less risky STAB move in Tera Blast.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives a valuable Fairy-type resistance and is a more powerful tool against Steel-types at the cost of a Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's Dragon-type immunity can help win Tera wars against foes like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting vastly improves Dragapult's match-up against Kingambit, Chi-Yu, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Meowscarada.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band guarantees that Breloom is OHKOed through its Focus Sash with Dragon Darts, and gives a 75% shot to the same happening to Chien-Pao.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Sucker Punch a less risky option.

  • Focus Sash: Dragaoult's bulk isn't terrible, but Focus Sash will save it from the huge amount of top tier Pokemon that are capable of OHKOing it, such as Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Gholdengo.

  • Choice Scarf: This may seem like overkill, but Choice Scarf gives Dragapult the edge over Booster Energy users such as Iron Bundle, Roaring Moon, and Flutter Mane, and other Choice Scarf foes such Gholdengo.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• Despite the lower offensive stat, the higher base power of Dragapult's special attacks makes it a serious threat.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is the recommended coverage move for hitting Corviknight and Dondozo hard.

  • U-turn: Even though it's weak, U-turn is a reasonable consideration for pivoting and breaking Mimikyu's Disguise.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Dragapult can use Terastallization to surprise its checks, the high power of Draco Meteor and good coverage Shadow Ball provides mean it isn't reliant on it to function.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon makes Draco Meteor nearly impossible to wall without a resistance, with even specially defensive Ting-Lu taking nearly 50% from it!

  • Fire: The Fairy-type resistance and powerful Flamethrower can make the Stealth Rock weakness worth it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel covers much of Dragapult's common weaknesses, and gives it a good Tera Blast to use against Fairy-types.

  • Ghost: Powering up Shadow Ball is perfect for cleaning up late-game, with only Normal-types and bulky resistances such as Ting-Lu, Wo-Chien, and Garganacl taking it well.

  • Fighting: The resistance to Sucker Punch Tera Fighting provides can be key in stopping Chien-Pao and Kingambit.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Dragapult's match-up against other Dragon-types, Great Tusk, and resists Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Bulky Status
sets.description:
• With usable bulk bolstered by Will-O-Wisp, this Dragapult can severely punish its weaker offensive checks, and surprise common users of Sucker Punch such as Kingambit and Chien-Pao.

  • Disable and Substitute: Disable makes Dragapult rely on Will-O-Wisp for Normal-types, but when combined with Substitute, it defeats Choice-locked foes and those that rely on one specific move to beat Dragapult.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor improves Dragapult against other Dragon-types, such as Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Flamethrower: This lets Dragapult deal decent unconditional damage to Steel-types, with Kingambit being the biggest target.

  • Dragon Darts: With a Naive nature, Dragon Darts gives Dragapult a consequence-free Dragon-type attack and decent mixed attacking potential.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Dragapult's typing gives it a lot of weaknesses, so Terastallization can help it stick around much longer, though the lack of good recovery means this isn't always the correct choice.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Dragapult preforms better against Dark-types it may still struggle with after Will-O-Wisp, such as Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu.

  • Steel: Steel Tera type is great for general defense and Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Mimikyu.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Dragapult's high Speed combined with Reflect and Light Screen make it an effective dual screens lead.

  • Curse: Curse reduces Dragapult's HP to get it off the field quickly once it has set up screens. It also forces opponents to use recovery moves or switch out, allowing Dragapult's teammates to get in and set up safely. Curse is Dragapult’s best option to bypass Substitute, Protect, and Mimikyu.

  • Shadow Ball: This breaks Focus Sash, hits Ghosts like Gholdengo and Flutter Mane that normally threaten it, and breaks Mimikyu's Disguise. Notably Gholdengo stops Curse with Good as Gold, making Dragapult totally helpless against it if it does not carry Shadow Ball.

  • Dragon Darts: Dragon Darts can be used for more power to make Dragapult more self-sufficient when it has to stay on the field, and breaks Focus Sash as well. Its dual-hit nature makes it bypass most Substitutes.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Will-O-Wisp can be used to cripple physical attackers. In tandem with Reflect, this can be a potent strategy to allow the next Pokemon to set up nearly risk-free.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Very Situational: As a dual screens lead, Terastallizing can compromise its teammates sweeping abilities, so it should only be done in emergencies.

  • Ghost / Dragon: If you are in a bad spot, Ghost and Dragon power up its STAB move of choice.

  • Steel: A defensive typing like Steel can allow Dragapult to survive certain moves like Iron Bundle's Ice Beam, boosted Cloyster's Icicle Spear, and boosted Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and retaliate.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type is useful for enemy Infiltrator Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

Items

  • Focus Sash: While Light Clay is standard, Focus Sash nearly guarantees setting at least one screen without having to Terastallize, in the event Dragapult leads off against Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Outrage is Dragapult's strongest move. It can defeat foes like Meowscarada and deal great damage against neutral enemies, such as Arcanine and Bellibolt.
  • Dragon Darts handles foes that may use Haban Berry, like Salamence and Garchomp.
  • Phantom Force defeats some Ghost-types like Skeledirge.
  • U-turn defeats Booster Energy Brute Bonnet, unless it raises Attack with Booster Energy.
  • Infiltrator enables Dragapult to win against Espathra.
  • Clear Body allows Dragapult to win against stall Azumarill, bulky Salamence, and stall Arcanine.
  • Being Adamant enables Dragapult to defeat Air Balloon and Booster Energy Iron Hands, the latter if it raises Attack with Booster Energy.
  • If running Jolly, Dragapult can outspeed Booster Energy Iron Bundle if it does not raise its Speed with Booster Energy.
  • Usually Dragapult should use its strongest move against the foe, but in the Annihilape matchup, Dragapult can win against some sets if it uses Outrage on the first turn, instead of Phantom Force, and Annihilape uses Bulk Up.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Neutral targets that lose to Dragapult's STAB attacks include non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, Meowscarada, Donphan, and Rotom-W.
  • Fire Blast OHKOes Scizor.
  • Hydro Pump is for non-Speed Booster Energy variants of Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Sandy Shocks.
  • Thunderbolt is for non-Choice Band Dondozo and Corviknight.
  • Clear Body ensures that Dragapult's Special Attack isn't lowered by Bellibolt's Eerie Impulse. Infiltrator lets Dragapult bypass Substitute from Volcarona and Espathra.
  • Dragapult should try to avoid possible matchups against faster Pokemon such as Speed Booster Energy Walking Wake, and Iron Bundle and Choice Scarf Meowscarada, as their set versatility is high and potential matchups sometimes won't be in Dragapult's favor.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Dragon Dance Dragapult is one of the most dangerous setup sweepers in the tier due to its blazing Speed and immense power. After a Dragon Dance, Dragapult outspeeds all Choice Scarf and Booster Energy users, such as Kartana, Greninja, and Iron Valiant, making it extremely hard to stop if it sets up successfully. Ghostium Z-powered Phantom Force enables a boosted Dragapult to blast through bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Heatran after slight chip damage. Dragapult's typing gives it opportunities to switch in and set up against certain Pokemon such as Volcarona, non-Ice Spinner Dragonite, and Urshifu-R locked into a Fighting-type move. Substitute is the preferred option in the last moveslot to ease prediction and facilitate setup while also avoiding priority. Substitute also allows Dragapult to play mind games with Kingambit. Fire Blast is another option that allows Dragapult to deal massive damage to physically defensive Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor, both of which can survive a boosted Never-Ending Nightmare at full health. Clear Body is the preferred ability to avoid stat drops from Intimidate, but Infiltrator can also be used to improve the matchup against dual screens teams. A Jolly nature lets Dragapult outspeed Mega Lopunny and Tapu Koko prior to setting up. Dragon Dance Dragapult fits best on offensive teams, where it can function as a potent late-game cleaner with its Z-Move. Entry hazard support from Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Glimmora can help chip bulky foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit into range of Dragapult's attacks. Gholdengo can block attempts to remove entry hazards, as well as pressure certain physical walls that give Dragapult a hard time, such as Ferrothorn. Dragapult can struggle with bulky physical walls such as Dondozo, Garganacl, and post-Tera Skeledirge, so powerful special wallbreakers that can take advantage of these Pokemon, such as Tapu Lele and Mega Charizard Y, are greatly appreciated. Tapu Lele also provides Psychic Terrain, which thwarts revenge killing attempts from priority moves. A late-game cleaner such as Dragonite or Booster Energy Iron Valiant can take advantage of the holes Dragapult left behind in the enemy defensive core.

sets.name: Hex
sets.description: Despite Hex Dragapult's lack of immediate offensive presence, it can be a very annoying threat; it excels in getting around many of Dragapult's normal checks and counters, pivoting to dangerous teammates, and spreading status. Against common checks like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Toxapex, it can bring in Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Great Tusk, and Tapu Koko, respectively, to punish the opponent. Will-O-Wisp boosts Hex to monstrous levels and threatens to pacify physical attackers like Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Kingambit. Dragon Darts is a strong physical move to better hit special walls like Clodsire, forcing it to recover lest Dragapult's teammates like Iron Valiant break through. With Tera Ghost, it can muscle through specially defensive Toxapex after burn and entry hazard damage with Hex, though Tera Fairy helps it tank hits from opposing Dragapult and Dark-type moves like Pursuit, and it can still check Zamazenta. Infiltrator allows it to check threats behind Substitutes, such as Iron Defense Zamazenta. Dragapult struggles to break through Heatran, so Pokemon that can pressure it such as Garchomp and Rotom-W are great partners. It also must be careful around Pursuit trappers like Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, as even after a burn they heavily chip it; teammates like Urshifu-R, Iron Valiant, and Great Tusk are thus mandatory to threaten said trappers. Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Mega Charizard Y very much appreciate Dragapult crippling and weakening Kingambit and Tyranitar, respectively, as this aids in the process of removing them. In return, Dragapult can clean up the opposing team after its checks are gone. Pivots like Rotom-W and Corviknight bring Dragapult in, with the former checking Heatran and forming a nice VoltTurn core with it, and the latter tanking Dragon- and Fairy-type moves for it. Entry hazards and Knock Off from the likes of Ferrothorn and Great Tusk weaken the opposition for Dragapult to clean, notably its checks like Toxapex and Clodsire.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Dragapult is a menacing wallbreaker, being able to threaten many teams with its STAB Shadow Ball and Draco Meteor. The former in particular is very spammable, as only a limited pool of Pokemon can switch into it. U-turn takes advantage of this limited pool, pressuring Shadow Ball switch-ins like Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar while bringing in teammates such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta. Flamethrower hits Kingambit for massive damage, while Hydro Pump helps against Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu. Finally, Thunder pressures would-be checks, such as Toxapex. Ghost is the best Tera type for Dragapult, as it propels its Shadow Ball to a near-unstoppable level, making it even more spammable. Dragon boosts Draco Meteor's damage while making Dragapult less susceptible to Pursuit, while Tera Fairy purely helps it defensively: not only does it not fear Pursuit, but it's also not weak to Ice Shard or Sucker Punch from Weavile and Kingambit, respectively. Finally, it gives Dragapult a Dragon immunity, which allows you to beat Dragon Dance Dragapult after it burns the Z-Move. Dragapult must be wary of Pursuit from Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit, as they can both shrug off multiple Shadow Balls and remove it from the game. However, it can pivot around its checks, so Pokemon that can take advantage of and remove them make great partners, such as Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant. The latter two also share checks with Dragapult, like Clodsire and Toxapex, meaning they can overwhelm these checks. Dragapult also greatly appreciates Knock Off support from Tornadus-T, Weavile, or Ferrothorn, as its checks such as Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Garganacl all rely a lot on their items. Finally, since checks such as the aforementioned Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit are very susceptible to Spikes, Dragapult appreciates its setters such as Ting-Lu, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon.

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: Ice Scales Zacian is an effective special wall against prominent special attackers like Palkia-O and Arceus-Ghost. Spirit Break dissuades setup from Arceus formes, Eternatus, and Palkia-O, though Magical Torque is a stronger alternative. While seemingly counter-productive with Spirit Break, Haze is the best option to neuter Nasty Plot Palkia-O and Arceus-Ghost, and it also ensures Zacian beats No Retreat Arceus-Ghost. Spikes provides support for the team and makes progress against Strength Sap users. Spirit Shackle traps Imposter users, preventing them from recovering health for free on Zacian. Toxic punishes most setup special attackers like Calm Mind Arceus formes. Covert Cloak prevents burns from Palkia-O's Steam Eruption and protects against status conditions inflicted by Nuzzle and Mortal Spin. Alternatively, Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers help mitigate entry hazard damage and keep Zacian healthy. Ability Shield is useful against Normalize users like Dragapult and Mold Breaker users like Palkia-O. Zacian pairs very well with a secondary specially defensive pivot like RegenVest Ting-Lu or Dialga-O, as they can scout for moves from Choice Specs users while not being chipped down by Volt Switch. In return, Zacian provides a switch-in to strong Dragon-type moves while also checking setup Pokemon like Palkia-O and Nasty Plot Flutter Mane. Imposter-proofs for Spikes variants include Fur Coat Groudon and Arceus-Ground, while Toxic variants can be Imposter-proofed by Arceus-Poison and Corviknight. Tera Steel provides a resistance to Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane's Boomburst while retaining a Dragon resistance, as well as providing a Toxic immunity.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Zacian differentiates itself from other Fur Coat users with its high Speed, outspeeding dangerous physical threats like Koraidon and threatening them with Knock Off or Will-O-Wisp. Spirit Break is a weaker alternative to Magical Torque that offers more PP and a useful secondary effect, preventing Calm Mind Arceus formes and Torch Song Eternatus from freely setting up. Knock Off removes important items like Choice Band and Assault Vest from Pokemon like Groudon and Ting-Lu, respectively, as well as removing Imposter Chansey's Eviolite. Will-O-Wisp neutralizes most physical attackers like Koraidon. Spirit Shackle threatens to trap and eliminate Imposter users and physical threats walled by Zacian. Toxic cripples Imposter users and most Fur Coat users. Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers help mitigate entry hazard damage, allowing Zacian to check physical threats more reliably, while Covert Cloak provides protection against status conditions from Nuzzle and Mortal Spin. Zacian can struggle to handle extremely powerful physical wallbreakers like Groudon and Mold Breaker Koraidon by itself, so secondary physical walls like Fur Coat Arceus formes are appreciated as teammates; they can also Imposter-proof Zacian. Despite outspeeding threats like Palkia-O and Flutter Mane, Zacian cannot switch in, so a special wall like Ice Scales Dialga-O or Chansey can help pivot Zacian in. Tera Water grants a resistance to V-create and Gigaton Hammer, the latterof which Koraidon commonly uses to threaten Zacian.

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Zacian is a powerful cleaner. Pixilate boosted Population Bomb is an incredibly strong STAB move, 2HKOing defensive behemoths like Fur Coat Dondozo at +2. Coil + Protective Pads and Swords Dance + Wide Lens both increase Population Bomb's power and accuracy, with the former bypassing Rocky Helmet and the latter providing a stronger boost, notably letting Zacian boost past Strength Sap. Rapid Spin with Pixilate provides unblockable entry hazard removal in a pinch, while Precipice Blades targets Fairy-resistant Pokemon like Arceus-Poison and Arceus-Fire. Spirit Shackle is an option with Coil to trap and eliminate Imposter users, which are otherwise problematic. Knock Off users like Ting-Lu and Groudon are mandatory for Wide Lens sets to remove Rocky Helmet. While Zacian can remove hazards with Rapid Spin, hazard setters often carry moves that can heavily cripple it like Nuzzle and Knock Off, making another hazard remover like Tidy Up Groudon or Mortal Spin Ting-Lu a good choice. Groudon notably also pressures Fairy-resistant Pokemon like Arceus-Poison and Arceus-Fire well. Imposter users serve as a strong check to this set, so having a sturdy Imposter-proofing teammate is necessary, with Rocky Helmet + Fur Coat users or Corviknight being good candidates.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Zamazenta is a potent wallbreaker in the metagame due to its high Attack and Speed stats, as well as its range of coverage options that allows it to bypass would-be checks. Zamazenta's potency as a wallbreaker is further amplified by its bulk, which allows it to either trade with revenge killers such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Booster Energy Iron Valiant from full, if needed, or soft check opposing Kingambit and Hisuian Samurott, especially when Dauntless Shield is active, subsequently granting it multiple wallbreaking opportunities. Zamazenta's Crunch allows it to hit and at least 2HKO checks such as Gholdengo, Dragapult, and Galarian Slowking. With Heavy Slam, Zamazenta OHKOes Enamorus and Iron Valiant and 2HKOes Tera Fairy Toxapex. Stone Edge affords Zamazenta the ability to 2HKO Zapdos, notably avoiding Static in doing so, while also 2HKOing Skeledirge; alternatively, Wild Charge can be used to 2HKO Toxapex. Tera Fighting boosts the power of Close Combat and accentuates Zamazenta's wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to blow past some bulkier Zapdos variants without requiring prediction in addition to 2HKOing Dondozo most of the time.

Zamazenta is well-suited as a wallbreaker on bulky offense teams. Consequently, Galarian Slowking is a very good teammate, as it provides Future Sight support, which heavily pressures otherwise solid checks such as Amoonguss, Toxapex, and Dondozo, allowing Zamazenta to break past its checks more easily. Additionally, Galarian Slowking provides a means of dealing with common counterplay to Zamazenta such as Zapdos, Enamorus, and Iron Valiant, as well as supplying Zamazenta with opportunities to come in through Chilly Reception. Other pivots such as Landorus-T and Zapdos are good partners too, as through their respective pivot moves, they also provide Zamazenta chances to safely come in and weaken the opposing team. Zamazenta is often worn down by hazards, as well as having to check threats such as Kingambit early on; solid checks to these which provide a means of hazard removal, like Corviknight and Great Tusk, respectively, are good partners. Kingambit is a strong teammate, as it appreciates the wallbreaking Zamazenta does earlier on to facilitate Kingambit's ability to clean late-game. Kingambit also appreciates the speed control Zamazenta provides, aiding Kingambit in revenge killing its offensive checks such as non-Choice Scarf Enamorus, non-Booster Energy Iron Valiant, and offensive Great Tusk. In return, Kingambit checks foes that take advantage of Zamazenta being locked into Close Combat, such as Gholdengo and Dragapult. Likewise, other cleaners such as Choice Scarf Enamorus and Booster Energy Iron Valiant also appreciate Zamazenta's weakening of the opposing team. In particular, Choice Scarf Enamorus provides Healing Wish support, affording Zamazenta a second chance at wearing down the opponent's team.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
An amazing Defense stat combined with a fantastic Speed tier and access to STAB Body Press makes Zamazenta a potent late-game cleaner, especially in conjunction with Iron Defense and potentially Dauntless Shield. Crunch is used to prevent Zamazenta from being walled by Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Dragapult. The last moveslot is fairly versatile; Substitute makes setting up multiple Iron Defenses easier and protects Zamazenta from status, while Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant and Enamorus for high damage. Rest can also be used in conjunction with a Lum Berry to offer a one-time reprieve from Zamazenta's lack of recovery. 168 Speed EVs let Zamazenta outrun Adamant Dragonite after a single Dragon Dance and neutral-natured Dragapult. Maximum HP EVs are used in order to maximize overall bulk, which lets it survive Moonblast from Choice Scarf Enamorus and Tera Dragon Dragapult's Draco Meteor. Leftovers's passive recovery makes Zamazenta even harder to KO and is vital for its longevity due to its lack of healing moves. It also synergizes excellently with Substitute. Tera Steel gives Zamazenta a fantastic defensive typing, letting it soak up Fairy-type attacks from the likes of Hatterene and Iron Valiant before retaliating with a STAB-boosted Heavy Slam. Tera Electric is another solid defensive option that lets it beat Zapdos, giving it an immunity to paralysis and a resistance to both of its STAB attacks. Lastly, Tera Fairy, in conjuction with Heavy Slam, gives it an advantage over other Zamazenta and Iron Valiant. Tera Fairy also enables it to better check physical Dragapult, preventing even the special variants of it from revenge killing it reliably even when behind a Substitute due to Infiltrator.

Zamazenta fits well on offensive teams, including hyper and bulky offense. Galarian Slowking makes for a great partner due to its ability to sponge hits from the Fairy-types Zamazenta despises, mainly Iron Valiant. It also provides offensive support with Future Sight and makes it easy for Zamazenta to get in with Chilly Reception. Other pivots, such as Landorus-T and defensive Zapdos, are appreciated so that Zamazenta can get in safely; the latter is especially useful for absorbing Flying-type moves and punishing Pokemon such as Sneasler and physical Iron Valiant with Static, negating any potential Speed boosts via Unburden or Booster Energy and enabling Zamazenta to revenge kill them. Due to Zamazenta preferring Leftovers, it is easily worn down by entry hazards. Great Tusk and Corviknight both provide hazard control, with the former also being able to set its own hazards to wear down the opposing team and the latter providing excellent defensive synergy, checking Fairy-types such as Choice-locked Enamorus. Wallbreakers that can muscle through Zamazenta's checks and weaken the opposing team are appreciated. Choice Scarf Enamorus provides speed control against Dragapult and has a favorable matchup against Iron Valiant, and Choice Specs Gholdengo helps cripple physically bulky Pokemon such as Dondozo with a combination of its sheer power and Trick. On hyper offense teams, Curse Dragapult is a great screens setter due to its high Speed stat and ability to set up on more passive threats as well as get Zamazenta in safely with U-turn or by causing itself to faint with Curse.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: When equipped with a Choice Band, Zamazenta becomes one of the strongest wallbreakers in the metagame, thanks to its amazing Speed, great Attack, and solid defensive capabilities. There's only a limited pool of Pokemon that can switch into Zamazenta's Close Combat safely, such as Gholdengo, Hex Dragapult, and Skeledirge, all of which falter to Crunch. Wild Charge deals massive damage to Toxapex, Tornadus-T, and Slowbro while Ice Fang hits Landorus-T. Tera Fighting propels Zamazenta's Close Combat to nearly unstoppable levels, letting it 2HKO on a large variety of Pokemon, including Fighting-resistant Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Mega Latias. Zamazenta appreciates pivot support, as even if it's bulky enough to switch into neutral or resisted moves, it doesn't like being chipped. Therefore, Pokemon like Landorus-T, Dragapult, and Mega Scizor make good partners. It also really appreciates Future Sight support from Tapu Lele and Slowbro, as it helps it beat its most common switch-ins, such as Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Buzzwole. Entry hazard support helps Zamazenta against Gholdengo and the aforementioned Toxapex, so Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Toxapex are valuable teammates.

sets.name: Howl
sets.description: Howl Zamazenta is a stupendous sweeper; thanks to its stellar bulk—improved by Dauntless Shield—and high Speed, it can set up multiples Howls and becomes near unstoppable once boosted. It also takes advantage of the many switches it forces with the threat of other sets and is ensured to setup at least one Howl without taking damage. Wild Charge, combined with an Electrium Z, gives Zamazenta a nuke to use against common switch-ins, such as Toxapex, Tera Water Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. Ice Fang hits Landorus-T, while Crunch Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Dragapult. This set, while scary, still possesses a pool of Pokemon capable of completely stopping it from making progress, such as Skeledirge, Unaware Clefable, and Dondozo. Therefore, Pokemon that can pressure them such as Mega Charizard Y, Heatran, and Tapu Lele are great teammates. Pursuit support from Kingambit, Weavile, and Tyranitar helps Zamazenta by removing Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Dragapult that can take a hit from it if Crunch isn't used. Knock Off from Ferrothorn, Tornadus-T, and the aforementioned Weavile cripples all of Zamazenta's checks, as they all dislike losing their items.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description: Body Press lets Zamazenta become an extremely strong sweeper, being hard to remove after a couple of Iron Defenses due to its already amazing bulk. Crunch hits Ghost-types such as Dragapult and Gholdengo. Rest cures its status while healing it; Sleep Talk can be used alongside it as a way to stack Defense boosts faster and be less passive, but it's very unreliable. The combination of Protect and Substitute allows Zamazenta to reliably beat Tornadus-T and Zapdos, taking advantage of Hurricane's lack of accuracy. Tera Water helps against rain, as almost all rain sweepers are physical attackers, like Floatzel and Mega Swampert. This lets Zamazenta use them as setup fodder. It is especially effective when paired with Protect and Substitute, as it can easily waste rain turns. While very threatening, this set tends to struggle against walls such as Skeledirge, Dondozo, and Clefable, so Pokemon that pressure them such as Mega Charizard Y, Tapu Lele, and Heatran are great partners. If not using Crunch, Pursuit support from Kingambit and Weavile should be used to remove Ghost-types that Zamazenta can't touch. Since this set struggles against Flying-types such as Tornadus-T and Zapdos, Knock Off support from Kartana and the aforementioned Kingambit helps in dealing with them.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• Specially defensive Eternatus functions as a good check to Kyogre and Calm Mind or Taunt Arceus formes thanks to Toxic, its high Speed and bulk, and reliable recovery.
  • Dynamax Cannon always does enough damage to break Kyogre's Substitute, allowing Eternatus to Toxic it on the next turn.
  • Flamethrower gives good neutral coverage with Dynamax Cannon, hits Zacian-C and Corviknight, and can fish for burns. Dragon Tail is an option to force out Arceus formes that Tera Poison or Steel to avoid Toxic, and it can annoy Clodsire. Toxic Spikes can be useful to pressure the opposing team, especially with smart double switches. In either case, the loss of Flamethrower leaves Eternatus more passive generally.
  • Sludge Bomb is much less reliable at setting poison than Toxic is; however, it allows Eternatus to have a chance against Calm Mind Tera Fairy Kyogre sets, which may otherwise use Substitute to block Toxic.
  • The given EV spread allows Eternatus to outspeed base 120 Speed Pokemon like Arceus and Palkia-O, with the rest of the EVs dumped into bulk.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots is optimal on teams lacking entry hazard removal, while Leftovers works better when Eternatus is paired with Giratina-O or Corviknight.
  • Tera Fairy is used, as its Dragon-type immunity is useful against Koraidon and Miraidon, and it provides a neutrality to Ice. Tera Water provides Eternatus with a resistance to Ice, making it much more reliable against Kyogre sets lacking Thunder, and a resistance to Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade.
  • Eternatus is very difficult to switch into generally, since it has strong neutral coverage and can poison most switch-ins. Its most reliable checks are Clodsire, Blissey, and Arceus-Poison, all of which don't care about being poisoned and can use Eternatus as a free setup opportunity. Exerting enough offensive pressure helps deal with these threats.
  • Eternatus works well as a third or fourth pokemon on defensive cores, since it absorbs Toxic Spikes and takes on the aforementioned Arceus formes and Kyogre. Ting-Lu makes for a fantastic partner as a result.
  • On teams lacking entry hazard removal, Skeledirge is a great partner, since both Pokemon can use Heavy-Duty Boots and have reliable recovery.
  • Switch-ins to Ground-types are much appreciated such as Corviknight, Giratina-O, and Landorus-T. Arceus-Ground makes for a good partner to pressure opposing Ground-types offensively.
  • While it can't switch in on Toxic, Mewtwo is a great annoyance, as it tends to be faster than Eternatus and can hit it with a super effective Psystrike. As such, pivots into Psystrike such as Corviknight or Ting-Lu are ideal teammates.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf Eternatus is one of the fastest Choice Scarf users in the tier. Its type combination and Fire-type coverage moves allow it to be a potent revenge killer. Unlike other common Choice Scarf users, Eternatus has the ability to absorb Toxic Spikes and Toxic many of its checks.
  • Dynamax Cannon is a strong and consistent STAB move used to revenge kill opposing Dragon-types and low HP neutral targets. Caution should be taken when using it, because while it is able to KO Koraidon from full health, it is not guaranteed to KO Miraidon and it doesn't even have a chance to do so against opposing Eternatus. That is why Draco Meteor can be used as a secondary option.
  • Sludge Bomb functions similarly to Dynamax Cannon, except that it can be used to hit Arceus-Fairy and Tera Fairy users super effectively.
  • Fire moves are used to hit Steel-types that resist both of Eternatus's STAB moves. Fire Blast can OHKO Zacian-C in sun, and it does much more damage than Flamethrower in general. However, Flamethrower's accuracy makes it more consistent.
  • Toxic can be used to put non-immune checks on a timer, such as Ting-Lu and many Arceus formes.
  • Modest is preferred to heavily increase Eternatus's odds to OHKO Zacian-C with a sun-boosted Flamethrower and guarantee a OHKO on Miraidon with Dynamax Cannon. Timid can be used for the greater consistency against Dragon Dance Arceus and ability to Speed tie other Choice Scarf Eternatus.
  • Tera Ghost is used for the Extreme Speed immunity and turning all of Eternatus's weaknesses into neutralities, which helps when facing off against Choice Scarf Koraidon or Miraidon.
  • Tera Fairy can be used to gain a Dragon-type immunity, which can preserve all of its health in the face of opposing Dragon-type attacks, probably thrown out by Choice Scarf Koraidon.
  • Tera Dragon provides a boost to Eternatus's Dragon-type moves. To use this boost as effectively as possible, Tera Dragon should be used with both Dynamax Cannon and Draco Meteor in Eternatus's moveset.
  • Tera Steel can provide a resistance to Zacian-C's STAB moves, Extreme Speed, and Dragon-type attacks; however, this leaves Eternatus extremely vulnerable to Choice Scarf Koraidon.
  • Terastallization with Eternatus should be avoided early-game, as Eternatus loses its ability to absorb Toxic Spikes.
  • Choice Scarf Eternatus can fit well on any type of team in need of a Toxic Spikes absorber and speed control in a single team slot, although it is generally a better fit on offensive teams.

sets.name: Mold Breaker
sets.description: Mold Breaker Eternatus is a threatening attacker that takes advantage of teams that heavily rely on Ice Scales to tackle special attackers. Torch Song hits Steel-types like Mega Steelix for good damage and allows Eternatus to boost alongside Calm Mind Arceus formes. Spikes allows Eternatus to take advantage of the switches it forces and notably ensures that it can make immediate progress against foes like RegenVest Primal Kyogre; alternatively, Toxic can wear away at foes without requiring multiple Special Attack boosts and high HP for Dragon Energy, and Sludge Bomb eliminates targets like Arceus-Fairy and Mega Diancie much faster and more reliably than Torch Song. Mold Breaker Eternatus appreciates support from mixed attackers like Mega Diancie and Arceus-Ghost, as these can help pressure one of Eternatus's best checks in RegenVest Primal Kyogre; these both also appreciate Eternatus's strong matchup into specially defensive Fairy-types if using Toxic or Sludge Bomb. Knock Off users are also similarly effective, as removal of Assault Vest puts both Primal Kyogre and Mega Steelix into 2HKO range. Imposter-proof Mold Breaker Eternatus with Imposter Chansey.

battlestadiumsingles.overview: This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

sets.name: One Punch!
sets.description:
• Urshifu-S can punch holes in the opposing team with its strong combination of STAB moves. Additionally, Urshifu-S can benefit from team preview against opponents who mistakenly assume it to be Urshifu-R.

  • U-turn: This move allows Urshifu-S to pivot out of bad matchups and scout out potential Tera types.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head can cover opposing Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane and Mimikyu, which threaten Urshifu-S.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Generally, Urshifu-S will utilize Terastallization offensively in order to extend the reach of its signature move Wicked Blow.

  • Dark: Tera Dark allows Urshifu-S to supercharge its Wicked Blow and muscle its way past various physically defensive foes. Notably, it gives Choice Band Urshifu-S a high chance to 2HKO Dondozo through Leftovers recovery.

  • Poison: This is a defensive Tera type that removes Fairy-type and Fighting-type weaknesses.

  • Steel: This Tera type allows Urshifu-S to resist Fairy-type attacks and additionally boosts the power of Iron Head.

sets.name: Dancing Bear
sets.description:
• After boosting its power through Swords Dance, Urshifu-S can leverage its complementary set of STAB moves to smash through the opposing team.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Typically, Urshifu-S will utilize Terastallization offensively to bolster the power of its Dark-type moves, but this set can benefit more from a defensive Tera type in order to stay on the field longer and make use of its ability to switch moves, which the Choice-locked attacker set cannot.

  • Dark: Tera Dark strengthens Wicked Blow and allows Urshifu-S to power its way through opposing walls. After a Swords Dance boost, Tera Dark-boosted Wicked Blow is a guaranteed OHKO on physically defensive Zapdos, while Close Combat has a high chance to OHKO Ting-Lu.

  • Poison: This Tera type allows Urshifu-S to survive common Fairy-type and Fighting-type attacks that would otherwise threaten to KO Urshifu-S.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash can help Urshifu-S more reliably get off a Swords Dance boost. It can survive hits from Fairy-types like Flutter Mane as well as powerful special attackers like Zapdos. With an Adamant nature, Urshifu-S can reliably beat offensive Tera Fairy Flutter Mane with Wicked Blow + Sucker Punch, provided Focus Sash is still intact.

  • Black Glasses versus Punching Glove: Both items boost the power of Urshifu-S's signature move, Wicked Blow. Black Glasses gives a slightly stronger boost, while Punching Glove helps to protect Urshifu-S from contact effects like Rocky Helmet and Zapdos's Static. Urshifu-S is much less vulnerable to these effects compared to Urshifu-R due to lack of a multi-hit move. Finally, despite the name, Punching Glove does not boost the power of Sucker Punch, while Black Glasses does.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Urshifu-R serves as a wallbreaker that fits on bulky offense and rain teams. Swords Dance on top of very strong Base Power moves in Surging Strikes and Close Combat means that Urshifu-R can effectively break through a variety of defensive cores, especially with Terastallization. This includes Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Unaware Clodsire. Urshifu-R's Water / Fighting typing gives it chances to pivot into offensive Pokemon such as Weavile and Mega Scizor, providing it defensive utility as well. Taunt lets Urshifu-R pressure defensive Pokemon and prevent Toxic and Haze from being used while negating recovery on checks without Regenerator such as Pelipper, Dragonite, and Buzzwole. Ice Punch pressures checks such as Dragonite and Dragapult. A boosted Aqua Jet is able to KO a chipped Tapu Koko, Mega Medicham, and Mega Lopunny, especially with support from Pelipper's rain and Tera Water. Thunder Punch can be used to pressure or break through bulky Water-types that would normally wall Urshifu-R, such as Pelipper, Tapu Fini, Toxapex, Slowbro, and Dondozo. Punching Gloves is the preferred option for boosting both Thunder Punch's and Surging Strikes's base power and preventing Rocky Helmet recoil. Swords Dance- and Tera Water-boosted Surging Strikes is able to break past checks such as Buzzwole, Dragonite, Tera Fairy Skeledirge, and Iron Hands, especially when supported by rain from Pelipper. Pelipper is one of the best partners for Urshifu-R because it provides rain support, boosting Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes to absurd levels. Tornadus-T is a great teammate for Urshifu-R, as it appreciates Urshifu-R's ability to break past Ferrothorn, Clodsire, Garchomp, and Blissey while soft checking Weavile and Tyranitar. In return, Tornadus-T with Taunt is able to take on defensive Water-types such as Dondozo and Toxapex as well as Kartana. Tornadus-T can also utilize Supersonic Skystrike to break shared checks such as Tapu Koko and Toxapex. Mega Diancie, Ferrothorn, and Garchomp are valuable partners for setting entry hazards to wear down Urshifu-R's checks such as Buzzwole, Dragapult, and Tangrowth. Tapu Koko is another synergistic partner for being able to pivot into Toxapex and other defensive Water-types. Future Sight support from Tapu Lele and Slowbro is much appreciated to make it easier for Urshifu-R to take on Dondozo, Tangrowth, Toxapex, and Buzzwole without using Terastallization or Swords Dance. Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Dragapult are also threats, since they resist all of Urshifu-R's common moves bar Ice Punch, can threaten it out with Choice Specs-boosted attacks in Dragapult's case, or Dragon Dance in front of Urshifu-R, though Dragapult cannot switch into Urshifu-R multiple times. Garganacl also acts as a consistent check to Dragapult, sets Stealth Rock for Urshifu-R, provides a consistent switch-in to Skeledirge, as well as Toxapex and Dondozo when Terastallized into a Fairy- or Water-type, and pressures them for Urshifu-R with Salt Cure. If not running Taunt, Swords Dance Urshifu-R struggles with bulky Unaware threats like Tera Fairy Skeledirge and Dondozo, so special wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele, Choice Specs Tapu Koko, Tera Grass Heatran, and Flyinium Z Tornadus-T are appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Urshifu-R is a very strong wallbreaker and pivot that pressures defensive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Unaware Clodsire. Urshifu-R can pivot into offensive Pokemon such as Weavile and Mega Scizor, but prefers to not lose its item. Since Urshifu-R forces switches with its STAB combo, U-turn is an excellent move to generate momentum on these switches, letting it bring in a teammate. Aqua Jet allows for Urshifu-R to KO a chipped Tapu Koko, Mega Medicham, Mega Lopunny, and pre-Tera Volcarona. Ice Punch hits Dragapult and Dragonite super effectively. Tera Water is the preferred Tera type, as once Rocky Helmet users are knocked off by a supporting partner and Garchomp and Ferrothorn are dealt with, Tera Water-boosted Surging Strikes can overwhelm checks such as Pelipper, Tera Water Garganacl, Tapu Fini, Toxapex, and Slowbro, especially with support from Pelipper's rain. Pelipper is a fantastic partner for Urshifu-R by virtue of it providing rain, which strengthens Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes. Entry hazard setters such as Glimmora, Garchomp, Clodsire, and Ferrothorn can help in wearing down its checks. Tapu Lele is a fantastic partner by providing Future Sight support, which lets Urshifu-R beat checks like Dragonite, Skeledirge, and Toxapex for Urshifu-R, as well as appreciating Urshifu-R's ability to pivot into Heatran and take on Ferrothorn. Urshifu-R struggles with defensive Water-types and Tangrowth, so partners such as Tapu Koko and Tornadus-T pair well with it. Tapu Koko also forms a pivot core with it, being able to consistently switch into Toxapex and Slowbro, and powering up Urshifu-R's Thunder Punch, while Urshifu-R pressures Ferrothorn for Tapu Koko. Tornadus-T is able to pressure defensive Water-types such as Toxapex with Taunt, check Kartana, remove entry hazards so that Urshifu-R can come in more often, bring Urshifu-R in with U-turn, and even utilize Supersonic Skystrike to break past shared checks such as Tapu Koko and the aforementioned defensive Water-types. Tornadus-T also appreciates Urshifu-R's ability to break Ferrothorn, while soft checking Tyranitar and Weavile. Urshifu-R struggles with Dragonite, so it appreciate partners such as Ferrothorn, Tangrowth, Pelipper, or Tera Fairy/Water Garganacl to help take on Dragonite. Rocky Helmet users such as Garchomp and Buzzwole make it harder for Urshifu-R to freely use Surging Strikes, so Knock Off support from users such as Weavile and Toxapex is much appreciated. Weavile in particular is able to take on Tornadus-T, Tangrowth, Dragonite, and Garchomp while also pressuring Toxapex. Urshifu-R is forced out by faster special attackers such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, and Tornadus-T, so Ferrothorn and Heatran are great partners for taking on these Pokemon and also providing entry hazard support. Pivots such as Rotom-W, Landorus-T, and Dragapult are good partners for being able to bring in Urshifu-R consistently throughout a game to wallbreak.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: With a Choice Scarf equipped, Urshifu-R becomes a potent pivot as well as a late-game cleaner. With a unique Speed tier, Urshifu-R gets the jump on the common Choice Scarf Tapu Lele while outspeeding setup sweepers such as Baxcalibur and Mega Gyarados. U-turn is integral, providing valuable pivoting potential on checks like Toxapex and Slowbro and serving as a midground into contact punishment from the likes of Ferrothorn and Garchomp. Aqua Jet allows Urshifu-R to halt Volcarona as well as pick off weakened sweepers such as Sneasler. Alternatively, Ice Spinner can be used to hit Dragon-types like Dragapult, Garchomp, and Dragonite. Additionally, Thunder Punch is a niche option to hit slightly harder against Slowbro and Toxapex. Tera Water boosts damage from Surging Strikes to ludicrous levels, as well as strengthening Aqua Jet to pick off bulkier sweepers like Iron Valiant. Teammates such as Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, and Heatran appreciate Urshifu-R's ability to pivot out on Toxapex in particular, letting them freely fire off attacks and maintain momentum. Additionally, Tapu Lele can also use Future Sight to let Urshifu-R bypass normal checks like Buzzwole and the aforementioned Toxapex. Contact punishment from Pokemon like Skarmory and Garchomp is problematic, but can be circumvented with teammates who can remove their Rocky Helmet such as Kartana, Kingambit, and Tornadus-T. Tornadus-T makes for a great teammate particularly, removing Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Dragonite and Toxapex, allowing Urshifu-R to rack up more significant damage against them.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Water)
sets.description:
Swords Dance Urshifu-R is a good choice on Water teams thanks to its high Attack - further boosted by Swords Dance - and decent Speed tier, allowing it to dispatch many of the metagame's defensive staples such as Unaware Clodsire, Alolan Muk, and Corviknight. Swords Dance allows Urshifu-R to set up on a predicted switch. Surging Strikes is a generally powerful move that allows Urshifu-R to muscle past threats such as Bulk Up Corviknight and defensive Gholdengo after a Swords Dance. Close Combat hits Dark- and Steel-types such as Hydreigon and Hisuian Goodra that try to switch in on Surging Strikes, while Drain Punch is weaker but provides some much-appreciated recovery. Finally, Urshifu-R has many viable options for its 4th moveslot; Aqua Jet deters Iron Valiant and Flutter Mane from attempting to revenge kill Urshifu-R, Thunder Punch hits Flying-types such as Pelipper as well as heavily damaging Toxapex, and Ice Punch hits Water Absorb Clodsire, Garchomp, and Flying-types such as Zapdos and Dragonite. Zen Headbutt can be run to damage Amoonguss and do well against Poison teams. Punching Glove allows Urshifu to gain a small boost to its punching moves while being protected from Zapdos's Static and other contact-punishing abilities.

Greninja and Hisuian Samurott are great teammates for Urshifu-R, as they take Psychic-type attacks such as Choice Scarf Indeedee's Psychic and Choice Band Hoopa-U's Zen Headbutt with impunity and punish them with Dark Pulse and Ceaseless Edge, respectively. Hisuian Samurott also sets Spikes to aid in Urshifu-R's wallbreaking efforts, while Greninja can threaten Fighting-types that Urshifu-R struggles with such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Sneasler with Extrasensory. In return, Urshifu-R can take Bug-type attacks such as Choice Band Scizor's U-turn and Choice Scarf Kleavor's X-Scissor, as well as threaten opposing Dark-types such as Chien-Pao. Pelipper provides rain support to augment Urshifu-R's already scary wallbreaking abilities as well as a Grass neutrality to take Choice Scarf Meowscarada's Flower Trick. Toxapex and Quagsire take Fairy- and Electric-type attacks, respectively, while both wearing attackers down with Toxic. Toxapex also removes Toxic Spikes, which can put Urshifu-R on a timer. Gastrodon is an alternative Electric immunity, sacrificing physical bulk for a better specially defensive profile. Rotom-W does well in the Water mirror matchup, as well as doing good damage to Toxapex with Volt Switch. Additionally, it can create setup opportunities for Urshifu-R by burning physical attackers such as Dragonite and Great Tusk thanks to Will-O-Wisp. Barraskewda provides a good source of speed control as well as respectable power, while Basculegion-F is a good special attacker that can blow through common Urshifu-R checks such as physically defensive Toxapex and Quagsire. Both of these appreciate Urshifu-R breaking through their checks: Bulk Up Corviknight for Barraskewda and Gastrodon for Basculegion-F. Finally, Walking Wake can blow through defensive staples such as Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Amoonguss with Choice Specs-boosted Draco Meteors. In exchange, Urshifu-R takes care of Hisuian Goodra.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description:
Urshifu-R is a great wallbreaker on Fighting teams thanks to its deadly STAB combination, decent Speed tier, and access to Swords Dance, allowing it to be a good asset versus types like Poison, Water, and Fire. Close Combat is preferred due to its superior damage output; however, Drain Punch may be used instead for recovery and to ignore adverse contact effects thanks to Punching Glove. Aqua Jet threatens frailer revenge killers, taking out faster targets like Flutter Mane, Sandy Shocks, and Volcarona after a Swords Dance boost. Alternatively, Thunder Punch may be used to better deal with Azumarill, Pelipper, and Toxapex, while Zen Headbutt hits Amoonguss in addition to Toxapex and Clodsire. Surging Strikes notably deals with Landorus-T, Skeledirge, and Great Tusk as well as threatening Bulk Up Corviknight and Iron Defense Zamazenta. Other options include Ice Punch to hit Amoonguss while also threatening Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Dragapult and Taunt to prevent Toxapex, Quagsire, and Water Absorb Clodsire from using recovery moves as well as Toxic and Haze. Heavy-Duty Boots improves the matchup against hazard stacking teams like Poison; however, Punching Glove is preferred to use Surging Strikes freely without activating Rocky Helmet chip or Static, easing the Flying matchup and minimizing the need for predictions.

Great Tusk is an amazing teammate, providing Stealth Rock to enhance Urshifu-R's wallbreaking abilities and removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin if Urshifu-R isn't using Heavy-Duty Boots. Furthermore, Great Tusk deals with Toxapex if Urshifu-R isn't using coverage to hit it. Iron Hands provides a buffer in the Flying, Water, and Fairy matchup, threatening Corviknight, Pelipper, and Basculegion-F as well as hitting Flutter Mane, Hatterene, and Iron Valiant with Heavy Slam. Furthermore, Assault Vest Iron Hands acts as a great pivot into special attacks, as Urshifu-R's Special Defense is rather lackluster. In return, Urshifu-R deals with the Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads along with Skeledirge. Sneasler is great in the Fairy matchup and provides pivoting and Toxic Spikes to accentuate Urshifu-R's wallbreaking potential. Zamazenta appreciates Urshifu-R heavily wearing down teams to allow it to easily clean up late-game with Iron Defense. Iron Valiant removes threats such as Hisuian Lilligant, Meowscarada, and Greninja while also being a huge asset in the Flying matchup thanks to Thunderbolt. Iron Valiant also values Urshifu-R's ability to break Clodsire and lure in Toxapex.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With its excellent typing and Surging Strikes breaking through Focus Sash, Urshifu-R is among the premier physical attackers of the metagame!

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet is perfect for picking off weakened foes that are faster than Urshifu-R, such as Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane, but this does come at the cost of coverage or a setup move.

  • Swords Dance: With Swords Dance, Urshifu-R becomes far more difficult to wall, with Surging Strikes now 2HKOing even the bulkiest Cresselia.

  • Ice Punch versus Ice Spinner: While Ice Spinner is more powerful when not using Punching Glove, Ice Punch is still preferred because it reveals less information about Urshifu-R's set.

  • Thunder Punch: Thunder Punch is overpowered by Close Combat even against foes that are weak to it, but it can potentially 3HKO Dondozo when using Tera Electric and Punching Glove and is a safer option against opposing Urshifu-R than Close Combat. This is also Urshifu-R's most powerful attack against Azumarill.

  • Jolly versus Adamant: Jolly is preferred for outspeeding Mimikyu, a key target of Surging Strikes. Adamant can make sense if using Swords Dance and Aqua Jet together, having a better chance of sweeping late-game against fast threats that often run some bulk investment, such as Flutter Mane and Thundurus-T.

Other Options

  • Drain Punch: While it offers no wallbreaking potential, Drain Punch is a good idea on bulkier sets with Punching Glove, letting Urshifu-R stick around much longer and potentially beat faster Urshifu-R that use Close Combat.

  • Bulk Up: Bulk Up takes advantage of Urshifu-R's underrated physical bulk, though it will fail to easily wallbreak defensive foes like Cresselia as easily.

  • Trailblaze: While difficult to fit in coverage-wise, Trailblaze's Speed boost can be a shocking win condition considering Urshifu-R's decent Speed, letting it outspeed even Dragapult and Iron Bundle!

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Urshifu-R is able to function perfectly fine without Terastallization, though it has both offensive and defensive uses for it.

  • Water: The Tera Water boost to Surging Strikes makes Urshifu-R even more difficult to wall, with even Ting-Lu that lack Sitrus Berry being OHKOed by +2 Surging Strikes. It also makes Aqua Jet a more effective cleaning move.

  • Electric: When paired with Thunder Punch, this is Urshifu-R's best shot of wearing down Dondozo, in addition to giving it a useful Electric-type resistance and paralysis immunity, making Zapdos and Thundurus-T far less reliable checks.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is a strong defensive option for Urshifu-R, letting it take on Fairy, Grass, Flying, and Psychic attacks that normally threaten to OHKO it. It also means Iron Bundle will no longer OHKO Urshifu-R with Freeze-Dry.

  • Poison: Tera Poison isn't quite as strong defensively as Tera Steel, but it does let Urshifu-R absorb Toxic Spikes and gives it a useful Fighting-type resistance instead of a weakness.

Items

  • Punching Glove versus Protective Pads: Both of these items protect Urshifu-R from taking devastating damage by hitting Rocky Helmet or Rough Skin with Surging Strikes. Punching Glove is a great option since it boosts the damage of Surging Strikes and other punching moves, but Protective Pads does let Close Combat and Aqua Jet bypass chip damage as well, and unlike Punching Glove, Protective Pads lets even punching moves ignore Protect from common foes like Garganacl and Dondozo.

  • Focus Sash: While it might seem strange with Urshifu-R's good physical bulk, Focus Sash lets it survive extremely powerful physical moves such as Chien-Pao's Electric Tera Blast and Landorus-T's Flying Tera Blast and powerful special attackers such Flutter Mane and Thundurus-T.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 20 Atk / 156 Def / 36 SpD / 52 Spe with Impish: This bulky EV spread allows Urshifu-R to survive a wide variety of useful attacks, usually allowing to survive Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao's super effective Tera Blast and allowing Tera Water or Tera Electric Urshifu-R to survive Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast. The Speed EVs outspeed Adamant Breloom, and the Attack EVs give Urshifu-R a high chance to OHKO Focus Sash Chien-Pao with Tera Water Surging Strikes.

Minor Optimizations

  • Female Gender: While very rare, Urshifu-R is vulnerable to Enamorus's Cute Charm if making contact, so using a female gender has no drawbacks.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description:
• Thanks to U-turn, Urshifu-R is a strong option for a Choice item pivot.

  • Ice Punch versus Ice Spinner: Urshifu-R greatly appreciates having a move that prevents it from being walled by Dragonite. While Ice Spinner is more powerful, Ice Punch is preferred due to revealing less about Urshifu-R's set.

  • Thunder Punch: If using Tera Electric, Thunder Punch deals good damage to Dondozo and is its best way of dealing big damage to Azumarill,

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet is a good way for Choice Band Urshifu-R to clean up weakened teams.

  • Choice Scarf versus Choice Band: Choice Scarf transforms Urshifu-R into an effective revenge killer, outspeeding important threats such as Chien-Pao and Dragapultand even Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle that lack Booster Energy. Choice Band, on the other hand, makes Urshifu-R a far more effective wallbreaker, letting it deal massive damage to foes like Dondozo and Ting-Lu.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Urshifu-R has both offensive and defensive uses for Terastallization, but it isn't vital for it to function.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Surging Strikes a healthy boost in power, letting Choice Scarf Urshifu-R OHKO Focus Sash Chien-Pao and Choice Band Urshifu-R 2HKO Cresselia.

  • Electric: Not only does Tera Electric make Thunder Punch a good option against Dondozo, it also gives Urshifu-R a vital immunity to paralysis and resistance against Electric and Flying attacks from Zapdos and Thundurus-T.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting works fantastically with Choice Band, letting Close Combat 2HKO even the bulkiest Dondozo! It's also reasonable on Choice Scarf Urshifu-R for cleaning weakened teams more easily.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is a great defensive option, letting Urshifu-R survive Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry and Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

  • Poison: Tera Poison doesn't cover as many of Urshifu-R's natural weaknesses as Tera Steel, but it still offers a vital Fairy-type resistance and makes Urshifu-R a decent absorber of Toxic Spikes.

Minor Optimizations

  • Female Gender: Urshifu-R's gender is not vital for this set's function, but it does protect it from activating the very rare Cute Charm on Enamorus, making a female gender slightly better on Urshifu-R.

sets.name: Choice Band (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band (Grass)
sets.description:
Zarude can serve as a physical wallbreaker with a great Speed tier and Choice Band, which allow it to outspeed and beat Pokemon like Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Heatran, as well as a great pivot with U-turn. Power Whip is an excellent STAB move that allows Zarude to 2HKO Toxapex and Hatterene. Drain Punch grants Zarude a form of recovery while still 2HKOing Hisuian Goodra and Heatran, whereas Close Combat grants Zarude a stronger Fighting-type coverage. Alternatively, Jungle Healing allows Zarude access to longevity and removing its own status safely, as it forces many switches.

Amoonguss is a great defensive partner for Zarude, as it is able to resist Fighting- and Fairy-type attacks from Flutter Mane, Sneasler, and Iron Valiant, melt Toxic Spikes, and spread status for more offensive teammates with either Toxic or Spore. In return, Zarude can threaten the Psychic-types Amoonguss loses to, like Hatterene, Armarouge, and Iron Leaves. Choice Scarf Meowscarada makes for another good teammate, as it can outspeed and threaten Dragon-types such as Dragonite, Dragapult, and Hydreigon with Play Rough. In return, Zarude can handle the aforementioned Steel-types that Meowscarada struggles with, and the two of the form a strong U-turn core to complement their teammates. Hisuian Electrode and Rotom-C is a great addition on any Grass team, as thanks to its Speed tier and Electric typing, it can threaten slower Flying-types such as Corviknight and Enamorus as well as Water-types like Toxapex and Volcanion. Zarude's wallbreaking and support role enables sweepers like Hisuian Liligant to sweep Flying thanks to the latter's access to Ice Spinner as well as being able to clean Steel teams. Brambleghast and Toedscruel make for great teammates, as they can set up hazards to wear down incoming Pokemon for Zarude to break easier and remove them with Rapid Spin to enhance Zarude's pivoting ability. Toedscruel also has enough Special Defense to survive a Flamethrower from Choice Scarf Iron Moth and OHKO it back. On the other hand, Brambleghast's Ghost typing also allows it to spinblock, thus preserving hazards on the field, and thanks to its ability Wind Rider, it can switch into anticipated Flying-type attacks. Iron Leaves makes for another great partner, being able to provide Grass teams a positive matchup against Fighting and Poison teams. In return, Zarude can threaten the Ghost-types it struggles with, like Skeledirge and Gholdengo.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Grass)
sets.description:
Decent in the Steel matchup. Black Glasses lets it 2HKO Skeledirge with Crunch.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Bulk Up can be run in order to give Zarude more bulk while setting up.

sets.name: Zoomies (Offensive Entry Hazard Support)
sets.description:
Regieleki offers Electric teams an incredibly fast cleaner and pivot, shocking threats such as Iron Valiant, Spectrier, and Greninja. Volt Switch lets Regieleki punish foes like Amoonguss, Galarian Slowking, and Hisuian Goodra, which can take advantage of it, allowing teammates like Zapdos and Iron Hands to exploit them instead. Rapid Spin leverages Regieleki's capability to force opponents to bring in a Ground-type or risk significant damage, providing Electric teams with much-needed entry hazard control. Thunder Wave mitigates the threat of Hisuian Lilligant, Spectrier, and Zamazenta if Regieleki is unable to finish these off. Heavy-Duty Boots enhances Regieleki's ability to pivot and consistently remove entry hazards. Alternatively, 28 Atk EVs in conjunction with a Naive nature could be considered, and Magnet is recommended when using Regieleki with Wild Charge to secure an OHKO against Flutter Mane. Magnet also enables Regieleki to reach specific damage thresholds, such as OHKOing Iron Valiant with Thunderbolt. A Timid or Naive nature with maximum Speed EVs is needed to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Iron Valiant, Enamorus, and Hisuian Zoroark.

Given that Ground-types like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Quagsire shut down Regieleki's antics, teammates like Nasty Plot Rotom-W, Swords Dance Iron Hands, and Substitute Zapdos that capitalize on these are crucial for its success. It's important to keep in mind that the player using Regieleki can also choose to double out when anticipating a Ground-type switch-in, allowing teammates to threaten these walls. In return, Regieleki eliminates Greninja, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao, which threaten its allies. Magnezone can equip an Assault Vest to check Choice Scarf users like Flutter Mane and Greninja, which zoom past Regieleki, and it can wear down Landorus-T and Quagsire as they repeatedly switch in. Sandy Shocks provides entry hazards to further wear down the opposing team, is bulky enough to bear a hit from and deal with Choice Scarf Sneasler, and puts pressure on Quagsire and Glimmora. Pawmot handles fast Ground-types like Landorus, applies pressure on Flying and Water teams with its Ice- and Grass-type coverage, and grants Regieleki a second chance at sweeping through Revival Blessing. Thundurus-T and Rotom-C are also appreciated, as Thundurus-T provides colorful coverage to deal with Poison- and Ground-types like Amoonguss and Great Tusk, while Rotom-C is able to greatly threaten the entirety of Water teams with its STAB moves.

sets.name: Special Refrigerate
sets.description: Regieleki makes use of its amazing Speed along with Refrigerate to be a solid offensive spinner and pivot that cannot be spinblocked; it also threatens Ground-types that could otherwise switch in and block Volt Switch such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Sandy Shocks with Tera Blast. Thunderbolt is a stronger STAB option to use on switch-ins such as Iron Moth and Skeledirge, forcing them to use their recovery moves while Regieleki can pivot out, while Explosion can be used to heavily chip common RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, opening up opportunities for Regieleki's teammates like Iron Moth and Enamorus-T. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item, as it allows Regieleki to have better longevity for spinning and pivoting, but Never-Melt Ice and Life Orb can also be used to make Tera Blast and Explosion more potent. Since Regieleki has a very high natural Speed tier, an alternative EV spread of 244 HP / 252 SpA / 12 Spe can be ran with a Mild nature to have more bulk while still being able to outspeed every unboosted Pokemon in the tier. Due to its frail bulk, it is highly recommended to pair Regieleki with another spinner such as Quaquaval or Iron Treads, as they can take hits from common hazard setters like Garchomp and allow Regieleki to pivot in teammates more freely with Volt Switch. Regieleki also pairs up well with physical pivots like Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Meowscarada, as they can create a strong VoltTurn duo and threaten the Pokemon that Regieleki lures in such as Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta while Regieleki can pivot them in safely. Regieleki can struggle with breaking through bulky Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Scream Tail, so pairing it with a Pokemon that can break through both of them such as Zamazenta-C, Magic Guard Volcanion, or Heatran is advised.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Modest nature guarantees the 2HKO on Corviknight with Dragon Energy.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
240 Speed EVs outspeeds Corviknight.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Spectrier is a deadly special attacker that is able to quickly snowball against teams thanks to its high Speed, outrinning some of the metagame's fastest threats like Greninja and Iron Valiant. Spectrier utilizes Draining Kiss to hit Dark-type Pokemon that would otherwise resist its STAB Shadow Ball like the aforementioned Greninja as well as non-Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Roaring Moon. Draining Kiss also serves as a secondary recovery option to help heal off the damage taken by setting up a Substitute. Nasty Plot is used to elevate Spectrier's Special Attack to incredible heights without having to KO foes beforehand. Spectrier shines best when it is able to set up a Substitute, and subsequently a Nasty Plot, in the face of a more passive foe like Toxapex, then begin spamming its scarcely resisted Shadow Ball + Draining Kiss combination. Leftovers is used to provide more substantial recovery than Draining Kiss, but Colbur Berry is an option to take a Dark-type attack from Pokemon like Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Chien-Pao, and Barraskewda. Will-O-Wisp should be used instead of Substitute if Colbur Berry is the item of choice, as it allows Spectrier to capitalize on surviving an attack from these extremely potent physical threats. If Will-O-Wisp is preferred over Substitute, Hex can also be used to deal more damage to burned threats.

Skeledirge can switch into strong physical attacks from Pokemon that threaten Spectrier such as Choice Scarf Gallade, Scizor, Ceruledge, and Mimikyu lacking Shadow Claw, then scare them with Will-O-Wisp. Mimikyu is also a great teammate, as it can help Spectrier deal with Pokemon that may not go down to a single Draining Kiss, such as Ting-Lu, as well as Kingambit and Chien-Pao if Disguise is in tact. Mimikyu is also able to finish off threats such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult with Shadow Sneak. Froslass and Brambleghast are teammates that work well with Spectrier, setting up Spikes for Spectrier to nab easier KOs and snowball with Grim Neigh. Froslass is also able to use Thunder Wave to slow down faster Pokemon, while Brambleghast is able to remove entry hazards via Rapid Spin, allowing Spectrier to pivot more freely. Choice Scarf Flutter Mane is a great teammate thanks to its incredible Speed and ablility to deal with common Choice Scarf users that give Spectrier trouble such as Gholdengo, Hisuian Samurott and Great Tusk. STAB Moonblast can also damage or remove Dark-type Pokemon to make Spectrier's job easier. Finally, Hisuian Zoroark is a solid teammate due to its ability to switch into Ghost-type attacks that would otherwise threaten Spectrier and all of its other teammates. Hisuian Zoroark can also apply utility support by wearing down opposing teams with Will-O-Wisp and Knock Off. Dragapult is a great teammate, as it can burn and force damage on common walls like Quagsire, Clodsire, Alolan Muk and Ting-Lu, and forcing damage on them to make sweeping easier. It is also important to note that burned Quagsire and Clodsire cannot break Spectrier's Substitute in one hit, making setting up a lot easier. Finally, bulky Nasty Plot Gholdengo is a great teammate for Spectrier. Gholdengo can wear down Dark- and Poison-type Pokemon like Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Clodsire, which Spectrier struggle with, while Spectrier can help with faster threats like Dragon- and Fighting-type Pokemon, such as Hydreigon and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
200 Speed EVs outspeeds Choice Band Meowscarada, 16 HP EVs in tandem with 140 Def EVs prevents Spectrier's Substitute from being broken by special walls such as Assault Vest Iron Hands and Ting-Lu.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!
