  • Leftovers: Leftovers has great synergy with Swords Dance and Encore, allowing it to set up while healing off some of the damage from weak moves.

EV Speads

  • 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly or Adamant: This is a simple offensive spread that takes full advantage of Air Balloon or Focus Sash for survivability. If running Jolly, you can repurpose 24 Speed EVs to defensive stats and still outrun Jolly Annihilape.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 148 Def / 20 SpD / 92 Spe with Careful: The HP and Defense investment let's Tinkaton survive Adamant Dragonite's Earthquake into Extreme Speed. The Special Defense investment allows Tinkaton to survive one Timid Choice Specs Fire Blast from Hydreigon, two Modest Choice Specs Shadow Balls from Dragapult, and three uninvested Shadow Balls from Gholdengo. The Speed investment allows Tinkaton to outspeed a paralyzed Choice Scarf Timid Chi-Yu.

vgc2023.overview:
• Tinkaton is primarily a bulky attacker, but it also has an amazing defensive typing and Fake Out, giving it good defensive utility.

  • Tinkaton does extremely well against Murkrow teams, including Pokemon common on them like Annihilape, Hydreigon, Meowscarada, Maushold, and Murkrow itself. This makes it a very good partner for Dondozo + Tatsugiri teams, which feel pressured by Murkrow's Haze. Many of the aforementioned Pokemon are also very common on teams without Murkrow, so Tinkaton checking them well is broadly useful.

  • Mold Breaker + Fake Out Tinkaton does well against dedicated Trick Room teams because its Fake Out bypasses Oranguru's Inner Focus and Farigiraf's Armor Tail, and it can OHKO Mimikyu through Disguise.

  • Tinkaton struggles with the extremely common Fire-types, as well as Garchomp and Steel-types like Corviknight and Scizor, which wall it entirely. Water-types help deal with the majority of its counters, especially Rotom-W.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
• Knock Off hits Pokemon that resist both its STAB moves like Gholdengo, Armarouge, and Ceruledge and can cripple Pokemon with the item removal, especially Dondozo.

  • Tinkaton has many opportunities to use Swords Dance, especially because opponents will often use Protect consecutively in front of it, expecting a Fake Out or Gigaton Hammer. It's also a good move to use on the Gigaton Hammer recharge turns.

  • Assault Vest turns Tinkaton into a sponge against special attackers, which helps against common Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Gholdengo.

  • Sitrus Berry lets Tinkaton run Protect, which helps it stall out Gigaton Hammer recharge turns. This also pairs well with Swords Dance, which is similarly convenient to have on the recharge turns.

  • Mold Breaker is mainly good when used with Fake Out, as the ability lets Tinkaton flinch Dragonite, Farigiraf, and Oranguru. Mold Breaker also bypasses Mimikyu's Disguise.

  • Own Tempo is valuable because there are multiple good Intimidate users: Arcanine and Gyarados, as well as Paldean Tauros-A, Paldean Tauros-B, and Salamence. If you're not very worried about dedicated Trick Room teams or Dragonite, this is a good way to improve your matchup against bulkier teams.

  • Tera Steel is by far the best Tera type for Tinkaton, as it makes Gigaton Hammer very powerful, even doing good damage to targets that resist it. For example, it 2HKOes maximum HP Talonflame.

sets.name: Tinted Lens
sets.description: Tinted Lens Tinkaton is a solid physical wallbreaker that provides utility while using Tinted Lens to bypass resistances to Gigaton Hammer, turning the tables on defensive Quaquaval and Corviknight, activating teammates like Choice Band Chien-Pao that are hindered by these Pokemon. Metal Coat can be considered as it grants Tinkaton a boosting option for Gigaton Hammer without recoil, granting good odds of OHKOing frailer offensive Pokemon like Ceruledge and Magic Guard Quaquaval after minor chip. Swords Dance allows Tinkaton to more effectively wallbreak, Knock Off is excellent utility that cripples switch-ins like Magic Guard Heatran and Volcanion while annoying switch-ins like Corviknight and Iron Treads, Stealth Rock allows it to act as an offensive entry hazard setter, Protect allows it to gain more Leftovers recovery on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn, and Thunder Wave cripples setup sweepers that may try to capitalize on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn. Tinkaton appreciates slow pivots like Corviknight and Meloetta that can live a hit and pivot in Tinkaton safely. Tinkaton also appreciates faster teammates that make up for its lackluster Speed like Roaring Moon and Hisuian Electrode. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu pair well with Tinkaton, as it forces numerous switches and removes Heavy-Duty Boots.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Bombirdier is unique in its role compression, offering teams valuable utility in Knock Off, Stealth Rock, and U-turn as well as helping pivot around threats like Zoroark, Rotom, and Appletun thanks to its incredible defensive typing. Knock Off is helpful for keeping Stealth Rock up, punishing Hattrem and Defoggers like Drifblim, Scyther, and Oricorio-F, in addition to pressuring walls like Umbreon and Eelektross. Parting Shot is an alternative to U-turn that gives frailer teammates an easier time switching in, which can be extremely useful on offense teams, though it doesn't deal any damage and unfortunately activates Passimian's Defiant and Lurantis's Contrary. With 72 Speed EVs, Bombirdier outruns and usually beats Modest Clawitzer one-on-one. The Speed investment also allows Bombirdier to outspeed Cacturne and defensive Qwilfish. Tera Ground lets Bombirdier block Volt Switch from Rotom and resist Haunter's Sludge Bomb, which can translate to a surprise OHKO against both foes.

Electric-types like Eelektross, Rotom, and Jolteon are among the biggest threats to Bombirdier and should be accounted for when using it. Grass-types like Appletun and Lurantis are very sturdy checks to such Pokemon, while Ground-types like Sandaconda can block Volt Switch. Fighting-types like Toxicroak and Paldean Tauros can easily set up on Bombirdier, so it appreciates having partners like Sandaconda, Drifblim, and Bruxish that can check them. In return, Bombirdier scares out Grass- and Dark-types like Lurantis and Cacturne. Some Pokemon that Bombirdier can check like Mabosstiff, Farigiraf, and Indeedee-F pack super effective coverage for it, so backup checks to them like Qwilfish, Muk, and Chansey are important to have. Additional pivots, such as Passimian and Eelektross, help maintain momentum alongside Bombirdier and love having their switch-ins worn down by Knock Off and Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Dedicated Lead
sets.description:
Bombirdier is a great dedicated entry hazard lead due to the incredibly deep utility movepool. Stealth Rock and Taunt are a classic staple for any dedicated lead, quickly setting up hazards while preventing the opponent from removing them or setting up their own. Bombirdier makes great use of its STAB Knock Off to deal a decent chunk of damage before going down while also hindering the longevity of the many Flying-type Defog users like Braviary, Drifblim, and Scyther by removing their Heavy-Duty Boots. Memento is an amazing move for Bombirdier, facilitating the hyper offensive teams it's commonly found on. Memento can block an incoming Defog, but its main purpose is to allow for easy setup of an ally like Lilligant or Hisuian Sneasel against a weakened foe. Rock Blast allows Bombirdier to get the edge on opposing dedicated leads like Bombirdier and Froslass, breaking their Focus Sash and potentially OHKOing them. Tera Ghost simply blocks Rapid Spin, namely from the likes of Cryogonal and Avalugg, both of which also greatly dislike having their Heavy-Duty Boots removed and taking powerful Rock-type attacks. Tera Ground lets Bombirdier potentially block an Electric-type attack; OHKOing Rotom with Knock Off or heavily damaging Eelektross could be crucial for Bombirdier's teammates, but as a dedicated lead, Bombirdier will not be Terastallizing often because it is best reserved for its offensive teammates.

As mentioned, Bombirdier is often relegated to hyper offensive teams, which make the most use out of the hazards and momentum generated by it. Fast setup sweepers like Lilligant, Hisuian Sneasel, and Vivillon all greatly appreciate both the entry hazard support and the setup opportunity granted through Memento. Bombirdier can be coupled with a dedicated Froslass lead, which can set Spikes and double up the entry hazards and support for the team, although Froslass is also direct competition for Bombirdier's role. Faster Taunt users like Pyroar and Qwilfish can shut down Bombirdier but must be wary of Bombirdier's attacks. Bombirdier is often dealt with by physical walls like Sandaconda and Qwilfish; using Knock Off to remove their Rocky Helmet and weaken them greatly assists physical sweepers like Hisuian Sneasel, Scyther, and Tauros.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
Bombirdier makes good use of Choice Scarf and Choice Band thanks to its great speed and access to pivoting moves. U-turn breaks Focus Sash and deals some damage, while Parting Shot lets other offensive teammates hit the field more comfortably and avoids contact with the opposing Pokemon. Bombirdier has access to some of the best offensive STAB moves in the game, with the highly coveted Knock Off, high-Base Power Brave Bird, and Rocky Payload-boosted Rock-type moves.

Other useful options would be to use Stone Edge as a Rock-type pseudo-STAB attack; it has more power than Rock Blast but comes with more risk due to its lower accuracy. Additionally, Memento is an option over Parting Shot, which would further weaken an enemy to allow for a safer setup turn with a sweeper like Dudunsparce or Veluza. With this set, the Tera Dark is recommended to increase the damage of Knock Off; Tera Rock can also be considered, but most of the time, if you want to deal damage, Knock Off is more reliable. Brave Bird, the second STAB move, is another spammable option that helps Bombirdier deal with Fighting-type Pokemon that can take Dark and Rock moves, like Paldean Tauros and Toxicroak. With Choice Band, Bombirdier can deal some real damage off its great Attack stat.

As for teammates, we have some options. Sandaconda its a good option because of its Electric immunity, and Parting Shot can help it boost up safety. Setup sweepers like Bruxish, Lilligant, and Farigiraf greatly benefit from Bombirdier's Parting Shot and Knock Off weakening the opposition. To continue the pivot partners, Scyther and Choice Scarf Rotom make a solid VoltTurn core with Bombirdier. Due to its Stealth Rock weakness, Bombirdier appreciates entry hazard removal from Braviary and Cryogonal.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Support (Flying)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Wave Crash is a very strong STAB move. With Stealth Rock support and Tera Water's power boost, it crushes walls Palafin normally might struggle to break, like Toxapex and Corviknight, and always OHKOes Miraidon.
  • Close Combat is a strong, reliable coverage move that hits many of Palafin's checks like Corviknight and Koraidon for solid damage, while also hitting Water-types barring Toxapex for neutral damage.
  • Ice Punch allows Palafin to hit Dragon-types like the very common Koraidon and Miraidon while also hitting Water Absorb Clodsire. However, it cannot OHKO Koraidon and is not guaranteed to OHKO Miraidon.
  • Zen Headbutt allows Palafin to hit Toxapex super effectively, as well as potentially OHKOing Koraidon and having fantastic odds to 2HKO Miraidon.
  • Tera Water powers up Palafin's Water-type moves and allows Palafin to achieve feats like 2HKOing Miraidon with Jet Punch from full HP if rain is up.
  • Choice Band Palafin functions best on offensive teams to revenge kill threats like Flutter Mane or to break walls for its teammates mid-game. Remember, base Palafin needs to be used very early in a game to transform into its Hero Form.
  • Pelipper is a great partner for Palafin, as it checks Koraidon decently and replaces its sun with rain, strengthening Palafin's powerful Water-type attacks.
  • Koraidon sets up sun and resists Water-type attacks Palafin throws at it, so Palafin appreciates teammates that threaten Koraidon, like Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane. Also, Palafin is weakened by the sun Koraidon sets up, so it is best not to pair Palafin and Koraidon together.
  • Miraidon is a good partner, as it destroys Alomomola, a great counter to Palafin, and can safely bring Palafin onto the field with either U-turn or Volt Switch. Miraidon also appreciates Palafin threatening Ground-type Pokemon that can take Miraidon's Electric-type attacks, like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• Jet Punch's strong priority allows this Palafin set to still be threatening to offensive builds, while Drain Punch keeps Palafin healthy against bulkier teams.
  • Taunt allows Palafin to prevent common responses to setup sweepers from working, such as Whirlwind from Ting-Lu and Haze from Toxapex, while also preventing Pokemon like Annihilape from setting up alongside it.
  • Fairy is the Tera type of choice to allow Palafin to resist both of Koraidon's STAB attacks and potentially set up on Choice Scarf variants of it. Fairy also removes Palafin's weakness to Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry and Miraidon's Electric moves.
  • Palafin struggles to deal with Koraidon or Miraidon, which can come in on this set easily, especially given that Zero to Hero forces Palafin to switch at least once before it can be offensively threatening. As a result, this Palafin needs teammates that can defensively handle these threats. Ting-Lu and Iron Treads both help with Miraidon, and Pokemon like Great Tusk, Scream Tail, and Skeledirge can provide defensive solidity against Koraidon.
  • This Palafin set functions best with a sturdy defensive backbone alongside it, to mitigate the impact of Zero to Hero. As a result, it does not work as well on more hyper offensive playstyles.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Palafin is a potent wallbreaker and revenge killer for rain teams thanks to its Hero forme boasting the highest base Attack stat in the game and the strong priority move Jet Punch. Flip Turn allows Palafin to generate momentum for its team by pivoting out on its checks, bar Clodsire, to bring in a teammate that can threaten them. Zen Headbutt 2HKOes Toxapex, OHKOes Clodsire, and OHKOes Koraidon after one layer of Spikes. Jet Punch is a useful tool that can deal with faster offensive Pokemon such as Tera Fairy Miraidon, Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, and Flutter Mane, turning Palafin into a potent cleaner late-game. Tera Water boosts Wave Crash to impressive levels of damage in rain, allowing it to achieve feats such as 2HKOing Toxapex, Pelipper, and Alomomola, 2HKOing Dondozo after Stealth Rock, and OHKOing Miraidon. Pelipper is an excellent partner for Palafin, as it sets rain and checks Koraidon—whose sun weakens Palafin's Water-type moves. Miraidon is another good teammate, as it threatens the bulky Water-types that check Palafin, such as Toxapex, Alomomola, and Dondozo, and safely brings in Palafin via U-turn, while Palafin threatens Ground-types such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads for Miraidon. Similarly, Iron Bundle can pivot Palafin in with U-turn and target Water-types for it with Freeze Dry while Palafin threatens special walls for Iron Bundle. Iron Bundle also offensively checks faster Pokemon that resist Water like Miraidon and Koraidon for Palafin, and it benefits from the rain support Palafin is often paired with. Palafin also appreciates being paired with checks to Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Walking Wake—which resist Jet Punch and OHKO Palafin in return—such as Iron Treads, specifically for the former, and Clodsire and Blissey for all three. Dugtrio can also be utilized to trap Clodsire and Toxapex as well as faster threats such as Miraidon and Koraidon, freeing up Palafin to wallbreak with its most common defensive checks removed and without fear of being revenge killed.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Bulk Up Palafin builds upon its natural bulk and Attack, letting it function as a strong priority attacker who uses its Defense to brazenly set up and become a threatening sweeper that is difficult to KO for common physical attackers like Chien-Pao, Landorus-T, and Kingambit. Jet Punch circumvents common speed control and is threatening against the frailer metagame, notably OHKOing Chi-Yu and Landorus at +1. Drain Punch is a reliable means of recovery in addition to Leftovers while also hitting popular Dark-types like Kingambit and Chien-Pao, as well as common Water-resistant or immune foes such as Rillaboom and Volcanion harder. Tera Grass provides an immunity to Amoonguss's Spore and Rage Powder, as well as resistances to Grass- and Electric-type attacks such as Rillaboom's Wood Hammer and Iron Hands's Wild Charge, which would otherwise OHKO Palafin. Palafin's base forme has poor damage output and bulk, so it is often ideal for it to lead and pivot out immediately to activate Zero to Hero. This is so crucial to Palafin's functioning that it is very telegraphed and easily exploitable with powerful attacks directed at it. To cover for this, Palafin may lead together with a Fake Out user or a redirector to reduce incoming damage. Bulk Up Palafin pairs well with partners that can remove Psychic Terrain, use Fake Out to generate free turns for Palafin to set up, and extend Palafin's longevity. Rillaboom fulfills all of these roles, with Grassy Terrain granting additional passive recovery. Cresselia is another good partner, as its Lunar Blessing heals Palafin and cures burn and poison, which would otherwise severely limit Palafin's offensive output or the turns it can stay on field. Amoonguss's Rage Powder redirects threatening attacks such as Iron Hands's Wild Charge, removes Toxic Spikes that reduce Palafin's longevity, and provides a major source of recovery for Palafin with Pollen Puff. Iron Hands is a Fake Out user whose Electric-type attacks eliminate opposing Water-types that resist Jet Punch. Grimmsnarl can also increase Palafin's bulk and create setup opportunities with its dual screens. As Amoonguss effortlessly walls Palafin and undoes its progress with Clear Smog, Palafin requires partners that deal with it effectively, like Heatran, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: This looks like a job for Palafin
sets.description:
• Palafin's stats are middling, but after switching out once it will forme change into Palafin-H, which boasts the highest base Attack in the format, making it an effective wall breaker with Wave Crash, and a great revenge killer with Jet Punch.

  • Flip Turn: Flip Turn is perfect for letting Palafin do some chip damage and escaping before it transforms into the heroic Palafin-H! It's possible to drop if coverage is desperately needed, but forcing Palafin to switch and losing out on a useful pivot move is not the right call in most cases.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch is Palafin-H's best bet against Dragonite before it Terastallizes, and deals decent damage to Amoonguss.

  • Close Combat versus Drain Punch: Close Combat is good coverage, hitting Rotom-W for neutral damage and covering Baxcalibur, Iron Bundle, and Roaring Moon. While weaker, Drain Punch's lack of defensive stat drops makes sense for a better matchup against Focus Sash Chien-Pao and restoring a good amount of health against Iron Bundle before usually KOing it with Jet Punch.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: An Adamant nature increases the damage Wave Crash and Jet Punch inflict, making Palafin-H a more effective wall breaker and revenge killer. A Jolly nature enables Palafin-H to outspeed Jolly Mimikyu, Jolly Baxcalibur, and Jolly Annihilape.

Other Options

  • Grass Knot: Grass Knot lets Palafin-H potentially 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo, whose normally a good Palafin-H check. It doesn't cover anything else that's useful, with Azumarill and Rotom-W being fairly lightweight.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Terastallization can make Palafin-H to an even more potent revenge killer and cleaner, but its not reliant on it.

  • Water: Tera Water makes Palafin-H a potent late-game cleaner, making it the Tera Type that makes sense for most teams.

  • Electric: If willing to give up on consistent coverage by using Tera Blast, Tera Electric Palafin-H deals a big amount of damage against common bulky Water-types like Azumarill, Dondozo, and Toxapex, in addition to saving Palafin-H from Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type turns all of Palafin-H's weaknesses into resistances, giving it a favorable matchup against Rotom-W, and making it immune to Spore from Breloom, Amoonguss, and Brute Bonnet, and having a good Tera Blast against Azumarill and Dondozo. If using the niche Grass Knot, it consistently 2HKOs all but specially defensive Dondozo.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band gives Palafin-H the most amount of wallbreaking and revenge killing power.

  • Assault Vest: Palafin-H's bulk is good enough to survive some powerful attacks with Assault Vest, such as Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry, and it works well with bulkier EV spreads.

  • Mystic Water: If Choice Band is used by another teammate, Mystic Water is a great alternative thanks to most of Palafin-H's attacks being Water-type anyways.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb works well with revenge killing and makes the niche Grass Knot always 2HKO specially defensive Dondozo, but the severe compromise to Palafin-H's bulk, especially with Wave Crash recoil, makes it a lesser option.

Bulkier EV Spreads

  • 140 HP / 252 Atk / 116 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread outspeeds Jolly Breloom, and lets Palafin-H survive Tera Flying Choice Band Tera Blast from Dragonite from full health.

  • 252 HP / 236 Atk / 20 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom, and survives Modest Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast after Stealth Rock damage. If surviving that isn't important or if using Assault Vest, feel free to swap the HP and Attack investments.

  • 60 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def / 12 SpD / 180 Spe with Jolly: This speedy Assault Vest spread outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, survives Jolly Life Orb Tera Dark Chien-Pao's Crunch from full health, and survives Modest Choice Specs Tera Fairy Flutter Mane's Moonblast after Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• Palafin-H's powerful priority and good Speed tier separate it from other Bulk Up sweepers, such as Annihilape.

  • Drain Punch: Even without Tera Fighting, Drain Punch's extra healing makes it a great choice for coverage, and it does massive damage to Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Meowscarada.

  • Taunt versus Substitute: With Taunt, Palafin-H excels at breaking through troublesome defensive Pokemon, such as Corviknight, Wo-Chien, and Skeledirge, and it also gives Palafin a decent move against Ting-Lu and Hippowdon before switching out for Zero to Hero. Substitute has a worse matchup defensive set-up Pokemon, but in exchange it turns Garganacl into an excellent set up opportunity and makes Palafin-H a fearsome sweeper with Toxic Spikes support.

Other Options

  • Ice Punch: If using Tera Water, Ice Punch is a reasonable option for hitting Dragon-types, though it does leave Palafin-H walled by Rotom-W.

  • Encore: While harder to justify than the other support options, Encore does give Palafin-H new chances to set up, punishing slower set-up sweepers like Annihilape in particular.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Unless using Tera Blast, Palafin-H is only pressured to Terastallize to improve certain matchups.

  • Fairy: Besides being an excellent defensive typing that punishes Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu for using Dark-type attacks, Tera Fairy gives Palafin-H a great offensive option against Dragon-types like Dragonite and Baxcalibur, as well as coverage against Wo-Chien and Meowscarada with Tera Blast.

  • Fighting: Boosting Drain Punch's power with Tera Fighting can make Palafin-H even more difficult to take down and can seriously compromise defensive Rotom-W thanks to Taunt or Substitute blocking Will-O-Wisp. However, it does make Palafin-H particularly vulnerable to Flutter Mane.

  • Water: Tera Water helps Palafin-H pick off more threats with Jet Punch, having a good shot to OHKO offensive Flutter Mane unboosted after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Poison: Besides offering a useful Fairy resistance, Tera Poison lets Palafin-H absorb Toxic Spikes and stop Toxic without a support move, making it a viable alternative.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers takes advantage of Palafin-H's slow setup and is a requirement if using Substitute.

  • Punching Glove: If using Taunt, Punching Glove is a good option to free up Leftovers for a teammate. Palafin-H appreciates the extra power Jet Punch and Drain Punch gain, and it becomes harder for Rocky Helmet Dragonite to wear it down.

  • Covert Cloak: If using Taunt, Covert Cloak turns the tables on the Garganacl matchup in addition to protecting Palafin-H from surprise Light Ball Flings from foes like Annihilape.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 140 SpD / 116 Spe with Careful: This spread maximizes Palafin-H's Special Defense while still outspeeding Jolly Breloom.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Speed allows Palafin-H to outspeed fast support Pokemon like Mimikyu and Annihilape so it can Taunt them. This spread also outspeeds the rare Choice Specs Hydreigon, which can deal massive damage with Draco Meteor if not using Tera Fairy.

  • 252 HP / 140 Atk / 116 Spe with Adamant: This is a far more offensive approach to the set, letting Palafin-H function more as a revenge killer with the potential to sweep rather than a bulky setup Pokemon. This is best used with Tera Water, as Palafin-H will then OHKO offensive Flutter Mane with unboosted Jet Punch. The given Speed is for outspeeding Jolly Breloom.

sets.name: Palafin
sets.description: Palafin's powerful priority offense and pivoting make it a dangerous threat even with its standard ability. Jet Punch from Palafin-H easily revenge kills dangerous threats like Kilowattrel, Sandy Shocks, and Talonflame, as well as Chien-Pao after minor chip damage. Palafin is heavily hampered by Desolate Land; to take down their users, Zen Headbutt from Palafin-H easily OHKOes Iron Moth and 2HKOes Ceruledge, while Close Combat flings Cinderace into the sun. Pivoting teammates such as Kilowattrel, Meowscarada, and Corviknight not only form dangerous pivoting cores with Palafin, but also position it to both activate Zero to Hero and fire off its powerful Jet Punch. Due to its frequent need to switch and reliance on a recoil move to wallbreak, Palafin requires effective entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Donphan; WishPass Scream Tail is also a great teammate to heal off chip damage. Even with its strong coverage moves, Palafin struggles mightily against opposing Desolate Land, so reliable switch-ins like Well-Baked Body Slither Wing are strongly recommended. Palafin struggles against Dondozo, making teammates that can punish it like Meowscarada and Spikes Garchomp good additions.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Overcoat is an option over Filter so Venomoth can't try to muscle past a weakened Revavroom with Sleep Powder and enough sleep turns.

sets.name: Shift Gear
sets.description: Tera Ground covers Steel- and Fire-types such as Klefki, Coalossal, and Paldean Tauros-F, but Tera Fire can be used for Bronzong.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: The given Speed EVs allows Cyclizar to outspeed Hisuian Zoroark. If running Draco Meteor or Overheat, Cyclizar should be run with a Timid Nature, 80 Special Attack EVs, and 176 Speed EVs in order to outspeed Maushold.

sets.name: Shed Tail Support
sets.description: Cyclizar's access to Shed Tail lets it facilitate dangerous setup sweepers on hyper offense teams. Draco Meteor gives Cyclizar a way to revenge kill weakened Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Miraidon, but Knock Off can be used instead with a Jolly nature for a way to chip down and remove Rocky Helmet or Leftovers from Pokemon that may use Cyclizar as an entry point, such as Toxapex, Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Hatterene. U-turn lets Cyclizar regenerate its health back from low ranges, while pivoting in teammates. Rapid Spin lets Cyclizar act as a form of entry hazard removal for its team, but this is generally an emergency removal option. Choice Scarf is generally preferred, since it lets Cyclizar use Shed Tail on usually faster threats like Iron Bundle, non-Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon, Flutter Mane outside of sun, and Chien-Pao lacking Ice Shard. Sitrus Berry, especially when paired with dual screens, provides Cyclizar with a way to recover enough HP to use Shed Tail after taking a hit such as Great Tusk's Headlong Rush, Air Balloon Flutter Mane's Moonblast, or Miraidon's Dazzling Gleam. Tera Fairy lets Cyclizar use Shed Tail against the likes of Koraidon, Miraidon, and Great Tusk by providing a resistance to their Dragon- and Fighting-type coverage. Tera Ghost gives Cyclizar a Fighting-type immunity, granting it the ability to use Shed Tail in front of Choice Scarf Koraidon leads. Cyclizar supports its teammates on hyper offense teams by passing them a Substitute, which lets them avoid status and set up more easily, especially under dual screens. As such, Grimmsnarl is a great partner for making it easier for Cyclizar to pass Substitutes with Shed Tail and for teammates such as Swords Dance Koraidon and Double Dance Miraidon to set up and sweep. Espathra especially enjoys Shed Tail, as a Substitute and dual screens support gives it the longevity to reliably use Calm Mind multiple times. Taunt variants of Koraidon also appreciate Cyclizar using Shed Tail, as it can thwart phazing attempts from Ting-Lu and prevent Toxic Spikes—which bypasses Substitutes—being set up by Toxapex. Great Tusk and Annihilape are also good partners for Cyclizar. Bulk Up variants of Great Tusk are able to take on Koraidon and appreciate Substitute blocking Toxic, giving Great Tusk leeway to set up. Annihilape also appreciates Substitute preventing Toxic and is immune to Koraidon's Fighting-type STAB moves.

sets.name: vroom vroom (Shed Tail)
sets.description:
• Cyclizar’s niche is in its ability to pass Substitutes to threatening sweepers, finding use solely on hyper offense teams.
  • Rapid Spin works well for teams weak to entry hazards. It’s a good way to support threats weak to Stealth Rock, like Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle.
  • Draco Meteor can be used over Rapid Spin to do big damage to Koraidon, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle for teams weak to them. However, it has no practical use outside of this.
  • U-turn lets Cyclizar scout for switches and bring its teammates in even when it’s low on HP, giving itself Regenerator recovery and eventually letting it use Shed Tail again.
  • Knock Off provides item removal, which helps its team break past otherwise irritating walls like Toxapex and Dondozo. Offensive Pokemon like Koraidon also really don’t like losing items such as Choice Scarf.
  • Choice Scarf is the preferred item on Cyclizar, as it allows it to easily use Shed Tail for a teammate as soon as it hits the field. However, Heavy-Duty Boots can be used on teams weak to entry hazards.
  • Cyclizar is a vital component on dual screens hyper-offense teams, as Cyclizar can feed its team free Substitutes, giving its teammates an easier time setting up and sweeping in combination with the bulk afforded by dual screens support.
  • Grimmsnarl sets up dual screens reliably, letting Cyclizar use Shed Tail easily and letting the rest of its team go to work.
  • Espathra is an excellent partner, as the free Substitute and dual screens set up by Cyclizar and Grimmsnarl let Espathra take hits and avoid status attempts, making it hard to stop.
  • Swords Dance Flame Charge Koraidon is also a good partner, as with dual screens and a Substitute, it has an easier time setting up while also avoiding the otherwise ruinous Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge.
  • Double Dance Miraidon loves the Substitute passed to it by Cyclizar, as it makes it significantly harder to revenge kill, allowing Miraidon to take over a game more easily.
  • Other frail sweepers like Nasty Plot Chi-Yu and Calm Mind Flutter Mane also appreciate Cyclizar’s Substitute, as it allows them to freely set up.

sets.name: Shed Tail Support (Normal)
sets.description:
Cyclizar is a good choice on Normal teams, as it facilitates sweeping attempts from Ursaluna as well as giving dangerous offensive threats, such as Hisuian Zoroark, a free switch-in opportunity. Shed Tail, when combined with Regenerator, causes Cyclizar to effectively only lose 27% of its HP every time it uses the move. This lets Cyclizar enable its powerful teammates multiple times throughout the game. Rapid Spin allows Cyclizar to act as an entry hazard removal option if it cannot set up Shed Tail. Draco Meteor is run over a secondary utility move to hit Baxcalibur and Hydreigon trying to set up on a predicted Shed Tail, but it can be dropped for another utility move. Additionally, Shed Tail allows Cyclizar to remove Draco Meteor's stat drops. Knock Off is useful for removing defensive items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots, while Taunt stops any setup attempts from Quiver Dance Volcarona as well as preventing more than one layer of hazards from Ting-Lu. Finally, U-turn allows Cyclizar to keep momentum for its team while chipping the opponent and without having to use Shed Tail.

Ursaluna is a great teammate for Cyclizar, as it can utilize Shed Tail to start setting up Swords Dance and activate Flame Orb safely. Additionally, Ursaluna's massive physical bulk means that defensive Pokemon such as Clodsire struggle to break Ursaluna's Substitute. Staraptor takes care of Fighting-types such as offensive Great Tusk and Zamazenta for Cyclizar while providing crucial speed control thanks to Choice Scarf. In return, Cyclizar provides an effective source of entry hazard control for Staraptor. Choice Scarf Indeedee also threatens Fighting-types while protecting Cyclizar from priority such as Breloom's Mach Punch thanks to Psychic Surge. Hisuian Zoroark can switch in on Fighting-type attacks thanks to its Ghost typing, allowing it to gain crucial momentum and deal with threats such as Urshifu-R. In exchange, Hisuian Zoroark appreciates a fairly safe switch-in opportunity as well as being able to gain pivotal turns to set up using Nasty Plot with Illusion disguising it. Maushold is another decent teammate for Cyclizar, as it can clean up games with Tidy Up and Population Bomb while appreciating Rocky Helmet being removed from foes thanks to Cyclizar's Knock Off. Tidy Up does remove Cyclizar's Shed Tail, however. Finally, Ditto can punish foes such as Swords Dance Chien-Pao and Quiver Dance Volcarona attempting to set up on a predicted Shed Tail by copying their boosts.

sets.name: Shed Tail
sets.description:
• Orthworm faciliates setup sweepers on hyper offense teams thanks to its Ground immunity and access to Shed Tail. Unlike Cyclizar, Orthworm is able to pass slow Shed Tails due to its low Speed.
  • Orthworm has access to both Stealth Rock and Spikes, helping it wear down walls for its setup sweeper teammates. Stealth Rock is usually preferred for limiting Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle, but Spikes can be used if your team already has a Stealth Rock setter. Body Press punishes Kingambit and Chien-Pao trying to wear down and set up on Orthworm. Iron Head is a STAB move that lets Orthworm hit Flutter Mane trying to Taunt it.
  • Tera Water allows Orthworm to safely set up Shed Tail on Koraidon. Tera Ghost lets Orthworm completely blank Fighting-type attacks from Koraidon and Great Tusk while preventing Rapid Spin users from removing entry hazards set by both Orthworm and its teammates. However, Terastallizing Orthworm instead of one of its teammates is often not worth it.
  • Sitrus Berry provides Orthworm with the flexibility to take an attack and use Shed Tail, but Mental Herb is an option to block Taunt.
  • Grimmsnarl is a fantastic partner, as it provides screens support that improves Orthworm's longevity and further eases setup for teammates behind Shed Tail.
  • Entry hazard setters such as Glimmora and Froslass can wear down opponents in conjunction with Orthworm's hazards and Shed Tail, making it easier for teammates to break through walls.
  • Setup sweepers such as Koraidon, Miraidon, Kingambit, Iron Moth, and Espathra appreciate Orthworm's Shed Tail preventing status while giving them some leeway to boost. Koraidon in particular also appreciates Orthworm walling Great Tusk without Fighting-type moves and deterring Great Tusk from using Ground-type moves. Swords Dance Chien-Pao and Calm Mind Flutter Mane similarly appreciate Orthworm's Shed Tail easing setup by compensating for their lower bulk.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Thanks to Earth Eater, Orthworm can wall sets of many physical Dragon-types like Garchomp and Baxcalibur.

  • Heavy Slam versus Iron Head: Heavy Slam can 2HKO offensive Dragapult, OHKOs Flutter Mane, and deals much more damage to Iron Valiant, while Iron Head is superior for Dragonite.

  • Rest and Chesto Berry: Rest is an option with Chesto Berry to heal Orthworm in a pinch, giving it better longevity.

  • Shed Tail: Shed Tail gives Orthworm use when IronPress isn't as effective. The surprise factor comes at the price of the reduced effectiveness of IronPress.

  • Substitute: Substitute stops Salt Cure damage from Garganacl and phazing from Garchomp's Dragon Tail.

Other Options

  • Earthquake is an option to hit Gholdengo, but it won't 2HKO, so Recover is still a problem.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry allows two uses of Shed Tail.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a consistent option, especially in conjunction with Substitute.

Tera Types

  • Poison: Tera Poison provides a key Fighting resistance and single weakness and maintains a key resistance to Flower Trick, letting Orthworm preform better against Meowscarada, Great Tusk, and Iron Valiant.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy provides a Fighting resistance and Dragon immunity, turning Dragon Tail Garchomp into setup bait, and dealing with Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Roaring Moon.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: This EV spread makes Orthworm much less likely to be 2HKOd by Life Orb Dragapult.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread can be used to outspeed Adamant Kingambit, most Corviknight, and Skeledirge. This can be very useful if using Shed Tail.

sets.name: Shed Tail Support
sets.description:
• Orthworm's good physical bulk and ability make it a great user of Shed Tail, and a reliable Stealth Rock user.

  • Body Press: Body Press has a good chance to OHKO offensive Meowscarada, and threatens Kingambit and Roaring Moon.

  • Heavy Slam versus Iron Head: A Steel-type STAB move helps hit some Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Flutter Mane, who are OHKOed by Heavy Slam, and deals massive damage to Iron Valiant. Iron Head is an alternative for heavy foes like Dragonite.

  • Spikes: Orthworm can also set Spikes, but this compromises its ability to pass Shed Tail.

  • A Special Teammate: Many Pokemon can benefit from Orthworm's Shed Tail. One example is Air Balloon Gholdengo, which puts a lot of pressure on defensive foes when behind a Substitute.

Tera Types

  • This Orthworm isn't usually meant to Terastalize, since that's better served by the teammates its passing a Substitute to.

  • Poison: Tera Poison leaves Orthworm with only one fairly rare weakness, and aiding it against former threats like Great Tusk and Iron Valiant.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Orthworm a Fighting resistance, as well as a way to absorb Garchomp's Dragon Tail while still staying in.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD: This spread maximizes Orthworm's physical bulk. Running a Speed IV of 0 may be tempting, but being outsped by bulky Brute Bonnet is risky.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread outspeeds Kingambit, and most Skeledirge and Corviknight. Outspeeding Kingambit and Corviknight prevents Taunt from stopping Shed Tail, and let's Orthworm bring in a teammate against Torch Song.

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 212 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom and Jolly Brute Bonnet. Mach Punch still does a lot, but thanks to Sitrus Berry, Orthworm will have enough HP left to Shed Tail to a check or counter.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
With Stealth Rock and its ability Toxic Debris, Focus Sash Glimmora functions as a lead that can set hazards both actively and, when hit by a physical attack, passively. Mortal Spin lets Glimmora remove entry hazards for its team and potentially poison an opposing Pokemon. Earth Power hits Steel-types like Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Iron Treads, which all block Mortal Spin. Energy Ball is mainly used to hit Great Tusk but also deals super effective damage against Garganacl, Rotom-W, and Greninja. Alternatively, Sludge Wave allows Glimmora to threaten Hatterene, which would otherwise be troublesome thanks to its Magic Bounce ability and STAB Psychic-type moves like Psyshock. Spikes is another option that allows Glimmora to set up as many entry hazards as possible. Tera Grass turns Glimmora's weakness to Ground into a resistance and increases the damage output of Energy Ball, both of which are particularly useful against Great Tusk. Alternatively, Tera Ghost blocks Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk and Iron Treads, ensuring all of Glimmora's hazards stay up.

Hyper offense teams appreciate Glimmora's entry hazards providing chip damage support for setup sweepers like Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Kingambit. Gholdengo is a great partner for Glimmora: its ability Good As Gold lets it block Defog attempts from Corviknight, while its Ghost typing prevents Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk and Iron Treads, so it allows Glimmora's hazards to stay up throughout the game. Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Choice Specs Dragapult can use Great Tusk as an opportunity to fire off powerful attacks–Great Tusk can crush Glimmora with Earthquake and remove its entry hazards with Rapid Spin.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Glimmora is an adequate revenge killer thanks to its power and coverage. Earth Power hits Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Iron Treads. Spikes allows Glimmora to take advantage of the switches it forces to support its teammates, with Toxic Debris allowing it to stack multiple hazards by itself, even as a revenge killer. Alternatively, Dazzling Gleam can be used to hit Great Tusk, Garchomp, Dragapult, and Hydreigon for super effective damage. Tera Ground gives Glimmora the extra power it needs to OHKO Steel-types like Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Iron Treads and 2HKO Garganacl and Toxapex. Tera Fairy makes Glimmora immune to Dragon-type attacks, such as Dragapult's Draco Meteor and Dragon Darts, and lets it OHKO Great Tusk, Dragapult, and Greninja. Alternatively, Glimmora can opt for Energy Ball paired with Tera Grass instead, as this removes its Water- and Ground-type weaknesses and lets it threaten Great Tusk and Rotom-W.

Bulky offense teams appreciate the Speed, power, and potential entry hazards Choice Scarf Glimmora provides. Steel-types like Kingambit and Gholdengo benefit from Glimmora's ability to deal with Fire-types like Cinderace. Physical attackers like Kingambit and Great Tusk benefit from Glimmora weakening physical walls such as Dondozo, Rotom-W, and Great Tusk. Likewise, Glimmora appreciates said physical attackers, as they help deal with special walls Glimmora has trouble breaking through such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and specially defensive Corviknight. Rotom-W can take on Great Tusk's Ground-type and Greninja's Water-type attacks, both of which Glimmora is weak to. Stealth Rock users such as Great Tusk and Garchomp can complement Glimmora's Spikes and help it deal with Steel-types. Cinderace lures in Skeledirge, Ceruledge, Dondozo, and Dragonite and uses U-turn for Glimmora to take advantage of them.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description: Glimmora is one of the metagame's best suicide leads because of its access to utility moves such as Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Memento as well as its signature ability Toxic Debris. Earth Power threatens Iron Treads and Gholdengo, which could otherwise block Mortal Spin, and does a lot of damage to Pokemon like Chi-Yu, Miraidon, Skeledirge, and Toxapex. Alternatively, Power Gem can OHKO lead Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao. Memento grants a free switch for Glimmora's teammates, such as Double Dance Koraidon and Miraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao to set up, and it also blocks potential attempts at hazard removal. Tera Ghost can block Rapid Spin from Great Tusk and Iron Treads if necessary. Glimmora best fits on hyper offense teams with Pokemon like Taunt Iron Bundle, Annihilape, and Gholdengo to block entry hazard removal, and setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Koraidon, Calm Mind Miraidon, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao to take advantage of the entry hazards it lays. Grimmsnarl is also a good partner that can set up dual screens and use Prankster Taunt to prevent Defog or entry hazards from foes.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description:
• Glimmora stands out as one of the best suicide leads in the metagame thanks to its signature ability in Toxic Debris and great utility movepool consisting of Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Memento. Its high Special Attack alongside STAB and coverage options in Power Gem and Earth Power let it threaten most foes including Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Iron Treads.
  • Tera Ghost Glimmora prevents common spinners like Iron Treads and Great Tusk from removing the entry hazards that Glimmora sets. Glimmora also benefits from Tera Ghost removing its 4x weakness to Ground-type attacks, letting it threaten these spinners with its coverage more reliably. However, given the nature of Glimmora as a dedicated lead, Terastallizing is not generally recommended.
  • Dazzling Gleam threatens Fighting-types like Koraidon and Great Tusk, as well as Miraidon. Its signature move, Mortal Spin, lets Glimmora act as an entry hazard remover and also cripples Stealth Rock setters like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk with poison.
  • Mortal Spin is a good option when facing setup sweepers that Glimmora cannot threaten if it doesn't have the right coverage like Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon, Double Dance Miraidon, and Bulk Up Annihilape.
  • Memento allows a teammate to come in easily while also preventing entry hazard removal attempts.
  • Glimmora likes offensive staples like Miraidon and Koraidon that can take advantage of the entry hazards it sets up. They both threaten to OHKO Defog Corviknight.
  • Glimmora also appreciates Ghost-types such as Annihilape, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo, while they appreciate the entry hazards that Glimmora sets.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Support (Poison)
sets.description:
Glimmora provides useful utility for Poison teams thanks to its status as the only entry hazard remover for Poison teams, ability to put walls such as Amoonguss and Corviknight on a timer with Toxic, and access to Stealth Rock, which completes Poison's entry hazard stacking core. Mortal Spin's poison wears down entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk and Hatterene looking to bounce back Stealth Rock over time. Steel-types like Iron Treads, Heatran, and Gholdengo can block Mortal Spin, so Earth Power is great, as it punishes these for switching into it; however, Stealth Rock is usually the better option, as it helps Poison teams wear down opposing teams more quickly. For similar reasons, Toxic is great for putting Steel-types, notably Corviknight, on a timer, and it also eases the Poison matchup, as Glimmora outspeeds and can inflict Toxic on the aforementioned walls before it faints. Power Gem prevents Glimmora from being too passive and lets it threaten non-Glaive Rush Baxcalibur if its Air Balloon is intact and Substitute + Bulk Up Corviknight. Energy Ball lets Glimmora threaten Water-types like Quagsire, which normally threatens it out. Maximum Special Attack and Speed boost Glimmora's offensive presence, allowing it to outspeed and possibly win against Gholdengo one-on-one with Earth Power. Air Balloon further increases Glimmora's utility, as it lets Gholdengo double as a switch-in to Choice-locked threats such as Great Tusk and Iron Jugulis, which tend to lock into a Ground-type move against Poison. Alternatively, Black Sludge along with a more defensive EV spread of 252 HP / 212 Def / 44 Spe and a Bold nature improves Glimmora's longevity, notably allowing it to survive a +2 Crunch from Chien-Pao and outspeed and inflict Toxic on Jolly Kingambit. If this is desired, Spiky Shield is a better option over Stealth Rock to further rack up recovery.

As Glimmora's typing is horrible into types such as Water and Ground, Toxapex and Amoonguss are great partners, as both sponge hits from threats such as Barraskewda, Quagsire, and non-Choice Band Great Tusk with ease. Furthermore, these Pokemon allow Glimmora's Toxic to do its job and take out Bulk Up Corviknight, opposing Amoonguss, and Clodsire by completely walling them. Amoonguss in particular is great into Ground-types like Landorus-T, which Glimmora can't do much against. Alolan Muk provides a Psychic-type immunity and is an extremely bulky special wall that helps against Choice Specs Dragapult, Hatterene, and Flutter Mane. It also provides Knock Off support, which leaves walls such as Toxapex to be vulnerable to Glimmora's entry hazards. Clodsire provides Spikes, checks other special attackers such as Quiver Dance Volcarona, Nasty Plot Hydreigon, and Regieleki. Alternatively, Overqwil may also be considered as Glimmora's entry hazard stacking partner, as it can deal with Iron Valiant and Belly Drum Azumarill. Salazzle forms a Corrosion core with Glimmora and can land Toxic on threats such as Heatran, which loathe coming into Glimmora. It also provides Encore to neutralize Swords Dance Kingambit and Bulk Up Landorus-T and has access to Knock Off to further disrupt foes. Sneasler threatens Kingambit and loves Glimmora's ability to wear down walls like Toxapex and Corviknight and lure in Gholdengo and hit it with Toxic or Earth Power, allowing Sneasler to clean up Water and Steel teams late-game. Iron Moth also appreciates Glimmora wearing down teams with its entry hazards and dealing with Skeledirge; it is also the best response Poison teams have against Nasty Plot Gholdengo. Galarian Slowking is also an option, as it makes progress in the Poison matchup with Future Sight and retains the ability to pivot or damage with special attackers like Basculegion-F, Landorus, and Nasty Plot Rotom-W, but it can be quickly taken advantage of by the multitude of Dark- and Ghost-types in the tier.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker (Rock)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Debris Lead
sets.description:
• With a solid early-game Speed tier, utility, high Special Attack, and decent coverage options, Glimmora can set the tone of a battle, sometimes scoring KOs before fulfilling its main role of setting entry hazards.

  • Mud Shot: This will fail to KO many foes—most notably other Glimmora—but it is a valuable form of speed control that can immediately turn the game in your favor.

  • Mortal Spin: If using Stealth Rock weak teammates like Dragonite, Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, or Baxcalibur, clearing the hazards with Mortal Spin can be quite useful, in addition to putting a timer on common entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Annihilape.

  • Memento: Memento immediately makes way for a devastating sweeper to set up against foes with halved offensive stats and potentially lowered Speed.

  • Toxic Spikes Partners: While Toxic Debris doesn't gurantee Toxic Spikes will be set up, it's still good to consider running a teammate with it in mind. Wo-Chien, Defensive Dragonite sets, Annihilape, and Bulk Up Palafin-H are good examples to consider.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Tera Flying vastly improves Glimmora's matchup against Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Garchomp.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type is an option to absorb Spore from Breloom, Amoonguss, and Brute Bonnet.

Items

  • Focus Sash: This is the most reliable item for setting up Stealth Rock.

  • Air Balloon: With Air Balloon, Glimmora vastly improves its match-up against Ground-type leads such as Garchomp.

sets.name: Bulky Support
sets.description:
• 244 HP / 132 Def / 132 SpD: This EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash.

  • 244 HP / 76 Def / 188 SpD: The given EVs allow Glimmora to almost always avoid a 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Tera Fairy Flutter Mane, survive Glaive Rush + Ice Shard from Baxcalibur, and have a good chance of avoiding a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash.

  • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Glimmora is a valuable dedicated lead on hyper offense teams that can reliably set up multiple entry hazards in Stealth Rock, Toxic Spikes, and potentially Spikes, as well as remove opposing ones with Mortal Spin. It can make use of its solid coverage options and remarkable Special Attack to pose a noticeable offensive threat itself, especially against common entry hazard setters, removers, and other dedicated leads. Power Gem threatens the metagame's best Defogger in Tornadus-T, while Sludge Bomb dents screens setters such as Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko and—if Focus Sash is still intact—Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant as well, which can be problematic against offensive teams. Earth Power pressures Steel-types like Heatran, Gholdengo, and Kingambit that would otherwise block Glimmora's Mortal Spin, while Energy Ball deals with other entry hazard setters and removers such as Great Tusk, Gastrodon, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W. Focus Sash guarantees that Glimmora can set at least one layer of entry hazards, potentially letting Toxic Debris trigger twice as well. Tera Ghost is used in a pinch to spinblock foes such as Great Tusk and Excadrill and remove its Ground weakness to set up multiple entry hazards in the face of other setters like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gastrodon. Gholdengo is a near-mandatory teammate to keep up entry hazards by blocking every attempts to remove them, such as Defog and Rapid Spin. Setup sweepers like Kingambit, Volcarona, Dragapult, Dragonite, and Iron Valiant appreciate entry hazards wearing down foes such as Dondozo and Clodsire and not being chipped down by opposing ones themselves; particularly, Kingambit's Knock Off can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Tornadus-T, Toxapex, and Volcarona to make them vulnerable to Glimmora's entry hazards.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Support (Rock)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: What the dog doin? (Offensive)
sets.description:
• Houndstone functions as a wallbreaker and occasional revenge killer for sand teams once some teammates have fainted.
  • Body Press is used to hit Blissey, as well as Tera Normal Flutter Mane.
  • Play Rough is ideal for Choice Band sets to hit common switch-ins such as Koraidon and Ting-Lu. Will-O-Wisp is useful on Spell Tag sets to cripple Koraidon.
  • Choice Band provides more upfront power, allowing Play Rough to OHKO Koraidon and 3HKO Ting-Lu. Spell Tag provides flexibility, easing prediction against teams with Normal-types and making Flutter Mane much easier to deal with by using Shadow Sneak.
  • The given EVs allow Houndstone to outspeed Iron Bundle in sand without Electric Terrain. The rest is dumped into HP.
  • Either Hippowdon or Tyranitar is a mandatory teammate to provide sand so that Houndstone can function. Hippowdon acts as a Koraidon switch-in, while Tyranitar can check Chi-Yu.
  • If not using Hippowdon, a solid Koraidon check such as Great Tusk is highly recommended, as Koraidon's sun can severely limit Houndstone.
  • Pelipper is another Pokemon that will get rid of sand upon entry, so be sure to pack anti-rain options.
  • Houndstone is severely limited by its average Speed even in sand, as well as reliant on fallen teammates to power up Last Respects. This makes Houndstone generally unreliable as a wallbreaker or revenge killer, though it is extremely strong in certain circumstances. As such, be sure to pack alternative wallbreakers and revenge killers.
  • Miraidon is a good teammate, as it can provide both revenge killing and wallbreaking power and appreciates Houndstone breaking down Koraidon and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Houndstone carves a niche in the metagame as a bulky spinblocker that can comfortably switch into Great Tusk and Iron Treads.
  • Will-O-Wisp prevents physical attackers from setting up on Houndstone and spreads status on passive Pokemon like Corviknight, Toxapex, and Ting-Lu.
  • Rest gets rid of status and helps Houndstone remain healthy throughout the game.
  • Houndstone's EVs and ability make it surprisingly bulky, allowing it to survive even a Tera Dark Crunch from Choice Band Chien-Pao and OHKO back with Body Press.
  • Tera Water grants Houndstone a resistance to Fire-type moves, which are otherwise super effective because of its ability. Additionally, it gives Houndstone a neutral typing against threats like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Annihilape.
  • Houndstone's primary role is to act as a spinblocker with some defensive utility, so it is essential to pair it with Pokemon that set entry hazards such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads, as well as strong wallbreakers like Chien-Pao, Koraidon, Annihilape, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle that make the most out of the chip damage.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Scrappy Choice Item
sets.description:
• Scrappy gives Flamigo a unique niche, letting it throw out powerful Close Combats that are unsafe for Gholdengo and Dragapult to take!

  • Throat Chop is a decent filler move, letting Flamigo shut down Sylveon's Hyper Voice and Skeledirge's Torch Song. Note that Close Combat still does more damage to most Ghost-types.

  • Tailwind is a filler move that gives Flamigo's team some extreme speed control before it goes down.

Tera Types

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting lets Flamigo fully take advantage of Scrappy, giving Choice Scarf sets a 81.3% chance to OHKO offensive Dragapult.

  • Fire: Tera Fire makes Flamigo immune to Will-O-Wisp, letting Choice Band sets more easily break through Skeledirge, and gives Flamigo the option to 2HKO Corviknight with Tera Blast.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With Choice Scarf, Flamigo outspeeds major threats such as Dragapult and Hydreigon, making it a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band lets Flamigo deal massive damage, giving it a shot at 2HKOing Skeledirge with Close Combat.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

nu.overview: Fillet Away in conjunction with Sharpness-boosted STAB moves turns Veluza into a terrifying sweeper capable of shredding teams with only a single turn of setup. Veluza is an excellent choice for hyper offense teams, where it acts as a deadly wallbreaker and late-game cleaner. Veluza can easily find setup opportunities against passive foes, such as Vaporeon, and Choice-locked foes, such as a Passimian that just used Close Combat. Although Veluza is extremely powerful after setting up, it may not always get the chance to do so due to its frailty. Veluza's defensive typing is also relatively poor; it is weak to common attacks, including pivoting moves like U-turn from Scyther and Volt Switch from Rotom. Furthermore, Veluza's speed and firepower are rather mediocre prior to setup.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Tera Ground enables Veluza to turn the tables on a Jolteon or Rotom trying to grab momentum with Volt Switch. Tera Electric is another option that lets Veluza avoid paralysis from Chansey and Sandaconda while also turning its Electric weakness into a resistance.

Checks and Counters

Offensive Pressure: Veluza's mediocre bulk and need to sacrifice half of its health to set up means that sufficient offensive pressure can prevent it from taking over a game.

U-turn and Volt Switch: Veluza's poor defensive typing renders it weak to both U-turn and Volt Switch, which means that foes such as Jolteon and Scyther can easily gain momentum on or KO it.

Cacturne: Cacturne is immune to Psycho Cut and Aqua Cutter, enabling it to completely wall any Veluza not running Tera Fairy Tera Blast.

sets.name: Physical Sweeper
sets.description:
Set Details

Fillet Away is one of the best setup moves in the game, doubling Veluza's Speed and power at the cost of half its health. Aqua Cutter and Psycho Cut are both boosted by Sharpness, and after a Fillet Away will OHKO many neutral targets, such as Rotom, Mabosstiff, and Clawitzer. For Veluza's last move, Substitute can be used to ease prediction, facilitate setup, and avoid Sucker Punch. Aqua Jet can also be used to revenge kill weakened foes and, after setup, outprioritize other priority moves such as Lycanroc's Accelerock. Tera Blast is an option with Tera Fairy to blast past Cacturne, which otherwise completely walls it. Otherwise, Tera Water is good choice to further boost the power of Veluza's Aqua Cutter, giving it a guaranteed OHKO on specially defensive Umbreon after Stealth Rock. Sitrus Berry helps Veluza set up sucessfully, and 4 HP EVs ensure that it will activate after a Fillet Away. An Adamant nature is preferred to maximize Veluza's damage output, but a Jolly nature enables Veluza to outspeed Timid Farigiraf prior to setup and Choice Scarf Zoroark post-setup.

Veluza's incredible Speed and power after setup make it an excellent choice for hyper offense teams. Entry hazard support from Lycanroc and Qwilfish can help chip Veluza's checks into range of its attacks. Bulk Up Paldean Tauros is a great partner for Veluza, as it can easily switch into and set up against Pokemon that give Veluza trouble, such as Cacturne. In return, Veluza can set up on Pokemon used to revenge kill or force out Paldean Tauros, like a Choice Scarf Indeedee-F locked into Psychic or Psyshock. Paldean Tauros also helps Veluza break past shared walls in Vaporeon and Tera Water Sandaconda, enabling one of them to sweep late-game. Other good offensive partners to pair with Veluza include Jolteon and Quiver Dance Vivillon. Jolteon provides an Electric immunity for the team while also giving Veluza points of entry through Volt Switch. Vivillon threatens Cacturne, and its Sleep Powder may cripple one of Veluza's checks, allowing it to sweep. Indeedee-F is another good teammate for Veluza, as Psychic Terrain shields Veluza from priority attacks, such as Sucker Punch, while boosting the power of Psycho Cut to absurd levels.

sets.name: Wall
sets.description:
Dondozo is one of OU's premier walls, capable of shutting down dangerous setup sweepers like Roaring Moon. Liquidation is Dondozo's STAB move of choice due to its lack of recoil, but Wave Crash's power has some merit against foes like Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, and Clodsire. While weaker, Waterfall is another option that has more PP than Liquidation, allowing Dondozo to perform better against stall; however, its use case is rare. Body Press makes use of Dondozo's massive Defense stat and punishes Pokemon like Tera Normal Dragonite and Kingambit. Avalanche + Earthquake is a decent alternative to hit most of the metagame at least neutrally. Rest + Sleep Talk provides Dondozo with good sustainability without making it too passive. Protect can also be used to accumulate Leftovers recovery and scout for Choice item users like Meowscarada and Iron Valiant. Tera Fairy offers a generally strong defensive profile and grants Dondozo an immunity to Dragon-type attacks like Tera Dragon Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and Walking Wake's Draco Meteor. Tera Grass can be run instead to maintain Dondozo's Water resistance while granting it a resistance to Grass- and Electric-type attacks like Meowscarada's Flower Trick, Brute Bonnet's Bullet Seed, and Zapdos's Discharge and Volt Switch. Tera Fighting can also be considered, as it boosts Body Press and lets Dondozo check Kingambit and Choice Band Roaring Moon.

Entry hazard setters like Clodsire and Ting-Lu pair perfectly with Dondozo, playing into its desire to outlast foes long-term with chip damage in the form of entry hazards, status, or Ruination. Both also check special attackers like Iron Valiant and Gholdengo, which Dondozo tends to struggle with. Garganacl deserves a special mention as a teammate due to its ability to wear down foes with Salt Cure; it, in turn, appreciates Dondozo taking on Great Tusk and Kingambit. Hatterene provides Dondozo teams with an excellent sweeper and appreciates Dondozo taking care of physical wallbreakers like Dragapult, and Kingambit. It also can help by blocking opposing entry hazards with Magic Bounce, letting Dondozo more comfortably tank a Knock Off from Great Tusk or Iron Treads. Similarly, entry hazard removal from Corviknight or Great Tusk is also helpful; Corviknight also deals with Meowscarada, which can force Dondozo to Terastallize early. Choice Scarf Gholdengo can help pressure opposing Dondozo while dealing with Dragapult and Iron Valiant. Dondozo also fits very well on stall teams, which appreciate its ability to wall so many physical attackers. Blissey is a standout teammate due to its ability to blanket check most special attackers, while Dondozo sponges physical attacks that Blissey cannot stomach. Lastly, Alomomola is a solid teammate on stall teams, as it can provide Wish support so Dondozo doesn't need to use Rest as frequently and can effectively utilize Whirlpool to trap opponents and prevent their double switches, allowing Dondozo to come in safely against physical attackers it walls.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description:
Curse Dondozo is a deceptively strong sweeper that provides good defensive utility before it attempts a sweep. Liquidation is preferred over Wave Crash due to its lack of recoil; however, Wave Crash is an option if a stronger STAB move is desired. Body Press makes use of Dondozo's naturally high Defense stat and Curse's boosts to deal with foes like Baxcalibur and Roaring Moon. The combination of Avalanche + Earthquake can be run instead, which hits most of the metagame at least neutrally. Protect lets Dondozo accumulate Leftovers recovery and scouting for Choice item users like Iron Valiant and Breloom. However, Protect can be dropped for Rest, which affords Dondozo greater longevity at the cost of becoming more passive. Leftovers is preferred over Heavy-Duty Boots, as Dondozo will be on the field for many turns in a row to adequately set up with Curse; however, if a team requires Dondozo to play more defensively, Heavy-Duty Boots is a fine choice, though it should not be run alongside Protect. Grass is Dondozo's Tera type of choice, removing its original weaknesses while giving it an important resistance to Ground. Maximum investment in special bulk allows Dondozo to become nigh-unbreakable once it sets up. However, other generally good defensive Tera types like Steel and Fairy are situational options that can be utilized instead.

Entry hazard removal is key for Dondozo if it does not run Heavy-Duty Boots; good options include Great Tusk, Cinderace, and Corviknight. Though Dondozo can have quite the offensive presence once it sets up, it is best to run it alongside consistent wallbreakers like Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Iron Valiant, which can help break open holes for it to sweep late-game. Similarly, entry hazards from teammates like Garchomp and Glimmora can facilitate Dondozo's sweep. Trick users like Iron Valiant and Gholdengo can cripple Dondozo checks like Clodsire and Skeledirge, causing them to lose to Dondozo over the course of the game. While Dondozo is a great sweeper, it is far from consistent at generating setup opportunities; accordingly, it is best to pair it with another bulky sweeper like Curse Garganacl or Hatterene, which can weaken or bait out answers to bulky sweepers like Trick users and Unaware Clodsire.

sets.name: Defensive Wall
sets.description: Good defensive stats and Unaware make Dondozo a solid defensive wall that can withstand physical attackers such as Swords Dance Koraidon, Swords Dance Chien-Pao, and Bulk Up Great Tusk. Earthquake 2HKOes Miraidon and Gholdengo after minimal chip damage, while Body Press OHKOes Chien-Pao and 2HKOes Iron Bundle. With Curse, Dondozo can spiral out of control and gain good sweeping potential. Sleep Talk can be used as an alternative with Rest to stop Pokemon from freely switching into Dondozo during its sleep turns. Miraidon's substantial presence makes Rest unreliable, so Protect can be used instead to scout for Choice item users such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle. With Leftovers, Dondozo can recover much-needed health constantly. Alternatively, Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk, so they can't attack for free. Tera Fairy allows Dondozo to resist Dark- and Fighting-type moves from Chien-Pao and Koraidon, respectively, while also gaining immunity to Dragon-type moves from the latter. Tera Ground removes Dondozo's Electric weakness and can catch Miraidon off guard. Dondozo fits well on balance and stall teams where it has support from specially defensive walls such as Clodsire and Blissey that can check Miraidon, Walking Wake, and Iron Bundle. Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads keep Dondozo healthy, stopping foes from taking advantage of a weakened Dondozo. Dugtrio is a great teammate, as it can trap and KO Miraidon, making Dondozo incredibly hard to deal with.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Dondozo is a solid physical wall due to its incredible physical bulk and Unaware. Dondozo fits well on bulky teams where it can switch into physical attackers such as Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao.
  • Liquidation hits Ground- and Fire-types such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Skeledirge. Earthquake lets Dondozo lure in and deal huge damage to Miraidon.
  • Curse makes Dondozo less passive and gives it sweeping potential. Protect lets Dondozo scout for Choice item users such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle while also recovering health.
  • Rest is the only recovery option for Dondozo and can be used with Sleep Talk to deal with physical attackers such as Koraidon and Chien-Pao better. However, Miraidon's extensive presence in the metagame makes Rest unreliable.
  • Tera Steel lets Dondozo resist Moonblast from Flutter Mane and Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle. Alternatively, Tera Fairy allows Dondozo to resist Fighting- and Dark-type moves from Koraidon and Chien-Pao while it also gains an immunity to Dragon-type moves.
  • Tera Ground gives Dondozo an immunity to Electric-type moves and can allow it to catch Miraidon by surprise and KO it using a boosted Earthquake.
  • Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk are great teammates, as foes can take advantage of Dondozo being worn down due to hazards. Dugtrio is a good teammate, as it can trap and KO Miraidon, making Dondozo incredibly tough to stop.
  • Dondozo appreciates special walls such as Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Blissey that can switch into threats such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane. In return, Dondozo checks their threats in Koraidon, Chien-Pao and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Curse + Resttalk
sets.description:
Dondozo is a staple on rainless Water teams due to its phenomenal bulk and ability to check setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Chien-Pao, thanks to Unaware. Dondozo faces competition from Quagsire as the team's Unaware user, as Quagsire has an immunity to Electric-type attacks and can stack entry hazards; however, it drops to Grass-type attacks. Curse allows Dondozo to apply offensive pressure, boosting its attack and allowing it to better hit targets such as Baxcalibur and Kingambit while also allowing it to better tank hits in return. Rest allows Dondozo to shrug off status and gives it longevity, allowing it to constantly absorb powerful attacks for Water teams, such as Great Tusk's Headlong Rush. Sleep Talk enables Dondozo to further take advantage of Rest, allowing it to continue to setup or attack its target while asleep. Dondozo takes advantage of its STAB through the use of Waterfall, doing more damage, but Avalanche allows Dondozo to OHKO Meowscarada, as well as pressure Water-immune Pokemon such as Clodsire and Gastrodon. Its EV spread allows Dondozo to tank attacks from Gholdengo and Flutter Mane, due to its already high physical defense, which may be further boosted by Curse.

Choice Specs Greninja is an insane wallbreaker, with coverage allowing it to take on a variety of Pokemon such as an opposing Dondozo or Ting-Lu with Grass Knot, Garchomp with Ice Beam, Amoonguss and Clodsire with Extrasensory, and Espathra with Dark Pulse. Toxapex absorbs Toxic Spikes for Dondozo, spreads Toxic, and shrugs off Grass-type attacks such as Flower Trick from Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Grass Knot from Greninja. Gastrodon provides an Electric immunity and it can tank attacks from special attackers such as Flutter Mane; however, it needs to be wary of Energy Ball. Gastrodon can also stack Spikes or set Stealth Rock, wearing down foes for Dondozo. The defensive core of Dondozo, Toxapex, and Gastrodon also gives Water teams opportunities to scout powerful attacks by allowing for each to switch-in for another, such as Dondozo switching in for Gastrodon or Toxapex to tank Chien-Pao's Crunch. Earthquake also allows it to take on Poison- and Electric-type Pokemon such as Clodsire and Sandy Shocks. Quaquaval can remove hazards with Rapid Spin for Dondozo and offensive Quaquaval sets can take on common threats to Water teams such as Greninja after one Aqua Step or Meowscarada after two.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: OHKO Fisher
sets.description:
• With immense bulk, Yawn, and Unaware, Dondozo is not only an impressive defensive Pokemon, but one of the most dangerous OHKO fishers in the game.

  • Wave Crash: Despite the recoil, Wave Crash is the preferred option over Liquidation in most cases, purely for the damage output.

  • Protect: Protect is not only useful for scouting for unexpected Tera types, but pairs well with Yawn and Leftovers to give Dondozo more longevity.

  • Rest and Sleep Talk: If Leftovers isn't possible to use, these two move are an alternative way to keep Dondozo healthy.

  • Avalanche: Avalanche can be used to deal more consistent damage against Dragon-types.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake deals massive damage to Magnezone, and punishes some Tera Electric Pokemon that may attempt to mess with Dondozo, such as Baxcalibur and Chien-Pao.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Dondozo's defensive typing is fantastic, so Terastallization is only needed in rather rare situations.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type is useful enough for covering Dondozo's weaknesses, and the Spore immunity makes it capable of beating Breloom and Brute Bonnet too.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Dondozo take on powerful Dragon-type attacks much more easily, and is just a good defensive typing in general.

  • Flying: Flying may seem like an odd Tera type, but it can lead to your Dondozo winning mirror matches thanks to the Fissure immunity.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP versus 252 HP: If using Leftovers, running 244 HP will give Dondozo one extra HP of recovery, which is easy to take advantage of with Protect. However, if not using Leftovers, 252 HP is better for taking less damage from Stealth Rock.

  • 244 HP / 148 Def / 116 SpD with Impish: This EV spread makes Dondozo extremely likely to avoid a 2HKO from Adamant Baxcalibur's Electric Tera Blast with Leftovers recovery, while still giving Dondozo decent Special Defense.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Def / 4 SpD / 4 Spe with Impish: This more extreme spread helps against powerful Tera users, with the ability to avoid a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Electric Tera Blast or Choice Band Tera Dragon Dragapult's Dragon Darts with Leftovers. This comes at the cost of being much more vulnerable to weaker special attackers.
