  • EV Spread: The given EVs outspeed paralyzed Dragapult, while maximizing physical bulk.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite Gholdengo's fantastic typing, Chien-Pao is easily able to break through any Gholdengo that doesn't Terastallize.

  • Fighting: Beyond boosting Focus Blast's power, it provides Gholdengo with a vital Dark-type resistance.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Gholdengo a much better matchup against Dark-type attackers like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada.

  • Flying: Avoiding Earthquake against foes like Garchomp makes Tera Flying extremely useful for Gholdengo; this also gives it protection against Fissure from the likes of Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is not incredible defensively, but it does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Mimikyu.

  • Water: Tera Water is the best Fire-type resistant Tera type for Gholdengo, letting it potentially survive an assault from Chi-Yu and Iron Moth, though their coverage moves will still seriously damage Gholdengo.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet takes advantage of Gholdengo's excellent typing against physical moves, making it a good way to punish contact moves such as Outrage from Garchomp.

  • Covert Cloak: This is Gholdengo's best shot of outstalling Garganacl, since it grants an immunity to Salt Cure's effect.

  • Weakness Policy: While this might seem strange on a defensive Pokemon, Weakness Policy lets Gholdengo beat opposing Gholdengo as long as they lack Choice Specs.

sets.name: Defensive Nasty Plot
sets.description: Gholdengo uses its great typing and decent bulk to switch into Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Hawlucha, most Mega Medicham, most Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta. Gholdengo's typing and unique ability in Good as Gold make it the premier stopgap to entry hazard removal and a good asset for entry hazard-stacking teams. Gholdengo can switch in on Defoggers like Rotom-W and Tornadus-T—the tier's top Defogger—and can switch in on status moves like Leech Seed from Ferrothorn and Toxic from Clodsire after Gholdengo Terastallizes. A STAB combination of Ghost / Steel hits many targets neutrally, with Shadow Ball being incredibly spammable and Make It Rain hitting Ghost-resistant Pokemon like Garganacl, Tyranitar, and Weavile; the former two are otherwise able to switch in freely. Tera Ghost allows Gholdengo to maintain its spinblocking abilities while strengthening Shadow Ball against foes like Toxapex and improving its matchup into Garganacl. Tera Fairy lets Gholdengo switch out of otherwise crippling Pursuit. Tera Water lets it stay in on four attacks Kingambit and begin setting up, but still leaves it vulnerable to Garganacl and taken advatange of by Rotom-W. The removal of a Ground weakness also allows it to take advantage of Heatran, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire. 128 Special Defense EVs let Gholdengo survive two Heat Waves from offensive Tornadus-T from maximum HP, while the Special Attack allows it to OHKO bulky Tornadus-T with Make It Rain after a Nasty Plot; the remaining are put in Defense to take hits from the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar much better after Terastallizing. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Mega Diancie appreciate their hazards staying up for as long as possible. Pokemon like Mega Lopunny appreciate Gholdengo beating common revenge killers in Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zamazenta. Rotom-W is notable in that it checks Pokemon like Mega Swampert, Heatran, and Victini, and it appreciates Gholdengo providing entry hazard control. Gholdengo struggles against Kingambit, which it lets in for free and struggles to switch out of due to Pursuit. Kingambit is punished by Fighting-type teammates such as Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny. Gholdengo also struggles against Mega Lopunny, which can switch in on stray Shadow Balls and bypass its Fighting immunity with Scrappy. Gholdengo also struggles against Clodsire and opposing Ghost-types, such as Dragapult and opposing Gholdengo. These can be checked by Pursuit users such as Weavile, Kingambit, and Mega Tyranitar.

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Ghost)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Leech Seed
sets.description:
Wo-Chien is a stalwart defensive option that checks offensive threats such as Sandy Shocks and Polteageist, and it takes advantage of some defensive Pokemon such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon. Knock Off is crucial to hinder the longevity of checks such as Talonflame and Salamence. Leech Seed and Protect are useful to quickly rack up residual damage against foes such as Tinkaton, and Protect scouts Choice-locked Pokemon like Iron Jugulis. The fourth moveslot is variable; Ruination is the most consistent option to quickly drop the health of enemies such as Salamence, forcing them to spend PP to recover health. Giga Drain helps Wo-Chien immediately pressure Quagsire, Gastrodon, and Tyranitar while providing more recovery. With Substitute, Wo-Chien has plenty of opportunities to set it up against Pokemon like Slowking and Brambleghast. It forces offensive checks such as Pawmot and Gallade to break the Substitute, giving Wo-Chien more opportunities to drain their health with Leech Seed + Protect. Foul Play is also an option in that moveslot for teams that struggle against Dragon Dance Gyarados or Tyranitar, though it requires Defense investment on Wo-Chien to be reliable, especially against a Tyranitar that hasn't Terastallized. Leftovers keeps Wo-Chien intact in longer games and helps mitigate its lack of reliable recovery. Maximum Special Defense investment is necessary to check threats like Tatsugiri and survive attacks from foes like Gengar and Noivern, punishing them with Knock Off. Tera Poison is common to block Quagsire's Toxic and counter Gengar, but Wo-Chien does become weak to Sandy Shocks's Earth Power. Tera Ghost lets Wo-Chien surprise foes like Toxtricity and Slither Wing, becoming resistant to their powerful attacks, and spinblock Tatsugiri and Brambleghast. However, it does become weak to threats like Choice Band Tyranitar and Polteageist. Tera Fairy patches Wo-Chien's weakness to Iron Jugulis and retains Poison's resistance to Fighting, but it lacks any other meaningful application.

Wo-Chien fits primarily on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams, which take advantage of it making progress with Knock Off and reliably wearing down foes such as Noivern and Tinkaton. Entry hazard setters such as Hippowdon, Gastrodon, and Tinkaton work to increase Wo-Chien's passive damage. They also check foes like Pawmot, Gengar, and Noivern. Toxic Spikes Gengar is also effective to leave offensive teams less room to overwhelm Wo-Chien, as it puts Pokemon like Lokix and Mimikyu on a timer, especially in conjunction with Leech Seed. Gengar also heavily appreciates Wo-Chien taking advantage of Hippowdon and Tyranitar. Talonflame is a crucial partner to Wo-Chien, as it revenge kills many of its common threats like Slither Wing, Paldean Tauros-B, and Scizor. Grafaiai is a solid check to Gengar that appreciates Wo-Chien reliably wearing down Tinkaton. Grafaiai can also mess with the offensive teams that Wo-Chien can struggle against, locking down setup threats like Salamence with Encore and lowering their threat potential with Parting Shot. It further pivots Wo-Chien into Quagsire, making sure it doesn't risk taking Toxic on the switch. Scream Tail is effective at checking foes like Pawmot and Iron Jugulis while providing Wish support. Scream Tail also appreciates Leech Seed support replenishing its health, making it better at switching into them repeatedly.

sets.name: Rest Talk
sets.description:
Wo-Chien is a great wall, as its typing lets it check Sandy Shocks, Hippowdon, and Greninja. Knock Off punishes Pokemon that rely on their items such as Talonflame, Iron Jugulis, and Tinkaton, while Foul Play lets Wo-Chien beat foes like Dragon Dance Tyranitar and Gyarados and threaten Scizor and Cyclizar. Ruination is an alternative option if Tyranitar and Gyarados are adequately covered by its teammates, allowing it to punish Pokemon like Tinkaton far more for trying to switch into it. Rest lets Wo-Chien check foes like Sandy Shocks and Greninja long-term. Heavy-Duty Boots helps it avoid being worn down by entry hazards from Pokemon like Gastrodon and Sandy Shocks when trying to check foes like Greninja and Tyranitar. Leftovers is an option if a team has reliable entry hazard removal, as it lets Wo-Chien take on Pokemon such as Tyranitar more reliably one-on-one. The Defense investment lets Wo-Chien avoid a 2HKO from +1 Tyranitar and lowers the damage from U-turn users like Cyclizar and Greninja while still retaining a solid amount of Special Defense for Sandy Shocks and Greninja. Tera Ghost allows Wo-Chien to spinblock against Donphan and Cyclizar while improving its matchup against foes like Maushold and Slither Wing, but it must be careful of Crunch Tyranitar and losing its ability to check Greninja. Tera Poison lets Wo-Chien become a very reliable Gengar counter, but it loses the ability to check Sandy Shocks and Tyranitar.

RestTalk Wo-Chien fits on a variety of teams, and is best used to play a long game against Pokemon such as Sandy Shocks. Talonflame is valuable to check foes like Scizor and Slither Wing for Wo-Chien and appreciates its ability to check Sandy Shocks and Tyranitar in return. Slowbro can provide a strong Quaquaval answer and assistance versus Dragon Dance Tyranitar, letting Wo-Chien Terastallize more freely. Scream Tail can help check Salamence and Noivern while also checking Quaquaval, and it appreciates Wo-Chien crippling checks like Tinkaton with Knock Off. Entry hazard setters, such as Sandy Shocks and Gastrodon, can help Wo-Chien better wear down its switch-ins, and they appreciate Wo-Chien's ability to potentially spinblock. Hippowdon and Salamence can help check Pawmot for Wo-Chien, as Wo-Chien provides it with relatively free switch-ins. Other Pawmot checks, such as Tera Fairy Alomomola and Tera Fairy Slowbro, are also appreciated. Entry hazard removers, such as Cyclizar and the aforementioned Talonflame, are useful even if Wo-Chien is running Heavy-Duty Boots, as they let it more freely take a Knock Off from Cyclizar or Tinkaton.

sets.name: Mixed Wall (Grass)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Bulky Wall
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Wo-Chien to survive a spread Heat Wave from Beads of Ruin-boosted Choice Specs Chi-Yu, then invests the remaining EVs into Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Leech Seed
sets.description:
• With excellent bulk and a unique array of moves to support it, Wo-Chien stands out as a dangerous user of Leech Seed and a prime Pokemon to stall matches out with.

  • Foul Play versus Knock Off: Foul Play is Wo-Chien's most consistent offensive move that also happens to punish setup sweepers, while Knock Off's support is especially helpful against Trick users such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W. Note that both are viable together if you're willing to give up a support move.

  • Substitute: When paired together with Toxic Spikes, Protect and Substitute makes even foes that should beat Wo-Chien get worn down before they can KO it, such as Chi-Yu. Substitute itself protects Wo-Chien from slow users of Yawn such as Dondozo and Hippowdon, and slow OHKO moves from Ting-Lu, Dondozo, and Kingambit.

  • Ruination: Ruination gives Wo-Chien powerful chipping down potential, though it should never be used as Wo-Chien's only attack due to it being extremely difficult to KO with. When paired with Knock Off, it's especially useful against Wo-Chien mirror matches.

  • Giga Drain: With Stealth Rock support, Giga Drain OHKOes Iron Bundle and almost always 2HKOes Chien-Pao. If you allocate 60 EVs to Special Attack, Giga Drain will OHKO Iron Bundle regardless of Stealth Rock.

  • Taunt: Taunt does an excellent job of surprising other Taunt Pokemon switching in, such as Annihilape and Corviknight.

  • Toxic Spikes Partners: Wo-Chien becomes far more deadly with Toxic Spikes support, letting it quickly wear down a wide variety of foes even faster. Toxapex is one of the best options thanks to its good defensive synergy with Wo-Chien, but other options include Iron Moth, Glimmora, Clodsire, Focus Sash Meowscarada, and the niche Gengar.

Other Options

  • Snarl: Snarl makes fearsome special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu far easier to switch into when Wo-Chien needs to escape, though Wo-Chien will need to have the correct Tera Type to outstall these foes itself.

  • Ingrain: In addition to providing some extra recovery, Ingrain makes phazers such as Ting-Lu and Hippowdon fail to stop Wo-Chien consistently, though Wo-Chien being trapped is a serious drawback.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Despite Wo-Chien's fantastic bulk, its vulnerability to Toxic Spikes and poor defensive typing mean it must often Terastallize to stall out teams.

  • Poison: Tera Poison provides a vital resistance to Fairy and Fighting, and it also lets Wo-Chien absorb Toxic Spikes.

  • Fairy: Besides being a great defensive type, Tera Fairy helps Wo-Chien against Fighting-types that'd normally beat it.

  • Water: Tera Water provides Ice and Fire resistances, helpful against Baxcalibur, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives useful resistances to Fairy, Fire, and Ice, which help against major threats like Flutter Mane, Baxcalibur, Chi-Yu, and Chien-Pao.

Items

  • Leftovers: Wo-Chien's stalling playstyle makes Leftovers the most consistent recovery item.

  • Big Root: If another Pokemon desperately needs Leftovers, Big Root is a viable alternative for getting extra recovery from Leech Seed and Giga Drain.

EV Spreads and Adjustments

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish or Bold: Maximizing Wo-Chien's physical bulk lets it pull off some incredible stunts, such as avoiding a 3HKO from Breloom's Mach Punch with Leftovers and, after Terastallization, avoiding a 2HKO from Choice Band Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful or Calm: With the correct Tera Type and maximum Special Defense, Wo-Chien can take on Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle much more effectively.

  • Using 60 SpA EVs: If you're willing to give up a bit of bulk, this investment is required to OHKO Iron Bundle with Giga Drain with either a Bold or a Calm nature.

  • Using 100 Speed EVs: With some sacrifice to bulk, this Speed investment lets Wo-Chien outspeed Adamant maximum Speed Kingambit, and it can be vital in Wo-Chien mirror matches after Terastallization makes it vulnerable to Leech Seed, due to Substitute blocking Leech Seed.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
• Ice Spinner is an alternative to Icicle Crash because of its better accuracy, but it is slightly weaker, cannot flinch, and is a contact move.
  • Ice Shard hits Miraidon and Koraidon for super effective damage, 2HKOing the former, and 2HKOes Flutter Mane reliably. Sucker Punch may be considered over Ice Shard, as it does more damage to Iron Bundle and can KO Flutter Mane, but it misses out on revenge killing Koraidon and is often prediction-reliant.
  • Sacred Sword allows Chien-Pao to OHKO Chi-Yu, Kingambit, and opposing Chien-Pao, which otherwise resist its STAB moves.
  • Chien-Pao can use Tera Dark to make Crunch stronger and 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex if it gets lucky with a Defense drop. Chien-Pao can also use Tera Ice in order to 2HKO Corviknight more reliably and boost Ice Shard damage—notably against Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Koraidon. Lastly, Tera Electric Chien-Pao with Tera Blast can easily break through bulky checks like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo.
  • Chien-Pao fits best with other strong wallbreakers that benefit from the removal of defensive walls. These include Koraidon, Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and offensive Great Tusk.
  • Defensive partners like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge are mandatory to handle fast and strong threats like Koraidon and Miraidon, as Chien-Pao cannot OHKO them if they are at full health. Additionally, Great Tusk and Ting-Lu can set up entry hazards, which is crucial for getting chip on defensive walls.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Icicle Crash 2HKOes Corviknight and avoids Rocky Helmet, while Ice Spinner is more accurate and has the bonus of removing Electric Terrain.
  • Sacred Sword hits checks such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Another option is to run a double priority combination with Ice Shard and Sucker Punch. Sucker Punch hits very crucial Pokemon that Ice Shard can't, such as Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Fire Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle.
  • An Adamant nature allows Chien-Pao to achieve ridiculous feats such as revenge killing Flutter Mane from 90% HP with Ice Shard. A Jolly nature lets Chien-Pao Speed tie with Koraidon, Miraidon, opposing Jolly Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane, giving Chien-Pao the freedom to click its strongest moves less reluctantly.
  • Tera Dark allows Chien-Pao to 2HKO the entire tier while letting it still switch into weaker moves such as Shadow Ball. Tera Ice gives Chien-Pao the ability to OHKO Flutter Mane with Ice Shard, making it a terrific late-game cleaner.
  • Choice Band Chien-Pao is a wallbreaker that is best suited for bulky offense structures that love its revenge killing and wallbreaking capabilities.
  • Pokemon like Iron Treads, Hatterene, and Koraidon, which can provide entry hazard control or pivoting, are excellent teammates for Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance makes Chien-Pao immensely threatening, letting it break through bulky foes such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Ice Spinner is a more reliable option thanks to its perfect accuracy, but Icicle Crash's power and flinch chance greatly help out against all foes that can take a hit from Chien-Pao, such as Corviknight and Great Tusk.
  • Ice Shard is a reliable priority attack mainly used to better deal with Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Sucker Punch can be used as a stronger but prediction-reliant alternative that OHKOes Flutter Mane without a boost and OHKOes the likes of Iron Bundle and Miraidon after a boost. It also provides a favorable roll to OHKO Koraidon if it has Terastallized into the Fire typing.
  • Tera Dark boosts Crunch, allowing Chien-Pao to more reliably beat physically defensive Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Dark Chien-Pao holding Life Orb can OHKO both Pokemon after a Swords Dance boost.
  • Tera Ice can be used instead to boost Chien Pao's Ice-type attacks. This also makes Ice Shard a better revenge killing option.
  • Sacred Sword can be used to hit foes that resist Chien-Pao's STAB moves, like Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao.
  • Life Orb is the primary item choice because it gives Chien-Pao a lot of power while allowing it to run a Jolly nature and not lose out on potential OHKOs.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots sacrifices a lot of power but gives Chien-Pao the ability to ignore entry hazards, allowing it to come in and potentially set up multiple times throughout a game.
  • Black Glasses in conjunction with an Adamant nature can be used as an alternative to Life Orb to not have recoil while still being able to OHKO the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex after obtaining a Swords Dance boost and using Tera Dark.
  • This set can be used as both an early-game wallbreaker and a late-game sweeper thanks to Chien-Pao's strong STAB attacks and priority moves.
  • Chien-Pao has very little defensive utility, so having a defensive core for it to fall back on is recommended for balance teams. On offensive teams, it can afford to run Focus Sash to take at least one hit from foes that would usually threaten it out.
  • Great Tusk is Chien-Pao's best teammate, as Great Tusk can handle one of Chien-Pao's hardest checks in Koraidon and provide Rapid Spin support. Rapid Spin also helps keep Focus Sash intact.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Chien-Pao is one of the most formidable wallbreakers in AG thanks to its incredible Speed tier, outpacing almost the entire metagame, and massive firepower. Icicle Crash is the preferred Ice-type STAB move due to its higher power, flinch chance to potentially beat walls like Corviknight and Garganacl, and avoidance of adverse contact effects like Baneful Bunker and Rocky Helmet; however, Ice Spinner is more consistent and can also remove Electric Terrain. Ice Shard gives Chien-Pao a powerful way to revenge kill opposing offensive threats, notably threatening Flutter Mane, Koraidon, Miraidon, and Choice Scarf Great Tusk. Sucker Punch is also an option, as it hits Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Iron Bundle much harder while still threatening Flutter Mane and Miraidon. In the last slot, Sacred Sword hits Garganacl and OHKOes Kingambit and Chi-Yu, which would otherwise switch in fairly safely and force Chien-Pao out. Alternatively, running Ice Shard and Sucker Punch together is also an option, allowing Chien-Pao to pressure both Iron Bundle and Koraidon effectively while also ensuring that it beats other Chien-Pao consistently. An Adamant nature is preferable as it guarantees a 2HKO on Toxapex after Stealth Rock with Crunch while also getting favorable rolls against Corviknight and Ting-Lu, although Jolly is also viable in order to speed tie with unboosted Miraidon, Koraidon, and Flutter Mane. Chien-Pao's best Tera type is Dark, which drastically boosts Crunch, making it much easier for it to break through Alomomola, Corviknight, and Toxapex while guaranteeing an OHKO on Iron Bundle with Sucker Punch. Tera Ice is also viable, notably netting an OHKO against Miraidon and a good chance to OHKO Koraidon with Ice Shard. Chien-Pao fits well on all manner of balance teams, pairing extremely well with Miraidon thanks to their ability to effectively pressure each other's checks, with Chien-Pao threatening Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads while Miraidon threatens Corviknight, Alomomola, and Toxapex. Gothitelle is also a great teammate that can trap and remove Chien-Pao's checks, notably beating Toxapex and Alomomola. Due to its frailty and its tendency to be forced out after locking into a move, Chien-Pao needs a sturdy defensive backbone to support it, so balance staples like Corviknight, Ting-Lu, Toxapex, and Skeledirge can all be good teammates for their ability to handle Pokemon like Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Miraidon which might attempt to take advantage of Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description: Chien-Pao is one of the most threatening sweepers in Anything Goes due to its solid typing, ability, and stats. Swords Dance allows Chien-Pao to break through walls such as Toxapex, Alomomola, and Corviknight. Ice Spinner can be considered over Icicle Crash due to its perfect accuracy, but it is a slightly weaker contact move that cannot flinch. Sucker Punch is the preferred priority move option, allowing it to OHKO Flutter Mane without a boost, as well as Iron Bundle and Miraidon after a Swords Dance. Alternatively, Ice Shard OHKOes Koraidon, Miraidon, and Flutter Mane at +2 Attack after Stealth Rock. Heavy-Duty Boots is the best item on this set, but Life Orb and Focus Sash are solid picks on hyper offense builds and other teams with good entry hazard control. Life Orb lets Chien-Pao get some crucial OHKOs at +2 Attack, notably against Miraidon and Koraidon with Ice Shard and Corviknight and Toxapex with Crunch. Tera Dark makes its Dark-type moves stronger while shedding the weaknesses from its Ice typing, notably reducing Stealth Rock damage and weakening Iron Head and Body Press from Corviknight as well as Torch Song from Skeledirge. Chien-Pao fits best on offensive teams and flourishes with other wallbreakers like Miraidon, Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and offensive Great Tusk. On bulkier builds, teammates like defensive Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads set entry hazards while checking fast Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon. If forgoing Heavy-Duty Boots, it is essential to pair Chien-Pao with lead entry hazard setters like Glimmora and Froslass on offensive teams and Iron Treads and Great Tusk on bulkier teams, as they additionally prevent opposing entry hazards from going up.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker (Dark)
sets.description:
Chien-Pao is an imposing force for any Dark team with its sky-high Speed, blitzing past threats like Iron Valiant and Greninja, and great Attack. Sword of Ruin lets it beat physical walls like Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Toxapex, though it doesn't have great bulk, has to watch out for super effective priority moves from Scizor, Lokix, and Slither Wing, and struggles to break past walls like Dondozo and Quagsire. With Swords Dance, it can boost up to beat even the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex if it has Crunch. Fighting-type coverage picks off Dark-types like Kingambit and Greninja. Sacred Sword picks off weakened Garganacl, while Brick Break destroys opposing Dark or Fairy team's dual screens. Ice Shard stops common revenge killers like Choice Scarf Meowscarada, Flutter Mane, and Great Tusk.

As Chien-Pao focuses on breaking down foes with its sheer power and Speed, it appreciates support from its teammates. Ting-Lu can set up Stealth Rock and Spikes, while Skuntank can set up Toxic Spikes and pressure Fairy-types, all of which make wallbreaking for Chien-Pao easier. Grimmsnarl provides Chien-Pao with dual screens support, making setting up easier. Sableye can burn opposing Pokemon and cripple them with Taunt and Knock Off, removing Heavy-Duty Boots and making foes susceptible to entry hazards, while also acting as a Fighting-type move switch-in. Choice Specs Greninja can clean up after Chien-Pao has done enough damage while also countering Fire-types that would annoy Chien-Pao such as Skeledirge and Cinderace if Chien-Pao does not have Crunch. Hydreigon can break Steel-types for Chien-Pao if it forgoes Fighting-type coverage or Swords Dance, beating Fighting-neutral Steel-types like Corviknight and Scizor. Choice Scarf Meowscarada is able to threaten Pokemon that counter Chien-Pao such as Quaquaval and Choice Scarf users such as Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Great Tusk while also being able to pivot to Chien-Pao with U-turn.

sets.name: Swords Dance Sweeper (Ice)
sets.description:
Chien-Pao's high Speed, solid Attack, and good offensive typing allow it to be a very potent setup sweeper. Icicle Crash is preferred over Ice Spinner for its flinch chance and higher Base Power, the latter of which—among other things—allows it to always 2HKO Sableye and bulky Great Tusk, while Ice Spinner may miss out on these 2HKOs. Crunch allows Chien-Pao to hit Skeledirge and Gholdengo—two problematic Pokemon for Ice teams. Sacred Sword and Brick Break both allow Chien-Pao to threaten Dark-, Steel-, and Ice-types such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Sacred Sword is stronger and comes with the ability to ignore Defense boosts, while Brick Break removes Reflect and Light Screen, which is extremely helpful against teams with support from Grimmsnarl or Klefki. Psychic Fangs is an alternative option to Sacred Sword or Brick Break to hit Toxapex and Fighting-types such as Paldean Tauros-F. Sucker Punch is significantly stronger than Ice Shard and allows Chien-Pao to hit Pokemon like Gholdengo, Scizor, and Flutter Mane.

This set very much appreciates Aurora Veil support from Abomasnow, as it allows Chien-Pao to set up on many Pokemon that would otherwise threaten it out as well as allowing it to survive revenge killing attempts from the likes of Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Extreme Speed Dragonite. Spikes support from Froslass is also greatly appreciated, as they wear down Pokemon that may otherwise be difficult for Chien-Pao to break, such as Dondozo and Klefki. Although Chien-Pao is able to fit on practically any team, it pairs especially well with other powerful sweepers such as Baxcalibur and Cloyster, weakening or even KOing their checks such as Air Balloon Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Baxcalibur in particular can take on Pokemon such as Toxapex and Paldean Tauros-F with a powerful Earthquake, allowing Chien-Pao to KO them and sweep the opposing team; furthermore, Choice Band Baxcalibur pressures Chien-Pao answers such as Quagsire and Corviknight. Baxcalibur's Thermal Exchange also allows it to switch into Will-O-Wisp that would cripple Chien-Pao as well as be an emergency switch-in to a Fire-type attack. Shell Smash Cloyster appreciates the removal of Skeledirge and Froslass.

sets.name: Choice Band Wallbreaker (Ice)
sets.description:
Choice Band Chien-Pao is a potent mid-game threat, powerful wallbreaker, and good late-game cleaner. Additionally, it is capable of breaking through physically defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Quagsire, both of which tend to be tough matchups for many other Ice staples. Icicle Crash is preferred over Ice Spinner for its flinch chance and slightly higher Base Power, notably being favored to 2HKO Azumarill and OHKO offensive Pelipper, neither of which are feats Ice Spinner is capable of. Sacred Sword and Brick Break provide crucial coverage for Pokemon such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao, and Sucker Punch allows Chien-Pao to KO faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

This set heavily appreciates Spikes from Froslass to wear down its switch-ins, sometimes allowing it to grab KOs it would otherwise miss out on; for example, Crunch always 2HKOes physically defensive Toxapex with one layer of Spikes, but it is favored to not 2HKO without any Spikes. Rapid Spin support from Avalugg is also appreciated, allowing Chien-Pao more opportunities to enter the field. Since this set focuses on opening holes in teams, setup sweepers are excellent partners for it, as Chien-Pao can dent or remove their checks to allow the sweep to happen much more easily. Shell Smash Cloyster in particular appreciates Chien-Pao's ability to beat Gholdengo and significantly damage other Pokemon such as Corviknight that Cloyster may otherwise struggle to break through. Dragon Dance Baxcalibur appreciates Chien-Pao's ability to 2HKO Quagsire and physically defensive Corviknight, which normally would stop Baxcalibur in its tracks. Finally, Belly Drum Cetitan appreciates Chien-Pao's ability to break Unaware walls such as Skeledirge and Quagsire; in return, Cetitan acts as speed control if snow is in effect, aiding in Chien-Pao's weakness to Choice Scarf users such as Iron Moth.

sets.name: Choice Band (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Cheems Pao
sets.description:
• Chien-Pao is a fantastic physical attacker that can improve its and its teammates' physical damage through Sword of Ruin. It is very effective with priority attackers such as Dragonite and Palafin, as well as other fast physical attackers such as Choice Band Dragapult and Choice Scarf Basculegion-F.

  • Ice Spinner is a STAB option that easily grabs OHKOs on Dragonite and Landorus-T while clearing Psychic Terrain for its own Sucker Punch and teammates' priority moves. Icicle Crash can be used for a slight increase in power, a sizeable flinch chance, and avoiding Rocky Helmet damage, however it comes with a chance to miss and cannot clear Psychic Terrain. If used with Rillaboom, Icicle Crash is recommended to avoid clearing your own Grassy Terrain.

  • Sucker Punch allows Chien-Pao to pick off faster threats such as Booster Energy Flutter Mane and Booster Energy Iron Bundle. Sucker Punch is also crucial to keeping Chien-Pao relevant against Tailwind or Trick Room, and pressures opposing priority users such as Palafin.

  • Sacred Sword OHKOs many relevant Pokemon that resist Chien-Pao's STAB combination such as Kingambit, Chi-Yu, and opposing Chien-Pao. Crunch is a more consistent option for Dark-type STAB, knocking out Indeedee-F through Psychic Terrain and threatening Pokemon such as Cresselia that are using status moves.

  • Life Orb is used to push Chien-Pao's offenses to dizzying heights, OHKOing bulky Rillaboom and Flutter Mane with Ice Spinner and Sucker Punch, respectively. Focus Sash gets around Chien-Pao's poor defenses and allows it to survive a hit against strong, fast attackers such as Flutter Mane and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu. However, the item is rendered useless by Stealth Rock, a relatively common sight.

  • Jolly nature Chien-Pao speed ties Flutter Mane and opposing Chien-Pao. An Adamant nature can be used for more power, giving Life Orb Chien-Pao a chance to OHKO Cresselia with Crunch.

  • Tera Dark boosts the damage of Sucker Punch, allowing it to more effectively pick off weakened foes and score an OHKO on all variants of Flutter Mane. Tera Ghost provides an immunity to Fighting-type moves, improving its matchup into Iron Hands, as well as priority such as Fake Out and Extreme Speed that would otherwise threaten Chien-Pao.

  • In addition to other physical attackers, Chien-Pao appreciates partners that can cover its defensive shortcomings, notably to Fire-, Fairy-, and Fighting-types. Volcanion and Heatran perform well against Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane and can hold off opposing Fire-types. Amoonguss and Landorus-T can be used to switch into Fighting-type attacks from Iron Hands aimed at Chien-Pao.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: RUINOUS ATTACKER
sets.description:
• With its high Attack and Speed, and incredible ability in Sword of Ruin, Chien-Pao is one of the strongest physical attackers in the game.

  • Icicle Crash: While Ice Spinner is perfectly accurate, Icicle Crash’s higher power and flinch chance makes it the preferred attack. Additionally, not being a contact move allows Chien-Pao to avoid unnecessary chip damage from Rocky Helmet users.

  • Sucker Punch vs Crunch: Sucker Punch offers priority with a strong base power at the cost of necessitating prediction, while Crunch is a more standard attack whose Defense drop can allow Chien-Pao to potentially break through bulky foes.

  • Ice Shard: Ice Shard is a more consistent albeit weaker alternative to Sucker Punch.

  • Sacred Sword: Sacred Sword provides coverage for Pokemon that resist one or both of Chien-Pao’s STAB attacks, like Heatran, Chi-Yu, and other Chien-Pao. Additionally, ignoring defense boosts allows Chien-Pao to deal more consistent damage to foes who boost their Defense.

  • Swords Dance: While it can be difficult to fit and very reliant on Focus Sash, Swords Dance boosts Chien-Pao’s Attack to unwallable levels, making it a very potent sweeper.

  • 0-1 SpA IV: If using Tera Blast on Jolly Chien-Pao, make sure to to use a SpA IV that's 0-1. This is because if Flutter Mane uses Charm, any SpA IV that's higher will result in Tera Blast becoming a Special Attack.

Other Options

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop disables the use of sound-based moves from targets like Skeledirge and Sylveon, but these matchups are so uncommon that it generally isn't worth using over Crunch.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner can be used as a more consistent Ice STAB, however it makes Chien-Pao more vulnerable to Rocky Helmet users.

  • Sheer Cold: While it may seem alluring, Sheer Cold is usually a waste of a slot on Chien-Pao sets like this, as its standard attacks already hit most relevant foes. Even if Chien-Pao fails to KO a foe, it will generally leave it within range for a teammate.

Tera Types

  • With few exceptions, Chien-Pao is about all-out offense. However, its choice of item drastically affects its strategy. Tera Types have been organized by item choice to better clarify how each Tera Type works in that context.

Tera Types for Focus Sash and Life Orb

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Chien-Pao offers power in spades without needing to Terastallize, only needing it on very rare occasions to break past specific walls or dodge priority moves aimed at it.

  • Electric: Tera Electric can be used in tandem with Tera Blast to improve Chien-Pao’s matchup against key threats such as Urshifu-R and Dondozo while also making it immune to paralysis.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost doesn’t offer much offensive benefit, but it allows Chien-Pao to dodge Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, which can be particularly useful if using Swords Dance.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Chien-Pao survive Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes, which otherwise threatens to OHKO through Focus Sash. Combined with Tera Blast, Chien-Pao still threatens big damage into Urshifu-R and Dondozo.

  • Dark: Tera Dark boosts Sucker Punch to extreme power levels while making Crunch exceptionally difficult to switch into without a resistance.

  • Ice: Tera Ice can allow Chien-Pao to finish foes off with Ice Shard from higher ranges and makes Icicle Crash an even more formidable tool.

Tera Types for Choice Band

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Chien-Pao is already plenty powerful, Choice Band combined with Tera can elevate 2HKOs to OHKOs on some of the bulkiest walls in the meta. For this reason, Tera can be worth using on Choice Band sets.

  • Dark: Tera Dark turns Choice Band Crunch into a devastating wallbreaker move that few can withstand, OHKOing Max HP Annihilape and Scizor if using an Adamant nature. Neutralizing Chien-Pao’s Steel-type weakness also makes it less vulnerable to Scizor’s Bullet Punch.

  • Ice: Tera Ice gives Choice Band Icicle Crash enough power to challenge even physically defensive Ting-Lu, having approximately a 69% chance to OHKO if using an Adamant nature; be warned, however, that Ting-Lu often Terastallizes in front of Chien-Pao, making this inconsistent. The extra power behind Ice Shard is also a welcome boost.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy combined with Choice Band Tera Blast handily defeats some of Chien-Pao's less common checks, OHKOing standard variants of Annihilape and Assault Vest Iron Hands. It also removes several weaknesses, most notably turning Chien-Pao's 4x Fighting-type weakness into a resistance.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly or Adamant: This offensive spread works with all standard sets. Adamant gives Chien-Pao a significant power boost, but Jolly is important for Speed tying with Flutter Mane and opposing Chien-Pao.

  • 252 Atk / 68 Def / 188 Spe with Adamant: This alternate spread is commonly associated with Choice Band, fully maximizing Attack while still maintaining enough Speed to outrun Timid Iron Moth. When used with an appropriate Tera type, the Defense investment lets Chien-Pao survive Life Orb Mimikyu's Play Rough into Shadow Sneak.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: With its incredible Attack and a near-unparalleled Speed tier, Chien-Pao excels as a revenge killer and late-game sweeper that can easily dispatch weakened defensive foes. Icicle Crash and Crunch are its main offensive options, threatening common pivots like Garchomp and Skeledirge; Icicle Crash also bypasses Fluffy. Sacred Sword picks up an OHKO on Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Heatran, and Kingambit while also threatening physical walls like Zamazenta-C and Garganacl. Ice Shard lets Chien-Pao revenge kill Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Hisuian Electrode, as well as Agility or Dragon Dance users like Galarian Moltres or Roaring Moon. This Pokemon is often paired with defensive entry hazard setters and slow, defensive pivots that can allow it to switch in freely. For example, Corviknight has both a slow U-turn to pivot Chien-Pao in freely and Defog to remove hazards. Additionally, Rapid Spin users like Iron Treads can clear the opponent's hazards, which punish Chien-Pao for switching in. Finally, bulky wallbreakers and Fire-type attackers like Kingambit or Ceruledge help Chien-Pao deal with physically defensive Steel-types, like Tinkaton and Intimidate Corviknight, weakening them and making Chien-Pao's job as an endgame cleaner more efficient.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Chien-Pao is a strong wallbreaker thanks to its high Attack and excellent STAB combination accompanied by a blazing fast Speed tier that outpaces all unboosted Pokemon bar Regieleki, Hisuian Electrode, and Barraskewda. It breaks holes in the opponent's defensive core for teammates like Roaring Moon and Kingambit to exploit, or it can sweep when a teammate like Garchomp or Zamazenta has weakened its checks. Ice Shard is useful priority for KOing weakened faster Pokemon such as +1 Fluffy Roaring Moon, Choice Scarf Meowscarada, and Choice Scarf Galarian Zapdos. Sacred Sword forgoes this utility for extra OHKOes against Greninja and Kingambit, as well as Hisuian Goodra after Spikes; it can also help revenge kill Zamazenta-C as Sacred Sword. Using Adaptability on Chien-Pao means its set is not immediately revealed and a teammate like Meowscarada can use Sword of Ruin. Life Orb is necessary for +2 Chien-Pao to OHKO many bulkier Pokemon like Heatran despite having to give up Heavy-Duty Boots and receiving recoil. Chien-Pao cannot break certian physically defensive Pokemon like Quaquaval, Unaware Scream Tail, and Intimidate Corviknight without significant chip, so teammates like Thundurus and Zapdos that can deal significant damage to them are recommended. Chien-Pao also appreciates defensive teammates like Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Quaquaval, which all can remove entry hazards for it and pivot Chien-Pao in safely.

sets.name: Defensive Hazards
sets.description:
Ting-Lu is an incredible entry hazard setter for bulky offense and balance teams alike thanks to its combination of gargantuan defensive stats, good utility movepool, and an amazing defensive ability in Vessel of Ruin. It also has a great typing that lets it answer threats such as Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge. Whirlwind is incredibly useful for thwarting setup Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Cresselia, and Dragonite. Ruination lets Ting-Lu deal consistent damage to bulky Pokemon like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Hatterene. Stone Edge allows Ting-Lu to hit Zapdos, Enamorus, and Moltres super effectively, as they can otherwise come in somewhat safely against it and use Roost to heal off any damage from Ruination. Rest is an option on bulkier structures like stall teams to give Ting-Lu much-needed recovery. Tera Poison lets Ting-Lu act as an answer to Iron Valiant while giving it an immunity to poison damage from Clodsire’s Toxic and letting it absorb Toxic Spikes from the likes of Glimmora and Iron Moth. Meanwhile, Tera Fairy is a generally solid defensive typing, letting it more reliably check Pokemon such as Dragapult and Great Tusk. Aside from granting a Fighting immunity, Tera Ghost allows Ting-Lu to spinblock foes like Great Tusk and Iron Treads, which is especially important if running both entry hazards. If so, Heavy Slam should be used over Earthquake to threaten Hatterene better, which would otherwise block them due to Magic Bounce, while hitting Enamorus more consistently. Red Card is an alternative over Leftovers on more offensive teams that can forgo the recovery; Ting-Lu's astronomical overall bulk allows it to take a single strong hit in a pinch—even super effective attacks such as from Calm Mind Iron Valiant and Enamorus—and phaze them, preventing its team from being swept by opposing offensive threats.

Ting-Lu’s premier defensive profile makes it most proficient on bulky offense and balance teams that can supply enough offensive momentum to make up for Ting-Lu’s relative passivity. Pokemon that can supplement offensive prowess to make up for Ting-Lu's passivity such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant and Kingambit make for excellent partners, as they can assist against threats like opposing Iron Valiant, Dondozo, and Great Tusk. Without Ruination, Ting-Lu is utterly helpless against Corviknight, so Pokemon that can threaten it such as Gholdengo, Zapdos, and Cinderace make for excellent partners. Bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex appreciate Ting-Lu's immunity to Electric while being quite helpful against Pokemon like Kingambit and Quaquaval in return. Other defensive Pokemon like Garganacl and Corviknight also make for excellent partners, being helpful against Pokemon like Scizor while appreciating Ting-Lu’s ability to check Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Additional entry hazard setters such as Hisuian Samurott, Garganacl, Landorus-T, and Great Tusk allow Ting-Lu to fit Ruination or Stone Edge into its moveset more capably, so it is less passive in the face of Ground-immune threats like Corviknight, Zapdos, Moltres, and Air Balloon Gholdengo.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Ting-Lu is a great entry hazard setter with defensive utility, checking threatening special attackers like Miraidon and Gholdengo. It setting both Stealth Rock and Spikes while providing an invaluable Electric immunity makes it a balance staple. Ruination can be used over one of the entry hazards to threaten potential switch-ins like Great Tusk, Koraidon, opposing Ting-Lu, Air Balloon Gholdengo, and Corviknight, which would otherwise come in freely and force Ting-Lu out. Whirlwind lets Ting-Lu deter setup attempts by Tera Fairy Miraidon or simply force out foes to inflict entry hazard damage. Alternatively, Protect can be used for more Leftovers recovery and scouting attacks, although it must be used carefully to avoid Chien-Pao, Koraidon, and Miraidon getting a free turn to set up. Ghost is the preferred Tera type to block Rapid Spin from Iron Treads and Great Tusk, as well as removing Ting-Lu's weaknesses to Iron Bundle's and Koraidon's STAB moves, which lets it effectively check them. Alternatively, Tera Steel grants immunity to Toxic, makes Ting-Lu a solid check to Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane, and eases the matchup against Double Dance Tera Fairy Miraidon. Ting-Lu is most effectively paired with Pokemon like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Alomomola that can handle physical attackers, notably Koraidon, Chien-Pao, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk, that force it out. Ting-Lu isn't a particularly consistent Miraidon check, notably struggling against Calm Mind and Choice Specs Miraidon sets, so backup checks such as Iron Treads and Clodsire can also be very useful. If Ting-Lu is running Spikes, spinners like Iron Treads and Great Tusk can be tremendously valuable, removing enemy entry hazards while leaving your own Spikes intact. It also greatly appreciates teammates such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao that can pressure opposing hazard removers, and in turn they appreciate Ting-Lu's hazards chipping down their checks. Gholdengo and Annihilape can also be good teammates because they outright block or severely punish hazard removal, respectively.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• Ting-Lu is the premier Miraidon check in the tier, being able to avoid the 2HKO from it without needing to Terastallize.
  • It can reliably generate chip damage using Ruination when it forces special attackers out, and it can even force Arceus to use up Recover PP. On these forced switches, it can also set up Spikes or Stealth Rock, which further chips down switch-ins for the rest of the game due to the limited distribution of entry hazard removal in the tier.
  • Whirlwind prevents opposing setup threats such as Double Dance Miraidon and Calm Mind Arceus-Ground from snowballing out of control, as well as using its own Spikes for chip damage. Protect can also be used in this moveslot, which allows for more Leftovers recovery and scouting of Choice item users and Tera types. The preference will come down to how much the team relies on Ting-Lu to phaze setup threats such as Calm Mind Arceus and Miraidon.
  • Leftovers is mandatory on Ting-Lu since it does not have any form of reliable recovery.
  • Ting-Lu will very rarely need to use its Tera types, as its natural typing provides a strong Electric immunity for Miraidon. Tera Steel provides a Dragon resistance versus Miraidon while also letting Ting-Lu handle Dazzling Gleam from Calm Mind + Tera Fairy Miraidon, and it also grants an immunity to Toxic from Eternatus and Toxapex. Tera Fairy provides a Dragon immunity against Miraidon, allowing Ting-Lu to better answer Tera Dragon sets with Calm Mind or Choice Specs, and Ting-Lu becomes resistant or immune to Koraidon's STAB moves. However, this comes at the expense of not resisting Fairy versus Tera Fairy Miraidon. Poison resists Close Combat and Zacian-C's Play Rough, and it allows Ting-Lu to absorb Toxic Spikes. Tera Water allows it to take Kyogre's STAB moves while also resisting Koraidon's Flare Blitz. It also lets Ting-Lu check the rare, but otherwise hard to check, Chi-Yu and Walking Wake. While all of these are good options for Ting-Lu, it benefits much more from its natural typing and should only Terastallize as a last resort.
  • Ting-Lu can also switch in safely against most defensive Pokemon in the tier, such as support Arceus formes, Groudon, Skeledirge, Giratina-O, and Toxapex, and then use this opportunity to set up a hazard or generate chip damage with Ruination.
  • It struggles against physical threats such as Koraidon, Zacian-C, and Arceus, so it is best paired with Pokemon such as defensive Arceus-Fairy, Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex that can switch into them reliably. Ting-Lu can also enable teammates such as Choice Scarf Koraidon, Miraidon, and Kyogre to clean more easily with the chip damage it generates from Ruination.
  • Due to Ting-Lu being unable to reliably check Choice Specs Miraidon long-term, it’s best to have some form of speed control alongside it, whether it be Choice Scarf Koraidon or Zacian-C.
  • Ting-Lu can function as a team's sole special wall, but it does appreciate naturally bulky Pokemon such as Kyogre and Groudon to handle some hits, which lets Ting-Lu remain a reliable Miraidon check. It can also pair well alongside the tier's Defoggers, Giratina-O and Corviknight as it is prone to Spikes chip damage and appreciates avoiding that to better check Miraidon. In a similar vein, Eternatus and Toxapex are good Toxic Spikes absorbers, the former of which can also soft check Kyogre and special Arceus formes.

sets.name: Defensive Hazard Setter (Dark)
sets.description:
Ting-Lu is a fantastic asset for Dark teams due to its access to entry hazards and great bulk, supported further by Vessel of Ruin weakening special attackers such as Iron Valiant and Hatterene. Earthquake is a reliable STAB move that hits most of the metagame for decent damage while also scaring Clodsire out and preventing it from setting Toxic Spikes. Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types that would otherwise overpower Ting-Lu, such as Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant, while also threatening Hatterene trying to bounce back hazards. Stealth Rock and Spikes allow Ting-Lu to support wallbreakers such as Meowscarada or Greninja. Whirlwind allows Ting-Lu to phase out setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Curse Dondozo and rack up entry hazard damage, while Ruination provides consistent damage against other walls such as Amoonguss and Corviknight that don't mind any of Ting-Lu's other moves.

Wallbreakers such as Meowscarada, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Greninja all appreciate Ting-Lu's ability to set entry hazards, as they wear down common defensive answers such as Toxapex, Iron Treads, and Dondozo. In return, they can scare out threats to Ting-Lu; Meowscarada can deal with Greninja, Chien-Pao and Greninja can threaten Great Tusk, and Kingambit can force out Fairy-types such as Hatterene. Skuntank is a good partner as well, since it offers a crucial neutrality to Fairy, threatens Fairy-types, and sets and clears Toxic Spikes, augmenting Ting-Lu's entry hazards and improving its longevity. Additionally, Skuntank can utilize Fire Spin to further chip down teams and trap Klefki, improving Ting-Lu's matchup against Fairy. In return, Ting-Lu can assist in Ground matchups through its bulk. Sableye is also a great partner due to its Fighting immunity, taking attacks Ting-Lu can't such as Great Tusk's and Iron Hands's Close Combat.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description:
Ting-Lu's exceptional bulk and utility options make it an invaluable asset to Ground teams, walling threats like Dragapult, Espathra, and Hydreigon. Earthquake threatens Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Volcarona. Alternatively, Throat Chop hits Espathra for more damage and shuts down Air Balloon Gholdengo. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to quickly wear down the likes of opposing Ting-Lu, Hatterene, and Dragonite, while Body Press may be used to deal more damage to Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Hydreigon. Spikes or Stealth Rock in conjunction with Whirlwind sets Ting-Lu apart from other entry hazard setters; it's capable of wearing down the opponent's defensive core and weakens threats such as Greninja, Meowscarada, and Baxcalibur. Additionally, Whirlwind phazes threatening sweepers like Scizor and Ceruledge.

Ting-Lu's entry hazards are heavily appreciated by Great Tusk, which threatens out Choice Specs Flutter Mane, Gallade, and Greninja; Sandy Shocks, which deals with Water-types like Pelipper, Quaquaval, and Dondozo; and Garchomp, which threatens Corviknight, Rotom-C, and Breloom with its Fire-type coverage. Furthermore, Choice Scarf Great Tusk removes Heavy-Duty Boots from Sableye and Brambleghast via Knock Off to enhance Ting-Lu's phazing, which enables Clodsire and Gastrodon as entry hazard setters to wither down threats such as Greninja and Ceruledge more efficiently. Water Absorb Clodsire adds a Water immunity, can switch into attacks from Greninja, Quaquaval, and Meowscarada, and helps wear down the opposing team with Toxic Spikes or Toxic. Gastrodon walls Water-type Pokemon like Pelipper, Dondozo, and Rotom-W and assists with spreading entry hazards. Iron Treads eases Ting-Lu's pivoting by removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin and checks Fairy-types like Flutter Mane and Hatterene. Quagsire stalls out physical setup sweepers such as Mimikyu, Chien-Pao, and Iron Hands and also helps wear down defensive cores using Toxic.

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• This EV spread and nature ensures that Ting Lu always OHKOs Chi-Yu with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake, and then uses the remaining EVs to maximize its special bulk.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Ting-Lu's absurd bulk and excellent support movepool make it the premier Stealth Rock setter in the metagame!

  • Ruination: Ruination gives Ting-Lu the most consistent option for damage output, without resorting to offensive investment.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam deals serious damage to Fairy-types, with Flutter Mane in particular needing a huge amount of defensive investment to avoid being OHKOed by it.

  • Taunt: While Ting-Lu's Speed is awful compared to most Taunt users, using Taunt against foes like Corviknight on the switch is still useful. Note that while using Taunt against Toxapex can be useful, it is highly likely to run Mental Herb, which risks getting Ting-Lu poisoned.

  • Protect: Protect with Leftovers is a strong choice when running Ting-Lu with high sustain teammates such as Toxapex.

Other Options

  • Fissure: Fissure lets Ting-Lu potentially punish passive Pokemon without Substitute, such as Toxapex.

  • Spikes: Getting Stealth Rock and Spikes together makes Whirlwind a very effective damage dealing tool, in addition to supporting other offensive Pokemon. However, it can be difficult to set up without compromising Ting-Lu's damage output.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Even with Ting-Lu's fantastic bulk, Terastallization greatly increases the amount of Pokemon it can beat one-on-one, such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: In addition to a useful Fighting resistance, Tera Fairy helps Ting-Lu against powerful Dragon-types like Choice Band Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Poison: Tera Poison gives Ting-Lu an important resistance to Fairy and Fighting, and it lets it absorb Toxic Spikes.

  • Water: With Tera Water, Ting-Lu has a significantly better matchup against Urshifu-R. The Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu matchups can also benefit, but be mindful of potential Tera Blast coverage.

  • Steel: Tera Steel retaining a Fighting weakness is unfortunate, but in exchange, Heavy Slam will OHKO even most bulky Flutter Mane, and it gives Ting-Lu a good matchup against Iron Bundle.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry versus Leftovers: Ting-Lu's lack of reliable recovery usually makes Sitrus Berry the most reliable method of surviving an extra attack. Leftovers is a good alternative if Sitrus Berry is needed somewhere else, and even preferable if running Protect.

  • Mental Herb: Mental Herb can be used to nullify one use of Taunt or Encore, which Ting-Lu is fairly vulnerable to, at the cost of reducing its lifespan with a lack of any recovery.

EV Spreads

  • Maximum Physical Defense versus Maximum Special Defense: Specializing in one defensive stat depends on which threats Ting-Lu needs to handle, with physically defensive variants preforming better against threats like Dragonite, Garchomp, and Kingambit, and when Terastallized, Chien-Pao, Azumarill, and Baxcalibur. For specially defensive variants, major targets include Gholdengo and Iron Moth, and when Terastallized, Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Chi-Yu.

  • 212 HP / 4 Atk / 116 Def / 156 SpD / 20 Spe with Impish: When Terastallized to a neutral typing, Ting-Lu survives up to four Icicle Crashes from Jolly Focus Sash Chien-Pao. With Leftovers and Protect, it also avoids the 2HKO from Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage. The Speed EVs let it outrun uninvested Hippowdon.

  • 44 HP / 252 Def / 212 SpD with Careful: This EV spread is optimized for use with Sitrus Berry, letting Ting-Lu avoid a 2HKO from Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage, and Timid Tera Fairy Flutter Mane's Moonblast when Terastallized to a neutral typing.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Assault Vest and Vessel of Ruin combine to make Ting-Lu an especially formidable tank.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam deals far more damage to Flutter Mane and Mimikyu than any other attack, with even Bold Flutter Mane having a good shot at being OHKOed after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Fissure: Fissure is Ting-Lu's best shot at KOing bulky foes like Dondozo.

  • Payback versus Throat Chop: Payback will usually deal more damage thanks to how slow Ting-Lu is, but Throat Chop will punish Pokemon that switch in more.

  • EV Spread: The given EV spread maximizes Ting-Lu's Attack and special bulk.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Ting-Lu doesn't need Terastallization to function, it makes it far more effective at beating a wide variety of Pokemon one-on-one.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy not only helps Ting-Lu against powerful Dragon- and Fighting-type attacks, but it also gives Ting-Lu a good Tera Blast to hit Dragonite with.

  • Electric: Tera Electric's resistances aren't amazing, but they give Ting-Lu a sole weakness to Ground. Futhermore, Tera Blast exploits common Tera Flying and Tera Water users like Gholdengo, as well as helping wear down Dondozo and Corviknight.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Ting-Lu a powerful STAB Heavy Slam, giving it a great matchup against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

  • Poison: Tera Poison gives Ting-Lu a vital Fairy resistance against Flutter Mane and Mimikyu, and it lets it absorb the dreaded Toxic and Toxic Spikes.

  • Water: Tera Water is a fantastic defensive typing, letting Ting-Lu avoid a 2HKO from Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu's Overheat.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Ting-Lu is a reliable special wall and a premier momentum generator. Regenerator gives Ting-Lu reliable recovery without conflicting with Assault Vest. Nuzzle discourages dangerous attackers like Palkia-O from switching in. U-turn allows Ting-Lu to safely bring in teammates thanks to its low Speed. Stone Axe forces chip damage on foes, letting offensive teammates wallbreak more easily. Knock Off removes items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Covert Cloak, making Ting-Lu's own utility more effective; it also punishes Imposter users attempting to gain Regenerator. Ting-Lu fits best on balance teams, which appreciate its ability to spread paralysis and safely bring in teammates thanks to its huge bulk. Dangerous wallbreakers like Koraidon and Palkia-O help maximize the effectiveness of U-turn pivoting. Ting-Lu is unable to naturally check Palkia-O and Fairy-types like Flutter Mane, so a teammate that helps shore up this weakness, such as Arceus-Grass or Hisuian Goodra, is appreciated. Tera Fairy provides an immunity to Dragon, allowing Ting-Lu to block Dragon Energy from Palkia-O and Glaive Rush from Koraidon; alternatively, Tera Grass provides a Water resistance, covering for Palkia-O's Water Spout.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Talonflame and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Lucario can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

sets.name: RegenVest Wall
sets.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Hydreigon and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce Ting-Lu's weakness to entry hazards.

sets.name: Defensive Support
sets.description: Ting-Lu is an effective defensive support in STABmons, as with Ceaseless Edge or Spikes, it can serve as a very bulky entry hazard setter. In addition, thanks to its ability, its well-distributed stats, and Shore Up, it is able to check many attackers such as Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Garganacl. Spikes should be used if reliability and lack of PP are a concern, especially on stall teams. Precipice Blades maximizes damage against Toxapex and other Ground-weak Pokemon like Iron Hands; however, Earthquake is a fine option if accuracy is a concern. There are multiple options for the last moveslot: Parting Shot lets Ting-Lu safely bring in offensive teammates via a slow pivot, Foul Play gives it a better matchup against setup sweepers like Salamence, Whirlwind phazes setup sweepers that Ting-Lu can't handle like non-Taunt Annihilape, and Knock Off can remove items like Heavy-Duty Boots from pivots like Tyranitar. Covert Cloak prevents Ting-Lu from being poisoned from Mortal Spin users like Toxapex, while Leftovers gives to it more passive recovery. Both Tera Ghost and Tera Poison allow Ting-Lu to surprise Fighting-types like Iron Hands; Tera Poison grants it an immunity to Toxic and lets it resist Grass-type attacks, while Tera Ghost allows it to spinblock. Alternatively, Tera Fairy and Tera Water provide great resistances to Roaring Moon and Palafin, respectively. Ting-Lu fits in a variety of teams, ranging from bulky offense to stall. Offensive teammates such as Iron Valiant, Palafin, and Iron Hands appreciate that Ting-Lu can both set Spikes and act as a slow pivot with Parting Shot. These three Pokemon also beat Great Tusk, one of Ting-Lu's biggest checks, as it is able to beat it with Fighting-type moves and remove its entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Dondozo are able to check Pokemon that Ting-Lu can't, which include Azumarill, Rotom-W, and Mimikyu. Ting-Lu struggles to make progress with entry hazards up, so entry hazard removal from the likes of Great Tusk, Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Corviknight is recommended.

sets.name: Weakness Policy
sets.description: This EV spread survives Choice Band Hisuian Avalugg's Avalanche and Timid Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump; the remaining EVs are invested in Attack.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu is an outstanding wall, utilizing its immense bulk, Vessel of Ruin, and useful defensive typing to check threats such as Dragapult, Espathra, and Tapu Koko well. With access to both Stealth Rock and Spikes, Ting-Lu is a flexible entry hazard setter that supports its teammates well. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to pressure Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T, which don't care about its Earthquake. Rest is an option for more longevity across the length of a game, but it renders Ting-Lu useless for a few turns. Whirlwind works exceptionally well with other hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Mega Diancie, as it lets Ting-Lu wear down Pokemon quickly for its teammates, as well as phazing setup sweepers such as Espathra and Dragonite easily. Tera Poison grants Ting-Lu a Toxic immunity while also preventing Fairy-types like Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant from taking advatange of it. Tera Water gives Ting-Lu a solid typing defensively, letting it switch into Barraskewda and Weavile easily. Ghost is also a solid Tera type, as it lets Ting-Lu check Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant, as well as blocking Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk. Water-types such as Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, and Floatzel easily force Ting-Lu out, making Water-resistant teammates such as Ferrothorn, Slowbro, and Dragonite great partners. Due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to Fighting-types like Mega Medicham, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta, Pokemon like Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge work really well alongside it. Gholdengo in particular forms a potent defensive core with Ting-Lu, preventing its entry hazards from being Defogged. Wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant all pair amazingly with Ting-Lu's hazard support. Lastly, due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to hazard chip damage, entry hazard removers like Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Great Tusk are invaluable partners.

sets.name: Mixed Wall (Dark)
sets.description:
Not 2HKO'ed by Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and OHKO'es it back with Heavy Slam.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Feesh (Offensive Wallbreaker)
sets.description:
• Overheat hits extremely hard and can 2HKO even the bulkiest of Pokemon. Fire Blast and Flamethrower can be used to KO foes without Chi-Yu suffering a Special Attack drop, with Flamethrower having perfect accuracy.
  • The only reason to run Timid over Modest is to outspeed Jolly Great Tusk, Jolly Annihilape, and fast Iron Treads with Special Defense investment.
  • Tera Fire allows Chi-Yu to turn 2HKOs to OHKOs, for example OHKOing opposing Chi-Yu with Overheat. Tera Fire also lets it 2HKO any prominent special wall, including Toxapex, Blissey, and Ting-Lu, OHKOing them with sun.
  • Choice Specs Chi-Yu is a wallbreaker, suited best for offensive teams. Koraidon is an excellent teammate because it sets sun and pivots Chi-Yu in with U-turn. Koraidon and Chi-Yu also threaten each other's checks, like Koraidon threatening Blissey and Garganacl and Chi-Yu threatening Skeledirge and Dondozo.
  • Helpful teammates are those that can get Chi-Yu in safely and force out its few checks. Corviknight and Koraidon are noteworthy examples, pivoting into special walls such as Ting-Lu. Lures such as Heavy Slam Koraidon and Great Tusk, which beat Dachsbun, and Psyshock Flutter Mane, which beats Toxapex and Blissey, are also appreciated teammates.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Fire Blast is Chi-Yu's strongest STAB move without any stat drops. Psychic is an alternative that 2HKOes common switch-ins such as Dachsbun and Toxapex. Overheat facilitates revenge killing, hitting even Pokemon that resist it such as Koraidon hard, and is a better midground play.
  • Memento serves as a way to facilitate sweepers like Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon that Chi-Yu is usually paired with.
  • Tera Fire powers up Flamethrower and Overheat to nuclear levels, turning 2HKOs against Pokemon such as Koraidon into OHKOs. Tera Dark nullifies Chi-Yu's Stealth Rock weakness while making Dark Pulse 2HKO Dachsbun and Toxapex. Tera Grass should only be used with Tera Blast; it gives Chi-Yu nice resistances to Ground and Water and allows Chi-Yu to OHKO Great Tusk and 2HKO Ting-Lu after Spikes damage.
  • Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a revenge killer best suited for offensive teams.
  • Pokemon that can get Chi-Yu safely into the field, such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Corviknight, are excellent teammates for it. Koraidon also sets up sun, further boosting Chi-Yu's Fire-type attacks.
  • Ting-Lu and Glimmora can set entry hazards to guarantee some 2HKOs, such as against opposing Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot Chi-Yu can threaten to KO foes it couldn't otherwise, such as Ting-Lu and Blissey. Overheat hits extremely hard and threatens to OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Flamethrower is valuable for its perfect accuracy.
  • A Modest nature alongside Life Orb lets Chi-Yu OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used instead to give Chi-Yu more opportunities to switch in, but the loss of power is notable.
  • Chi-Yu fits best on offensive teams with Pokemon such as Cyclizar and Grimmsnarl that can facilitate its setup. Sticky Web support from Masquerain is also useful, as it lets Chi-Yu outrun Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon and KO them at +2.
  • Chi-Yu's best partner is Koraidon, since it sets up sun, can safely bring Chi-Yu into play with U-turn, and threatens Blissey. Other good partners are special attackers that benefit from special walls being neutered by Chi-Yu, such as Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo. Great Tusk is also greatly appreciated, as it can remove Stealth Rock and threatens Blissey and Ting-Lu for Chi-Yu. Chi-Yu can deal with Corviknight and Dondozo in return.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a potent revenge killer and a strong wallbreaker with good resistances, allowing it to check threats like Chien-Pao, Gholdengo, and Kingambit while also threatening balance and bulky offensive teams. Overheat is its strongest STAB move, which allows it to OHKO the bulkiest Pokemon like Blissey and Ting-Lu especially when boosted by Tera Fire and sun. Dark Pulse lets it pressure Fire-resistant foes like Miraidon, Toxapex, Pelipper, Alomomola, and Garganacl more easily. Fire Blast is a stronger option than Flamethrower that doesn't drop Special Attack, which lets Chi-Yu break through Garganacl and Blissey after minimal chip damage when boosted by sun and Tera Fire. Alternatively, Psychic may be used to deal greater damage to Toxapex and Koraidon. Tera Fire is mandatory to boost Chi-Yu's strength and let it spam its Fire-type moves more freely. Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is unreliable at breaking stall teams, so it is necessary to pair it with wallbreakers that perform this role such as Choice Band Chien-Pao, offensive Great Tusk, Gothitelle, and Swords Dance + Life Orb Koraidon. Koraidon in particular is mandatory to have as a teammate, as it sets sun, which makes up for the power lost by opting for Choice Scarf on Chi-Yu. Additionally, it also creates many opportunities for Chi-Yu to switch in safely thanks to U-turn and Chi-Yu's ability to exploit common Koraidon checks. Defensive partners like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, Clodsire, and Toxapex can set and remove entry hazards for Chi-Yu, allowing it to freely switch in multiple times and break teams more easily, and they also check strong revenge killers like Choice Scarf Koraidon, Miraidon, and Quark Drive-boosted Iron Bundle.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Chi-Yu is one of the metagame's most devastating wallbreakers. Beads of Ruin and a high Special Attack stat let it consistently force a KO whenever it comes in. Overheat allows Chi-Yu to OHKO or 2HKO even bulky resistant foes, with Flamethrower having perfect accuracy and not dropping Chi-Yu's Special Attack. Dark Pulse allows Chi-Yu to immediately threaten Fire-resistant Pokemon like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Garganacl, 2HKOing or OHKOing them without sun. Fire Blast can reach important damage thresholds, such as 2HKOing Blissey, without the Special Attack drop that accompanies Overheat, with Psychic instead preventing Toxapex from scouting Chi-Yu's move. Tera Fire turns Chi-Yu's 2HKOs against Pokemon like Toxapex and Double Dance Miraidon into OHKOs under sun, and it guarantees 2HKOs on even the bulkiest defensive Pokemon like Blissey and Garganacl, OHKOing them in sun and with minor chip damage. A Modest nature is preferred, but a Timid nature can be considered if Jolly Great Tusk is an issue. Koraidon is an incredible partner, setting sun and bringing Chi-Yu in with U-turn; in exchange, Chi-Yu greatly threatens all of Koraidon's checks. Pivots such as Corviknight and the aforementioned Koraidon are greatly appreciated, as they can let Chi-Yu switch in without worrying about its poor bulk. Entry hazard removal from Great Tusk, Corviknight, or Iron Treads is very helpful due to Chi-Yu's weakness to Stealth Rock and its tendency to switch out after a KO. Chi-Yu is often forced out by faster Pokemon like Miraidon and Koraidon, so defensive switch-ins to them like Clodsire, Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Corviknight are good partners.

doublesou.overview: Chi-Yu poses itself as one of the most menacing special attackers in DOU, with its high Special Attack, near unresisted STAB combination, and Beads of Ruin allowing it to hit the majority of the metagame extremely hard. Beads of Ruin also not only indirectly makes Chi-Yu hit harder but also empowers its special attacking teammates, with Iron Bundle and Gholdengo in particular being excellent partners due to their ability to either overwhelm shared checks like Ting-Lu or outright beat some of Chi-Yu's checks, such as Garchomp for the former and Glimmora for the latter. Furthermore, Chi-Yu has very good Speed, allowing it to naturally outspeed a considerable portion of the metagame. However, Chi-Yu is not without glaring weaknesses, as its HP and Defense are absurdly low, which leaves it vulnerable to common priority moves such as Palafin's Jet Punch and Dragonite's Extreme Speed. In addition, despite Dark / Fire being a good type combination offensively, it leaves Chi-Yu vulnerable defensively, as its weaknesses to Ground-, Rock- and Water-type moves in addition to Stealth Rock compromise its ability to switch in and fire off more attacks. Finally, Pokemon such as Glimmora, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp have the ability to potentially switch into Chi-Yu and threaten it out, with Ting-Lu's Tablets of Ruin being a particular annoyance due to it offsetting Beads of Ruin. However, it is important to note that Chi-Yu's strength is still to the magnitude that it can 2HKO all the aforementioned Pokemon under the right circumstances.
doublesou.comments:
Other Options

EV investment into Chi-Yu's HP and Defense allows it to survive a significant number of moves it would normally be OHKOd by, notably Dragonite's Extreme Speed, while a Modest nature can be used on both sets to further increase the amount of damage Chi-Yu can do overall. However both options can cut into Chi-Yu's Speed, with the former also potentially lowering the amount of damage Chi-Yu can do depending on the amount of investment.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Heat Wave allows Chi-Yu to pick off Pokemon like Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Chien-Pao, as well as being a good method of spreading damage.

  • Dark Pulse can hit Ghost- and Psychic-types like Dragapult and Armarouge, as well as Pokemon that resist Fire-type moves, like Glimmora.

  • Flamethrower and Overheat both give Chi-Yu the ability to focus its damage on a singular Pokemon, with Overheat being significantly stronger but far more punishing than Flamethrower.

  • Snarl is useful for spread damage when both Pokemon on the field can take Heat Wave, as well as supporting its team.

  • Choice Scarf lets Chi-Yu outrun almost the entire tier, allowing it to either threaten out Pokemon like Dragapult and Chien-Pao and pick off weakened targets.

  • The EV spread and a Timid nature both maximizes the number of Pokemon Chi-Yu can outspeed along with its damage output.

  • Tera Fire allows Chi-Yu to pick up KOs it normally wouldn't be able to otherwise, such as Amoonguss with Heat Wave, while Tera Ghost grants an immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, blocking two common methods to stop Chi-Yu, as well as making it immune to Fighting-type moves, which it would normally be weak to, like Drain Punch from Iron Hands.

sets.name: All Out Attacker
sets.description:
• Heat Wave provides excellent spread damage severely threatening Steel- and Grass-types like Gholdengo and Amoonguss while still being able to scorch neutral targets.

  • Dark Pulse hits several Pokemon that resist Heat Wave, such as Glimmora, as well as Ghost- and Psychic-types like Armarouge and Dragapult hard, as well as just being a solid STAB move

  • Flamethrower and Overheat deal more damage to a single target than Heat Wave, which can allow Chi-Yu break past Pokemon it normally wouldn't be able to, such as Ting-Lu. Overheat allows Chi-Yu to deal an insane amount of damage, accomplishing feats such as OHKOing Tera Normal Dragonite, while Flamethrower is weaker than Overheat by a significant margin but doesn't have the Special Attack drop and imperfect accuracy.
