  • Snarl provides a secondary spread attack that can hit deceptively hard, in addition to debuffing the opposing team, while Tera Blast can be utilized with Tera Grass in order to give Chi-Yu an option to hit Pokemon like Palafin and Iron Bundle. Protect should only be used with Life Orb, but can keep Chi-Yu safe for a turn while a teammate either repositions or sets speed control to assist it.

  • Choice Specs and Life Orb both boost Chi-Yu's damage output to absurd levels, with the former allowing Chi-Yu to switch moves in exchange for the recoil and loss of power.

  • Tera Fire exponentially increases the strength of Fire-type moves for Chi-Yu, while Tera Grass patches up Chi-Yu's weakness to Water-type moves, and Tera Ghost prevents Fake Out and Extreme Speed from slowing down or picking off Chi-Yu, in addition to turning the Fighting-type weakness to an immunity.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Choice-Yu
sets.description:
• With a Choice Item, Chi-Yu can choose to become either a spicy revenge killer or a scorching wallbreaker!

  • Flamethrower versus Lava Plume: Flamethrower's higher power makes it the better cleaning tool, but Lava Plume's higher burn chance gives Chi-Yu a good shot of punishing major physical attacking fores such as Dragonite, Azumarill, and Garchomp that resist Fire.

  • Psychic: This is Chi-Yu's most powerful attack against Iron Moth and Toxapex and can pick off weakened Annihilape without Overheat's Special Attack drop.

  • Tera Blast: Even before Terastallizing, Tera Blast is a decent coverage move that hits Azumarill and Roaring Moon.

  • Memento: Memento is a great filler move on Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, especially for setting up dangerous sweepers like Chien-Pao and Dragonite.

  • Sleep Talk: Sleep Talk makes Chi-Yu a decent Spore absorber against Amoonguss and Brute Bonnet and even against Breloom with a bulkier EV spread or the correct Tera type.

  • Modest versus Timid: Modest is generally preferred since Chi-Yu's Speed isn't too impressive, but Timid does ensure that Chi-Yu outspeeds Annihilape and Mimikyu, who are fully capable of revenge killing Chi-Yu that lack Choice Scarf.

Other Options

  • Fire Blast: Fire Blast's shaky accuracy can be an issue, but it's a far better sweeping tool than Overheat.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Chi-Yu's damage output is red hot even without Terastallization, making it a fairly flexible Pokemon.

  • Fire: Tera Fire Overheat is extremely difficult to wall without a resistance, making it an easy choice for Chi-Yu. It also lets Tera Blast become a powerful STAB move while Chi-Yu is locked into using it, letting it get around the normal limitations of using a Choice Item.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is Chi-Yu's best shot of defeating Roaring Moon and Hydreigon and gives it an important Fighting-type resistance.

  • Grass: Tera Grass is a good response to Azumarill and Palafin-H and lets Chi-Yu avoid being OHKOed by Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump.

  • Dark: While Tera Dark is nowhere near as impressive as a boosted Overheat, Dark Pulse has excellent coverage and also removes Chi-Yu's troublesome Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Water: Getting a Water-type resistance is always useful, but the real key for Tera Water is that it helps Chi-Yu in the mirror match-up, especially against Assault Vest Chi-Yu.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost lets Chi-Yu surprise Extreme Speed Dragonite and Mach Punch Breloom.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf patches up Chi-Yu's lukewarm Speed into something usable for revenge killing and also makes bulkier builds easier to use.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs trades revenge killing for terrifying wallbreaking power. With Tera Fire, the heat gets so extreme that even Blissey is 2HKOed by Overheat!

Bulkier EV Spread

  • 228 HP / 12 Def / 124 SpA / 4 SpD / 140 Spe with Modest: This is a bulky spread meant for Choice Scarf, outspeeding up to Iron Bundle. The bulk investment survives Breloom's Mach Punch, Mimikyu's Play Rough followed by Shadow Sneak, and has a good shot of surviving Tera Normal Choice Band Dragonite's Extreme Speed. 40 EVs can be moved from Special Attack to Speed to outspeed Dragapult at a serious cost to power.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Chi-Yu's sizzling offensive power lets it get away with a wide variety of options that wouldn't fit on a Choice item set.

  • Flamethrower versus Lava Plume: Flamethrower's greater power makes it the better option in most instances, but Lava Plume's higher burn rate is good at punishing switch-ins like Azumarill and Dragonite.

  • Flame Charge: Chi-Yu is powerful enough that even without an offensive item, getting a Speed boost makes cleaning teams late game very achievable.

  • Psychic: Psychic is Chi-Yu's best option against Iron Moth and Toxapex. Note that Overheat will out-damage targets like Annihilape though.

Other Options

  • Will-O-Wisp: If not using Assault Vest, Will-O-Wisp severely punishes bulky physical threats like Azumarill and Dragonite that may switch in and works great with Terastallization to surprise other bulky threats such Ting-Lu.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Chi-Yu has a ton of weaknesses to common attacking types, so while Terastallization isn't needed to function, it can especially help bulkier Chi-Yu check more threats and otherwise focus less on hit-and-run attacking.

  • Fire: Beyond giving Overheat soul-melting damage output, Tera Fire gives Chi-Yu a vital Fairy-type resistance against Flutter Mane and a good shot of OHKOing even bulky Flutter Mane with Overheat.

  • Water: Tera Water works great on Assault Vest Chi-Yu with Tera Blast, ironically turning it into a decent check against other Chi-Yu! It also eases the matchup against Palafin-H.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy has good synergy with Chi-Yu's former typing, giving it a vital Fighting-type resistance and ensuring Chi-Yu is not walled by Roaring Moon.

  • Grass: Tera Grass is a huge help against Azumarill and Palafin-H and lets Chi-Yu more safely set up Flame Charge against Spore users like Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost is Chi-Yu's best hope against Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Breloom's Mach Punch.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Chi-Yu has shockingly decent Special Defense, so Assault Vest lets it preform much better against Flutter Mane and opposing Chi-Yu.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets you get away with playing this set far more offensively at the cost of being even weaker to priority attacks than usual.

  • Focus Sash: If using a more offensive spread, Focus Sash can be worth it to flip the tables on fast offensive foes such as Iron Bundle.

  • Eject Pack: This turns Overheat into a one-use pivot move, surprising foes with a momentum shift in your favor.

EVs

  • 228 HP / 12 Def / 124 SpA / 4 SpD / 140 Spe with Modest: This bulky spread is perfect for Assault Vest and Flame Charge, letting Chi-Yu outspeed Iron Bundle after a boost and avoid an OHKO from Breloom's Mach Punch. It also avoids a KO from Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak following Play Rough and often survives Tera Normal Dragonite's Choice Band Extreme Speed. If outspeeding Dragapult after Flame Charge is a priority, 40 Special Attack EVs can be moved to Speed.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest or Timid: When using more offensive items like Life Orb or Focus Sash, going a more offensive route makes Chi-Yu a better late-game sweeper. Modest is preferred for the damage output, but Timid outspeeds Annihilape and Mimikyu.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• While not easy to sweep with due to it's Speed, Chi-Yu becomes a a hot wallbreaker after setting up Nasty Plot!

  • Overheat: Overheat's Special Attack drop may conflict with Nasty Plot, but it'll deep-fry almost any Pokemon slower than Chi-Yu, making it a worthy wallbreaking tool.

  • Substitute: Substitute does a great job of punishing common status users such as Wo-Chien, Amoonguss, and Toxapex. If Terastallized, Chi-Yu has a good chance of retaining its Substitute against Salt Cure as well.

  • Flame Charge: While setting up both Nasty Plot and Flame Charge is unlikely, it does give Chi-Yu a different avenue to sweep late-game.

  • Timid versus Modest: While this Chi-Yu is more focused on extreme wall-frying than sweeping, Timid is nice for outspeeding Annihilape, who certainly can't handle boosted attacks well.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Chi-Yu's poor defensive typing can make it fairly easy to revenge kill, so having Terastallization free gives Chi-Yu much more KO opportunities beyond cooking slower threats.

  • Fire: Tera Fire makes Overheat an insane wall-breaking move, with Life Orb threatening to OHKO Blissey after a boost!

  • Grass: With Tera Grass, Chi-Yu can threaten to OHKO Azumarill after a boost in addition to avoiding an OHKO from Aqua Jet and Jet Punch.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Chi-Yu a helpful Fighting-type resistance and a better match-up against powerful Dragon-types like Dragonite and Roaring Moon.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost covers Chi-Yu's Fighting-type weakness and helps against Extreme Speed, making it much harder to stop its sweep.

  • Dark: With Nasty Plot and Life Orb, Tera Dark Chi-Yu is capable of OHKOing even the most specially defensive Annihilape with Dark Pulse!

  • Water: Tera Water lets Chi-Yu deal with opposing Chi-Yu more comfortably and punish the common Tera Fire Annihilape with Tera Blast.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash makes setting up Nasty Plot much easier, at the cost of power.

  • Life Orb: While it makes Chi-Yu even more vulnerable to priority moves, Life Orb is otherwise an excellent wallbreaking item, notably giving Chi-Yu a better matchup against Annihilape.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 24 HP / 12 Def / 220 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid or Modest: If using Substitute, this spread prevents Garganacl with 4 Attack EVs from breaking a Terastallized Chi-Yu's Substitute with Salt Cure. Note that Body Press and Earthquake will still break the Substitute unless using the correct Tera Type.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Cinderace and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Sand Stream Garganacl and non-Unaware Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Meowscarada and Kingambit make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance Roaring Moon is one of the tier's most threatening late-game setup sweepers due to its high offensive stats, strong coverage moves, and decent bulk. Earthquake is a strong, consistent coverage option that hits Kingambit, Garganacl, Iron Hands, and Clodsire super effectively. Roost, on the other hand, gives Roaring Moon access to reliable recovery, which gives it more setup opportunities throughout the game even if its Booster Energy is already used up. Acrobatics has fantastic coverage, as it hits Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Breloom super effectively and should always be run alongside Tera Flying to maximize its power. Since Acrobatics + Earthquake hits most of the metagame at least neutrally, Crunch can be dropped in favor of Taunt to shut down common defensive foes, most notably Corviknight and Rotom-W that would otherwise resist the aforementioned move combination. However, this makes Roaring Moon very reliant on Terastallization due to the lack of reliable STAB moves. Iron Head is a viable alternative to Acrobatics and should always be run alongside Tera Steel, as it deals with Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Hatterene simultaneously. Tera Flying removes all of Roaring Moon's baseline weaknesses bar Ice, gives it a resistance to Fighting- and Bug-type attacks, a Ground immunity, and a STAB boost to Acrobatics. Tera Steel, though more niche, allows Roaring Moon to resist Hatterene's Dazzling Gleam, Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Tera Normal Dragonite's Extreme Speed. A Jolly nature is typically run to outspeed Booster Energy Iron Valiant after a Dragon Dance, but Adamant is a decent alternative, particularly on teams that allow Roaring Moon to obtain more than one Dragon Dance boost. After a Dragon Dance, Adamant Roaring Moon can more easily OHKO defensive variants of Gholdengo and Great Tusk.

Dragon Dance Roaring Moon best functions on offensive teams, pairing well with setup sweepers that can wear down each other's checks. Iron Valiant can opt out of running Psyshock, since Roaring Moon breaks past Clodsire for it, and Breloom can more effectively utilize its STAB moves and Spore once Roaring Moon eliminates Gholdengo. Dondozo and Tera Fairy Skeledirge are major threats to Roaring Moon due to their ability to ignore its boosts with Unaware, while strong priority users like Dragonite and Breloom can revenge kill Roaring Moon thanks to its low Defense. Ting-Lu can force Roaring Moon out with Whirlwind, and Choice Band Iron Hands survives a boosted Earthquake from full health and can OHKO Roaring Moon with Close Combat. Iron Valiant offers immediate damage against Dondozo, Iron Hands, and Ting-Lu due to its excellent mixed coverage. Offensive Great Tusk and Technician Breloom can help wear down Ting-Lu with their super effective STAB moves, and Breloom's Technician-boosted Bullet Seed can also break past Dondozo. Grimmsnarl's ability to set up dual screens allows Roaring Moon to set up multiple Dragon Dances and survive attacks from Dragonite.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
When equipped with a Choice Band, Roaring Moon becomes a solid wallbreaker in OU, 2HKOing common physical walls such as Toxapex and Garganacl. Earthquake hits Kingambit, Toxapex, and Garganacl. Alternatively, Iron Head can be run to punish Fairy-types such as Tera Fairy Skeledirge, Iron Valiant, and Hatterene. U-turn is used to pivot out of checks such as Great Tusk and Corviknight, gaining momentum for the team. Tera Dark allows Roaring Moon to OHKO Clodsire and Volcarona with Crunch. Alternatively, a Steel Tera type gives it a resistance to Fairy-, Ice-, Dragon-, and Normal-type moves from Iron Valiant, Dragapult, Baxcalibur, opposing Roaring Moon, and Dragonite while also improving Iron Head's damage output.

Roaring Moon best fits on bulky offense teams, so teammates that can help out with its Fairy-type weakness such as Corviknight and Skeledirge are appreciated, with Corviknight luring in Gholdengo for Roaring Moon to take advantage of. Great Tusk can use Rapid Spin to clear away entry hazards. Garganacl provides Stealth Rock support and can use Salt Cure to chip down Rotom-W and Great Tusk, both of which defensively pose a problem for Roaring Moon, and Amoonguss can provide status support with Spore, forcing switches for Roaring Moon to gain momentum. In turn, Roaring Moon can defeat Gholdengo and Toxapex, which opens up the game for teammates such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant. Volcarona can deal with Corviknight, and Kingambit can weaken Great Tusk when paired with Roaring Moon.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• With Dragon Dance and Acrobatics, Roaring Moon is a strong sweeper on offensive teams, with coverage to beat almost all Pokemon.
  • Tera Flying allows Roaring Moon to set up on Great Tusk and Body Press Corviknight and boosts Acrobatics's power to achieve feats such as OHKOing Toxapex and Ting-Lu after two Dragon Dances and entry hazard or slight chip damage.
  • Crunch is more reliable, having a chance to drop Defense with no potential drawback, while Jaw Lock has the potential to give Roaring Moon a free chance to set up when paired with Roost, assuming a favorable target is trapped. If an unfavorable target is trapped, however, it has a major downside, making it less consistent.
  • Roost gives Roaring Moon more opportunities to use Dragon Dance, turning weaker Pokemon like Brave Bird Corviknight and Whirpool Alomomola into setup fodder.
  • Earthquake hits Kingambit, Garganacl, and Iron Treads, which can otherwise survive hits and wear down Roaring Moon.
  • Taunt stops defensive Pokemon like Haze Toxapex, Will-O-Wisp Skeledirge, and Whirlwind Ting-Lu from dealing with Roaring Moon, making it devastating against bulkier teams if positioned right.
  • Hyper offense leads such as Glimmora, Froslass, and Grimmsnarl all give Roaring Moon good support to break through a team more easily.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Tera Fire Koraidon, and Tera Fairy Miraidon can all be used to bait Chien-Pao and take it out, helping Roaring Moon greatly, as it is one of the most reliable revenge killers that can be used against it.
  • On bulkier teams, Roaring Moon requires teammates that can switch into Ice-type moves from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, making Toxapex and specially defensive Corviknight great partners. The latter can also pivot with U-turn, giving Roaring Moon more chances to set up on defensive Pokemon.

sets.name: Full Moon (Choice Band)
sets.description:
• Earthquake lets Roaring Moon break past Pokemon that would otherwise check it, like Garganacl, Toxapex, and especially Kingambit.
  • Iron Head lets Roaring Moon hit Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Tera Fairy Garganacl and Skeledirge super effectively.
  • U-turn lets Roaring Moon generate offensive momentum for its team and is especially useful against targets Roaring Moon scares out, like Skeledirge without Tera Fairy and Gholdengo.
  • The given EVs and a Jolly nature ensure Roaring Moon's Speed is boosted in sunlight, letting it get the jump on crucial threats like unboosted non-Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon and threaten them with its STAB Dragon Claw. The remaining 36 Special Defense EVs improve Roaring Moon's chances to survive Iron Bundle's Ice Beam after Stealth Rock while giving it a chance to survive Overheat in sun from Modest Choice Specs Chi-Yu.
  • Tera Dark strengthens Roaring Moon's Crunch to the point where it always 2HKOs physically defensive Corviknight and always 3HKOs Dondozo while easing predictions with Earthquake against Garganacl.
  • Tera Steel lets Roaring Moon resist otherwise super effective Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type attacks from the likes of Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, Koraidon, and Miraidon. Tera Steel also powers up Roaring Moon's Iron Head.
  • Tera Fairy allows Roaring Moon to resist Fighting-type attacks while becoming immune to Dragon-type attacks, letting it defeat Koraidon and Iron Valiant, both of which outspeed and threaten to OHKO Roaring Moon otherwise.
  • Roaring Moon loves the support of Koraidon, as it activates Roaring Moon's Protosynthesis via Orichalcum Pulse and reliably threatens Pokemon such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Ice-types like Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle. In return, Roaring Moon threatens non-Terastallized Skeledirge.
  • Koraidon and Roaring Moon both struggle with defensive Great Tusk, so they can team up with Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao, which threaten all Great Tusk sets. Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao also threaten Koraidon and Miraidon, with Iron Bundle naturally outspeeding non-Choice Scarf variants and Chien-Pao threatening them with priority Ice Shard.
  • Defensive Great Tusk and Ting-Lu also work well with Roaring Moon, as they can set up entry hazards for Roaring Moon's team and check Koraidon and Miraidon, respectively. Great Tusk in particular can use Rapid Spin, giving Roaring Moon more opportunities to switch in, while Ting-Lu can phaze threatening boosters like Espathra with Whirlwind and set up Spikes.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight can check Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, both of which outspeed and threaten Roaring Moon, and can Defog hazards away, giving Roaring Moon more opportunities to switch in.
  • Roaring Moon can easily pivot into Chi-Yu, which takes advantage of the sun set by Koraidon and threatens walls like Great Tusk, Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Terastallized Skeledirge.
  • Gholdengo also makes for a decent partner, as not only does it have perfect defensive synergy with Roaring Moon, but it can also reliably block all common forms of hazard removal. This allows Roaring Moon’s team to keep up hazards, in particular Spikes, for it to eventually break down walls.

sets.name: Offensive Tailwind Setter
sets.description:
• Roaring Moon has grown into the role of DOU's premier offensive Tailwind setter, using its blazing Speed to provide both damage and team support.
  • Booster Energy lets Roaring Moon outspeed every other Pokemon in the format besides Booster Energy Iron Bundle. This ensures Roaring Moon is able to set Tailwind before being KOed and may even allow its partner to KO opposing threats instead.
  • Breaking Swipe offers survivability for Roaring Moon and its partner as well as chip damage that can break the Focus Sash of Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle.
  • Acrobatics is immediately activated when Booster Energy is consumed and offers strong damage, nearly matching Roaring Moon's best STAB options, Throat Chop and Dragon Claw. With Tera Flying, it becomes Roaring Moon's best damage-dealing option, threatening massive damage on Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Great Tusk.
  • Throat Chop can be used over either Breaking Swipe or Acrobatics as a consistent STAB option that hits Indeedee-F and Armarouge for super effective damage.
  • Roaring Moon's defenses are decent, but both Dragon / Dark and Flying have notable weaknesses, especially to opposing Ice-types like Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao; Protect gives Roaring Moon the opportunity to avoid these attacks while its partner removes such threats. Protect can also be used to stall out field effects like weather, Trick Room, and an opponent's Tailwind.
  • The listed EVs will boost Roaring Moon's Speed with Booster Energy. If an Attack boost is desired instead, 32 HP EVs can be moved into Attack.
  • If being used on sun teams, Life Orb is preferred as the item. Sun will activate Protosynthesis without consuming Booster Energy, keeping Acrobatics at a measly 55 Base Power. Keep this in mind while facing sun teams as well.
  • Taunt is an option to prevent opposing forms of speed control such as Tailwind and Trick Room.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Acrobatics
sets.description:
• With Booster Energy juicing up Tera Flying Acrobatics and one of Roaring Moon's stats, it's an excellent choice for late-game sweeping!

  • Earthquake: Earthquake is Roaring Moon's best shot at beating Kingambit.

  • Taunt: Taunt is the best way around troublesome defensive foes, such as Dondozo, Corviknight, and Tera Fairy Skeledirge.

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop is the preferred Dark-type STAB move over Crunch, since it can shut down important sound moves from Skeledirge, Volcarona, and Sylveon.

  • Roost: Recovery really allows Roaring Moon to take advantage of its good special bulk, especially if investing in it.

EV Spreads

  • 220 Atk / 36 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread gives Roaring Moon a Speed boost from Protosynthesis, making it a good revenge killer.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: This simple spread makes Protosynthesis boost Attack, potentially letting Roaring Moon 2HKO Skeledirge with Acrobatics.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 20 Def / 204 SpD / 28 Spe with Careful: This spread takes a slower, bulkier approach to boosting, getting a Special Defense boost from Protosynthesis and outspeeding Dragapult after one Dragon Dance. This spread is best used with Roost, and Taunt is also highly recommended to get past Skeledirge.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• While Roaring Moon is most known for using Booster Energy and Acrobatics, other Tera Types and moves can let it defeat a different set of threats and be used earlier in the game.

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop shutting down important sound moves such as Volcarona's Bug Buzz makes it the better option over Crunch.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head is good at punishing Fairy Terastallization, especially when using Tera Steel Roaring Moon.

  • Roost: Even with the offensive nature of this set, Roost is good against Choice locked foes.

  • Scale Shot: While lowering Roaring Moon's Defense makes it even more vulnerable to priority, the Speed boost can lead to some surprising sweeps when picking off foes. It also has a shot of OHKOing offensive Dragonite through Multiscale.

Other Options

  • Outrage: This is by far Roaring Moon's strongest attack, though being locked in can easily lead to counter play via Terastallization and Fairy-types.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel's good matchup against Fairy- and Dragon-types makes it a prime candidate.

  • Fire: With Tera Fire, Roaring Moon gains a useful resistance to Bullet Punch and cooks Scizor, Tinkaton, and Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is an excellent answer to faster Dragon-types such Dragapult and Choice Scarf Garchomp and gives Roaring Moon a vital Fighting-type resistance against otherwise troublesome foes like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Annihilape.

  • Ghost: Roaring Moon gains a useful Extreme Speed and Mach Punch immunity, making Dragonite and Breloom far less problematic. This is especially useful if using Scale Shot.

Items

  • Life Orb: While making Roaring Moon more vulnerable to priority, the reliable damage output means Roaring Moon doesn't have to set up to deal massive damage.

  • Booster Energy: Beyond making Roaring Moon more suited for late-game sweeping, Booster Energy is perfect for making opponents think its the more common Acrobatics set.

  • Loaded Dice: When using Scale Shot, Loaded Dice is a strong consideration, letting +1 Roaring Moon always OHKO offensive Dragonite and almost always OHKO Breloom with Scale Shot.

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry is perfect for taking advantage of Pokemon that are likely to inflict status on Roaring Moon, such as Tinkaton, Rotom-W, and Umbreon.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: This classic spread will give Roaring Moon an Attack boost from Protosynthesis.

  • 220 Atk / 36 Def / 252 Spe: This is the spread to use if a Speed Boost from Protosynthesis is needed.

sets.name: Jaw Lock Trapper
sets.description:
• With Jaw Lock, Roost, and Taunt, Roaring Moon is capable of severely punishing defensive answers to it, which is worth the risk of trapping itself.

  • Dragon Dance: If trapping a very passive foe such as Hippowdon, Roaring Moon can threaten to get to +6, slicing through teams like a hot knife through butter!

  • Substitute: Substitute works great with Toxic Spikes support, giving Roaring Moon a means to rack up Toxic damage.

  • Earthquake: This prevents Roaring Moon from being walled by Kingambit.

  • U-turn: U-turn gives Roaring Moon a way to switch out of bad Jaw Lock matchups, reducing its risk greatly without using up an item slot.

Other Options

  • Acrobatics: If using Booster Energy and Tera Flying, Acrobatics is far more powerful than Jaw Lock, punishing Annihilape and Great Tusk in particular.

Tera Types

  • Poison: In addition to providing a vital resistance to Fairy- and Fighting-type attacks, Tera Poison lets Roaring Moon freely switch into Toxic, which would ruin this set otherwise.

  • Fairy: Taking on Dragon- and Fighting-type attacks makes Fairy a reliable Tera type.

  • Flying: Tera Flying grants Roaring Moon safety from Garganacl and Dondozo's Fissure and pairs nicely with Acrobatics.

  • Don't Use Ghost: Tera Ghost is tempting to allow Roaring Moon to switch out of Jaw Lock, but be warned: you must Terastallize only on the turn after using Jaw Lock, because otherwise, the trapping effect will fail to activate if using Jaw Lock as a Ghost-type!

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Dragon Dance, the residual recovery makes setting up multiple Dragon Dances much easier.

  • Shed Shell: Shed Shell lets Roaring Moon switch out of Jaw Lock, massively reducing the risk.

  • Booster Energy: This turns Tera Flying Acrobatics into a powerful form of offense.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Making Roaring Moon immune to Toxic Spikes gives it much more flexibility against stall teams with Toxic Spike setters such as Clodsire and Toxapex.

  • Protective Pads: Protective Pads will guard Roaring Moon against Volcarona's Flame Body and Rocky Helmet for otherwise good trapping targets such as Dondozo and Clodsire.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 196 Def / 36 SpD / 28 Spe with Impish: This EV spread outspeeds Dragapult after one Dragon Dance, avoids a 2HKO from Iron Bundle if Roaring Moon is Terastallized, and avoids a 2HKO from an unboosted Dragonite Tera Normal Extreme Speed.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 20 Def / 204 SpD / 28 Spe with Careful: This spread gets a Special Defense boost from Protosynthesis while still outspeeding Dragapult after one Dragon Dance.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: While much less bulky than the other spreads, maximum Speed ensures Roaring Moon outspeeds Iron Valiant, Scream Tail, and Dragon Dance Tyranitar. The former two can ruin Roaring Moon with Encore.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description:
• With great offenses and U-turn, Roaring Moon is a good and unexpected choice for pivoting.

  • Throat Chop versus Jaw Lock: Shutting down troublesome sound moves such as Torch Song and Bug Buzz make Throat Chop the superior choice over Crunch. If using Assault Vest, Jaw Lock's trapping capabilities come in handy, especially with U-turn reducing its risk.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head is good coverage against Tera Fairy-types with Levitate such as Rotom-W and Hydreigon.

  • Outrage: Outrage is a risky move, but it excels at cleaning teams in the late game.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Roaring Moon a good matchup against Fairy types with Iron Head, and the Stealth Rock resistances lets it pivot out with less consequences.

  • Fire: Tera Fire's Stealth Rock weakness is a bit problematic with U-turn, but has great offensive and defensive synergy, letting Roaring Moon take Fairy-type attacks, and roast Scizor and Air Balloon Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy not only absorbs Dragon-type attacks, but it also massively improves Roaring Moon's matchups against strong Fighting-types such as Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Annihilape via Tera Blast.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: A Choice Scarf in wing will let Roaring Moon outpace some of its common revenge killers, such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Dragapult.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band gives Roaring Moon incredible wallbreaking power, now being able to 2HKO Skeledirge and Dondozo with Outrage.

  • Assault Vest: Roaring Moon makes for a great bulky using of Assault Vest, being able to easily take on Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane when Terastallized into the correct type.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: The old-school offensive spread gives Roaring Moon an Attack boost from Protosynthesis.

  • 220 Atk / 36 Def / 252 Spe: This spread gives Roaring Moon a Speed boost from Protosynthesis, which can be useful if running Choice Band on a sun team.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Roaring Moon is a fierce wallbreaker that dents large holes in balance teams and has specific coverage to beat its would-be checks. Strong Jaw-boosted Fire Fang threatens Zamazenta-C and Fluffy Corviknight attempting to tank Crunch while Thunder Fang OHKOes Galarian Zapdos and 2HKOes defensive Quaquaval. U-turn allows it to maintain momentum in the face of hard counters like Hippowdon and a healthy Corviknight while also being a midground option for predicted switch-ins. An Adamant nature gives Roaring Moon a chance of OHKOing Hisuian Goodra and is guaranteed to 2HKO Corviknight and Quaquaval, while a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed and threaten Azelf and Iron Moth. Roaring Moon pairs well with other physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Chien-Pao and Meowscarada that can clean up teams after checks like Zamazenta-C and Quaquaval have been removed. Pivots like Zapdos, Regieleki, and Hisuian Electrode form a VoltTurn core with Roaring Moon that wears down each other's checks. Roaring Moon's unimpressive physical bulk and weakness-laden typing mean that it is a prime target of revenge killers like Slither Wing and Triage Enamorus-T; walls like Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra pair well with Roaring Moon, as they absorb revenge killing attempts while providing defensive utility that Roaring Moon lacks.

sets.name: Choice Band Wallbreaker
sets.description: Roaring Moon is an exceptional wallbreaker that deals devastating damage to typical defensive foes, such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Rotom-W, thanks to its newfound access to high-power STAB moves such as Glaive Rush, Dragon Darts, and Knock Off. Moreover, its high Speed along with Sucker Punch allows it to revenge kill boosted setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo. Dragon Darts can be run over Glaive Rush to more easily ensure the 2HKO on Great Tusk by committing Tera without fainting to bulkier walls such as Great Tusk due to Glaive Rush's self damage multiplier. Earthquake can be used to inflict more damage against Toxapex and Pokemon that resist both Roaring Moon's STAB types such as Fairy-types like Azumarill. U-turn allows Roaring Moon to both maintain momentum when faced with difficult matchups like Ting-Lu and chip the opponent's Pokemon. Tera Dragon maximizes Glaive Rush and Dragon Darts's damage. Roaring Moon fits best alongside offensive teammates that can help to dismantle defensive cores; examples include Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Gyarados. Due to its lackluster coverage against Fairy-types like Azumarill and common physically defensive Tera Fairy users such as Skeledirge and Toxapex, Roaring Moon needs teammates capable of handling them such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, Clodsire, Toxapex, and Dondozo. As a final note, Roaring Moon heavily benefits from being on sun teams alongside teammates commonly found on them like Torkoal and Scovillain, as its ability, Protosynthesis, lets it gain an Attack boost.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dragon)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Choice Specs Iron Valiant functions as a special wallbreaker thanks to its speed, power, and coverage moves. Psyshock hits Poison-types like Clodsire, Toxapex, and Amoonguss. Shadow Ball targets Gholdengo and Skeledirge, while Thunderbolt is used to hit Corviknight, as well as doing super effective damage to Toxapex, Tera Flying Gholdengo, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Trick is another option to cripple common switch-ins such as Clodsire, Skeledirge, and Toxapex. Focus Blast threatens an OHKO on Garganacl while greatly damaging Corviknight. However, Aura Sphere is another option that is more consistent thanks to its accuracy, though it misses out on the damage output of Focus Blast. Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast and removes Iron Valiant's weakness to Fairy-, Psychic-, and Flying-type attacks. Alternatively, Tera Ghost makes Iron Valiant immune to Dragonite's Extreme Speed, allows it to OHKO Gholdengo, and increases its damage output against Skeledirge. Tera Electric is a final option to OHKO Toxapex and physically defensive Corviknight and turn its Steel-type weakness into a resistance.

Physically offensive Pokemon such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Cinderace benefit from Iron Valiant, as they struggle against Dondozo, Great Tusk, and Rotom-W, all of which Iron Valiant can pressure effectively. Entry hazard support from partners like Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Garchomp provides chip damage against Pokemon that try to play around Iron Valiant such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Clodsire. Pivots such as Rotom-W, Dragapult, Cinderace, and Corviknight give Iron Valiant opportunities to get on the field, reducing the risk of it taking damage. Iron Valiant enjoys the presence of partners that it can rely on to take hits, such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl, due to its frailty. Keeping the field free from hazards grants Iron Valiant more chances to get on the field and make progress, so teammates with access to Rapid Spin or Defog such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Corviknight are appreciated.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description:
High attacking stats and a wide array of coverage moves make Iron Valiant a devastating mixed attacker that can 2HKO common defensive walls physically and specially; Moonblast and Thunderbolt threaten physically defensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Dondozo, while Close Combat and Psyshock deal with specially defensive foes like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Its Quark Drive-boosted Speed from Booster Energy turns it into a potent late-game cleaner, letting it outspeed would-be revenge killers like Dragapult, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, which is further enforced by its unique typing that resists Sucker Punch from Kingambit. However, it can also be used to revenge kill boosted threats like Dragonite in a pinch, especially since Iron Valiant can take on Dragonite's +1 Tera Normal Extreme Speed from full health. Tera Fairy boosts Iron Valiant's Moonblast while still retaining its defensive profile to take on Sucker Punch. Alternatively, Tera Electric amplifies Thunderbolt's damage, notably allowing it to 2HKO would-be checks like Toxapex, specially defensive Dondozo and Tera Water Garganacl, and offensive Gholdengo after Stealth Rock, as well as preventing Iron Valiant from being revenge killed by Scizor's Bullet Punch.

Mixed Iron Valiant is commonly seen on offense and bulky offense teams. Due to the lack of a damage boosting item or setup move, it can still fall short of threatening bulky Pokemon like Amoonguss, and without Shadow Ball or Knock Off, Skeledirge and defensive Gholdengo as well; thus, Pokemon that can deal with them such as Great Tusk, and Kingambit make good teammates. Particularly, the aforementioned Pokemon can overwhelm a shared check in Corviknight and are generally effective as early-game wallbreakers that can open up Iron Valiant to clean up late-game easily. Entry hazards from teammates like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Glimmora can chip down foes like Garganacl, Amoonguss, and Tera Grass Dondozo. A sturdy defensive backbone with the likes of Corviknight and Ting-Lu can help check offensive threats that threaten Iron Valiant out, such as a boosted Roaring Moon, opposing Iron Valiant, and Gholdengo. Pivots like Dragapult, Scizor, and Rotom-W can compensate for Iron Valiant's lack of bulk by bringing it in safely on foes like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Blissey, respectively; the latter can also cripple Amoonguss with either Trick or Will-O-Wisp. Gholdengo is a great partner, as it reliably prevents the much-needed entry hazards from being removed by Rapid Spin and Defog, threatens Skeledirge and Tera Fairy Garganacl, and appreciates Iron Valiant dealing with foes like Corviknight and Dark-types like Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon in return.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Iron Valiant utilizes a deadly combination of offensive power, coverage, and Speed to function as one of the best sweepers in OU. After a Quark Drive boost, Iron Valiant outspeeds and OHKOes a plethora of premier offensive threats in the tier, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon. Thunderbolt allows Iron Valiant to damage Corviknight and bulky Water-types like Dondozo, Azumarill, Toxapex, and Tera Water Garganacl, while Shadow Ball threatens Hatterene, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge. Psyshock scores a 2HKO on any Clodsire looking to stop Iron Valiant's sweep. With Calm Mind, Iron Valiant can switch roles from an endgame sweeper to a powerful wallbreaker. After one Calm Mind, Moonblast 2HKOes defensive Garganacl, and +1 Tera Electric Thunderbolt 2HKOes specially defensive Slowking and OHKOes Corviknight. Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast, which can now 2HKO Garganacl and Hatterene. Tera Electric boosts the power of Thunderbolt, which secures important 2HKOs on specially defensive Dondozo, Corviknight, and Toxapex, lets Iron Valiant survive Scizor's Bullet Punch, and grants Iron Valiant an immunity to paralysis from Hatterene's Nuzzle. Tera Ghost boosts Iron Valiant's Shadow Ball, letting it 2HKO specially defensive Skeledirge, and prevents revenge killing attempts from Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

Iron Valiant relies heavily on its super-effective coverage moves for damage output. As a result, it struggles to make progress against Pokemon like Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Scizor. Thus, teammates like Clodsire and Ting-Lu are good defensive partners for Iron Valiant, with the added benefit of being able to set up entry hazards. Iron Moth has strong offensive synergy with Iron Valiant, being able to threaten Amoonguss, Iron Treads, and Tera Fairy Garganacl, while also being able to chip down special walls like Clodsire. On offense teams, Iron Valiant complements powerful wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and Kingambit, since they can overwhelm defensive cores and open up the path for Iron Valiant to sweep. Finally, Iron Valiant is highly reliant on Booster Energy to sweep, as it cannot normally outspeed common revenge-killers like Dragapult, Cinderace, and Meowscarada. Therefore, it is important to time when to switch in to Iron Valiant to ensure defensive counters like Skeledirge are either removed or heavily damaged so it can sweep or break through the opposing team effectively. Along these lines, it is important to conserve Iron Valiant's health, since it can survive key priority moves such as Extreme Speed from Tera Normal Dragonite after a Dragon Dance. Therefore, Pokemon that can remove entry hazards, such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, are great teammates for Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
With its high Attack and Special Attack, as well as blazing Speed augmented by Choice Scarf, Iron Valiant becomes an outstanding mixed revenge killer. Choice Scarf allows Iron Valiant to outspeed faster Pokemon such as Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, Dragapult, and Greninja and threaten an OHKO with Moonblast. Close Combat targets Steel-types such as Kingambit and Iron Treads. Knock Off hits Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Iron Moth for super effective damage while also crippling other Pokemon that resist both of its STAB moves such as Iron Moth and Moltres. Trick can be used to cripple walls such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Clodsire. Maximum Special Attack allows Iron Valiant's Moonblast to OHKO Great Tusk and Walking Wake. Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast, letting it secure OHKOs against Garchomp and Zamazenta. Alternatively, Tera Ghost makes it easier for Iron Valiant to revenge kill Dragonite thanks to its immunity to Extreme Speed.

Iron Valiant can be found on bulky offense teams that appreciate the speed it provides. It can take advantage of Slowking's Future Sight, as Steel- and Dark-types that resist or are immune to it are threatened by Close Combat, while Future Sight hits Iron Valiant's switch-ins such as Amoonguss and Toxapex for super effective damage. Pokemon weak to Dark-type attacks such as Skeledirge, Dragapult, and Gholdengo appreciate Iron Valiant's resistance to said attacks, particularly Sucker Punch from Kingambit, and ability to threaten said Dark-types with either one of its STAB moves. Great Tusk provides entry hazard removal, preventing Iron Valiant from getting chipped throughout the game, and complements Iron Valiant to make for a sturdy duo against Kingambit, which often times Terastallizes to deal with either one of them but has a harder time dealing with both. Corviknight in particular resists all of the attacks that Iron Valiant is weak to, while other walls such as Skeledirge and Clodsire can sponge Fairy- and Poison-type hits.

sets.name: Tera Water + Swords Dance
sets.description:
Iron Valiant makes use of its high offensive stats and Swords Dance to become a formidable physical wallbreaker that can also clean up late-game thanks to its Quark Drive-boosted Speed tier, threatening out metagame staples like Kingambit and Garganacl for setup opportunities. Liquidation is a crucial coverage move to hit most of its would-be checks such as Iron Moth, Skeledirge, and Unaware Clodsire. It is also a strong neutral attack against Gholdengo and Hatterene, as well as hitting defensive Great Tusk super effectively. Both Knock Off and Spirit Break help Iron Valiant in hitting Dragapult; Knock Off also provides great neutral coverage against Toxapex and Amoonguss, crippling them as well as other bulky foes such as Dondozo and Tera Fairy Garganacl, while Spirit Break covers Dragonite, Azumarill, and Tera Dragon Dondozo. Taunt prevents the recovery, status, Haze, and Defense-boosting attempts of defensive stalwarts such as Toxapex, Dondozo, Tera Water Skeledirge, and Tera Fairy Garganacl, letting Iron Valiant muscle past them much more easily. Tera Water is mainly used to amplify Iron Valiant's Liquidation, notably netting the OHKO on Gholdengo at +2 as well as 2HKO on Skeledirge, the latter of which would otherwise ignore Iron Valiant's Swords Dance boost with Unaware. Defensively, the Water typing helps Taunt variants beat Toxapex and Skeledirge one-on-one due to resisting their Surf and Torch Song, allows Iron Valiant to set up on Gholdengo's Make it Rain, and prevents it from being revenge killed by Scizor's Bullet Punch and Azumarill's Aqua Jet easily.

Swords Dance Iron Valiant finds a place on offense and hyper offense teams. Support from Grimmsnarl's dual screens and Orthworm's Shed Tail grants Iron Valiant more setup opportunities and prevents revenge killing attempts from Pokemon like Choice Band Dragonite and Scizor; Shed Tail in particular lets it set up on walls like Garganacl and Skeledirge, avoiding Salt Cure's periodic chip and Will-O-Wisp. Entry hazards from Glimmora, Garchomp, Meowscarada, and the aforementioned Orthworm can chip down foes like Amoonguss, Toxapex, and Dondozo, letting Iron Valiant break past them more easily, especially if complemented by Knock Off to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from them and other Pokemon like Clodsire and Tera Water Skeledirge; moreover, Garchomp helps in threatening Toxapex, while Meowscarada does the same to Dondozo. Other setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Agility Walking Wake are great teammates to keep up the offensive pressure against the opposition, especially as they appreciate Iron Valiant crippling Toxapex with Knock Off as well as luring in and beating Clodsire and Skeledirge for them. Early-game wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Gholdengo and Greninja are similarly important to punch holes in the opposition, notably pressuring foes like Amoonguss and Dondozo that Iron Valiant has trouble breaking through.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description: Mixed Iron Valiant is a wallbreaker with wide-reaching coverage for the majority of defensive pokemon; it can also revenge kill faster offensive threats thanks to Quark Drive. Thunderbolt lets it break through Toxapex and Corviknight, notably OHKOing them in Electric Terrain after minimal chip. Thunderbolt is also Iron Valiant's best method of hitting Skeledirge, 2HKOing it under Electric Terrain. Psyshock lets Iron Valiant break through Clodsire. Alternatively, Knock Off removes items from switch-ins like Skeledirge and Corviknight, but its outclassed by Psyshock on most teams. Tera Fairy powers up Iron Valiant's Moonblast while maintaining its resistance to Chien-Pao and Kingambit's Sucker Punch and Breloom's Mach Punch, as well as maintaining its immunity to Dragon-type moves. Iron Valiant is best used on offensive teams, which appreciate it taking on common walls like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Toxapex, and Corviknight, as well as it threatening offensive pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Miraidon and Koraidon, Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Great Tusk under Electric Terrain. Miraidon is a fantastic partner because it sets Electric Terrain for Iron Valiant. Additionally, Miraidon can pivot into Iron Valiant so it can threaten its checks. Cleaners such as Swords Dance Chien-Pao, Swords Dance Koraidon, Kingambit, Breloom, and Iron Bundle appreciate Iron Valiant softening up their checks early-game for them. Choice Scarf Miraidon and Koraidon, Flutter Mane under sun, and Iron Bundle outspeed and threaten out Iron Valiant, so checks to them such as Clodsire, specially defensive Corviknight, defensive Great Tusk, Skeledirge, and Toxapex are appreciated. Corviknight and Great Tusk in particular can also remove entry hazards, alllowing Iron Valiant to switch in more freely,increasing its longevity. Gothitelle also pairs well with Iron Valiant, as it traps defensive Pokemon such as Clodsire and Toxapex. This is especially important for Knock Off variants of Iron Valiant, as they cannot break through Clodsire.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description:
• Life Orb Iron Valiant is a strong wallbreaker that can threaten common walls such as Corviknight, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Skeledirge, Blissey, and Toxapex.
  • Thunderbolt is a good coverage move to hit Corviknight and Toxapex hard and is especially powerful under Electric Terrain. Psyshock is Iron Valiant's strongest option for breaking through Clodsire.
  • Knock Off lets Iron Valiant wear down potential checks by removing Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots. Shadow Ball hits most targets neutrally and Skeledirge and Scream Tail, which would otherwise wall it, super effectively. However, this option is outclassed by Knock Off and Psyshock.
  • Tera Fairy makes Iron Valiant's Moonblast immensely strong while maintaining its Dragon immunity and resistance to Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao.
  • Iron Valiant fits on offensive teams thanks to its ability to outspeed and KO common offensive foes while under Electric Terrain, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk, while pressuring walls including Ting-Lu, Corviknight, Clodsire, and Toxapex. However, Life Orb recoil and the ever-present entry hazards make it difficult for Iron Valiant to maintain pressure in longer games, and common, faster wallbreakers, such as Scarf Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Protosynthesis-boosted Flutter Mane, force Iron Valiant out.
  • Miraidon is a fantastic partner for Iron Valiant thanks to it providing Electric Terrain support and pivoting Iron Valiant in with U-turn. In return, Iron Valiant can take on Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Blissey, and Chien-Pao for Miraidon while switching into Dragon moves from opposing Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Wallbreakers like Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane appreciate Iron Valiant breaking through Corviknight and Toxapex while they take on Skeledirge for Iron Valiant.
  • Great Tusk and Skeledirge are great teammates for dealing with Koraidon, which can take on any of Iron Valiant's attacks with Tera Fire and set up sun to make it harder for Iron Valiant to revenge kill Flutter Mane.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight is a fantastic partner for soft checking Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane while removing entry hazards with Defog. Great Tusk also clears hazards, making it easier for Iron Valiant to consistently come in during a match.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance Iron Valiant functions as a decent setup sweeper for offensive teams, thanks to its good coverage and high Speed with Quark Drive and Booster Energy.
  • Knock Off annihilates Gholdengo and is Iron Valiant's best option against Skeledirge.
  • Alternatively, Shadow Sneak OHKOes Flutter Mane after a Swords Dance boost, which otherwise outspeed Iron Valiant in the sun.
  • Iron Valiant excels against teams that rely on defensive Great Tusk as their main check to physical attackers, so teammates that appreciate Great Tusk being gone, such as Koraidon, are recommended.
  • Skeledirge completely walls Iron Valiant, with Iron Valiant only being able to remove it's Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off. This is exacerbated thanks to the nature of Booster Energy only activating once.
  • As a result, special attackers such as Miraidon, Iron Moth, and Chi-Yu are recommended, with Miraidon's Electric Terrain allowing Iron Valiant to keep Booster Energy longer, while the latter two's burn immunity grants them an easy time switching in.
  • Lures to Skeledirge such as Outrage or Stomping Tantrum Koraidon are also useful.
  • Even after Booster Energy is activated, Speed-boosted Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane as well as Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon can revenge kill Iron Valiant without much issue. Due to this, Grimmsnarl is a helpful teammate, as its Reflect and Light Screen support makes revenge killing Iron Valiant more difficult.
  • Spikes support from Froslass or Glimmora is greatly appreciated, as a layer of Spikes will guarantee the OHKO on Great Tusk from +2 Tera Fairy Spirit Break, not to mention Iron Valiant's Knock Off naturally pairs well with entry hazards.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
• Booster Energy Iron Valiant is a good anti-offense Pokemon, as it outspeeds and revenge kills many hyper offense staples such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Miraidon.
  • Thunderbolt hits Toxapex and Corviknight hard, while Focus Blast is Iron Valiant's strongest STAB option against Tera Steel Pokemon like Ting-Lu which would otherwise check Iron Valiant. Focus Blast also 2HKOes Blissey after a Calm Mind boost, something that Psyshock fails to do.
  • Psyshock hits Unaware Clodsire and the rare Iron Moth for super effective damage. Shadow Ball, on the other hand, hits Skeledirge, Iron Valiant's biggest roadblock, but it doesn't offer much outside of that.
  • Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast while retaining Iron Valiant's useful defensive niche against Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Kingambit. However, Tera Electric Thunderbolt 2HKOes Toxapex and Corviknight without a boost. It also makes Iron Valiant immune to Thunder Wave and removes its weakness to Steel-type attacks.
  • Booster Energy Iron Valiant is best suited for offensive teams and, as such, should be used offensively, using its perfect coverage to break enemy walls and revenge kill threats to its team.
  • Miraidon is Iron Valiant's best teammate, as it sets Electric Terrain, letting Iron Valiant conceal its item; it also powers up Thunderbolt and can get Iron Valiant safely into the field with U-turn. Iron Valiant, in return, deals with Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Blissey for Miraidon. Other hyper offense Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and Dragonite appreciate Iron Valiant for its good matchup against other offensive teams.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Iron Valiant is a potent offensive threat that is difficult to switch into thanks to its spammable STAB attacks and high Speed under Electric Terrain.
  • Thunderbolt breaks through Corviknight and Toxapex and is further boosted by Electric Terrain. Shadow Ball pressures Skeledirge and Scream Tail, but Psyshock is an option to beat Clodsire, which would wall this set otherwise.
  • Fairy is Iron Valiant's best Tera type, as it makes its Moonblast incredibly difficult to switch into, threatening to OHKO Flutter Mane, while maintaining its Dragon immunity and resistance to Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao.
  • Iron Valiant fits on offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take on common Dark- and Dragon-types such as Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, Miraidon, and Koraidon. Iron Valiant also helps break past walls such as Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex, which are roadblocks for its teammates such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Miraidon is the best partner for Iron Valiant thanks to powering up Thunderbolt, boosting its Speed because of Quark Drive, and pivoting into Iron Valiant with U-turn. Similarly, wallbreakers such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao appreciate Iron Valiant breaking Corviknight and Toxapex, and they can take on Skeledirge for Iron Valiant in return. Finally, Skeledirge uses Corviknight as setup fodder, and Great Tusk threatens Tera Fire Koraidon for Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Fighting)
sets.description:
Iron Valiant is a special attacker with an unmatched Speed tier in a sea of physical attackers, making it a solid pick for Fighting teams. It also has a spammable Fairy STAB move in Moonblast, which allows it to ease the Dark match up by threatening Sableye while also neutering opposing Fighting-types such as Great Tusk and Breloom. Thunderbolt hits Water- and Flying-types such as Dondozo and Corviknight. Psyshock hits Poison-types such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Clodsire, whereas Future Sight can apply pressure to opponents like Toxapex for teammates such as Breloom and Gallade. Shadow Ball hits Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Aura Sphere can be used instead as a hard-hitting STAB move, while Trick is a neat option that cripples potential switch-ins such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, Clodsire, and Skuntank.

Wallbreakers such as Breloom and Gallade appreciate Iron Valiant's ability to take out physical walls as well as its ability to pressure the opponent with Future Sight. Assault Vest Iron Hands is a fantastic partner as well thanks to its ginormous HP stat that lets it deal with Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane and Hatterene that can outspeed or wall Iron Valiant. Choice Scarf users such as Flamigo, Quaquaval, and Slither Wing pressure Pokemon faster than Iron Valiant such as Greninja, Dragapult, and Cinderace. Tauros-F is another fantastic partner thanks to its ability to shatter dual screens with Raging Bull, making Iron Valiant more effective in matchups against Dark, Fairy, and Ice, all while avoiding burns thanks to its part Fire typing, which helps against Ghost and Dark teams.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Fairy)
sets.description:
Iron Valiant is a very valuable asset for Fairy teams with the combination of its amazing Speed tier, typing, and offensive stats. One of Iron Valiant's best qualities for Fairy teams is its access to Fighting-type STAB moves to counter Steel-types. Thunderbolt is a good option to hit Corviknight, Dondozo, and Toxapex super effectively and make cleaning up against Flying and Water teams easier after the Ground-type is removed. Energy Ball is a good alternative to more easily beat specially defensive Gastrodon and Rotom-W, but Grass Knot is an option to beat Dondozo after Spikes. Psyshock is a good tool versus Poison-types like Clodsire, Iron Moth and Amoonguss, while Shadow Ball lets it hit Skeledirge and Gholdengo that otherwise wall Iron Valiant. Trick is another great option to hinder defensive switch-ins like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Clodsire if Iron Valiant forgoes the moves to deal with them. Choice Scarf makes Iron Valiant an excellent revenge killer, being able to outrun threats such as Dragapult, Chien-Pao, and slower Choice Scarf users like Iron Moth and Gholdengo.

Iron Valiant has amazing coverage, which makes it an effective cleaner; however, it cannot run all of them at once. Hence, it appreciates teammates that can cover what it cannot, and it also appreciates teammates that help it switch in, as it is quite frail. Klefki can set up dual screens, which aids it in switching, and also set up Spikes, which makes it easier for Iron Valiant to clean. Klefki is also a good switch-in against opposing Fairy-types like Mimikyu. Flutter Mane and Mimikyu can weaken teams to let Iron Valiant clean up or they can clean up after it. They also deal with Ghost-types such as Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, and Skeledirge if it forgoes Shadow Ball. Azumarill checks Fire-types such as Paldean Tauros-F, Volcarona, and Iron Moth and Ground-types such as Iron Treads and Clodsire. Hatterene is a great partner, as it can break through Poison-types like Glimmora, Toxapex, and Amoonguss while also preventing entry hazards. Tinkaton can set up Stealth Rock and is a good counter to Fairy-types that check Iron Valiant otherwise such as Hatterene, Flutter Mane, and opposing Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Special Attacker (Fairy)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Iron Valiant's blistering Speed and the threat of Destiny Bond make it a cybernetic assassin that's excellent at taking foes down with it!

  • Shadow Sneak: Shadow Sneak is Iron Valiant's best tool against Flutter Mane and is useful for picking off Focus Sash foes such as Iron Bundle.

  • Encore: Encore plugs in perfectly with Destiny Bond, punishing foes that use support moves to avoid getting taken down with Iron Valiant.

  • Moonblast versus Spirit Break: Even without investment, Moonblast will often deal more damage to foes with even defenses or lower Special Defense such as Garchomp and Wo-Chien, and avoid Rocky Helmet damage. However, Spirit Break's Special Attack drops give Iron Valiant a chance to help teammates set up after it gets KOed, and it will still put Terastallized offensive Flutter Mane into Shadow Sneak's KO range.

  • Knock Off: This is Iron Valiant's only way to 2HKO offensive Gholdengo, and removing items gives it a good support niche.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Since this Iron Valiant often uses Destiny Bond, Terastallization isn't very important for it, thought the surprise value still makes it viable in certain matches.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost lets Iron Valiant safely Encore Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

  • Fighting: An extra powerful Close Combat gives Iron Valiant better late-game cleaning potential.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Getting around Iron Valiant's aluminum-thin bulk gives it the potential to take down multiple Pokemon.

  • Booster Energy: Getting a one-time Speed boost trades Iron Valiant's great early-game potential for excellent revenge killing potential.

Alternate EV Spread

  • 12 HP / 228 Atk / 84 Def / 36 SpAtk / 148 Spe with Naive: This Focus Sash EV spread gives Iron Valiant a very high chance of surviving Adamant Baxcalibur's five-hit Icicle Spear and likely OHKOing it back with Close Combat. The Special Attack investment 2HKOs maximum HP Dragonite through Multiscale while the Speed investment outspeeds up to Garchomp.

sets.name: Special Destiny Bond
sets.description:
• Iron Valiant's high Special Attack and Destiny Bond make it a highly unpredictable threat that can surprise its more physically defensive checks, such as Dondozo.

  • Encore: This will give any foe attempting to use support moves to escape Destiny Bond a nasty shock.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball 2HKOes Skeledirge and will often 2HKO defensive Gholedngo, both of whom are common issues for the physical variant of this set.

  • Shadow Sneak: While weak enough to be unable to 2HKO bulkier Flutter Mane, Shadow Sneak is still a great choice for picking off Focus Sash foes such as Great Tusk and Iron Bundle.

  • Close Combat versus Aura Sphere: Even without physical investment, Close Combat is generally the stronger move, and it ensures Blissey and Chansey will not wall Iron Valiant without Terastallization. However, Aura Sphere does hit many physically defensive foes such as Corviknight harder, and it gets around Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: This set's focus on Destiny Bond makes Terastallization a waste fairly often, but it can make sense in more late-game contexts.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Iron Valiant an opening to Encore Extreme Speed Dragonite and gives Shadow Sneak a more acceptable amount of power.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's boost to Moonblast potentially gains a 2HKO on Dondozo and Terastallized Skeledirge.

  • Steel: With Tera Steel, Iron Valiant gains a useful resistance to Bullet Punch and Ice Shard, making Booster Energy variants harder to revenge kill.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash is particularly useful for letting Iron Valiant surprise Skeledirge, who normally OHKOes with a +1 Torch Song.

  • Booster Energy: While unlikely to enable a sweep unless it's late-game, this consumable Speed boost transforms Iron Valiant into an effective revenge killer.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
• Iron Valiant's excellent special movepool gives it an effective wallbreaking mode that can catch foes such as Skeledirge and Dondozo by surprise.

  • Encore: Encore is perfect for punishing attempts to set up on Iron Valiant.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball is handy for 2HKOing Skeledirge before it Terastallizes, as it's normally a great Iron Valiant check.

  • Thunderbolt: This programs Iron Valiant to 2HKO Corviknight and physically defensive Dondozo with Life Orb.

  • Psyshock versus Psychic: Psyshock deals massive damage to Iron Moth and Clodsire, who are otherwise big problems. Psychic on the other hand, is preferred if Amoonguss is a serious problem due to being able to consistently 2HKO physically defensive vairants.

Other Options

  • Calm Mind: Calm Mind makes Iron Valiant even more difficult to wall, but it's very difficult to set up without Focus Sash or Encore.

  • Aura Sphere: Close Combat's higher power is usually preferred, but Aura Sphere does better against Corviknight and makes Iron Valiant less vulnerable to priority attacks.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Iron Valiant can do plenty of damage without Terastallization, but resisting important priority Attacks or boosting its power certainly makes it useful.

  • Ghost: With Tera Ghost, Life Orb Shadow Ball OHKOes physically defensive Skeledirge, in addition to giving Iron Valiant an important immunity to Extreme Speed.

  • Fairy: Powering up Moonblast with Tera Fairy can 2HKO even specially defensive Dondozo.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has fantastic defensive synergy, giving useful resistances to Scizor's Bullet Punch, Chien-Pao's Ice Shard, and Flying- and Fairy-type attacks.

  • Electric: Tera Electric means Iron Valiant no longer needs Life Orb to reliably 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo without Life Orb, in addition to giving a vital resistance to Scizor's Bullet Punch.

Items

  • Life Orb: While the recoil makes Iron Valiant even more vulnerable to priority attacks, it provides immense wallbreaking power.

  • Booster Energy: Taking advantage of Quark Drive trades easy wallbreaking in exchange for incredible revenge killing power and late-game sweeping.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• While tricky to set up without support, Swords Dance Iron Valiant is a niche but dangerous sweeper that requires dedicated defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Dondozo to easily check.

  • Encore: Encore lets Iron Valiant short-circuit support moves and have a shot of setting up Swords Dance, but this does come at the cost of one of its STAB moves.

  • Close Combat versus Spirit Break: If giving up a slot for Encore, Close Combat's high power against bulky foes such as Kingambit, Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and bulky Chi-Yu makes it the easy option. Spirit Break's low Base Power reduces Iron Valiant's general sweeping potential in exchange for dealing big damage to common Tera Fairy Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Garchomp.

  • Shadow Sneak versus Knock Off: With a boost, Shadow Sneak is capable of ruining Flutter Mane's attempt to revenge kill, but Knock Off lets Iron Valiant deal with Gholdengo, hit Volcarona and Iron Moth hard, and punish Skeledirge switch ins.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: While this set isn't reliant on Terastallization, it does make late-game sweeping a much more feasible task for Iron Valiant, making it less vulnerable to priority attacks that can ruin its sweeping potential.

  • Ghost: Powering up Shadow Sneak can make cleaning easier and the Extreme Speed immunity can turn Extreme Speed Dragonite into setup bait with Encore.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has excellent defensive synergy, giving Iron Valiant an important Bullet Punch and Ice Shard resistance and covering Flying- and Fairy-type attacks.

  • Fairy / Fighting: Terastallizing into one of Iron Valiant's STAB types can make cleaning through bulky foes easier if dropping coverage for Encore.

  • Fire: In addition to a useful Bullet Punch resistance, Tera Fire gifts Iron Valiant a burn immunity and can even be used with Tera Blast to break defensive Gholdengo and Corviknight.

  • Electric: Not only does this help Iron Valiant against Scizor, but Tera Electric can be paired with Life Orb and Tera Blast to wear down Dondozo.

Items

  • Focus Sash: If not using Encore, this is the most reliable way to get Swords Dance set up.

  • Booster Energy: Quark Drive's Speed boost makes it far more difficult to revenge kill Iron Valiant, outpacing key threats such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Iron Valiant more effective at hit-and-run tactics and can let it OHKO bulky threats such as Corviknight after a boost and Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Valiant leverages its strong attacks, great typing, and good Speed tier to act as a potent special attacker. Fleur Cannon, its most powerful move, threatens common defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Ting-Lu; Moonblast trades power for consistent damage. Vacuum Wave picks off frail, weakened, or faster Pokemon, allowing Iron Valiant to revenge kill Kingambit and Roaring Moon, even after setup. Psyshock pressures specially defensive Pokemon, such as Clodsire, Blissey, and specially defensive Toxapex, while Thunderbolt hits Corviknight and physically defensive Toxapex. Choice Specs Iron Valiant fits best on balance or bulky offense teams that appreciate its immense wallbreaking ability. It pairs well with strong physical attackers such as Roaring Moon and Choice Band Dragonite, as they can work together to pressure each others checks. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Great Tusk also make good partners, as they chip Iron Valiant's checks enough for it to beat them. Iron Valiant isn't very bulky, so it appreciates bulky teammates such as Ting-Lu and Garganacl; Ting-Lu can also use Parting Shot to help Iron Valiant enter the field safely. Cyclizar can clear hazards and pivot Iron Valiant in with Shed Tail.

sets.name: Physical Life Orb
sets.description: Life Orb Iron Valiant uses its powerful moves and coverage to wallbreak and threaten a large portion of the tier. Triple Arrows threatens most defensive Pokémon, such as Garganacl and Ting-Lu, with its chance to drop Defense and flinch. Zen Headbutt hits Toxapex and Clodsire, which resist Iron Valiant's STAB moves, and Iron Hands, which can be problematic for non-Magical Torque Iron Valiant. Mach Punch revenge kills offensive Pokemon such as Roaring Moon and Kingambit. Knock Off wears down Iron Valiant's checks by removing their Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots, while Magical Torque gives it another strong STAB to hit the many Dark- and Fighting-types of the tier, such as Grimmsnarl and Iron Hands, respectively. Life Orb Iron Valiant's lack of longevity makes it fit best on bulky offense teams. It pairs well with defensive pivots who can help it safely switch in, such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight, and entry hazards setters who help it wear down its checks, such as Iron Treads and Great Tusk. Other physical attackers such as Garchomp and Slither Wing make good partners, as together they can overwhelm most defensive cores.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Iron Valiant is a threatening physical attacker thanks to its great typing and offensive stats. Triple Arrows is preferred over other Fighting-type moves thanks to its Defense drop chance, flinch chance, and high critical hit rate, which can put physical walls such as Corviknight and Rotom-W under pressure. Knock Off helps Iron Valiant wear down its checks more quickly, removing key items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots from switch-ins. Mach Punch allows Iron Valiant to threaten faster Pokemon such as Roaring Moon, Meowscarada, and Cyclizar. It can also help to revenge kill boosted setup sweepers such as Sucker Punch Kingambit and, if weakened, Azumarill. Choice Band Iron Valiant fits on offensive and bulky offensive teams, as both physical and special wallbreakers appreciate the pressure it puts on the opposing team. Notable partners are Dragonite, which complements it offensively with priority and wearing down physical walls together, and Cyclizar, which helps it enter the field safely with Shed Tail. Iron Valiant's frailty and Choice lock make strong defensive teammates like Toxapex, Garganacl, and Corviknight helpful to switch into threats such as other Iron Valiant, Azumarill, and Dragonite.

sets.name: Encore + Disable
sets.description:
• Protect allows Iron Valiant to scout the moves used before using Encore and Disable as well as being able to beat Slaking.
  • Encore and Disable can be used in tandem with each other to force foes to Struggle. Generally, Iron Valiant will use Protect, Encore, Protect, Disable, and Encore in that order to ensure your opponent cannot attack. Against choice locked targets like Choice Specs Sylveon and Choice item Rotom-W, use Protect turn 1 followed by Disable.
  • Moonblast is a stronger and more free to use STAB option that hits Annihilape, Sableye, and Dragapult. Aura Sphere is weaker but allows it to hit Iron Bundle, Magnezone, and Arcanine for more damage.
  • The Defense EVs allow Iron Valiant to take more hits from Struggle, while the Speed EVs and Booster Energy allow it to outspeed Dragapult.
  • You should generally avoid possible matchups against faster Speed Booster Pokemon like Iron Bundle and Walking Wake or Choice Scarf users like Meowscarada; while they can't guarantee an OHKO, neither can Iron Valiant with Moonblast.
  • Knowing when to use Moonblast is also key information. Some Pokemon, like Dragapult, can take advantage of Iron Valiant using Protect turn 1. Against Dragapult and opposing Iron Valiant, Iron Valiant should always use Moonblast turn 1 for the best chances of winning.
  • If Iron Valiant locks the foe into a weak move or status move with Encore, do not use Disable, as you can repeat the Encore later on or go for the KO with Moonblast or Aura Sphere.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Psyshock hits Iron Moth and Clodsire.
  • Thunderbolt hits Corviknight, while Grass Knot is able to OHKO Dondozo.
  • Trick + Disable can reliably beat Weakness Policy Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and non-Mental Herb Corviknight.
  • Against Espathra, Iron Valiant should always use Moonblast for the best chance of winning. Moonblast has a favorable chance to OHKO non-specially defensive variants, which win if they use Calm Mind.
  • If running Trick + Disable, you should be cautious of Skeledirge and Bellibolt because they can beat Iron Valiant after Trick gives them Choice Specs.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Valiant is a threatening wallbreaker, punching holes in teams with its good offensive stats and wide special movepool. Iron Valiant can't fit all its desired options, but its versatility means opponents must scout it. Thunderbolt helps deal with Pokemon like Toxapex and Corviknight. Psyshock dents Clodsire,which usually hard counters Iron Valiant otherwise, while Shadow Ball helps against Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Trick can cripple Iron Valiant's switch-ins such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Corviknight. Fairy is the premier Tera type to boost its Moonblast to extreme levels, with it even denting resistant foes like Gholdengo and Victini. Electric is also a good choice, as it helps against Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor and Hurricane from Tornadus-T and Zapdos, and Thunderbolt becomes an extra STAB move. Steel works in the same vein, but it doesn't have any offensive utility, although it provides Iron Valiant a Toxic immunity and more resistances. This set appreciates pivots like Landorus-T, Tapu Koko, and Slowbro to pressure the opponent's team and bring it in. In particular, Tapu Koko also boosts Iron Valiant's Speed thanks to Electric Terrain activating Quark Drive, while Slowbro provides Future Sight support, helping Iron Valiant to push through Toxapex and Clodsire. Entry hazards from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Gastrodon help wear down Iron Valiant's checks, such as Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Toxapex. They also can switch into faster Pokemon that threaten Iron Valiant, such as Tapu Koko, Choice Scarf Rotom-W, and Choice Scarf Victini. Pursuit Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar can trap and remove Pokemon that Iron Valiant struggles to break through, like Gholdengo and Victini.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description: Iron Valiant has the stats to be a good mixed attacker. The given EV spread allows it to OHKO Blissey with Close Combat. Psyshock helps deal with Clodsire, and Thunderbolt hits Corviknight and Toxapex. Knock Off is a good option, as it helps beat Gholdengo while usefully removing items from the likes of Skeledirge, Volcarona, and Corviknight. Fairy is the best Tera type for this set, as it lets Moonblast's damage skyrocket. Steel can make up for Iron Valiant's atrocious bulk, which is even worsened by the Naive nature, and Electric also brings some defensive use while giving Thunderbolt STAB.
