Both also help Iron Valiant against Tornadus-T and Mega Scizor, as it can resist Hurricane and Bullet Punch. Iron Valiant appreciates slow pivots like Landorus-T, Slowbro, and Corviknight bringing it in safely. Entry hazard control is required to ensure Iron Valiant's survivability. Therefore, Defoggers like Corviknight and Tornadus-T, Rapid Spin users like Great Tusk, and even Magic Bounce users such as Mega Diancie are good partners.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: Calm Mind Iron Valiant is a strong wallbreaker and a potent wincon due to its offensive pressure and Speed boost from Booster Energy. It already possesses a high base Speed, meaning it outpaces every relevant Choice Scarf user besides itself. Calm Mind helps it pressure supposed checks such as Toxapex, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor, although you'll need to Terastallize Iron Valiant to beat the latter. Thunderbolt helps it hit these threats, while Psyshock allows Iron Valiant to properly beat Clodsire and the aforementioned Toxapex. Thunderbolt in combination with an Electrium Z can dent checks like Toxapex and Gholdengo once boosted. Steel is the best Tera type, as it lets Iron Valiant block poison and resist strong priority moves, such as Fake Out from Mega Lopunny and Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor. Electric is also a very strong option, as it still helps against Bullet Punch and allows Iron Valiant to bash through Skeledirge and the aforementioned Mega Scizor. Since Booster Energy only activates once, this set requires a lot of support before coming in and setting up. Therefore, it's limited to very offensive playstyles. Entry hazards from Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T are needed to weaken Iron Valiant's checks such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Mega Scizor, helping it punch through them. Pokemon that share checks with Iron Valiant are also valuable teammates, like Dragon Dance Dragonite, Weavile, and Volcarona, as together they can overwhelm common checks like Corviknight and Toxapex. Iron Valiant also appreciates dual screens from Grimmsnarl or Tapu Koko. The latter brings Electric Terrain, which can be useful for Quark Drive and Thunderbolt in extended endgame scenarios. Finally, Swords Dance Kingambit and Swords Dance Garchomp can deal with its checks like Toxapex and Clodsire.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Thanks to its high Speed and capable offensive stats, Iron Valiant is a very potent Choice Scarf user, revenge killing Dragonite and Zamazenta and cleaning up weakened teams. Close Combat and Moonblast hit a large variety of Pokemon, and Knock Off cripples foes while hitting Gholdengo and Skeledirge hard. Trick cripples checks like Toxapex and Clodsire. Tera Fairy helps Iron Valiant clean through weakened teams, and Steel allows it to reliably beat Dragonite while resisting priority moves from the likes of Mega Lopunny and Mega Scizor. Entry hazards from setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu are heavily recommended to weaken Iron Valiant's checks such as Mega Scizor, Toxapex, and Clodsire. Trappers can remove Pokemon it tends to struggle against, such as Toxapex and Gholdengo. Therefore, Heatran, Kingambit, and Weavile are good teammates. Mega Charizard Y, Heatran, and the aforementioned Kingambit can break through Iron Valiant's aforementioned checks. Finally, defensive Pokemon, such as Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, and Heatran can cover for Iron Valiant once it gets forced out after revenge killing.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fairy)
sets.description: Iron Valiant's combination of stats, typing, and coverage makes it an excellent wallbreaker for Fairy teams, capable of outrunning Mega Diancie, Nihilego, and Iron Treads. At +2 Attack, All-Out Pummeling OHKOes troublesome walls such as physically defensive Celesteela and Corviknight. Spirit Break notably breaks Mega Sableye, enabling Iron Valiant to greatly pressure Dark and Ghost teams. Knock Off deals with Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Aegislash, allowing Iron Valiant to heavily dent Steel. It also removes important items from Clodsire, Klefki, and Toxapex. Shadow Sneak can be used over Knock Off to pick off weakened foes like Blacephalon. Iron Valiant loves Klefki's ability to set dual screens and Spikes, as this allows Iron Valiant to set up more easily and deal with bulkier cores better. Tapu Lele sets Psychic Terrain, neutralizing Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, and it also deals with Poison-types Iron Valiant has a hard time with, such as Mega Venusaur and Toxapex. Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain activates Iron Valiant's Quark Drive, letting it outspeed the likes of Mega Lopunny and Mega Swampert under rain. Tapu Bulu improves the Water and Ground matchups and removes bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo. Mega Diancie and Azumarill love Iron Valiant's ability to soften walls, as it allows them to clean up late-game.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Fighting)
sets.description: Iron Valiant is one of Fighting teams' best assets with amazing qualities between its typing, Speed, and offenses. Choice Scarf accentuates its Speed further and lets it outspeed many threats to Fighting teams such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf users such as Tapu Lele and Galarian Zapdos. Its STAB Moonblast is one of its best qualities, being able to easily beat Mega Sableye and OHKO most opposing Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Buzzwole and Mega Altaria. Thunderbolt is great coverage to hit Flying- and Water-types like Tornadus-T and Toxapex that otherwise wall Iron Valiant, while Energy Ball lets it deal with Mega Swampert, which it can outspeed even under rain, Rotom-W, and Gastrodon more easily. Shadow Ball prevents Iron Valiant from being walled by Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Aegislash while also improving the Psychic matchup. Knock Off and Trick cripple defensive switch-ins such as Toxapex, Celesteela, and Clodsire by removing or replacing important items and forcing them to go without passive recovery or be Choice locked. Iron Valiant is also a great asset in the Fairy and Electric matchups, as it uses opposing Tapu Koko's Electric Surge to activate its own Quark Drive and outspeed even Regieleki and Alolan Raichu under Electric Terrain. Iron Valiant appreciates support from Mega Gallade, as it easily takes care of Poison-types like Clodsire, Mega Venusaur, and Alolan Muk. Iron Hands and Great Tusk are great teammates for the Electric matchup while also beating the likes of Toxapex, Galarian Moltres, and Gholdengo. Cobalion and Great Tusk can set up Stealth Rock and even clear entry hazards in the case of the latter. Cobalion also helps against Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu and Tapu Lele, while Great Tusk helps deal with Tapu Koko and Assault Vest Iron Hands. Choice Band Urshifu-R is a great ally to beat Fire-types such as Volcarona and Skeledirge and Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Excadrill. Kommo-o deals with bulky Water-, Fire-, and Grass-types like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Mega Venusaur with its massive Clangorus Soulblaze in conjunction with Taunt. Breloom is also a natural counter to Water-types, being able to deal with Swampert, and hindering defensive walls such as Toxapex with Spore. Galarian Zapdos is another great teammate that can weaken foes and safely get in Iron Valiant with U-turn.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf Koraidon is one of the best revenge killers in Ubers thanks to its high Attack and Speed.
  • Low Kick is usually preferred over Collision Course due to it hitting most Pokemon harder in the heavy Ubers tier.
  • Dragon Claw is a reliable Dragon-type STAB move, while Outrage usually 2HKOes Skeledirge. This can force it to use Tera Fairy, which Zacian-C can take advantage of.
  • U-turn allows Koraidon to take advantage of predictable switches to Skeledirge or Groudon and bring in dangerous wallbreakers, such as Flutter Mane, Chi-Yu, Walking Wake, or Kyogre. Be careful not to use U-turn too much when facing Rocky Helmet users like Toxapex.
  • Flare Blitz hits targets like Arceus-Fairy hard, especially when boosted by Tera Fire. Tera Fire also prevents burns from Skeledirge or Giratina-O and gives Koraidon a useful Fairy resistance.
  • Tera Steel is a good option for the myriad of resistances it brings, most notably Normal for E-Killer Arceus, Dragon for opposing Koraidon or Miraidon, and Fairy against Arceus-Fairy or Zacian-C.
  • As a revenge killer, Koraidon provides numerous advantages compared to others, such as having high Defense and Fighting-type STAB moves to take on E-Killer Arceus, and attacking physically lets it heavily damage Calm Mind Arceus formes.
  • It's nigh on impossible for this Koraidon to break past Skeledirge, Toxapex, or Dondozo reliably, so pairing Koraidon with strong wallbreakers that can take advantage of U-turn is a must.
  • Arceus-Fairy takes on Koraidon well and doesn't mind U-turn, so checks to Arceus-Fairy such as Skeledirge, Zacian-C, and Clodsire are good partners.
  • Flare Blitz recoil, Rocky Helmet damage, and entry hazards can quickly pile up damage on this Koraidon, so having a solid defensive core is recommended so you don't have to rely on Koraidon's revenge killing as much.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Choice Band Koraidon has no reliable switch-ins, thus making it one of the most powerful wallbreakers in the tier.
  • Low Kick makes for a strong STAB move with few drawbacks, as it often sports high Base Power in the Ubers tier. Close Combat is the preferred Fighting-type STAB move when running Tera Fighting, as it has a chance to 2HKO both Toxapex, which takes little from Low Kick, and most Arceus-Fairy sets outright.
  • Dragon Claw usually 2HKOes Skeledirge and is a reliable Dragon-type STAB move, so it tends to be preferred over Outrage. Outrage does sport overwhelming power and can 2HKO Toxapex and Alomomola, which Dragon Claw cannot do without entry hazard support. This is particularly notable for Tera Steel sets, which may otherwise lack enough breaking power.
  • Flare Blitz is a very strong move under the sun and becomes incredibly powerful when boosted by Tera Fire, to the point that it even 2HKOes Fire-resistant Pokemon like Skeledirge and Toxapex. Tera Fire has the additional benefit of granting a Fairy resistance and a burn immunity.
  • While not providing any boost in offensive power, Tera Steel offers several useful resistances to Fairy, Ice, and Dragon, which can help Koraidon take on Pokemon like Zacian-C, Miraidon, Arceus-Fairy, and Chien-Pao.
  • Choice Band Koraidon is an insanely powerful wallbreaker that can break past all of its normal checks and switch-ins. However, it tends to be worn down easily due to being vulnerable to all entry hazards and often taking Rocky Helmet damage and Flare Blitz recoil. Thus, it pairs best with teammates like Zacian-C, which can clean up after Koraidon has broken down the main defensive core. Koraidon's breaking power allows Zacian-C the flexibility to run coverage options outside of Tera Blast such as Crunch and Wild Charge, and Zacian-C provides the team with a revenge killer as well, making the two a particularly good pair.
  • Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy sets also work well with Choice Band Koraidon, as Arceus-Fairy can sweep much easier once Skeledirge and Toxapex are taken out of the picture.
  • Koraidon provides excellent utility for teams that are looking for a way to force out Calm Mind Arceus formes, Calm Mind Kyogre, and Calm Mind Cresselia, as its higher Speed and overwhelming physical power can easily break past the aforementioned foes.
  • Koraidon tends to be revenge killed by Zacian-C, opposing Choice Scarf Koraidon, and Choice Scarf Miraidon. As such, sporting a solid defensive core with Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex is critical for Koraidon's success.

sets.name: Life Orb Attacker
sets.description:
• Koraidon is one of, if not the strongest, wallbreakers in the tier. Life Orb gives it a crucial power boost that allows it to knock defensive staples out in a single hit after setting up a Swords Dance. Groudon, Toxapex, any Arceus forme, Landorus-T, Kyogre, and others can be knocked out in a single hit, even if they adapt fully defensive EV spreads.
  • Low Kick is a powerful STAB move that takes advantage of the heavy weight of most Pokemon in the metagame. This is better than Close Combat, as it doesn't drop Koraidon's defenses while still having 120 Base Power against crucial targets.
  • Stomping Tantrum allows Koraidon to 2HKO Toxapex and Skeledirge without power boosts. However, if the prior move failed, Stomping Tantrum will do double damage and OHKO Skeledirge. This is triggered when Skeledirge switches into Low Kick, for instance.
  • Swords Dance is one of the most important moves in Koraidon's arsenal, allowing it to get OHKOs on anything that doesn't have the Unaware ability, as long as Koraidon has the right moves for the situation.
  • Flame Charge is the key to Koraidon's sweeping abilities because of the Speed boost it provides in addition to the Fire-type coverage with no recoil. Usually, Flame Charge needs the boost from Tera Fire to fix its low Base Power and allow Koraidon to pick up KOs on healthier targets.
  • Flare Blitz is a more powerful alternative to Flame Charge, which makes Koraidon significantly less reliant on Terastallization to score KOs on the opponent's defensive Pokemon like Arceus-Fairy after Swords Dance. This can open up opportunities for its fellow sweeping teammates.
  • Dragon Claw fixes Koraidon's issues with Rayquaza and Giratina; however, it does make Koraidon much less threatening against Skeledirge and Toxapex, as it can no longer 2HKO either.
  • Life Orb is the key to Koraidon's functioning. Life Orb is absolutely necessary, as the power boost and recoil differentiate how this Koraidon is used compared to its other sets.
  • Tera Fire is necessary, as it gives Koraidon an immunity to Will-O-Wisp, resistances to Fairy and Steel, and a huge power boost to Koraidon's Fire-type attacks. This is especially efficient with Flame Charge and is often key to enabling Koraidon to sweep.
  • Life Orb Koraidon fits well on any remotely offensively-minded team because it has the ability to lure in defensive Pokemon and beat them due to its unexpected Life Orb-boosted power. This can be used to open up teammates like Swords Dance, Dragon Dance, or offensive Calm Mind Arceus formes, Zacian-C, and Double Dance Miraidon.

sets.name: Swords Dance + 3 Attacks
sets.description:
• Low Kick is Koraidon’s best attack, having 120 Base Power against many relevant threats like Arceus, Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Kyogre. However, Collision Course can be used for universal damage, as well as threatening Ting-Lu and Extreme Killer Arceus harder.
  • Tera Fire gives Koraidon resistances to Fairy and Steel, letting it handle Zacian-C and Arceus-Fairy. It also boosts Flame Charge‘s power to the point it is able to OHKO Zacian-C without a boost. However, it makes Koraidon weak to common attacks like Arceus-Ground’s Earthquake, Arceus-Fairy’s Earth Power, and Kyogre’s Surf or Origin Pulse. Stealth Rock also cuts into Koraidon a lot more as Tera Fire makes Koraidon weak to it.
  • Swords Dance Koraidon is a sweeper best used mid- or late-game on offensive teams, when its checks and counters have been worn down enough for Koraidon to break through them.
  • The abundance of Pokemon that can effectively Terastallize into the Fairy typing, like Miraidon and Eternatus, hurts Koraidon, as it is not strong enough to break these Pokemon with just Flame Charge. Baiting out Terastallization earlier in the game massively helps out Koraidon, as that ensures it can no longer be revenge killed by a defensive Tera Fairy when going for a sweep.
  • Kyogre setting up rain hurts Koraidon, as rain removes Koraidon’s Orichalcum Pulse boost and weakens Flame Charge, making it much easier to play around. However, Kyogre has no reliable recovery, so it can be chipped to the point where it can no longer compete with Koraidon’s sun.
  • Physical walls like Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Dondozo are by far Koraidon’s best counters, so Koraidon appreciates teammates that can threaten them, like Miraidon, Kyogre, and Flutter Mane. Flutter Mane in particular loves Koraidon’s sun activating Protosynthesis for it.
  • Physical attackers like Zacian-C, Arceus-Ground, and Groudon can all threaten damage on defensive Landorus-T, Groudon, and Arceus-Fairy, which can comfortably take on Koraidon at high HP but can easily get overwhelmed by both these physically offensive Pokemon and Koraidon.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Flame Charge gives Koraidon solid sweeping potential by allowing it to outrun most Choice Scarf users. Swords Dance provides maximum damage potential, allowing Koraidon to reliably break past most walls. Low Kick hits Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl hard and without any drawbacks; alternatively, Drain Punch is a weaker option that boosts Koraidon's resiliency. Wild Charge deals with Pelipper and Toxapex, which otherwise wall Koraidon. Stomping Tantrum may be run to overwhelm Skeledirge instead, while also denting Toxapex after a boost. Outrage overwhelms all of these checks in one slot, but it also makes Koraidon susceptiple to revenge killers such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane. Tera Fire boosts Flame Charge and lets Koraidon resist Ice- and Fairy-type moves from Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane while also making it immune to Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge. Tera Steel can be run with Iron Head, providing key resistances to Ice, Fairy, and Dragon. Special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Walking Wake, and Chi-Yu appreciate Koraidon setting up sun. In return, they pressure Koraidon's checks in Skeledirge, Pelipper, and Great Tusk. Koraidon's ability to pressure special walls such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire is appreciated by Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Miraidon, and Gholdengo. This set fits well on hyper offense teams, so support from entry hazard setters like Glimmora, Masquerain, and Froslass as well as dual screens support from Grimmsnarl is appreciated. Miraidon and Chien-Pao are good teammates, as they can pressure Toxapex and Skeledirge, respectively. Great Tusk is a great teammate, as it can take advantage of Koraidon's sun and break through Toxapex and Skeledirge while also pressuring Pelipper with Knock Off.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Koraidon is an excellent revenge killer, taking out non-Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon, Iron Bundle outside of Electric Terrain, and Chi-Yu with ease. U-turn lets Koraidon generate momentum for its team thanks to the many switches it forces. Close Combat is Koraidon's strongest Fighting-type STAB move, but Collision Course avoids dropping defenses. Dragon Claw is a secondary STAB option that OHKOes opposing Koraidon and Miraidon, but Wild Charge hits Water-types such as Pelipper and Toxapex. Flare Blitz allows Koraidon to threaten Corviknight, Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, and Tera Fairy Miraidon. Tera Fire further boosts Flare Blitz while also thwarting Will-O-Wisp attempts from Skeledirge and letting Koraidon resist the common Fairy- and Ice-type moves aimed at it. Wallbreakers such as Chi-Yu, Great Tusk, Choice Band Chien-Pao, Choice Specs Walking Wake, and Miraidon make excellent partners for Koraidon, as it can bring them in safely with U-turn. Chi-Yu, Walking Wake, and Great Tusk especially enjoy Koraidon being able to set up sun for them, which boosts the former's Fire-type attacks and activates the latter two's Protosynthesis. Koraidon also appreciates having hazard removal options in Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Corviknight to avoid being too quickly worn down by the combination of entry hazards damage, Flare Blitz recoil, and Rocky Helmet damage from common Koraidon checks. In addition, defensive counterplay in the form of bulky Pokemon such as Corviknight, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, Toxapex, or Clodsire is required to handle Pokemon that Koraidon cannot outspeed and reliably revenge kill, such as Flame Charge Koraidon, Iron Bundle under Electric Terrain, Agility Miraidon, Ice Shard Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: Great Attack and Speed stats along with a solid moveset make Koraidon an incredible wallbreaker. Close Combat hits Steel- and Dark-types such as Iron Treads and Ting-Lu. Flare Blitz OHKOes Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Gholdengo and allows Koraidon to deal with Scream Tail better. Flare Blitz also breaks through Toxapex, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge if they have Terastallized into the Fairy type. Stomping Tantrum 2HKOes Skeledirge and Toxapex. Additionally, Skeledirge switching into Close Combat on the previous turn doubles Stomping Tantrum's power, allowing Koraidon to OHKO Skeledirge. Wild Charge OHKOes Pelipper and 2HKOes Toxapex. Alternatively, Outrage is a good all-around Dragon-type STAB option that still hits Pelipper and Alomomola but makes it vulnerable to Tera Fairy from checks such as Pelipper and Toxapex as well as revenge killers such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle. Tera Fire boosts Flare Blitz, lets Koraidon ward off Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge, and lets it resist Ice- and Fairy-type moves from Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, Double Dance Miraidon, and Flutter Mane. Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads are good teammates, as Koraidon can easily get worn down due to Life Orb and Flare Blitz recoil as well as Rocky Helmet chip from Alomomola and Toxapex. Corviknight can also switch into Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane, which can KO Koraidon after minimal chip. Offensive Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Walking Wake, and Chi-Yu take full advantage of Koraidon's ability to set up sun. Miraidon pressures Koraidon's checks like Great Tusk and Skeledirge well and appreciates Koraidon's ability to pressure its checks like Iron Treads and Ting-Lu as well.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Koraidon is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its strong STAB moves and massive firepower. U-turn is a safe midground that lets Koraidon generate momentum for its team while gradually whittling down checks like Skeledirge, Scream Tail, and Great Tusk. Heavy Slam can be used over Flare Blitz to hit Dachsbun and Scream Tail at the cost of making Koraidon even more dependent on predictions to break through Corviknight. Tera Fire is Koraidon's Tera type of choice because it boosts Flare Blitz's damage output and grants a resistance to Ice- and Fairy-type moves from Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle, Miraidon, and Flutter Mane. Choice Band Koraidon fits best on balance teams that appreciate its massive firepower and can give it the support it needs to excel. Notable offensive teammates include Chi-Yu, Great Tusk, and Miraidon which all appreciate it setting sun and can pressure its few checks in Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Great Tusk. Koraidon is extremely prediction-reliant and susceptible to revenge killing from Pokemon like Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, Miraidon, and Choice Scarf Koraidon, so it needs a solid defensive core to support it with balance staples like Corviknight, Toxapex, Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Miraidon is perhaps the best wallbreaker in Ubers, with the extra power allowing Draco Meteor to 2HKO Clodsire and Arceus-Ground.
  • U-turn is useful to gain momentum on predictable switches as well as not revealing Miraidon's item. Volt Switch does the same thing with much more power but requires that the opposing team's Ground-types be eliminated first.
  • Overheat annihilates Iron Treads, and since immunities to both of Miraidon's STAB attacks are common, it can ease prediction against players attempting to cycle between Ground- and Fairy-types.
  • Tera Dragon allows Miraidon to 2HKO Ting-Lu, one of the only Pokemon capable of taking two consecutive Choice Specs Draco Meteors.
  • Tera Electric lets Miraidon break nearly any Pokemon without an Electric immunity in the game, even 2HKOing Blissey outright. Tera Electric is also useful to overpower Calm Mind Arceus formes without the Special Attack drop from Draco Meteor.
  • Since Choice Specs Miraidon has no reliable check in the metagame, it works excellently as a wallbreaker for the vast majority of teams.
  • Its ability to break or greatly weaken Ting-Lu is a boon for teammates like Calm Mind Arceus-Ghost, Arceus-Poison, Arceus-Ground, and Arceus-Dark and is helpful to prevent Ting-Lu from laying Spikes at all.
  • Miraidon can lure in and KO Clodsire, so Pokemon that appreciate Clodsire taken out make good partners such as Eternatus, Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy, and Kyogre.
  • Physically offensive teammates like Zacian-C can make for good partners, as Miraidon can come in on many of their checks such as Skeledirge and Toxapex with little worry.
  • Since Miraidon can quickly overwhelm Ting-Lu and Clodsire, it's important to anticipate Tera Steel or Tera Fairy from them and react accordingly.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Life Orb Miraidon is one of the fiercest wallbreakers in the Ubers tier, having a 50% chance to OHKO Ting-Lu outright with a Calm Mind and Tera Dragon-boosted Draco Meteor.
  • Parabolic Charge OHKOes Zacian-C at +1 and provides Miraidon with a source of healing to counteract Life Orb, Substitute, and entry hazard damage. This also usually lets Miraidon win against Blissey without Tera Ground. Electro Drift's higher damage output allows Miraidon to OHKO bulky Arceus-Fairy sets and OHKO Zacian-C from behind a Substitute.
  • The fourth slot is flexible. Substitute eases prediction and can take advantage of passive walls and foes that attempt to pivot around Miraidon. Overheat nails Iron Treads and can also hit Ting-Lu or Clodsire, which often use Tera Steel on Miraidon's Draco Meteor, and it can also be used as a neutral hit to prevent switching between Ground- and Fairy-types to stall out Electric Terrain turns. Taunt can help prevent setup from Pokemon that could take advantage of Miraidon after a Draco Meteor stat drop such as Calm Mind Arceus formes and Ting-Lu or Clodsire using Spikes.
  • If the opponent has not already Terastallized, care should be taken when facing Ting-Lu and Clodsire, as their Tera Steel or Tera Fairy can turn the tide against Miraidon quickly. While this leaves both foes open to being chipped down, Miraidon can in turn be hit by Whirlwind, Toxic, or damaged heavily outright by Earthquake and Ruination. If Miraidon wins the exchange, it's often left at low HP and open to being revenge killed.
  • This set works excellently on Sticky Web teams in particular, as it greatly appreciates being able to outspeed Zacian-C and Choice Scarf Pokemon like Eternatus. At the same time, it also works excellently for bulky offense and balance teams that are seeking a solid way to break opposing balance and stall teams.
  • Spikes support can be crucial for this set, as the chip damage can guarantee the OHKO on opposing Ting-Lu; Ting-Lu, Groudon, or Clodsire can set up Spikes for Miraidon.
  • Arceus formes such as Arceus-Ghost, Arceus-Ground, and Arceus-Dark make for good offensive partners, as all of them like Ting-Lu being taken out of the picture.
  • Zacian-C is a huge annoyance thanks to its higher Speed and Dragon-type immunity; as such, solid checks to it such as Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex are much appreciated. Lures for Zacian-C such as Thunder Wave Arceus-Fairy or Arceus-Grass can cripple Zacian-C and leave it as an easy target for Miraidon later in the game.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf makes Miraidon an effective revenge killer, late-game sweeper, and pivot, taking advantage of its great Speed, naturally amazing offenses, and access to U-turn. Its most important application is being able to outspeed Koraidon, Flutter Mane, opposing Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Speed-boosted Arceus.
  • Electro Drift allows Miraidon to hit a lot of Pokemon for neutral damage, most notably Zacian-C and Arceus-Fairy, which are immune to Draco Meteor.
  • Draco Meteor is a strong STAB move that allows Miraidon to deal with slower Dragon-types as well as hit a lot of Pokemon for neutral damage, most notably Ground-types.
  • Overheat can OHKO Zacian-C, hit foes trying to pivot between Ground- and Fairy-types, and damage neutral targets in sun, which makes it is as strong as Draco Meteor.
  • U-turn helps Miraidon pivot out of the Ground-type Pokemon that are used to check it.
  • Dragon Pulse can be used instead of Overheat to increase consistency and prevent the opponent from exploiting the drawbacks of Draco Meteor.
  • Volt Switch can be used instead of Electro Drift to keep up the momentum after attacking.
  • Tera Electric allows Miraidon to power up its Electro Drift and make itself less exploitable, OHKOing Zacian-C and dealing massive damage to most Arceus formes. This is an especially devastating end-game cleanup tool after the opposing Ground-types have been removed.
  • Tera Steel gives Miraidon a Normal- and Dragon-type, resistance which allows it to take a hit from Pokemon like Extreme Killer Arceus and opposing Miraidon. Tera Steel also gives it resistances to both of Zacian-C's STAB moves.
  • Tera Dragon powers up its Dragon-type attacks, which allows Miraidon to break through Ting-Lu and Clodsire and pick up KOs from higher ranges of health on other neutral targets like Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground.
  • This set fits best on balance teams where it can help ease off the pressure from its defensively oriented teammates like Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu by outrunning and forcing your opponent's offensive Pokemon to switch out.
  • Miraidon can also help teammates like Zacian-C, Koraidon, Kyogre, and Chien-Pao with U-turn, which would allow them to get into favorable positions such as against Ting-Lu and potentially force your opponent into having to switch again.
  • Some teammates that can lure in and weaken Ting-Lu are Eternatus and Toxapex, which can use Toxic and Toxic Spikes, your own Ting-Lu with Ruination, and Giratina-O, which can status and phaze the opposing team with Dragon Tail. This greatly helps Miraidon because Ting-Lu is Miraidon's most common check.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Miraidon is a powerful pivot, being able to comfortably 2HKO most Pokemon in the tier with Electro Drift. Draco Meteor allows it to wear down any reliable Electro Drift switch-in, and U-turn enables Miraidon to bring in its teammates with ease.
  • Taunt can stop opposing Arceus formes and Clodsire from clicking Recover and Ting-Lu and Groudon from setting up hazards. It can also stop setup from the likes of Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy, Calm Mind or Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground, and Dragon Dance Arceus.
  • Miraidon is required to run 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature or it runs the risk of underspeeding Eternatus, Arceus, and Arceus-Ground.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Miraidon from taking unnecessary chip damage from hazards, which are set most of the time due to the lack of reliable hazard removal in the tier. This gives pivot Miraidon more longevity compared to boosting items and allows it to bring in its teammates for longer.
  • Tera Dragon and Tera Electric give Miraidon's STAB moves a power boost, allowing it to 2HKO Ting-Lu with Draco Meteor and to 2HKO specially defensive Arceus-Fairy with Electro Drift, respectively.
  • Miraidon is best used alongside setup threats such as the aforementioned Arceus formes, Swords Dance Koraidon, and Swords Dance Zacian-C to deny opposing walls entry hazards and recoveryand chip them with its powerful Electric- and Dragon-type STAB moves.
  • It can struggle to deal with Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and bulky Arceus formes due to lacking power compared to Choice Specs sets, so it appreciates teammates such as Koraidon, Zacian-C and Flutter Mane that can reliably come in on them after it uses U-turn.
  • Pivot Miraidon can form a strong momentum core with other pivots such as Landorus-T and Koraidon to provide chip damage for other teammates to clean.
  • Teams with it do require some form of alternative speed control such as Zacian-C, Choice Scarf Koraidon, and Flutter Mane, as Miraidon is unable to outpace other threats itself.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description: Agility makes Miraidon a lethal late-game sweeper, taking advantage of its natural good Speed to outspeed every Pokemon on the metagame at +2 without major Speed investment, allowing for more bulk investment to live hits it normally wouldn't be able to. Roseli Berry helps Miraidon take a Play Rough from Zacian-C or Judgement from Arceus-Fairy, allowing it to set up against them more easily. Electric Seed provides a +1 Defense boost, allowing it to have easier setup opportunities against physical attackers. Parabolic Charge allows Miraidon to recover health while also doing consistent damage. On the other hand, Electro Drift is a stronger move that OHKOes Zacian after one layer of Spikes. Dragon Pulse can be used with Tera Dragon, while Dazzling Gleam is used exclusively on Tera Fairy Tera Fairy is an amazing defensive typing that turns its weaknesses into neutralities and grants it a Dragon-type immunity, letting it 2HKO Ting-Lu after one layer of Spikes and OHKO opposing Miraidon and Koraidon with STAB Dazzling Gleam. However, this set is completely walled by Clodsire. Tera Dragon powers up Dragon Pulse, which allows Miraidon to 2HKO Ting-Lu and Clodsire with a 2 HKO at +1 after Spikes damage and pick up KOs from higher ranges of health on other neutral targets like Arceus-Ground. This set should be considered on either balance offense teams as a cleaner or hyper offense sweeper that can break open the opposing team. Partners in hyper Offense teams such as dual screens Grimmsnarl allow it to easily set up and sweep. On the other hand, leads such as Meowscarada and Froslass can aid Miraidon's sweep by setting up Spikes to weaken opposing Pokemon into range of Miraidon's attacks. Miraidon benefits from partners that can allow it to break its checks much more easily such as Arceus-Fairy, Arceus-Ground, Kyogre. and Koraidon. It also benefits from other teammates such as Eternatus that weaken their shared checks such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire for it.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Miraidon is an extremely threatening wallbreaker due to its great stats along with its good movepool. Draco Meteor + Electro Drift make a great STAB combination, allowing Miraidon to hit almost every Pokemon in the metagame at least neutrally. Overheat is a great coverage move that lets Miraidon KO Iron Treads, which otherwise walls Miraidon pretty easily. Parabolic Charge is an alternative to Electro Drift on sets with Substitute in order to recover health while also making Miraidon a good late-game cleaner. Tera Dragon lets Miraidon OHKO Ting-Lu and Clodsire using Draco Meteor after a single Calm Mind boost. Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads are great teammates, as Miraidon can wear down quickly due to Life Orb recoil and hazards; those teammates can also soak up offensive pressure from Pokemon such as Iron Bundle, Koraidon, and Flutter Mane, respectively. Corviknight can also pivot Miraidon in, giving it a great opportunity to set up. Physical attackers such as Great Tusk, Koraidon, and Chien-Pao are good teammates, as they can easily force out special walls such as Blissey, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu, making it easier for Miraidon to sweep.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Miraidon can break through all of its checks owing to its excellent stats and stellar movepool, making it the strongest wallbreaker in Anything Goes. Overheat hits Iron Treads and also eases predictions against defensive cores such as Corviknight + Great Tusk. Tera Dragon boosts Draco Meteor, notably allowing Miraidon to 2HKO Ting-Lu while also getting rid of its weakness to Dugtrio. A Timid nature allows Miraidon to Speed tie against Koraidon and Chien-Pao, but Modest may be used to further boost its strength. Miraidon is threatened by revenge killers like Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf users like Koraidon, Miraidon, and Great Tusk, so special walls like Clodsire and Blissey and physical walls like Toxapex, Great Tusk, and Alomomola are used to soak the offensive pressure. Dugtrio can trap Iron Bundle, Clodsire, and Iron Treads, as well as opposing Miraidon and Koraidon locked into Dragon-type moves with Tera Fairy.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Miraidon is a powerful cleaner and revenge killer, forcing out many of the tier's most powerful wallbreakers such as Choice Band Koraidon, Choice Specs Miraidon, and Great Tusk while threatening to sweep late-game after its checks have been removed. Overheat is a nice midground option that lets Miraidon take out Corviknight and Iron Treads while threatening Ground-types without risking being locked into a move that has immunities. U-turn takes advantage of Miraidon's ability to threaten most of the metagame to generate momentum for its teammates. Miraidon's preferred Tera type is Fairy, which allows it to force a 50/50 against opposing Choice Scarf Miraidon and Koraidon. Tera Fairy also removes Miraidon's Ice-weakness, allowing it to survive hits from Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao. Alternatively, Tera Dragon can be used to substantially increase the damage done by Draco Meteor, allowing Miraidon to heavily damage Ting-Lu and more effectively break Clodsire. Tera Electric is a third option, maximizing the power of Electro Drift once opposing Ground-types have been removed. Choice Scarf Miraidon fits well on many balance teams that appreciate the revenge killing that it offers. It pairs especially well with Pokemon that can wear down its Ground-type checks, notably Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, and other Miraidon. Defensively, balance staples like Clodsire, Corviknight, Iron Treads, Ting-Lu, and Toxapex are greatly appreciated, as they can deal with Pokemon like opposing Miraidon, Great Tusk, Koraidon, and Chien-Pao that can potentially come in for free after Miraidon has picked up a KO. Gothitelle is also an especially good partner thanks to its ability to trap and remove many of Miraidon's most effective checks, notably beating Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Blissey, clearing the way for it to sweep late-game. Similarly, Dugtrio is also a decent partner, as it can trap and eliminate opposing Choice Scarf Miraidon and Koraidon that have locked into Dragon Moves and Choice Band Chien-Pao that hasn't locked into Ice Shard while also beating Blissey, Clodsire, and chipped Iron Treads.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description: Double Dance Miraidon is one of the most potent sweepers and wincons in the AG metagame. It outspeeds the entire metagame after using Agility, and can muscle through defensive Pokemon after a boost or two from Calm Mind. Parabolic Charge greatly improves Miraidon's longevity, and Electric Terrain makes up for its low Base Power, notably letting Miraidon outheal Blissey's Seismic Toss after two Calm Mind boosts. Dazzling Gleam hits Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and opposing Dragon-types for super effective damage. Tera Fairy enables setup on the Ice-, Ground-, and Dragon-type attacks that would otherwise threaten it, boosts the power of Dazzling Gleam, and limits revenge killing attempts from Koraidon, Miraidon, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle. The given EV spread allows Miraidon to outspeed Quark Drive-boosted Iron Bundle after an Agility and maximizes Leftovers recovery; the rest is put into Special Attack and Defense. Gothitelle and Dugtrio are phenomenal partners for their ability to trap Clodsire and Iron Treads, removing defensive counterplay to Miraidon. Chien-Pao and Great Tusk are able to bait in physically defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Alomomola for Miraidon to set up on and greatly threaten Clodsire and Iron Treads. With dual screens support from Grimmsnarl, Miraidon is able to set up on more Pokemon, and revenge killing it becomes even more difficult. Toxic Spikes is a major hindrance, so Poison-types like Toxapex and Clodsire, or hazard removal from Iron Treads or Corviknight is greatly appreciated.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Miraidon is a great offensive pivot that is able to force plenty of switches due to its high Speed and incredible firepower. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Miraidon to continuously threaten the opposing team without accruing entry hazard damage. U-turn scouts for potential switches and generates momentum for teammates and is chosen over Volt Switch for the ability to pivot out against Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Overheat hits Iron Treads for super effective damage and alleviates predictions against teams with both Ground-types and Dragon-resistant foes, notably being a safe midground option against Corviknight and chipped Great Tusk. Tera Dragon maximizes Draco Meteor damage and increases the chances of breaking through Clodsire and Ting-Lu while also allowing Miraidon to beat Dugtrio that attempt to trap it. Trapping support from Gothitelle and Dugtrio is greatly appreciated, allowing Miraidon to bypass its limited pool of checks with ease. Koraidon, Great Tusk, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle are all great partners for their ability to threaten Miraidon's checks and provide opportunities for wallbreaking by forcing in Pokemon like Corviknight and Toxapex. In return, they benefit greatly from Miraidon's ability to generate momentum and bring them in safely to threaten its own checks. A strong defensive backbone is helpful to make the most of the longevity provided by Heavy-Duty Boots, so defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Clodsire are potent teammates that also check revenge killers like Choice Scarf Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao. Fellow pivots like Iron Bundle, Koraidon, and Corviknight create potent VoltTurn cores with Miraidon that can wear down the opponent and give Miraidon the most opportunities. Entry hazard support from Ting-Lu or Clodsire allows Miraidon to wear down and outlast its checks, especially in tandem with VoltTurn support, so Gholdengo and Annihilape are valuable partners for their ability to deter Defog and Rapid Spin.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Miraidon is an excellent support Pokemon due to its favorable typing and high Speed, crucially outspeeding threats like Mega Mewtwo X and Kartana to neutralize them with Strength Sap. Thunder Cage provides a consistent, high PP STAB move that is effective at wearing down checks such Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy. Passive damaging moves synergize well with Thunder Cage; Mortal Spin provides entry hazard removal in a pinch and is effective against Imposter users, while Leech Seed and Salt Cure are alternate options that also prevent Imposter users from removing the partial trapping of Thunder Cage. Calm Mind allows Miraidon to act as a bulky setup sweeper, with Lava Plume pressuring checks like Mega Steelix and Ferrothorn, while Judgment hits Dragon-types like opposing Miraidon; however, Calm Mind should never be used with Salt Cure. Steel-types synergize well defensively with Miraidon by switching into threatening wallbreakers like Mega Diancie and Kyurem-B and can also block Imposter users' Mortal Spin. Ho-Oh checks Mega Diancie, provides a Ground-immunity, and appreciates Miraidon as an Imposter-proofer. Other strong physical wallbreakers like Kartana and Mega Blaziken can also be Imposter-proofed by Miraidon.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Choice Specs Walking Wake is a powerful wallbreaker thanks to its great Special Attack and Speed alongside an excellent typing complemented by decent bulk, fantastic STAB moves, and good coverage. Hydro Steam is Walking Wake's excellent signature move; in addition to having zero drawbacks its power is increased with sun active, making safely switching into Walking Wake a difficult task. Flamethrower hits Grass-types like Amoonguss, and Steel-types like Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Corviknight for super effective damage. Draco Meteor is Walking Wake's strongest attack and eliminates Dragapult, Dragonite, opposing Walking Wake, and Roaring Moon while dealing high damage to Water-types like Toxapex and muscling past Unaware walls like Skeledirge and Dondozo. Dragon Pulse is a weaker but safer move that still hits opposing Dragon-types hard and lacks drawbacks, which makes it more useful late-game when Draco Meteor's higher damage output is no longer needed to secure KOs. Tera Water removes Walking Wake's Fairy weakness while increasing Hydro Steam's damage output to nuclear levels, allowing it to outright 2HKO moderately bulky Water-resistant Pokemon like Rotom-W. Tera Dragon turns Walking Wake's Grass neutrality into a resistance while allowing it to 2HKO Clodsire and Slowking, allowing Walking Wake to blow past its checks and more reliably sweep late-game. 244 Special Attack EVs put Walking Wake's Special Attack exactly one point lower than its Speed, causing Protosynthesis to increase Speed and drastically improve Walking Wake's matchup against otherwise-faster threats like Meowscarada, Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Roaring Moon; however, 252 Special Attack EVs to allow a Special Attack boost from Protosynthesis is still perfectly viable to further capitalize on Walking Wake's wallbreaking prowess, albeit at the cost of now losing the one-on-one matchup against the aforementioned faster threats. Even Assault Vest Azumarill, which otherwise checks Walking Wake, has a chance of being 2HKOed by a sun-boosted Tera Water Hydro Steam with a Special Attack boost.

Though its offensive presence is useful in general, Walking Wake's unique attributes make it most powerful on and against sun teams. Torkoal is an excellent partner for Walking Wake, as its ability to set sun with Drought maximizes its damage output with Hydro Steam and Flamethrower and enables its Protosynthesis to boost its Speed or Special Attack. Torkoal can also set Stealth Rock to allow Walking Wake to more reliably 2HKO threats like Clodsire and Toxapex and remove opposing Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin, and it appreciates Walking Wake’s ability to break past opposing weather setters like Tyranitar and Pelipper with ease. Specially defensive walls like Slowking and Water Absorb Clodsire give Walking Wake a lot of trouble, since they can sponge its attacks. Powerful physical attackers like offensive Great Tusk and Choice Band Roaring Moon are excellent teammates due to their ability to muscle past these threats; in return, Walking Wake breaks past their own defensive checks such as Ting-Lu, Dondozo, and Corviknight. Moreover, both of these teammates can also utilize Protosynthesis effectively. Assault Vest Azumarill resists both Hydro Steam and Flamethrower, is immune to Walking Wake's Dragon-type attacks, and threatens to OHKO it with Play Rough, though it can be worn down over time due to its lack of recovery. Offensive Grass-types like Meowscarada and Breloom cannot switch into Azumarill, but they can greatly threaten it with their super effective STAB moves. Eject Button Amoonguss is another excellent teammate, as it checks Azumarill both offensively and defensively and can safely pivot Walking Wake in. In return, Walking Wake can handle bulky Steel-types like Kingambit and Corviknight for Meowscarada and Gholdengo for Breloom and Amoonguss.

sets.name: Agility
sets.description:
With Agility, Walking Wake becomes a terrifying sweeper on offense teams. After a single boost, not only can it outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, but also boosted Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Iron Moth, and Roaring Moon. Its STAB combination threatens metagame staples like Great Tusk, Dragapult, Roaring Moon, and Garganacl. Hydro Steam is preferred over Surf if Walking Wake is used on sun teams. Substitute is an option to protect Walking Wake from revenge killing attempts like Kingambit's Sucker Punch and status moves like Amoonguss's Spore. With Flamethrower as coverage, it can also threaten the likes of Gholdengo, Amoonguss, and Corviknight harder. Tera Water makes Surf and Hydro Steam a nuke, especially on the respective weather teams. Tera Dragon boosts Dragon Pulse, allowing Walking Wake to 2HKO specially defensive Rotom-W. Tera Fairy turns Walking Wake's Dragon weakness into an immunity, improving its matchup against various Dragon-types like Choice Band Roaring Moon and Dragapult, and gives it a resistance to Kingambit's Sucker Punch and Breloom's Mach Punch.

Walking Wake best functions on hyper offense, sun, and rain teams. In order to sweep more efficiently, it appreciates entry hazards from Greninja, Meowscarada, and Glimmora. In return, Walking Wake can threaten common hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight. On weather teams, Torkoal and Pelipper make for necessary teammates, as they can set up sun and rain to boost its Hydro Steam. Sun from Torkoal in particular allows Walking Wake to activate Protosynthesis multiple times and boost its Flamethrower. Walking Wake gets forced out by specially defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Water Absorb Clodsire, and Toxapex; hence, wallbreakers that can wear them down such as Breloom, Meowscarada, and Choice Specs Dragapult are appreciated. Great Tusk is another good teammate, as it can remove entry hazards for Walking Wake to switch in without getting worn down. In return, Walking Wake can threaten spinblockers like Gholdengo and Hisuian Zoroark after an Agility. Lastly, Walking Wake pairs well with other sweepers like Iron Moth and Kingambit, as they can pressure each other's checks; Walking Wake can deal with Great Tusk for Kingambit and Garganacl and Ting-Lu for Iron Moth. In return, Kingambit can threaten Toxapex, while Iron Moth can threaten Hatterene.

sets.name: Substitute
sets.description:
Walking Wake finds a lot of opportunities to set up a Substitute against defensive Pokemon that don't threaten to break it like Dondozo, Slowking, and non-Assault Vest Toxapex as well as on switches that it forces by threatening meta staples like Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Hydreigon. Substitute relieves the need for prediction, protects Walking Wake from revenge killing attempts, and allows it to avoid residual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure. Hydro Steam's power boost in sun makes it desirable both on and against sun teams. If this attribute is not sought after, then Hydro Pump can be run instead. Roar prevents Pokemon like Terastallized Garganacl as well as Belly Drum Azumarill from setting up on Walking Wake. It is also a good way for Walking Wake to make progress via residual entry hazard damage even when the opposition has a counter like Water Absorb Clodsire, Assault Vest Toxapex, or specially defensive Dondozo. However, Flamethrower can be used instead to round out Walking Wake's coverage, doing more damage to Pokemon like Kingambit, Amoonguss, and Corviknight. Flamethrower also gains a boost in power from sun, which alongside the Protosynthesis boost can allow Flamethrower to OHKO the aforementioned targets. Tera Water increases the damage output of its Water-type STAB move, potentially 2HKOing Pokemon like Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Corviknight. Tera Dragon powers up Dragon Pulse, allowing it to OHKO Garchomp and Hydreigon. Finally, Tera Fairy removes Walking Wake's original weaknesses, allowing for surprise KOs on Dragon-types like opposing Walking Wake and especially Dragapult—a thorn in Walking Wake's side because of Infilitrator nullifying Substitute—as well as others like Kingambit and Iron Valiant.

Walking Wake is a sun team staple, so of course it is often paired with other sun team staples like Torkoal and Eject Button Hatterene. Torkoal sets sun with Drought, which gives Walking Wake a boost to its Special Attack and makes it an even more threatening wallbreaker. Torkoal is also good at forcing switches with Yawn, which gives Walking Wake opportunities to come in. Hatterene also provides a switch-in opportunity thanks to Eject Button, and it can also regenerate Walking Wake with Healing Wish, giving it more chances to wallbreak. Both can prevent irksome entry hazards either via Rapid Spin or Magic Bounce, a valuable attribute, as damage inflicted by hazards, most notably Toxic Spikes, limits Walking Wake's wallbreaking potential. Because Dragapult is such an issue for this set, Pokemon that can take advantage of it like Kingambit, Iron Valiant, and Ting-Lu are good partners for Walking Wake. Walking Wake has numerous roadblocks that stop it from making much progress like Water Absorb Clodsire, Assault Vest Toxapex, and Slowking; additional wallbreakers like Great Tusk, Roaring Moon, and mixed Garchomp to smash through them are appreciated. Hazard setters like the aforementioned Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Torkoal are indispensable as allies, for their hazards wear down checks and punish forced switches, be it through threatening the opposition or by phazing via Roar.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: A good Special Attack stat, good typing, and Choice Specs make Walking Wake a devastating wallbreaker. Hydro Steam is a powerful STAB option that is extremely difficult to switch into under sun, especially with the Protosynthesis boost. It notably 2HKOes Toxapex, Miraidon, and Koraidon, as well as OHKOing Corviknight and Iron Bundle. Draco Meteor OHKOes Dragon-types such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and opposing Walking Wake, preventing them from switching in, while also 2HKOing Water Absorb Clodsire and OHKOing Toxapex in sun. Flamethrower lets Walking Wake deal with Tera Steel Clodsire. Hydro Pump provides a strong Water-type STAB move outside of sun, and it can also be used with Pelipper's rain, boosting Walking Wake's damage output to massive levels. Alternatively, Dragon Pulse can be used for greater consistency than Draco Meteor, but note that it doesn't 2HKO Clodsire. Tera Water boosts Walking Wake's Hydro Steam to an insane level, allowing it to 2HKO Blissey and OHKO Assault Vest Flutter Mane in sun. Tera Water also lets Walking Wake survive Moonblast from Flutter Mane, Dragon Claw from Koraidon, and Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle in a pinch. Because Walking Wake can be easily revenge killed, it fits best on balance teams alongside walls such as Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex. Physical attackers like Koraidon and Chien-Pao are good teammates, as they pressure Walking Wake's checks in Blissey and Water Absorb Clodsire. Koraidon in particular sets sun for Walking Wake, and it potentially lets Walking Wake in safely through U-turn, allowing it to pressure Koraidon's checks in Skeledirge, Pelipper, and Toxapex.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Walking Wake is one of the most dangerous sun wallbreakers in Ubers, capable of 2HKOing even the bulkiest of Water resists and special walls alike.
  • Hydro Steam is Walking Wake's most spammable move; in sun, it 2HKOes Koraidon, OHKOes Flutter Mane, and 2HKOes Toxapex, making it very hard for teams to have a consistent switch-in to it.
  • Dragon Pulse, albeit weaker than Draco Meteor, doesn't come with any drawbacks, making it a much better move to spam if lowering Walking Wake's Special Attack is not desired.
  • Tera Water turns Walking Wake into an unwallable Pokemon, 2HKOing defensive walls like Blissey and OHKOing offensive pivots like Assault Vest Flutter Mane in sun. Tera Fairy can be used instead, as it gives Walking Wake useful resistances to Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao and Kingambit while also making it immune to Dragon-type attacks from Koraidon and Miraidon. Lastly, Tera Steel gives Walking Wake a resistance to Iron Bundle's Ice-type attacks, mainly Freeze Dry.
  • A Modest nature lets Walking Wake wallbreak with extreme ease, allowing for Draco Meteor to 2HKO Clodsire in sun. Alternatively, a Timid nature gets the jump on Timid Chi-Yu and opposing Modest Walking Wake, although the difference in power is very noticeable.
  • Walking Wake is best suited for offensive sun teams and should be used as such, making use of its unique typing to switch into Pokemon like Chi-Yu and counterattack with a nuclear Hydro Steam.
  • Walking Wake is somewhat slow for Ubers standards, so fast partners like Choice Scarf Koraidon and Flutter Mane are a must to compensate for its Speed stat. Koraidon's sun also greatly powers up Walking Wake's attacks.
  • Secondary wallbreakers such as Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu are also recommended, as Walking Wake's Speed hinders its performance as a standalone wallbreaker. Defensive teammates like Clodsire and Great Tusk are also helpful, as they check Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Koraidon, respectively.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dragon)
sets.description:
Walking Wake is a great Choice Scarf user for Dragon teams due to its part-Water typing and coverage, allowing it to revenge kill a plethora of threats such as Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Scizor. It also outspeeds common Choice Scarf users such as Great Tusk, Flamigo, and Iron Treads, which lets it clean Ground, Flying, and Fire teams late-game. With strong STAB moves in Draco Meteor and Hydro Pump, Walking Wake blows past Baxcalibur and Great Tusk. Flamethrower roasts Steel-types like Scizor and Gholdengo, though it lacks the firepower to 2HKO specially defensive Corviknight. Hydro Steam, emboldened by sun, lets Walking Wake demolish Fire teams. Alternatively, Dragon Pulse provides a weaker but more consistent STAB attack, which is great against opposing Dragon teams. The given EV spread and Timid nature cause Protosynthesis to boost Speed, allowing Walking Wake to outspeed Chlorophyll Scovillain and Choice Scarf Cinderace.

Choice Specs Dragapult is an excellent teammate, as it can wear down or eliminate bulky threats such as Corviknight and Hatterene and is also fast enough to deal with Choice Specs Flutter Mane for Walking Wake. Baxcalibur, Hydreigon, and Haxorus appreciate Walking Wake providing speed control, allowing them to wallbreak more effectively. These teammates also batter down defensive walls such as Clodsire, Gholdengo, and Toxapex, making cleaning up with Walking Wake much easier. Dragalge can pivot into Fairy-type moves from Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Choice Scarf Iron Valiant as well as set Toxic Spikes to further wear down the opposing team. This also synergizes well with Garchomp, which sets entry hazards in Spikes and Stealth Rock, phazes the opposition with Dragon Tail or Roar, and pressures Poison- and Steel-types like Clodsire and Klefki. Cyclizar gets rid of entry hazards for Walking Wake, allowing it to come onto the field more.

sets.name: Sun Attacker
sets.description:
• Walking Wake is a powerful special attacker and can function as a Water-type attacker on sun teams thanks to Hydro Steam and Protosynthesis.
  • Hydro Steam is Walking Wake's primary STAB move. While it's simply good outside sun, there are very few things that can switch in on it in sun.
  • Draco Meteor is Walking Wake's strongest move and can slam common Water-resistant Pokemon such as opposing Walking Wake and Palafin.
  • Flamethrower is a strong sun-boosted coverage move that deals super effective damage to Pokemon like Amoonguss and Kingambit, which otherwise resist Walking Wake's STAB moves.
  • Protect keeps Walking Wake safe against faster threats and through field effects and should always be used with Life Orb. Choice Specs Walking Wake should run Dragon Pulse as a consistent Dragon-type STAB option to lock into.
  • Tera Fairy is chosen to remove Walking Wake's weaknesses to Dragon and Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry. Tera Dragon can also be run to increase Draco Meteor's damage and grant Walking Wake an important Electric resistance against Iron Hands. Tera Water greatly increases Hydro Steam's damage while removing Walking Wake's weaknesses to Dragon- and Fairy-type moves.
  • The EVs listed boost Walking Wake's Speed in sun. If a Special Attack boost is desired, move 8 EVs from Special Defense into Special Attack.

sets.name: Special Attack Booster Energy
sets.description:
• Flamethrower beats Corviknight and non-Assault Vest Iron Leaves.
  • The HP and Defense EVs allow Walking Wake to survive a hit from Adamant Choice Band Great Tusk, the Special Defense EVs allow Walking Wake to survive Dazzling Gleam from Modest Choice Specs Iron Moth, and the Speed EVs allow Walking Wake to outspeed maximum Speed Corviknight.
  • After using Aqua Jet, Special Attack Booster Energy Walking Wake beats Magnezone and Avalugg with Flamethrower while avoiding being KOed by Mirror Coat.
  • Walking Wake 2HKOes Donphan and Assault Vest Iron Moth by using Aqua Jet after Hydro Pump, and it OHKOes non-specially defensive Sableye by alternating between Hydro Pump and Draco Meteor to OHKO and avoid Sableye's Disable.

sets.name: Speed Booster Energy
sets.description:
• Snarl beats non-Clear Amulet Espathra and Farigiraf.
  • Flamethrower beats Scizor, as well as non-Weakness Policy Magnezone after using Snarl.
  • Hurricane beats Iron Valiant, Slither Wing, and most Meowscarada.
  • Speed Booster Energy allows Walking Wake to outspeed and OHKO Great Tusk, Haxorus, Dragapult, non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, and Garchomp.
  • 244 Special Attack EVs allow Walking Wake to maximize its Special Attack while also getting the Speed boost from Booster Energy.
  • Walking Wake should use Snarl twice against non-Choice Specs Magnezone and then use Flamethrower to ensure that it does not lose to Weakness Policy Magnezone.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Iron Leaves is a consistent wallbreaker in Electric Terrain thanks to its immense power and unique type combination. It can force out most walls and has a plethora of switch-in opportunities against the common Ground-types in the tier, such as Great Tusk and Ting-Lu.
  • Wild Charge is an important coverage option that allows it to hit Corviknight, which resists Iron Leaves's STAB moves. It also OHKOes Pelipper.
  • Close Combat hits the Steel-types that resist Iron Leaves's STAB moves, like Kingambit and Tera Steel users. Close Combat is also crucial for OHKOing Chi-Yu and Chien-Pao on the switch in.
  • Swords Dance is an alternative option that can be used over one of the coverage moves to punish foes trying to stall out Electric Terrain turns by predicting Protect or a switch.
  • Leftovers mitigates passive damage from hazards, Rocky Helmet, poison from Baneful Banker, and recoil from Wild Charge, providing Iron Leaves with some staying power. Iron Leaves with Leftovers and four attacks is best used as an early- to mid-game attacker that aims to create opportunities for teammates to sweep.
  • Life Orb gives an immense power boost but reduces Iron Leaves's longevity. It will be worn down severely by the time it manages to beat its check, which allows it less opportunities to attack afterwards. Notably, Life Orb allows Psyblade to OHKO Miraidon and 2HKO Skeledirge in Electric Terrain. Life Orb is best in combination with Swords Dance to minimize recoil. Using Iron Leaves this way is most potent mid- to late-game.
  • A Jolly nature is necessary to be able to outspeed Timid Chi-Yu and max Speed Palafin.
  • Tera Psychic is the main option to increase Psyblade damage, remove Ice and Fire weaknesses, and actually be able to take a U-turn in a pinch. Tera Psychic allows Iron Leaves to OHKO Koraidon without Electric Terrain, OHKO defensive Great Tusk and Miraidon in Electric Terrain, and guarantee a 2HKO on Skeledirge and Terastallized Alomomola. It's meant to be utilized with four attacks.
  • Tera Steel can be used to face off better against Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Kingambit. It also has the benefit of a Poison immunity, which can allow Iron Leaves to not get worn down by Baneful Bunker from Toxapex, and a U-turn resistance that can be used to catch the opponent off guard. This is a riskier Tera to commit to, as it makes Iron Leaves weak to both of Great Tusk's STAB moves instead of resisting them. Tera Steel is meant to be utilized with four attacks.
  • Tera Fighting gives Iron Leaves a Close Combat that OHKOes physically defensive Corviknight after a Swords Dance without Electric Terrain. Tera Fighting's defensive contributions are useful against the aforementioned Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and especially Kingambit. This Tera type is meant to be utilized with Swords Dance and Close Combat.
  • Tera Electric can be used to power up Wild Charge, which is useful against Corviknight and Tera Flying users like Kingambit, and it also gives Iron Leaves neutrality to all of its weaknesses. This Tera type is meant to be used with Swords Dance and Wild Charge to deal with Pokemon that resist Iron Leaves's STAB moves but are neutral to Electric. Tera Electric is the most risky, as you're investing your Terastallization for a Pokemon that's likely to KO itself quickly.
  • The biggest downside to Iron Leaves is how dependent it is on Electric Terrain to function properly. It can still be used to force out Great Tusk and Ting-Lu without Electric Terrain, but it's underwhelming compared to when Electric Terrain is active.
  • Miraidon is invaluable as a partner to Iron Leaves because it provides Electric Terrain and lures in Ground-types to U-turn on, which gives Iron Leaves a free switch. Specifically, Choice Scarf Miraidon is the best for the job, as it can provide Speed control and function as a late-game cleaner to take advantage of the holes Iron Leaves leaves behind.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight is a great partner, as it can also provide U-turn support to get Iron Leaves in, as well as make up for the Iron Bundle weakness Miraidon and Iron Leaves share. Corviknight can provide hazard control with Defog, but an additional Rapid Spinner like Great Tusk or Iron Treads is also advisable.
  • Iron Leaves fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, which also makes defensive pivots that are used in the archetype, like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, good partners.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Grass)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: With its high Attack stat and variety of Sharpness-boosted moves, Iron Leaves is a decent wallbreaker that can OHKO common metagame threats like Garganacl and Quaquaval. Sacred Sword allows Iron Leaves to hit Grass- and Psychic-resistant foes like Kingambit and Hydreigon, while Wild Charge threatens Flying-types like Talonflame and Corviknight. Iron Leaves struggles with being prediction-reliant and having low physical bulk, especially with its 4x weakness to the extremely prevalent U-turn, which makes wrong predictions very punishing. Therefore, having defensive teammates like Ting-Lu and Corviknight that can repeatedly pivot it in safely are necessary. Due to its lack of recovery and need for repeated switching, Iron Leaves appreciates entry hazard removers like Iron Treads to keep it from getting worn down. Hadron Engine users like Sandy Shocks are also great teammates that power up both Psyblade and Wild Charge with Electric Terrain.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
EV Spreads

  • 100 Speed EVs: This Speed investment outspeeds Jolly Ursaluna.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Alternate EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 100 Atk / 92 Def / 60 Spe with Adamant: This bulkier spread outspeeds Iron Bundle after Trailblaze, while avoiding a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch. The Speed EVs can be dropped to 36 if not using Trailblaze, to outspeed Jolly Breloom.

cap.comments:
Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Common Fairy-types such as Jumbao and Iron Valiant take a pittance from Arghonaut's attacks and can break through it easily with their STAB moves. Hatterene deserves a special mention, as it can bounce back Arghonaut's Spikes with Magic Bounce. However, Tera Fairy Arghonaut can wall most Iron Valiant sets and phazes it.

Poison-types: Venomicon, Toxapex, and Amoonguss wall Arghonaut with ease and threaten it out with Hurricane or Sludge Bomb. Venomicon-E and Plasmanta can both hit Arghonaut super effectively before and after Terastallizing thanks to their STAB combinations; the former can also absorb Knock Off.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Great Tusk, Breloom, and Iron Moth are capable of 2HKOing Arghonaut even after it Terastallizes. Meowscarada and Krilowatt deal significant damage to Arghonaut before it Terastallizes, but Arghonaut has little to fear from them after Terastallizing. Furthermore, Krilowatt must be careful when switching in, since it is heavily crippled by Knock Off.

Miasmaw: Miasmaw ignores Unaware thanks to Neutralizing Gas, making it extremely difficult for Arghonaut to handle. After a Swords Dance, Miasmaw can easily 2HKO Arghonaut with Scale Shot or Gunk Shot and OHKO Tera Fairy Arghonaut with the latter move. However, Miasmaw dislikes being phazed due to its Stealth Rock weakness.

Status: Toxic from Pokemon such as Clodsire and Snaelstrom puts Arghonaut on a timer, greatly reducing its ability to stay in and wall powerful threats. On the other hand, burn from threats such as Astrolotl, Rotom-W, and Dragapult makes Arghonaut significantly more passive, reducing its ability to pressure resilient threats such as Gholdengo.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Set Details

Great mixed bulk and Unaware make Arghonaut one of the metagame's most formidable walls, capable of taking on threats such as Gholdengo, Volcarona, Stratagem, and Kingambit. Additionally, Arghonaut's ability to force switches and strong matchup into Equilibra make it an excellent user of Spikes. Circle Throw phazes common setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Baxcalibur and whittles down the opposing team in conjunction with Spikes. Knock Off is Arghonaut's best way to force progress against walls such as Garganacl and Venomicon and deals heavy damage to Ghost-types trying to switch into Circle Throw such as Dragapult and Gholdengo. Leftovers provides Arghonaut with extra longevity and makes it less reliant on Recover, while Covert Cloak shields it from chip damage from Salt Cure and other bothersome secondary effects such as Special Defense drops from Shadow Ball. The given EVs allow Arghonaut to avoid the 2HKO from Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and from Krilowatt's Tera Water Surf. Tera Fairy flips many of Arghonaut's bad matchups, letting it check a wide array of threats including Venomicon lacking Sludge Bomb, Krilowatt, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult.

Arghonaut fits mostly on balance and stall teams that appreciate its ability to blanket check various offensive threats and force progress with Knock Off and Spikes. Stealth Rock setters such as Venomicon, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu are strong partners that can stack entry hazards with Arghonaut. Venomicon additionally handles threats to Arghonaut such as offensive Great Tusk, Meowscarada, and Iron Valiant, while Garganacl appreciates Arghonaut removing Covert Cloak from opposing Arghonaut and Gholdengo. Ground-types such as Equilibra, Great Tusk, and Garchomp can deal with Electric- and Poison-types such as Iron Hands and Toxapex, while in return Arghonaut can switch into Greninja lacking Grass Knot. Skeledirge forms a formidable Unaware core with Arghonaut, taking on Jumbao, Venomicon, and Iron Valiant while Arghonaut covers it against threats like Snaelstrom, Garganacl, and Choice Band Roaring Moon. Bulky setup sweepers such as Naviathan, Ceruledge, and Hatterene take advantage of Arghonaut whittling down their checks with Spikes and Knock Off over the course of the game.

cap.comments:
Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Jumbao has nothing in its arsenal to meaningfully damage Fire-types such as Skeledirge, Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge, all of which can take advantage of it by setting up or firing off a powerful attack. While Cinderace has to be more wary of repeated hits, it can switch into Jumbao at least once with relative impunity and force it out.

Poison-types: Amoonguss switches into Jumbao relatively well and can use Spore as it is forced out but must watch out for Tera Blast Fire. Toxapex, Clodsire, and Venomicon can wall Jumbao and use it as an opportunity to set entry hazards or force progress with Toxic or Knock Off. Venomicon-E outspeeds Jumbao and can take at least one hit and OHKO back with Gunk Shot or Brave Bird.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Bulletproof Equilibra can wall and KO Jumbao with their STAB attacks, but they take significant damage from Tera Blast Fire if Jumbao Terastallizes.

Faster Pokemon: If Jumbao does not hold a Choice Scarf, it is vulnerable to faster attackers with super effective coverage such as Greninja, Dragapult, and Stratagem.

sets.name: Drought Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Set Details

Jumbao is one of the best Pokemon in the metagame thanks to its excellent offensive stats, defensive utility, and incredible ability in Drought, which enables a host of powerful offensive partners. Tera Blast Fire pressures the Steel- and Poison-types that resist Jumbao's STAB combination, such as Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Venomicon. Alternatively, if Jumbao is paired with teammates that rely on Terastallizing, Focus Blast can be used to retain the OHKO on Kingambit. Synthesis lets Jumbao continuously keep sun up with Heat Rock and outlast Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Roaring Moon. Tera Fire allows Jumbao to take advantage of Tera Blast Fire's coverage and improves its matchup against Steel-types such as Scizor and Gholdengo by removing its Steel weakness.

Jumbao can fit comfortably on a variety of playstyles from bulky offense to balance thanks to the team support it provides through Drought. Fire-types such as Skeledirge, Cinderace, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth and Protosynthesis users such as Roaring Moon, Sandy Shocks, and Great Tusk are Jumbao's best offensive partners, as they all become extremely dangerous under sun. Since Jumbao is incredibly vulnerable to opposing Fire-types, defensive Pokemon that can handle them, such as Toxapex, Arghonaut, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl, are excellent partners. The latter three can also set entry hazards to help Jumbao wallbreak, while Toxapex can handle opposing Jumbao and Glimmora. Toxapex and Hatterene can create momentum for sun teams with Eject Button, the latter of which also keeps entry hazards off the field for Fire-type teammates. Bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight and Equilibra can check Poison-types that Jumbao struggles to break such as Amoonguss and Venomicon and appreciate Jumbao handling their checks, such as Krilowatt and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Set Details

Choice Scarf Jumbao picks off normally faster threats such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Krilowatt and supports offensive teammates with Healing Wish. Drought allows Jumbao to use Solar Beam quicker and provide sun support for teammates such as Great Tusk and Cinderace. Trace, on the other hand, allows Jumbao to copy valuable abilities such as Toxapex's Regenerator and Venomicon-E's Tinted Lens; however, it requires Jumbao to run Leaf Storm to retain a powerful Grass-type STAB move because of Solar Beam's two-turn wait outside of sun. Tera Fire with Tera Blast grants Jumbao coverage to hit Steel-types such as Corviknight and Gholdengo and resistances to key attacks such as Gholdengo's Make It Rain, Iron Valiant's Moonblast, and Baxcalibur's Ice Shard. Focus Blast, on the other hand, lets Jumbao OHKO Kingambit without Terastallizing.

Choice Scarf Jumbao is a strong asset to bulky offense teams, providing them with speed control and incredibly useful Healing Wish support. Defensive pivots that lack reliable recovery, such as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, Equilibra, and Rotom-W, benefit immensely from Jumbao's ability to bring them back to full health late in the game, which gives them the freedom to take more hits early on. These Pokemon can also handle the Steel- and Fire-types that can take Jumbao's STAB attacks, such as Cinderace, Gholdengo, and Iron Moth. Pivots like Rotom-W, Corviknight, and Cinderace can bring Jumbao in safely against Pokemon it threatens, such as Krilowatt and Hydreigon. Bulky setup sweepers such as Hatterene and Kingambit can break down teams for Jumbao to clean late-game and greatly appreciate Jumbao giving them a second chance to sweep with Healing Wish. Poison-types such as Toxapex, Venomicon, and Clodsire wall Jumbao, so wallbreakers that can threaten them, such as Dragapult, Baxcalibur, and Smokomodo, are good teammates. Lastly, if Jumbao opts to use Drought, it can set sun to support Fire-types such as Skeledirge and Iron Moth and Protosynthesis users such as Great Tusk and Roaring Moon.

cap.comments:
Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Jumbao, Pyroak, and Amoonguss wall Caribolt's STAB combination, forcing it out.

Faster Attackers: Before Caribolt uses Rapid Spin, Pokemon like Cinderace and Ice Beam Greninja can outspeed and OHKO it. Fast Dragon-types like Dragapult, Roaring Moon, and Astrolotl can switch in to check Caribolt once, but they cannot do so if Caribolt reaches both +1 Speed and +2 Attack.

Strong Priority Attacks: Strong priority attacks from Kingambit, Dragonite, and Revenankh can circumvent Caribolt's Speed boosts and KO it after it has taken some chip damage from Double-Edge.

sets.name: talahbolt (Swords Dance)
sets.description:
Set Details

Caribolt is a nuclear wallbreaker for offensive teams. Double-Edge with Galvanize can break through even the tier's most stalwart walls, 2HKOing Pokemon like Skeledirge and Garganacl with ease, especially once Caribolt Terastallizes. Horn Leech provides some modicum of recovery to compensate for Double-Edge's recoil. Rapid Spin both increases Caribolt's Speed, giving it sweeping potential, and supports teammates weak to Stealth Rock like Baxcalibur and Iron Moth, allowing them to forego Heavy-Duty Boots. Leftovers helps make up for Double-Edge's recoil alongside Horn Leech, while Magnet powers up Caribolt's Electric-type attacks even further. A Jolly nature is preferred to outspeed Choice Scarf Jumbao at +1 Speed and Krilowatt at +0, but Adamant is an option to deal as much damage as possible, supporting its hyper offense teammates. Tera Grass is an option to turn Ground-types like Equilibra and Great Tusk into setup fodder, but Caribolt's main focus should be on wallbreaking as much as possible for its teammates.

Caribolt is best utilized on hyper offense teams, which appreciate its incredible wallbreaking ability. Stealth Rock-weak Pokemon like Iron Moth, Baxcalibur, and Venomicon-E appreciate Caribolt removing the hazard, allowing Iron Moth and Baxcalibur to run more offensive items over Heavy-Duty Boots. Other physical sweepers like Dragon Dance Roaring Moon and Dragonite love Caribolt powering through Unaware walls like Skeledirge and Arghonaut; Roaring Moon pairs particularly well with Caribolt, as it can threaten the Grass-types like Jumbao and Amoonguss that give Caribolt trouble with Tera Flying + Acrobatics. This love is shared by special sweepers like Iron Valiant and Hatterene, which need Skeledirge off the table before attempting a sweep. Caribolt appreciates entry hazards weakening physically bulky Ground-types like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu—which can beat Caribolt if it Terastallizes—into KO range of its attacks, so pairing it with a dedicated lead like Greninja or Meowscarada is suggested.

cap.comments:
Checks and Counters

Water-types: Rotom-W hard counters Equilibra, as it takes negligible damage from any of Equilibra's moves and threatens it with Hydro Pump. Arghonaut similarly brushes off Equilibra's attacks and threatens to cripple it with Knock Off. Greninja and Krilowatt can switch in on Flash Cannon and threaten to deal significant damage to Equilibra, but they are 2HKOed by Earth Power.

Bulky Flying-types: Bulky Flying-types such as Corviknight, Venomicon, and Tomohawk give Equilibra trouble, as they don’t take much damage from Equilibra's moves and force it out with super effective attacks.

Ground-types: Offensive Great Tusk sets OHKO Equilibra with Close Combat, while defensive sets can either deal significant damage with Body Press or cripple it with Knock Off. Other bulky Ground-types such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire are easily capable of dealing with Bulletproof Equilibra, but it has little to fear from them if it forgoes Bulletproof for Levitate.

Item Manipulation: Equilibra heavily relies on the passive recovery granted by Leftovers, so it must be careful when switching in on Pokemon with Knock Off or Trick, such as Iron Treads and Gholdengo, so as not to risk taking a significant blow to its longevity.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Set Details

Equilibra's solid typing, great stats, and access to Rapid Spin make it one of the premier defensive pivots and entry hazard removers in the metagame. Levitate is the recommended ability, as it drastically improves Equilibra's matchups against opposing Ground-types, such as Clodsire and Garchomp, while also presenting more opportunities to clear entry hazards without worrying about taking Spikes damage. Alternatively, Bulletproof blocks Focus Blast from Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Jumbao and Shadow Ball from Ghost-types such as Dragapult and Hisuian Zoroark. Protect allows Equilibra to scout the foe's moves and get additional healing from Leftovers, while Pain Split gives it an alternative form of recovery, lowering its reliance on Leftovers. Alternatively, Aura Sphere allows Equilibra to beat opposing Levitate Equilibra and improves its matchup against Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Colossoil. The given EV spread allows Equilibra to avoid an OHKO from Choice Specs Greninja's Hydro Pump, survive the combination of Moonblast into Close Combat from mixed Tera Fairy Iron Valiant, and outspeed Adamant Breloom after getting a Speed boost from Rapid Spin. Tera Water allows Equilibra to tank Fire-type attacks from Pokemon such as Iron Moth, Astrolotl, and Skeledirge. Alternatively, Tera Flying flips Equilibra's matchups against Fighting-types such as Great Tusk and Breloom on their heads while allowing Bulletproof Equilibra to safely stay in against opposing Ground-types.

Equilibra struggles against Water- and Flying-types, so Electric-types such as Caribolt, Iron Hands, and Plasmanta make for great partners. Water-types such as Arghonaut and Rotom-W synergize well with Equilibra, since they can switch in on Fire-type attacks aimed at it; they, in turn, appreciate Equilibra's ability to absorb Electric-type attacks and pressure Jumbao, one of their greatest threats. Venomicon is one of the best defensive partners for Equilibra, since it walls many of the Fighting- and Ground-types that Equilibra struggles against such as Great Tusk; in return, Equilibra deals with Pokemon that Venomicon struggles against, such as Stratagem and Hatterene. Equilibra relies heavily on Leftovers for recovery, so it appreciates support from teammates that don't mind taking Knock Off, like Corviknight and Toxapex. Thanks to Equilibra's ability to consistently keep entry hazards off the field, it works well with teammates that are worn down by them, such as Snaelstrom, Iron Moth, and Loaded Dice Baxcalibur.
